HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Hilary Ann Stout And Peter Truell

 BODY:
Hilary Ann Stout, a White House correspondent for The Wall Street Journal, and Peter Robert Michael Truell, a business reporter for The New York Times, are to be married today in Shelburne, Vt. The Rev. John Stroyan, an Anglican priest who is a cousin of the bridegroom, is to perform the ceremony at Shelburne Farms.
Ms. Stout, 35, will keep her name. She graduated from Brown University. Her parents, Marilyn and Neil Stout, live in Burlington, Vt., where the bride's father is a professor of American history at the University of Vermont and her mother is a freelance writer. 
 Mr. Truell, 41, is a co-author of "False Profits" (Houghton Mifflin, 1992), a book about the B.C.C.I. banking scandal. He graduated with honors from Cambridge University and received a master's degree in modern standard Arabic and oil economics from Oxford University.
His mother, the late Margaret Dorothy Truell, was a history and English teacher at the Bruton School for Girls in Bruton, England. His father, the late Michael Pomeroy Somerville Truell, was a manager at Clarks, the shoe manufacturer in Street, England.
The bridegroom is a descendant of William Herschel, the astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Before an Election, Prisons Are Good. The Bills Come Later.

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
This is an election year in New Jersey, and it is not a good time to be a criminal.
With Governor Whitman and every state legislator up for re-election in November, lawmakers have passed one bill after another to keep thousands of criminals behind bars for longer times. And the Governor has signed the bills with much fanfare, saying they will make New Jersey a safer place. 
 But rarely does the Governor, or any other elected state official, Republican or Democrat, mention what it is costing taxpayers to put an ever greater number of people away. Nor do they much discuss where they plan to put new inmates when state prisons are already crammed with almost half again as many prisoners as they were designed for.
"We are more willing to deal with the growth in prison population than to see violent criminals on the streets," said a spokeswoman for Governor Whitman, Julie Plocinik.
State corrections officials estimate that the toughest new law, which requires violent offenders to serve at least 85 percent of their sentences, will add a total of 4,100 prisoners over the next 18 years to a prison population of more than 27,000 men and women. The officials say it will cost $329 million just to build enough cells for those new inmates. And it will cost taxpayers $26,000 a year for each prisoner for food, security, electricity and other costs of running the prisons.
Most prisoners now serve about 40 percent of their sentences before being paroled.
Last week, Governor Whitman signed another crime bill, which stiffens sentences for drug dealers who sell large amounts of marijuana, hashish or methamphetamine.
She signed the bill while sitting at a table in front of the Passaic County jail, which, like most county jails in New Jersey, holds hundreds of state prisoners for whom the 13 state prisons do not have room. But the Passaic County jail, which holds about 1,600 inmates in cells that were intended for 839, is even more crowded than the prisons.
Last fall, 150 police officers provided the backdrop as Mrs. Whitman signed another bill prohibiting parole to anyone convicted of murdering an on-duty law enforcement officer. That bill-signing ceremony was filmed by the Republican State Committee in case Mrs. Whitman decided to use clips in her campaign commercials.
The legislature had passed all three bills almost unanimously.
"If you are going to do a crime in New Jersey, you are going to have to do the time," said State Senator John O. Bennett, Republican of Little Silver, who sponsored the bill requiring violent offenders to serve 85 percent of their sentences. "I many times say that it is too bad that not every year is an election year."
Mr. Bennett said he believed that corrections officials might be overestimating the impact of the new crime bills on the prison population. And he said he believed that the state might be able to relieve some of the overcrowding by moving some nonviolent drug offenders out of the prisons and into drug rehabilitation programs.
But Mr. Bennett has also proposed another bill that would ask voters to agree to build another state prison. The state's newest and largest prison, the $237 million South Woods prison in Bridgeton, opened in May, but corrections officials say the 3,200 new beds will not even take care of the 5,500 state inmates now in the county jails.
The state's prison population is now rising by about 100 people each month. To cope, state prison officials have put double bunks in most cells and have created dormitories from gymnasiums, classrooms and even a chapel. At Bayside State Prison, tents that officials set up in 1989 as temporary housing still house more than 100 prisoners.
"Overcrowding has been like a virus that has gobbled up every inch of space," said Bob McHugh, a spokesman for the Department of Corrections. "We are just trying to keep from being overwhelmed."
Late last month, a corrections officer at Bayside, Frederick Baker, died after a prisoner stabbed him with a handmade knife. Officials of the labor union that represents the corrections officers said the state had created dangerous conditions at that Cumberland County prison and others by jamming in too many prisoners.
Governor Whitman recently credited the state's tougher sentencing laws with helping to reduce the violent crime rate. Violent crimes in New Jersey dropped 11 percent in 1996, largely because of large decreases in murders and other crimes in Newark and Camden.
But James A. Hemm, the executive director of the New Jersey Association on Correction, a group that works to improve prison conditions, said he did not believe the crime rate was dropping because of the new laws. Instead, he said, crime may be falling because fewer people are unemployed and because there are fewer people between 16 and 28, the age group more likely to commit crimes.
Mr. Hemm added that the new laws meant more offenders would be imprisoned late in their lives, a time when it is far less likely that they would commit another crime.
"You don't hear a lot about 56-year-olds getting arrested for armed robberies," he said. "You're locking up a whole lot of people who likely wouldn't commit crimes."

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Whom to Call if the Neighbor Never Cuts the Grass

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: LONG BRANCH

 BODY:
Nobody dropped a sack of garbage on Kevin Hayes's desk last week.
In fact, it hasn't happened since June. But metaphorically speaking, whenever residents of Long Branch feel dumped on by their neighbors -- by their uncovered trash cans, their overhanging branches and untrimmed hedges, or the funny smell coming from the improvised auto body shop next door -- they are only too happy to dump their problems on Mr. Hayes. 
 And Mr. Hayes, the city's chief of code enforcement, is relatively happy to be dumped on.
"If they don't complain, we don't know there's a problem," he said. "And to us, if someone complains, they got a reason for it."
The police may go after the burglars and murderers, but in most towns, much of the burden of defending the quality of life rest on code officers, who enforce state and local cods on health, housing, zoning, property maintenance, fire and public nuisances.
"Our job is to protect the public health, safety and welfare to see that the home, workplace and recreation space are safe from hazards," said Gary Lewis, president of the New Jersey Fire Prevention and Protection Association, a state organization of code enforcement officials.
Mr. Lewis, the head code officer in Summit, did receive an unsolicited gift of trash in his office last week.
"Mrs. Vespucci just brought us a bag of garbage from the car dealer she lives next door to," he said Tuesday afternoon. Inside were dozens of the paper mats that mechanics put on the floor in front of the driver's seat when they're working on a car, which many customers apparently toss into the parking lot and which then blow onto Mrs. Vespucci's lawn. Mrs. Vespucci, who Mr. Lewis said had also complained about the noise from the car dealer's outdoor paging system, is not unknown to local authorities.
"If she had simply called me, I would have believed her," Mr. Lewis said. "But I guess she chose to make the point a little more saliently."
Even those who simply call tend to make their points saliently enough that the code enforcers need to hold the phone away from their ears.
"What happens is that people see something for three or four weeks and it festers and drives them crazy," Mr. Hayes said. "Then they call up and they say: 'This has been going on for months. When are you people going to do something about it?' "
What they do, usually, is try to solve the problem by the gentlest means possible.
"Our goal is not to bring people into court to fine them," said Mr. Hayes, a good-natured, heavy-set man of 39 who was once Long Branch's fire chief. "We'd rather have them put the money into fixing up their property. A $500 fine would go a long way toward painting a building, fixing leaks, boarding it up, whatever."
Complaints in Long Branch, an economically, ethnically and architecturally diverse city of 28,000 with a five-mile oceanfront that includes $15 million castles at one end and a burned-out amusement pier at the other, tend to be about almost anything.
"We had a complaint about chickens in the alley behind a botanica," Mr. Hayes said, referring to a Hispanic religious goods store. "When we went in the back, we came to find out they were doing some kind of voodoo and cutting the heads off them."
"We got another complaint that someone was operating a business out of an apartment selling lesbian products. I guess it was some type of accessories. But it proved to be unfounded because they were doing a little mail order business, and that's legal as long as you don't have stock and entertain customers in your home."
The stack of green complaint provides terse portraits of small-city life. "There is an old Corvette parked in the rear side yard with weeds growing up around same," one report says. "Running illegal rooming house for Mexicans, living in basement, camping in backyard," says another. "Neighbor has built a stockade fence over three feet high in violation of 20-7.2," reads a third.
Not every complaint is happily resolved.
Around 4 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Hayes took a phone call.
"A woman in Vine Court Apartments says they got some stuff washing up on the beach," Mr. Hayes said to Fran Varacalli, the city's new watershed environmental coordinator. "Fran, you want to take a ride out?"
Ms. Varacalli, a recent Rutgers University graduate who was hired five weeks ago, leaped at the chance. She and Mr. Hayeswere soon walking the beach. A line of trash several hundred feet long was scattered along the beach: six-pack rings, tampon applicators, motor oil quart containers, half a calabash, a shampoo bottle, a small magnetic letter P from somebody's refrigerator.
"This is definitely household," Ms. Varacalli said.
"Looks like somebody had a party on a boat and instead of bringing the trash in, they just dumped it overboard," Mr. Hayes said. The two of them scanned the trash for a piece of mail or a prescription bottle that might identify the culprit, to no avail.
On the way back to the car, Ms. Varacalli paused against the railing of the boardwalk and looked out at the ocean.
"I come to this beach almost every day," she said, "and to see what the effects are of a little garbage bag all over the beach -- ooh, it makes me so angry."
Mr. Hayes had seen worse.
"By tomorrow morning, the beach rake will come by and it'll all be gone," he said, lowering himself into the car. "Another day in the big city."

HEADLINE: Legislation Would Ban Beach-Badge Fees

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I have introduced legislation, along with Assemblyman Neil Cohen of Union, that would enable beachgoers to enjoy free access to New Jersey's public beaches. Under the measure, shore towns would be responsible for seeking state reimbursement for public beach costs. This would eliminate the need for beach badges. 
 Shore communities would stand to benefit economically from our legislation because excessively high beach fees are an impediment to shore tourism, New Jersey's second largest industry.
 
WILFREDO CARABALLO
South Orange
 
The writer is a Democratic Assemblyman representing District 28, in Essex County.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
In Fair August, Work Is but a Midsummer Daydream

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
IT seems T. S. Eliot was wrong. August, not April, is the cruelest month, at least for trying to conduct business. Just try setting up a meeting this month. Or arranging a job interview. Or getting a telephone call returned.
Yes, technology has taken some of the angst out of working in August with cellular phones and E-mail. Still, these technological leashes are not long enough or pervasive enough to tether the many Americans who flee their jobs, if not their towns and even the country, for the entire month. And in many parts of this country, as has been true in Europe for years, August is an all-purpose reason nothing gets done. 
 "August is the month we dread," said Ricky Eisen, president of Between the Bread, a caterer for 2,000 businesses in New York City. "Our clients depend on us when they do business. If their business is off, our business is off, and August is our slowest month."
And the dog days of Ahhhhhgust are getting even more somnolent. For example, in August 1994 business at Between the Bread fell 10 percent from July. Last year, it fell 20 percent. "Nothing happens," Ms. Eisen said. "Important people go away. There are fewer meetings, fewer big decisions."
The annual August abandonment afflicts the professional class in addition to corporate wheeler dealers and businesses big and small. Do not be arrested in August; your lawyer may be lounging in the Hamptons. Do not be audited in August; your accountant may be taking the children to the Grand Canyon. Do not become sick in August; your doctor may be puttering around the golf courses of Ireland. And do not even try to get a Prozac prescription in August; your psychiatrist is dictating a self-help book at his vacation home on Cape Cod.
"Most shrinks take August off as a vacation month," said Dr. Robert R. Butterworth, a psychologist in Los Angeles.
Vacation is not always the right word, though, especially in an age that has elevated the entrepreneur to rock star status.
"It is uncool to 'go on vacation' in the career-crazed late 1990's," said Patricia Rosenberg, a public relations executive in Tustin, Calif.
"Everyone I try to contact is 'traveling,' simply 'away from the office,' an interesting view of one's personal time," she said.
But while so many are ostensibly traveling so far for business, not much seems to be accomplished, with August the universal excuse. While some companies in Europe are now trying to have employees stagger their time off, August has long been known as a getaway month there.
In France, everyone from the owner of the local patisserie to the prime minister heads for the Cote d'Azur, a tradition with roots in les grandes vacances -- the summer school break -- and labor laws that guarantee paid vacation. In Italy, the fleeing of Rome in August causes the ability to do business to go from difficult to impossible. In Germany, even the Bundesbank shuts down for four weeks.
The whole world does not shut down in August, of course. "The sharpest marketing organizations schedule South American and Australian tours during the dead months of July and August," said Steve Foote, vice president of Research Strategy at the Hurwitz Group, a management consultant and market research company in Newton, Mass. "One: It's wintertime in the Southern Hemisphere in July and August, therefore there's no vacation issues. Two: South America is a rapidly growing market and economy, fifth largest in the world by most any metric."
In the United States, some areas fall asleep in August more noticeably than others. Washington is notorious for shutting down. In Manhattan, getting away is part of the status game, even if it means enduring hours of traffic jams and arriving in towns filled with the people many New Yorkers are trying to escape: other New Yorkers.
August may yawn the widest in South Florida, however, where many businesses still close for the entire month as their owners decamp to places like the North Carolina mountains and Bar Harbor, Me.
Despite August's hold, or lack of hold, on Americans, it is not the busiest month for vacations. July holds that spot, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. July vacationers must be campers, though, because August is the busiest month for both air travel and hotel stays, industry trade groups say.
"I have worked for nonprofits for many years, and we wouldn't even try to raise money from businesses or individuals in August," said Winter Prosapio, now a spokesman with P.G.& E. Gas Transmission-Texas in San Antonio. "Your solicitation letter ends up in the summer reading circular file, even with companies who are on September to August business cycles."
In the news business, August is regarded as a permanent weekend, a calendar page of Sundays. Often, editors think news waits to happen until August is over.
But August's reputation as a no-news month is undeserved. Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait in August 1990; Hurricane Andrew struck Miami in August 1992, and Elvis Presley died in August 1977. In fact, so much happens in August that after Boris N. Yeltsin rescued Mikhail S. Gorbachev from a coup d'etat in August 1992, President George Bush quipped: "What is it about August?"
August can be enough to make one turn to drink. But even that is not easy. "We own a small tavern," says Sharon Clark of Eastampton, N.J. "But in August, the liquor companies close down for two weeks every year. All of them, at the same time, and there is no place else to purchase liquor for the bar."
"To handle it," she added, "we had to stockpile two weeks' worth of liquor and pray that we ordered enough to get us through."

Miles flown by airplane passengers each month in 1996. (Source: Airport Transport Association of America)

HEADLINE: THE NEW TAX LAW: Amid Complexity, Opportunities Abound;
Planning Your Estate Around the New Exemptions

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
For all Washington's celebratory mood over the nation's first major tax cut in 16 years, Congress and the Clinton Administration hardly issued an open invitation to the party. Rather than an across-the-board tax cut, the $96 billion package is a series of narrowly focused measures intended to achieve specific goals. How much you benefit depends on your personal circumstances. Here is a guide to achieving key financial objectives under the new rules.
FOR countless American families grief strikes twice, first when a person dies, and next when heirs learn that taxes will take a big chunk of the estate, taxes that could have been significantly reduced by planning.
The hue and cry over estate taxes has gotten louder in recent years, as inflation has eroded the value of the $600,000 estate that is exempt from gift and estate taxes, which go as high as 55 percent, and as housing values have climbed and soaring financial markets have swollen pension assets, making millionaires of people who have been middle-class all their working lives. 
 The distress signal has been especially loud from family-owned businesses, because in extreme -- but not unusual -- cases heirs have had to sell off plant and equipment to pay estate taxes, sometimes crippling the business.
The new law addresses these concerns by gradually raising the amount that is exempt from gift and estate taxes to $1 million in the year 2006, beginning with $625,000 next year, and by raising the exemption for qualifying family businesses to $1.3 million next year.
"It is not the major relief that had been sought," said John H. Gardner, senior manager in the Washington national tax office of KPMG Peat Marwick. He added that the provisions for family businesses are "really complicated" and may not help many businesses.
Still, for small, family businesses in which the next generation would be active, Sidney Kess, a New York tax lawyer and accountant, said, $277,000 in taxes could be be avoided on an estate of $1.3 million. For a business like a store, that might be the difference in carrying on or selling.
"It is terribly important for all people to have their wills and estate plans reviewed in light of these rules," Mr. Kess said.
Sanford J. Schlesinger, head of the wills and estates department of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, a New York law firm, who is and head of its wills and estates department, said the first thing he asked a new client to do was make a list of assets. "They are nearly always surprised at how much they have," he said. "In New York a school teacher with a $200,000 to $300,000 house, life insurance and a pension plan can be a millionaire," with a taxable estate.
The goal of an estate plan is to cut tax liabilities by reducing the size of the estate. Life insurance, for example, can be removed from an estate by transferring ownership to an irrevocable trust. And a couple, instead of owning everything jointly, can put some assets in the husband's name and some in the wife's. They can then set up trusts so that a surviving spouse gets the benefit of the other's assets, but upon that spouse's death a child, or someone else, inherits the assets.
Under the old law, a $1.2 million estate that would have owed taxes of $235,000 could have been divided into two $600,000 estates in this way, and taxes would have been avoided.
Jonathan Herlands, the partner in charge of the trusts and estates department of Janvey, Gordon, Herlands, Randolph, Rosenberg & Cox, a New York law firm, said that "a lot of people have wills that talk about $600,000 in trust." Now, with the exemption gradually rising to $1 million in 2006, many documents will have to be revised. One way is to use percentages, as is often done in will-writing, instead of specific dollar amounts.
However, other wills do use percentages, known as formula provisions, he said, and for a $1 million estate, that might now effectively disinherit a spouse or family members, who could then contest the will. So each estate plan will have to be reviewed individually.
The family businesses provisions are especially complex, and "the details of this make it unavailable to the majority of business owners," said Ross W. Nager, a partner in Arthur Andersen in Houston and national executive director of the firm's Center for Family Business. "The rationale is buried in the political sausage-making process," he said.
One difficulty is that if the business is sold within 10 years of the owner's death, and the heirs have taken advantage of the $1.3 million exemption, they will then be liable for what is known as recapture of the taxes that were avoided, plus interest, and for taxes on any capital gains on the sale. And there are no exceptions or hardship provisions in the law.
Other problems are the law's stringent requirements that family members materially take part in the business, that the business be at least 50 percent of an estate, and that 50 percent of the business be owned by one family, 70 percent by two or 90 percent by members of three families, which could exclude many third and fourth-generation businesses.
But for a bigger business -- one with millions in assets and several hundred employees -- the new law is unlikely to be helpful, Mr. Nager said. Families with large businesses still need sophisticated succession and estate plans.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1226 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Pension Concerns Move to the Picket Line

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
IF you are among the millions of Americans worried about being able to retire in comfort, you may want to pay close attention to the strike that began Monday at United Parcel Service and the tentative settlement the same day of the steel industry's longest strike ever, at Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel.
Pensions were the core issue at Wheeling-Pittsburgh and are the No. 2 issue in the U.P.S. talks. And at companies from Continental Airlines to Rochester Telephone, workers are telling unions that pension benefits are almost as important to them as wages. 
 This interest marks a shift from the last decade, when, after wages, the big issues in collective bargaining were job security and preserving health insurance benefits. Sustained economic growth and lower inflation, together with a deluge of news coverage telling the nation's aging workers how poorly they may fare in retirement, have raised the profile of pensions.
Bill Patterson, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s pension policy chief, said: "The central issue is the security of retirement benefits. The trend by employers is to downgrade retirement benefits and shift the risks to workers."
At issue in the strikes is the unions' desire to preserve the traditional defined-benefit pension plan, in which the employer makes a fixed monthly payment, based on salary and years of service, and then makes investing decisions and guarantees a monthly check at retirement. In their stead, companies are increasingly offering defined-contribution plans, like 401(k)'s, to which the employer, and often the workers as well, make contributions. Employees make investment decisions from options offered by the employer -- and are therefore responsible for the profits (or the losses) caused by their investing decisions.
Employees like those at U.P.S. and Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel like the traditional pension plan because the employee gets a check for life -- whereas the investment choices made by an employee with a 401(k) can leave him or her broke. Although stocks have risen sharply, amateur investors may fear they will lose their investments if the market falls. Many companies dislike defined-benefit pensions because such plans are highly regulated and put all the investment risk on the company. Moreover, companies say workers under 50 do not value the plans.
Mr. Patterson said, "The bull stock market makes it easier for companies to promote defined-contribution plans because right now it looks like everyone who is in the stock market can get rich, but that won't last and the danger is that there will be losses and there won't be enough money at the end of the road."
Alan Glickstein, a principal at Kwasha Lipton Group, the benefits consulting arm of the Coopers & Lybrand accounting firm, said unions were increasingly resistant to changes in retirement plans.
"We are seeing more and more a very educated union leadership that is raising pension design issues, sophisticated issues that were never even discussed in the past," said Mr. Glickstein, whose group has been in the forefront of designing less expensive pension plans for employers.
Corporate spending on all types of retirement plans, adjusted for inflation, has fallen by more than a third, from 84 cents an hour worked in 1977 to 53 cents an hour last year, said Lawrence Mishell, research director at the Economic Policy Institute, a research organization partly financed by unions.
The percentage of private-sector workers with defined-benefit pensions fell to 28 percent by 1992, from 40 percent in 1975, Mr. Mishell said. The percentage with defined-contribution plans grew to 33 percent from 13 percent in the same period, according to the Employee Benefits Research Institute.
At Wheeling-Pittsburgh some 4,500 steelworkers walked picket lines for 10 months to win a traditional defined-benefit pension of $1,200 a month after 30 years of work. The company for years had the same pension plan as other steelmakers, but after going through bankruptcy proceedings a decade ago the company switched to a defined-contribution plan with what the union regarded as minimal benefits.
The United Steelworkers said the financier Ronald LaBow, who bought the company while it was in bankruptcy, had promised to restore traditional pensions when Wheeling-Pittsburgh became healthy, a situation the union felt was reached in 1995.
Winning back the traditional pension with lifetime payments came at the cost of 850 jobs, some of them held by workers ages 55 to 62 who will get just $450 a month until they become eligible for Social Security.
At U.P.S., management wants to withdraw from seven regional multi-employer defined benefit plans, to which many companies contribute, and set up its own single-employer fund -- also a defined-benefit plan -- for its employees. The company calculates that it would need to pay $700 million to cover its share of the existing shortfall in these plans, which do not have enough money to meet their obligations. Yet, the company says, it would still be better off, able to either spend the same amount on pensions it does now and offer much bigger benefits, or to cut its costs and produce the same benefits.
The problem is that the potential withdrawal of U.P.S., the strongest participant in these seven regional plans, raises concerns that teamsters with other trucking companies may not collect all the benefits due them, said Greg Tarpinian, executive director of the Labor Research Institute, a union-financed group in New York.
"It is the nature of multi-employer plans that stronger companies tend to subsidize weaker ones," Mr. Tarpinian said. "From a strictly economic standpoint, U.P.S. can get a bigger bang for its buck by creating its own plan. But the union cannot possibly allow that to happen without putting at risk the pension of hundreds of its members at other companies."
At Continental, leaders of the Independent Association of Continental Pilots were surprised to find when they surveyed their 5,100 members that "the pension was neck-and-neck with pay as an issue," said Bob Borelli, a vice president of the union.
The issue was complicated by the company's 1983 bankruptcy. The union says a captain with 30 years at Continental qualifies for a pension with a lump-sum value of less than $300,000, while an American Airlines pilot gets $3.7 million. This is true because the American pilot, who makes more money in the first place, also gets credit for 30 years of service in one plan, while Continental's bankruptcy means the pilot gets 16 years in the pre-bankruptcy pension plan, one year without coverage and 13 years in the new plan.
Mr. Borelli said that 150 Continental captains who reached 60 -- the Government-mandated retirement age for pilots -- had to take work as flight engineers because their pensions were inadequate. "I have 15 years to go and I don't intend to leave my captain's chair to be a flight engineer," Mr. Borelli said. "And a lot of our members feel that way because they have told us that pensions and wages are the pillars on which they want our new contract built."
Ned Walker, a Continental spokesman, said, "We recognize this as an important issue and have offered some creative solutions." He said the disparity between the Continental and American pensions for pilots is only one-fifth what the union says.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A New Wave of Retirement Benefits"
Unions say that their members are pressing to preserve and enhance pension benefits. In traditional, defined benefit-pension plans, the investment risks are borne by the employer and the retiree gets a check for life. Over the last two decades, however, the trend has been toward defined-contribution plans like profit-sharing and 401(k)'s, in which workers bear the investment risk and are not guaranteed a fixed amount for life. (Source: Employee Benefits Research Institute)

HEADLINE: For Cleaner Air, Try Electric Trucks

 BODY:

To the Editor:
An Aug. 6 news article reports that Judge Lawrence E. Kahn ruled that New York State can order auto manufacturers to sell thousands of electrically powered vehicles in the state beginning this fall. But the real question is whether he can order customers to buy the cars. 
 I am old enough to recall the Ward Baking Company electric vehicles delivering their products to grocers in the 1930's. It had nothing to do with environmentalism; it was simply more economical for a truck that did short-haul, stop-and-go driving to be powered by electricity.
The effort should be made to electrify this class of trucks. They contribute a disproportionate amount of pollution with their mode of operation. Why California and New York try to promote the electric vehicle for use by the average motorist defies all reason.
 
MORTON SOBELL
San Francisco, Aug. 7, 1997

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
New Frenzy: A Split, a Beep and an Option

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
CARL CZEREPAK was sitting in a barber shop last June, getting a haircut and a shave, when his beeper went off.
The barber's phone did not work, so Mr. Czerepak rushed out to his car, not on the news of a birth or an emergency at home but on a flash bulletin from Wall Street: Caterpillar Inc. had just announced a 2-for-1 stock split. 
 "I ran out with a bib on, got my cellular phone and called my broker," said Mr. Czerepak (pronounced SEH-re-pack), a law-enforcement officer. "I knew Caterpillar was a blue-chip stock, so I didn't hesitate to buy."
Like scores of other investors who hope to reap the rewards of the raging bull market, Mr. Czerepak has been swept up by stock split fever, the bet that once a company splits its stock, the shares will soar.
Some academic studies have found that share prices do tend to rise on news of a stock split, though there is no clear reason they should: all a split does is take one share worth, say, $100 and turn it into two shares worth $50 each.
Some analysts suggest that cheaper stocks are more attractive to amateur investors, who drive their prices up; others say a split is a sign that management of a company is confident about its future. Investors who have picked up on such logic from seminars, investing guides and Internet newsletters are rushing out to capitalize on it.
The boom has created its own mini industry of advisers and seminars as well as paging services like the one Mr. Czerepak uses. And it has contributed to a surge in trading volume at securities exchanges around the country.
But the frenzy worries some Wall Street observers, who say that stock splits are simply a meaningless division of the stock pie into smaller pieces. They fret that amateur investors are getting swept up in a speculative bubble that is bound to burst, leaving them with big losses.
"It's a sign of the times," said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. "This is a market in which pretext follows speculation, and the new pretext for speculators is that there are two shares in place of one, and that more is better than less, even though a stock split has no financial value."
Adding to critics' concerns is the way many investors are playing the stock-split game -- by using call options. These options are contracts that give investors the right to buy a stock at a particular price, within a set period. They are relatively inexpensive, compared with equities, and far more volatile. And while a successful options trade can bring an investor big profits, many options become utterly worthless.
"Of course, it is a fact that this strategy will not work forever," Bernard Schaeffer, president of the Investment Research Institute, wrote recently in a bulletin to his customers. He added that it is likely to end "very, very badly for the latecomers to the game."
Trading in equity options set a record in July, according to the Options Industry Council, and some of it, at least, is attributable to speculation on stock splits.
For instance, Caterpillar announced on June 11 that it would split its stock a month later. Before the announcement, trading volume in Caterpillar options on the American Stock Exchange had averaged 927 contracts a day; but on the day of the announcement, volume hit 7,693 contracts -- an eightfold rise.
"It's our feeling that it's happening because there are people out there with pagers," said Joseph B. Stefanelli, who oversees options trading at the American Stock Exchange. "They get a call that says, 'There's been a stock split. Buy Amalgamated Garbage Pails.' "
In recent months, the number of investor paging services has proliferated. Among the best known are Splitalert, Splitxpress and the IQ Pager. The services can cost up to $1,500 a year. There is also an Internet site called the Right Line Split Report, which is "devoted to the short term dramatic investment profitability of companies who have declared stock splits."
Trading options, "particularly on the split announcements, is probably the biggest thing going on Wall Street right now," said Kevin Tuohy, chief operating officer at Data Research Group, which runs Splitalert.
Anthony LaPine, the chief executive at Datalink Systems, an electronic-paging company, said that in recent months Datalink received scores of calls asking for a stock-split service. In response, his company created the Splitxpress pager, which already has several hundred subscribers. He said, "I'm led to believe that a lot of the history derives from people like Wade Cook."
Indeed, the name Wade B. Cook came up repeatedly in interviews with those who use stock split pagers. Mr. Cook is an evangelizing investment guru who spreads his word through seminars, tapes and best-selling books. He is also under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for securities fraud, according to documents his company, the Profit Financial Corporation, filed with the agency. Mr. Cook has denied any wrongdoing.
In a recent book, "Wall Street Money Machine," Mr. Cook -- a former cab driver whose proverbs include "God wants us to prosper" -- has an entire chapter devoted to buying options on stock splits. He also has an Internet site that, among other things, markets his IQ Pager. And a growing number of investors are taking his advice.
For instance, Edward Iskra of Clifton, N.J., a computer consultant, said that although trading on stock splits can be risky, he has done very well. "I can't say I've made a mint off of it, but the returns on investment I've gotten are large versus the market."
But even Mr. Cook thinks things may have gotten a little out of hand. "Options are just the latest craze," he said in a telephone interview on Wednesday, adding that no more than 5 percent of investors are sophisticated enough to make what he allows can be risky trades.
Still, earlier that day, he said, he was attending a meeting at an investment bank when his beeper sounded. Ingersoll-Rand had announced a 3-for-2 split. He tried to buy options, he said, "but we didn't get in there in time." He settled for buying 1,000 shares of stock.
It's a fast-moving market, even for those with beepers; just ask Mr. Czerepak, the law-enforcement official who had phoned his broker to buy options on Caterpillar. After less than a half-hour, Mr. Czerepak placed another call to his broker, only to find that the price of the options he owned had already risen substantially. He quickly sold them.
"I got a hot one, and got out and made a nice profit in 20 minutes," he said. "Of course, I gave the barber a nice tip."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward Iskra of Clifton, N.J., wears a beeper that alerts him to stock splits so that he can rush to buy options when he hears news he likes. (Lenore Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Staying Too Close to Home

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
Many investors own some mutual funds that invest overseas in the hope that these funds will help protect their portfolios from losses. After all, when markets sag in the United States, the international markets should soar, at least in theory.
But in practice, a lot of investors are not getting the benefits of international diversification, said Olivia Barbee, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund trackers. The reason: Many "international" funds have big holdings of American stocks. And these funds have recently been the best performers, attracting a lot of investors. 
 Moreover, in a global economy markets are increasingly linked. Many overseas investments have started to move in tandem with markets in the United States, rather than in the opposite direction.
Investors looking for diversification, Ms. Barbee said, should seek funds active in Japan, Latin America or emerging markets. Though risky standing alone, these funds can lower a portfolio's overall risk because their performance is so poorly correlated with American stocks.
Funds that invest in emerging markets may give the best diversification because they have expanded beyond Latin America and Asia and are moving into Russia, Poland and other eastern European countries.
Ms. Barbee suggests Templeton Developing Markets and a closed-end fund, Templeton Emerging Markets, both run by Mark Mobius, who has a long record of finding good values in out-of-the-way places. She also likes Vanguard International Equity Emerging Markets.
As for Latin American funds, while Mexico and Brazil have strong economic ties to the United States, the currencies and securities markets in both countries do not track American markets, Ms. Barbee said. She recommends Scudder Latin America, which buys high-quality large-capitalization stocks.
The stocks of Japanese companies also march to their own drummer. Ms. Barbee suggests that investors look at Vanguard International Equity Pacific, which keeps 80 percent of its money in Japan, and Schwab International Index, which invests in the largest companies outside of America and has big investments in Japanese equities. Among actively managed funds, she likes T. Rowe Price Japan.
 
Openings and Closings
Managers who have closed their funds to new investors, usually because the funds have become too big to be effectively managed, sometimes change their minds. A few reopen because of new opportunities.
But sometimes, unwieldy funds find that the market solves the problem for them. In other words, their performance declines, investors flee, and the fund shrinks.
Such was the case with PBHG Select Equity, which had $650 million under management at its peak last September. It closed a month later, but reopened in July after assets slid to $418.6 million because of its poor performance. The fund has gained less than 8 percent this year, while the average capital appreciation fund is up almost 19 percent, Lipper Analytical Services says.
Sometimes, funds have to close earlier than planned. The NI Growth and NI Micro Cap funds, run by John C. Bogle Jr., announced in mid-July they would close on Aug. 29, when the funds were expected to have each accumulated $100 million in assets. But strong performance lured investors, and the funds closed on Aug. 8, already over their target by more than $10 million. NI Growth, which invests in small companies, rose 20.2 percent in the first seven months of the year, while NI Micro Cap gained almost 25 percent in that time.
 
Mergers
Seven Invesco Advisor funds became AIM Advisor funds last Monday, though Invesco continues to manage the funds. (Last February, Invesco, which sells funds through direct marketing, bought AIM, which sells funds through brokers.)
The seven funds are Large Cap Value, Flex, International Value andMultiflex, which retain a 5.5 percent sales charge; Real Estate, with a 4.75 percent charge, and Income and Cash Management, also 4.75. The last two will be closed to new investors on Oct. 3 and be merged into existing Aim funds, subject to board approval.
Marketing and operations of two fund families, Turner and Clover, have been consolidated. The four Turner funds, Small Cap, Mid Cap, Ultra Large Cap and Growth Equity, and the three Clover funds, Equity Value, Small Cap Value and Fixed Income, will be renamed the TIP funds. TIP Turner Small Cap, which has $97 million under management, will be closed on Aug. 30.
Evergreen Keystone, a unit of the First Union Corporation, has merged six of its funds.
Keystone Balanced II merged into Evergreen Foundation; Keystone Mid-Cap Growth (S-3) into Keystone Strategic Growth (K-2); Evergreen Short-Intermediate Municipal-California into Evergreen Short-Intermediate Municipal; Keystone Liquid Trust into Evergreen Money Market; Keystone World Bond into Keystone Strategic Income, and Keystone Government Security into Evergreen U.S. Government.
 
Manager Changes
Nick C. Thakore, who runs Fidelity Select Telecommunications, will add to his responsibilities by taking the reins of Fidelity Utilities, Fidelity Select Utilities Growth and Fidelity Advisor Utilities Growth on Aug. 18. He replaces John M. Muresianu, who was named associate manager of American Trust Portfolio, an offshore fund managed by Fidelity International.
At the same time, Douglas B. Chase, the manager of Fidelity Select Automotive, will take over Fidelity Select Consumer Industries and Fidelity Advisor Consumer Industries from Paul L. Antico, who continues to run Fidelity Select Leisure. James F. Catudal, an equity analyst, takes over Fidelity Select Industrial Materials from Mr. Chase.

HEADLINE: THE NEW TAX LAW: Amid Complexity, Opportunities Abound;
Lower Capital Gains Rates, but the Devil Is in the Detail

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
For all Washington's celebratory mood over the nation's first major tax cut in 16 years, Congress and the Clinton Administration hardly issued an open invitation to the party. Rather than an across-the-board tax cut, the $96 billion package is a series of narrowly focused measures intended to achieve specific goals. How much you benefit depends on your personal circumstances. Here is a guide to achieving key financial objectives under the new rules.
TAXES on capital gains went down under the new tax law signed by President Clinton. They also got a lot more complicated, in part because the long term is becoming longer.
Under the new law, taxpayers who own an asset, like a stock or a bond, for at least 18 months and one day, and sell it at a profit, will owe a capital gains tax of 20 percent, or 10 percent for those in the 15 percent tax bracket for ordinary income. 
 One important change is in the holding period. The old law deemed as long-term assets those that were held for at least one year and a day. People who sell assets on or after July 29 that they have held for more than one year, but less than 18 months and a day, will still be subject to the old law, paying a rate of 15 percent if they are in the 15 percent tax bracket on ordinary income, and 28 percent otherwise.
The treatment of short-term capital gains has not changed. Any profits on an asset held for 12 months or less are taxed at ordinary income-tax rates of up to 39.6 percent.
Proving that tax laws can be complicated, taxpayers can get the 20 percent rate on sales between May 7 and July 28, even if they held the assets for no more than one year and a day. The new law also introduces a five-year rate, with different rules and effective dates for those who earn a lot and for those who earn a little.
Those who are in the 15 percent bracket in the year 2001 will be able to sell assets they have owned for at least five years and pay a capital gains rate of just 8 percent, two points below the 10 percent they would otherwise owe.
The catch is that people in that group -- with taxable incomes for a married couple of $41,200 in 1998, and a little bit higher in 2001, assuming inflation leads to bracket changes -- tend to have small capital gains. And if they have very much, they would be pushed into a higher bracket. But the provision may be of use to some retirees.
For those in higher brackets, the five-year break is more complicated. It will normally apply only to assets acquired in 2001 or later. So the 18 percent rate, instead of the normal long-term rate of 20 percent, will not generally apply to assets sold before 2006.
But if you own shares on Jan. 1, 2001, and would like to have them become eligible for the five-year rule, you can do so at a cost. The cost is that you will pay taxes then on the profits up to that point, at the 18 percent rate if you have then owned them for at least 18 months and a day. Then you would need to hold them for at least five more years, and would owe taxes at 18 percent on the additional appreciation when you sold them.
A popular way to defer capital gains taxes on stock has been to borrow identical shares and sell them short. This tactic -- called shorting against the box, in a reference to the old days when stock certificates might be held in a strong box -- is similar to selling because the holder no longer has any economic interest in the stock. But until now tax law has not treated it as a sale.
Now it will. And such shorting against the box after June 8 will be deemed a "constructive sale," resulting in capital gains taxes, unless the short position is covered by Jan. 30, 1998. Then, once the person had refrained from shorting the stock for at least 60 days, he or she could short it again, thereby hedging against a decline in the stock. To avoid having that hedge treated as a sale, however, it, too, would have to be removed by the following Jan. 30.
There are other ways to hedge against loss without becoming subject to the constructive sale rules. If you use options to limit risk, but leave yourself open to a possibility of at least some loss if the stock falls, or some profit if it rises, you will escape capital gains taxation while still reducing the risk of a plunging stock market. Just how much risk you have to keep will not be clear until regulations are issued, but they will not be retroactive.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Favorable Rates On Capital Gains"
In the past, capital gains were taxed at much lower rates than ordinary income. They lost their preferential treatment in 1986. Now the gap is widening again. (Source: American Council for Capital Formation)

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By DAVID RAMPE

 BODY:

REBIRTHING PAINS
Apple Makes Its Peace
Apple Computer and its archrival Microsoft exchanged words last week -- harmonious ones, for a change. In a stunning alliance, Microsoft agreed to invest $150 million in the struggling Apple, and to cooperate on several fronts. That offered Apple a much-needed vote of confidence. Microsoft apparently concluded it would pay too high a price if it let Apple die, since Microsoft is the largest seller of programs for Macintosh computers. And cleaning its own house, Apple changed its board, bringing in Steven P. Jobs, its co-founder, below, to a more official role and sweeping out A. C. Markkula Jr., another co-founder and power broker. Mr. Jobs joins the board with a number of industry and investment veterans, including Lawrence J. Ellison, chairman of the software company Oracle and a critic of Microsoft. The changes mean that virtually every major computer hardware and software company -- many of which had been fighting each other -- have entered into the Apple camp. Apple's stock jumped on the news, but gave up some of its gains in Friday's market selloff.
 
THE BUDGET DEFICIT
A Monster at Bay
The Government's budget deficit is dwindling to a mere $37 billion this year, from $107 billion in 1996. That will bring it to its lowest level since 1974, President Clinton forecast. The strong economy and high tax receipts -- thanks in part to increases passed in 1990 and 1993 -- brought a great improvement even before the balanced-budget agreement he signed into law last week had a chance to take effect. Economists said the budget deal would control the deficit in coming years, however, when the gap between revenue and spending would otherwise begin widening. 

STOCK INVESTING
Cloud on the Market
Stocks teetered at the end of the week, as interest rates rose. For the week, the Dow gave up its record-setting ways and fell 162.82 points, to 8,031.22, down 1.99 percent. Virtually all the drop came on Friday, on profit-taking and rising concerns that inflation may accelerate in the third quarter, forcing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. In the credit markets, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond climbed to 6.63 percent from 6.29 percent a week earlier. But mutual funds investors have kept on pouring money into the market. New estimates for July show that investors put $23 billion in new cash into equity funds, the most since January and the fifth-biggest month ever.
 
TAX AVOIDANCE
Kicking Back at the Rich
The cosmetics company Estee Lauder went public two years back, and some shrewd maneuvering by its namesake and her son Ronald avoided as much as $95 million in capital gains taxes on the sale, a feat that impressed Wall Street. Rather than selling their own shares, they borrowed shares from family members and sold them, a move based on the classic tax-avoidance technique called shorting against the box. Now, in the new tax law, Washington has struck back. Unless one of the Lauders dies in the next few months, or unless the law is amended or struck down in court, the Lauders or their estates will end up facing a big tax bill. The provision could catch other investors as well.
 
HEALTH CARE GIANTS
The Leader Stumbles
Columbia/HCA Healthcare is changing the way it does business, vastly transforming a company that upended the sleepy world of hospitals and pushed the proposition of medical care for profit, to the point that it drew the interest of Federal investigators. Gone apparently is the obsession with 15 percent profit growth each year. Gone also is the seemingly insatiable appetite for acquiring competing hospitals. And gone is the unshakable faith that to succeed, a modern health care company must own businesses that provide every phase of treatment, from hospital care to home care. The jettisoning of many of its controversial practices, like its cash bonuses for executives who met financial targets, may portend changes in other parts of the consolidating industry.
 
PHONE REGULATION
Heat Is on the Foreign Carriers
Washington issued tough rules to cut the $5.4 billion that American phone companies pay foreign carriers to complete their calls. The rules represent the Government's aggressive entry into the back-room haggling of phone companies and may have a dramatic impact on the average phone bill. Reed E. Hundt, the chairman of the F.C.C., said the rules would help slash the average cost of calling overseas from 88 cents a minute, to just 20 cents six years from now. "There has been a consensus for a decade that a cartel of companies has jacked up prices to a hideous level," he said. But foreign carriers howled, and some might refuse to go along. For good measure, they also questioned the agency's jurisdiction.
 
GLOBAL WARMING
Oil Companies Relent
The industry monolith that opposed efforts to curb greenhouse gases is cracking up. Just a few years ago, the energy industry spoke with one voice dismissing the whole idea of global warming, particularly the need for a treaty to control gas emissions into the atmosphere. Now that unanimity has cracked and from an unlikely direction -- producers of coal and oil. British Petroleum, the world's third-largest oil company, said it believed there was enough evidence to warrant concern about whether burning coal and oil was changing the Earth's climate. The dominant scientific view is that greenhouse gases are probably responsible for at least part of a rise of 1 degree Fahrenheit in the average global temperature over the last century. And the next century could see a rise of 3.5 degrees.
 
BOTTLED WATER FRENZY
Eau de Buffalo, Coming Up
Tapping into the $4 billion-a-year market for bottled water, cities of lesser cachet, like Kansas City and North Miami Beach, are exploring plans to market their tap water, with eye-catching labels and the ever-popular "sport caps" that enable the thirsty to open the container with a pull of the teeth. The marketing plans dare consumers to pay $1 or more for a quart that could be drawn from their own taps and put in a refrigerator for less than a tenth of a cent. Water drinkers praise the trend as a sign of marketing genius, or deride it as worthy of P. T. Barnum.
 
CITY SLICKERS
Garth Takes Manhattan
Simon and Garfunkel conquered Central Park, and so did Diana Ross, but let's face it, country music is far afield in Manhattan. But nationally country music has exploded, and Garth Brooks is the best-selling performer of the decade and one of the most successful singers in pop history, a blend of "classic rock" and country. His appearance in the park, before a live audience estimated at a quarter million people, drew a crowd of folks in cowboy hats, some carrying a cell phone to boot. HBO spent $5 million or more to advertise and produce the concert, which it broadcast simultaneously. It operated 22 cameras and 600 speakers over 25 acres of the park.

HEADLINE: The World;
It Takes One to Start a War, but Four to Make Peace

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WAR, its tensions and repercussions, can endure long after the last shot is fired. Then there is Korea, where the war wages on.
North and South Korea, split by the cold war in 1945, remain in a state of perpetual hostility, with few hopeful signs of a thaw. The ailing and isolated totalitarian regime in the north shows an old, familiar truculence -- even as the country's headlong slide into famine forces it to accept aid from the outside and stokes fears in the south of economic disaster if North Korea collapses. Business ties between the two countries are nominal, the goodwill nonexistent. 
 In a modern conference room at Columbia University, encircled by a sweeping view of New York City, diplomats from the United States, China and North and South Korea met last week to try once again to ease the tensions by bringing the Korean War to an official end.
The war, which no one really won, was never really over. The armistice, signed in Panmunjom on July 27, 1953, was designed to silence the guns just long enough to arrange peace talks and a permanent and legal truce. Instead it lasted 44 years, however tenuously at times, leaving the Korean peninsula in a state of war-not war that has made it one of the most tense and most heavily defended regions in the world.
"This is a war that's never been won by either side," said Charles K. Armstrong, a professor of history at Columbia's School of International and Public Affairs, which played host for the talks. "It resulted in a stalemate, and that's what's carried on all these years."
The meetings in New York were meant to lay the foundation for "four-party talks" now that the United States, China and the two Koreas have agreed to replace the fragile armistice with something more lasting. After all these years, that goal may prove all but impossible.
After three days of meetings, the delegations abruptly broke off their talks Thursday evening. They were unable to agree even on an agenda for further talks, although they agreed to try again in September.
It was a reminder, if one was needed, that starting a war can be a lot easier than ending one.
The Koreas, of course, are not the only countries in such a state.
Cyprus is a torn and potentially explosive place, restrained only by the presence of United Nations peacekeepers 23 years after Turkey invaded, ostensibly to protect the island's Turkish minority from a Greek coup attempt.
Ecuador and Peru keep fighting -- for three bloody weeks in 1995 -- over a swath of mountain jungle because Ecuador in 1960 stopped recognizing a peace treaty the two countries signed in 1942. Israel, nearly half a century after its founding, remains officially at war with Syria, which has not yet made peace with the Jewish state, unlike Egypt (in 1979) and Jordan (in 1994).
The Koreas, though, are unique.
For most of the century, the peninsula has experienced only occupation and division. Japan was the first, occupying the country from 1910 through the end of World War II. Promised independence by the Allies, Korea was instead cleaved in two by the Soviet Union and the United States, creating separate societies, each isolated from and increasingly suspicious of the other.
 
'A Throwback'
 The Korean War, which is often called the Forgotten War, sandwiched as it was between the epic of World War II and the American quagmire in Vietnam, was the first real battleground of the cold war. It has now outlived it.
"Korea is a throwback," a senior Clinton Administration official said. "There is no other place in the world where this type of cold war remains."
The fighting in Korea ended more or less when the generals decided enough was enough. After North Korea's invasion in 1950, the American-led United Nations counteroffensive and China's intervention, the war had reached a stalemate, but the slaughter continued. Three years of fighting had killed 118,000 soldiers on the United Nations side, nearly half of them Americans; the South Koreans lost 70,000 soldiers, the North Korean and Chinese more than a million.
The Military Armistice Agreement was what it sounds like: a military solution, not a political one, signed by the commanders of the United Nations forces, China's "volunteers" and the "Supreme Commander of the Korean People's Army," Kim Il Sung. Complications now arise from South Korea's not signing the armistice, which allows North Korea to claim that the south should not even be represented in peace talks. North Korea has long tried to negotiate directly with the United States over the peace terms, freezing out the south.
The armistice, with its preamble and five articles that went on for 63 paragraphs, quieted the guns, established a demilitarized zone more or less along the 38th parallel, separating the badly battered armies, and created a Military Armistice Commission to act as a sort of arbiter of the cease-fire.
The military commanders agreed to stop fighting "in the interest of stopping the Korean conflict, with its great toil of suffering and bloodshed on both sides," as the preamble put it, but left the "final peaceful settlement" to the civilians. The civilians met in Geneva in 1954, but the talks broke down almost immediately. And despite subsequent attempts over the years, they never resumed.
 
Regrets Only
 But if the armistice has held so long, is it really necessary to replace it?
Jeong Ho Roh, associate director of the Center for Korean Legal Studies at Columbia University's School of Law, said a formal end to the war is crucial. The lack of a peace treaty, he explained, frees both North and South Korea of accountability. Either side can violate the armistice more or less with impunity, as happens repeatedly in clashes along the demilitarized zone.
Last September an incident involving a North Korean submarine ended with 24 of sailors and commandos being killed South Korea. That incident, condemned as a provocation by the South and the United States, actually allowed the diplomatic breakthrough leading up to last week's meeting: North Korea delivered an unprecedented "expression of regret." Last week Pyongyang released the remains of American soldiers killed four decades ago.
A peace treaty, Mr. Roh said, would bind the two sides to certain international norms.
And that may explain why the effort to arrange peace talks among the United States, China and the Koreas -- first proposed by President Clinton and South Korea's President Kim Young Sam of South Korea in April 1996 -- have dragged on so long.
Officially ending the war would be, for North and South Korea, tantamount to recognizing the legitimacy -- in fact, the very existence -- of the other. Neither seems fully prepared for that, and so the status quo, for all its flaws, preserves the claims of each to represent the one, true Korea.
"Without a legal end to the war," Mr. Roh asked, "how can there be a start to a new relationship between the two Koreas?"

HEADLINE: Boomerang;
What Goes Up Must Usually, Well, Stop Going Up

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
WHEN the history is written of America's mid-1990's economic boom, a fat chapter will certainly be devoted to the mystifying strength of corporate profits -- how they were able to rise so fast for so long. But there must also be a chapter that describes what happened when this extraordinary performance became ordinary, or worse. And the material for this second chapter seems to be falling into place now.
Part of the foundation undergirding the boom is quietly being eaten away. Stagnant wages -- the workers' contribution to their bosses' profits -- are beginning to rise. And there is agitation for more improvement. Workers for the United Parcel Service began a nationwide strike last week that was partly a protest against the insecurities of the Age of Downsizing. As if on cue, stock prices fell sharply on Thursday and Friday, suggesting the vulnerability of another engine of prosperity to shifting circumstances. 
 That's not to say that the profits, the equally spectacular stock market and the thriving economy -- all of them interconnected -- won't be able to continue their upward climb. But even if they do, the good times seem likely to take on a different, more precarious character.
The keys to this story are corporate profits and wages. More than usual, the market and the economy have fed off the strength of profits at the expense of wages. For every $100 in new production -- the assembly of a car, the services of a doctor, the dry cleaning of a suit -- nearly $10 is going into profits. Not since 1968 has the percentage been so high. From then until the mid-1990's, it rarely rose above $8.50. And much of the rise has come out of wages and benefits, which, according to new Commerce Department numbers, have declined as a percentage of national output to their lowest level in more than a decade.
The record-breaking stock market is the offspring of the profits squeezed from this process. The rising stock prices, in turn, feed the economy by encouraging spending. But there is a problem. Not often in history has the Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at 8,031 Friday, gotten so high in relation to earnings, even unusual earnings. And that leaves a lot of experts casting about for ways to make what is happening sound rational and lasting. If profits can't keep rising at the expense of wages -- and many experts think that vein has played out -- then some more enduring engine will have to kick in soon.
"People are looking for an easy explanation of why profits are doing well," said David Wyss, director of research at DRI-McGraw Hill, a consulting firm.
And not surprisingly, one has been summoned. The heartening explanation, the one that would keep profits and stock prices rising if it turns out to be true, depicts the American economy as having entered, in the last year or two, a new, robust era.
The main characteristic of this new era is rising productivity. The new technologies, particularly computers and telecommunications, are finally making workers more productive, the story goes. Using the new tools, workers are producing more in each hour on the job. Already, they may be keeping some of this extra revenue from their production, while the rest goes into profits. And the stock market -- the great indicator of American prosperity -- will continue upward, reinforcing the process.
"Evidence of higher productivity abounds," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "You may not accept it, because it does not show up in the official Government statistics. We think most of the statistics are out of date."
There are problems, however, with the rosy productivity scenario, which has attracted varying degrees of endorsement from a range of business executives and economists. One is that it may not be happening, although it certainly sounds logical. Indeed, it fits neatly with the well documented rise in profits. Consider this example:
A carpenter is paid $25 an hour to make one birdhouse every hour, which is sold for $35. The profit from that hour of work is $10. If the price does not change and the carpenter's wage does not either, but the profit rises to $20 an hour, then it must be that, having finally mastered some cutting-edge technology, the carpenter is turning out two birdhouses an hour. Or so the rosy scenario goes, by deductive reasoning.
Maybe. But as Mr. Jasinowski acknowledges, the improvement has not shown up in Government statistics that measure the rate of productivity growth across the nation's private businesses. Quite the contrary, these statistics show productivity rising more slowly in the 1990's than they did in the 1980's.
The believers say the statistics don't tell the story.
"We have good theoretical reasons to believe that productivity is higher than what is measured in the aggregate numbers," said Bennett Harrison, an economist at the New School for Social Research in New York, joining Mr. Jasinowski in this view.
Their productivity thesis -- and the accuracy of the Government's statistics -- is likely to be tested soon. Tight labor markets give the hypothetical carpenter, like the real U.P.S. drivers, leverage to demand a higher wage. If his productivity has in fact not risen to two birdhouses an hour, then the higher wage he gets will squeeze profits. Either that or companies will raise prices to preserve profits, pushing up the until- now languid inflation rate.
And if that happens, stock prices seem destined to fall, puncturing the larger economic boom. For workers, the world shakes. The very act of earning more threatens to consign them to doing worse.
Whatever the outcome, let the test begin. Indeed, it has begun. The first tentative signs that wages may be trending upward are starting to appear in Labor Department data. What's more, company payments to provide health insurance for employees, which had been held down as a result of cost-cutting among hospitals and doctors, are beginning to rise again, adding gradually to labor compensation.
"All this upward pressure on labor costs means that profits can no longer grow as much as they have," Mr. Wyss said. "If productivity does not kick in, profits slow down."
Other factors have helped to postpone this showdown. In hindsight, they contribute to an understanding of how corporate profits could have grown so much over the last three years without a boost from productivity.
Interest rates on corporate debt have declined, and the savings have gone into profits. The debt itself has been paid down, further reducing corporate America's monthly installment payments, and this saving, too, has gone into profits rather than raises. Constant downsizing has cut costs, and again, the savings have fed into profits.
 
Faster and Faster
 The thriving economy has also helped. Many companies have stepped up production from existing machinery and personnel. Simply by eliminating the slack in their operations, they have been able to sell more without adding much to their cost. It is as if the carpenter actually turned out a birdhouse in 30 minutes and spent the other half-hour relaxing at the water cooler -- until a foreman got on his case. And the extra sales revenue from his harder work once again has gone mainly into profits rather than wages.
But all these lucky circumstances are wearing out. The final episodes in this particular history are just ahead. Either the new age of rising productivity shows itself, saving the day. Or that does not happen and, as profits fall back to more ordinary levels, stock prices fall back, too, and the economy weakens.
Or, alas, some inconclusive middle course unfolds. Mr. Jasinowski sees that possibility. Any number of companies, he says, still have room to fatten profits through cost-cutting, particularly downsizing. "The overwhelming reality of so many companies," he said, "is that you can't raise prices. So you eliminate waste, you downsize. Cost-cutting is still a big opportunity."

HEADLINE: Patience of Jobs;
An Industry and Its Founders Grow Up

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
THE personal computer industry was created in the mid-1970's by a few hundred fiercely competitive, idealistic young men barely out of their teens. Their mission was to change the world by democratizing digital technology (and, yes, to get rich too). They pursued their goals with the energy and passion of youth. Disagreements had a way of escalating into shouting matches, and conflicts became holy wars.
Today, the computer industry has grown to become a $150-billion-a-year business and the people who built it have grown up as well. Most of them are now in their 40's, married with children. They have less hair and more pounds. Many are worth millions or, in a few cases, billions of dollars. 
 "It used to be that I was the youngest person in business meetings," Steven P. Jobs, the co-founder of Apple Computer Inc., said recently, "But I'm an old man in this industry now, with a lot of experience and scar tissue."
Last week, the 42-year-old Mr. Jobs announced a surprising alliance between Apple and its long-time archrival, the Microsoft Corporation. It was a sure sign that those vigorous holy wars have been replaced by a kind of pragmatic maturity. Experience, scar tissue and a flair for imaginative deal-making prompted Mr. Jobs to save Apple by reaching out to a seemingly unlikely patron -- William H. Gates, Microsoft's 41-year-old chief executive. Microsoft is investing $150 million in Apple, and the two companies have agreed to cooperate on several sales and technology fronts.
For Microsoft, the $150 million is lunch money. But the deal was a striking symbol to the high-tech world that even Microsoft has a direct stake in Apple's future. The two companies have long competed and cooperated at the same time. Microsoft's Windows operating software -- a program that handles a computer's basic operations -- got its start by mimicking Apple's Macintosh software, and then went on to dominate the market. Yet Microsoft also makes word processing and other office programs that run on Macintosh computers, which are used by eight million customers and generate several hundred million dollars a year in business for Microsoft.
When Mr. Jobs announced the pact with Microsoft at the Macworld trade show in Boston last Wednesday, he was greeted with catcalls from some Macintosh loyalists. Mr. Jobs advised them to grow up. "We want to let go of this notion that for Apple to win, Microsoft has to lose," he said. "We better treat Microsoft with a little gratitude."
Or at least with equanimity. Mr. Jobs, who was ousted from Apple in 1985 and returned last December as an adviser when Apple acquired his company Next Software Inc., clearly views Microsoft's dominance of mainstream personal computing as a fact of modern life. Railing against Microsoft, he suggests, is like complaining about the weather -- emotionally satisfying, perhaps, but pointless.
So finding a way to work with Microsoft, or make a living in its slipstream, is what strategy is in the PC industry today. "Every company, no matter how much they may dislike Microsoft, has to work with Microsoft as well," observed David Yoffie, a Harvard business school professor.
 
Gore and Doerr
 As they age, the computer industry's elite are learning to accept the necessity of working with Washington, too. For years, Silicon Valley's entrepreneurs would boast of their aversion to the Government. With their free-market libertarian bent, the architects of the high-tech economy used to view Washington as the last refuge of the industrial economy's losers, seeking protection and subsidies.
But today, Silicon Valley is losing its disdain for Washington. The spread of the Internet as a medium of communication and commerce raises the prospect of Government oversight, if not conventional regulation. And at the very least, the techies want to make sure the dunderheads in Washington don't mess things up.
So, last month a group of Silicon Valley executives and venture capitalists formed a bipartisan political action committee, the Technology Network, to push their "new economy" agenda. The group is headed by John Doerr, senior partner of Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers, a leading venture-capital firm, and James Barksdale, chief executive of the Netscape Communications Corporation. Mr. Doerr has become such a close adviser to Vice President Al Gore that a recent article in "Fast Company" magazine ran under the half-jesting headline: "Gore and Doerr in 2004?"
There was a time when Steve Jobs declined to even vote, a lingering effect, he said, of his reaction to the Watergate era. But now he has become politically engaged again. He played host to a dinner for Bill Clinton at his home in Palo Alto, Calif., last year. And he contributed enough to the Clinton campaign -- about $100,000 -- to have been invited to the sleep in the Lincoln Bedroom.
Mr. Jobs says that having children made him realize how important some public policy issues are. Family life, too, has changed some of the tone and style of cyber business. In their talks about the Microsoft-Apple deal, Mr. Gates, who has a young daughter, said he and Mr. Jobs, who has three children, spoke not only of software and money but also of the miracle of watching firsthand as the brain of a young child gets wired.
At Pixar Inc., the computer animation studio behind the hit film "Toy Story," a company Mr. Jobs founded, the management style is not what it was like at Apple in the early 1980's. And family is a key reason. "If Steve calls you at home, you can tell him you'll call him back because you're reading a bedtime story to your kids," said Lawrence Levy, Pixar's chief financial officer. "Steve does it and he's totally tolerant of others doing it."
That's a far cry from the early 1980's, when Mr. Jobs headed the Apple team that developed the Mac, working around the clock, in a building with a pirate's flag flying outside.
