HEADLINE: It's Wrong to Demonize China

BYLINE: By Jimmy Carter; Jimmy Carter, the 39th President of the United States, is chairman of the nonprofit Carter Center.

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
I spent the spring of 1949 in the seaports of China as a young naval officer on my first submarine cruise. Nearly 30 years later, Deng Xiaoping and I normalized diplomatic relations between our countries. We knew that even with this opening, decades of patience and persistence would be required before the bonds between our greatly different countries would be firm and predictable.
I consider sound Sino-American relations, along with the importance of maintaining human rights as a foundation of American foreign policy, to be legacies of my Administration. These two goals are not incompatible, but can be reached only if we try to understand each other. 
 Americans have benefited from the unprecedented stability and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region made possible by close ties among the United States, China and Japan. But the greatest beneficiaries have been the Chinese people, whose quality of life and human rights have improved enormously during the last two decades.
Both China and the United States continue to share many interests: maintaining peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, controlling weapons of mass destruction, preventing conflict on the Korean peninsula and fostering open trade. Unfortunately, many Americans and Chinese have lost sight of the original vision that brought us together. Ill-informed commentators in both countries have cast the other side as a villain and have even forecast inevitable confrontation between the two nations. The accomplishments of a quarter century are at risk.
Since my Presidency, I have been to China periodically to discuss world and domestic affairs and to visit rural areas. On my latest trip last month, I met with President Jiang Zemin, Prime Minister Li Peng, the chairman of the National People's Congress, Qiao Shi, and other leaders. They expressed concern that our leaders are encouraging Japanese rearmament and extending Japan's defense perimeter to include Taiwan. They also deeply resent American sales of F-16 jet fighters and other weaponry to Taiwan, saying that these deals seem to violate pledges made to them by Presidents Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan and me.
We also discussed America's concerns, including the mounting trade deficit, human rights and particularly the treatment of the Tibetan people.
Mutual criticisms are proper and necessary, but should not be offered in an arrogant or self-righteous way, and each of us should acknowledge improvements made by the other.
Significant changes are taking place throughout China. There is no longer a single unquestioned government policy. Instead, China's top leaders have a wide range of opinions on such issues as the role of parliaments, expansion of the election process and privatization. Since normalization, an increasingly free economic system has transformed the lives of Chinese people. Farmers now retain profits on practically all crops planted on their land, and many villagers own their own businesses. Incomes and educational opportunities have also risen sharply.
Although congregations must still register with the Government, membership in Christian churches is booming. The pastor of the church we attended in Shandong Province knew of only 200 believers in his rural county after the Cultural Revolution, and they had no churches or Bibles. There are now 15 congregations in 11 churches, 3,000 members have been baptized, and Bibles are distributed freely.
A 1987 law mandates elections in nearly a million villages. Citizens can choose among multiple candidates, including those who are not members of the Communist Party, in a secret ballot, and many nonparty members have been chosen as village leaders. The Carter Center has observed some of these contests. Arbitrary power is still exerted by some political leaders, but progress is being made in promoting the rule of law. Some citizens are even bringing lawsuits against government agencies that violate their rights.
Citizens are more free to move from one place to another, and the nation has been opened to outside interests and influence. Until 1985, no outsiders were permitted to enter the rural county we visited; now village leaders are trying to expand their 45 joint ventures with foreigners.
President Jiang's long overdue state visit to Washington in October -- the first by a Chinese leader in 10 years -- will provide an opportunity to address human rights and other issues.
American criticisms of China's human rights abuses are justified, but their basis is not well understood. Westerners emphasize personal freedoms, while a stable government and a unified nation are paramount to the Chinese. This means that policies are shaped by fear of chaos from unrestrained dissidents or fear of China's fragmentation by an independent Taiwan or Tibet. The result is excessive punishment of outspoken dissidents and unwarranted domination of Tibetans.
But frank discussions on these and other issues can sometimes yield real progress. In private discussions in 1979, Deng Xiaoping agreed to address the issue of religious freedom, and great improvements were made. In 1987, after a visit I made to Tibet, and after subsequent conversations with the exiled Dalai Lama, discussions were arranged between his emissaries and Chinese Government officials. Unfortunately, the Tiananmen Square tragedy aborted the initiative.
In spite of our differences, China and the United States must continue to pursue ways to co-exist peacefully and productively. In addition to summit meetings, ordinary Americans and Chinese can help. For example, more than 100,000 Chinese students have attended American universities since 1979, providing an invaluable cultural and intellectual exchange for both countries.
Only through continued dialogue at many levels can we resolve differences and build a foundation for better understanding.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Summary of Major Actions in the 220th Session of the Legislature

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 9

 BODY:
As the New York State Legislature sleepily stumbled to the close of its 220th session at 3:40 P.M. on Aug. 4, party leaders in both houses rose to give valedictories expressing their abiding affection for their staffs, their colleagues, even their opponents.
What they failed to mention were the nerve-jangling confrontations, the harsh invective and the simmering distrust that had been the session's real trademarks. This was not merely one of the Legislature's longest sessions ever -- 210 days, or seven months -- but also among its most contentious and least productive in recent years. 
 The year began with a bruising fight over a proposal to amend the State Constitution to allow casino gambling in places other than Indian reservations. The measure had the support of Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. But opposition from religious leaders, environmental groups and Donald Trump, the New Jersey casino owner, killed the measure in the Senate.
The defining battle was over laws that limit rent increases on more than one million apartments in and around New York City. The laws were scheduled to expire on June 15, and Mr. Bruno, supported by landlord groups, had vowed to let the laws lapse unless Democrats agreed to scale back many tenant protections. After months of intense public relations campaigns by both sides, Mr. Pataki and the legislative leaders reached agreement shortly after midnight on June 16 to extend the laws, but with changes allowing landlords to charge significantly higher rents on vacant units.
The Assembly passed 1,498 of the roughly 8,000 bills introduced into that house. The State Senate passed 1,418 of 5,793 bills. A total of 749 bills passed both houses. Of those, the Governor has signed 255 and vetoed 30. The remaining 464 bills are awaiting Mr. Pataki's decision on whether to sign them into law.
The following were the major actions of the session.
 
The Budget
 This year's budget was the latest in history, enacted 126 days after the April 1 start of the fiscal year, and it contained none of the austerity that was seen in Mr. Pataki's first two years in office or in the spending plan he proposed in January.
Despite the tardiness, the budget was negotiated this year with considerably less rancor than in the previous two years; the fighting that delayed it was primarily over the state's rent regulations and the new welfare laws.
The process was made easier by an extraordinary influx of cash, largely generated by the stock market boom, that led to a significant increase in spending.
Overall spending, which includes Federal aid for programs like welfare and Medicaid, rose 4.2 percent, to $67.4 billion. The state-funds portion of the budget, financed by taxes, fees and tuition, rose 2.5 percent, to $45.1 billion. And spending from the state general fund, financed just by state taxes, rose 5.2 percent, to $34.6 billion, after declining slightly for two consecutive years.
Most of the general fund increase was in aid to local school districts, which rose 7.3 percent, to $11 billion, the largest percentage increase since the 1980's.
The Governor and the Legislature also locked the state into a series of school aid increases for prekindergarten education, smaller elementary class sizes, and other measures, that will, by 2001, cost an additional $1.5 billion a year.
They also placed a $2.4 billion bond measure on the November ballot to build new schools and rehabilitate old ones.
Lawmakers enacted a broad range of tax cuts, which will be worth $4.8 billion a year when fully implemented in 2001, but most of them will not take effect in this fiscal year.
For the third straight year, the Legislature largely rejected Mr. Pataki's attempts to make deep cuts in Medicaid spending, the single biggest portion of the budget; indeed, when it became clear how much income tax revenue was pouring into the state's coffers, the Governor, himself, abandoned the proposed cuts.
The Legislature also turned back the Governor's proposals for a $400-a-year increase in public college tuition and deep cuts in tuition aid to poor students.
On welfare, the parameters were largely set by the Federal Government, which last year mandated a five-year lifetime limit on aid to families with children and required that the states place half of all recipients of Federal aid into work programs or work-related activities, like job training.
The Legislature rejected Mr. Pataki's proposed cuts in Federal benefits. The Governor wanted to eliminate the state's cash assistance program for people who do not qualify for Federal aid, and replace it with a system of vouchers for basic needs. Instead, the changes enacted limited cash assistance to two years, followed by a combination of vouchers and cash.
 
Taxes
 
LEGISLATION ENACTED
 Lowers residential property taxes to support school systems by about 30 percent -- an average of about $500 a year for each homeowner, a total of $2.2 billion -- by 2001.
Lowers the New York City income tax by 10 percent, or $62 a year for a person earning $36,000, by 2001.
Extends for two years a 12.5 percent surcharge on the New York City income tax that has been used to pay for policing, which costs $78 a year for a person earning $36,000.
Eliminates the gross receipts tax on hospitals, nursing homes and home care providers, saving $530 million a year by 2001.
Lowers the gross receipts tax on utility bills by 30 percent, or $440 million a year, by 2001.
Reduces estate taxes by a total of $440 million a year by 2001.
Eliminates the 4 percent state sales tax on clothing, except shoes, up to $100 per article in 1999, for a total of $430 million a year.
Increases the child care tax credit in 1999, primarily for low- and middle-income families, raising the maximum credit to $536 a year from $211 a year for a two-income family earning $25,000 a year.
Allows a family to exempt from personal income taxes money invested in a state-run fund for a child's college education. A family can invest up to $5,000 a year, up to a maximum of $100,000, in an investment account managed by the State Comptroller.
Eliminates a 1-cent tax on drink bottles and cans.
Eliminates the sales tax on coin-operated devices like vending machines, car washes and copying machines.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have required the Legislature and the Governor to act each year to reauthorize the phased-in tax cuts that were approved.

Education
 
LEGISLATION ENACTED
Extends for one year the law that allows the state's Dormitory Authority to issue bonds for construction projects for the State University of New York.
Directs the state's Commissioner of Education to encourage every public school to display the American flag in its classrooms.
Places a measure on the November ballot that would authorize the state to spend $2.4 billion on repairing schools and constructing new ones.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have allowed parents, teachers and community groups to create small schools that are financed by taxpayers but independent of local school boards.
Would have curbed state spending on special education by eliminating incentives that encourage schools to send children with mild problems to expensive and segregated classes.

LEGISLATION VETOED
Would have required at least four SUNY alumni to serve on the university's board of trustees.

Crime and Justice
 
LEGISLATION ENACTED
Authorizes construction of a new, 1,500-bed, maximum-security state prison near Tupper Lake in the Adirondack Park, and the addition of 1,600 maximum-security beds to existing medium-security prisons.
Allows time off for good behavior for nonviolent felons, up to one-sixth of their minimum sentences for inmates who do one of the following: complete a vocational training program, earn a high school equivalency degree or complete a drug rehabilitation program.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have increased sentences for juvenile offenders, expanded the list of crimes for which juveniles could be tried as adults, lowered the age for trying juveniles as adults for crimes like murder and assault, and allowed Family Court judges to issue search warrants in juvenile cases.
Would have sentenced adults who had committed offenses as juveniles within the previous five years as repeat felons, rather than as first-time offenders.
Would have opened juvenile cases to the public.
Would have moved serious juvenile criminal cases from Family Court to the Supreme Court.
Would have consolidated the state's nine layers of trial courts into two, and would have eliminated certain limits on the number of Supreme Court justices.
Would have created a "super-maximum" detention complex for juveniles.
Would have required that anyone who enters into a contract with a convicted criminal for the rights to the criminal's story notify the state Crime Victims Board.
Would have allowed cameras in courtrooms.

Welfare and Families
 
AWAITING SIGNATURE
 Would increase penalties against parents or legal guardians who repeatedly fail to pay court-ordered child-support payments.
Would set a five-year time-limit on cash benefits for poor families.
Would provide two years of cash benefits and then a combination of vouchers and cash to poor people who do not qualify for Federal welfare benefits.
Would deny state-financed benefits to legal immigrants during their first year in the country.
Would allow welfare recipients to earn up to $1,080 a month in salary without taking away any of their public-assistance benefits.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
 Would have cut monthly cash benefits for poor families by 45 percent over five years.
Would have required mandatory drug testing of all welfare recipients.
Would have stopped the transfer of a foster child from one set of foster parents to another until a hearing determined if such a move was in the child's best interest.
Would have required the authorities to notify parents before examining their children for signs of abuse.
Would have made it easier to prosecute those who batter other family members by lowering the severity of injury that a prosecutor must prove.
 
Transportation
 
LEGISLATION ENACTED
Extends for three years a law requiring immediate license suspension for anyone arrested for driving while intoxicated.
Enacts the Metropolitan Transportation Authority capital program, which spends $7.3 billion over three years for more than 100 new subway trains, hundreds of new buses, commuter trains, station renovations and other projects.
Enacts the five-year, $12 billion statewide highway and bridge construction and repair program.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
 Would have required the New York City Parking Violations Bureau to respond to any complaint that a vehicle was wrongfully towed and would have granted expedited review of such allegations before a panel of three arbiters.
Would have allowed a court to suspend a driver's license based on a conviction for boating while intoxicated, or suspend a boating license based on a conviction for driving while intoxicated.
Would have required that children under age 16 wear seat belts while riding in the rear seat of a car, which is now required only for children under 10.
Would have applied the requirement to set aside parking spaces for disabled people to any store parking lot with 20 or more spaces, a requirement that applies now only if the lot serves three or more stores.
 
Energy and Environment
 
LEGISLATION ENACTED
Authorizes the Long Island Power Authority, a quasi-state agency, to buy a portion of the Long Island Lighting Company as a way of reducing Lilco's long-term debt and thereby cutting energy costs on Long Island.
Extends a moratorium on new licenses for fishing, lobstering and crabbing.
Will make available 400 megawatts in electric power to be sold at below-market rates to help companies create or retain jobs.
Will provide a tax credit worth up to $5,000 to purchasers of electric vehicles.
 
AWAITING SIGNATURE
Would allow people who use solar power to sell excess power back to their utilities and so reduce their energy bills. Would also provide a tax credit for the purchase and installation of solar panels.
Would require the Department of Environmental Conservation to establish criteria for judging projects eligible for financing under the $1.75 billion Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act of 1996.
Would prohibit feeding of deer within 300 feet of a public highway.
 
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have allowed utility companies to refinance their debt at lower interest rates by using "intangible properties" -- which could include the expense of building a power plant -- to back the sale of bonds.
Would have allowed owners of billboards to cut down trees that prevent drivers along state roads from reading their advertisements.
Would have allowed the snaring of beavers.
Would have allowed private citizens to sue companies that violate state environmental laws.
Would have allowed the state to penalize New York companies that sell so-called pollution allowances -- which effectively provide a legal license to pollute -- to industries outside the state whose pollution may contribute to acid rain in New York State.
Would have required commercial pesticide companies to notify neighbors when they plan to apply chemicals outdoors.
 
Health Care

Bans the practice of genital mutilation on women who are 18 or under.

AWAITING SIGNATURE

Would allow New York City teachers with 10 years' experience to retire at the age of 55 with full pension benefits.

AWAITING SIGNATURE

Agriculture

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: In U.S. Deportation Policy, a Pandora's Box

SERIES: DEADLY EXPORTS -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: QUEZALTEPEQUE, El Salvador

 BODY:
On a stifling afternoon, Luis Arnoldo Lopez, late of Los Angeles, gathers with members of the Mara Salvatrucha gang to smoke marijuana, sniff glue and inscribe gang tattoos on one another's skin. Suddenly, their conversation shifts to the rival 18th Street gang.
"They killed Cuchillo, so we have to kill them," a teen-ager nicknamed "Snoopy" complains to Mr. Lopez. "They have been robbing and killing us, so we have to protect ourselves." 
 Wearing gray pants that say "L.A. County Jail," Mr. Lopez, 18, nods in agreement and begins to goad his comrades.
"We've got to defend each other and our barrio," he tells them. "Every time they kill one of our homeboys, one of theirs should also die."
If Mr. Lopez speaks in a peculiar mixture of American and Salvadoran street slang, it is no accident. For he is one of a growing number of immigrants whom the United States has shipped back to their countries of origin under an effort mandated by Congress a decade ago and strengthened with new financing in the last four years. It requires the deportation, at the end of their prison sentences, of those immigrants, legal or illegal, who have been convicted of a broad range of felonies, from murder to drug possession.
The policy is having a profound effect here in El Salvador. Since January, just in this dusty town of 13,000 people at least 7 people have died in gang violence, the police say. The victims included a 3-year-old girl killed when she and her family came out of church and walked into the middle of a grenade fight between two gangs, each with roots in the United States.
In the last fiscal year, the Immigration and Naturalization Service reports having deported about 37,000 criminals, up from about 27,000 three years before. And in the first half of this fiscal year, it has stepped up the pace further, deporting more than 23,000, for an annual rate of more than 45,000.
The program was intended to lower the American crime rate, free up prison space and save American taxpayers money by getting rid of people who were not citizens and were considered likely to commit new crimes after having served their sentences. The policy may have had a small effect in those directions, officials in the United States say, but it is also having a set of far more noticeable unintended side effects, including these:
*American gang habits -- and branches of the gangs themselves -- are being exported to El Salvador and other countries in and around the Caribbean. In these smaller cultures, weak police forces already have their hands full struggling to control individual crime or politically motivated violence. Now the police face slick, organized, well-armed gangs that operate with all the truculence of their parent groups in Los Angeles and other American cities. Political leaders fear the effect on their lands' stability, and they are complaining to the Clinton Administration about it.
*In the United States, law enforcement officials are contending with a "boomerang" effect -- the rapid return to America of criminals who were recently deported. Deportation has given them opportunities to forge new connections to drug and other crime rings in their own lands. In turn, this only compounds their ability to commit new crimes in the United States.
*Inflexibilities built into the law have trapped and marked for deportation a small but significant number of people who under other circumstances would be considered good candidates to become law-abiding and productive.
Perhaps the most dramatic of these side effects was in plain view in the safe house where Mr. Lopez and the Mara Salvatrucha gang were talking so matter-of-factly about murder. Five years after a peace accord ended El Salvador's long and brutal civil war, gang warfare transplanted from the United States has emerged as a new threat to security.
Throughout the country, thousands of young men, recruited and led by deportees who learned their trade on the streets of American cities, have been joining the gangs, which officials blame for much of a marked postwar increase in violence and criminality. Subcommissioner Carlos Ramirez Landaverde, deputy director of the department of criminal investigation, said there have been dozens of gang-related deaths in the last year.
The gangs bring with them a deadly rivalry that dates back to their founding in Los Angeles. And when not trying to kill each other, their members rob travelers, rape women, steal cars, deal in drugs and extort businesses.
Since 1993, more than 4,000 Salvadorans, mostly teen-agers and young adults, with United States criminal records have been forcibly repatriated to a homeland that many of them barely remembered, since most were children when they fled this country as refugees during the civil war.
"As the deportations have increased, so has crime, and the deportees are responsible for a disproportional amount of that," Mr. Ramirez Landaverde said. "Many of the most violent offenses, like murder, kidnapping and robbery, are committed by people who have been in the United States and are sent back here without any prior notice, with all the bad habits they developed there."
 
The Villages
Armed Gangs, Outgunned Police
That crime wave extends even to the most remote peasant villages, which are now blighted with graffiti, much of it in English. Local branches of two Los Angeles gangs -- Mara Salvatrucha and 18th Street -- and their allies in the similarly transplanted Crazy, Mau-Mau and White Fence gangs, use the scrawled messages to threaten vengeance on each other and express their contempt for a police force that is undermanned, underarmed and undertrained. "We control the nation," the Mara Salvatrucha brags in graffiti here, an hour's drive from the capital.
"The cops up there are real tough, but the ones here are a joke," said Mr. Lopez, who says he joined the White Fence gang, an ally of Mara Salvatrucha, when he lived in California. He was deported to Quezaltepeque in November after being convicted of armed robbery and drug trafficking charges. "Up there, if you do a drive-by, at least there is an investigation. Here, there is nothing."
For their part, the police bitterly acknowledge that the deportees and their gangs often have them outmaneuvered and outgunned. "Our weapons are lousy, and they're running around with M-16 rifles and guns they have smuggled in from outside the country," said Antonio Cruz Preza Sanchez, a police inspector who is leading the investigation into the April slaying of a police officer in the town of Conchagua, in which a deportee is accused.
El Salvador's traditional police force, accused of widespread human rights violations, was disbanded as part of the 1992 peace agreement that ended the 12-year civil war. Thousands of soldiers and guerrillas were demobilized, and many of their weapons were destroyed. A new Civilian National Police was established, but it is still not operating at full strength and has been plagued by recruitment, budget and other problems. In part to instill confidence among civilians, its members have not been given the same kind of routine access to heavy armaments that the national police forces had during the civil war. Today the police on patrol carry pistols and nightsticks, not assault rifles.
One result of the inability of the police to contain the new gang activity is a re-emergence of death-squad activity in El Salvador -- not against political enemies, but against suspected gang members. During the civil war, right-wing death squads linked to the military were responsible for the deaths of many of the 75,000 people estimated to have died. Now new squads with names like The Black Shadow and The Lightning Command have sprung up. But this time, ordinary citizens weary of crime have largely applauded their efforts.
In April, three men said to be members of The Black Shadow went on trial in the eastern city of San Miguel, charged with "illicit association" and the 1994 slaying of three Mara Salvatrucha members. Part of a larger group of 12 civilians and four police officers who had initially been arrested in connection with the killings, they were praised by the Mayor, who said that crime was "devouring" his city. A jury quickly absolved them.
"This is a very serious problem," said President Armando Calderon Sol, who was one of several Central American and Caribbean leaders who raised the issue of deportees when President Clinton visited the region in May.
"The United States lets these dangerous types out and tells them 'Go back to where you came from.' But we have no way to try them or jail them" for crimes committed on foreign soil, he said, "and so we must not only let them in, but let them go free."
The situation may be especially serious here, but El Salvador is by no means alone in its alarm at Washington's policy on deportees. Throughout Central America and the Caribbean, from Guatemala east to Guyana, government officials have expressed anger and frustration at a crisis they regard as foisted on them by United States and beyond their ability to control.
 
The Nations
Lands Inundated By Tough Outlaws
 The overwhelming bulk of "criminal removals" by the I.N.S. have been to Mexico, Central America and Caribbean countries. In Jamaica, for example, more than 3,000 such deportees have arrived since the agency began increasing its effort four years ago, said Keith D. Knight, that country's Minister of National Security.
In general, "these are persons who have severed all ties to Jamaica and are sent back to us destitute, with convictions for the most violent offenses, like murder and assault and trafficking in drugs and firearms," Mr. Knight said in an interview in Kingston earlier this year. "They simply become part of the criminal fraternity, and the intelligence we have suggests deep involvement in serious and sophisticated crime activities here."
The English-speaking island nations of the eastern Caribbean, with their small populations and limited resources, have similar complaints. They are under increasing pressure from the United States to help Washington fight the boom in drug trafficking noticeable throughout the region, but they are being inundated with deportees they say are likely to gravitate to exactly such ventures.
"If they are sending the worst criminals back to us, that is a bit cold, calculating and uncaring, and certainly not the action of a fair and concerned friend," Keith Mitchell, Prime Minister and Minister of National Security of Grenada, said in an interview in April. "If a man was born in Grenada but has spent 30 years in the U.S., he is not going to know one person here, and with no means of supporting himself, the chances are he will commit a crime."
Even after they are returned to the countries of their births, officials throughout the region note, deportees maintain ties to the gangs to which they belonged in the United States and continue to cooperate with them in criminal activities. Here, for instance, gang members are reported by the police to receive and resell cars stolen by former comrades in California and Texas and to be involved in illegally transporting would-be immigrants to the United States.
In addition, gang members here are said to buy and smuggle weapons left over from the civil war, including rifles, pistols, grenades, ammunition and rocket launchers, to and from the United States and neighboring countries. Salvadoran police officials also say that gang leaders here and in the United States have formed alliances with cocaine and marijuana traffickers from Mexico and Colombia to move drugs through El Salvador and neighboring countries.
The flourishing gang network here also provides an underground railroad of sorts for gang leaders still living in the United States when they need to evade charges there. El Salvador does not have an extradition treaty with the United States, so gang members facing arrest in an American city can simply vanish into the protective structure that their branches here offer.
"That's what I'm doing right now, chillin' with my homeys," a leader of the Mara Crazy in the eastern city of San Miguel, who identified himself only by his street name, "Dreamer," said this spring, speaking in bilingual gang argot. "I've got some problems in the States, so I came down here to hang for a while."
 
The Friction
Calls for Warnings And Rap Sheets
That reverse side of the flow of deportees, wanted outlaws taking refuge in their home countries, has become a source of tension between the United States and its neighbors in Central America and the Caribbean. Washington says that these countries do not make enough of an effort to arrest such criminals and that they have antiquated extradition laws, and is pressing for constitutional changes.
But the receiving countries have complaints of their own, noting that the United States has sent most of the deportees to them without any advance notification or warning.
In an interview at the National Palace in San Salvador, Mr. Calderon Sol said his Government needed greater cooperation. "They send us deportees without any prior warning, and that complicates things," he said.
The Salvadoran Government has proposed legislation that would require deportees with foreign criminal records to register with Salvadoran immigration authorities immediately upon their return to the country. Once they find a place to live, they would also be required to report regularly to the local police.
"We can't deny any citizen the right to return," Mr. Calderon Sol said. "We have to take them back, and we can't ask the United States to take charge of them. But we need measures that require these dangerous types to report every week or fortnight."
As things have stood until now, Salvadoran law enforcement officials say, often they have learned of a deportee's return only after a crime has been committed and a suspect apprehended. Except in a few extraordinary cases, they say, there has been no prior notification from American immigration or police authorities that a criminal deportee is on the way, which only makes their job more difficult.
"It would help us a lot to know in advance, especially in cases of the type where they are involved in a crime just as soon as they arrive," Mr. Ramirez Landaverde said. "It is important for us to be able to have an album of photos that we can show to people, to have fingerprints and a rap sheet of the crimes these people have committed in the United States, to know what tattoos or other identifying features they may have."
Just before Easter, for example, Jesus Enrique Flores was deported to his home town, Conchagua, after living in the United States for 11 years, jail terms for gang-related drug and assault convictions included. Less than two weeks later, the police in his hometown said, he shot and killed one police officer and gravely wounded another outside a local bordello.
In an interview at the ramshackle jail where he was being held, Mr. Flores, stocky, shirtless and with a large "18" tattooed on his chest, maintained that local the police had singled him out merely because he was a deportee. "I am innocent," he said. "They have accused the wrong person."
Mr. Flores, a 26-year-old who said he had worked as a gardener and construction worker in Washington and Los Angeles before being jailed, acknowledged being a member of the 18th Street Gang. After serving his most recent term in a California prison, he said, he was handed over to the I.N.S. early this year and held while his deportation order was being processed.
Then, Mr. Flores said, "they just put me on an American Airlines flight from Los Angeles." Asked if he had been shackled or held under guard, he said that he had not, but had traveled as an ordinary passenger.
On his arrival at the international airport outside San Salvador, he said: "I gave the immigration and customs people my passport, it was stamped like anybody else's, and I came home here. I'd never had any problems with the law here, so there was no reason for them to hold me, and my name wasn't on any blacklist that the Government had of people who were to be detained."
A spokesman for the immigration service in Washington, Russ Bergeron, acknowledged that the agency has not systematically advised foreign immigration or law enforcement officials when their citizens are deported.
"We recognize that these countries want more information, and we are working with foreign governments to provide them with new mechanisms" for prior notification, he said.
On Aug. 1, the agency began using new notification guidelines intended to address some of the complaints of countries being sent deportees. Under the new procedures, foreign governments are to be supplied the name, date of birth, birthplace, criminal record and expected date of arrival of deportees, though not their photographs or fingerprints, Mr. Bergeron said.
The Salvadoran police said the background of Mr. Flores, the man accused of shooting two police officers in Conchagua,matched that of the typical deportee: male, in his late teens to mid 20's and from a poor and broken family. The gang problem is nationwide, they add, but most acute in those areas of the country where heavy fighting, human rights abuses and forced flight were most prevalent during the civil war.
"In 1981, the death squads came to our house, yanked my uncle out of bed and shot him and tried to kill my mother, my sister and me, so my mother went to Houston and left me with my grandparents and cousins," said Edwin Castillo, a 25-year-old member of the Mara Salvatrucha who was deported to Quezaltepeque late last year. "She brought me up north later, and the seed of my liking for the gangster life was planted there, and just kept on growing."
But once back home, Mr. Castillo and other deportees said, it is easy to recruit local teen-agers into the gang life. Unemployment is high, school is expensive, amusements are minimal, and, thanks in large part to the gangs, drugs are increasingly available.
"If you keep sending these guys back, we're going to have another civil war on our hands," Mr. Preza Sanchez, the police investigator, warned. "People will arm themselves again, and this new police force will be nullified. We are very worried."

HEADLINE: Mud From Clogged Harbor May Be a Resource in the Rough

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN

 BODY:
In an experiment to try to solve several serious environmental and economic problems, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania have agreed to use mud dredged from clogged channels in New York Harbor to seal some of the abandoned coal mines that scar the Pennsylvania countryside and leach acid runoff into thousands of rivers and streams.
If successful, the procedure could clear the harbor's channels by providing a near boundless repository for dredged mud, while helping Pennsylvania fix a centuries-old environmental problem for less than the current estimated cleanup cost of $15 billion. 
 Some mud could begin moving to Pennsylvania from the harbor before Sept. 1, if suitable dredging projects are settled on, and if New York, New Jersey and Federal harbor officials agree on how it should be paid for. Pennsylvania's Department of Environmental Protection issued a permit in June allowing a test of as many as 500,000 tons of harbor mud.
Shoals of river-borne mud are threatening maritime commerce in New York Harbor, the East Coast's biggest seaport. For decades, the mud, most of which contains traces of dioxins, heavy metals and other pollutants, was dumped at sea, but new Federal rules protecting marine life now prohibit that practice.
Efforts by New Jersey and New York to find places to dump or use the mud on land have been hampered by public fears of harmful effects, even though Federal and state environmental officials agree that the material poses no significant risk to people or the ecology on land.
Now, though, environmental officials in Pennsylvania see use of the same, often maligned, mud, after it is mixed with ash and other materials to form cement, as a way to erase two centuries of scars from surface coal mining. New Jersey and New York would pick up the cost of shipping the mud, which is likely to cost less than almost any other option.
Pennsylvania's director of mine reclamation, Ernest Giovannitti, toured New York Harbor last week to see dredging operations and discuss ways to move the mud. "It's potentially a win-win for everybody," he said. "The harbor benefits, and we get some reclamation accomplished for nothing that we probably wouldn't get to do otherwise."
Pennsylvania residents have given the planned test sharply mixed reviews, with some private environmental groups attacking it for adding to the flow of waste into the state -- which already leads the nation in taking other states' garbage and hazardous waste.
Jeffrey K. Schmidt, a lobbyist in Harrisburg for the Pennsylvania chapter of the Sierra Club, said the project appeared to be hastily approved and poorly defined. He added that the Sierra Club was concerned that some of the ash for the project would come from incinerators in New Jersey.
But Susan Wilson, the executive director of a citizens' advisory committee for the state's environmental agency, said that state environmental officials had addressed many concerns of committee members -- for example, allowing the nearest town to the planned test, Penfield, to have its own inspector monitor the project.
Other groups that are focused on the need for mine reclamation have welcomed the test, as long as it is carefully run.
The project is still in the planning stages and can go forward only if it is chosen over a host of competing proposals for using the dredged mud in construction projects around the harbor or for sealing landfills or toxic waste sites. But environmental officials from all three states said that no single option offered a solution to the dredging problem on a scale remotely like that of the coal-mine cleanup.
Pennsylvania is pocked with more than 9,000 abandoned surface mines, including more than 5,000 barren pits and miles-long trenches that leach more than 100 million gallons a day of highly acidic water, damaging 2,400 miles of streams and rivers and ruining ground-water supplies.
Much of the mining in Pennsylvania in the past took place where foot-thick beds of coal were within 60 or 80 feet of the surface, allowing mine operators to scrape the earth away to reach the coal without digging tunnels.
In some places where coal seams emerged along the sides of hills, the overlying dirt was excavated all along the seam in a strip, leaving some 80-foot-high scars that ran for miles.
The acid problem is created when water percolates through iron pyrite, or fool's gold, a mineral that lies exposed in shattered rock left behind after coal has been extracted.
The budget for the test project is confidential, because the plan to take harbor mud to Pennsylvania must compete in a Federal bidding process with plans to dispose of it elsewhere, said Andrew T. Voros, who helped negotiate aspects of the pilot project. Mr. Voros is the executive director of the Clean Ocean and Shore Trust, a commission created three years ago by the New York and New Jersey State Legislatures to find solutions to shared pollution problems.
The mud-into-mines disposal option is expected to be economical, because many of the mine sites have rail lines leading to them.
The cost of the pilot project would probably be borne primarily by New Jersey and New York, which have substantial amounts budgeted for the dredging problem, Mr. Voros said.
The mud would be blended with other materials to stiffen it sufficiently to transport it in containers.
It would then be carried by train to Bark Camp, a former mining site in west-central Pennsylvania that has been turned into a laboratory for mine cleanup techniques.
There, lime would be added to solidify the cement, in a simple process similar to one the Romans used to build the Colosseum, officials said.
The cement's alkaline properties could buffer the acidity in the mines and help break down some of the industrial contaminants in the mud, said Barry E. Scheetz, a professor of cement chemistry at Pennsylvania State University who has helped design the pilot project.
Like the Colosseum, the plugs in the mines would probably "be stable for thousands of years," Dr. Scheetz said. He said the project would proceed in steps, first testing the mud-ash mix on the surface before trying to seal seeps of tainted mine runoff.
Darlene Crawford, a spokeswoman for the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection, said the test would be carefully monitored to be sure that any contaminants in the mud remain locked in the cement.
She said Pennsylvanians wanted to make sure that no new pollution problems would be created in a state that has suffered so much already. "First they've seen their land raped by the coal barons, and now they don't want to see it as a dumping ground for New York's sludge," she said.
But more and more, officials from the participating states said, people are recognizing that the dredged material can be useful. Once the mud is mixed with ash, the resulting substance meets environmental standards for construction fill or landfill cover.
"This isn't municipal waste," John Cahill, New York State's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, said. "It's a resource."
More than one million tons of a similar mixture of harbor mud and other materials have already been used to create a parking lot for a new mall in Elizabeth, N.J. But the Pennsylvania mines could provide a repository for perhaps hundreds of millions of tons of dredged mud, more than enough to absorb the mud from dredging for decades, Mr. Voros said.
The project grew out of discussions among the three states during the last two years, Mr. Voros said. From these talks grew the realization that New York Harbor's problem might be Pennsylvania's solution.
"It's as if your basement is flooded and your neighbor's house is on fire," Mr. Voros said. "There's an answer there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In an experiment that is planned to be mutually beneficial, mud being dredged from Port Elizabeth and Port Newark, N.J., and New York Harbor to allow entry to deeper-draft ships will be taken to Pennsylvania. There, it will be used to seal coal mines that have been leaching acid runoffs into thousands of rivers and streams. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)(pg. 29)
 
Chart: "HOW IT WORKS: From New York Harbor to Pennsylvania's Mines"
New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania plan to use sediment dredged from New York Harbor to seal abandoned coal mines in Pennsylvania, which could resolve difficult environmental problems in all three states.
 
1. Sediment
Millions of tons of sediment from rivers and streams feeds into New York Harbor each year. Much of it is contaminated by dioxins and other pollutants.
 
2. Dredging
To keep the harbor open to big ships, the sediment is continually dredged. New laws prohibit disposing the mud at sea.
 
3. Adding ash
Under the plan, the sediment would be mixed with ash waste produced by coal burning plants to stiffen it sufficiently to transport it. It would then be sent to Pennsylvania.
 
4. Adding lime
In Pennsylvania, the ash and mud would be mixed with more ash and lime to make cement. The cement's alkaline properties make it an excellent buffer for pollantants.
 
5. Strip mines
The cement would be used to fill in old coal strip mines in Pennsylvania. The mines are an environmental risk, having leached acid runoff into rivers and streams. (Source: Clean Ocean and Shore Trust)(pg. 32)

HEADLINE: Wanted Now in New York: 3,000 (or 9,000) Teachers

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Forgive Caryl Cohen if she reached for an antacid last week, as talk swirled that bills just passed in Albany may force New York City to hire as many as 6,000 new teachers over the coming year.
Ms. Cohen, who oversees recruitment for the Board of Education, had a more pressing problem: filling the 3,000 teaching positions already open, before the new school year begins three weeks from Wednesday. 
 Despite an intensive recruiting campaign that has met with moderate success -- college seniors were buttonholed in teacher-training programs as far north as Plattsburgh, state-certified teachers across New York were flooded with enticement letters, and subways were plastered with recruitment posters -- the city's public schools will open with hundreds of teachers who have not met state standards and who have never stood in front of a classroom.
In New York City's suburbs, where teacher salaries are generally higher and the classes are smaller than in the five boroughs, there is a glut of qualified applicants for precious few teaching jobs this summer: in Mamaroneck, N.Y., alone, there were nearly 1,000 resumes submitted for seven elementary-school positions.
But in New York City, the schools have gone begging for qualified teachers -- particularly in math, science and bilingual education. And that has left Ms. Cohen wondering where to look to fill the 6,000 jobs that the board estimates would be created by two measures passed by the Legislature in its final days: one to reduce class sizes (an estimated 3,600 jobs over the next 12 months) and another, still awaiting Gov. George E. Pataki's signature, to allow teachers to retire at 55 rather than 62 (an estimated 2,000 jobs, some of which would open immediately).
"I feel we've just about exhausted every available resource, through a multitude of strategies," Ms. Cohen said, her eyes bleary. "If this happens, I don't know where we'll find certified people."
The estimated 3,000 teaching vacancies that must be filled by the start of the new school year are largely the result of retirements, maternity and other leaves, and a projected growth in enrollment of about 18,000 students systemwide -- an increase that, by itself, calls for 600 more teachers.
Many of the vacancies represent the loss of some of the system's most seasoned professionals. But others offer schools a welcome opportunity for a new beginning. About 500 vacancies were created by the dismissal of teachers who had taken more than four years to attain state certification -- passing a state teaching examination and completing concentration of courses in a particular subject area and in the practice of teaching.
Some of the lag in filling the jobs is out of the board's hands. Few college graduates with math and science degrees are choosing to teach, preferring industry or business. And many of the vacancies in bilingual positions reflect the city's burgeoning immigrant enrollment -- and an inability to find teachers who can, for example, speak Haitian-Creole and instruct special-education students.
But part of the problem remains a convoluted bureaucratic system in which teachers are recruited and screened centrally, then interviewed at the local districts (which administer the city's elementary and junior high schools) before being hired, often just days before school begins.
"Teachers would be more willing to come here," said Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, "if they knew what classroom they would be in and could look at the place."
While shortages persist in hard-to-staff specialties and districts, the board can boast some progress this year in recruiting certified teachers -- a perennial challenge in a system where roughly 7,500 of 65,000 teachers lack certification.
Last spring, for the first time, the board held two job fairs at a Manhattan high school, bringing together superintendents from all of the city's community school districts, and many of their principals. The timing was critical: while suburban districts do much of their hiring in the spring, the board had always waited until August, when the burdensome task of surveying the needs of all of its 1,100 schools was nearly complete.
This year, the board felt confident it could better anticipate some of its needs earlier, and sent invitations to the hiring fairs to thousands of teachers who, according to state records, were either about to graduate from teacher-training programs or had not yet found employment. All had been certified by the state.
All told, 2,000 certified teachers attended the sessions, 900 were offered jobs and school officials expect as many as 600 to accept positions, although they have until the day before school begins to decide.
Barbara Baltz of Rye Brook, N.Y., attended a fair and came away impressed. A former human resources administrator at several area companies, she recently received her master's degree in elementary and special education at Manhattanville College, in Purchase, N.Y. Ms. Baltz left the job fair with an offer to teach third-grade special education at a Bronx elementary school, and, she said, she expects to take the job.
"I need to feel comfortable where I am working," said Ms. Baltz, 46. "I really liked the people I met from the school. The special-ed department seems really well organized."
The board also intensified its talent searches this year at colleges and universities in the metropolitan region and upstate, with Ms. Cohen, the director of recruiting, making dozens of personal appearances and netting about 100 applicants.
With a personality that is equal parts cheerleader and used-car saleswoman, Ms. Cohen told seniors graduating from education programs, all of whom had secured certification, that they should not fear for their safety if they choose to teach in New York City (after all, the crime rate is way down), that millions of dollars had been committed to fixing up the classrooms and that the city offered ample opportunities for class field trips to some of the world's greatest museums.
Vincent Ambrosio, 22, who graduated in the spring with an education degree from Ms. Cohen's alma mater, the State University College at Cortland, said her pitch was enough to persuade him to apply for a job teaching high-school English, and he is awaiting word on his placement.
"She said they needed people who care, who want to teach," he recalled. "The straightforward attitude about the whole situation impressed me."
In recent weeks, hundreds of candidates have also responded to advertisements in city newspapers imploring them to "Shape the Future. . . . Teach New York!" and alerting them to September vacancies in subjects like general science, earth science, Spanish, biology and reading.
Many of those who have responded and come down to the board's hiring headquarters, at 65 Court Street in downtown Brooklyn, are certified teachers, but have turned to New York City only as a last resort, when jobs in suburban schools did not materialize.
Ms. Cohen said she was happy to have them anyway.
"You can't blame someone who lives in Suffolk and wants to work in Suffolk," Ms. Cohen said. "If they are qualified, I will take them."
After five years of hanging on in the Mineola, N.Y., public schools, hoping in vain that her part-time job as a reading teacher would become permanent, Jennifer Phillips made the two-hour trip last week to 65 Court Street and applied for a job.
An hour later, Ms. Phillips, who is certified, walked out the door with a referral for placement in an elementary school in Community School District 19 in East New York -- a district she had requested because a friend teaches there and had described "changes going on for the better, like renovations."
Having avoided applying for a New York City job because of "the travel, the commute and the classroom overcrowding," Ms. Phillips said she had ultimately been persuaded by economic reality: "I just got married, bought a house and I need the benefits."
Ms. Cohen says she will have to hire hundreds of candidates who have college degrees, but little or no experience teaching, but at least she has enough candidates so that no classroom will go unsupervised.

HEADLINE: U.P.S. and Union Break Off Negotiations

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Negotiators for the teamsters' union and the United Parcel Service broke off talks yesterday just two hours after returning to the bargaining table, with both sides signaling that they might be digging in for a long strike.
U.P.S. and the union said the talks had broken off indefinitely, dissipating hopes of a quick end to the six-day-old walkout by 185,000 drivers, loaders and sorters. 
 After emerging from the talks at a Federal mediator's office in Washington, James P. Kelly, the chairman of U.P.S., said: "The position of the teamsters continues to be unrealistic. That position does not allow us to compete. We're heading back to Atlanta to make the difficult decisions that we have to make going forward."
The two sides held their brief negotiating session yesterday after they met for a total of 19 hours on Thursday and Friday without reporting significant progress.
Ronald Carey, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said: "At this point it appears it's just senseless to continue any discussions. It's time for us to start digging in."
The two sides do not even agree on what is the main stumbling block to reaching a new contract. U.P.S. officials say it is a dispute over pensions, with the company pushing to set up a new pension plan and pull out of the teamsters' multi-employer plan. But the union insists that the main obstacle is the company's refusal to turn more part-time jobs into full-time ones. The union complains that part-timers do not earn enough to support a family.
"This issue is vital not just for teamsters and their families, but for every American family," Mr. Carey said. "Part-time America won't work."
Officials close to the talks said the negotiators spent 21 hours at the bargaining table over the last three days explaining and defending their positions and feeling each other out for how the two sides might barter items -- the company might abandon one of its demands if the union did likewise. These officials said the negotiators had made some progress on minor points but remained far from an overall package.
"This is the biggest strike in our nation in a quarter century," said John Calhoun Wells, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. "There are issues of enormous complexity."
Assessing the likelihood of a settlement, he said, "It ain't going to happen overnight."
With the talks broken off, the union vowed to rally the public behind it, saying that millions of Americans identify with its concerns that U.P.S., the world's largest shipping company, should not create so many part-time jobs. Over the past four years, U.P.S. has added 46,000 unionized workers: 38,000 part-timers and 8,000 full-timers. Part-time workers average $9 to $10 an hour after two years, while full-timers average $19.95.
At baseball stadiums this weekend, union members are distributing thousands of score cards that say the teamsters are fighting for full-time jobs. The union also plans a big rally on Wednesday in Liberty State Park in Jersey City, and another large rally outside U.P.S. headquarters in Atlanta on Thursday.
Before the talks resumed yesterday, Mr. Carey said: "If the company is prepared to move, I'll be here until tomorrow morning. If they're not, we've got work to do. We've got to get out there and get together with the members."
U.P.S. said it was sticking with what it called its "last, best and final offer," one that called for a 1.5 percent raise a year for full-time workers and a $3,060 bonus this year. Under the company's proposal, a part-time worker who started at $8 an hour would earn $10.50 after five years and get a $1,530 bonus.
"We continue to believe we made a very good offer," said Gina Ellrich, a U.P.S. spokeswoman.
The union faults the company's proposal because it would not raise the part-timers' starting wage, which has not risen since 1982.
After the talks broke up yesterday, Mr. Kelly seemed to leave open the door to hiring temporary or replacement workers, a practice that would certainly step up pressure on the union.
"We're willing to do whatever it takes to keep our business strong and provide security for our people," he said.
U.P.S. officials acknowledge that the strike has paralyzed their operations, reducing their daily volume to less than 10 percent of the 12 million packages the company handles on an average day. The company is urging President Clinton to seek an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act to halt the strike on the ground that it is causing severe economic damage.
But Mr. Clinton said at a news conference on Wednesday that the Taft-Hartley Act sets a high standard for Presidential intervention and that the strike was not yet imperiling the nation's safety or health.
In recent days, teamster leaders have sent urgent letters to hundreds of union halls telling them to be prepared for a long strike. Teamster officials say the company might think that the strikers cannot weather a long walkout because the union's strike fund is nearly depleted, but union officials insist that members can withstand a protracted walkout.
The two sides also have differences over pay, subcontracting and the company's demand to delete a provision from the old contract that allowed U.P.S. drivers to honor other unions' picket lines.
Indicating a hardening of positions, Rand Wilson, a teamsters' spokesman, said, "It's clear that full-time jobs and the other issues that teamster members want to see addressed are to be won on the picket lines and in the community, not at the negotiating table."

HEADLINE: Deeper Shade of Blue Collar

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Until now, almost every strike that has commanded the nation's attention has involved organized labor's high-paid elite: the four-month steel strike in 1959 involving 650,000 workers, the two-month General Motors walkout of 1970, the air controllers' strike of 1981 and the unpopular baseball players' strike of 1994. But the week-old walkout at the United Parcel Service is the first strike to capture the national spotlight that involves labor's lower castes, in this case part-time parcel sorters and truck loaders who earn about $10,000 a year.
This high-visibility walkout by 185,000 teamsters reflects not just deep changes in the makeup of the labor force and the labor movement but also a profound shift in the focus of organized labor. Labor has now directed its attention to lifting up those at the bottom of the heap, like janitors, supermarket clerks, hotel maids, farm workers and even workfare participants. 
 This new focus is in part a natural response to underlying changes in the work force: The number of manufacturing jobs is stagnant, and the number of service-sector jobs, especially low-wage ones, has mushroomed. Organized labor is concentrating on the low-wage sector because that is where so many workers are. The shift in focus also reflects the vision of John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., who brings to his job deeply held Roman Catholic beliefs about the importance of helping the humble and meek. He climbed to the top of the labor movement after heading the service employees' union, which used strikes, sit-ins and slogans like "Justice for Janitors" to win higher pay for low-wage workers.
Mr. Sweeney, to be sure, recognizes that helping those on the bottom rungs makes not just moral sense but strategic sense in his crusade to reverse labor's decades-long slide. Those at the bottom are, understandably, often the most receptive audience to labor's appeals. And unions stand a better chance of winning public sympathy and of becoming a broad social movement, one of Mr. Sweeney's goals, if they focus on assisting low-paid nurses' aides or truck loaders instead of labor's elite.
Organized labor no doubt lost a lot of sympathy when baseball players making $2 million a year paralyzed America's pastime and broke children's hearts while uttering Samuel Gompers's famous motto: More. The U.P.S. strike is not about winning $50,000 more a year for pampered workers but about full-time jobs and better wages for the $9-an-hour part-timers who sort 2,000 parcels an hour or load several tons of goods into a truck each three-hour shift.
The U.P.S. strike, said Richard Hurd, a professor of labor relations at Cornell University, "resonates with a large segment of our society that is concerned that corporations have reduced their commitment to their workers, that they're doing too much downsizing and using too much contingent labor and temporary agencies."
The U.P.S. showdown dovetails neatly with Mr. Sweeney's vision and strategy, and it is no coincidence that he pledged as much of labor's energy and resources as it takes to make sure the teamsters win.
U.P.S. argues that it makes sense to hire so many part-timers -- four-fifths of the 46,000 unionized workers it has added since 1993 are part-timers -- because it needs flexibility and because much of its work comes in three-hour bursts. U.P.S. officials argue that because their full-time drivers are the best paid in the industry, the company needs lower-wage part-timers to compete with nonunion shippers like Federal Express. At U.P.S., full-time drivers earn $19.95 an hour after two years, while part-time sorters earn $10 an hour and part-time loaders, $9 an hour.
"If the teamsters win," said Stanley Aronowitz, a sociology professor at the City University of New York, "it's going to send a signal to the rest of the labor movement that you can succeed in fighting for low-wage and part-time workers. It will fulfill John Sweeney's commitment that 'America needs a raise' in a way that any salary increase for pilots or auto workers cannot."
There is another reason unions are focusing more on low-wage service jobs and less on high-paid manufacturing, the one-time stronghold that gave labor its swagger but whose workers now account for only 17 percent of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s 13 million members, down from 46 percent three decades ago.
Labor leaders see that when they try to organize, say, an apparel factory or an electronics factory, the workers often vote against unionizing because they fear the employer will close the plant or move it to Mexico if the union is victorious.
And when the union wins, employers often do move operations to Mexico or other low-wage countries, causing union leaders to question why they spent thousands of hours and dollars on an organizing drive. Labor leaders often say one reason they are focusing on organizing workers in supermarkets, hotels and hospitals is that those operations cannot jump south of the border.
"There's hardly anything going on in organizing manufacturing," Professor Aronowitz said. "In manufacturing, you organize a factory, and a day later it goes away."
In many ways, labor's focus on low-paid employees is a big gamble. Employers often find these workers easy to intimidate. And many cannot afford to weather a strike.
"This is the wrong approach from a historical standpoint," said Leo Troy, an economics professor at Rutgers University. "Organized labor always focused on the better-paid workers. Low-paid workers have a higher turnover. They are often low-productivity workers, and it doesn't make much economic sense for the employer to raise their wages."
But Professor Hurd said the new focus made sense. "There is a recognition in the A.F.L.-C.I.O.," he said, "that if you want to change the image and the appeal of labor, it's necessary to change what it's fighting for. Working on behalf of low-wage workers certainly fits into that."

HEADLINE: Health Care Law Shows Big Government Lives;
No Increase in Uninsured

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Douglas J. Besharov (Op-Ed, Aug. 5) cites only one of four studies examining whether public insurance "crowds out" private insurance. 
 In contrast to the cited article, the three other studies show that previous expansions of Federal health insurance decreased the number of uninsured poor and near-poor children. Furthermore, there was little switching from private to public insurance.
More important, the social costs associated with the absence of health insurance motivate government action to correct the private sector's failure to consider these costs.
Mr. Besharov disguises a political argument with a scientific veneer. If he wanted to make a scientific argument, he might have noted that there is little empirical evidence showing that insurance improves children's health.
 
ROBERT KAESTNER
ESEL YAZICI
New York, Aug. 5, 1997
 
The writers are, respectively, an associate professor of public affairs at Baruch College and a Ph.D. candidate in economics at CUNY.

HEADLINE: Health Care Law Shows Big Government Lives;
Congress Should Act

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Douglas J. Besharov (Op-Ed, Aug. 5) complains that even in this "hot" economy, business will respond to public health insurance for children by eliminating benefits for the children of low-paid workers. 
 This problem has a straightforward solution.
That is for Congress not only to establish a minimum wage sufficient to raise a family but also to require that every employer provide children's health benefits that meet the preventive health standards set out by the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Government's objectives for the year 2000.
 
THOMAS K. GILHOOL
Philadelphia, Aug. 5, 1997

HEADLINE: ART;
Giacometti, Haiti in Norwalk

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
WHEN reviewing two shows in the same article, art writers will usually try to cleverly make the transition from one to the other. Sometimes the best transition is no transition, for there is little linking the graphic work of Alberto Giacometti and a raft of paintings from Haiti. The bond between them is that they are complete opposites, but the city of Norwalk is big enough to hold them both.
The Giacometti prints are lithographs plus a few etchings at Connecticut Graphic Arts Center. They come from the collection of Herbert C. Lust of Greenwich, who knew Giacometti well from 1949 until his death in 1966, and from the collection of Judith and Stephen Wertheimer, also of Greenwich. Viewers will find that the Swiss artist's graphics are as austere as the tall thin sculptures that are his major work. 
 Mr. Lust, who has written the definitive catalogue of Giacometti's prints and drawings, contends that it wasn't until 1954 that Giacometti emerged as a major graphic artist. Several etchings, particularly the 1934 "State For: Andre Breton," subtitled in the confounding way of Surrealism, "L'Air de L'eau," are reminders of Giacometti's Surrealist beginnings. In the lithographs from the mid-1950's, though, he emerges as established and comfortable in his characteristic idiom. His black lithography crayon seems almost to be self-directed. Its meanderings resemble nothing so much as an unraveling ball of yarn that somehow makes pictures with a precise descriptions of objects.
In a lithograph like "Studio II" Giacometti describes an inventive artist's requisite paraphernalia, and his line's tendency to tangle is appropriate for this. When some of Giacometti's sculptures show up in a work it's a matter of art about art. In "Studio" two sculptures are readily seen, especially a tall one making histrionic gestures.
But signs of sculpture aren't as sought after by viewers as are two animals, appearing in such works as "Head of a Cat," and "Dog, Cat Picture." It is the dog alone in "Studio II." The dog is a lean Afghan often drawn with its head lowered, while the cat is pluckier. The presence of these animals does much to ingratiate Giacometti with viewers; the artist becomes less remote. It is said that Giacometti was once asked if his house were burning and he had to choose between saving a Picasso or his cat, which would it be? Some of the lithographs confirm the creatures as animating spirits.
Full-fledged human figures often appear, doing ordinary things. In this respect Giacometti might be in the tradition of Pierre Bonnard, ennobling the commonplace. It's interesting that the lithograph of a man evidently reading at a desk under a chandelier is titled after the fixture, not the person. With the chandelier, Giacometti had the chance to draw a complex and voluminous piece of sculpture.
Two specially spare lithographs of heads are especially powerful in conveying solitariness. Giacometti's mature work has been called an embodiment of existentialism, but he also seems to be allied with Edward Hopper, who at the same time was also exploring isolation.
"The Evolution of Haitian Art in the Twentieth Century" is the ambitious title of an exhibition of 50 paintings packed into the art gallery at Norwalk Community-Technical College. Surveying the show, viewers can see a lot of change but nothing like a discernible evolution. After all this is essentially folk art, prized for staying true to its roots. In fact the evidence of the show might be to illustrate that a retrenchment is occurring. As a group, the older painters in this survey are livelier than many of their younger counterparts, who seem to be caught up in a unimaginative academic mode.
Viewers are better off forgetting about tracing development of a national style, and concentrate instead on individual sensibilities, many of which are fantastic. Prefitte Duffaut, for instance, conjures a couple of "imaginary cities" built on a futurist-like zigzag pattern and peopled with scores of ciphers standing for humans. The number of these abstract marks swells enormously in the third painting, "Exodus," in which the city is being emptied.
But most of the paintings tap traditional themes. The marketplace persists as a symbol of normality and relative abundance in paintings by Gary Rochebrun, Simeon Victor and Jean Masden Gilles. The jungle is an occasion for wildness and color, and Jackson Charlot's "Jungle" is full of animals huddled together in a kind of peaceable kingdom. Wilson Bigaud uses the jungle as a setting for his version of Eden. Viewers scanning this enormous bountiful earthly paradise may feel regret that the first couple had to give up all that. Patrice Piard and Yves Rigaud display an ability to paint nocturnes, which adds mystery to what should be ordinary, as in Mr. Rigaud's "Dancing at Moonlight." The harsh light from candle flames helps.
Some rueful paintings should be expected, given Haiti's wrenching political history. Haitian painters usually don't render political subjects directly, but rather show the effect of politics reflected in ordinary lives. In this show, Yveson Celadon fills the cynicism bill but hysterically. One of his paintings is bluntly called "Among Crazy People." In it a young married couple clinging to each other is surrounded by family members portrayed as snarling beasts in street clothing. But viewers may be distracted by incidental images such as a comical-looking bird perched proudly on an expensive-looking watch.
The exhibition is sponsored by the Norwalk Community-Technical College Haitian-American Student Association, and Haiti Beyond 2000 Inc., based in Fairfield, which is devoted to economic development in Haiti.
The Giacometti prints are on view through Aug. 30; the show of Haitian paintings closes Aug. 20.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Studio II," 1954 lithograph by Giacometti, on view at the Connecticut Graphic Arts Center. Above: "Marketplace," Jean Madsen Giles. Left: "Dancing at Moonlight," Yves Rigaud.
