HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Hiram Chirel;
Foot Doctors Try to Ease Pain of H.M.O.'s

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
HIRAM CHIREL is executive director of the 1,400-member New York State Podiatric Medical Association, the nation's largest state organization of foot specialists. In February the group voted to join the nation's first labor union for doctors, the First National Guild for Health Care Providers of the Lower Extremities. The move is an attempt to increase their influence against what the doctors see as restrictive rules imposed by managed care associations. Dr. Chirel, 66, was a president and board member of the medical association before becoming its executive director. He received his Doctor of Podiatric Medicine degree in 1956 from the New York College of Podiatric Medicine, and served on the faculty there as well as at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Dr. Chirel and his wife, Elba, also a podiatric physician and who is president of the Nassau County Podiatric Medical Association, live in Port Washington. They have two grown children.
Q. The idea of doctors becoming unionized seems kind of strange. 
A. Traditionally, unions have been for employees, not employers. But situations have occurred in the health care delivery system and we are trying to find some other avenue for accomplishing some of the things we are trying to do.
Q. What are you referring to?
A. The H.M.O.'s, health maintenance organizations, whose whole objective is to reduce the cost of health care. However, in order to reduce cost, they reduced the number of health care providers and benefits to subscribers because most of them set up what is called a gatekeeper system. In order for the patient to go to a specialist, he has to go to the gatekeeper first. The gatekeeper has a financial incentive not to refer. So what is happening is that there are less referrals than before.
Q. The gatekeeper is the primary care physician.
A. That's correct.
Q. And he has a financial interest not to refer to specialists?
A. The H.M.O.'s withhold 10 or 15 percent of his fee and it goes into a pot. If he does a lot of referrals -- and they figure it has cost them more money because of all those referrals -- he's not going to get it back. If he's a nice guy and he doesn't do a lot of referrals, he is going to get that money back. So that's the incentive not to refer.
Q. How much are we talking about?
A. It could be a couple of hundred thousand dollars a year.
Q. Is that across the board with all of the H.M.O.'s or just a few?
A. Most of them have a gatekeeper and most of them have the withhold, which is financial protection for them at the end of the year. The H.M.O.'s are big business in the United States. In order for the H.M.O.'s to make money, there are two people they can squeeze -- the provider, by cutting down the reimbursement to them, and the patient, by not giving them the care they ordinarily would get if they were in an imdemnity plan where they could go to any provider they chose. So the finest health care system we had years ago is slowly deteriorating.
Q. How competent are the primary care physicians to handle problems that used to be handled by specialists?
A. In many instances, the primary care physician doesn't know what he's talking about. That's why specialists developed in this country, because they are more qualified to treat specific conditions of podiatry.
Q. Are all of your members in H.M.O.'s?
A. No, about 20 to 30 percent were not taken in to any H.M.O. So the patient who was seeing a doctor regularly in the past can't continue to go to him.
Q. Why were some podiatrists excluded from H.M.O. panels?
A. One of the ways H.M.O.'s keep costs down is to limit the number of doctors in the panel. So it becomes more difficult to see a doctor.
Q. How do the H.M.O.'s go about determining which doctors to accept in their panel? Is it based on the quality of the physician?
A. That's what they would like you to believe. They have certain criteria that really don't hold water. You may be a great doctor but not meet their criteria. There may be somebody who is a poor doctor who meets the criteria..
Q. If there is a gatekeeper handling referrals, why not add all specialists to the panel?
A. By limiting the number of specialists, those in the H.M.O. will become very busy and you may have to wait two months to see a doctor. In that way the H.M.O.'s are limiting the number of patients who can come into the office. And they have established a fee that in most cases is less than what the specialist was accepting before. The doctor accepts it because he is afraid he will lose patients.
Q. What about patients who do not belong to an H.M.O.?
A. Somebody was telling me yesterday that he called his internist to make an appointment. The nurse said the doctor couldn't see him for a month. When he told her that he was a paying patient who did not belong to an H.M.O., she said, "When would you like to come in, this morning or this afternoon?"
Q. What is the difference between what the H.M.O. will pay the doctor and his normal fee?
A. Fifty percent.
Q. Of podiatrists in H.M.O.'s, what percentage of their patients come from primary care physicians?
A. In New York State, there has been quite a proliferation of H.M.O.'s in the last two years. So I would say that probably 50 or 60 percent of their patients come from H.M.Os.
Q. What has happened to the practice of some podiatrists?
A. I've had some members call me and say they used to see 120 patients a week; now they see 20. Some podiatrists are actually going out of practice because they cannot economically make it.
Q. What percentage of your membership has come to that conclusion?
A. The 20 percent who are not included in the H.M.O.'s are being forced to drastically curtail their practice or close the door.
Q. And what about those who are included?
A. It's happening to the M.D.'s too. I'm not crying for them, but they are having to work harder to maintain the volume that they had before in terms of dollars. Their income has been reduced and they see more patients because of it.
Q. So they have to see twice as many patients because the reimbursement rate is cut in half?
A. More or less.
Q. Are the H.M.O.'s saying there are too many podiatrists out there and this is a way to weed them out?
A. Yes, and many other specialists are in the same position.
Q. Is there something wrong with that?
A. In a number of years from now, I don't know how many, there are not going to be that many specialists and we're just going to rotate back to where we were before and there won't be anybody here to properly use the diagnostic machines.
Q. How did the union idea come about?
A. In the United States we have the American Podiatric Medical Association, which is the umbrella organization, and each state has its own chapters. Each decided individually whether it would join the union. It's not really a union, it's a guild. So far 17 states have signed up.
Q. What are you hoping the union will do for you?
A. We're looking for the union to help us legislatively to correct some of the problems that have occurred.
Q. The association could have hired lobbyists, why was the guild necessary?
A. We have our own lobbyists, of course, but our union lobbyist represents us in New York State, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. union lobbyist represents 2.5 million members, plus their families. So politically they represent a large number of voters.
Q. How has Medicare been affected?
A. It has contracted with some H.M.O.'s to allow them to sign up Medicare patients. It's become a contest with some of the H.M.O.'s to see how fast they can sign up Medicare patients. So they have breakfasts for Medicare beneficiaries and explain to them that if they sign up with them, there won't be any out-of-pocket expenses for them. Now, if a doctor were to tell a Medicare patient you don't have to pay me the co-insurance and deductible, they could go to jail. But with these H.M.O.'s, they are forgoing the co-insurance and the deductible. So now the same thing happens in which the patient cannot see the doctor that he has seen for years.
Q. Have there been cases in which a patient has suffered needlessly because he was not referred to a podiatrist?
A. Yes, we had instances in which the primary care physician has prescribed antibiotics for severe infections in the toe when the patient really needed a surgical correction. Only after playing with it for a couple of visits and getting nowhere is the patient sent out. And you've heard stories like the one in California where a patient who had cancer was not referred out until it was too late. It doesn't happen every day, but patients are not being referred because the primary care physician has an incentive not to refer him.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Hiram Chirel heads a podiatric group that has voted to join a labor union for doctors. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON THE SOUND: Mary Parker Buckles;
Quest for the Spirit of L.I. Sound

BYLINE: By MARJORIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
"I AM absolutely a muck nut," Mary Parker Buckles said as she picked her way through grasses, sand and rock near Long Island Sound.
Mrs. Buckles said she had found an antidote to the stresses of the modern world -- developing a relationship with intertidal zones. 
 "There is beauty to be discovered in this waterscape, beauty that can renew us like the mountains and contain us like the sea," she said. "In addition to being a place and a process, it is a metaphor for a state of mind. An ambiguity itself, it is a model for the human tolerance of ambiguities."
A book by Mrs. Buckles, "Margins" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), is an idiosyncratic appreciation of the Sound. The premise for "Margins," she said on a visit to Glen Cove, was as much a spiritual quest as a "physical chase."
Her concern, she added, was not to provide information on sewage and oxygen problems, but to contribute an intimate perspective for understanding the ecosystem to celebrate what is worth saving.
"The Long Island Sound is not dead," Mrs. Buckles said. "Today's Long Island Sound is probably as clean for swimming and for harvesting seafood cautiously as it has been at any time in the 20th century."
On a walk along the shore Mrs. Buckles discussed the life just below the surface that provides clues to the importance of the Sound. "Becoming aware of the coming and going of the tides are as useful as learning to use a watch or a calendar," she said. "They have changed my life, made me less rigid. They have taught me about the importance of fluidity and constant change."
The technical director of the Long Island Sound Study for the Environmental Protection Agency, Mark A. Tedesco, agreed that the Sound was at its cleanest in 50 years.
The study, Mr. Tedesco said, aims for a regional focus, with assistance from environmental and other groups, including governments, to reduce the nitrogen in the water. Excess nitrogen causes algae blooms.
Mrs. Buckles, who is not a scientist, a boater or a swimmer, said she based her observations on years of curiosity, patience and a fascination with details. She is intrigued by medicinal research that involves horseshoe crabs, and she observes shorebirds and lunar gravity.
Mrs. Buckles has a love of music that she links to her career as a naturalist. Between observing ospreys and fiddler crabs, she performs at Carnegie Hall as a member of the New York Choral Society.
To Mrs. Buckles there is a connection between the rhythm of the tides and jazz. "Salt tides' embrace of the land's margins and the land's acceptance of that advance tap out a beat on the globe, a 'MON-day' rhythm played against a 'SUN-day' time," she said. "The mix is jazz, like the syncopation of our own breaths and heartbeats. It rewards careful listening. And the voice heard above it in the wing beat of swans, in the kingfisher's rant and the gull's cry is the ancient voice of flux, forever new."
Mrs. Buckles was born in Jackson, Miss. Her father, Carter Harmon, was a biologist and a photographer, and her mother, an avid gardener. After graduating from Millsaps College in Jackson, she met her husband, an economist, while they were graduate students at Vanderbilt University in Nashville.
Arriving in New York City, she was an educational writer and editor for the National Audubon Society. To ease the transition to city life, she said, she hauled in dirt from New Jersey for a roof garden for Southern vegetables.
Her position at the Audubon Society fostered her career as a naturalist and led to the publication of three books on natural history, including a children's primer on mammals.
The book, "The Flowers Around Us," a photographic essay on their reproductive structures, was a collaboration with her father that was published in 1985, a few years after he died.
"That book was most like 'Margins' in the personal text that I wrote to accompany my father's photographs," she said.
When she settled in 1989 in a cottage along the coast in Darien, Conn., she began a journal about her new environment. "Though I didn't grow up on the water I've always been drawn to it."
Searching bookstores and libraries for information about the Sound, she recalled, she found little aside from social and commercial history combined with geology. Gradually her impressions and discoveries became the basis for her book.
Her collection of essays is meant as a tribute. "Love letters," they are divided into four life zones, land, air, water and intertidal zones.
Filled with literary references from nature writers, poets and musicians, the book says, "The sea and the marsh are one," as Sidney Lanier, a Southern poet, wrote. Memorizing Mr. Lanier's poem "The Marshes of Glynn" was mandatory for high school students in the South in the 1950's, she said.
"Mr. Lanier perceived that the entire marshlands-tidewater ecosystem is the moist yin and yang of a process, as well as a place, a mutual embrace and interchange," she said.
A review in The New York Times Book Review said the book was "essentially a tribute," adding that Mrs. Buckles "reacts with a delightful mix of elation and deprivation."
"She sees our obligation not so much to be worthy of it as to love and nurture it, and to infuse it with a human music that makes it perennially fresh," the review said.
Mrs. Buckles will be reading and signing on Friday at the Barnes & Noble bookstore in Huntington and on Saturday at the Garvies Point Museum and Natural Preserve in Glen Cove.
The museum, which celebrated its 30th anniversary last month, is on land occupied by the Matinecock Indians as early as 2500 B.C. It was purchased as part of a larger tract of land in 1668. Later 62 acres became part of the estate by Dr. Thomas Garvie, who emigrated from Scotland in 1803.
The museum has permanent exhibitions on regional geology and Indian archeology and offers many programs for schoolchildren. The preserve has five miles of marked trails, including one for people with sight problems.
It is also the new Long Island branch headquarters for Save the Sound, founded in 1972 as a bistate organization to protect, restore and appreciate the Sound.
Mrs. Buckles has developed what she calls "crab eyes," an ability to spot a male fiddler crab from afar simply by locating his pale lure.
Her descriptions of birds are inspired by a friend and mentor, Roland Clement, former vice president of the Audubon Society.
Inspiration also came from a Gulf Coast artist, Walter Anderson, who recorded the gulf's intricate life through line drawings and watercolors.
Mrs. Buckles recalled visiting his widow at his home. The house was filled with shells, bones and natural objects, and she returned with a keen appreciation for his passion.
Mrs. Buckles said she hoped that "Margins" would be a catalyst for others to celebrate the Sound. Hers is one written attempt, she said, to relate the discovery of "snails and webbed feet and granite, of tentacles and feathers and mud and clouds with more than 100 miles of salty liquid in a way that guides the reader into what Walter Anderson once described as a 'constant state of applause' for the natural world."
"In this way," she said, "the work is about both science and magic. But it is about belief first."

(Photograph by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)(pg. 1); Mary Parker Buckles has spent years studying the flora and fauna of the Sound, which she says has affected her life. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)(pg. 4)

HEADLINE: A Handmade Boat Meant for Everyone

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
NEVER mind that it's downtown Hartford, right out in the open with the Old State House as a backdrop and the towering Fleet Bank building right across the street; more than a dozen teen-agers have been building a boat. And this week, after applying some finishing touches to the 32-footer and painting it blue, members of the Riverfront Rangers program will launch the vessel and take it out for a cruise on the Connecticut River.
"After all this work, I just hope it doesn't sink," said 14-year-old Damion Campbell, who will be a freshman this fall at Prince Tech High School in Hartford. "It's been great learning how to measure things and use all these tools. Now I just hope it stays afloat." 
 Seventeen-year-old Jamaa Parks said that when he applied to the city for a summer job he figured on being hired for some kind of parks or recreation program.
What he never imagined was being among a group of young people -- most of whom had never even been on a boat -- assigned to build one in the middle of the state capital. "This is probably the last thing I thought I would be doing this summer, but it's been really cool, one of the best experiences I've had," said Mr. Parks, who will be a junior this year at Bulkeley High School in Hartford. "It's been a lot of fun working with the other kids, but I never knew that building a boat was such hard work."
The work -- which involves measuring, calculating, sawing, drilling, sanding and painting 30 hours a week -- is all part of the Rangers program sponsored by Riverfront Recapture, a nonprofit organization leading a $35 million project to improve the quality of the Connecticut River and re-establish it as a vital economic and recreational resource for the greater Hartford area.
The group, which has been working for 16 years to develop a network of riverfront parks and public recreational centers, is also trying to create a regional park system that will combine the efforts of four riverfront towns: Hartford, East Hartford, Wethersfield and Windsor.
The summer boat-building project, which pays $5.25 an hour, is designed to give young people practical work and job training, while at the same time providing the city with a fleet of vessels for recreational events such as its community rowing program.
Boat-building also offers lessons about the city's rich navigation history. "This opens up inner-city kids to an adventure they never thought they would have," said David Gilroy, an amateur boat-builder who is overseeing the project. "They also get job training skills that they'll be able to use for the rest of their lives, and maybe most important of all, learn how to work together as a team."
Mr. Gilroy, a psychotherapist with a "compelling fascination" for boats, said that "this is a program that encourages these kids to go after their dreams, to do something they might have thought impossible."
He said that building the type of boat that was once common in Colonial America also helps to bring the city's waterway history alive, much more than any classroom lesson or description in a book.
"These are the kinds of boats used to carry passengers and freight up and down the waterways," Mr. Gilroy said. "They were the main mode of transportation in those days -- kind of like the pickup trucks of their time. I think that working to create that kind of boat, and then actually taking it out on the river is a tremendously valuable teaching tool."
But it is the tools of the boat-builder's trade that make the biggest impression on the students.
Joey Texidor, 16 and soon to be a sophomore at Wethersfield High School, he lined up two long wooden planks alongside the hull. As an aspiring architect, he said the training he's getting this summer is more valuable to him than anything he's ever learned in a classroom. He also likes the attention from a steady stream of downtown workers and passersby. "It's really cool," he said, "because people walk by and are curious about what we're doing out here and it's a great feeling to explain that we're doing it for the city, that the boat is for everyone."
Paul Birchette, 15, who will be a junior this year at Bulkeley High, said the program has been a good training ground for him, too, because he wants to be a carpenter. But when he first heard about building a boat, he wasn't so sure. "I thought at first that it might be kind of boring. But was I ever wrong about that!" he said, "I've learned a lot that I'll be able to use someday, and it's been a great way to spend the summer -- a lot better than just hanging out on the streets doing nothing. And it's nice to be making some money too."
Jessica Santiago, 15, agreed with that. "I like the idea that I'm actually learning how to build a boat," she said. "It's something I'll be able to tell my kids about someday."
Mr. Gilroy, along with his professional boat-building assistants, said the toughest part is "convincing these kids that they can build a boat -- and that it won't sink."
"They're very skeptical at first whether they can really transform all these piles of wood and nails into a real boat that will stay afloat in the water," said 31-year-old Andres Bermudez, a professional boat builder who has tried to instill in the students a feeling of pride in creating something of artistic and practical value.
"What we try to stress to them is patience and as the weeks go by and it really starts looking like a boat -- they gain a lot of confidence and become very dedicated," he said. "By the time we're finished, they realize that it feels good to have accomplished something that will last for years to come."
Craig Mergins, director of programs and operations for Riverfront Recapture Inc., said "It's an amazing process to watch these kids learn how to build a boat from absolutely nothing and with absolutely no experience. Most of them have never even been on a boat before and here they are building one that the city will be able to use for a long time."
Joseph Marfuggi, executive director of Riverfront Recapture Inc., added, "We're not expected to create a new generation of boat builders -- but what we are helping to create is a generation of teen-agers who know how to work with tools and with each other." The public site of the project was carefully selected, he said, to showcase the students' work.
"Here we have a rare opportunity for suburban people who work in the city stopping by to talk to urban kids, which gives both groups a chance to understand each other better," said Mr. Marfuggi, adding that "It is especially empowering for the kids as they explain details of the project."
Many downtown office workers said that at first they were amused, but then very much impressed as they watched the boat take shape.
"I would buy the boat myself if it were for sale," said Ronald Kiley, an insurance company sales representative who calls boating his most passionate hobby. "Every day I pass by there and watch the progress they're making -- and it's truly astounding to me that these inexperienced kids are doing such a good job. It's not easy to steer a boat, let alone build one."
A Bulkeley High School senior, Anthony Almedina, 18, agreed that the project has drawn a lot of attention downtown.
"People ask what we're doing all the time and it's a good feeling to tell them about it," said Mr. Almedina, who added that while he had hoped for a summer job in an air-conditioned office, "working out here in the sunshine building a boat in the middle of the city was probably the next-best thing."

David Rodriguez gets up close and personal with a saw. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1024 words

HEADLINE: Strong Economy Leads to Land-Sales Boom

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
THE current demand for land in Westchester is unlike anything seen in the region in many years, brokers and developers involved in land sales say.
"By contrast to the early 90's when no one was buying and land was literally lying fallow, this market is just amazing," said Ebie Wood, a regional vice president of Houlihan/ Lawrence real estate. 
 Ms. Wood, who oversees the company's offices across northern Westchester, said vacant land in the region, including individual lots and large parcels, are selling at an unprecedented rate.
"For example, take Rock Rim Ponds in Pound Ridge," she said, "one of the last rural enclaves of 266 acres, comprising 52 home sites ranging in size from 3 to 12 acres, selling from $250,000 to $400,000: it has been thoughtfully developed, preserving the intrinsic character of the land."
She continued: "In 1996 we closed on 5 parcels at Rock Rim, but during the first six months of this year, we have already sold 5 parcels, and 10 sales are pending."
Overall, land sales in the northeast corner of the county totaled 72 last year. This year, 50 land sales were recorded in the first six months. "And an additional 15 sales are pending in our one office alone," Ms. Wood said.
The land rush is directly tied to the economy. "With a strong economy, buyers become future oriented," she said. "In the early 90's, the economy made them apprehensive about making long-term commitments. Today, people seem to have no qualms about building a custom house, which won't be completed for eight to nine months down the road."
The buyers, Ms. Wood said, are "affluent, Wall Street types in the 35-to-45-age range, very specific and savvy" about what they want. "For most, it's their first house, and they want quality," she added.
Environmental awareness is a big part of today's land buyers' outlook, with developers responding by "treating the land with respect," she said.
Rock Rim Ponds, for one, won the American Nurseryman's Award for environmental landscaping, Ms. Wood said.
In Waccabuc on Rock Shelter Road, a new offering of 21 parcels on 100 acres recently came on the market after 10 years of navigating through a sea of local and state environmental regulations.
"It is almost impossible for anybody to win environmental approval to subdivide anything," said John Ciardullo, a partner in the project. "The process in New York State is abstruse."
Mr. Ciardullo, an architect with a successful business in Manhattan, said he and his partner, Arthur Samberg, originally bought the land simply because it was so beautiful.
"Land like this is finite," he said. "When it's gone, you can't make more. The vision I had was very simple: we would do a subdivision that didn't look like a typical subdivision but one that blended into the land, preserving the stone walls, mature trees and the rock outcroppings."
Now, 10 years later, Mr. Ciardullo has found there is a large market for old stone walls, rock outcroppings and narrow, meandering roads.
"There has been a tremendous interest from all types of potential buyers," he said. "Wacabbuc is an affluent, prestigious community, extremely desirable to a lot of people."
Four-acre parcels are selling for $300,000 to $350,000. "We're building a model on one of them to show buyers what we can offer them, a custom house designed by an architect, built on the lot of their choice," Mr. Ciardullo said, adding that buyers can also engage their own architect or builder, subject to approval.
Single parcels of land in northern Westchester are still available, ranging from modest building lots that meet minimum zoning requirements to extraordinary parcels like Cross Winds in Pound Ridge, a spread of 212 acres, which includes a 9-acre lake, being marketed in its entirety at $5.75 million.
In southern Westchester the situation is very different. Even single parcels of land have all but disappeared there.
"Land is at a premium and so scarce that a good lot in the estate area of Scarsdale will fetch almost $1 million," observed Mary Ellen Tolan, branch manager of the Houlihan/Lawrence office in Scarsdale.
Scarcity of land has created a new phenomenon, the demolition derby.
"What is happening is that buyers will find a 40's or 50's so-so house on a beautiful piece of land in a neighborhood they like," Ms. Tolan said. "They buy it, only to demolish it and build a house from the ground up on the lot. Believe it or not, it usually costs less than extensive renovating."
In areas like the Fox Meadow section of Scarsdale, with quarter-acre zoning, Ms. Tolan said land is being subdivided from an existing parcel and sold to builders.
"Some owners go so far as to remove a porch on an existing house in order to portion off the land," she said. "In one case, a large old Tudor, on an acre, was torn down and two houses were built in its place."
Buying a house for demolition is not as outrageous as it appears if the land and location warrant it, Ms. Wood said.
"In the Guard Hill estate area of Bedford, for example, a modest house on beautiful land with fabulous views was razed, not remodeled. In its place is a beautiful carriage house built on speculation by Glazer Builders of New Caanan who are offering it at slightly over $3 million."
Louise and Joseph Paolicelli, who live in East Northport on Long Island, are about to go to contract for a parcel of land at Rock Rim Ponds.
"We started by looking at houses and land on Long Island, and when we didn't find what we liked we came to Westchester," Mrs. Paolicelli said. "We found it to be much more rural. The land we bought is beautiful, unspoiled. We're very excited and hope to be in our new house a year from now. Rock Rim doesn't look like a subdivision. In a few years the houses should look as if they've been here forever."
The Paolicellis are typical of Rock Rim Ponds buyers, said John Gutleber, president of Castagna Realty, the developer.
"The dearth of residential properties has helped create a strong market for us," he said. "When people can't find an existing house they really like, they buy some land and build exactly what they want."

HEADLINE: Mall Site Receives Approval

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WITH news that the Common Council here gave the nod to yet another shopping mall late last month, hope grew that this central Westchester municipality would once again live up to an earlier nickname.
Once touted as the City of a Thousand Stores, it frayed at the seams in the late 1980's and early 90's as the recession took its toll. Some shops in the downtown area closed, and many of those that remained fared poorly. One large mall, the Galleria, hung on, although barely. 
 But, increasingly, that all seems like ancient history. In 1994 the Westchester Pavilion, a 275,000-square-foot power center, opened along Maple Avenue here with competitive-priced merchandisers. A year later, The Westchester, an upscale million-square-foot mall anchored by Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom, also opened on Maple Avenue, with a glittering array of expensive merchandise.
Contrary to predictions, the two new malls did not detract from the existing 883,000-square-foot Galleria, which spent $11 million for a face-lifting and held its own in the growing constellation of shopping options.
Now the way is clear for yet another developer, Alexius Conroy, who plans to anchor the new mall with Saks Fifth Avenue, an existing 120,000-square-foot store.
Late last month, Mr. Conroy and Saks officials won city approval here to build the $65 million open-air mall at Bloomingdale Road and Maple Avenue -- directly across the street from The Westchester and barely a stone's throw from the Westchester Pavilion.
The Saks store, which has been faring poorly against the competition, is planning to modernize.
"We are all fired up," Mr. Conroy said last week, outlining his plan for 30 stores and several full-service restaurants. "We will be complementary, not competitive, with the other malls."
Rather than worry about the competition across the street at The Westchester, Mr. Conroy said he was encouraged by it. He predicted that shoppers would patronize both malls.
Robert T. Guerra, assistant general manager of The Westchester, agreed that the two sites would be drawing similar upscale customers, who could cross the street to shop at either mall.
Most retailers believe that the county has not yet fully tapped the high-end retail market.
"Before, shoppers were leaving Westchester to go elsewhere, like New York City," Mr. Guerra said. "Now the dollars are staying in the area. This establishes White Plains as a shopping mecca."
He added, "It's terrific. The competition is healthy."
Not to be left out of the burgeoning retail scene, Bloomingdale's, which is less than a mile away, recently announced plans to expand its 20-year-old, 250,000-square-foot store. It leases land from New York Hospital and has suggested that it might situate one of the entrances to its park-like shopping area near the main entrance to The Westchester to reduce the apparent distance between them.
Meanwhile, Mr. Conroy said he expected to open the new fashion mall, called the Shops at Saks Fifth Avenue, by late 1998. He said he would break ground this year.
The developer said that he once considered bringing Bloomingdale's to the Saks site, but that plan never materialized.
At the county's offices here, Eric Langeloh, Finance Commissioner, said sales tax receipts for Westchester have reflected the increased shopping activity in White Plains. Retail sales generated $200.5 million in tax revenues for the county last year, up from $184.7 million in 1995, he said.
"Certainly a piece of that has to do with the opening of The Westchester and the other stores," Mr. Langeloh said. "The spending climate is encouraging."
Looking ahead at the Saks mall,Mr. Langeloh said the additional shopping mall would most likely generate even more income for Westchester.
"But how many more stores we can absorb, I can't predict," he said. "But as new stores and malls come on line, others go out of business. There are usually adjustments in the cycle."
Similarly, sales tax receipts for White Plains have grown to $31.8 million in the fiscal year 1996-97 from $26 million in 1994-95.
Joseph R. Potenza, the White Plains Planning Commissioner, said the city anticipated $1.6 million a year in sales tax revenues from the new mall. The Westchester generates about $5 million a year in sales tax revenues.
The newest mall is also expected to generate about $150,000 annually in property taxes for the city and $375,000 in property taxes for the school district, Mr. Potenza said. And it will lead to about 300 new retail jobs.

HEADLINE: Blacks Seeing Economic Growth

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
AS a successful black architect and political leader, Ernest D. Davis relishes the trappings of the upper-middle-class status he has worked so diligently to achieve: his five-bedroom house with manicured grounds here, an extensive art collection acquired over the years, membership in the same college fraternity as the television star Bill Cosby and acceptance in social circles where other prominent political and business leaders congregate.
Yet he worries. 
 Like other blacks who have achieved middle- and upper-middle-class status, Mr. Davis, the 59-year-old Mayor of this city, fears that those gains may be short lived.
"All this can change tomorrow," he said one recent sunny afternoon, sprawled on a porch chaise outside his home, as he pointed to his gracious garden, the renovations under way on the house and the driveway lined with vintage automobiles.
"Blacks don't have the cushion that whites do," he said, warning against putting too much emphasis on the accouterments of prosperity. "We haven't yet learned to perpetuate our successes, to dominate certain industries, to get a strong foothold any place. That's why we idolize basketball players and other sports figures, even though their successes aren't long lasting."
Uncertainties about tomorrow notwithstanding, all indicators are that increasing numbers of blacks, in Westchester and around the country are faring better economically than ever before.
As testament to that trend in Westchester, the Carver Federal Savings Bank, the largest black-owned financial institution in the country, opened a mortgage and loan center here last year "to sow the seeds for yet more growth," said Thomas L. Clark Jr., the bank's president and chief executive officer.
The loan center is offering commercial, residential and auto loans, secured and nonsecured credit cards and other services.
The financial institution, which opened in a storefront in Harlem in 1949, was founded by an association of community advocates, church leaders and small business owners, who established Carver in an area that white-run banks had turned their backs on. The $363 million institution, named for the black scientist and educator George Washington Carver, now has two locations in Manhattan, three in Brooklyn, two in Queens and one in Roosevelt on Long Island. More are on the drawing board.
Speaking of the decision to open a loan center in the heart of the business district here, Mr. Clark, a Greenburgh resident and another of Westchester's more affluent blacks, said: "We're going where the market is. This isn't for charity. The numbers are showing it to be a good business move."
While the national median household income for blacks in 1989 was $19,758 (for whites it was $31,435), according to the 1990 census, Westchester's numbers were much higher.
The median family income for blacks in the county more than doubled in less than a decade to $36,537 in 1989 from $16,485 in 1980, the county's Planning Department reported. That was, however, still significantly less than the average median family income for all Westchester residents -- $58,852 in 1990, up from $27,278 in 1980.
Despite the gains, there is a long way to go.
Some middle-class blacks like William Brown Jr., a management consultant in White Plains, worry that the advances they fought for are in danger of being undercut because affirmative-action policies continue to come under attack.
"It's upsetting, because my children are now experiencing some of the problems that I did 25 years ago," said Mr. Brown, who is running for White Plains mayor on the Democratic ticket. "I was hoping that would have gone away."
Mr. Brown said that his grown daughter is a lawyer who still battles racism in the job, and his son is a salesman who has been denied promotions because he is black.
"It's a great disappointment for me to hear about their problems," he said. "It holds us back."
Gene A. Capello, a Yonkers resident and vice president and assistant general counsel for a major financial services concern in Manhattan, said that while "people of color have had better entree into the corporate world in the past 25 years," they are still grossly underrepresented at the policy and major decision-making levels.
"Until that changes, our opportunities are limited," he said. "We've hit a ceiling."
In periods of layoffs, too, blacks suffer disproportionately, Mr. Capello said, because as the most recent hires, they are often the first to be discharged.
Because of blacks' fragility within the corporate structure, the trend of late has been for increasing numbers to start their own businesses.
In 1982, there were 1,640 black-owned companies in Westchester; by 1992 that number had risen to 3,397, according to county records.
The road, however, has been a rough one for black entrepreneurs, said Robin Douglas, president of the African-American Chamber of Commerce of Westchester and Rockland.
"We're playing catch-up," Ms. Douglas said, explaining that many black companies are still learning basic business principles, like the concept of becoming partners with competitors to get more business.
"In past years, the attitude of many small- and mid-sized black companies has been win, lose or draw, they'll do it their own way," she said.
"Now they're having to learn that that doesn't always work," she added.
Education, too, continues to be an area of concern for middle-class blacks, who want their children to receive the same quality schooling that affluent whites do.
Gerald M. Coleman, a member of the Mount Vernon School Board, worried that blacks' hopes for the future were being undercut in the classroom.
"The danger is that kids in school districts like Scarsdale will become the technical masters of the future and our kids in the urban settings will become just the workers," he said.
Kenneth W. Jenkins, a former chapter president of the Yonkers branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has similarly focused on education as a yellow brick road to the future for middle-class blacks.
"Success for any ethnic group doesn't happen by luck," said Mr. Jenkins, who is running for City Council president in the state's fourth-largest city. "Education is the key, and if you don't have that, then you're working with a truly serious handicap."
Mr. Jenkins was ousted from his position by the N.A.A.C.P. because he took an unorthodox stand on busing. He said more emphasis should be placed on upgrading neighborhood schools in black areas than in transporting young students to white areas.
As blacks have moved up economically, they have also sought better housing, but studies have shown that with success they do not necessarily move far away from others of their race.
Researchers at the Urban Studies Group at the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University in Albany, studied nine metropolitan areas in the United States and found few high-income, residential areas that have black majorities.
"Why this is happening we don't yet know," said Richard P. Nathan, director of the Rockefeller Institute.
In part, the study suggested, it is because the number of blacks that are getting ahead remains small proportionately: as of 1990, 13 percent of black households in the country earned more than $45,000 and only 6 percent earned more than $75,000.
But, also, it is because blacks do not always feel welcome in white neighborhoods, Mr. Capello said, recalling a May 12 bias incident in Yonkers in which a white man set off a super M-80 firecracker on the windshield of a vehicle owned by another white man who had sold his house to a black woman and her three children.
Mr. Capello, who said he earns six figures a year, lives in a gracious residential area not far from Yonkers' poorest neighborhoods in the city's southwest quadrant.
Mr. Jenkins observed that getting ahead, for all of its pluses, put many successful blacks in stressful positions.
"On the one hand, members of your own race accuse you of forgetting where you came from, of moving out of the neighborhood, literally and figuratively," he said. "On the other hand, you have to do things twice as well in the white world. You have to really always cross your T's and dot your I's. It's a hard burden to carry."

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:

Traffic Plan
To accommodate an expected 25,000 spectators a day for the Professional Golfers' Association Championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck tomorrow through next Sunday, the county has set up a special traffic plan. The goal, said James P. Doughty, a spokesman for County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, is to keep all but a small amount of traffic away from the narrow, winding residential streets that surround the tournament site. 
 The County Executive's office said there will be no spectator parking at Winged Foot, and violators will be towed away.
Those attending the events are encouraged to use Metro-North's New Haven Line to Mamaroneck, where they can board a free, five-minute shuttle to Winged Food. For train information, call (800) 638-7646.
Ticket holders who intend to arrive by car are being notified by mail to park at one of two satellite sites: Westchester Community College in Valhalla or Yonkers Raceway. There will be free, continuous bus service to Winged Foot from those sites.
 
Poll Results
In a recent poll, Manhattanville College found that taxes and education topped the list of Westchester voters' concerns.
The voters were asked to identify the issue facing the county that most concerned them. Of the 450 people who responded, 31 percent identified taxes as the primary concern, with half of those respondents referring to school and property taxes.
Another 16 percent singled out education. And 8 percent of respondents said crime and drugs were major concerns. Seven percent cited the environment, and 6 percent listed poverty and the needs of the elderly. The rest mentioned overcrowding, affordable housing, jobs and the economy, rent control, welfare, government spending and the privatization of county services.
In another question, 6 percent rated the county's economy as excellent, 54 percent said it was good, 33 percent said it was fair, and 7 percent said it was poor.
Those who rated the county's economy favorably included residents making more than $100,000, people with a postgraduate education, those who lived in the southern half of the county but outside the cities and those older than 51.
Those who held more pessimistic views included residents with a high school education or less, people with a yearly income of $24,000 or less and those who lived in a larger city.
 
Texaco Cites Progress
Texaco's chief executive officer, Peter I. Bijur, reported recently that the company has taken major steps toward diversifying its work force.
"Last December, Texaco made a commitment to a more inclusive and diverse work force and to broader relationships with women- and minority-owned businesses," Mr. Bijur said. "In the first six months of the program, the people of this company made excellent progress toward the goals we stated in our plan."
In the first half of this year, 50 percent of the company's 4,400 new employees in the United States were women and 38 percent were from minority groups. The breakdown among minority employees was 16 percent black and 15 percent Hispanic. Of the 325 employees promoted in the first half of the year, 47 percent were women and 24 percent were from minorities.
Mr. Bijur also said that the number of minority- or female-owned law firms that Texaco does business with rose to 21 this year from 6 last year, and the number of advertising agencies owned by members of a minority group is up to 2 from none.
 
O'Rourke Son Arrested
Andrew P. O'Rourke Jr., 41, the son of the County Executive, was arrested last month in the village of Ossining after he failed to pay a fine for maintaining a substandard apartment house there, the police said. He had pleaded guilty in April to violating building codes, Sgt. Michael Brown said.
George Pires, the village's building inspector, said the younger Mr. O'Rourke, who lives in Yonkers, had a "history with our department" and had been issued a summons for building-code violations twice since last year. Mr. Pires also said he fell on a step of a house owned by the County Executive's son because it was in disrepair.
Mr. Pires said that at another point, the building had been declared unfit for habitation because the utilities had been turned off. After that, the younger Mr. O'Rourke rented out a first-floor apartment in the building before he had approval from the Building Department to do so.
In the most recent violation, he was fined $250, but did not pay it, Mr. Pires said. The younger Mr. O'Rourke was summoned to court but failed to appear. He turned himself in on July 22, posted bail of $250 and was released, Sergeant Brown said, in effect paying the fine.
The younger Mr. O'Rourke, who is a journalist, said last week that he had been in the hospital with spinal meningitis and had been out of work for a year. He also said the tenants had damaged the house.
The County Health Department, too, has had problems with the County Executive's son. Mary Landrigan, a spokeswoman, said the same building, which has two three-bedroom apartments, had past asbestos violations. But those problems have since been fixed, she said.
 
Patients' Rights
Support is growing for a state bill, the Patients Fair Appeals Act, which would amend New York's current medical insurance law.
Most recently, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, who supports the bill, and State Senator Catherine M. Abate of Manhattan, who has introduced it in Albany, were at Greenburgh's Town Hall to discuss the bill with residents. The proposal would provide a statewide standard for health insurance coverage for experimental drugs and those in trial. It would also cover devices and treatments prescribed by doctors for patients with life-threatening, degenerative or permanently disabling conditions. In addition, the bill would provide patients with a timely right of appeal when insurance companies deny coverage for care that doctors have prescribed.
"The proposal is designed to make sure that insurance companies do not control the fate of patients for the sake of profits," said Paul J. Feiner, Greenburgh's Supervisor. He had extended the invitation to the Lieutenant Governor and Ms. Abate.
In addition, the bill would create a new position of consumer advocate, whose job it would be to help people choose appropriate health insurance and assist them if they are dissatisfied with their coverage. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: Charitable Giving Taps New Donors

BYLINE: By GITTA MORRIS 

 BODY:
TWO new funds at the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven have captured the imaginations of a new breed of philanthropists who want to become more involved in the decision making.
One, the Women and Girls Fund, was started two years ago with the goal of helping women learn more about philanthropy. "Traditionally women give time, men give money," said Sherry Mordecai, the foundation's development and donor relations officer. "When it comes time to make the charitable gift in the family, the husband's college, his interests, get the most." 
 Things have changed, however. "Women are making their own money and are capable of making the gift on their own," Ms. Mordecai noted. "We wanted to build on that."
The second new venture is the Catalyst Fund, which was started last year. It brings together younger leaders of the community who, while they are not yet ready to making major financial gifts, like the idea of having a voice in how their charitable dollars are spent.
The New Haven Foundation was developed in 1928 by trustees of the banks that were handling various charitable funds. Four years ago the name was changed to the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven, to better reflect the donor base and grant range from Clinton to Milford, and as far north as Cheshire and Wallingford. According to the Council on Foundations in Washington, D.C., in comparison with similar-sized community foundations, it is among the 25 top community foundations in the country.
Serendipitously, shortly after the Fund for Women and Girls was set up, a donor appeared. "This was a teacher who was very concerned about women's issues," Ms. Mordecai said. "She had received a small inheritance from her father, and she wanted to do something special with it. She thought a woman's fund was a terrific idea."
"Awarding money is very difficult. It's hard to believe but true," Ms. Mordecai noted. "It's not unusual for people who are contemplating a family foundation, or currently have one, to consider transferring it over to a community foundation. They don't have to deal with tax forms or other details. It streamlines the process and cuts the cost tremendously."
The fund, which was designed to be affordable, calls for a minimum contribution of $1,000, which can be pledged over a five-year period. "I've been a professional fund-raiser for 17 years, and I've never seen pledges coming in like this," Ms. Mordecai said. "There have been no defaults."
Phyllis Seton, a North Haven resident and one of the founders of the fund, said the new fund now has $100,000. Among the beneficiaries of the Fund for Women and Girls are Elm City Girls Choir and the Martin de Porres Quilting Workshop. The rational is not singing or quilting, rather, the objective is bringing together women of diverse economic, racial and age groups as friends and mentors. Another award went to the Survivors of Domestic Violence shelter for a playground.
"Who knows," Mrs. Seton said, "maybe the people who benefit from these grants will continue the idea of giving, if they have the means, not only financially but also by volunteering."
Last year, the foundation felt it was once again time to expand the donor base. Peter Culver, a 45-year-old lawyer who lives in Guilford, formed a group called Catalyst, with an annual membership contribution of $500. "Typically, to start a fund at one of these foundations, you have to give $10,000," Mr. Culver explained. "That's more of a commitment than many people want to make. So the first thing is to give people, who want to give at a significant but not ultra-rich level, a chance."
Catalyst has two unusual components, Mr. Culver noted. "We are going to meet at least once a year to have a forum about issues that are pressing needs in the community, with people who are knowledgeable in that area to talk to us," he said. "And we will be involved in the decisions about where the funds that we raise actually end up being directed."
Also appealing to the Catalyst donors is that the foundation acts as a clearinghouse for potential donees, with knowledge that the average prospective donor does not have. "It's important, too, that the New Haven Foundation is an endowment and builds over time," Mr. Culver said.
From six areas of giving or interest, the Catalyst group has selected food, shelter and education for grants this year. Awards will be granted in December. The foundation awards around 500 grants a year. In 1996, $4.9 million was raised in new money and 18 new funds.
"One thing that the donors in the Women and Girls and the Catalyst Funds want is to see tangible results," said Joan Huwiler, the foundation's communications officer. "They want to know their check isn't lost in the shuffle. When you see your mailbox full of appeals, they all sound so compelling. The key to the foundation is, we can fully educate the donor and provide that follow up."

Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 711 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW TAX LAW: Amid Complexity, Opportunities Abound;
Socking It Away for College, With Uncle Sam's Help

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
For all Washington's celebratory mood over the nation's first major tax cut in 16 years, Congress and the Clinton Administration hardly issued an open invitation to the party. Rather than an across-the-board tax cut, the $96 billion package is a series of narrowly focused measures intended to achieve specific goals. How much you benefit depends on your personal circumstances. Here is a guide to achieving key financial objectives under the new rules.
THERE are few parents who have not looked at tables showing how much they will have to save each month to pay for their children's college educations without some combination of horror and guilt. Several measures in the tax bill may take the edge off those feelings, although not eliminate them, especially not with tuition costs rising faster than inflation.
The law creates a new class of educational savings accounts modeled on Individual Retirement Accounts. It allows contributions of $500 a child a year. The contributions are not tax-deductible, but earnings in the account accumulate tax free, and withdrawals are tax free when used for undergraduate or graduate-level tuition, room, board or books. 
 Because of the $500 limit, the new educational I.R.A.'s alone will not be enough for parents intent on saving all or most of the money needed to pay for four years of college. According to Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, a $500 annual contribution from birth through age 18, earning 8 percent a year, will grow to $22,381 -- less than the costs of a single year at a private university even today.
The educational I.R.A. is subject to income limits, which affect couples filing jointly with modified adjusted gross income of $150,000 and single filers with modified adjusted gross incomes of $95,000. But it is unclear whether the income limits will really have much meaning. Some financial advisers said the law appears to allow parents whose incomes exceeded the limits to give $500 to another family member whose income fell within the limits, who, in turn, could use that $500 to establish the educational account for the child.
"It's a nice tool to shift resources from high-tax individuals to lower-tax individuals," said Joan Vine, the national director of employee benefits tax services for Grant Thornton, the accounting firm.
There is a penalty for people who do not use all the money accumulated in the account for college expenses. Such money would be considered income and taxed at ordinary income-tax rates -- plus a further 10 percent tax.
For some people, the tax bill provides other relief from college expenses. That includes a credit of up to $1,500 for the first two years of college, and then a credit of up to $1,000 -- increasing to $2,000 after 2002 -- for additional years of college. The credits would be fully available for families with incomes up to $80,000 a year and partially available for families with income up to $100,000 (phasing out for single filers would be between $40,000 and $50,000).
But for the most part, people will have to choose between the credits and the educational I.R.A., because the two cannot be employed at the same time. For families in the 15 percent income-tax bracket especially, the credit, which reduces taxes dollar for dollar, could be much more attractive than tax-sheltered savings, said Clint Stretch, a partner at Deloitte & Touche. For families in higher tax brackets, the education I.R.A. would probably be more attractive.
The tax law also would allow tax-free, penalty-free withdrawals from both traditional I.R.A.'s and Roth I.R.A.'s for higher education expenses of the account's owner, a spouse, a child or a grandchild, Ms. Vine said. Such withdrawals would mean that the money saved would not be available for the contributor's retirement -- the original purpose of the account -- or for the purchase of a first home.
The law is written in a way so that it would be difficult if not impossible to set up a traditional I.R.A. or a Roth I.R.A. in a child's name.
 The article also misattributed the reference to the provision. While Joan Vines of the Grant Thornton accounting firm described some permissible uses of the money, the reference to the tax status was not hers but The Times's.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 31, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 10 about the effects of the new tax law on saving for college referred incorrectly to a provision concerning withdrawals from individual retirement accounts for higher-education expenses. Under the law, such withdrawals from traditional I.R.A.'s are penalty-free, but not tax-free. With the new Roth I.R.A., the withdrawals are both penalty-free and tax-free, but only if the money has been held in the Roth I.R.A. for at least five years.

An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders for a book.
Ruth W. Messinger was forced last night into a runoff for the Democratic mayoral nomination with the Rev. Al Sharpton, as a low voter turnout in a three-way race, combined with a strong performance by Mr. Sharpton, dashed her hope for a jubilant primary night sendoff into the fall campaign.
With all 5,627 precincts reporting, Ms. Messinger had 155,913 votes or 39 percent, to 126,799 votes or 32 percent, for Mr. Sharpton. The third major candidate in the race, Councilman Sal F. Albanese, had 83,402 votes, or 21 percent. 
 Under state law, a candidate in a mayoral primary is required to win 40 percent of the vote to capture the nomination. The runoff, to be held on Sept. 23, will be the first Democratic runoff since 1977, when Edward I. Koch defeated Mario M. Cuomo.
Ms. Messinger's aides attributed the result last night to the case of Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who prosecutors said was assaulted while in police custody in Brooklyn on Aug. 9. Mr. Sharpton -- who had nowhere near the organization or financial resources of Ms. Messinger or Mr. Albanese -- quickly identified his campaign with the Louima case, and Ms. Messinger's aides pointed to Mr. Sharpton's victory in Brooklyn as proof of the success of that strategy.
But Ms. Messinger was also hurt by Mr. Albanese's healthy showing, which interviews suggested drew support away from Ms. Messinger, and from what may have been the worst voter turnout in a Democratic primary since World War II. Only 395,395 of the 2,246,987 registered Democrats voted, about 18 percent.
Mr. Sharpton, beaming in the brightest spotlight he has enjoyed in a high-profile career as a protest leader and civil-rights advocate, pledged to adhere to the traditional values of his party. In an energetic, televised speech to supporters last night, he also scolded Democrats who he said had sought to abandon those values.
"This is our day. This is our time. I can fly! I can fly! I can fly!" Mr. Sharpton declared exuberantly, repeating the words of the popular song, "I Believe I Can Fly," by R. Kelly, the hip-hop artist, which he plays in his car, in his home and at most campaign stops.
Turning his attention to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- who has until now refused to engage Mr. Sharpton in any debate -- the candidate declared: "Whatever skirmish Ms. Messinger and I have, Mr. Giuliani, at the end of the skirmish, we're coming to City Hall and one of us is going to take your seat in 1997."
A few blocks away, Ms. Messinger, standing next to a glum David N. Dinkins in the ballroom of the Grand Hyatt, presented the outcome as just a small setback. "Well, friends, they never said this would be easy," she commented. There was a scattering of boos when she said that there would probably be a runoff. "We're going to have to win this the hard way, but win it we will,' she said.
Still, by any measure, the runoff appears to be a huge setback for Democrats seeking to unseat Mr. Giuliani. It will delay for two weeks the general election assault on Mr. Giuliani, forcing Ms. Messinger and Mr. Sharpton to devote resources against each other instead.
A runoff against Mr. Sharpton is likely to prove particularly uncomfortable for Ms. Messinger. She will now be forced to run head-on against a candidate with a strong following in some parts of the black electorate, but without alienating the black voters who are critical to any hope she has of defeating Mr. Giuliani.
The runoff is also likely to complicate Ms. Messinger's efforts to position herself on the center of the political spectrum in anticipation of a race against Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Sharpton has repeatedly scolded Ms. Messinger for trying to win election by abandoning the liberal wing of the party. Until now, she has been able to ignore him, but that might be difficult starting today.
Ms. Messinger herself seemed unprepared for the outcome yesterday. Right up to the eve of the election, she had been predicting that she would not only avoid a runoff but win easily. She in effect raised expectations for herself, which made her showing last night appear even more damaging. Mr. Sharpton's showing, on the other hand, was almost exactly what he predicted it would be.
There were two other candidates on the ballot: Eric Ruano-Melendez, who received 18,940 votes, or 5 percent, and Roland Rogers, with 11,061 votes, or 3 percent.
Ms. Messinger was almost certainly hurt by the presence of Mr. Albanese on the ballot. Still, her performance was a startling setback for a woman who has been a fixture on New York's political scene since she emerged on the Upper West Side 25 years ago, running first for school board, then for the City Council and then, in 1989, for Manhattan borough president. Her history, base of support and fund-raising ability had led Democratic leaders across the city to view her as the almost certain nominee from the day Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, dropped out of the mayoral race in early May.
Even before the polls closed, Democratic leaders across the city were criticizing the campaign Ms. Messinger and her advisers had run as they began seeing signs of her defeat.
In particular, they were critical of one central tactical decision by the Messinger campaign: to forgo the heavy "get out the vote" operation that has always been integral to winning primary elections in this city. The campaign instead devoted its resources to a television advertisement. And that ad spoke only about what Ms. Messinger had presumed would be her contest with Mr. Giuliani -- thereby not even alerting her supporters to yesterday's vote.
Influential Democrats in Ms. Messinger's own neighborhood, reporting during the day on signs of duress in her backyard, said they had been constantly frustrated in their attempts to persuade her staff to turn its attention to what is known as street campaigning. "All we got on the West Side was 150 pieces of literature on Saturday," one Democrat supporting Ms. Messinger said last night. "This has taken a media strategy to a new dimension."
The result last night underscored questions raised by several political analysts over Ms. Messinger's decision to staff her office with political professionals who had little or no experience in New York. Her campaign manager, Jim Andrews, is from Chicago; her media consultant, Mandy Grunwald, is from Washington, though her clients include Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
The difficulties of the comparatively well-financed Messinger campaign seem all the more stark when put up against the bare-bones campaign waged by Mr. Sharpton that has forced Ms. Messinger into this position. He broadcast no television advertisements, hired no campaign consultants and did not retain a media adviser. Instead, he adhered to a relentless schedule of campaigning across the city.
And he raised so little money that he could not even meet the $250,000 threshold for qualifying for city campaign finance money.
But Mr. Sharpton's campaign benefited from the Louima case, as evidenced by the vote in Brooklyn. And he also may have been helped by the primary for Manhattan borough president. Democrats said there was a high turnout in black communities for C. Virginia Fields, who won the Democratic nomination yesterday.
Beyond that, Mr. Sharpton offered what many Democrats saw as a far more extensive -- and, from a Democratic perspective, traditional -- view of what he thought the party was about. He repeatedly criticized Democrats who moved to the center, arguing that the party should not abandon its traditional position of helping the poor and oppressed.
Mr. Sharpton discussed that last night, taking full advantage of his suddenly huge platform to present his view of the Democratic Party. But he also took care, at least initially, to frame his challenge as one to Mr. Giuliani, rather than Ms. Messinger.
"Ruth Messinger is not the loser at all tonight," Mr. Sharpton said. "The real loser is Rudy Giuliani." Addressing his remarks to Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Sharpton said: "You will not be able to ignore the issues and the constituency that I've tried to represent. Those days are over. The issues of unemployment and police brutality and schools' not working are on the front burner. And you can run, Rudy, but you can't hide."
Ms. Messinger has framed her campaign around the condition of the schools, which she says have deteriorated under Mr. Giuliani's watch. She visited a public school yesterday, before the polls closed, and spoke of the issue again last night.
But mostly, Ms. Messinger seemed to be trying to reassure her supporters that the results last night were nothing more than a small setback, and not the end of what even her own friends had come to see as a troubled campaign. In doing so, she for perhaps the first time acknowledged the existence of strong opponents for the nomination.
"Tonight, my friends, is just a first step," she said, smiling. "When I decided to run for Mayor, I knew that we would have a fight on my hands. A tough fight against a bully of a Mayor, and yes, a tough fight against my rivals in the Democratic party."
Mr. Albanese, speaking at his early concession speech, declined to say last night whom he would support in a runoff. He could barely disguise his disappointment.
"We campaigned for a year and half," he said after his concession speech. "We shook a lot of hands. But you have 8 million people in this city; you have 2.5 million registered voters. You have to get on the air. But we rallied a lot of people together around the same issues. It was a good campaign. I have no regrets about it."
Interviews with Democrats around the city yesterday suggested that many had decided to skip the primary because they had concluded that the candidates had simply said and done too little to motivate them. Others said they were not at all eager to throw Mayor Giuliani out of office, so why bother voting in the primary?
Sol Sobel, a 73-year-old lawyer, said he had never passed up an opportunity to vote in a Democratic primary. Until now.
