SECTION: Section 6; Page 37; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 4170 words

HEADLINE: The Real-Estate Royals. End of the Line?

BYLINE: By David Samuels; David Samuels is a contributing editor at Harper's Magazine. This is his first article for The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
It is not a sight for the faint of heart: a ballroom full of tuxedo-wearing owners, builders and managers of the city's prime real estate shouting at the top of their lungs at lenders, lawyers and assorted factotums as white-jacketed waiters stagger by beneath silver trays of salmon roulade. If the 101st annual banquet of the Real Estate Board of New York lacks the laid-back charm of dinner for two at the Rainbow Room -- there are few spouses, no dancing, and only a handful of the guests bother to sit down -- the importance of tonight's event can be seen from even a quick glance at the dais. Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani are here, along with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Senate Majority Leader Joseph Bruno, various City Council members and a youthful-looking official in a sharp blue suit whose game but puzzled expression indicates that he is happy to honor his distinguished constituents in the real-estate business but has never seen anything quite like this before in his life.
The roar that fills the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton tonight, loud enough to tinkle the glass chandeliers and to overpower all attempts at conversation in the balcony above, is the sound of Manhattan's $90 billion real-estate market in the first flush of exuberance. New construction is up. Midtown vacancies are down near the single digits. As the ceremonial part of the evening continues on -- the Governor; the Mayor; Samuel (Sandy) Lindenbaum, the knife-thin lawyer who helped make so many of these people rich; Joseph B. Rose, head of the City Planning Commission and a son of the developer Daniel Rose, mounting the dais one by one -- the small fish swim in frantic circles, darting anxious glances at the big-deal owners who won't return their calls during the rest of the year. 
 And there they sit at the center of the room, the royal families of Manhattan real estate: the Rudins, Dursts, Roses, Fishers, Tishmans and Resnicks. Unlike Donald Trump (who, the families like to point out, is not a member of REBNY) or the late Harry Helmsley (more an owner-manager than a builder), the names of these men barely ring a bell. Yet the families are to New York what the oil barons are to Houston or the steel bosses were to Pittsburgh. With their careful blend of dynastic savvy, wealth and behind-the-scenes clout, they have shaped the city through good times and bad. Let the Wall Street bonus babies squirm and jump with every flutter of the Dow. The rulers of Manhattan's prime real estate are a throwback to the distant, more family-oriented age when Wall Street was ruled by Lehmans and Loebs and Hollywood was run by Warners and Mayers.
The Rudins are represented tonight by William C. Rudin, heir apparent to an empire of some 39 buildings currently valued at more than $1.5 billion. Jack Rudin, his uncle, is the family builder. William's father, Lew, who combines a streetwise Rodney Dangerfield voice with the broad sentimental streak of the successful Jewish machers in Saul Bellow novels, is the Rudin who speaks to the press. The Dursts, some of whom are seated nearby, are olive-skinned with big brown eyes, known in the business for saying very little and for pursuing a disciplined program of acquisition and construction that has transformed the area near Grand Central Terminal into a family-held principality. The latest Durst contribution to the city's skyline, 4 Times Square (the first new Manhattan office tower in nearly a decade), is being built by John Tishman and his son, Daniel; John is a wry, inquisitive man whose Tishman Realty and Construction is the descendant of the company founded by his grandfather Julius in 1898. Daniel Rose, seated nearby with his nephew Adam and his niece Amy, is the house intellectual, more likely to be found at a reading on the Upper West Side than at an industry event like this.
With a few additions and subtractions, these are the same families that dominated the city's real-estate market 40 years ago. They have survived the assaults of the big insurance companies of the 60's, the near-bankruptcy of the city in the 70's, the entry into the market in the 80's of well-capitalized foreign giants like Sumitomo and Ladbroke and Olympia & York. They have expanded their fortunes as arriviste competitors have come and gone. They are as close to a stable ruling class as New York has enjoyed since the beginning of the century, when Manhattan was owned by the Astors and the Rhinelanders, and Sam Rudin, David Rose and other family founders were cutting deals on Court Street in Brooklyn or 149th Street in the Bronx. And though factions and alliances still exist (Roses and Rudins; Tishmans and Dursts; Tishmans and Rudins), the families are more likely to do business with one another now than at any time in their collective history.
While the understated permanence that the families bring to the city is impressive, this group portrait of wealth and power handed down from generation to generation is hardly carved in stone. Indeed, some analysts believe that Manhattan's prime real estate, and the social and political power that goes with it, will soon be owned not by the families but by real-estate investment trusts, or REIT's -- publicly owned and operated companies that invest in and manage real estate. REIT's have already made inroads into property markets in Chicago, Atlanta, San Francisco, Houston and Dallas. Now that New York State's 10 percent tax on property transfers has been abolished, there are hints that prominent Manhattan developers are preparing to take their holdings public, too.
Those who believe that the families' glory days may be numbered do not have very far to look. The revolution -- if that's what it is -- began on March 12 of this year when Bernard H. Mendik, chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York, announced that he would merge his family-held company and seven Manhattan office towers with the publicly traded Vornado Realty Trust, headed by Steven Roth. Vornado already controlled a prime midtown development site at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue, once occupied by Alexander's, and is one of five bidders for the Coliseum site at the southwest corner of Central Park. With the addition of Mendik's holdings, Vornado now controls more than five million feet of prime Manhattan office space. "The financial strength of our combined companies," Roth promised in a written public statement on the day the deal was announced, "will enable us to capitalize on opportunities, including those in the Manhattan office market." Roth has proved as good as his word. On April 25, he bought 90 Park Avenue for $185 million. In a $160 million joint venture in June, he bought a half interest in the Hotel Pennsylvania and paid $75 million for a parcel of property around Madison Square Garden. According to an article in The New York Times, the developer has told friends that "he intends to become the largest owner of commercial real estate" in all of New York.
 Of course, the families have heard this talk before. nurtured over three and sometimes four generations, their sense of connection to the city they built carries with it a touch of the seigniorial feeling with which noblemen of a different century must have regarded their estates. "This is the farm," says Richard L. Fisher, the elegantly dressed heir to the Fisher Brothers fortune, who also holds a master's in English literature from the University of Pennsylvania. "It's not just an asset. It is family and business joined as one."
Meanwhile, the frequency with which real-estate-family names appear on major boards is a very public sign that the current generation of Jewish owner-builders has achieved the place in the city that their parents were denied. The Roses, Rudins, Tishmans and other families support such institutions as Mt. Sinai and Beth Israel Hospitals; Columbia and New York Universities and the New School for Social Research; Lincoln Center; Carnegie Hall, and in recent years, the Metropolitan Museum, the Asia Society, the Museum of Natural History and the Whitney. They do their best to keep out of the papers. "Real estate was not very high profile until the late 70's, early 80's," says Adam R. Rose. "The big-name developers, whose names I'm not going to use, dragged the rest of us out of the closet, if you will, because they were very high-profile people with very flashy, expensive projects, who pronounced on every subject and were in the headlines with their divorces and this and that."
The families' political influence -- whether helping to get city loan guarantees through the Senate in the 70's or pushing for more cops on the street during the Dinkins era -- is also considerable. "Whoever the mayor is, they want that person to succeed," says former Mayor Edward I. Koch, a friend of the Rudins. "I knew I could call on all these people, and I always did." Through a broad and influential network of contacts, the families and their fellow developers exercise their influence through elected officials, through REBNY, through industry-led coalitions like the Alliance for Downtown New York and through the city's Business Improvement Districts, which provide once-basic public services like security, street lighting and trash removal for an increasingly large portion of Manhattan.
"The real-estate tax is the largest thing that comes into the city's budget," says Hadley W. Gold, whose service as first assistant corporation counsel during the Koch administration gave him a wide-open window on the families' dealings with the city. "These are very smart people. Do you follow what I mean? They know what makes the city function, they know how to make people comfortable and they don't overreach." More pointed development questions, meanwhile, are handled by lawyers like Sandy Lindenbaum, whose father, the late Abe (Bunny) Lindenbaum, served as a political broker between the Brooklyn Democratic machine and developers. "They don't need me to call the Mayor," says Sandy Lindenbaum, who, like Howard J. Rubenstein, the public-relations expert, has been a venerable aide-de-camp to the families. "They get on the phone and call the Mayor themselves. But if what they need is a change in zoning, you don't call the Mayor -- so they call me."
Yet after decades of building, borrowing and exercising clout, the families' place in the city may finally be up for grabs. With their huge reserves of public capital, and their investor-friendly corporate governance, real-estate investment trusts offer the virtues of liquidity and transparency in a market that has often resembled a high-stakes Monopoly game, where properties are bought and sold among the same small group of players. Martin Cohen of Cohen & Steers, which manages more than $5 billion in REIT's, says of the families: "They weren't so smart. They just had dumb financial partners. So now that they've bankrupted their partners, they're proud to say, Well, we're left standing. But they still need financing. One, because their loans have matured and they have obligations" -- a reference to the borrowed money on which so many real-estate empires were built. "And two, because the proceeds of selling their properties wouldn't be great enough to pay their taxes."
A former partner at a well-known Wall Street firm, who declined to be named, takes a similar view. "The empires you're talking about were all based on the fact that for many years, private ownership of real estate was rewarded with these ungodly tax breaks sponsored by the Government," he says. "As an individual owner, you could make money in any one of dozens of ways. You could deduct your losses at the highest rate and keep whatever you earned in rents. You could sell your losses to other wealthy individuals. When the value of the building went up, you could borrow against that and deduct those payments, too. To invest in real estate as a public entity meant you were crazy." With the 1986 Federal tax reforms, however, the real-estate playing field was abruptly leveled. "The smart ones will always survive, of course," the banker says. "For the rest of them, the ride is over."
Even developers who have no plans to go public anytime soon are impressed by the speed with which the REIT's have moved. "Large institutions will play an increasing role," predicts Daniel Rose. "I would not be surprised if some of the family companies you see today do not survive in their present form." Marty Cohen takes Rose's prediction one step further. "Within the next 20 years or so," he says, "I would not be surprised if half of the visible buildings in Manhattan are owned by public companies."
Richard Fisher is not quite so sure. "I remember the recession in the 70's," he recalls, with a faraway look in his eyes. "I remember credit drying up. I also remember one lender walking into this office and suddenly demanding that a loan be paid off. I sent a messenger over there, and I enjoyed that experience immensely. I might also note that bank is out of business now. And that becomes part of your memory, too."
 On any weekday morning at around 8 o'clock at the Regency Hotel, you might find Henry Kissinger conversing with Bob Tisch while men at the surrounding tables get the inside scoop on the latest hot I.P.O. over egg whites and coffee. The atmosphere is understated and cozy, a combination of private club and neighborhood coffee shop for New Yorkers whose net worth numbers in the hundreds of millions. For anyone hoping to understand the role the family real-estate dynasties play in New York, Lew Rudin's table at the Regency is a good place to start.
The ambassador-at-large of Manhattan real estate, Rudin, 70, is a gruff, streetwise man known in the business as a compulsive talker and a soft touch. The first Rudin to own property in Manhattan was his grandfather Louis Rudinsky, an immigrant from Volozhin, Poland, who became a grocer on the Lower East Side. "What his father instigated in him," Rudin says, "was the love of freedom of religion and the freedom to own property, which he couldn't own in Europe." In 1902, Rudinsky invested his savings, site unseen, in an apartment house on 54th Street, on the wrong side of the tracks from the Rockefeller mansion. "We still own and operate that property," Rudin adds, "although now it's a 32-story office building."
As the founder and chairman of the Association for a Better New York, Rudin has also been a significant power behind the scenes -- eminence grise would be too geriatric-sounding a term for a man who can hit a half-dozen board meetings, cocktail parties and dinners in a single evening -- in the administrations of every Mayor since Abe Beame. "The secret of my relationship with the political world is, I never ask them for anything," he says. "So I owe them nothing. Most of the time, they owe me something."
Evidence of Lew Rudin's political muscle is not hard to find. Under his leadership, the families prepaid hundreds of millions of dollars in property taxes, as did other major real-estate taxpayers, during the 70's to keep New York afloat. When Morgan Stanley threatened to jump ship in the 80's, Rudin and Bob Tisch (whose own Manhattan holdings are considerable) convened a meeting to convince the bankers that leaving the city would be a mistake. "Moynihan, Rangel, the Cardinal, David Rockefeller -- it was intimidating," Rudin says. "Moynihan got up and said, 'I'm going to be the chairman of the Finance Committee.' Rangel got up and said, 'I'm the No. 2 guy on Ways and Means in the House.' In any event, we did them a favor. And they recognize it now."
Was the Mayor at the Morgan Stanley meeting? "I don't know who the Mayor was then," Rudin says, swatting the question away with the flat of his hand as he leans over the table. "Dinkins? Koch? I don't know if the Mayor was there." The look on his face is easy to read: Who cares?
The Rudins' latest development project, 55 Broad Street, is a textbook example of the families' ability to combine enlightened self-interest and political acumen to shape the city's future and to insure their prosperity for decades to come. The aging, asbestos-ridden, Rudin-owned building went dark for five years after the real-estate bust of 1990. Last year, 55 Broad Street was reborn as the Information Technology Center, a hive of flexible office space where content providers from companies like N2K, Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. sit in front of glowing blue computer screens -- thanks to a plan developed by the New York City Partnership, investments like the $40 million by the Rudins and generous incentives from the city and the state for tenants.
Padding around his office, showing off his pictures of Presidents and mayors, children and grandchildren, Rudin notes that this very office building was constructed on the site of the grade school attended by his father, Sam, at the turn of the century. It was completed in 1969 with a 120-year ground lease held by the U.S. Steel pension fund. Twenty years later, in the late 80's, the Rudins purchased the lease for $25 million. What does the future hold for the Rudins? "Owning the land here is going to be very good for my children and grandchildren," Rudin says. "I would say we got a very good deal."
 The Prudential Insurance Company's March 17 announcement that the three remaining sites it controls in Times Square are up for grabs set off an immediate scramble for financing and tenants among the families and their corporate rivals, REIT's included. As the latest battle in the Manhattan real-estate wars began, however, one winner was already apparent: the Dursts. "All of us here grew up involved not just with real estate but with New York City and its operation," says Douglas Durst as various cousins and nephews and in-laws, gathered around a polished conference table in one of the Durst Organization's buildings, nod their assent. "And because this is a family business, we're not thinking about tomorrow or next week. We're thinking about our children and grandchildren, and so we do develop buildings and begin planning them 20 and 30 years before they are actually built."
The Dursts are pleasant but shy, communicating in sentences of three or four words punctuated by the occasional glance or stare. If they are not the most colorful real-estate family in New York, they are, next to the Fishers, the richest, with a fortune estimated by Forbes at $650 million.
"I look at it as a puzzle -- putting all the pieces together," Douglas Durst says. "That's what interests me. Putting together the 4 Times Square site, for example, was an incredibly complicated puzzle." Eighty-six percent leased before the ground was broken last August, the 1.6 million-square-foot building will be the largest Durst-owned building yet. The tower itself, a model of which sits on the table at the far end of the room, reflects the family's emphasis on state-of-the-art materials and boiler plants over glitzy architecture and show. Durst says that the tax benefits attached to the site add up to $70 million. (Published reports put that figure at more than four times as high.)
"With that site," Durst says, "part of the puzzle was that the footprint was too small, although there were tax advantages that convinced me that it would be the next place somebody could develop. So we had to enlarge the site. We had to buy the main property from people we had spent the last couple of years suing and who weren't very fond of us, we had to buy more property we didn't own, we had to find financing and we had to do it all concurrently." Another part of the puzzle was the developer's apparent use of the press to send confusing signals to his rivals, first telling reporters that the days of large-scale building in the city were over and then, once the acquisition was announced, flatly denying that Conde Nast would be a tenant. (The publisher will be sharing the building with the law firm of Skadden, Arps.)
Durst's foxy, chess player's approach to the development business is, like the buildings he owns, an inheritance from his father, Seymour, who helped build the Durst Organization on the properties accumulated by his father, Joseph, a cobbler's apprentice from Poland who purchased his first building in Manhattan in 1915. A puckish man known among his peers for his sly humor and eccentricities, Seymour Durst turned his Manhattan townhouse into a shrine for his private collection of New York City historical materials (including a room lined with billboards from the old Times Square) and indulged what appears to have been a case of true graphomania by sending countless letters to city newspapers and serving as a columnist for Street News, the publication distributed by the homeless. Seymour Durst was also the premier site assembler of his generation, using byzantine chains of shell companies to disguise his intentions from sellers and rivals. Insisting that he would never buy anything he couldn't walk to, he built an empire that is currently unrivaled in its profitability, strategic concentration and 98 percent occupancy rate.
Which may explain why, when it comes to the REIT's, the latest in the family's long line of competitors, Douglas Durst does not seem worried at all. "Our goal is to be the last company being fought over by the REIT's," he says. Around the polished wood conference table, the Dursts look at one another and smile. "My own feeling is," Douglas continues, as if stating the obvious, "that the REIT's will get into trouble, the public will get disenchanted and they will disappear off the face of the earth."
 Whether the real-estate families of Manhattan will survive the passing of the current generation with the power and glory of their empires intact, however, remains an open question -- and not just because of the arrival of the REIT's. Outside the sleek modernist conference room of the Rose Associates' office hangs a black-and-white photograph of Manhattan as seen from the sky immediately after World War II. Shaded pathways wind through Central Park. The Chrysler Building glints in the sun. Other features of the landscape, however, are not so familiar. The saw-toothed piers are filled with dozens of ships unloading passengers and cargo onto bustling docks. The peaks of midtown and Wall Street, an Everest-like mountain and its smaller, no less ambitious cousin, tower over a landscape that seems startling in its flatness. "Every street corner had a crane," instructs Elihu Rose, standing in front of the picture and slipping into his familiar role as family historian. "And we had our share," adds his older brother, Fred.
The office towers that line the avenues of the city today, rising 40 and 50 stories into the sky, are impressive symbols of the families' rise from immigrant poverty to wealth and power. Nearly a century after that rise began, however, perhaps the most telling criticism of the city that the families have built is that part of it is missing. The buildings are bigger and the families are richer, but the legions of artisans who did the millwork, made the door bucks and windows and lent their skills to Manhattan's once vibrant building trades are gone. Where 60,000 residential units were built in the city in 1963, residential construction in 1995 was just over 7,000 units. Among the surprisingly large number of those in the families who agree with at least some part of this critique is John Tishman, whose family construction business built the World Trade Center, the Hancock Tower in Chicago and Century City in Los Angeles. "It's no coincidence that all of a sudden we have no good housing," Tishman says. "The Government gave these incentives for commercial buildings, whereas good planned housing, as a social thing, is what the Government should have been supporting."
As the current generation of real-estate moguls dies off or retires and family estates are divided, it seems safe to predict that at least some of the mammoth glass-and-steel towers so lovingly pictured in the family brochures will appear someday in shareholders reports sent out by the REIT's. As REIT holdings grow, families that stay in business are ever more likely to form REIT's of their own, or to merge their holdings with those of existing REIT's in exchange for cash and a share of the power. It is also true that REIT managers, with shareholders to satisfy, will have even less of an incentive than the city's current landlords to worry about new street lamps or after-school programs or multimillion-dollar donations to hospitals and museums. For REIT investors, however, Manhattan real estate will continue to look good -- as long as the current boom continues.
But as the families know only too well, no boom lasts forever. When the dust settles on the next Manhattan real-estate bust -- and eventually there's always a bust -- chances are that with a few additions and subtractions, the landscape will look very familiar.

HEADLINE: New Petersen Owners Take Aggressive Stance in Magazine World

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
Less than a year after taking control, the new owners of the Petersen Companies are preparing to seek the rewards of reshaping the company that publishes Motor Trend, Hot Rod, Teen and 70 other special-interest magazines.
With its automotive focus, Petersen was better known in Detroit than in traditional publishing circles. Now, its new owners, a coalition of private investors and publishing executives, are working to raise the company's profile on Madison Avenue and Wall Street. 
 Since emerging last August as the surprise winning bidder for the Los Angeles-based magazine empire begun by Robert E. Petersen in 1948, its new top executives, D. Claeys Bahrenburg and Neal Vitale, are decisively reshaping the company.
Mr. Bahrenburg, the former president of Hearst Magazines, and Mr. Vitale, the former general manager of the Hollywood trade paper Variety, folded the money-losing Sassy into their other youth title, Teen. They moved their sales team to New York and met with ad agency executives. And they struck such licensing deals as a Motor Trend cable television show, and rolled out 11 new publications, including ones for shotgun lovers and Volkswagen die-hards.
"Historically, Petersen undermarketed itself," said Steven R. Greenberger, vice president and director of print media for Grey Advertising. "The old owners felt the magazines sold themselves."
The new management's more aggressive stance, along with strength in the magazine market, is already improving Petersen's operations. Last week, Petersen signaled its intent to take that good news to investors with a first-time public offering of as much as $172 million in stock in the next few months. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said it planned to use the proceeds to repay some of its $277 million in debt and redeem some preferred stock.
Before the S.E.C. filing, some industry executives had estimated the company would be valued at more than $700 million. That sum would surprise industry skeptics, who last fall were quick to deride as excessive the $463 million price agreed to by Petersen's buyers, which include Willis Stein & Company of Chicago and the Dunning Group, based in Stamford, Conn.
There was reason for skepticism, since Petersen in its peak year of 1994 posted profits of only $19 million. In 1996, Petersen lost $47.7 million as a result of the debt load from the buyout of the company.
This year, though, Petersen's new management has made significant strides. For the first six months of 1997, revenue rose 4 percent, to $120 million, compared with the first half of 1996. Moreover, the company's operating cash flow before taxes, interest and other items rose threefold, to $30 million, the company said in a statement last month.
But $31.3 million in interest and payouts to preferred stockholders left the company with a $20.4 million loss in the half-year period, said Mr. Vitale, Petersen's president and chief operating officer.
Still, "it's more of a windfall than they bargained for," said one executive whose company dropped out of the bidding for Petersen.
Asked about the company's rationale for making a public stock offering so soon, Mr. Vitale said: "It's a strong market. Who knows how long it will last."
Brad Freeman, a founder of Freeman Spogli & Company, a Los Angeles buyout firm that acquired Vibe and Spin magazines and also bid for Petersen, had a similar view. "You raise money when you can, not when you need it," he said.
Mr. Vitale said proceeds from the stock offering would be used to retire $60 million in debt and $50 million in preferred stock. "With less leverage, our debt capacity would rise," he said.
Some magazine industry executives expect Petersen to use part of the proceeds to buy other periodicals. Petersen has been mentioned in the advertising press as one of the companies interested in the six tennis, sailing and ski magazines put up for sale by The New York Times Company in March.
Mr. Vitale declined to say if any remaining proceeds from the stock offering would be used to expand Petersen's portfolio of titles.
Nancy Nielsen, a spokeswoman for the Times Company, said the company's policy was not to comment on potential deals of any kind.
While the magazine industry has generally benefited from a rising economy and increasing advertiser spending, circulation figures for big glamour books have stagnated in recent years. One of the few areas of real growth are niche publications that cater to special-interest audiences, such as the teen-age girls and automotive buffs that Petersen reaches. Its best-known magazine, Motor Trend, has a circulation of 1.15 million, making it the best-selling auto monthly.
In the last year, the K-III Communications Corporation, a rival media company, has also begun mining this vein, focusing on the automotive sector that Petersen had dominated. In recent weeks, K-III acquired such titles with tiny cult followings as Low Rider, Muscle Mustangs and Vette, and now boasts it is the nation's largest automotive enthusiast publisher by number of titles and advertising pages. The category caters to those whose passion is customizing their vehicles and to advertisers whose gadgets are not driven by Detroit's economic cycles.
Luck helped make the new owners of Petersen look prescient rather than profligate. Prices for the 84 million pounds of paper Petersen bought annually rose sharply in 1995, cutting into Petersen's earnings. But paper prices have since declined, and that cut $4.2 million from Petersen's 1996 operating costs, part of $25 million in expenses eliminated by the new owners in the first quarter, according to a securities filing in January. Other savings included $11 million in personnel costs, $3 million on bad software and nearly $1 million for "excess travel and entertainment expenses."
Such expenditures were part of the old company's culture. Bob Petersen, the company's founder, was known for his hunting expeditions, in which he would bring an entourage of advertisers and editors along to Africa or the Arctic. The seventh floor of Petersen's old headquarters on Sunset Boulevard was known as Polar Bear Square for its game trophies that included a seven-foot-tall white bear.
"It was his personal playground," a former Motor Trend editor said. "He went on his own instincts. His passions were cars and guns."
Mr. Petersen, who grew up in California desert towns where his father was a mechanic, began with a single title, Hot Rod, that he hawked from his motorcycle at race tracks. Over the decades, Mr. Petersen repeated that formula, creating periodicals that catered to his interests like Guns and Ammo and Dirt Rider.
Now nearly 71, Mr. Petersen has no heirs to whom he could pass along his magazine empire.
Even before the sale, Forbes magazine said Mr. Petersen was worth $400 million. He retains a 15 percent stake in his old company.

HEADLINE: A Newspaper for Half a Hemisphere?

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Long before the first copies of Tiempos del Mundo ever hit the newsstand last year, the flashy, Spanish-language newspaper that is linked to the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church was making headlines of its own.
At the newspaper's gala inauguration, former President George Bush called Mr. Moon a "visionary" for creating Tiempos del Mundo, or Times of the World, an 80-page tabloid that its backers said would be distributed by satellite to almost every country in North and South America. 
 But critics strongly denounced Tiempos del Mundo as just another vehicle for the Unification Church to proselytize Latin America, where the Korean-based sect has invested hundreds of millions of dollars in real estate, hotels, banks and other businesses.
Today, nine months after its introduction and $10 million in start-up costs, Tiempos del Mundo is struggling to get off the ground, burdened by logistical problems and its association with Mr. Moon's church, which is viewed with great skepticism in Latin America. Its proprietors say it has a circulation of 5,000 in Buenos Aires and 5,000 around the rest of the continent, but those figures are unaudited.
"Tiempos del Mundo is insignificant as far as the newspaper market is concerned here in Buenos Aires," said Pepe Eliaschev, one of Argentina's most respected journalists. "I've never seen a colleague of mine reading that paper or even talking about it. It's very clear to everyone that this paper is a Moonie outlet, and no one here has forgotten that in the name of anti-Communism, his church supported the military dictatorships of the 1980's."
While media experts believe the market is ripe for Spanish-language publications like Tiempos del Mundo that exploit growing economic, political and cultural links between countries in the hemisphere, the Moon publication seems far from reaching its ambitious goal of publishing daily local editions in every country of the Americas from Canada to Chile.
The paper's front page does, however, reflect its larger ambitions. Tiempos del Mundo typically has one main story with a banner head, a large photo, and five or six lines of type summarizing the story. Above and below the lead story are headlines from around the region and to the left is a digest of sports, business, arts and technology reports from various countries.
The newspaper, which is edited in Buenos Aires and distributed in 17 countries, is currently printed only weekly. There has been little advertising -- most of what there is comes from local businesses, including a Uruguayan bank, some continuing education programs, a few restaurants in Buenos Aires and some Argentine radio stations.
Meanwhile, other regional publications oriented toward Latin America have been relatively successful in capturing large readerships and advertising dollars, including Newsweek in Spanish, an expanded Reader's Digest in Spanish and The Wall Street Journal Las Americas.
Started in 1994, The Wall Street Journal Las Americas publishes two pages in Spanish or Portuguese inside the business sections of 20 leading Latin American papers with a total circulation of 2.5 million. Newsweek began publishing an edition in Spanish in May 1996. It has a circulation of about 54,100.
In addition, Latin America has seen an explosion in the number of 24-hour Spanish news services that are also seeking to tap what analysts say is a growing demand for regional news in Spanish. Among the leading players in the television news market are CNN en Espanol; Eco, a subsidiary of Televisa Group of Mexico, and Telenoticias, which is owned by CBS.
Establishing a pan-American newspaper with a common voice and identity will not come easy, mainly because Latin America is not a Spanish-speaking monolith but a mosaic of distinct countries, each with its own culture, nationalistic fervor and journalistic tastes.
Beyond those questions, concerns about the paper's ownership persist. "Certainly there is a market for hemispheric publications like Tiempos del Mundo, but what concerns me and many readers the most is whether this is a legitimate journalistic operation or a proselytizing instrument of Rev. Moon's sect," said Rosenthal Calmon Alves, a professor of journalism at the University of Texas College of Communications who specializes in Latin America.
"That's the biggest obstacle this paper will have to overcome," the professor said. "I get scared when I hear that Rev. Moon is involved."
The paper's editors maintain that Mr. Moon, who has suggested in his religious teachings that he is the Messiah, has absolutely no influence on the publication's editorial content and that his investment and civic activities are independent from his spiritual leadership.
"We have absolute freedom to pursue whatever story we please, and there will never be any intervention from Moon or the church," said Jose Cardinale, the paper's editor in chief. "If we didn't have such freedom, we couldn't have convinced so many well-established journalists to come and work for us."
But critics have expressed concern that the church's connection with big business will give the church undue influence in Latin America.
Tiempos del Mundo is published by News World Communications Inc., which owns The Washington Times, a conservative daily; the Spanish-language Noticias del Mundo of New York and the evening newspaper Ultimas Noticias of Montevideo, Uruguay. News World Communications is controlled by a board that has close ties to Mr. Moon.
Officials of Tiempos del Mundo said that the publication had been unfairly selected for criticism because of its association with the church but that Tiempos del Mundo was back on course and expected to be publishing daily local editions in every country of the hemisphere by the end of the year.
"We want to be to Latin America what USA Today is to the United States," Mr. Cardinale said. "Our target audience is the middle- and upper-class business traveler who is somewhat family oriented. Since our paper will be in every hotel and airport and newsstand, readers will become familiar with us."
Newspaper officials said that they expected circulation and advertising to rise quickly once Tiempos del Mundo was up and running throughout the region. To be profitable they said the paper should gain between 200,000 and 500,000 subscribers within the next five years.
"We knew the first year would be weak in terms of advertising because basically we couldn't sell what hadn't been launched yet," said Richard Pera, who is the continental coordinator for Tiempos del Mundo. "Once all our countries are on line, we will be in a position to capture both local and regional advertisers who want to market their products to a wider audience."
Mr. Pera said that, as it did with The Washington Times, News World Communications was prepared to sustain heavy losses to underwrite Tiempos del Mundo until it could stand on its own. He said that the company planned to make another $10 million investment to introduce local editions and go daily and that its total investment in the publication could run as high as $50 million over the long term.
"The reason nobody has introduced a daily product like this before is because it would be foolhardy to do so without having something to get people hooked," Mr. Pera said. "I think our association with Rev. Moon gave us more promotion than we could have bought. And over time people will begin to focus on the product and forget about Rev. Moon."

HEADLINE: United Parcel Asks Clinton To Intervene In Walkout

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Officials at the United Parcel Service stepped up their calls yesterday for President Clinton to intervene to end the week-old teamsters' strike, but Administration officials said Mr. Clinton was leaning strongly against such action.
Because the negotiations broke down indefinitely on Saturday, United Parcel executives said Mr. Clinton should use his powers under the Taft-Hartley Act, which authorizes the President to seek a court order to end a strike when the nation's economy or safety is imperiled. 
 "Certainly the strike has had a devastating impact on our customers and our people," James Kelly, the company's chairman, said yesterday on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." Then, referring to President Clinton, he added, "We would certainly encourage him to become involved."
But the leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters insisted that invoking Taft-Hartley would be improper interference in the collective bargaining process.
Last Monday, 185,000 drivers, loaders and sorters went on strike against U.P.S., the nation's largest shipping company, in a dispute over pay, pensions and part-time jobs.
Appearing on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman indicated that the Clinton Administration was not seriously considering seeking an injunction against the walkout.
"We don't believe that this situation has reached the state of what we define as a national emergency, as it is defined in the Taft-Hartley legislation," she said.
On the ABC News program "This Week," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin added that Taft-Hartley "has very stringent requirements. It hasn't been invoked in over 20 years. In fact, the last time a President tried to use it, he was rebuffed by the courts."
Mr. Rubin insisted that the Administration was following the proper course by pushing both sides to return to the bargaining table to resolve the dispute, which involves more workers than any other strike in this decade.
Both union and management said they would be happy to confer with Administration officials, but neither indicated that formal negotiations would resume soon. The two sides had held 21 hours of talks on Thursday, Friday and Saturday with a Federal mediator, but they broke up when both sides said it was useless to continue the negotiations.
Also appearing on "This Week," John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, made it clear that organized labor was opposed to invoking Taft-Hartley. "There's no national emergency right now, and we have a right in this country to bargain collectively," he said. "We have a right to strike."
Both labor and management sought public support yesterday.
Appearing on "Face the Nation," Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president, said, "We're talking about vital issues that are so important to Americans, issues about part-time workers. What we have going on in this country -- and U.P.S. is the biggest violator -- is that more than half of their work force are part-time workers with low wages."
The union is angry that 38,000 of the 46,000 union jobs the company has added over the past four years have been part-time jobs, which teamsters officials say do not pay enough to support a family. Full-time drivers average $19.95 an hour after two years. Part-time loaders average $9 and part-time sorters $10, with pay rising to about $11 after five years.
Mr. Carey argued that the company could easily transform thousands of part-time positions into full-time jobs because in an average week, some 10,000 part-time U.P.S. employees work at least 35 hours.
Mr. Kelly, the company's chairman, insisted that the union was blowing the part-time issue out of proportion. He said that many of the company's workers were college students or others who wanted to work part time and not full time.
He also defended the company's part-time jobs, contending that they were better than those at many other companies.
"We've created tens of thousands of jobs during the course of this last contract," Mr. Kelly said. "Some of them have been full-time jobs. Some of them have been part-time jobs. The part-time job at U.P.S. is a great job. The average wage is $11 an hour. They receive a full level of benefits. They have 25 paid days off."
The strikers welcomed Mr. Kelly's statement that the company did not plan to hire replacement workers. Such a move would have turned up the pressure on the strikers, but the company might have found it hard to replace 185,000 workers while the unemployment rate was so low.
"The last thing we want to do, the last thing I want to do, is replace U.P.S. workers," Mr. Kelly said. "We want the strike to end and we want them back on the job."

HEADLINE: U.S. Increasing Its Dependence On Oil Imports

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
American drivers are consuming record quantities of gasoline so far this year, with about half refined from imported oil.
Indeed, the nation's dependence on imported oil is also setting records as domestic production of oil slowly declines. 
 The prospect, oil industry experts say, is for all these trends to continue robustly, at least as long as the economy remains strong. But the heavy demand means that any sharp increase in gasoline prices would have an even bigger effect on the American economy.
The soaring gasoline consumption is driven by more than just the strong economy, though. A long period of relatively low oil and gasoline prices has led to a change in the types of vehicles on the roads: The cars and trucks reaching the junkyards this year have higher gasoline mileage, on average, than the new ones rolling off dealers' lots, for the first time on record. As a result, the introduction of new cars and trucks, which had previously helped conserve gasoline because of the vehicles' fuel efficiency, is now adding to the demand.
Because of that shift, and because an increase in the car population is swelling the total miles driven by 2 percent to 3 percent every year, gasoline consumption in June was the highest ever for that month. The same was true for May and will probably be true for July, although statistics for that month have not been reported.
Despite the increased consumption, the Government reported on Tuesday that gasoline prices on average have fallen by 7 cents a gallon since January and could drop more this year. According to the Energy Information Administration, the national average price of a gallon of regular unleaded self-serve gasoline was slightly more than $1.19 as of Aug. 4.
Oil imports, which account for about 50 percent of consumption, fill far more of Americans' petroleum needs than they did at the beginning of the first oil crisis in 1973, when they accounted for 36 percent of the oil supply. American production is declining because it is easier to obtain oil from other countries than from the dwindling reserves in the United States.
Imports reached more than 10 million barrels a day in April. They may decline when the peak summer driving season ends, but for the first half of the year they averaged 9.9 million barrels a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's trade association. In contrast, imports were less than two-thirds as large, about six million barrels a day, in the last two oil crises, in 1973-74 and 1979, both of which provoked recessions because crude oil prices soared.
The rise in imported oil means that the Strategic Petroleum Reserve -- which was established after the first oil crisis as a hedge against future shortages -- is becoming a smaller and smaller shield. The reserve is not growing despite rising demand; indeed, it has shrunk several times after Congress voted to sell oil to help balance the budget.
While oil experts say that the United States is not vulnerable to a single country's cutting off supplies because oil comes from so many countries, the increase in fuel consumption means that any increase in gasoline prices most likely would have a bigger effect on the economy.
Behind the surge in demand for gasoline is a big change in consumption patterns. The Environmental Protection Agency recently estimated that over the lifetime of the vehicles in the 1996 model year, the mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles would together use more gasoline than the cars. If that trend continues, within a few years all the cars on the nation's roads will be consuming less than half the gasoline that is sold.
Two decades ago, Congress required that the average car get 27.5 miles a gallon, but mileage of the 1996 model year has declined to 24.6 miles a gallon because cars make up only 60 percent of the fleet.
"Back in 1975, when the statistics started, trucks were a 19 percent market share," said John M. DeCicco, a senior associate at the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy. "They felt it was such a small and insignificant part of the market, they would just leave it to the Department of Transportation" to set a standard.
But such light trucks, which include mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, have since doubled their share of the automotive market. At the same time, auto makers have persuaded Congress to bar the Transportation Department from raising the minimum fuel efficiency on light trucks, which is 20.7 miles a gallon.
In response to the oil shortages of the 1970's and the price spike of 1979-80 after the revolution in Iran, auto makers shifted their production to more-fuel-efficient vehicles. As a result, by the time oil prices crashed in 1986, these cars and trucks dominated the market, bringing the fleet's average gas mileage to its highest, 25.7 miles a gallon in 1986 and 25.9 miles a gallon in 1987 and 1988. Then it began falling again.
By 1994, 1995 and 1996, the fleet average for those model years had fallen to 24.6 miles a gallon, and E.P.A. experts say the number will be the same, or perhaps slightly lower, when the 1997 numbers are calculated later this year. For years, fleet economy improved because vehicles that got more than 20 miles a gallon were replacing the inefficient pre-1973 models that got less than 20. But most of those old cars have long since been junked, and those that remain are not used much.
The average car or light truck lasts about 12 years, so the vehicles leaving the fleet now are the ones from the mid- to late 1980's, which had the highest fuel efficiency.
And new vehicles are driven more than old ones, experts say, with multi-vehicle households taking the newer car or truck on the longer trips, so the least-fuel-efficient models are already racking up most of the miles.
With a booming economy, the demand is also strong for jet fuel. Diesel is in big demand, too, because of the economy and a shift to just-in-time manufacturing that has helped create a boom in trucking.
In the face of this rising demand, Congress and the Clinton Administration are debating about what to do with the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which was established after the Arab oil embargo of 1974 to cope with interruptions in supply. But the debate is not over whether to add to the reserve, which has not happened since 1994. Instead, the question is whether to continue draining some of the oil from the underground salt domes in Louisiana and Texas where it is stored and selling it to pay the reserve's operating costs. The Government has sold 28 million barrels in the last two years.
Earlier this year, the House of Representatives and the Senate Appropriations Committee voted to sell $200 million more worth of oil, or about 10 million barrels. But under the Federal budget agreement signed into law last week, no more oil will be sold, although Congress has still not resolved how to pay the reserve's operating costs.
Even without sales, the reserve is shrinking, as measured by the number of days of imports it could replace, because imports are on the rise. Measured that way, the reserve reached its peak in 1985, when it had 493 million barrels but was equal to 115 days. Now, at 566 million barrels, it equals 67 days. Federico F. Pena, the Secretary of Energy, told the Energy and Natural Resources committee in May that this would dwindle to 46 days by 2002.
In addition, the reserves are getting smaller relative to world oil production, which was 52 million barrels a day when the American reserve was established. Now production totals 74 million barrels a day and is expected to rise by 1.5 million to 2 million barrels a day each year.
C. Kyle Simpson, senior policy adviser to Mr. Pena, said the reserve was no longer intended to physically replace oil that had been blocked by, say, another Middle East war. Rather, he said, an interruption anywhere in the global oil market would be followed by a worldwide price increase. Gas lines would not develop again in the United States, officials say, because prices would rise until demand adjusted to reduced supply.
But a sale from the reserve could push prices down again, experts inside and outside Government say, as was the case when President George Bush sold oil from the reserve in 1991 after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

HEADLINE: Mayor Extols the Benefits Of Tax-Free Shopping Week

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Making the most of an election-year gift from the Legislature, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ventured into the Manhattan Mall in Herald Square yesterday to announce the suspension of the sales tax on clothing purchases during the first week in September -- just in time for back-to-school shopping.
Taxes will not be charged Sept. 1-7 on individual clothing purchases under $100. Mr. Giuliani said the effort will help keep New Yorkers from shopping in Connecticut or New Jersey, where there is no sales tax on clothing. 
 Last month, the Legislature agreed to abolish the 4 percent state sales tax on clothing purchases of $100 or less beginning in 1999, after a persistent campaign by Mr. Giuliani. Legislators also agreed to allow two tax-free weeks for clothing sales: one this September -- two months before the mayoral election -- and another in September 1998.
The city held its first tax-free week in January, when clothing costing less than $500 was free of sales tax in much of New York State. Though Mr. Giuliani called the effort a resounding success, some economists said the impact of the experiment was likely to be more political than economic, with the Mayor benefiting the most.
All three Democratic mayoral candidates -- the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, City Councilman Sal Albanese and the Rev. Al Sharpton -- denounced the Mayor's attempt to shine the spotlight on his efforts yesterday, saying it was the lawmakers in Albany who made the actual decision.
Mr. Giuliani has waged a campaign against the unpopular 8.25 percent tax, which is made up of the 4 percent state tax, a 4 percent city tax and a one-quarter of 1 percent tax levied by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Appearing at the gleaming nine-story Manhattan Mall yesterday, Mr. Giuliani urged middle-class buyers to take advantage of the tax-free week.
"Traditionally this sales tax hits poor families hardest because they spend a large percentage of their incomes -- sometimes as high as 12 percent -- on clothes," he said. "As a result of our efforts in Albany, this sales-tax-exempt week will occur again next year and will become permanent on Dec. 1, 1999."
Appearing with the Mayor, Jack Perlman, a spokesman for Modell's Sporting Goods, said Modell's will try to make it easy for shoppers to determine which items are included in the exemption. The store will put signs above items that are exempt, he said, urging other stores to do the same.
The exemption applies to most clothing that is worn on the body, but there are exceptions that can be confusing: hair barrettes are taxable, for instance, but head scarves are not.
Mr. Giuliani said that he would work hard to get the message out about the tax-free shopping week, but he did not say how he would go about it.
During the tax-free week in January, Mr. Giuliani was criticized for using taxpayer dollars to take out radio and print advertisements encouraging people to shop. He defended the ads as a legitimate governmental effort to stimulate the city's economy.
In the weeks leading up to the next tax-exempt week, Mr. Giuliani said, "We'll figure out the best way to do it."

HEADLINE: Medicine Is Altering Tie To Government

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
When New York State announced last month that it had negotiated a $1.25 billion Federal aid package to help its hospitals and clinics make the adjustment to managed care, critics said an industry with intimate connections to the highest levels of state and local politics was being coddled once again.
In many ways, however, the aid package does not tell the story of a marriage, but of a breakup. Economists and health care experts say it reveals the cracks in an industry that is being forced to give up its decades-long dependence on planned, predictable, government-coordinated growth. The transition money, intended as a bridge into a new era of health care, will also hasten that transition, the experts say, undermining the old stability even as it clears the way for innovation. 
 New York medicine has often been compared to the subsidy-drenched agriculture industry: just as farmers are paid not to grow certain crops, medical schools in New York are paid not to train new doctors, to stave off a glut. A stark example of the industry's disconnection from market forces is the recession of the early 1990's: as much of the rest of the state's economy wilted, health care -- particularly in New York City -- was the only major industry to add jobs.
But the old system has had a tough time as big government's role has shrunk. In agribusiness, the retreat of subsidies has prompted farmers to experiment -- cotton farmers have planted corn and wild-rice growers have tried cranberries. In New York, the Medicaid adventure is likely to produce unforeseen spinoffs and experiments, too -- as well as some dead ends -- health experts and economists say.
The expected consequences of the Medicaid agreement are profound enough. It will shift 1.6 million people into managed care over the next three years, making it the largest such experiment in the nation. Health experts say that local neighborhood doctors' offices should increase in number as managed care takes hold, and that the job mix of the health industry will change; there will be fewer low-skilled workers in fields like hospital food service and more computer workers handling claims for health-maintenance organizations.
The stakes are enormous: New York takes in nearly one-sixth of the entire Federal Medicaid budget and educates one in five of the nation's doctors and dentists. Across the state in 1996, more than 1 in 11 jobs was in private health care, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. A study by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1995 said that the New York metropolitan region had a higher dependence on health care business -- about one in eight jobs -- than Boston, Chicago, Houston or Los Angeles. Statewide, the health care system was by far the largest employer last year, with 741,000 employees of private businesses alone.
Jarring changes certainly have been occurring in New York health care for years, as hospital consolidations, cost-cutting pressures and a competitive price setting structure for hospitals -- established earlier this year -- have shaken many of the old patterns.
The Medicaid agreement is expected to accelerate the pace of change sharply. This is partly because it is in the care of the poor that New York has been most generous to hospitals, and because a huge new enrollment in managed care will greatly expand the power of the managed care companies to press doctors and hospitals to cut costs.
Health care economists say managed care commonly moves the location of treatment away from hospitals and hospital-based clinics to local doctors' offices. The $1.25 billion in transition money is directly aimed at helping hospitals establish those off-site offices and train people to work in them. But James R. Tallon Jr., the president of the United Hospital Fund, a 118-year-old research and philanthropic organization, said that local neighborhood medical care had never been a tradition in New York, especially in poor areas.
For generations, beginning well before the social programs of the New Deal, health care for the indigent in New York has been based around institutions rather than doctors, Mr. Tallon said. When Medicaid was created, it solidified and codified a hospital-based system that was already deeply embedded. How the essentially suburban-bred system of managed care is to be grafted onto those old systems and traditions will be an exploration in itself, Mr. Tallon said.
New York's next recession is also likely to be different in the new era. Whenever the next downturn occurs, and whatever its severity, the health care industry's stalwart stability of years past may not be as bankable as it once was.
"Is health care still the ace in the hole for New York?" said Howard S. Berliner, a professor of health policy at the New School for Social Research. "The answer, I think, is probably not."
Professor Berliner said the main economic effect of Medicaid's shift to managed care would be felt in the job market. Health care will still be a large employer with a large economic presence, he said, but as a mass employer of people on the lower economic rungs -- low-wage, low-skill workers in 24-hour hospitals -- its best days are probably already a memory. Demand for such workers, Professor Berliner said, will decline along with the length of hospital stays and the shift to outpatient treatment. Jobs under managed care generally require better education and communication skills, he said.
Countering those fears somewhat is the fact that despite the Medicaid agreement, much of the state's stable old government medical system remains firmly in place. Of the $24 billion in combined Federal, state and local Medicaid money that is spent in New York each year, 40 percent will not be affected at all. That untouched sector is also one in which New York has been particularly tenacious and successful in getting matching Federal Medicaid dollars -- for services like long-term and psychiatric care.
And that sector could, in fact, grow. Health experts say that while managed care tends to shorten hospital stays for acute care, it often increases the demand for long-term care and rehabilitation. What the shift to managed care takes away with one hand may thus be given back by the other.
"There are going to be winners and losers," said Mr. Tallon at the United Hospital Fund. "Long-term is going to get bigger."
Federal aid to New York will also increase in a little-noticed health program called Home Relief, which serves about 370,000 poor people around the state. New York was able to negotiate a provision that will bring Home Relief, for the first time, under Medicaid and its provision for Federal matching funds. It will save New York State money, but Federal health care spending, at least in the short term, will go up.
New York State health officials say that New York has always received more of the Federal Medicaid budget because the state has been willing to spend more itself, under the 50-50 matching formula: spend a state dollar and you get an additional Federal dollar. How the state got $1.25 billion in transition money -- something none of the 13 states that have received approval for Medicaid managed care were able to get -- shows how much more there is to the story than that.
The largest union representing hospital workers, 1199, which is closely connected to the national Democratic Party, and the Greater New York Hospital Association, which has ties to the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki, coordinated to lead the charge. The union's president, Dennis Rivera, worked on Vice President Al Gore. The head of the hospital association, Kenneth Raske, worked on Albany. The argument was always the same, state officials said: In New York, health care means more than just medical treatment.
The State Health Commissioner, Barbara DeBuono, said that other states could perhaps afford not to calculate economic consequences, but in New York, she said, everyone does.
"Unlike a lot of states, we had to think about the consequences on the hospital industry," she said. "We're all just sort of feeding on each other -- it's a big, big business."

HEADLINE: Wrong Place for a Prison

 BODY:
The $68 billion budget approved by the New York State Legislature last week is crammed with special-interest items benefiting one regional interest or another at the expense of broader considerations. One such item authorizes $130 million for the design and construction of a new 1,500-bed maximum-security prison for violent offenders, smack dab in a valuable wilderness area of the Adirondacks.
There are several things to say about a proposal to quarantine murderers and rapists inside Adirondack Park, only one of them good. It would obviously bring new jobs to the northern town of Tupper Lake, a once-vibrant mill town that, like many poor Adirondack villages, needs an economic transfusion. That is why Ron Stafford, the State Senator who has long exercised almost total control over most legislation affecting the Adirondacks, worked so hard for this provision. The prison would be built in his district and would create, his staff says, between 400 and 600 jobs. 
 As is almost always the case in Albany, however, there were no public hearings on the idea and no attempts to reach out to environmentalists, planners and economists to see if there were better ways of increasing Tupper Lake's tax base or more benign sites to choose. Nor was there any public examination of whether the prison would damage the region's wilderness value.
Tupper Lake -- which already has a large state facility for retarded children -- is located in the northwest section of the park, known as the "Northwest Frontier." It is surrounded by large tracts of privately owned back country, which contain some of the most spectacular rivers and lakes in the park. If the state ever approves a plan to reintroduce the Eastern timber wolf to the Adirondacks, the Northwest Frontier is one place the wolves would go, in part because it replicates their original habitat.
More broadly, the prison proposal is yet another instance of the state's piecemeal, blinkered approach to the park as a whole. In his State of the State address last year, Gov. George Pataki promised to bring together local citizens, politicians and environmentalists to develop a comprehensive strategy to satisfy the economic needs of local residents without undermining what is still a largely unspoiled environment. That was precisely the approach he took to New York City's watershed. But so far there is no plan for the Adirondacks, just isolated initiatives that seem to come from nowhere, like the prison.
The prison proposal must still clear a few hurdles. The state's Department of Correctional Services must certify that the prison is in fact needed to house the state's violent offenders, and the State Comptroller, Carl McCall, must sign off on any spending contracts associated with the prison. But if the prison does go forward, it is crucial that Governor Pataki intervene to insure that it is sited in a way that does minimum damage to the town and the surrounding area.
In a jab at the environmental community, Mr. Stafford said that "reason and understanding" rather than "elitist arrogance" should prevail on the prison question. Fair enough, but so far environmentalists have had no real chance to sit down and reason with Mr. Stafford.

HEADLINE: Philosophies Differ on Future of Socrates Sculpture Park

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
In a Queens neighborhood of abandoned warehouses and scampering rats, Socrates Sculpture Park rises as a kind of crazy vision, a surreal space where gigantic contortions of steel, stone, wood and plastic sprout.
A caterpillar made from the yellow fenders of old taxicabs appears to squirm on the patchy grass. An array of logs forms a monumental bouquet. Immense steel beams seem almost ethereal in a work by the sculptor Mark di Suvero. Hundreds of mirrors transform an ordinary chain-link fence into an optical extravaganza. 
 But if artists supply the wonder, it is the location of this patch of city-owned land -- on the edge of the East River in Astoria, facing Manhattan's jagged, imperial skyline -- that makes for the majesty. This is at least a million-dollar view. In fact, it is a $100 million view, according to a neighborhood boy made good who is the latest in a long chain of developers trying to claim it.
And so, everything has come down to this: Can New York afford the luxury of allowing a bunch of messy, however inspired sculptors to claim a prime slice of municipal real estate, a place whose development might spur the economy of a dilapidated waterfront?
Angelo Joseph Acquista, a doctor and investor, has been making the rounds of Queens bureaucrats, the City Council and the local community board to propose investing $100 million to build 300 enormous apartments (with balconies), a large catering hall and a marina where wealthy Manhattanites would keep boats that could be delivered minutes after being requested. "This may be a way to bring a little bit of Manhattan into Queens," he said.
The doctor's proposal has gained momentum in part because he has enlisted one of his patients, former Gov. Hugh L. Carey, to help by visiting politicians and organizing financing, though official requests for zoning variances and environmental clearance have yet to be made. Mr. Carey is also furnishing his signature rhetorical flourish, trumpeting the proposed development as "the Queens equivalent of Sag Harbor."
Dr. Acquista, whose parents still live a few blocks from the park, recalls playing on a pier that used to be on the site, and swimming in long-gone floating swimming pools off to one side. He promises to restore these, as well as to offer the public more usable, and certainly more elegantly landscaped, parkland than Socrates provides. And yes, he said, he is eager to display large sculpture -- though he draws the line at allowing artists to fabricate pieces on site.
For many, that alone would be an incalculable loss. The Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, characterized "a set of sculptures in a condo courtyard" as a "sorry substitute" for the park cum outdoor studio.
More than 200 pieces of sculpture have already been created at Socrates in full view of the public. A sculptor working there now, John Clement, spoke of working to the point of exhaustion and suddenly being refreshed by a fresh breeze, or welding in the falling snow. And Tadashi Hashimoto, another sculptor, suggested that the garden possessed "an intangible energy."
That may come from the energy that went into creating a sculpture garden at such an unlikely spot, along a dip in the Queens coastline known as Hallett's Cove, at the treacherous juncture of the East and Harlem Rivers.
But Mr. di Suvero's studio is to the north of what became the park, and just to the south was the late sculptor Isamu Noguchi's studio, now a museum. In the 1980's, the area was a prime site of illegal dumping; there was no fence, and broken steel and abandoned cars defined the landscape. Mr. di Suvero and Mr. Noguchi looked at the garbage and envisioned a protected park that could provide an "ongoing experimental narrative" in the medium of sculpture.
The city agreed to let the sculptors use the land, but only temporarily. Hundreds of neighborhood volunteers pitched in to clean out truckloads of trash. After a year's work, the first exhibit was held in 1986. Since then, there have been two shows of 20 or so pieces a year. Children's education classes, lectures, tours and concerts have also been offered.
Mr. di Suvero and others continued to push for more permanent protection for the park, because developers for years had hungered to build luxury housing there but had been defeated by real estate recessions, lack of local amenities, distant transportation and other problems.
In 1993, the city agreed to make Socrates a park for five years. Though the deal can be unilaterally revoked by the city with one month's notice, the artists saw it as a major step toward securing the park's future. And Mr. di Suvero hopes that City Hall will side with him, if the development plan creates the kind of zoning debate that make political hay. In May, before Dr. Acquista began circulating his plan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wrote a note to those gathered for the opening of this summer's show. "I wish you the very best," the Mayor wrote, "and hope that you will continue your work for many years to come."
It may take a fight to decide who has rights to what. At the time Socrates was dedicated as a city park in 1994, Mr. di Suvero said that the city had wanted to develop the site, but "we fought nip and tuck to save it." But some insist that the park was never "saved" and had been only for temporary use until full-scale development could proceed.
"The problem is di Suvero has become entrenched," said George Delis, district manager of Community Board 1 and a strong proponent of development. "The problem is how to get rid of him."
It will not be easy. In a written message from Paris, where he is installing an exhibition of his work, Mr. di Suvero said he was deeply disturbed by anything that would threaten Socrates. "We hope to fly the Parks Department flag here forever," he said of the park.
The Parks Commissioner hopes so, too. "Socrates is a thriving park that has brought great sculpture to Queens," Mr. Stern said. "They should not be dispossessed."
Dr. Acquista says he will not proceed if his development proposal does not draw wholehearted support. "If the community doesn't support us, we have no business there," he said.
Walter L. McCaffrey, the City Council member who represents the area, said he was not convinced that Dr. Acquista would be any more successful than others who have tried and failed in the past. He pointed out that the area is home to several public housing projects, drug rehabilitation centers and homes for the mentally ill, as well as being a haunt of prostitutes. It is also nine blocks from the nearest subway station, and it is in one of the city's most overcrowded school districts, he said.
Instead, Mr. McCaffrey favors more development 20 blocks to the south, in Hunters Point, where the city has spent more than $30 million on sewers and other infrastructure and only one building of a planned luxury complex has so far been built.
Of the new development proposal, Mr. McCaffrey said, "It lacks substance."
Of Socrates, he said, "It's a world-class attraction."
