HEADLINE: Labor Secretary's Efforts Fail to Budge Negotiators in U.P.S. Dispute

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Labor Secretary Alexis Herman met yesterday with top negotiators for the teamsters' union and United Parcel Service as the Clinton Administration stepped up its efforts to resolve the eight-day-old strike.
Ms. Herman reported no progress after meeting for two hours with Ronald Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and then for two hours with David Murray, the chief U.P.S. negotiator. 
 In a statement issued after her meetings, Ms. Herman said she discussed in detail what it would take to get the parties back to the bargaining table after they broke off talks indefinitely last Saturday.
"I made it clear that everyone involved must show greater flexibility and a willingness to compromise," she said.
After meeting with the Labor Secretary, Mr. Murray said the company would stand by its latest offer. He again urged union leaders to let the rank and file vote on that offer.
U.P.S., the world's largest parcel-delivery company, wrote to members of Congress as a way to step up pressure on President Clinton to seek an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act to halt the strike.
But Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, again indicated the President's reluctance to take such a move.
"We can't solve the labor-management conflicts between the parties," Mr. McCurry said.
Mr. Clinton and other Administration officials have repeatedly said that the strike by 185,000 workers has not created the serious economic damage that would be required to invoke Taft-Hartley. Under the law, a President can ask a court to issue an injunction to stop a strike, but no President has invoked the act in more than two decades.
After his meeting with Ms. Herman, Mr. Carey, the union's president, said he urged her to press U.P.S. to negotiate about increasing wages and converting more part-time jobs into full-time jobs.
Mr. Carey said, "What has to happen here is that the company has to get the message that the Government is not going to intervene on their behalf. They've been playing games. They haven't been serious."
U.P.S. received some support from Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, when Mr. Gingrich called on Mr. Clinton to ask the union to let the rank and file vote on what the company has called its "last, best and final offer."
Teamster officials insist that the company's call for a rank-and-file vote is a ploy intended to sabotage the strike and divide the members from their leadership. Union officials assert that their members would overwhelmingly reject the company's offer, and they say the company wants the union to suspend the strike while the vote is taken, a move that would reduce the union's leverage.
In Nashville yesterday, a U.P.S. manager, Floyd Parta, was killed when the tractor-trailer he was driving plunged off a highway ramp. The company said Mr. Parta was licensed to operate the truck.
In Miami, the police said Roderick Carter, a U.P.S. worker who crossed the picket line, was stabbed on Thursday. The Associated Press said four men had been charged with attempted murder -- including two who were identified as U.P.S. workers -- and two other men were being sought.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan to Lead Group In $16 Billion Thai Rescue
The I.M.F. and a group of Asian nations led by Japan agreed to a $16 billion rescue of Thailand's troubled financial system, which has been jolted by a currency crisis that has spread through the region, threatening its rapid growth. 
 The loan package is the second-largest international bailout, though it is significantly smaller than the $50 billion rescue of Mexico from the peso collapse of 1994-95. [Page A1.]
 
Credit Suisse to Buy Big Insurer
Credit Suisse agreed to buy Winterthur Insurance of Switzerland for $8.8 billion, another in a series of deals that combines financial companies with insurers. [D4.]
 
Earnings Rise at Store Chains
Two large retailers, Nordstrom and May Department Stores, reported robust earnings for the second quarter. [D2.]
 
Chrysler Wins Aid for Jeep Plant
Chrysler has won a $232 million package of government incentives to invest $1.2 billion to build a Jeep assembly plant in Toledo, Ohio, and to upgrade an aging plant there. [D3.]
 
F.A.S.B. Sticks to Derivatives Plan
The Financial Accounting Standards Board said that it planned to adopt its proposed rules on accounting for derivative securities, despite recent criticism from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. [D2.]
 
Quick & Reilly Said to Seek Bids
Quick & Reilly Group, the big discount brokerage firm, has reportedly put itself up for sale, giving a dozen potential buyers a chance to submit preliminary bids. [D2.]
 
E.P.A. Wants Pollution Disclosure
If the Environmental Protection Agency has its way, people who live near hundreds of factories in several major industries -- including producers of oil products, steel and other metals, autos and paper -- will soon gain easy on-line access to mountains of data about the pollution given off by the plants. [A1.]
 
Dollar Rallies After Big Drop
The dollar rallied sharply from its selloff on Friday, helped by rebounding stocks and by doubts that the German central bank would raise interest rates. [D6.]
 
Treasury securities prices were flat, with the yield on the 30-year bond edging up to 6.64 percent from 6.63. [D15.]
 
TV Ad Campaign by A.F.L.-C.I.O.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has come up with a new capitalist wrinkle to woo workers to the union banner: slick broadcast spots. New ads for the 13-million-member labor group show workers, with hip music in the background, explaining how unions have helped them. [A12.]
 
BMW is getting back to basics with a campaign that parks recent pitches focused on attributes like safety and value in favor of taking the performance aspects of "the ultimate driving machine" for another spin. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
No Progress in Strike Talks
Labor Secretary Alexis Herman met with negotiators for U.P.S. and the striking teamsters but reported no progress. [A12.]
 
The teamsters say their main goal in the strike is for part-time workers to gain full-time jobs that pay enough for them to live on. But the company says it cannot transform many part-time jobs to full-time ones because its day is made up of busy bursts and long lulls. [A1.]
 
Union Pacific Discloses Offers
Union Pacific Resources Group disclosed in an S.E.C. filing that it had received offers from third parties that would be interested in buying Pennzoil assets or participating in joint ventures if Union Pacific's hostile bid for Pennzoil is successful. [D2.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.M.F., With the Help of Asians, Offers Thais $16 Billion Bailout

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund and a group of Asian nations led by Japan agreed today to a $16 billion rescue of Thailand's troubled financial system, which has been jolted by a currency crisis that has spread through South and Southeast Asia, threatening the region's rapid growth.
The package of loans, announced after a meeting here, is the second-largest international bailout, though significantly smaller than the $50 billion rescue of Mexico from the peso collapse of 1994-95. 
 The money will be used by Thailand to help shore up its foreign reserves, which were depleted by a futile attempt to save its currency, the baht, from being devalued last month. The reserves are needed to pay for imports and to meet some foreign-debt obligations.
Officials announcing the package called it a precedent-setting example of regional cooperation, as Asian nations acted to keep Thailand's problems from spreading. "What is impressive about the financial package this time is we have substantial contributions from the countries of the Asia-Pacific region," Eisuke Sakakibara, Japan's vice finance minister for international affairs, said at a news conference.
The United States attended today's meeting, as did Germany, Britain, France and Canada, but those nations are not taking part in the rescue directly. This appears to result in part from a feeling that the Asians, with the most at stake, can and should handle the problem.
Among the countries taking part, Japan -- Asia's dominant economy and with huge investments in Thailand -- is playing the leading role, contributing $4 billion. That matches the amount to be contributed by the International Monetary Fund. Australia, Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore will each contribute $1 billion, while Indonesia and South Korea will chip in $500 million apiece. The remaining $3 billion or so is expected to come from the Asian Development Bank, the World Bank and possibly from China. The loans will come due in three to five years, and will generally be in line with market rates.
In addition to the government and international lending agency help, Thailand is expected to receive billions of dollars in new financing from commercial banks, led by those in Japan. The Thai Finance Minister, Thanong Bidaya, is scheduled to meet with major Japanese banks on Tuesday. And Mr. Sakakibara of the Japanese Finance Ministry remarked, "I think the discussion between the Thai authorities and Japanese banks will proceed smoothly."
Once the paragon of a fast-growing Asian economy, Thailand has suffered a slowdown in exports because of new competition from China and other nations with lower wages, and also because the baht had been tied to a strengthening dollar. Even more damaging has been a huge-scale bad debt problem caused by overinvestment in real estate and factories.
After long denying the severity of its problems, the Thai Government was forced last week to agree to emergency measures to restructure its economy in return for the loans announced today.
Other Asian countries have an incentive to help Thailand because many of them are affected, though perhaps to a smaller degree, by the same economic problems and pressures on their currencies. However, previous agreements among Asian central banks to cooperate on currency stabilization were ineffective in preventing the recent turmoil.
Since Thai officials gave up trying to defend the baht -- allowing it on July 2 to float at market rates -- the currency has fallen about 20 percent against the dollar. The Philippine peso, Malaysian ringgit and Indonesian rupiah have fallen roughly 6 or 7 percent. Three and a half weeks ago, the International Monetary Fund approved a $1 billion loan to the Philippines to help it cope with the currency crisis.
But the problems in Thailand have wider effects, and pose a particular threat to Japan. Its auto makers control virtually all of the Thai car market; its electronics companies have made Thailand a big manufacturing and export base, and Japanese banks hold about half of the country's $89 billion in foreign debt. Already, some Japanese-owned auto plants in Thailand have had to slow operations because of the financial crisis.
Yet Tokyo, which since the end of World War II has been reticent about taking the lead in world affairs, has not played as strong a role as Washington did in rescuing Mexico. Although the Japanese are exercising influence, they have allowed the International Monetary Fund to be out in front. The rescue generated little controversy here, unlike in the United States when the Mexican bailout was proposed. There was perhaps some worry that Japan would set a precedent, that it might have to rescue other Asian nations in financial trouble. But by enlisting the help of other countries in the region, it mitigated such concerns.
Officials at today's meeting here said that Thailand required $14 billion for 1997 and 1998, so the $16 billion agreed upon should be more than enough for current needs.
While the rescue package is expected to shore up international confidence in Thailand, the hard work of changing some aspects of the Thai economy lies ahead. Dissatisfaction in Thailand, both with the Government's perceived mishandling of the crisis and with the bitter economic medicine to follow, has caused speculation on a coup attempt, though the Prime Minister, Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, has insisted that he has full control of the often-assertive Thai military.
To qualify for the international bailout, Thailand agreed last week to reduce public spending, raise the value-added tax to 10 percent from 7 percent, and suspend the operations of 42 debt-ridden financial companies.
The nation's currency losses mean that interest payments on the Thai foreign debt have swelled 20 percent, as measured in baht. Prices on imports will climb, contributing to inflation. The slowdown in construction, factory production and consolidation of the financial industry is expected to increase unemployment.
"We realized the devaluation of the baht will create some inflationary pressure in Thailand," Mr. Thanong, the Finance Minister, said at the news conference today. "But somehow we feel it's a necessary step to make Thai exports more competitive."
He predicted that Thailand will grow 3 percent this year and 4 percent next year, well down from growth of more than 6 percent in 1996 and the 9 percent spurts that were once considered normal. Mr. Thanong said he expected Thailand to resume rapid growth in 1999. Some economists find these projections optimistic.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Japan joined the International Monetary Fund yesterday in bailing out Thai finances. At a Tokyo briefing, the Thai Finance Minister, Thanong Bidaya, left, was joined by Eisuke Sakakibara, a vice finance minister. (Associated Press)(pg. D4)

HEADLINE: Budget Deal Creates Heat for District of Columbia's Delegate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
For years, she has been the city's most popular public official, a landslide winner in every election who moves easily across the ethnic and economic lines that often fracture the community spirit of the nation's capital.
Yet not since she was first elected to Congress as the District of Columbia's nonvoting delegate in 1990 has Eleanor Holmes Norton's popularity faced such a hard test. 
 With new Federal legislation shifting the power of running the city from elected officials to appointed overseers, Ms. Norton has suddenly been caught in the political storm of her life, one largely of her own creation. Initially an ardent supporter of the measure for its enormous financial benefits to the city, she turned into a vociferous critic after residents expressed outrage that the law costs them their sovereignty.
Ms. Norton, a Democrat, is now hearing constituents question whether her loyalties are to her party or her people.
"She has been too addicted to being on the prevailing side, rather than a principled side," said Lawrence Guyot, a supporter of local self-government and a friend of Ms. Norton for decades. "She has an awful lot of explaining to do."
To defuse tensions and avert growing strains between the mostly black city leadership and the Clinton Administration, Ms. Norton met today with President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore to discuss how to swing back the pendulum of power, even if slightly, to the city's elected officials from a financial control board appointed by Congress two years ago.
She emerged from the meeting with what appeared to be a forced smile and with the promise of a strategy: she said the Administration would try to amend the law to give the District Council a meaningful role in confirming heads of city agencies.
The Council and Mayor lost that right to the control board as part of the new legislation.
"He suggested it even before I raised it," Ms. Norton said of Mr. Clinton. "It was a mistake in the legislation. We both feel it's a place to begin so we can work our way back to full self-government."
The changes in local governance were part of the Federal budget bill that Mr. Clinton signed last week. The measure included almost $1 billion over five years as well as new management restraints on the local government demanded by the Republican leadership of Congress.
The legislation gave the control board many bold new powers that were once the province of the mayor and District Council, including the right to hire private consultants to run the city's major agencies. Earlier, the control board appointed a board of trustees to run the public school system, in place of the elected school board.
Ms. Norton, who has been a strong supporter of home rule for the District, initially hailed the legislation, largely for the financial relief, but also for what it did not include, the creation of a city manager form of government, which she said would have usurped even more authority of the local government, leaving the mayor as little more than a ribbon-cutter. "A big win" for the city, Ms. Norton called the measure last week, "an extraordinary deal for the District."
But a groundswell of protest erupted. Marion S. Barry Jr., who has been Mayor for 15 of the last 19 years, called the change "a rape of democracy" that turned the calendar back more than 25 years, to when unelected commissioners ran the city at the behest of Congress.
To many other District residents as well, the new law was a step backward. In protests staged last week in front of the White House and in a church where the control board was meeting, several hundred local residents demonstrated and more than a dozen were arrested.
The winds of disaffection reached Ms. Norton quickly, and she almost instantly changed her public stance.
By the weekend, she was protesting with the protesters, asserting that the deal was, in effect, a theft of fundamental rights and insisting that when the managerial changes were written into the law, "I was not in the room." She vowed to speak to the President.
After the half-hour meeting at the White House, she appeared with the Administration's point man on District matters, Franklin D. Raines, the Federal budget director, and told reporters it had been "an excellent exchange." She expressed her appreciation for the financial help in the form of the Federal Government's agreement, among other things, to assume the city's pension liability, to pay a greater share of Medicaid costs and to take over a prison.
She also maintained her position that there had been "no need, from the beginning, for Congress to legislate" the shift in powers.
Characterizing her change of heart as a move of political expediency, Mr. Guyot, the Norton critic, predicted that Ms. Norton could face a viable challenge in next year's election, even with her striking ability to attract votes: she won with 62 percent of the vote in 1990, 85 percent in 1992, 89 percent in 1994 and 90 percent in 1996.
But Mark Plotkin, a local political analyst for public radio, said the fact that Ms. Norton had altered course so quickly would only solidify her position among voters.
"She made a strategic mistake," he said of Ms. Norton's original support for the measure. "But she might have helped herself by admitting she made a mistake and seeking to rectify it."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Martinez Clouts 38th To Support Pettitte

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The scorched baseball sailed off Paul Molitor's bat toward the left-field seats and virtually everyone at the Metrodome figured that the Twins would have no trouble scoring off Andy Pettitte in the third inning. But it turned very quiet after Chad Curtis raced to the warning track, backed up against the fence and gloved the ball. It was quiet and Pettitte kept it that way.
The scorched baseball clanged off the facing of the right-field luxury boxes and virtually everyone at the Metrodome turned into a Tino Martinez fan before he finished trotting out the three-run homer in the Yankee fourth. It was very loud, much louder than it should have been for an opposing player. 
 These two snippets underscored the Yankees' 11-0 victory tonight. Who could blame the fans for respectfully cheering Martinez's major league best 38th homer? They could not be excited about the pitching of Rich Robertson, who dropped his eighth straight decision as the Yankees concluded a 6-2 road trip with a season-high 21 hits.
Pettitte was the polar opposite of Robertson in nearly notching the second shutout of his career and his second in five weeks. The valiant left-hander stifled Minnesota on five hits in eight innings before yielding to Jim Mecir and permitted only two Twins to reach third base in winning his team-best 14th game. He struck out nine and walked three.
"It's usually a tough call, but tonight I was out of gas," said Pettitte, who whiffed two with the bases loaded in the eighth to keep the shutout intact. "I don't know how I got through the seventh, I was so stiff. I felt like I had good stuff tonight and I mixed it up."
Tonight was one of those nights that the Yankees proved how impressive a team they can be, while winning for the 11th time in the last 14 games.
"We're probably playing better now than we were last year," said Manager Joe Torre, whose 1997 team (69-47) has the identical record of the 1996 team after 116 games. "Last year, we were trying to protect a lead. This year, we're chasing. I sort of like the way we're doing it now better."
Pettitte pitched splendidly and the defense was sensational. But it was the hitting that was truly awesome. Martinez, who has the most homers by a Yankee first baseman since Lou Gehrig's 49 in 1936, also poked a run-scoring single to give him 108 r.b.i. Curtis, who socked five hits, now has seven in a row and might keep Tim Raines on the bench forever And Luis Sojo, the Mariano Duncan of this year, had three hits and scored twice.
Because the Yankees fashioned their best road trip since going 6-2 in Cleveland and Minnesota last June, they quietly sliced first-place Baltimore's bulge from six games to four and a half games in the last week. Torre has already admitted that the Yankees will probably not catch the Orioles if they do not sputter, but the two teams will meet eight times next month so Torre could be playing possum. More important for the Yankees, their slick play has enabled them to maintain a lead in the battle for the wild-card berth.
Pettitte was economical in squashing the Twins for the second time in 11 days. He bulldozed through a tough jam in the third. With runners on first and second, he whiffed Denny Hocking and exhaled, then heard the crowd go silent when Molitor's shot died on the warning track. The Twins died after that.
Robertson was more of a target than a pitcher in a four-run third. Bernie Williams hammered a one-out single off Robertson's left shin to put runners on first and second and Paul O'Neill's two-out chopper bounced off the left-hander's glove to knock in the first run. Charlie Hayes doubled in two runs and Curtis doubled in another for a 4-0 cushion.
With one out and Derek Jeter on third in the fourth, Manager Tom Kelly of the Twins had Robertson walk Williams and face Martinez. It was a poor decision because Martinez drilled an off-speed pitch 371 feet for a three-run homer.
"You know how Tino is, he's intense," Torre said. "He needed that one. He's a very intense guy. That three-run homer helped his personality. It helped ours, too."
 
INSIDE PITCH
KENNY ROGERS said the muscle stiffness between his right shoulder blade and spine that caused him to leave Sunday's game after three innings has subsided. The left-hander felt that he would be able to pitch in about five days and vowed that he would not go on the disabled list. "This isn't something you go on the d.l. for," Rogers said. "It's not that bad. I ain't going on the d.l." Manager JOE TORRE said Rogers would be evaluated in a few days. . . . TIM RAINES will be activated Tuesday and DARRYL STRAWBERRY was expected to follow him to the majors this weekend. . . . The Yankees claimed the right-handed pitcher JOSE ALBERRO off waivers from Texas, where he was 0-3 with a 7.94 earned run average in 10 games. He was optioned to Class AAA Columbus. . . . Outfielder SCOTT POSE will likely be demoted to Columbus when Raines is activated, with pitcher JIM MECIR expected to join him once HIDEKI IRABU is promoted Wednesday. MARK WHITEN or PETE INCAVIGLIA will be sacrificed when Strawberry arrives.

PUB-DATE: August 12, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2148 words

HEADLINE: Where Tribe Saw Promise, Democrats Saw Pledge

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
In June 1996, Charles Surveyor, an American Indian leader from Oklahoma, found himself in heady company at a White House luncheon. Along with top executives of a handful of big companies, he was getting to make his case to the President, and this was his best chance, Mr. Surveyor thought, to win the return of 7,500 acres taken by the Government more than a century ago.
For 20 minutes, the President listened intently as Mr. Surveyor, the chairman of the Cheyenne-Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma, described his impoverished people's 50-year struggle to regain their sacred -- and enormously valuable -- land. In an interview on the reservation near Concho, Okla., Mr. Surveyor recalled that Mr. Clinton had looked him square in the eye and said, "We'll see what we can do to help you." 
 Those few words of encouragement from the President led the 11,000-member tribe to keep its pledge to contribute $100,000 to the Democratic National Committee, which amounted to nearly 18 months of bingo earnings. Even then, the Indians did not have quite enough.
The tribe's first political contribution, and the flow of other donations to an event that one fund-raiser described as an "intimate White House luncheon," is now being criticized by Senate Republicans investigating possible campaign finance abuses. Though the money was later returned, and the President took no action, the Republicans call it one of the most explicit examples of the aggressive role the White House played in Democratic Party fund-raising in 1996.
Unlike the slightly larger fund-raising coffees that have drawn wide attention, the luncheon included only seven guests. At the coffees the President spoke broadly to the group about a variety of issues, whereas at the luncheon, some guests said, they were able to raise specific issues with Mr. Clinton.
Though the President "made no promises" to his tribe, Mr. Surveyor said, he returned to the reservation, about 30 miles west of Oklahoma City, so overcome with joy that he was nearly speechless.
Michael C. Copperthite, a campaign manager and consultant to the Democratic Party, said, "They went back to Oklahoma thinking they were walking among the gods."
Mr. Copperthite has tried since December to help the tribe reclaim the land from the Agriculture Department. It includes unmarked graves, ritual dance grounds and an estimated $500 million in oil and gas reserves.
It was the tribe's idea to contribute $100,000, after a lawyer it had hired suggested that a large campaign contribution would get the Administration's attention and buy two seats at the White House luncheon, tribal officials said.
Fourteen months later, the tribe is still waiting for good news from Washington.
 
The Luncheon
Plenty of Company From Corporations
The Cheyenne-Arapaho tribal members were not the only guests at that luncheon to give $50,000 apiece to the Democratic National Committee.
Executives of several big companies were also there and at least two, the Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Railway Company, and Fidelity Investments, contributed $50,000 each within several weeks. A third company, the Beneficial Corporation, a financial services company, gave $100,000. Executives from all three corporations denied that their contributions bought the invitations or were linked to any promises from Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Surveyor said that a party fund-raiser, Michael Turpin, told him a week before the luncheon that if the tribe contributed $100,000 to attend, they would be given an opportunity to take their quest directly to Mr. Clinton.
A Philadelphia businessman, Peter L. Buttenwieser, has said that Terry McAuliffe, the finance chairman for the Clinton-Gore campaign, tried to sell him admission to the same lunch for a $50,000 campaign contribution.
"I would not, under any circumstances, pay $50,000, or any stipulated amount, to break bread with President Clinton," Mr. Buttenwieser wrote in a June 20, 1996, letter to Mr. McAuliffe. "Luncheon, yes. Luncheon for a contribution price, no!"
Mr. McAuliffe responded in an interview, "Of the thousands upon thousands of people whom I called for money, if one person misinterpreted what I said, then so be it."
Lanny J. Davis, the White House special counsel, denied that fund-raisers had established a "financial requirement" to attend the luncheon. Mr. Davis also said the President routinely listened to concerns of people at White House luncheons and coffees.
"I would say, as a general matter, that it would not be surprising for the President to listen to a concern expressed by a visitor," Mr. Davis said. "In such a situation, the President would often express sympathy or at the very least promise to look into the matter raised."
Mr. Davis added, "No solicitation for funds occurred at this event, and no change of policy or commitment to change policy was expressed by the President as a result of anyone attending this event."
 
The Tribe
A Poor People Make a Big Gamble
After the tribe's contribution was first reported last March, the Democratic National Committee quickly announced that it was returning the donation, which it said had not been reported to the Federal Election Commission because of an oversight. Committee leaders said they returned the money because they wanted to be clear that there was no link between a donation and a fair hearing on the request for the return of tribal lands.
And two weeks ago, Newsweek magazine reported that tribal leaders had contemplated hiring a Washington firm to investigate Senator Don Nickles, the Oklahoma Republican who has opposed the tribe's efforts to regain the land. Tribal leaders said they wanted to prove that Senator Nickles opposed the return of the land because he had ties to the oil and gas industry, which is also interested in acquiring the land. The tribe has chosen not to hire the firm.
During the Senate hearings on campaign finance, Mr. Nickles accused the Democrats of orchestrating a "shakedown" of the tribe. But tribal leaders in Oklahoma watched the hearing with bemusement.
"He is no friend of ours," said Archie D. Hoffman, 60, the secretary of the Tribal Business Committee, "but he is pretending that he is. "We're fighting Nickles on this. We gave that money to get around him."
In an interview, Mr. Nickles said the suggestion that he was blocking the tribe because of oil and gas ties was "hogwash." He said he was outraged that the tribe was asked to make good on their pledge, and had to use emergency money, which he said the tribe needed to pay for funerals and utility bills, to make contributions.
"I just think this was an outlandish shakedown by the Clinton Administration," Mr. he said. "If they were promised something in exchange for a contribution, that happens to be called bribery. It is wrong. And when you are hitting up a group like this, a very low-income tribe, it makes it doubly as bad."
Mr. Surveyor, 42, said, "The impression I got is the President would try to help us, as best he could, and do everything possible."
Recalling his report to tribe members, he said, "And when I told them what the President said, everyone said, 'This is it.' "
Because Oklahoma prohibits casino gambling by its 39 tribes, the Cheyenne-Arapaho tribe has not benefited from a high-stakes gambling windfall. Instead, it has managed to survive on $5,000 a month from a bingo hall whose parking lot is usually nearly empty. Sixty-three percent of the tribe's 10,890 members are unemployed. Those with jobs earn average annual incomes of $6,074, Bureau of Indian Affairs statistics show.
 
The Land
An 1883 Promise Remains Unfulfilled
Tribal leaders say they believe their economic salvation is connected to the 7,500 acres known as the Fort Reno lands, taken from the tribe in 1883. Tribal leaders said they hoped to develop the land and turn Fort Reno, into a tourist attraction.
According to an executive order by President Chester A. Arthur in 1883, the land was to be returned to the tribe when it was no longer used for military purposes. In 1948 Fort Reno was closed, but the land was shifted to the Agriculture Department.
The tribe has tried, in vain, to persuade officials in Washington to declare the land surplus or to have the President to return it.
In 1994, tribal leaders went to Mr. Nickles's office in Washington, but they said a Nickles aide denied them an opportunity to meet with the Senator. Mr. Hoffman said that was when they decided to form a political action committee and register thousands of American Indians to vote.
In November 1995, the tribe sought the advice of Michael Turpin, the former Oklahoma Attorney General who was chairman of the Oklahoma Democratic Party. Mr. Turpin, who was paid $10,000 by the tribe to lobby for the return of the land, suggested that tribal leaders could gain the Administration's attention by contributing $100,000 to the Democratic National Committee.
Mr. Turpin did not return calls to his Oklahoma law office.
"We knew it was a lot of money," said Richard Grellner, the tribe's lawyer, "but we figured it was the best way for us to be heard."
Tribal leaders said that they agreed to give $100,000 and that Mr. Turpin then called to say they could have two seats at a White House luncheon with the President for $100,000. The tribe accepted the invitation but did not write a check until after the luncheon, they said. That amount made the tribe the largest donor in Oklahoma.
Both Mr. Surveyor and Tyler Todd, another tribal leader who attended the lunch on June 17, 1996, recalled that Mr. Clinton listened carefully to them. Mr. Surveyor said Mr. Clinton asked how the land was taken and whether Senator Nickles had helped the tribe, and said he would try to help.
The next day, Mr. Surveyor returned to his reservation and asked tribal leaders to approve the $100,000 contribution. A few were doubtful about parting with $100,000, he said.
James Pedro, one of eight elected members of the Tribal Business Committee, argued, "I guess the bottom line here is that we committed -- we can't back out now," Mr. Pedro told his fellow tribe members, according to a transcript of the meeting.
The committee agreed to cash in its certificates of deposit and wired $87,671.74 to the Democratic National Committee on June 27, 1996. Within weeks, Democratic fund-raisers told the tribe it still owed about $12,000. The tribe then gave $20,000 more for the President's birthday dinner at Radio City Music Hall on Aug. 19.
After last November's election, Mr. Grellner said, "all of a sudden, we were off their radar screen."
 
The Offer
Oil And Gas Rights In Return for Help
Last December, the tribe sought the help of Mr. Copperthite, the Democratic campaign manager, who said in an interview that he had put the tribal leaders in touch with Nathan Landow, a Democratic fund-raiser for Vice President Al Gore.
Mr. Landow, a wealthy developer, offered to help the tribe if its leaders agreed to give him 10 percent of the oil and gas rights to the land for 20 years, according to a contract he signed and sent the tribe in March.
Mr. Copperthite and Mr. Grellner both said that Mr. Landow told the tribe that without the deal, they would never get their land back.
Mr. Landow denied making a threat, saying he tried "to explain to them that it seemed obvious that after close to 100 years of effort, they must be doing something wrong. And they should try to select people that can help them."
In March, a day after The Washington Post and The Philadelphia Inquirer published articles about Mr. Landow's proposed deal, the tribe began discussions with Cody Shearer, who identified himself as a friend of the President and offered to help them without charge, tribal leaders said.
Mr. Shearer insisted, however, that the tribe keep the matter quiet, Mr. Grellner said. Mr. Shearer did not return phone calls to his Washington office. And a White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: "As far as we know, no one had any awareness of what Mr. Shearer was doing."
Mr. Shearer offered to get an answer within 10 days, Mr. Grellner said, but the 10 days turned into 10 weeks, the tribe became suspicious of Mr. Shearer's motives, Mr. Grellner said.
"I think he just wanted to keep us quiet until the campaign finance hearings ended," Mr. Grellner said.
That seems unlikely now. The F.B.I. has been here, and several lawyers and investigators with the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses plan to visit this week to talk with tribal leaders.
Mr. Surveyor said he would tell the investigators what the President told him, and how much it meant to his tribe. He said he would continue to fight for his land, though he planned to stay far from Washington for a while.
"It's pretty hard to trust people from that town," Mr. Surveyor said.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
State's Private Investing Is Up

BYLINE: By NOAM COHEN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
State investment in private building projects increased 79 percent during the first half of 1997, indicating continued growth in New Jersey's economy, state officials said yesterday.
From January through June, the New Jersey Economic Development Authority issued $522 million in bonds to help finance 145 projects costing a total of $831 million, said Rose M. Smith, a spokeswoman for the agency. A year earlier, the state invested $292 million in bonds to assist 116 projects worth $385 million, Ms. Smith said. 
 This year's projects, which include expansion of St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, will create 1,400 permanent jobs and 3,650 construction jobs, more than were created in the first half of last year, Ms. Smith said.

HEADLINE: Budget Bill's Downfall

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Peter Passell (Economic Scene, Aug. 7) argues persuasively that an eventual rise in the Federal deficit will likely more than offset the rise in household savings resulting from the new balanced-budget bill. We should also note that we are at the peak of the business cycle, with full employment and correspondingly large tax revenues. 
 A pause in growth will certainly increase the deficit beyond the bill's forecast. Then, to make the budget balance, we will have to forgo the usual built-in, counter-cyclical mechanisms like unemployment or welfare payments and see any recession prolonged. The bill is a monstrosity. It will almost certainly be abandoned before 2002, the year projected for the balanced budget.
Business should be ashamed of itself for letting ideology and special interest displace the principle that what is good for the country is good for business.
 
JOHN T. BENNETT
Alexandria, Va., Aug. 11, 1997

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Markets Fall, Paring Early Gains by Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose modestly yesterday, erasing some early gains as United States financial markets fell and offsetting the positive effects of a decision by the German central bank to leave a key money-market rate unchanged.
"The Dow tumbled, bonds tumbled and then the dollar tumbled," said Jay Werthheimer, senior currency trader at Banco di Sicilia. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 101.27, most of it in late trading; bond prices declined less steeply, with yields at the highest level in almost six weeks. 
 The dollar had risen against the mark earlier in New York trading after the Germans left their 14-day repurchase rate unchanged at 3 percent. Still, the dollar's gains were limited as the central bank set the rate for one week rather than the usual two weeks.
Some German bank officials, concerned about the recent slide in the value of the mark, had recently hinted at the possibility of a rate increase, though most analysts were skeptical that such a step would be taken in light of the country's 11 percent-plus unemployment. While a rate increase would make investments in marks more attractive, it could also hamper an economic recovery by raising borrowing costs.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.8645 marks, up slightly from 1.8634 on Monday. The dollar also rose a bit against the Japanese yen, settling at 116.43, up from 116.12 yen on Monday. It rose, too, against the British pound, which fell to $1.5802 from $1.5922.
Southeast Asian currencies continued to tumble after a spokeswoman for the Monetary Authority of Singapore suggested that the agency would not resist a decline in that currency's value. "Investors have looked at the prospects and risks in individual markets and reacted accordingly," the spokeswoman said. "The exchange rate is appropriate to what's happening in the market."
The dollar rose to a three-year high of 1.5140 Singapore dollars in Asian trading. It also rose to a three-and-a-half-year high of 2.7945 Malaysian ringgit. Currencies in Thailand and Indonesia slumped, as well.
Financial troubles in Thailand have prompted a selloff of South and Southeast Asian currencies in recent weeks, leading to a $16 billion international rescue program.

LENGTH: 879 words

HEADLINE: Norman B. Ture, Architect of the 1981 Tax Cut, Dies at 74

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Norman B. Ture, an uncompromising advocate of supply-side economics and an architect of the 1981 tax cut that was one of the largest in the nation's history, died on Sunday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 74.
The cause was pancreatic cancer, said a friend, Barry Rogstad. 
 For the better part of 30 years beginning in the early 1950's, both Democratic and Republican Presidents, as well as many Congressional leaders, sought out Mr. Ture for his advice on taxes and supply-side theory, the economic concept built on the belief that lower taxes spur greater economic growth.
He was, in the judgment of Jude Wanniski, an economic consultant in Morristown, N.J., and a longtime advocate of supply-side thinking, "the one American who bridged the Kennedy and Reagan tax cuts" both of which lowered individual tax rates at times when the economy was lagging.
Supply-side economics has long divided political leaders and economists. Opponents say the economy suffered from huge budget deficits throughout the 1980's in part because the 1981 tax cut was not accompanied by equivalent offsetting spending cuts. Proponents counter that the 1981 cut laid the groundwork for today's growth, low inflation and unemployment.
Mr. Ture was a consultant to Representative Wilbur D. Mills, the Arkansas Democrat who was chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee in the 1960's.
"The speech that Wilbur Mills gave in 1963 that introduced the Kennedy tax cut proposal was written by Norman Ture," Mr. Wanniski said. "John Kennedy was a wall-to-wall supply-sider."
Not everyone agrees with that. Still, President Kennedy adopted key elements of supply-side economics, Mr. Wanniski said, after "the usual Keynesian ideas, like investment tax credits, didn't do anything" and pushed tax cuts to revive the economy.
President Lyndon B. Johnson won passage of the Kennedy tax cut after assuming office in 1963 and, Mr. Wanniski said, "Norman Ture was part of that action."
When asked whether Mr. Ture was a Republican or a Democrat, Mr. Wanniski said: "Nobody knew what his politics were. He was a tax guy."
It turns out that Mr. Ture was a Republican, said Stephen J. Entin, a resident scholar at the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation in Washington.
Mr. Ture founded the institute, which Mr. Entin described as "a nonpartisan, free-market think tank," in 1977, left it in 1981 to join the Reagan Administration and returned to it as president in 1982, after he quit the Administration to protest repeals of parts of the 1981 tax cut.
People have stumbled over the pronunciation of the economist's name. His wife, Donna Cramer, said today that the family traditionally had pronounced it TOO-ray, until he became Under Secretary of the Treasury for Tax and Economic Affairs in 1981 and an article in The New York Times rendered it too-RAY. That led others to pronounce it with the stress on the second syllable, she said, and Mr. Ture decided to adopt that pronunciation himself.
Mr. Ture was born in Cleveland and received a master's and doctorate in economics from the University of Chicago. He served in the Army in World War II.
He was a member of the Treasury Department's tax analysis staff from 1951 to 1955 and a staff member of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress from 1955 to 1961. So thorough was his knowledge of the subject that Mr. Entin said today: "Someone once told me that when people came to Wilbur Mills with tax questions, he told them, 'Talk to Norman about it. He understands taxes.' "
Mr. Ture served on tax panels for President Richard M. Nixon and was director of tax studies at the National Bureau of Economics. He taught economics at George Washington University, the Wharton School of Finance at the University of Pennsylvania and at Illinois College.
Mr. Ture's marriages to Pearl Roberts and Daphne Laird ended in divorce.
Besides Ms. Cramer, he is survived by their daughter, Claire Cramer-Ture of Alexandria; three daughters from his marriage to Ms. Roberts, Julianne Ture of Boston, Heather Turey of Capitola, Calif., and Martha Ture of Fairfax, Calif.; a son from that marriage, Peter Ture of Bethesda, Md.; a stepdaughter, Keli Cramer of Baltimore, and two grandchildren.
Mr. Wanniski and Mr. Entin described today how Mr. Ture got to play a pivotal role in pushing the 1981 tax cut. "When Reagan was elected in 1980 and needed people who knew how to move this issue along, the search led to Norman Ture," Mr. Wanniski said. "Reagan chose Donald Regan as his Treasury Secretary. All of us supply-siders were nervous about Regan."
But they were pleased when Mr. Regan chose Mr. Ture, their candidate for the top tax post in Treasury.
"Norman came in as a chief architect of the 1981 tax cuts," Mr. Entin said. "But as soon as the ink was dry on the 1981 act, there were people in Washington who wanted to repeal parts of it, and in 1982 they repealed large parts of the business section that constituted serious back-tracking by the Administration.
"Norman resigned in 1982, largely in protest over the over the tax increase that repealed substantial portions of the 1981 law," Mr. Entin said. "He was one of the few people who went in on principle and went out on principle. He didn't compromise."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Huizenga, Toyota and the Perils of Lawsuits

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 12

 BODY:
A vicious legal fight between H. Wayne Huizenga's Republic Industries and two Japanese auto makers is proving that few problems can be as deadly to a stock as the uncertainty created by big lawsuits.
Republic's stock closed today at $23.4375, having lost nearly half its value since reaching a high of $42.75 on Jan. 23. This precipitous drop in a rising market is particularly serious for Republic, which has an expansion strategy of using its stock to buy up other businesses. 
 Republic blames Toyota and Honda -- which have sued Republic to block it from buying some of their dealerships -- for the stock slide. "They are deliberately trying to hurt the stock," Mr. Huizenga said in an interview today. "I think they know they can't stop us, but I think they are just trying to slow us down."
The auto makers denied that they were deliberately trying to hurt Republic's stock and said that their lawsuits were intended to force Republic to comply with their rules limiting the rapid acquisition of dealerships. "There's not one shred of truth to his allegation," said James E. Press, senior vice president of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. "When they disregard our policies, what other choice do we have?"
Both Toyota and Honda have allowed Republic to buy some dealerships, but have sought to limit the number it can buy quickly. Art P. Garner, a Honda spokesman, said his company's suit had nothing to do with Republic's stock price. "Our intent is to protect the Honda brand name and the Honda image," Mr. Garner said. "The only way to challenge them is in court."
Wall Street analysts agree that the lawsuits have hurt investor confidence in Republic, though opinion is divided on the extent to which the auto makers have used the courts as a tool in their commercial fight with Mr. Huizenga's company.
Since last winter, Republic has agreed to buy 153 dealerships belonging to various auto makers, becoming the nation's largest owner of car dealerships. Nearly all the transactions have been paid for with Republic stock.
But the decline in the stock's value means that nearly twice as many shares are now required for comparably valued deals; in Republic's view, that shows that the filing of lawsuits can sometimes do as much damage as the eventual rulings do. "It has had a definite effect on our stock," said Mr. Huizenga, who acknowledged that buying dealerships had now gotten more costly. "It is expensive, but we are still going forward because we have a strategy and a plan."
The Big Three American auto makers have not raised significant objections to Republic's series of deals because they have been trying to thin their own ranks of dealers, and Republic's consolidation plans align with their interests. "The Republic strategy plays into their hands," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto analyst with Lehman Brothers.
Indeed, some have even taken a page from Republic's playbook: the Ford Motor Company has begun to consolidate its dealerships in Indianapolis and Salt Lake City by investing with local dealers there to form groups that will close the weakest outlets.
"We believe in the franchise system," Alexander Trotman, chief executive of Ford, said in an interview last week. However, he added, "We can't sit still and let the world go by as we see what might be a revolution."
While Wall Street analysts agree that the legal fight is making investors less willing to buy Republic stock, they said that the lawsuits were not the only cause of the slide in the stock price. Rival dealership groups have turned in disappointing earnings, and analysts are uncertain how the new groups would perform in an economic downturn, Mr. Phillippi of Lehman Brothers said. But the legal fight certainly "has colored investors' sentiments," he said.
Others agree. "It has held the stock back from performing as well as the market," said Thomas M. Galvin, a managing director of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
Toyota sought on April 2 to block Republic's purchase of a Toyota franchise in Houston. Republic's stock dropped more than 10 percent on the news. Since Honda sued Republic on May 6 to stop it from carrying out a plan to buy more than 60 Honda and Acura dealerships in the next 18 months, Republic's stock has drifted down to trade between $20 and $25 a share. (Honda amended its suit today to reflect what it said were "numerous violations" of its dealership policies.)
Recently, Republic has been using the courts to fight back. Last Thursday, it filed a petition with the Tennessee Motor Vehicle Commission seeking an order that would allow it to buy dealerships in Tennessee; in addition, it is seeking civil and criminal penalties and sanctions against Toyota over the auto maker's attempt to block the sales. Today, Republic filed a lawsuit in Alabama charging Toyota with unfair and deceptive trade practices.
Particularly angry these days are car dealers who thought they had made fortunes by selling their family businesses to Republic, only to have the transactions tied up in court by auto producers. The dealers and Republic point to state franchise laws requiring that auto makers approve sales of dealerships, unless the buyer fails to meet simple standards such as having "good character."
And a Toyota dealer in Spokane filed a complaint with the Washington State Department of Motor Vehicles accusing Toyota of blocking the sale of his dealership to Republic.
Other dealers are also upset. "I have the right in this country and in this state to sell my business as long as the buyer is qualified -- this isn't Japan and this isn't Russia," said Ronald M. Salhany, a Florida car dealer who has been blocked by Toyota from completing the $45 million sale of two Lexus dealerships to Republic. "If I lose my merger agreement, which ends Sept. 9, I'm suing them."
But Toyota officials have insisted that they have the right to add a provision to their franchise agreements limiting the rate at which any buyer can snap up dealerships. They have lost patience as Republic has continued to sign acquisition agreements with Toyota dealers even while continuing to negotiate with Toyota executives.
"They keep saying they want to be partners, and my grandfather said to me many years ago, 'Listen to what people say but watch what they do," Mr. Press of Toyota said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Record Fifth Loss in a Row

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury market, after being pummeled by dealers and investors for four sessions because of a poor quarterly refunding and concern that a strong economy would lead the Fed to raise interest rates, enjoyed a brief respite yesterday morning, only to reverse course and chalk up its fifth loss in a row.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 13/32, to 96 7/32, to yield 6.67 percent, up from 6.64 percent on Monday. That was its highest level since July 2, when it was 6.71 percent. 
 Encouraged in the morning by a report of a drop in weekly retail sales ahead of today's July report, market participants bought bonds in what many thought were oversold conditions. In addition, the Atlanta Fed report on business activity showed a pickup in July, while its inflation signals were mixed. This apparently eased concern that a resurging economy would accelerate inflation.
However, in the afternoon, the LJR Redbook report showed that weekly retail sales rose a higher-than-expected nine-tenths of 1 percent in the first week of August, and that turned market sentiment bearish again.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., said it was easy to get the prices of Treasury securities to move higher after reaching an oversold condition. "What I'm seeing today is a lot of hedge-fund buying," he said, and some follow through as a result of reports on Monday that a Fed governor, Susan Phillips, had suggested the Fed would not raise interest rates soon.
Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif., said the release of the Redbook report had accelerated a decline that began on rumors of a large seller of zero-coupon bonds.
"It tells you that even after showing decent gains for the first time in almost a week, the market's basic makeup is still fragile ahead of retail sales and producer price numbers," Mr. Jones said.
"It tells you a lot when the market comes down over a full point off its high for the day," he said. "We dropped on a rumor and a strong weekly retail reports, which two weeks ago wouldn't have caused a ripple. We expect tomorrow's retail sales report to show a gain of 0.8 percent and the P.P.I. to be up 0.1 percent over all and at the core, excluding food and energy. Even if everything comes in as expected, the trend is toward higher yields going into the Federal Open Market Committee meeting next week."
David Ader, regional director of fixed income for Technical Data of Boston, said the market had demonstrated a frightening ability to come down a lot faster than it goes up, showing that many who are holding Treasury securities "are very nervous about their positions." He said the market might improve if forthcoming economic reports, "especially retail sales, come in friendly." But, he added, "I am convinced that there will also be a lot of selling into that strength as these longs get out."
"Bottom line," Mr. Ader said, "until we unwind the refunding paper and strong selling, the Street is going to continue to view upticks as an opportunity to lighten up, even with good information."

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Rate Of Productivity Is Up Only a Bit

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The productivity growth rate of American workers -- measuring how much more they produce in an hour on the job -- rose at an annual rate of only six-tenths of a percent in the second quarter, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The announcement was greeted with hoots of criticism from a growing number of economists and business people who insist that the official data greatly understate a flourishing efficiency in the workplace.
"The numbers must be wrong; they must be understated," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "There is no way we could have had the outstanding economic performance this country has had over the last couple of years if those numbers were remotely accurate." 
 The new Labor Department numbers were doubly disappointing for those who hold, as Mr. Steinberg does, that the boom in corporate profits and stock prices, and the low inflation rate result chiefly from rising productivity. In the spring, the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics had announced a spurt in productivity in the first quarter, and the productivity optimists had expected the second-quarter data to reinforce this trend -- finally giving their views statistical support.
Instead, not only was the second-quarter number weak, but the bureau revised downward the bullish first-quarter number. Productivity growth for all of American business except farms grew at an annual rate of 1.4 percent in that quarter, the bureau said, not the 2.6 percent originally reported.
The latest report seemed to intensify a spreading debate between those who believe the American economy has entered a new prosperous era characterized by rising productivity and those who resist embracing such a concept in the absence of statistical evidence from the Labor Department, the official scorekeeper.
"The way I would put this is that the burden of proof is on someone who thinks there is a dramatic change, and every quarter that comes along without it is some evidence against that view," said Robert M. Solow, the Nobel laureate in economics.
Productivity, in everyone's view, is the path to rising income, profits and standard of living. When a worker -- making shoes or repairing a car or cleaning a suit -- increases in a single hour the sales revenue from his or her output to, say, $102 from $100, then that worker's productivity growth rate is 2 percent. The additional revenue can go into profit or raises or both. And a company can prosper, along with its workers, without having to raise prices.
The productivity growth rate nationwide averaged 2.8 percent annually from 1947 until 1973. Since then, it has averaged 1 percent, or less, according to the official data, and yesterday's second-quarter report reconfirmed that trend. For the 12 months through the second quarter, productivity rose at an annual rate of seven-tenths of a percent, down from a revised 1.1 percent in the year ended with the first quarter.
The Labor Department also said that in the 1990's the annual productivity rate for nonfarm business has averaged 1 percent, including an upward revision to 1.3 percent in 1996 from a previously estimated seven-tenths of a percent.
Most of the weak productivity growth this year came from downward revisions in output -- the revenue from selling what workers produce -- without similar downward revisions in hours worked. The big exception, as usual, was in manufacturing, where productivity rose by 3.2 percent in the second quarter, up from 2.5 percent in the first quarter. That implied that productivity in the much larger and harder to measure service and financial sectors of the economy was very weak.
But Mr. Steinberg and others say this cannot be. The combination in recent years of sharply rising corporate profits and a small upturn in wages has convinced them that rising productivity is generating the extra revenue to make this possible throughout a strong economy. They cite the low inflation rate as evidence for this view. If they are wrong, the prosperous combination could come apart.
The official data, they say, are failing to capture technology's growing contribution to productivity, for example, or the hidden output generated by computer software, or the true efficiency of service sector workers, or the organizational improvements in corporate America.
The opposite side in this debate says the contribution of computers to productivity is greatly overstated, the service sector includes large areas of inefficient labor and much production today is often labor intensive.
Some of the dispute stems from a disagreement over the proper measure of output. Should it be the sum of the revenue from the sale of every worker's output, known as the product side of the ledger? Or should it be the sum of all the "income," that is, the wages, salaries, profits and dividends earned from all the sales? In theory, the two should be equal, but lately income has been higher, suggesting a higher productivity number -- if only, the optimists argue, the Labor Department would shift to using "income" instead of "product."
Government statisticians reject this shift, arguing that the product calculation is more accurate. The Bureau of Labor Statistics is using the best available data, said Edwin Dean, chief of the bureau's productivity division. "Our methodology for computing labor productivity is widely accepted."
The bureau also reported that unit labor costs, the wages and benefits paid for each unit of output, had risen at a 2.4 percent annual rate, down from 3.1 percent in the first quarter. That meant that wage costs were exercising less upward pressure on prices, thus dampening the inflation rate. What is more, compensation per hour worked rose at a 3.1 percent annual rate in the second quarter, down from 4.5 percent in the first period.

HEADLINE: Affluent Turning to Public Colleges

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
The nation's public four-year colleges and universities, long the backbone of economic opportunity for moderate-income Americans, are increasingly serving the economic elite, who as a group no longer put so high a premium on private education.
The proportion of students from rich families sending their children to public universities has risen sharply in the last 15 years, according to data to be published next month by Michael McPherson of Macalaster College in St. Paul and Morton Schapiro of the University of Southern California. 
 These two economists estimate that 38 percent of the college freshmen from families earning more than $200,000 a year enrolled in public institutions in 1994, compared with 31 percent in 1980.
Those findings are underscored by recent studies in Minnesota, Florida and Oregon showing that students in four-year public institutions come from wealthier families, on average, than their counterparts in private colleges and universities in those states.
The gentrification of public colleges accents what Tom Kane, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, calls "the simmering crisis" in education finance. And it is a crisis carrying its full share of questions about fairness.
While the demand for higher education is widely expected to rise by a third in the next decade, there is little indication that state legislatures are prepared to come up with the greater subsidies to support the extra students at the public institutions. If across-the-board tuition increases are used to fill the gap, Mr. McPherson argues, "the poor will bear the brunt," because an even higher percentage of places in four-year public colleges will be filled by students whose parents could have paid the full cost of their education. This, in turn, will tighten the financial noose on private colleges that depend on affluent families to pay a disproportionate share of the institution's bills.
"Parents are buying college the way they buy consumer goods," concluded Mr. Schapiro, co-author of the forthcoming "Student Aid Game" (Princeton University Press). "They're saying to themselves, 'Why pay full tuition at Stanford when you can get almost as good an education at Berkeley for one-third the price?' "
Economists and educators suggest that the findings challenge the underlying logic of the way public higher education is priced. With strong support from taxes, most public institutions charge uniform fees to all. But many experts argue that one-tuition-fits-all pricing unfairly burdens taxpayers and hard-pressed middle-income students alike. The better way, they assert, would be to charge on a sliding scale according to family income, long the approach of private colleges with strong commitments to equitable access.
"The taxpayers are getting less education for fewer people than they could have with means-tested tuition policies," argued James Day, a consultant on education finance in Minneapolis.
It has long been conventional wisdom that public higher education is the way up for the hard-working children of low- and moderate-income families, while the affluent enjoy the perquisites of private college. In fact, the numbers show how much these demographic lines are blurring.
One reason is the price of private education. Mr. McPherson and Mr. Schapiro calculate that in 1992-93, families with incomes exceeding $60,000 paid an average of $11,600 for tuition at private four-year colleges, compared with just $3,100 at public colleges.
Another reason is the shrinking difference in perceived quality between private and public education, given fine state-financed flagship campuses from San Diego to Ann Arbor to Chapel Hill.
And the consumerist approach to picking colleges has been psychologically validated by heavily publicized college rankings that factor in price as well as quality, giving new prominence to institutions like the State University of New York at Binghamton.
Recalculating all their numbers in terms of 1994 dollars, Mr. Schapiro and Mr. McPherson found that the proportion of families with incomes exceeding $200,000 that sent their children to the best public research-oriented institutions -- places like Indiana University and the University of Wisconsin -- rose to 24.6 percent in 1994 from 19.6 percent in 1980.
Equally striking, the upper middle class has discovered the relative virtues of second-tier public four-year colleges, like those in the California State system, that compete with less selective private institutions.
The proportion of families with incomes between $100,000 and $200,000 that enrolled freshmen in these public colleges rose to 20.1 percent in 1994 from 15.5 percent in 1980, adding to state education costs and depriving private colleges of the students, increasingly rare, who could be expected to pay the full sticker price.
Those national results are reinforced by research in individual states.
A 1991 study underwritten by the Lilly Endowment showed that students at the University of Minnesota's three main campuses came from families with a median income within a few dollars of their counterparts at the state's private colleges. The proportion of enrollees with family incomes between $45,000 and $80,000 was actually higher at the state university.
A 1993 report by the Postsecondary Education Planning Commission in Florida showed that undergraduates at all public four-year institutions came from families with a median income of $50,750, while those in private colleges had median family incomes of $45,850.
In Oregon, corresponding figures for 1992, estimated by the Human Capital Research Corporation, based in Chicago, were $47,210 for public colleges and $45,734 for private.
The pattern may ring a bell among those with long memories.
In the 1960's, the explosive growth of state university systems was hailed as a triumph of liberal capitalism, a distinct American variation on the welfare state that emphasized opportunity over entitlement. Two economists, Lee Hansen of the University of Wisconsin and Burton Weisbrod of Northwestern University, demurred, publishing a study that challenged the logic of taxing low-income Californians to educate the children of the elite in the highly regarded California system. The education establishment noted their argument, and brushed it aside.
But now Mr. Kane, of the Kennedy School of Government, argues that the issue is becoming increasingly difficult to ignore.
According to the Williams College Project on the Economics of Higher Education, a year at the average four-year public college cost the institution $12,100 to deliver in 1994. That cost, rising rapidly, has been partly buffered over the last 15 years by a 15 percent decline in total enrollment, entirely a result of the drop in the college-age population.
But the demographic trend is about to reverse, with a 20 percent rise among that population in the next 15 years. And the total demand for space in college classrooms, turbocharged both by new Federal tax incentives and by compelling evidence that a four-year degree nearly doubles average lifetime earnings, is likely to rise by far more.
If the past is precedent, states will respond with austerity measures -- "more teaching assistants and televisions, fewer and larger classes," as Gordon Winston, an economist at Williams College, puts it.
By the same token, tuition increases are a certainty. According to the Department of Education, four-year public colleges raised charges by 91 percent from 1980 to 1995, even after adjustments for general price inflation.
Mr. Winston argues that higher tuition is not necessarily a bad thing, inasmuch as so many of the beneficiaries of state-supported colleges are more affluent than the average state taxpayer. He supports raising the sticker price of public education to cover a higher proportion of its total cost, along with means-tested scholarships that offset the increases for low-income families.
Among other advantages, this would give a lift to private institutions that still educate nearly one-quarter of those attending four-year colleges.
But states have never been inclined to link college fees to ability to pay. Typically, notes Brian Zucker, head of the Human Capital Research Corporation, tuition goes up only when legislators are wrestling with budget deficits.
"There is no relationship between changes in tuition and changes in need-based financial aid," Mr. Zucker concluded.
Mr. Day, the education finance consultant, sees all this as a classic case of elected officials' following the path of least political resistance. "Legislators have found it convenient to buy into the myth that one tuition fits all," he said.
This suggests that four-year public colleges will remain a refuge for affluent bargain-hunters and, in spite of new Federal tax breaks, that the barriers to attendance for moderate-income students will become more formidable. Indeed, the refuge could become even more inviting if the states abandon affirmative action.
"Since entrance exam test scores and family incomes are closely linked," Mr. Schapiro said, "the result would be more rich kids going to college at the taxpayers' expense."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
