HEADLINE: Home Buyers Find the Bidding Wars Are Back

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Encouraged by relatively low interest rates and the swelling value of their stock portfolio, Bruce and Alexis Goria plunged into the home buying whirl last spring. They tramped through dozens of houses in Bergen County, N.J., just west of New York City, before finding one they liked.
But the Gorias, a 30-something couple looking for their first home, soon learned that buying a house is not for the weak of heart or pocketbook these days. After losing out on their first choice, they did not find something again until early July. The only problem: Another couple had just signed a contract at the asking price of $264,900. 
 Undeterred, Mr. Goria talked his way inside that night -- in the midst of a thunderstorm that knocked out electricity in the neighborhood. By flashlight, he offered $275,000. When the bidding war ended four days later, the Gorias had agreed to pay $282,500, or $17,600 more than the original deal.
Such experiences, reminiscent of some of the red-hot housing markets of the late 1970's and the mid-1980's, are happening with rising frequency in areas of the country where home prices had been weak for years. Bidding wars are no longer uncommon, particularly in affluent areas of northern New Jersey, Los Angeles, the San Francisco Bay area and Boston, as competing buyers push selling prices well beyond the asking price. The last time that happened was just before the stock market crash of 1987.
More broadly, for the first time in a decade, prices are rising nearly everywhere, with 80 percent of the nation's metropolitan areas showing a rise in home prices that exceeds the inflation rate.
By contrast, only 54 percent of the 130 major metropolitan areas regularly surveyed by the National Association of Realtors experienced price increases in excess of inflation in 1994 and just 30 percent did in 1990. Prices fell in merely 4 percent of the metropolitan areas last year, compared with 16 percent in 1994 and 21 percent in 1990.
"For the first time in the 1990's, all regions of the country are participating in the housing boom," said Mark Zandi, chief economist with Regional Financial Associates, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. "Housing is running at full tilt everywhere."
Even Southern California, which has long lagged behind the surging real estate markets in the Rocky Mountain West, the South and the Midwest, has finally bottomed out and is expected to show a rise in house prices for the first time in years. The once-depressed New York area, which had a banner year in 1996 that was the best since 1987, is continuing to improve.
True, with inflation low, most homeowners are not seeing the kind of frenzy that once turned even modest houses into speculative investment vehicles. In general, price gains are relatively moderate, though some cities in the South and Midwest are chalking up double-digit price increases. And a few scattered areas, from Providence, R.I. to Riverside, Calif., still lag behind.
The biggest gains in the housing market are occurring at the high end of the market, where buyers are flush with stock market riches and generous pay packages. But the low end is strong, too, as starter homes are being eagerly snapped up by young two-income families, by recent immigrants and by upwardly mobile black and Hispanic buyers who were often shunned by lenders until new programs encouraged banks and savings institutions to seek them out. The rate of home ownership recently hit a record 65.8 percent of all households, surpassing the previous peak set in 1980.
With demand for housing strong almost everywhere, the number of house sales topped four million last year, more than ever before. Median prices nationwide rose 4.5 percent in 1996, modest by 1980's standards, but roughly double the inflation rate, and higher than the gains of 3 percent or less that were common earlier in the decade. Prices are continuing to climb at nearly the same rate so far this year, according to figures released yesterday by the realtors association.
Many real estate brokers and economists expect that residential housing in the United States will continue to do as well or better for at least the rest of the year and perhaps longer. Rising employment and a strong stock market lifted consumer confidence to a 28-year high in June. A month later the number of applications for mortgages hit a record high. And with interest rates comparatively low so late in this economic cycle, the housing market has remained surprisingly strong long after most experts had expected it to fade.
To be sure, not everyone is enjoying the benefits of a robust real estate market. The gulf between homeowners and renters has grown wider. The number of home owning households with incomes above $50,000, adjusted for inflation, has doubled while the number of rental households with incomes of $10,000 or below has grown from 7 million to 10 million over the last 20 years. Half of all renters, estimates William C. Apgar, executive director of the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard, now spend half their income on housing.
"Rental housing," Mr. Apgar said, "is increasingly home to the nation's poorest households."
The driving force behind the current housing revival has been job growth and healthy gains in personal income, economists say. The rebound began first in the Rocky Mountain and Pacific Northwest states, then spread to the industrial areas of the Midwest, where the old Rust Belt label has been scraped off and replaced by a new shine, and to the fast-growing business centers of the South. Now, California and even the Northeast are experiencing solid job gains, too.
Over all, the economy has added a net 14.2 million jobs since the recession ended in 1991. Unemployment fell to 4.8 percent last month, a 23-year low.
All of that, and a rising stock market to boot, have built up consumer confidence in purchasing a new or larger house. Stock prices have tripled since the early 1990's, adding $5 trillion to the net worth of America's households, much of it going to the most affluent but also benefiting millions of middle-income families.
"The stock market has made so much money for the average person," said James Weichert, chairman of Weichert Realty, which has 200 offices from Connecticut to Virginia. "They're now taking it out of the stock market and leveraging housing."
There are significant differences across the country and from one neighborhood to another, of course.
In the New York area, the market varies widely, though home prices generally have been rising slightly faster than inflation for a couple of years. The pace slowed in the second quarter, but the median home price in the bedroom communities of Bergen and Passaic Counties in New Jersey was $203,600, about 4 percent above the level a year earlier, according to the realtors association. On Long Island, prices were up just 1 percent, to $163,800. Figures were not published for Westchester County or the Connecticut suburbs.
In New York City itself, where hefty Wall Street bonuses and tourism dollars are fueling the economic engine, cooperative and condominium apartment prices are 12 percent higher than a year ago, while the city's most exclusive apartments, on Fifth Avenue, have soared by more than a third, according to the Corcoran Group, a real estate broker.
Indeed, expensive homes are where a lot of the appreciation is occurring. In Morris County, N.J., a suburban base for several Fortune 500 corporations, the average price in Chester has jumped 9.9 percent, to $275,900, since 1995, while the average in the wealthier Mendham Township leaped 20 percent, to $595,400, according to Weichert Realtors.
The Washington area has rebounded recently after a long decline, with the median price up to $172,300, 5 percent higher than the year before.
Elsewhere in the country, increases in home prices have been spurred by a continuing regional shift of jobs and people. In Spartanburg, S.C., for example, the opening of a BMW automobile assembly plant added 1,900 jobs to a fast-growing area in which Michelin tire, Wilson sporting goods, Dunlop and other companies have built offices and factories where textiles mills and farms once reigned. The median home price there is up 29 percent from three years ago.
"The builders have put neighborhoods in places I didn't expect," said Pam Jordan, a lifelong resident. "They took a cow pasture and put 50 nice homes in it."
In March, Ms. Jordan and her husband sold their five-year-old home for $85,000, which was $23,000 more than they paid for it. They bought a larger three-bedroom home for $130,000. "We're taking advantage of the boom," Ms. Jordan said.
By contrast, the feeding frenzy that characterized the housing market in Colorado Springs in the mid-1990's has halted as a glut of new homes has helped stabilize the market. But the median price of $131,200 is still up 26 percent from 1994 and with new employers like MCI, Apple Computer, and Focus on the Family, a large Christian organization from California, the area is now much less dependent on the volatile military and energy industries.
"I don't see our local economy going into the pits like it did in the past," said Martha Taylor, president of the Pikes Peak Association of Realtors, "because we're so much more diverse."
For the second quarter of 1997, the Midwest continued to rise, with median prices at $105,600, 4.6 above the period a year before.
"New homes are being built everywhere," said Ken Lockard, the owner of the Lockard Realty Company in Waterloo, Iowa. "We've had a lot of new companies come here, and we now have some of the lowest unemployment in the nation."
In Southern California, where home prices fell sharply from the beginning of the 1990's until bottoming out last year, the strength of the entertainment and high-technology industries has finally pushed up house prices in Orange County and wealthy neighborhoods in Los Angeles, while the more middle-class areas remain weak. At the end of June, the median price for homes in the high-priced neighborhoods on the west side of Los Angeles was $598,000, up 6.3 percent from a year earlier. The modest homes in the northeast section of the San Fernando Valley did not fare as well; the median price was $130,000, down 2.1 percent.
"Prices are moving up," said Fred Sands, president of Fred Sands Realtors, one of the largest brokers in California and a specialist in more expensive homes. "At the very high end, above $2.5 million, we're seeing double-digit price jumps."
The news is just now soaking in. Larry Goldstein, a health care executive, enjoyed some unexpected gains when he moved from the exclusive Los Angeles suburb of Bel Air to the Washington area to take a new job. His four-bedroom California house, which he bought for about $550,000 in 1995 when prices were still dropping, sold quickly for $700,000 this spring.
"The buying panic has started to hit," he said. "In a market most people thought was soft, we made $150,000."
For his new home across the country, Mr. Goldstein found a five-bedroom house on a wooded half-acre in Potomac, Md., one of Washington's pricey suburbs. Mr. Goldstein said he felt pressure from other potential buyers, prompting him to raise his bid to $625,000.
"I knew we had to come in with a good offer," Mr. Goldstein said, "or we would run the risk of losing it."

HEADLINE: Made in Finland, Sold Just About All Over;
Cell Phones Make Nokia a World Player

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland

 BODY:
About five years ago, Nokia hatched a telecommunications project with the code name "Responder" and formed a secretive unit to carry it out. Some 25 researchers, managers and scientists gathered discreetly in Tampere, a bastion of high-technology research in Finland, and were given this broad mission: "Look at the next challenge" in tapping the exploding world of wireless communications.
That challenge, they decided, was to combine Internet, computer and phone technologies to produce a portable machine that could use all of them equally. When presented with the idea, Nokia's top management pressed their engineers to move quickly to outflank the company's two giant competitors, Motorola of the United States and Ericsson of Sweden. And sure enough, the Nokia 9000, or Communicator, will hit American stores this fall. 
 It is a risky move. For with mobile phones everywhere, only the most innovative ones will turn a decent profit, but it fits Nokia's aggressive strategy. The company has not only transformed the portable phone -- with five factories around the globe turning out some 1.5 million phones a month, it is the world's No. 2 producer, after Motorola -- but has also transformed itself from an old-line paper company into a leading technology company.
Along the way, it has also helped transform the Finnish economy. "We used to have two clusters of strength in the Finnish economy: Wood and paper, and metals," notes Kurt Nordman, chairman of the Helsinki Telephone Company, a private telecommunications company that is a big client of Nokia. "Now we have a third: it's called Nokia."
How could tiny Finland give birth to such a company? Simple. Though its population is only five million, Finland is by all accounts the world's most wired country, with a highly educated and technologically savvy population.
 Nokia, with an ever-growing staff of 34,000 scientists, researchers, salespeople and other employees peppered around 45 countries -- 6,000 of whom joined last year alone -- is rapidly joining the ranks of international household names like Sony and Microsoft.
Inside Nokia House, the new headquarters six miles west of Helsinki in Espoo, a growing sense of confidence is palpable. This "ecologically sensitive" building, an architectural marvel set on the shore of the Baltic Sea, is encased with 26,000 glass plates flooding its eight-story atriums and offices with the light of Finland's long summer days.
 As the Communicator project progressed, the focus became to create, essentially, the world's first movable, pocket-sized office. The device would allow conference calls, receive and send faxes, handle E-mail and cruise the Internet -- all from a moving car, train or sidewalk cafe. It would, says Yrjo Neuvo, senior vice president for product creation, "turn one-plus-one into more than two," which he calls a creed of Nokia's corporate culture.
The culture must work. Revenues hit $8.5 billion last year, and Nokia's share price went from $35 in January 1996 to $56.50 a year later and now stands at $85.75. Its price-earnings ratio of 26 exceeds the 23.5 of the Standard & Poor's 500.
It is an article of faith in Finland that by 2002 well over half the world's data, voice and images will travel without wires, which is why Nokia is heavily focused on what its vice president for communications, Arva Suominen, calls the manufacture of "mobile phones and everything you have in between."
Long gone are the days when Nokia was known for its paper-processing mills nestled by the Nokia River. Nokia executives calculate that by 2000 the world will have 500 million mobile phones, up from 135 million today. And 60 percent of them, they predict, will use a technology supported by Nokia called Global System for Mobile Communications.
Nokia's upbeat mood is enhanced by a widely shared conviction among its executives that new markets in Asia, Latin America and the Middle East will insure growth well into the next century.
"Our objective is to continue to grow annually by 25 to 35 percent a year," says Pii Kotilainen, vice president for human resources, and Nokia employees have a clear incentive to meet those targets. Every worker gets a bonus of 5 percent of salary if profit growth beats 35 percent, and some 2,000 top executives also get lucrative stock options.
Such growth, though, is by no means guaranteed. Luke Szymczak, a telecommunications analyst at Prudential Securities in New York, agrees that "if you looked at Nokia 10 years ago, you would have never predicted they'd be where they are today." But he cautions that the company may be putting too many eggs in one basket. "I mean 55 percent of their mix is into handsets," he said. "This is a very favorable thing right now, but could be a risk sometime in the future."
For one thing, Mr. Szymczak says, Motorola is catching up quickly in Nokia's specialty, "smart" mobile phones. And other analysts note that many other companies, like Phillips, Lucent and Sony, are also set to produce mobile phones. The risk is that what happened with color televisions could happen to portable phones -- with rising volumes but falling profits on each phone.
To Nokia executives, the immediate risk lies in failing to meet demand for smart phones like the Communicator, those with added features that they believe consumers will pay more for. "Handsets will increasingly enable the use of advanced digital services which can be loaded with all kind of services to consumers," says Pekka Ala Pietila, president of the mobile telephone division.
For Nokia, the challenge is to keep its enormous research and development staff -- 8,000 employees -- focused on the cutting edge of smart, user-friendly products.
This year, Nokia is marketing set-top boxes that turn televisions into Internet terminals, mobile pay phones that can be placed in taxis or restaurants, and credit card-size inserts that turn portable computers into phones.
Then there is the Nokia 8110 phone line, with a single key that opens a menu of options allowing a user to track a stock, a news item, a ball game and send and receive written and audio messages. Or the Nokia Cellular Data Suite, which allows the use of Windows 95 with a digital portable.
And Nokia just introduced the 2180 portable, its first foray into the competitive digital standard growing in the United States.
"They put quite a big emphasis on the 'music' part of their business, so to speak," comments Risto Linturi, technology multimedia director of the Helsinki Telecom Company, a large private concern. "Take the Communicator, for example. It has all the components necessary for hand-held communications. It's pragmatic, easy to use and a simple touch-button proposition."
True. But the failure of competitors to match the Communicator, noted an executive at a competing company who insisted on anonymity, could be their belief that "the market is not ready" for such sophisticated gimmicks. Sales of the Communicator, with an initial cost of about $1,000, have been sluggish in Europe, but Nokia insists it is too early to gauge demand.
"It will be interesting to see how it will do in the U.S.," said Mr. Neuvo, the Nokia vice president. "It takes some time before people realize how convenient some services are."
Meanwhile, Nokia's chief competitor, Motorola, thinks it is on the verge of surpassing the Finnish company's technological lead. Margaret Rice-Jones, Motorola's product marketing director for Europe, says her company has its own smart phone, to be released around the end of the year, with "capabilities that go beyond those of the Communicator."
When Nokia began to emerge as a telecommunications phenomenon, one company executive said its success was founded on "enthusiasm and madness." Today, the focus in collegiality. Its core is held together by several common denominators: a requirement that all employees speak English; a younger crowd, with a median age of 31, and a hiring policy marked by extensive interviews designed to insure a staff with the ability to get along with others.
"No politics, a lot of trust, realism with equality between people, titles are not important -- teamwork with openness is," explains Matti Alahuhta, president of Nokia Telecom, who has worked for the company for two decades. "There is a Finnish word, Noyrwws, which means humility, humbleness, that you take pride in the past but don't project it into the future."
To workers this seems attractive enough. "They understand what you need," said Siberg Jukka-Pekka, an engineer who joined Nokia a year and half ago. "It is the same pay, but what attracts here is being on the cutting edge."
Much of the success has to do with Nokia's being a Scandinavian company born in Finland. Scandinavia took a giant leap into deregulating telecommunications in the late 80's. That gave Nokia and Ericsson free rein to learn how to operate in a competitive environment and establish a lead over others in Europe and surpass the technology then in place in the United States.
Nokia has also forged strong ties with many of Finland's 20 universities. At Tampere, about 100 miles north of Helsinki, Nokia's research laboratories are next to Tampere University's media lab, and professors regularly stroll over to the labs for lunch. "It guarantees the universities know where the business is and where the business is going and Nokia knows what the scientists are doing and thinking," Mr. Pietila notes.
"It means that many more researchers are finding killer applications," says Markku Laukkanen, chairman of the administrative council of Finnish Broadcasting, which does business with Nokia.
But what if the world eventually heads for satellite-driven communications, not earth-based switches and relay stations. Indeed, satellites are being deployed by rivals like Motorola, at great expense.
"Satellites will have two million subscribers after the year 2000," Mr. Neuvo predicts. "Cellular phones will have nearly 400 million, at a much lower cost for use. In my opinion, satellites are a niche market -- certainly a big niche, but still a niche, for places like the Gobi desert, the Atlantic Ocean or the Sahara."
Just in case, however, Nokia is also coming out with a phone for anyone stuck in the Gobi desert. It is a new solar-powered model, the Nokia 1610.

Nokia, Finland's homegrown electronics company, has become one of the world's leading makers of cellular phones by continually upgrading the technology of its products. The latest example is the Nokia 9000 Communicator, which goes on sale in the United States this fall. It is a portable phone and computer in one. The versatility comes at a price, though -- it retails for about $1,000 in Europe -- and some industry experts wonder whether people will pay to have everything in one box.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Gephardt Find Common Ground at Fund-Raiser

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, do not always see eye to eye these days.
Mr. Gephardt, who acts as though he is gearing up for a primary challenge to Vice President Al Gore in 2000, broke with Mr. Clinton over the balanced budget law. He opposed the President on renewing normal trade status for China. And he could soon be at odds with Mr. Clinton over the President's quest for new authority to make trade agreements. 
 But here today on Mr. Gephardt's home turf, the two Democrats put aside their ideological differences and appeared side by side with Gov. Mel Carnahan, a Democrat, at a luncheon fund-raiser where 70 people paid $15,000 a couple to raise about $250,000 for the Democratic Party for the 1998 midterm elections.
Noting that Republicans in the House recently staged a near rebellion against Representative Newt Gingrich, Mr. Carnahan said, "Certainly we here would agree with them that they need a new Speaker, but I have a suggestion: Let's make it Dick Gephardt."
"I accept," said Mr. Gephardt, who on this day, at least, was praising the achievements of the Clinton Administration as a record for Democrats to run on next year.
Mr. Clinton praised his fellow Democrats for insisting on some of the spending programs contained in the budget agreement and for fighting to see that its child tax credits applied to lower income families. He implored the donors to keep giving to Democrats, who he said were in sight of winning back control of the House.
"We know that they will have more money than we will," he went on in a reference to Republicans, "from all sources, maybe a lot more. But my experience in this business has been it's O.K. if they have more. But you have to have enough."
Earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton visited the sweltering concrete and brick warehouse of the Midwest Manufacturing Technology Corporation, a business consortium that trains inner-city residents for manufacturing jobs. His appearance was part of his effort to encourage businesses to hire welfare recipients who face strict benefit limits under the welfare law that the Republican Congress passed and Mr. Clinton signed almost a year ago.
The President noted that the law requires most people to work after two years on welfare and restricts them to a total of five years of benefits across a lifetime.
"Now if you say that to someone and you don't want to be cruel to them or their children," Mr. Clinton said, "then you must acknowledge that we, the rest of us, have a moral obligation to make sure there is a job there, and that if they need training that they have the training they need for the job."
Calling on employers to "join this crusade," Mr. Clinton repeated a toll-free phone number for employers who want to hire a welfare recipient. "I feel like I'm hawking something on one of those channels in television," the President said, "1-888-USA-JOB1. I can do this."
Mr. Clinton reported that 1.4 million people had left the public assistance rolls since he signed the welfare law in August 1996. He said that since he took office four years ago, the welfare rolls had declined by 3.4 million or 24 percent, which he called "the biggest decline in history."
The White House also said 11 states -- Indiana, Kansas, Massachusetts, Mississippi, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Carolina, Tennessee, Wisconsin and Wyoming -- had seen caseloads fall by 40 percent or more in that four-year period. New York lags with a 12 percent decline in its caseload.
"Now a lot of people said that welfare reform would never work, because the private economy wouldn't do its part, or the government wouldn't do its part, or we couldn't get people from welfare to work," the President said. "You know, I heard all the reasons that people said it wouldn't work. But a year later I think its fair to say the debate is over. We know now that welfare reform works."
One critic of the new welfare law was Mr. Gephardt, who sat quietly in the warehouse while Mr. Clinton spoke, even though he voted against the measure. Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said today that the President "acknowledges that there were people within our party who had principled reasons to be against that bill and had a great deal of skepticism."
Mr. Clinton's aides said the decline in welfare rolls to 10.7 million had brought the nation's caseload to its lowest level since 1970. They acknowledged, however, that the statistics did not track how many of the people who had left the welfare rolls had found work.
Bruce Reed, the assistant to the President for domestic policy, said some of the decline in welfare rolls was due to the booming economy and low unemployment rates. But he said some of the states that had seen the largest declines were pioneers in using work programs. And he said that the message in the press and from caseworkers that welfare was no longer a long-term income maintenance system had led some people not to apply for assistance.

Dow Loses 101 Points On Worries About Rates
Stocks fell sharply as concern persisted that the strength of the economy may cause the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
The Dow industrials plummeted 101.27 points, or 1.26 percent, to 7,960.84. The Dow has now fallen 3.6 percent from the closing high of 8,259.31 it reached last Wednesday -- the sharpest decline in the Dow since it fell 9.8 percent from March 11 to April 11. [Page D8.]
 
The Treasury market suffered its fifth straight loss, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 6.67 percent from 6.64. [D15.]
 
The dollar rose modestly, but slipped from its early level, as the losses in the stock and bond markets offset the positive effects of a German central bank decision to leave a key interest rate unchanged. [D6.]
 
A.M.A. to Endorse Sunbeam Goods
The American Medical Association has for the first time agreed to allow its name to be used in endorsing a line of products, in return for potentially millions of dollars. The products, made by Sunbeam, will include blood-pressure monitors, heating pads, thermometers, humidifiers and vaporizers. Advertising. [A1.]
 
Intel Accuses Digital on Patents
In response to a patent suit by Digital Equipment, Intel filed a counterclaim, accusing Digital of violating Intel patents that appear to affect nearly every aspect of Digital's business. Still, Digital's stock rose. [D4.]
 
Tougher Stances in U.P.S. Strike
Both sides ratcheted up the stakes in the United Parcel Service strike. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. said that other unions would lend the striking teamsters $10 million a week to help them weather the walkout, and U.P.S. officials warned that business losses could force the company to lay off 15,000 workers. [A1.]
 
Fund Executive Out, in Surprise
Thomas F. Marsico, the portfolio manager of two top-performing mutual funds of the Janus Funds, left abruptly as "a result of philosophical differences" with the company, a spokeswoman said. Mr. Marsico was the manager of the $5.3 billion Janus Twenty fund and the $1.5 billion Janus Growth and Income fund. [D15.]
 
Wal-Mart and Penney Post Results
Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, said that net income rose nearly 13 percent in the most recent quarter as each of its divisions recorded a sales increase and a profit. And J. C. Penney said operating earnings grew almost 24 percent as the company cut costs and pared inventories, though net income fell 3 percent because of special charges. [D2.]
 
Over-the-Counter Crackdown
The N.A.S.D. plans to toughen the rules for small companies and brokers that trade on the over-the-counter bulletin board, which has been plagued by fraud, an official said. [D2.]
 
Housing Market Back in Order
For the first time in a decade, prices are rising nearly everywhere in the United States, with 80 percent of the nation's metropolitan areas showing a rise in home prices that exceeds the inflation rate. The strength in housing, particularly at the high end of the market, is even causing some bidding wars reminiscent of the 1980's. [A1.]
 
Clinton to Add Drug Regulation
President Clinton will order changes in the testing of prescription drugs to insure that manufacturers specifically examine their effects on children if the medications are to be used by a significant number of young patients, White House officials said. [A17.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

HEADLINE: LABOR UNIONS PLAN A TEAMSTERS LOAN TO SUSTAIN STRIKE

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Ratcheting up the stakes in the United Parcel Service strike, John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, announced yesterday that the nation's labor unions would lend the International Brotherhood of Teamsters $10 million a week for "many, many weeks" to sustain members during the strike.
Officials with the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said the unions had never before lined up so much financial support for a strike, demonstrating that labor leaders view the walkout by the 185,000 workers as a pivotal showdown for the increasingly assertive labor movement, which hopes to show that it cannot be pushed around by management. 
 "Because their fight is our fight, we are making this strike our strike," Mr. Sweeney said at a press conference at the teamsters' headquarters in Washington. "Before the week is out, we will have enough loan commitments from other unions, large and small, to finance the worker side of this confrontation for a long strike, if that's what it takes -- many, many weeks at $10 million dollars a week."
Ronald Carey, president of the teamsters, welcomed the financial aid as an unusually generous show of solidarity. It will be used to finance strike benefits of $55 a week for each member and public relations efforts by the teamsters to help strikers endure a long walkout. The strike fund went broke in 1994 and benefits were eliminated. But last year, when Mr. Carey balanced the union's budget, he set the benefit at $55 a week. The union will have to dip into its general fund to begin paying benefits at the end of this week.
The unusual size of the financial assistance announced yesterday, labor leaders say, stems from the sheer number of workers on strike against U.P.S. and the symbolic importance of the issues: pensions and part-time work. In addition, the strike is by far the biggest test faced by the labor movement since Mr. Sweeney took the labor federation's helm 22 months ago, with a widely publicized pledge to revive union influence in the workplace.
While Mr. Sweeney sought to give the strikers the wherewithal for a long strike, James Kelly, the U.P.S. chairman, issued a layoff warning that union officials said was intended to push the strikers to return to work. Mr. Kelly said that if the strike, now in its 10th day, lasted two weeks, the drop in business would cause layoffs of 15,000 unionized workers -- and possibly many more if the strike lasted a month or more.
"The longer it goes on, the fewer jobs we'll have, so this is about destroying jobs at U.P.S." Mr. Kelly said on the NBC "Today" program.
Mr. Carey said the talk of layoffs was "intimidation," and he questioned whether United Parcel had lost enough business to make layoffs necessary.
Mr. Kelly again called on President Clinton to seek an injunction ordering the teamsters back to work under the Taft-Hartley Act, which gives the President such powers when a strike is deemed to have done serious damage to the nation's security or economy.
"We have customers who are closing down shifts," Mr. Kelly said. "We have customers who are laying off people. We have customers who have their business stacked up, and they tell me they can't hold out much longer."
The teamsters and their labor allies oppose an injunction, asserting that the strike has not caused severe economic damage. Union leaders say they fear they will lose a bargaining leverage if the strikers are forced back to work.
At the news conference yesterday, Mr. Sweeney said: "President Clinton needs to let U.P.S. know definitively that he will not be providing an escape hatch for U.P.S. negotiators. Once it is made clear to these giants of private enterprise that they can't count on rescue by the Government, they will bargain in good faith and the strike will soon be over."
U.P.S. was feeling financial pressure from the strike. Investment analysts estimated that the company was losing $30 million to $50 million a day because it had many fixed costs, and also had to pay the salaries of the 100,000 managers, accountants, clerks and nonunion employees who have continued working.
"They're into the several hundred millions of dollars of losses and the meter is still running," said Philip Baggaley, an analyst at Standard & Poor's. "U.P.S. can withstand a strike quite well in terms of financial resources -- it has a $4.5 billion bank line and a fair amount of cash. The risk is the longer-term damage from customers choosing to use other transporters instead of relying exclusively on U.P.S."
Yesterday, the two sides seemed far more interested in playing hardball than in returning to the bargaining table.
Huge efforts have been orchestrated in recent days to win public support. United Parcel, the world's largest package-delivery company, ran full-page advertisements yesterday in more than a dozen newspapers, saying it had made a generous offer to the union and apologizing for any difficulties caused by the strike.
For their part, strikers have visited hundreds of the company's customers to explain their cause, and have given out thousands of pro-union flyers at football and baseball stadiums across the country.
Discussing the strike, Mr. Sweeney said, "It's about a greedy, hugely profitable employer who wants to make even more money by shortchanging workers on their wages and benefits."
Talks broke down again last Saturday after the two sides failed to reach agreement about wages, pensions and the company's widespread use of part-time workers.
Labor Secretary Alexis Herman briefed Mr. Clinton yesterday on the situation after having met with negotiators from each side on Monday. Even though no talks are scheduled, Ms. Herman sounded a note of optimism. "I'm encouraged in that I believe that both sides expressed a willingness to be more flexible in looking at their own differences," she told reporters while accompanying Mr. Clinton on a trip to St. Louis.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said Secretary Herman would have another round of "contacts" with the two sides on Wednesday in the hope of persuading them to resume negotiations.
Administration officials say they are monitoring the strike, which involves more workers than any other walkout this decade. In addition, U.P.S. normally handles 12 million parcels a day -- almost 80 percent of the parcels shipped by ground nationwide -- but the strike has pushed its volume below 10 percent of that.
Speaking privately, some union leaders expressed fears that United Parcel would seek to press the teamsters to the wall because its strike fund was close to zero. It ran out in 1994 during a 24-day freight strike by 70,000 drivers. The fund was already low because the union had voted in 1991 to raise strike benefits to $200 a week but refused to increase dues.
"The strike won't be decided by the strike funds," Mr. Carey said. "This is a strike about the future -- about good jobs, about our children, our grandchildren."
Explaining why unions agreed to make loans to the teamsters fund, Denise Mitchell, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. communications director, said: "Unions generally understand that this is a strike that affects all workers. They all have a strong stake in making sure that workers don't get undermined in this economy. There is huge support for this strike."
Labor leaders said unions have a long history of providing financial aid to strikers at other unions, pointing to long strikes at Caterpillar Inc. and Staley Works.

HEADLINE: White House Talks Likely With Albany on Medicaid

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Advisers to President Clinton said today that the White House was prepared to open negotiations with the Pataki administration to resolve a dispute that had jeopardized the payment of hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal Medicaid money to the state.
The three-year-old argument came to the forefront on Monday when the President used his new line item veto powers to delete a Federal budget provision intended to preserve rules that have allowed New York State to collect up to $2.6 billion in Federal Medicaid matching funds since 1992. 
 State officials say they are concerned that the veto will lead to a reduction in Federal Medicaid payments to the state by $200 million or more in the coming year.
Because the Medicaid funds in dispute have helped finance health care programs for the poor, Mr. Clinton's veto came under intense attack by state labor leaders, hospital officials and political leaders in both parties today, many of whom said they had already begun lobbying blitzes to persuade the President to reverse his action.
Amid the protests, Chris Jennings, deputy assistant to the President for health policy, said that he would attempt to convene a meeting between budget and health care advisers to the President and aides to Mr. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani within the next several weeks.
"We will do everything we possibly can to work this out," Mr. Jennings said.
His remarks came as an array of Democratic and Republican officials denounced Mr. Clinton's inaugural use of the line item veto, saying it was inappropriate and vowing to challenge it in court.
At City Hall, Mr. Giuliani, appearing with several Democratic members of Congress, said that if Mr. Clinton did not reverse his action, the city would bring a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the line item veto. "I think the case is a very strong one," the Republican Mayor said.
In Albany, aides to State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, said that he had spoken today to Clinton Administration officials, including Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, urging them to resolve the dispute quickly and in a way that would not be costly to the state.
"The Comptroller believes the President was wrong to have singled out New York and vetoed this provision," said Steven Greenberg, a spokesman for Mr. McCall.
At stake is an array of taxes that the state imposes on hospitals, nursing homes and other health care providers to help finance health programs, including hospital services for the indigent and insurance for low-income children. Under the complex rules of Medicaid, the health care program for the poor, the Federal Government reimburses the state for 50 cents on every dollar the state collects in those taxes.
But in 1991, Congress enacted a law intended to prevent states from using health care taxes to improperly reap millions of dollars of Medicaid matching funds. In 1994, the Clinton Administration said some of the state's provider taxes might be in violation of that law, raising the possibility that New York might have to return hundreds of millions of dollars in Medicaid overpayments to the Federal Government.
In 1995, the Pataki administration asked for the state to be exempted from the 1991 law. But that waiver was never granted. So this year, at Mr. Pataki's' behest, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato inserted an amendment to the Federal budget that would have deemed the state's provider taxes permissible under the 1991 law, circumventing the waiver process. That amendment is what Mr. Clinton deleted from the budget on Monday.
At least 15 other states have applied for similar waivers, and aides to Mr. Clinton said that he decided to veto the provision for New York State to prevent other states from trying to sidestep the 1991 law in similar ways. Were that to happen, it would cost the Federal Government $3.5 billion more in Medicaid payments, the Administration estimated.
"We felt we had to do it for policy reasons despite the political costs," Gene Sperling, the President's economic coordinator, said in an interview today. "I think the people who care about the program, like the President, need to take steps to protect its integrity or it will become a target for those who would like to tear it down."
But several New York Democratic officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they thought the President had miscalculated in attempting to single out the D'Amato amendment as a symbol of Congressional excess. "This was just a colossal error," one Democrat said. "With all the waste and bloat in that budget, all he could find was something that clearly benefits the poor?"

HEADLINE: Israelis and Palestinians Agree To U.S. Role in Attack Inquiry

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The Israeli and Palestinian authorities have agreed to report all they have learned about the suicide bombing at a Jerusalem market to a three-way panel whose American representative will be the C.I.A. station chief in Tel Aviv, senior American officials said tonight.
The decision to use the panel, which is to meet regularly to review findings about the attack, was made at a meeting late Monday night among intelligence officials representing all three sides, American officials said. It was refined at talks today between Dennis B. Ross, the special American envoy, and the Israeli and Palestinian leaders. 
 The mechanism will in effect allow the United States to serve as referee and arbiter in a dispute that has raged since the bombing on July 30 about whether the Palestinians are doing enough to cooperate with Israeli demands to crack down on suspected Islamic militants. The twin explosions killed 16 people, including the two suicide bombers.
A panel had already existed to allow cooperation among the Israelis, the Palestinians and the Americans. But by elevating the panel's role now, the United States has essentially committed itself to being at the table during all discussions related to the suicide bombing and perhaps other security matters.
The C.I.A. station chief, whose identity is not widely known, is unlikely to play any kind of a public role in that process. He would presumably report his judgments about the extent of cooperation and actions taken by the two sides only to the American Ambassador in Tel Aviv and to his superiors at the agency's headquarters in Langley, Va.
It would be left to the Ambassador, Martin Indyk, or to Mr. Ross, or even to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright to decide whether to either publicly or privately accuse either side of bad faith or whether to declare that cooperation had resumed in earnest.
There remained no immediate indication tonight that the Palestinians were yet willing to act as aggressively as Israel and the United States would like in rounding up the dozens of Islamic militants that Israel suspects might have played a role in the most recent suicide bombing attack.
Mr. Ross, who arrived on Saturday night, had been scheduled to leave the region this evening. But the situation remains so fragile, American officials said, that he will stay until late Wednesday to meet for the fourth time in as many days with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, in hopes of making further progress.
After meeting with Mr. Arafat tonight in the West Bank town of Ramallah, Mr. Ross said only, "We have to see the process work toward results, and we're working toward that end."
A senior American official said there were continuing fears that the parties responsible for the twin suicide bombings may be preparing to strike again.
"There is a grave and urgent situation out there," said a senior American official, who said he believed that the quest for a broader peace between the Israelis and the Palestinians was now "hanging by a thread."
A spokesman for the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv declined tonight to identify the C.I.A. station chief there, maintaining his anonymity under a practice that is standard at most American embassies around the world.
The station chief and other American intelligence officers are nevertheless known to have worked closely in the past with their Israeli and Palestinian colleagues. But meetings between Israeli and Palestinian intelligence officials have more often taken place away from American eyes. Although the process has sometimes worked well, it has led to accusations of bad faith during periods of mutual mistrust like this one.
American officials said the decision to give the C.I.A. station chief a central role was motivated by the view that intelligence-sharing and judgments about it might prove most productive at arm's length from diplomats and political leaders.
One question that American and Israeli officials described as unanswerable was whether the acknowledged central involvement of United States intelligence in reviewing evidence into the bombing investigation might prompt guerrillas to consider attacking American targets.
The new mechanism may help the Clinton Administration to finesse some of the questions raised by Ms. Albright's announcement last week that she would visit the region by the end of the month but only if the two sides had made progress toward renewed cooperation.
By making an American intelligence officer a judge as well as a witness to what is actually being shared, the central role to be played by the panel could allow the Administration to insist that its judgments had nothing to do with politics.
The new system could also serve to pre-empt some of the rancor caused by rival interpretations of Israeli-Palestinian exchanges in which no third party is present.
If no further progress is made before Mr. Ross's departure, it seems possible that the Administration might now put off a formal decision about when and whether Ms. Albright will make her journey until it receives reports from the new panel.
The Secretary has said her agenda will include the kinds of political issues more central to Palestinian concerns than the security matters that Mr. Ross has pressed. That has left the Palestinians in particular eager for the visit, as the Palestinian Planning Minister, Nabil Shaath, made clear tonight.
He said that while Mr. Ross's visit might have halted the deterioration in relations between the two sides, "we are looking forward to going on from security to the bigger issues of the peace process."
But Israeli officials have expressed concern that any good will shown by the Palestinians as a gesture to enlist Ms. Albright in the progress might cease the moment she says explicitly that she is coming, and would prefer that any announcement to be postponed until the Palestinians mount a major security crackdown.
Mr. Arafat has insisted that his security forces are doing all they can to find out who might have carried out the attack in Jerusalem. But Mr. Netanyahu, with some American support, has insisted that the Palestinians do far more by arresting scores of suspected militants, including 88 on a list that Israeli intelligence officials have presented to their Palestinian counterparts in the last week.
So far, that is something the Palestinians have shown little willingness to do, despite a commitment under the peace accord they have signed with the Israelis to do everything necessary to suppress violence and terror.
A Palestinian military court today sentenced a member of Mr. Arafat's presidential guard to death and two other guards to long prison sentences. But while Israel has asked the Palestinians to crack down on security personnel whom it accuses of involvement in terrorism, the three men who were sentenced today had been convicted of treason and collaboration with Israel.
Even as Mr. Ross proved successful today in establishing the new security mechanism, and as he urged the Palestinians toward a course of further cooperation, it became increasingly evident that he is also trying to persuade the Israeli Government to make a conciliatory gesture, but so far to little avail.
In elliptical remarks late Monday night, Mr. Ross spoke to reporters about "measures that are not helpful and would be counterproductive."
But during his meeting with Mr. Netanyahu this afternoon, both Israeli and American officials said he had explicitly asked the Prime Minister to resume payment of millions of dollars owed to the Palestinians that since the bombing have been frozen as a punitive measure.
Mr. Netanyahu is certain to hear the same message on Wednesday in the Jordanian port city of Aqaba, where he is scheduled to meet with King Hussein. That session will mark his first meeting with an Arab head of state since the suicide bombing sent Israeli-Palestinian relations into a downward spiral.
Israel's imposition of economic sanctions against the Palestinians has caused alarm across the Arab world, in large part because they have left the Palestinian Authority unable to pay most of its 80,000 employees their monthly salaries.
In the West Bank town of Nablus today, some 10,000 Palestinians demonstrated against what they called American and Israeli pressures, and American officials made clear their worry that Israel's use of the weapon could backfire.
Much of the money that is being withheld is normally used by the Palestinian Authority to pay the police officers and other security personnel who Israel is now asking to carry out a security crackdown.
But Mr. Netanyahu's communications director, David Bar-Illan, noted this evening that some Palestinian policemen have been implicated in attacks against Israelis, and that Israel has issued an arrest warrant for Ghazi Jabali, the head of the Palestinian police, whom it has accused of directing officers to carry out an attack on Jewish settlers.
"It's a little ludicrous for us to pay the salaries of the very same force that's mounted terrorist attacks against us, and has shown no change in this policy," Mr. Bar-Illan said.
Today was Mr. Ross's third working day in the region, and his visits with Mr. Netanyahu in Jerusalem and Mr. Arafat in Ramallah marked the third time he has met with each of them since arriving.
The main purpose of today's sessions, American officials said, was for Mr. Ross to discuss with the two leaders the agreement reached late Monday night at the meeting of high-level officials from Israeli, Palestinian and American intelligence.
To avoid giving the session a political cast, Mr. Ross himself attended only briefly. According to American and Israeli officials, those who attended included the C.I.A. station chief and the deputy chief of Shin Bet, Israel's domestic intelligence agency, neither of whom they would identify by name.
It also included Jibril Rajoub and Mohammed Dahlan, who head the Palestinian Preventive Security forces on the West Bank and in Gaza, respectively, and are the Palestinian officials who have long cooperated most closely with Israel and the United States.
There had been six previous three-way meetings in the days since Mr. Ross began his mission, but little had been achieved until the Monday night meeting in which a senior American official said there had been "much less polemics and much more substance."
In return for committing themselves to full security cooperation, the Palestinians want an Israeli commitment to address Palestinian grievances, including the halt in the flow of money and the blockade that has kept tens of thousands of workers in the West Bank and Gaza from reaching their jobs in Israel.
But Israel has insisted that the closing of Israel to Palestinian workers is a security measure, and thereby not a subject for negotiation. And Israeli officials have said they can begin to ease the economic sanctions only once the Palestinians undertake the wave of arrests that the Israelis have demanded.

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
If There's Heaven, It Should Expect Changes

BYLINE: By JOSEPH GIOVANNINI 

 BODY:
IN the 1960's, Paul Rudolph sneaked a triplex rooftop addition onto a brownstone on Beekman Place, just before the historic-preservation police would have stopped him. Embarking on the New York phase of his brilliant career, Mr. Rudolph -- often called the most fertile architectural imagination of the postwar generation -- piled a hanging architectural garden on the rather plain building: the fragile steel-and-glass superstructure cantilevered over the street and spilled off the back in an interlocking succession of landscaped terraces overlooking the East River.
When I first moved to New York in 1983, I dropped my bags and made the hajj. The expansive intervention opened the lid of the boxy brownstone, aerating not only the building but also the densely packed block. The exuberant and joyous gesture was the best thing that could have happened to the rather pickled enclave. 
 Mr. Rudolph obsessed on the house for years, creating the only architect's house in New York equivalent to the treasure Sir John Soane left in London. By the time I finally saw the interior of the triplex in the late 1980's, it had evolved into a daring trapeze of thin mirrored steel beams, glass floors and transparent acrylic shelves. The acrylic wash basin in one bathroom acted as a skylight for the bedroom below.
At a reception in its shimmering dizziness one night, I put down a plastic cup of wine on what I thought was a shelf, only to see the cup drop three stories straight through projecting transparent acrylic planes to the white marble floor below. Mr. Rudolph always smiled mischievously as he recounted the story of a woman who, during a benefit in the 1970's, froze at the sight of the space and had to be carried out on a stretcher. The disorientation was part of the spatial intrigue, and it drew the intrepid on promenades of discovery. Interior views unfolded up and across the highly porous, forestlike plateaus -- you couldn't see the building for the architecture.
Mr. Rudolph's heart stopped beating in the filigreed wilderness last week. He had been bedridden for months with an asbestos-related cancer, tethered to machines that kept him alive in the living room. A stream of the modernist faithful hiked up to his aerie to pay their respects to an architect who had been cruelly dropped by an amnesiac press and academia. The triplex was a reminder of the contributions made to American architecture by this poet of space.
Houses designed by architects for themselves tend to be autobiographical, and Mr. Rudolph's triplex epitomized his reaction to the bracing doses of stiff Germanic modernism meted out to Harvard architecture students under Walter Gropius during and just after World War II.
"We wanted to get out of the German thing, and some of us exploded our way out," said the New York architect John Johansen, who was at Harvard in the same period. "Paul spoke for a whole generation which went on after school to practice with great exuberance, diversity and originality in the 50's and 60's."
Mr. Rudolph abandoned the austerity and pursued his freedoms first in Florida, where he designed a series of startlingly original houses -- light, hovering structures with flowing spaces and hinged wall panels, counterbalanced by weights at the ends of cords, that opened like wings to admit breezes and create shade. Mr. Rudolph also designed schools that avoided tunneling, factorylike corridors in favor of strikingly lighted, modulated spaces with spontaneous gathering places. Already he exhibited his abiding belief in open rather than closed, contained form: he was a spiritual descendant of Frank Lloyd Wright, and his work fused American and European strains of modernism.
In about 1950, Mr. Rudolph, the son of a minister, spoke at a national convention of the American Institute of Architects. "It was like the boy Jesus in the temple," Mr. Johansen recalled. "He admonished the old established architects to get off it, to leap out of the certainty of the German idiom: 'Why can't we enjoy design? Why not picturesqueness? Why do we have to be so grim?' He was very independent." Freedom was the message, not theory.
No building defined his career, and caught the spirit of the times, like the Art and Architecture Building at Yale, where he was architecture chairman from 1957 to 1965. "I asked him what he liked most when it was finished," Mr. Johansen said, "and he answered, 'The 37 levels.' " Within a 10-story building, he managed to nest 37 levels of interlocking spaces divided only by walls of plate glass.
"What impresses me most about his work is that he's been everywhere in it," Mr. Johansen continued. "Whether he's drawn it, or seen it in his mind, he's been at every turn of stair, every turn of angle, every new view, every accommodation of one level to another, every source of light coming in."
The Art and Architecture Building staked out its corner in New Haven with declarative towers, broken by strong horizontal bands. The poured-in-place concrete was bushhammered, and the blocky masses and vertically striated surfaces resembled the sheer faces of a quarry. Inside, the spaces metamorphosed as they flowed, alternately expanding and contracting with low and high ceilings and wide and narrow passages.
When it opened in 1963, the building became an object lesson. As a Yale freshman, I experienced the building as a revelation of space: I raced up staircases that offered overlooks, tiers of tectonic plates and framed exterior views. Fossils and abalone shells were embedded in the concrete walls, and plaster casts of classical friezes hung in the overlooks. Gates from a Louis Sullivan design enclosed a library carpeted in a gorgeous orange that snapped the building together.
Besides making space itself sensuous, Mr. Rudolph radicalized design with the symphonic complexity of his composition, conceived at a time when simplicity was the cardinal virtue. Frank Lloyd Wright and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe had both created spaces flowing in plan, but Mr. Rudolph took the idea into the third dimension, no longer thinking of an elevator building as a stack of pancakes. In other designs Mr. Rudolph would make space palpable by drawing schools of arrows swimming through baroque voids: space flowed, but it flowed in a direction.
Mr. Rudolph remarked that as the Yale dean, he had to remain open to all ideas, so he left the school to focus on a narrower band of principles. At Yale, he was succeeded by Charles Moore, who built with his students a Mylar hut full of iconoclastic attitude on the main floor of the building. The coy structure proved an early call in a hounding chorus of post-modernism emanating from Yale. Mr. Rudolph became the lightning rod for criticism.
In the late 1970's, a fire of suspicious origin engulfed several floors of the building, and the brilliant but misunderstood structure never really recovered either from the catastrophe or from the unsympathetic renovations. Mr. Rudolph remained incredulous that, until relatively recently, the school did not consult him about the restorations.
He had hung out his shingle on West 57th Street and steadfastly resisted succumbing to the common New York practice of being an executive architect who doles out the initial sketches to his subordinates. Mr. Rudolph could regularly be found at his drafting table overlooking the traffic, drawings pinned up within arm's reach, palms smeared with graphite. "He had nice things to say about working all night with a stubby pencil," Mr. Johansen said.
If post-modernism and the rise of historic preservation marginalized Mr. Rudolph in the United States (lesser architects got the Pritzker Prize), Asians still believed that modern architecture symbolized progressive, future-oriented societies. Colonial-style architecture hardly appealed to post-colonial cultures. His complex, labor-intensive architecture also suited countries with inexpensive labor, and the deeply sculptured structures thrived in the chiaroscuro of the tropical sun.
"He felt that America had lost its optimistic outlook, and that Southeast Asia was still riding a trajectory of innovation," said Donald Albrecht, who organized a show of Mr. Rudolph's work in 1993 at the Van Alen Institute in Manhattan. "He was happy as long as he had work, and there was plenty of work in Asia."
The Asian commissions allowed him to explore ideas at scales hardly tolerated in the United States. Among his contributions to architecture are his investigations of the high-rise. Even in structures where economies of scale encouraged repetition and air-conditioning necessitated containerization, he always broke the box. The sculptural involutions of the facades invited terraces; atria several stories high created piazzas inside. Form was not used for the sake of form, but to humanize the building and cityscape.
During the last two decades, his was a schedule of all-night flights, his red buzz cut -- "chinchilla sunset," one critic remarked -- still standing alert after grueling trips. As post-modernism faded and architects again reassessed modernism, Mr. Rudolph was one of the few of his generation left standing with a functioning practice. Peter Blake wrote in "No Place Like Utopia" that Mr. Rudolph was one of the great architects of the century: Mr. Rudolph seemed amused that someone remembered him. (Mr. Blake is organizing an exhibition to run from Sept. 19 through Oct. 15 at the Architectural League in New York.)
All this time, Mr. Rudolph tinkered with his triplex, which exemplified the elusive Chinese principle that subdividing space expands it. Disappearing behind its panels, platforms and myriad planes, space seemed infinite because its end could never be seen; but the many subdivisions of pieces into small parts also extended the infinite into the infinitesimal. His favorite neighborhood was Canal Street, where he ventured to find new plastics to apply to surfaces in the triplex. Beams were often clad in pieces of reflective metallic plastic less than an inch wide, and the reflections fragmented light, sending it deeply and unpredictably into the interiors. The quality of the light changed throughout the day and varied by season. In the morning, as he lay dying, light off the East River cast cool silver blue tones through the white space. As the sun set, the interior warmed to orange. The fractured horizontal levels and the scores of mini-levels were harpooned by great vertical rises of space and structure.
The solace is that a man who lived for architecture died in an aerie of his own ideas. He asked that there be no memorial.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A living room at Paul Rudolph's Beekman Place triplex, with its play of levels. (Peter Aaron/Esto)(pg. C1); Above, Yale University's Art and Architecture Building (1963), a complex assemblage of textured concrete and floods of light. Left, 1986 drawing for a Singapore project. (Ezra Stoller/Esto, 1963)(pg. C10)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Mark After Bundesbank Warning

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the mark and other major currencies after the German central bank, the Bundesbank, warned that it would monitor exchange rates to see if the sagging German currency was fueling inflation.
Even though Germany's economy is sluggish and unemployment is near a post-World War II high, the Bundesbank has recently hinted it may raise interest rates to curb the mark's weakness. 
 "Today was obviously quite a setback for the dollar, mainly against the mark," said James McGroarty, chief currency manager at Potomac Babson Inc., a money management firm. "The tone of the Bundesbank was that it's unhappy with the mark's weakness."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.8352 marks, down from 1.8645 marks on Tuesday and the lowest since July 24. The dollar fell to 115.69 Japanese yen from 116.43 yen and dropped more than 1 percent against the Swiss and French francs, the Italian lira and the Dutch guilder. The British pound rose to $1.5840 from $1.5779.
The dollar began its descent in European trading after the Bundesbank said in its monthly report that it would "closely observe the further development of exchange rates with regard to the risks of a stability-oriented policy." The mark has lost 16 percent of its value against the dollar so far this year, pushing German import prices up -- which could bolster inflation.
The Bundesbank's comments about the weakness of the mark probably represented more of an effort to "jawbone" the dollar down than a sign that the bank is about to raise rates, traders said.
"They just don't want to wake up and see the dollar at 1.90 marks," said Richard Koss, market strategist at MFR Inc., a money management and consulting firm. The dollar reached an eight-year high of 1.8900 marks last week.
The dollar also fell as financial markets in the United States erased most of their early gains. Falling stocks and bonds hurt the dollar because investors selling American securities often convert the dollar proceeds into other currencies.
"We keep going with the asset markets and they continue to feel heavy," Mr. Koss said.

HEADLINE: Freelancers Lose Test Case On Electronic Publishing

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
A Federal judge ruled yesterday that publishers could reproduce articles by freelance writers in some electronic media without their permission or paying them extra.
The ruling came in a lawsuit, filed in 1993 by a group of writers, that was widely viewed as an early test of the economic rights of freelancers and copyright law in the new realm of electronic publishing. The plaintiffs challenged the right of six publishers, including The New York Times Company and Time Warner Inc., to reproduce newspaper or magazine articles on CD-ROM's or in electronic data bases -- without seeking the permission of the freelance writers and without paying them beyond what they were paid for the original articles. 
 An important issue, under the Copyright Act of 1976, is whether the reproduction is the same as the original publication or amounts to a slightly revised version of the original. If either is the case, the publishers have reproduction rights. That, for example, is the copyright interpretation that permits publishers to put archive versions of newspapers and magazines on microfilm.
Judge Sonia Sotomayor of the Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled that for CD-ROM's and certain electronic data bases, publishers could reproduce without permission. But since the suit was filed, the biggest arena of electronic publishing has become the World Wide Web. In their Web versions, newspapers and magazines often include articles and pictures not found in their original publications and sometimes even video and audio.
Given the rise of the Internet and the increasing importance of electronic publishing, representatives for both the defendants and the plaintiffs predicted that the court ruling yesterday would not be the end of the conflict between publishers and freelancers.
"The judge ruled that CD-ROM's and some kinds of data bases are the functional equivalent of microfilm," said Bruce P. Keller, a partner at Debevoise & Plimpton, the law firm representing the defendants. "But it is not a sweeping decision that determines copyright in all forms of electronic media."
The lead plaintiff, Jonathan Tasini, the president of the National Writers Union, termed the judge's decision "murky, wrong and somewhat contradictory." But he noted that in her ruling, the judge acknowledged that copyright law might not have kept pace with today's technology and its implications.
"The court does not take lightly that its holding deprives plaintiffs of certain important economic benefits associated with their creations," Judge Sotomayor wrote.
But, she added, "the plaintiffs' real complaint lies in the fact that modern technology has created a situation in which revision rights are much more valuable than intended at the time that the specific terms of the Copyright Act were being negotiated."
Congress, she noted, "is of course free to revise that provision to achieve a more equitable result."
Mr. Tasini said he was considering an appeal of the ruling. In addition, he said the writers' union, an affiliate of the United Automobile Workers, had been talking to members of Congress about trying to bring copyright law into the Internet era.
"The judge is essentially saying, 'Don't beef to me -- take it to Congress,' " Mr. Tasini said.
In the last couple of years, publishers have also moved to strengthen their control of copyright in cyberspace. Beginning in 1995, most major newspaper and magazine publishers began requiring freelancers to sign so-called all-rights contracts, giving the publishers reproduction rights for all forms of electronic media, including Web sites.
"Even if we won the case today," Mr. Tasini said, "we would still be fighting these all-rights contracts."
Besides The New York Times Company and Time Warner, the defendants in the case were Newsday, which is owned by the Times Mirror Company; Mead Data, a unit of the Dutch-British conglomerate Reed Elsevier P.L.C., which runs Nexis, a data service that provides the archives of many news organizations via computer, and University Microfilms, a division of Bell & Howell that for many years has provided the archives of The New York Times and many other newspapers on microfilm.

HEADLINE: In Prime Minister's Life, A Parable of His Country

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Aug. 12

 BODY:
At 77, Prime Minister I. K. Gujral, who has been buffeted from crisis to crisis since taking over as head of India's 15-party coalition Government four months ago, is by his own account a transitional figure. But he has a vision -- ending decades of enmity with Pakistan -- that would have likely found favor with the leaders who won India's independence 50 years ago.
"I would like our borders to be completely soft, like Canada and the U.S.A.," Mr. Gujral said in an interview on Tuesday in the parliamentary office once occupied by Jawaharlal Nehru, India's first Prime Minister. Nehru worked tirelessly in the months before Aug. 14, 1947, to find a formula to prevent the subcontinent from being partitioned into the separate nations of India and Pakistan. 
 The quest for improving relations with Pakistan comes naturally to Mr. Gujral, who was one of at least 10 million Hindus and Muslims who migrated across the new frontiers. Born in what is now Pakistan, Mr. Gujral lingered at his family's timber business in Karachi, Pakistan's biggest city, until anti-Hindu riots forced him out in February 1948. Like Muslims headed in the other direction, the Gujral family lost all it owned and started out in New Delhi living with three other families in one room.
As Prime Minister on India's 50th anniversary, Mr. Gujral has looked back on his experiences in rising from being "a penniless migrant" in 1947 to India's top job, and found in them a parable of India's achievements. While many Indians have been disparaging the country's failure to solve its problems, especially poverty, Mr. Gujral said he was upbeat.
"I don't think there is any reason for my being defensive, or in a state of self-reproach," he said. "There are a lot of things of which India can be proud."
While Government figures showed 350 million people still in poverty, he said, about the same number were now counted as middle-class. The last famine was in 1967, and the country is now producing four times as much food as at independence -- a 200-million-ton grain harvest with a surplus to export. Hundreds of thousands of Indians are going to college, and nearly one million migrants to the United States have competed on equal terms with the best American talent.
In addition, Mr. Gujral said, India now has a vast industrial and scientific base, capable of producing missiles, space satellites and "nuclear technology and whatever you want to call it," meaning the country's secret stockpile of nuclear bombs.
He contrasted this with 1947, when a neighbor in Karachi, whom he described as "a very rich man," had made his fortune importing sewing needles. "Importing sewing needles!" he said. "That was the level of accomplishment of British India."
India has also experienced a social revolution since 1947, he said, characterized by increasing opportunities for the hundreds of millions of Indians born into the lower social classes.
An example of this mobility, he said, was the men who now held the country's highest two posts: K. R. Narayanan, a veteran diplomat born into an untouchable family, who was elected to India's largely ceremonial presidency last month, and Mr. Gujral himself, who said he never imagined in 1947 that he could one day fill Nehru's chair.
The issue uppermost in the Indian leader's mind seemed to be Pakistan. Like many people at the time of partition, he said, he believed that normal life would quickly resume. Instead, India and Pakistan have fought three wars, and enforced a separation that has persisted for 50 years. Now, Mr. Gujral said, he hopes that his new dialogue with Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, will help end the enmity.
"I think the legacy of partition is gradually wearing out," he said.
Mr. Gujral said nothing to indicate he has found a way around the stumbling block of Kashmir, the predominantly Muslim territory fought over, and divided, by Indian and Pakistani troops in 1947. Pakistan's stand is that India must withdraw its troops and allow a free vote among Kashmiris on joining Pakistan, and that only then can there be the broad opening of the kind Mr. Gujral has said he wants -- in trade, people-to-people exchanges and relaxation of military rule.
Mr. Gujral, following the line India adopted since the 1950's, said India's borders were fixed. Although some Indians feel India "should undo the partition" by handing over Kashmir, he said, "I don't contribute to this."
He added: "That never solves the problem. The sovereignties of each of us must be respected. We must now think that the partition was final. We have to respect each other, and be friends with each other, and cooperate with each other. That's it."
