HEADLINE: Competitors Say Strike Is No Blessing

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Competitors of the United Parcel Service are doing about as much business as they can possibly handle, but not one said it was thrilled about the strike against the nation's biggest package-delivery company.
"No one would be happier than me if this were to end," said Bram Johnson, a spokesman for RPS Inc. in Pittsburgh. 
 Like other overnight and parcel delivery companies, RPS, a subsidiary of Caliber System Inc. in Akron, Ohio, is running full bore: since the strike, its volume has jumped 50 percent, to 1.5 million parcels a day. The company is not taking on any new customers, and has no intention of considering new business until after the strike is resolved.
Business is also booming at the Federal Express Corporation, where daily volumes have jumped to between 3.5 million and 4 million from 2.8 million. But Federal Express, which has shortened pickup and operating hours, eliminated overnight guarantees and placed limits on the number of additional parcels its regular customers can ship, clearly could be doing even more business if it had more personnel.
"We are limiting volume as much as we can," said Jess Bunn, a spokesman for Federal Express, which is based in Memphis. "And people just don't seem to understand why we can't take their packages, that we are not U.P.S., which handles 12 million parcels daily. People seem to think we should be able to step right in. We wish this strike had never happened."
Capacity is close to the breaking point at the Airborne Freight Corporation, which normally handles about 1.3 million parcels a day.
As of yesterday, Airborne's shipments were up 35 percent from the day of the walkout, to 1.755 million.
"We are at the point now where we are concerned about service levels," said Tom Brannigan, a spokesman for the company, which is based in Seattle. Airborne has not limited the number of packages its regular customers can ship, but it is restricting the weight of each shipment.
Sandra Harding, a spokeswoman for the United States Postal Service, which moves more parcels than anyone save U.P.S., did not sound especially upset by the strike.
"This is not the best-case scenario," Ms. Harding said. But she added, "A number of small and large customers have said they are going to start shifting business our way."
Since the strike began, Ms. Harding said, the volume of the Postal Service's overnight mail, called Express Mail, has risen 70 percent; Priority Mail (with delivery in two to three days), 50 percent, and regular parcel post service, 20 percent.
The strike has also prompted a sharp increase in package delivery service at major bus companies.
"Before the strike, we were shipping about 10,000 to 11,000 packages a day," said Katherine Williams, a spokeswoman for Greyhound Lines Inc. "That volume has about doubled," she said. Ms. Williams added that the company, based in Dallas, has started to add buses that carry no passengers, only freight.
Economists said the drag on business output caused by the strike will depend on how long it lasts, but there are already some signs. Yesterday Russ Berrie & Company Inc. in Oakland, N.J., a maker of dolls and gift items, and National TechTeam Inc. in Dearborn, Mich., a provider of data services, said they had laid off a total of 200 part-time and temporary employees because of the strike.

HEADLINE: United Parcel and Teamsters to Resume Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Negotiations to end the strike at United Parcel Service are scheduled to resume on Thursday as pressure mounted on the President to intervene more aggressively in the labor dispute.
Labor Secretary Alexis Herman said that the resumption of bargaining between U.P.S. and striking members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters came after she had repeated telephone conversations with both sides. 
 But after her announcement the teamsters' president, Ronald Carey, expressed little grounds for optimism.
Even as the two sides headed back to bargaining, the stakes in the dispute seemed to be escalating rapidly for the White House as each day passes without an end to the walkout, now well into its second week. The strike has severed the inventory pipeline for thousands of businesses. But it also represents a crucial test of strength for the labor movement, which has been one of Mr. Clinton's strongest supporters.
So far, Presidential aides have tried to keep Mr. Clinton out of the line of fire, urging representatives of U.P.S. and the teamsters to settle the dispute on their own, while limiting the Administration's involvement to the informal jaw-boning and arm-twisting by Ms. Herman.
But with no sign of progress toward a settlement, Republican lawmakers and business groups are sharpening their demands that the President intervene directly. One way Mr. Clinton might do that is by invoking the Taft-Hartley Act, the Federal labor law that allows the President, in cases of economic emergency, to go to court to force strikers back to work for up to 80 days while a board of inquiry studies the issues. Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, wrote to Mr. Clinton, urging the President to carefully weigh his powers under the law.
But Mr. Clinton's aides said that the Taft-Hartley law was an unwieldy tool that set an extremely high legal threshold. To meet it, the Administration would have to present evidence in Federal court that the strike affected an entire industry and endangered "national health or safety."
U.P.S. representatives and some employer groups contend that the terms of the law have already been met. They suggested that Mr. Clinton was reluctant to act more decisively for political reasons, chiefly that he is unwilling to oppose the teamsters and the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which oppose any effort to invoke the statute.
The teamsters have been an important contributor to the Democratic Party. The union donated a total of $161,021 to the party in 1995 and 1996, but contributed nothing to the Republican Party, according to figures compiled by Common Cause, a citizens' group. In the same period, U.P.S. contributed $148,325 to the Republican Party and nothing to the Democratic Party.
Today, White House aides denied that Mr. Clinton's support from labor was connected to his unwillingness to invoke the Taft-Hartley law.
"There's a statutory standard in law that would allow the President to invoke back-to-work proceedings under the Taft-Hartley Act," said Michael D. McCurry, the President's spokesman. "Those are rarely invoked.
In 1978, President Jimmy Carter tried to invoke the law, but a Federal judge ruled that the Administration had failed to meet the standards of the act. It was the last time the Government tried to apply the law.
Experts said Mr. Clinton could feel more pressure if consumers found increasingly empty shelves.
But today, White House aides expressed confidence in their hands-off approach, partly because public opinion polls showed many Americans supported it. One poll, by ABC News, showed that while nearly three-quarters of those polled said they were affected by the strike, only 26 percent said that the President should intervene.
Since he has been President, Mr. Clinton has followed a zig-zag course in handling labor disputes. On the eve of Thanksgiving in 1993, he informally intervened in a five-day-old strike by American Airlines flight attendants, persuading the parties to submit to binding arbitration.
But Mr. Clinton's informal efforts to end the Major League Baseball strike in 1995 failed.
Mr. Clinton did intervene to halt a strike by pilots against American Airlines in February, minutes after the walkout began. He suspended the strike by invoking emergency powers under another law, the 1926 Railway Labor Act. The law, which does not apply to the U.P.S. strike, has a lower threshold than the Taft-Hartley law. It allows the President to intervene if a transportation strike threatens severe economic impact.

Pride and Ambivalence Mark India's Anniversary
Indians are by and large delighted that their country has survived 50 years of independence without having succumbed to undemocratic temptations. But they are less sanguine about the extent of poverty and rising criminality within the new political class. A1

Canada Will Shut 7 Reactors
Seven of the 19 operating nuclear reactors in the Canadian province of Ontario will be shut down after a report concluded they were badly managed and inadequately secure. All of the reactors are within 100 miles of the United States border. The president of the utility that operates them resigned, and more departures were expected. The Candu reactors in question have figured prominently in a multi-billion dollar export program and versions have been sold to Argentina, Romania, South Korea and China. A6
 
Class Bias Seen in Brazil
The impunity of Brazil's upper classes was reaffirmed by a federal judge's decision to dismiss murder charges against four affluent youths accused of killing a sleeping Indian leader by dousing him with gasoline and setting him on fire. The judge cited a picture of one of the youths with his dog as evidence that he was a "good person." Human rights activists were outraged and an appeal was expected. A6

Clive Derby-Lewis, the man convicted of murdering one of South Africa's most popular black leaders, testified to a well-attended session of the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission that he was in a "state of shock" when he learned of Chris Hani's death in 1993. He said he had long plotted to kill Mr. Hani and given his accomplice a gun for the purpose, but he thought they had agreed to postpone the assassination until after that Easter weekend. A7

Dennis Ross, the American special envoy to the Middle East, returned to Washington after four days of frenetic meetings with Israeli and Palestinian leaders. He reckoned his mission had at least stanched further deterioration in the two sides' relations after a suicide bombing last month cast a grim pallor over peace talks. He said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's first trip to the region would be accelerated if she deemed that security ties had resumed in earnest. A3
 
Bosnia Refugees Can Return
Around 400 Muslim refugees have been promised full security to return to their homes in the Jajce region of central Bosnia, according to a Bosnian television report. Local Muslim and Croat officials agreed that the Muslims, who fled intimidation from Croat gangs early this month, could return starting this weekend. But United Nations officials said they expected most of the refugees to be too frightened to reclaim their homes. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Sales Are Robust; Inflation Remains Feeble

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Revived after a spring rest, shoppers briskly increased spending at retail counters for the second straight month in July, while an important gauge of inflation was even more subdued than expected, Government reports showed today.
"The consumer is back," said Daniel Laufenberg, senior economist at American Express Financial Advisors in Minneapolis. "The second-quarter slowdown was just a breather, not the start of a moderating trend." 
 Retail sales, the Commerce Department estimated, climbed six-tenths of 1 percent last month, and that was after the June sales gain was revised upward to seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Nonetheless, economists said they still believed the Federal Reserve would find scant reason to raise interest rates when its chief policy arm meets next Tuesday in one of its eight yearly sessions to plot monetary policy.
"Why fool with an economy so balanced" that inflation remains tame in the face of moderate to strong growth? asked Cliff Waldman, economist for the National Federation of Independent Business. He said the Fed would not act next week.
Indeed, the Labor Department reported that prices obtained by the nation's producers fell for an unprecedented seventh straight month in July, with all three stages of production -- finished goods, crude goods and raw materials -- recording drops last month and since July 1996.
Moreover, when the wide-swinging energy and food components were excluded, prices of finished goods, those ready for sale to consumers or business users, edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in July and stood exactly where they did a year ago.
"Fabulous," exclaimed Joseph Liro, economist at CIBC Wood Gundy in New York.
One of the most visible examples of vanquished inflation was cars. With the aid of incentive programs, car prices fell 1.6 percent last month so that auto makers received 3 percent less for them than they had a year ago. This no doubt contributed to the announcement by Chrysler today that its 1998 models would carry sticker prices slightly below this year's.
Computers dropped 1.8 percent at the producer, sometimes called wholesale, level last month, bringing the 12-month drop to 21.6 percent, the Labor Department's tally also showed.
Flour fell 5 percent, fresh fruits and melons 9.7 percent, gasoline 1 percent, primary nonferrous metals 5.3 percent, wheat 10.4 percent, copper scrap 7.8 percent, beef and veal 1.3 percent and refined sugar 2.9 percent.
On the other hand, fresh eggs soared 21.7 percent, wood pulp rose 3.1 percent and raw cotton, hit by drought, jumped 8.4 percent.
The increased affordability of cars helped lift automotive sales 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department's initial estimate of retail activity found. Auto dealers took in $51.1 billion in July, nearly one of every four retail dollars.
But even without motor vehicles, retailers took in five-tenths of 1 percent more money than in June. This reflected broad strength, the lone pronounced exception being a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent for merchants selling furniture and other home equipment, a bit of a puzzle given the buoyant real estate market. The category of building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes posted an increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Among nondurables, items expected to last less than three years, the overall increase was six-tenths of 1 percent for July, two-tenths of a point more than in June.
All categories showed gains, nine-tenths of 1 percent for drugstores, eight-tenths of 1 percent for gasoline stations, seven-tenths of 1 percent for department stores and others selling general merchandise, four-tenths of 1 percent for food stores and for restaurants and bars and two-tenths of 1 percent for stores selling apparel and accessories.
"The current pace of retail sales is consistent with our view that consumer spending will rise at a 2.5 to 3 percent rate during the second half," Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, advised clients. "That does not constitute excess demand."
But solid gains for June, now seven-tenths of 1 percent, and for July followed three straight monthly declines, contributing to Mr. Laufenberg's appraisal that there is a 50 percent chance that the Fed will raise rates when it meets on Sept. 30, the next scheduled meeting after Tuesday's session.
A more skeptical view was offered by Susan M. Sterne, proprietor of Economic Analysis Associates, a Greenwich, Conn., a specialist in consumer behavior. She said the summer was such a slack time for retailing that it was too early to judge "whether we have a rebound." If one does occur, she added, it is likely to be mild.
Consumers are financially stretched, she has long maintained, and "the more overextended you get, the more price-conscious you get," thereby keeping pressure on merchants' profit margins, as well as sales volume.
Today's price report showed that both finished goods and raw materials edged down one-tenth of 1 percent last month, while those at the intermediate stage of production eased two-tenths of 1 percent.
"There is still no sign of pressure at the earlier stages of production," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
From Inside and Outside, A Portrait of India at 50

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

INDIA
From Midnight to the Millennium
By Shashi Tharoor
Illustrated. 392 pages. Arcade Publishing. $27.95.
 India is 50 years old as an independent nation this weekend, and, of course, it has for thousands of years been one of the great expressions of human civilization. But India is unlike any other country. It is a place made and unmade by British imperialism and populated by every racial type on the globe, people who speak 17 major languages and 22,000 dialects and engage in some of the most ferocious sectarian fighting -- Hindus against Muslims, Sikhs against both -- going on anywhere in the world these days.
Shashi Tharoor, a novelist who is also a senior official at the United Nations living in New York, uses the half-centennial to examine the question of what is India, what makes it a country? In "India: From Midnight to the Millennium," Mr. Tharoor is a thoughtful and well-informed observer, one who demonstrates the balance of insiderness and outsiderness that has often made for the best writing about India. (V. S. Naipaul, who grew up in Trinidad, is another very good example.) 
 Mr. Tharoor, who was born in London but grew up in Bombay and Calcutta, writes a series of essays focusing on different aspects of his two major concerns: India's terrible poverty and the rise of sectarian feeling powerful enough to threaten the common sense of nationhood. He writes elegantly and often colorfully, and when he blends his political interests with his personal experience, his portrait is especially vivid.
But he also writes at times too much as a politician himself. He takes positions, but they are often tinged with a bromidic quality, as if he were a candidate for office striving not to offend anybody while building a broad base of support for his views. Perhaps consistent with that, his "India" goes rather more deeply into local politics and politicians than most Americans would want. His 75-page chapter, "Better Fed Than Free," in which he reflects on the debate between the advocates of unrestrained democracy and those of authoritarian rule in a poverty-stricken country, is a rambling and repetitive exercise.
In it, Mr. Tharoor covers the various excuses and justifications that have been made for authoritarianism -- especially during the emergency declared by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in 1975; acknowledges that the "bargaining, compromise and consensus-building" needed in a democracy make authoritarian government seem efficient by comparison; discusses India's intellectuals as "torn between the pull of an ancient tradition and the attractions of the modern world" and quotes everybody from Woodrow Wilson to a Congress Party president, D. K. Borooah. In the end, Mr. Tharoor opts for democracy over authoritarianism, but one feels, aside from the fact that the subject is a bit old, that he could have come to that not surprising conclusion in a crisper, shorter and less dutiful essay.
Still, Mr. Tharoor makes no apologies for India's shortcomings, including those that stem from the mistakes made by the Indians themselves. While he clearly admires Jawaharlal Nehru, India's first Prime Minister and the founder of the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty (Indira was his daughter), he blames Nehru's soggy socialist ideology for much of India's economic backwardness today. "For most of the five decades since independence, India has pursued an economic policy of subsidizing unproductivity, regulating stagnation and distributing poverty," Mr. Tharoor writes. "We called this socialism."
In 1986, he points out by way of example, the Steel Authority of India "paid 247,000 people to produce some 6 million tons of finished steel, whereas 10,000 South Korean workers employed by the Pohan Steel Company produced 14 million tons that same year." He is correspondingly supportive of the economic reforms begun in the early 1990's by former Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao, which in Mr. Tharoor's opinion are the best hope for Indian prosperity in the half-century of self-rule.
Among Mr. Tharoor's most compelling passages are those that deal with India's descent, after centuries of relative harmony, into sectarian violence. As always, he is at his best when he links his own experience -- in this instance, his beliefs in the nature of Hinduism -- with his country's political experience. He repudiates the fundamentalist Hinduism that brought about the destruction of the Babri Mosque in Ayodhya in 1992, which in turn led to the most horrific religious bloodletting in many years. Indeed, in Mr. Tharoor's vision, Hinduism cannot be fundamentalist because it is a religion without dogma, enriched by the beliefs of others.
In explaining the rise of sectarianism, Mr. Tharoor does not hesitate to place the blame on Hindu fanaticism, even if that fanaticism has been provoked by what he calls "other chauvinisms," Muslim and Sikh. "The rage of the Hindu mobs is the rage of those who feel themselves supplanted in this competition of identities, who think that they are taking their country back from usurpers of long ago." In this sense, Mr. Tharoor writes, "the battle for India's soul" will be waged between "two Hinduisms, the secularist Indianism of the nationalist movement and the particularist fanaticism of the Ayodhya mob." He offers no cause for optimism that his brand of Hinduism will prevail.
His best story has to do with a man named Charlis from the author's ancestral homeland, Kerala. Charlis as a boy was repudiated by Mr. Tharoor's family because he belonged to an untouchable caste. With each visit that Mr. Tharoor makes to Kerala, the situation changes incrementally, until at the end Charlis has become an important local official and an honored guest in the household.
Mr. Tharoor's book would have been more rewarding had he dwelt more on people like Charlis. When the author deals with the more abstract, highly serious questions, his book has a familiar feel. When he gets down to India as a concrete personal experience, everything seems new and fresh.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Singing the Course Of Human Events

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
SO maybe it is the squarest thing on Times Square. It's often gratingly corny; it's dotted with the kind of nudging sexual jokes that might be swapped in the boys' room of an elementary school, and its songs feature rhymes that make Madison Avenue jingles seem like models of sophistication. Besides, doesn't the very idea of America's Founding Fathers gamboling to a souped-up minuet give you the willies?
But darn it if "1776," the 26-year-old musical about (oh, please) the Declaration of Independence, doesn't prove itself to be a surprisingly (if oddly) skilled seducer. It's like some facetious history nerd of a blind date you couldn't imagine, at the evening's beginning, enjoying yourself with. Yet by the end of three hours in its company at the Roundabout Theater, you're amazed at how quickly, and even pleasurably, the time has gone. 
 "1776," which has music and lyrics by Sherman Edwards and a book by Peter Stone, was the show that nobody expected to like when it opened in 1969, not exactly a banner year for Yankee Doodle patriotism. But it wound up beating its far racier and hipper rivals, "Hair" and "Promises, Promises," for both the Tony and New York Drama Critics Circle Awards for best musical. The current revival, impeccably mounted by the director Scott Ellis and featuring an assured, nicely balanced ensemble, makes it clear that its laurels weren't just nods to jingoistic values in a time of social upheaval. "1776," of course, plays on the shiny residual sentiments about the nation's beginnings instilled by old history books. But it does so with considerable ingenuity and in a way that actually finds dramatic suspense in a most familiar plot. It may be shameless, but it isn't stupid.
The show was the long-gestating offspring of Edwards, who was previously known as a writer of pop hits ("Johnny Get Angry," "See You in September") and who died in 1981. He was also a former schoolteacher. And "1776" does indeed seem to have been conceived by the sort of passionate introductory history professor whom young students tend to make fun of but secretly like: the fellow who sees long-ago events in the present tense and tries to convey his excitement through whatever means are required.
This probably accounts for both the central weaknesses and strengths of the work. "1776" definitely panders to its audience: it can be unconscionably cute and leering at the same time.
But in portraying the long, long assembly of the Second Continental Congress one spring and summer in Philadelphia, it also creates an immediate environment of sensory discomfort, personal (and often petty) conflict and overriding frustration. (It's the frustration, as in so many musicals, that keeps you hooked here.)
It is "hot as hell in Philadelphia," as one lyric (showing Edwards's irrepressible fondness for internal rhymes) puts it; the flies are legion; and when a bedraggled courier (Dashiell Eaves) stumbles in with another discouraging missive from one General G. Washington, the gentlemen of the assembly recoil from his stench.
Moreover, the show does a miraculously solid job of giving specific, discrete identities to each of the score of delegates at the Congress. (Yes, there were many more at the real thing, but economy, if nothing else, makes such license forgivable.) Actually, these characters (in many cases, drawn from figures who have become national archetypes) have far more individuality than those of Mr. Stone's current history-based musical hit, "Titanic."
Mr. Ellis's handsome production, with traditional but first-rate sets and costumes by Tony Walton and William Ivey Long, respectively, doesn't attempt to impose a contemporary, ironic gloss on the proceedings. The director and his ensemble, ably led by Brent Spiner as the agitating John Adams, do a fine job, though, in conveying the irksome thrust and parry, and the compromise and counterplotting, that have always made American legislatures move (or, just as often, not move).
With a couple of exceptions, the actors kindly avoid stepping over the line into buffoonish exaggeration. And there's enough troubled shading, in both plot and characterization, to remind us that great events are often shaped by mixed motives and less-than-noble emotions. As the wily old Benjamin Franklin (played in a dry, low key by Pat Hingle) points out, these are not demigods; they're ordinary men trying to get a job done. And the show's form is dictated by the twisting stratagems involved in accomplishing that job.
The music, from a man who had a pop tunesmith's knack for paying foxy homage to familiar melody lines (here including even "The Star-Spangled Banner") in songs that stick to the memory, has its irritating low points but more high ones than most people probably remember.
The trio in which Adams, Franklin and Thomas Jefferson (Paul Michael Valley) harmonize about the "hatching" of a new nation in a song called "The Egg" comes close to realizing your worst fears about what this show could be. So does a coy, double-entendre number called "He Plays the Violin," in which Jefferson's bride, Martha (the appealing Lauren Ward, making the best of a bad lot), brought in to relieve her husband's sexual frustration so he can write the Declaration, describes her husband's particular brand of foreplay.
But the score of "1776" also finds invigorating musical metaphors for the political process. The opening number, "Sit Down, John," an irascible call-and-response argument between Adams and his adversaries, is full of cantankerous life and is a terrific mood setter.
Even better is "Cool, Considerate Men," with exquisitely droll staging by Kathleen Marshall, in which the Congress's conservatives (led by an excellent Michael Cumpsty) find their political tempo in the measured rhythms of a minuet. And as Edward Rutledge of South Carolina, a fiery, charismatic Gregg Edelman turns the haunting "Molasses to Rum," a sinister account of slavery, into the show-stopping equivalent of senatorial grandstanding.
There is also the graver lyricism of the ballad of a dying soldier sung by Mr. Eaves's courier, a reminder that while Congress piddled, America burned. And Mr. Spiner (yes, the one who plays the android Data on "Star Trek: The Next Generation") and Linda Emond, as Abigail Adams, are charming in their sentimental epistolary duets.
It should be noted that large stretches, especially in the first act, have no songs at all, as the book focuses entirely on the clash of Congressional wills. But Mr. Stone, who has fine-tuned his book for this production, knows how to turn political debate into pleasurable, and remarkably lucid, spectator sport. At its best, the show suggests -- in its Classic Comics way -- what you want C-Span to be but all too seldom is.

1776
 
Music and lyrics by Sherman Edwards; book by Peter Stone, based on a concept by Mr. Edwards. Directed by Scott Ellis; musical direction by Paul Gemignani; musical staging by Kathleen Marshall; sets by Tony Walton; costumes by William Ivey Long; lighting by Brian Nason; sound by Brian Ronan; orchestrations, Brian Besterman; conductor, Mark Mitchell; dance arrangements by Peter Howard; hair by David Brian Brown; production stage manager, Lori M. Doyle; dialects, K. C. Ligon. Presented by the Roundabout Theater Company, Todd Haimes, artistic director; Ellen Richard, general manager. At Criterion Center Stage Right, 1530 Broadway, at 45th Street.

WITH: Pat Hingle (Benjamin Franklin), Brent Spiner (John Adams), Paul Michael Valley (Thomas Jefferson), Dashiell Eaves (Courier), Lauren Ward (Martha Jefferson), Michael Cumpsty (John Dickinson), Gregg Edelman (Edward Rutledge) and Linda Emond (Abigail Adams).

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
India, Mon Amour

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
When I was young in India . . .
Often, when I give myself time to think about my life the words pronounce themselves to me. Sometimes they startle me, the times I hear them when I thought I had been thinking about other things and other places. Until a few months ago I believed the words had to do only with the four years I spent as the New York Times correspondent in India, in the second half of the 1950's. 
 But in March, on one of many journeys back, I understood that what the words said to me was that I had felt young not just in the 50's but always since, whenever I returned to India. I realized that every return was like starting fresh -- the same excitement and zest, the same sense that not just a country but a whole world of infinite variety was spread out before me and that I had the delicious chance to learn about it, just by going forward to meet it.
All year, as India approached the 50th anniversary of its independence on Aug. 15, 1947, it has been getting unsparing analysis and criticism. I contributed a share.
But not today, and I hope never will I send her one of those black-bordered cards she's been getting for decades. They arrive with every birthday or crisis from Indians and foreigners. Americans and Indian professionals share a particular delight in kicking their country around.
By now you may have guessed I am seized by India. It could be said I love India, so I say it.
I love India for personal reasons. It gave me decades of discovery, learning and friendships -- and lots and lots of stories to write. All I had to do was go out and scoop them up; for reporters a golden land.
I love India because when almost all newly independent countries became Communist or Fascist, or militaristic tyrannies that the world prettified by calling authoritarian, and through all the decades when the West poured its treasure into dictatorships and its contempt into India, the Indians stuck with democracy. That is the most personal reason of all for a foreigner who knows he himself could not thrive, and might not live, without it.
Some birthday mourners say yes, India has elections but elections themselves do not a political democracy make. No, but they certainly do when they are as free and regular as India's and when India adds freedom of press, worship, courts, speech, assembly and politics -- and a usually vote-smart public.
In the 50 years since 1947 Indians created a single nation where none existed before, out of 500 princely states. They built it despite religions at war with each other for centuries, and the death of a million people in the war of partition. They fashioned a steadily industrializing state, which produced a huge middle class. Its scientists, doctors and computer wizards bolster not only India but America and other Western countries.
Indians have not solved the old evils that still threaten their future -- poverty, illiteracy, the birth rate, violence between Hindu castes and among Hindu, Muslim and Sikh. And newer evils are eating into the national marrow: epidemic corruption and business regulation that Indian politicians keep promising to end but don't.
However, consider the West's record in the 50 years before 1947:
Two world wars. One Holocaust. Fascism and Communism. Unknowable millions slaughtered by Germany. Policies that helped Japan defeat China and then helped the Communists take over China. Nuclear bombs, two used (thousands still available). World depressions. Famines in Western colonies -- like India.
And now for a few world highlights since 1947, during India's half-century of self-rule.
Corruption: Italy and Russia. Religious and communal warfare: Bosnia. Racial tensions: France and Germany. Appeasement of dictators: Western arms and technology to Iraq, Communist China, etc. Famines: Mao bringing death by starvation to unknowable millions. Disease: AIDS and tobacco-cancer. Drugs, crime and cynicism: see everywhere. Exception: the U.S., which knows no poverty, disease, corruption or racial tensions.
After examining the above two paragraphs could we please wait before sending more black-bordered cards on India's birthdays -- wait say 50 more years?

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rise 0.2% As Growth Stays Controlled

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Government statisticians produced an avalanche of fresh data on the economy today, but when analysts added things up, they found little to alter opinions: growth is solid, inflation is subdued and Federal Reserve policy makers will stand pat next Tuesday.
Consumer prices, the Labor Department found, climbed two-tenths of 1 percent in July, a touch higher than in the preceding four months, but still in line with expectations. 
 Industrial output, according to the Federal Reserve, also expanded by only two-tenths of 1 percent last month as automotive production, hurt by strikes, acted as a drag. The pace of increase slowed from June, reducing the risk that the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities is overheating.
"We have an economy that's doing well, and there's virtually no inflation pressure," said Richard B. Berner, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. He agreed with what has solidified into a near-unanimous view that the Fed will defer any increase in interest rates for at least six weeks, perhaps longer.
Still other figures today showed that first-time claims for unemployment benefits increased by 12,000 last week, a reading that suggested that the labor market, while perhaps moderating a bit, remains very tight. Because of required waiting periods in states that allow strikers to collect benefits, there was no impact from the 185,000 idled workers at U.P.S.
And the Commerce Department issued a report on June inventories that showed bigger buildup at the retail level than previously estimated, indicating the possibility of reduced production requirements in the future. Some analysts expressed concern about high inventories while others dismissed such fears.
The Consumer Price Index provided further reassurance that inflation remained well in check. On Wednesday, the Labor Department reported that producers in July received less for finished goods for a record seventh straight month.
While the C.P.I., which includes services and goods, is not showing a total absence of inflation these days, it registered no increase in the cost of medical care, the first time this occurred since late 1975.
This category, accounting for 7 percent of the index, had long been a chief source of inflation pressure but has now moderated to a 2.7 percent increase during May, June and July.
But some analysts noted that while the price of products showed virtually no inflation -- prices were up one-tenth of 1 percent in July and 1.1 percent over the latest 12 months -- services were less well contained.
John Youngdahl, senior money market economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said this trend could eventually make the Fed uneasy. Services account for 57 percent of the Consumer Price Index.
"Goods pricing is getting more and more favorable and yet services are looking a little bit firmer," he said, pointing to six consecutive advances of three-tenths of 1 percent for services other than those involving energy. This meant an annual rate of 3.4 percent, well above the 2.8 percent rate posted for the six months through January.
Food prices rose moderately, the report showed, with sizable increases for eggs, beef and coffee partly offset by another decline for dairy products. Coffee is 23.5 percent more costly than in February.
In transportation, airline fares reversed course to jump 2.3 percent, and prices accelerated for new motor vehicles. But used cars fell 1.1 percent, and gasoline was lower for the fifth straight month.
The so-called core C.P.I., which excludes the volatile categories of food and energy, rose the same as the overall index, two-tenths of 1 percent, and is 2.4 percent above the July 1996 reading.
For the New York metropolitan area, consumer prices climbed three-tenths of 1 percent last month, more than in Philadelphia, Los Angeles or Chicago but less than San Francisco's four-tenths of 1 percent increase. Since July 1996, New York's inflation is 2.5 percent compared with 2.2 percent for the nation.
The Fed's production report showed that the industrial operating rate for July was down two-tenths of a point, to 83.1 percent, comfortably below the point, albeit indefinite, at which inflationary bottlenecks could be expected to develop.

HEADLINE: Job Boom in New York City Excludes City Residents

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In an unexpected twist that reflects the lopsided nature of economic expansion in the New York region, a robust spurt of job creation in New York City has apparently created a wealth of new opportunities, but not for people who live in the city, where unemployment has hit double digits. It is the suburbs that have benefited.
The apparent contradiction, described in a report to be issued today by Alan G. Hevesi, the New York City Comptroller, results from the type of jobs that are being created: mainly positions on Wall Street, at high-technology companies, and at firms that require advanced skills and education. 
 But the report said this newly created pool of jobs, about 21,900 during the first six months of the year, would have seemed a mirage for most city residents in search of work. Overall employment among city residents fell by 23,900 during the same period, and the unemployment rate rose to 10 percent, double the rate for the nation and a level not seen since the depth of the city's recession in 1991.
The main reason, according to Mr. Hevesi and several other experts, is that skilled suburbanites have been flocking to fill the new jobs in Manhattan, displacing lesser-skilled city residents and rapidly increasing ridership on commuter trains and buses. In contrast to 1996, when more than 25,000 city residents found new jobs in the suburbs, the regional employment pattern shifted to the opposite direction in the first half of 1997, with an increase of more than 45,000 suburban residents finding jobs in the city.
"In the context of an economic boom that is driving city revenues beyond our expectations, this is a serious item of bad news," Mr. Hevesi said in an interview.
Advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani disagreed.
"It is simply a flawed analysis," Randy M. Mastro, New York City's Deputy Mayor for operations, said of the report, which derived its employment data mainly from the New York State Department of Labor. Mr. Mastro said that the data were in error for the first half of 1997, and that the report was even more misleading if it was regarded as a measure of the New York City economy during Mayor Giuliani's tenure. Since 1994, Mr. Mastro said, more than 150,000 jobs have been created, most for city residents.
But Ruth W. Messinger, the leading Democratic candidate for mayor, said the report was "further proof of what I've been saying: that 1 out of 10 New Yorkers is out of work because jobs are going to people who don't live in New York City."
"It may be good times for people who live across the Hudson River, but it's bad times for people in the five boroughs," Ms. Messinger said.
Among Mr. Hevesi's recommendations were that the city and state, while dedicating more money to education, also find ways to expand public transportation options for city residents to northern New Jersey, Westchester County, Nassau County and elsewhere where demand for workers is intense and unemployment rates are less than half that of New York City.
"Creative use of buses and trains during periods when they would otherwise sit idle, and discounts for reverse commutes, would help address this problem," Mr. Hevesi said.
But economists and business executives said yesterday that the mismatch between the location and skill level of new jobs in the region reflected longstanding demographic shifts that are simply being heightened this year, and that government policies cannot be expected to reverse.
"It is absolutely true that the labor market is tight in Fairfield County and we would endorse initiatives to make commutation more feasible in both directions," said Christopher Bruhl, the president of the Business Council of Southwestern Connecticut, where unemployment in such cities as Greenwich, Stamford and Norwalk is below 4 percent.
"But we are a very high-skilled labor market, and it would not be the right idea to provide people with public transportation so they can be told no, they don't qualify," he said.
The disjointed employment trends documented by Mr. Hevesi come amid a legacy of more than 25 years in which high-skilled, high-paying New York City jobs have been moving to the suburbs, starting with the relocation of large corporate headquarters from Manhattan during the 1970's. The shift of high-paid employment spawned a fresh migration of workers to homes in affluent suburban communities.
But during the 1990's, corporate layoffs have trimmed the payrolls of many of the same companies. And while smaller high-technology companies, publishers, investment houses and others have followed those companies to the suburbs, preventing a steep reversal for what had become suburban bastions of high salaries, high skill levels and high-cost living, the burst of job growth experienced in New York City this year has not been duplicated in the suburbs.
Mr. Hevesi said that the situation has prompted many of the suburban professionals, even those who had hoped to combine a suburban home with a suburban job, to commute into the city. In one indicator of the trend, he said, the number of residents of Westchester, Nassau and other counties who had jobs had grown far more rapidly in the first half of 1997 than the number of jobs that were available in those counties.
In another indicator, the report said that bridge and tunnel commuter traffic into Manhattan had increased sharply, with bus travel over the George Washington Bridge from New Jersey up 5 percent and auto traffic through the Holland Tunnel up 6.8 percent during the early months of this year.
James Hughes, an economist and urban planner at Rutgers University in New Jersey, said yesterday that the shift was in part a result of the aging of the generation born after World War II. Many of the baby boomers, now 30 to 50 years old, are committed to raising children in the suburbs, and will remain there even if a growing share of the region's jobs are in the city, he said.

HEADLINE: Dow, in an Up-and-Down Day, Ends Up

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market bounced around yesterday, seemingly directionless, despite a good inflation report and a decline in interest rates.
After the Government said that consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July, a sign that inflation is tame, the bond market rallied, but stocks languished. 
 Through much of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average moved up and down, largely in negative territory, until a sudden rash of buying at the close lifted the average a meager 13.71 points, to 7,942.03.
In the previous five sessions, the Dow had lost 4 percent of its value, dragged down by concerns about higher interest rates, a weakening dollar and the threat of inflation.
But two days of excellent reports on the inflation front have been unable to return the market to its exalted height of just a week ago, when the Dow was at a record 8,259.31.
Wall Street analysts attributed the weakness to the fact that the tremendous gains of the previous four months -- gains that saw the Dow rise about 29 percent -- were just too much, too fast.
"The market was overextended," said Larry Wachtel, a market analyst with Prudential Securities. "I don't care what kind of inflation news you get. You can throw all the good news in the world at it, but it's got to rest."
What gains there were yesterday were modest. While oil stocks were weak yesterday, drug stocks rebounded from several days of sharp losses.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.75 points to close at 924.77 and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index gained 3.29, to 1,586.69.
Advancing issues beat decliners by a 5-to-4 margin on the Big Board on volume of about 532.3 million shares.
Among Dow stocks, Procter & Gamble was the best performer, up 2 11/16 , to 144 7/16 , along with Hewlett-Packard, up 2, to 69 7/8. Of the Nasdaq issues, Micron Technology rose 2 1/4, to 44 7/8, one day after falling 7 1/2 points on worries about a profit slowdown.
A large portion of the trading volume in recent weeks has been program trading, according to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm based in Greenwich, Conn. And that may be contributing to the sharp price swings.
"There aren't a whole lot of people anxious to buy or sell," said Laszlo Birinyi, the president of Birinyi Associates. "And in that vacuum, the marginal investor has a much more significant impact on prices."
In other words, with fewer players, a program trade, or even a smaller trade, can more easily sway prices.
Michael Metz, the chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company, believes that there is something more ominous at work in the market.
"The market's discounted the perfect scenario already," said Mr. Metz, who has long been bearish. "The inflation figures were great, but that's past history."
Indeed, Mr. Metz believes that most of the gains in the last few months were the result of "trend following" and the popularity of investing in mutual funds that track the major indexes.
But now, he said, many investors may be coming to the conclusion that profit margins cannot continue to rise, as they have been doing for some time.
One reason for such a concern, he said, was last Friday's warning from the Coca-Cola Company, which said that its earnings would slow in the third quarter of this year.
Mr. Metz said that the warning -- coming from a company that has seen steady, double-digit gains for some time now -- was a sign that corporate earnings growth was slowing.
Such concerns, he said, were one reason the market failed to respond yesterday to better-than-expected inflation news. Instead, investors are worried that they may have paid far too much for their stocks.
"It's just like a patient that doesn't respond to medicine," he said of the market's performance. "He's sicker than you think."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Joining Low- and High-Income Rentals at the Hip

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Seventy-two rental apartments for low-income tenants are going up in two projects on the North Shore of Staten Island. At the same time, a 22-story 246-unit luxury rental tower is under way on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The projects are linked by New York City's 421a tax certificate program.
Under this program, developers who build low-income housing receive tax abatements from the city that can be used for market-rate housing projects in Manhattan, underscoring the reliance of new construction on public benefits. 
 The program works like this: For each low-income unit that developers build, the city gives them five transferable property tax abatement certificates under which the tax rate rises over a 10-year period. Developers typically sell the certificates to a builder of market-rate housing between 14th and 96th Streets in Manhattan.
Projects in that area are not eligible for tax abatements unless they are tied to low-income housing usually built outside that zone or the low-income units are built as part of a new Manhattan development under the so-called 80-20 program, which uses tax-exempt-bond financing. In this program, 20 percent of the units are leased to low-income residents. Buildings financed with such bonds are eligible for a 20-year city tax abatement.
Of the 72 one- and two-bedroom low-income rentals being built on Staten Island, for which the developer received 360 tax certificates, 28 units, known as Harbor Manor, are on Harbor Road in the Mariners Harbor section. The remaining 44 units are at Nicholas Manor on Nicholas and Slaight Avenues in Port Richmond. The developer is Harbor Court Associates of Bulls Head on Staten Island.
The building at 230 East 86th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, will have studio to three-bedroom units. The Related Companies of Manhattan is the developer.
Both developers said that without the tax certificate program, they would not have proceeded.
Developers say there is renewed interest in the program, which began in 1984, as the city's housing market has improved and other government subsidies for low-income housing have dwindled.
The 360 tax certificates from the Staten Island projects were sold to Related, raising $3.6 million of the $7.8 million needed to build the low-income rentals, said R. Randy Lee, president of Harbor Court. The remaining $4.2 million was raised by Harbor Court's sale of Federal tax credits, bought by individuals or corporations for tax write-offs.
The Related Companies is using the tax certificates to keep real estate taxes low for 10 years on its Upper East Side tower.
Jeff T. Blau, a senior vice president at Related, said that even with today's higher rents, rental construction, given the combination of taxes and higher development costs in Manhattan, still is not economically possible without public benefits like abatements.
Related has four other rental projects, with 1,091 units recently completed or under way in the city. All are mixed-income projects that use the 80-20 method of tax-exempt financing.
The New York State Legislature recently authorized the State Housing Finance Agency to issue $350 million more in bonds under the 80-20 program, but most of that money has already been spoken for. "With resources limited, the tax certificate program is an alternative," said David J. Wine, president of Related's management arm, the Related Management Company. "Without it, rents would have to be 15 to 17 percent higher."
Mr. Wine said that over the 10-year life of the abatements, property taxes would be reduced by as much as 50 percent on the Upper East Side project.
But there are concerns about the program's viability because the city is getting fewer Federal credits, the other subsidy needed to create privately built affordable housing.
This year, the Pataki administration redirected many of the Federal credits elsewhere in the state, saying New York City had been getting about 70 percent of them for years. Though some credits have been restored to the city, it has lost the ability to construct thousands of affordable units, housing analysts said.
Some developers, including Related, say that with fewer low-income projects being built, fewer tax certificates will be sold, which could slow the pace of market-rate construction. At the Staten Island projects, designed to resemble town houses, the 650- to 1,100-square-foot apartments will be leased to tenants earning $19,000 to $29,000 a year based on family size. Monthly rents will be $390 to $520, plus utilities.
At 230 East 86th Street, rising on a site once occupied by a turn-of-the-century apartment row, the units will have 450 to 1,300 square feet. Rents are expected to start at $1,600 for the smallest unit and $3,000 for the larger ones, Mr. Wine said. The $75 million project will also have 40,000 square feet of retail space and such amenities as a health club and a sun terrace.

HEADLINE: Iran's Moderate President Faces Dissent Over Cabinet Choices

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 14

 BODY:
President Mohammed Khatami of Iran has had the briefest of political honeymoons -- and his differences with political opponents are now coming out in the open.
Analysts and diplomats said today that Mr. Khatami, a moderate Shiite Muslim cleric, was facing a stern challenge by conservative opponents over some of his choices for Cabinet ministers. 
 The 54-year-old President inherited an economy that was showing early signs of a possible slowdown and an electorate filled with high expectations of change, they added.
Conservatives and hard-liners, who had largely refrained from publicly criticizing Mr. Khatami since his election in May, have opened up with harsh attacks on his Cabinet selections ahead of a parliamentary debate on Tuesday.
"It is now certain that a noteworthy number of these nominees will not be able to get the Parliament's vote of confidence," the Teheran Times newspaper said today.
Some analysts said the 270-seat Parliament was expected to approve the majority of Mr. Khatami's 22-member Cabinet but vote against the proposed Culture Minister, Ataollah Mohajerani.
Mr. Mohajerani has been criticized by conservatives for his advocacy of greater cultural freedoms and his call in 1990 for direct talks with the United States.
"Introducing a person like Mohajerani, who seeks relations with America, is an insult to the Majlis," deputy Mehdi-Reza Darvishzadeh told the Resalat newspaper today.
The Culture Ministry plays a key role in domestic life in Iran since it has oversight over what books and films can be printed and the extent of media freedom.
Conservatives are also expected to question the nomination as Interior Minister of Abdollah Nouri, a cleric deputy who leads a pro-Khatami faction in Parliament, analysts said.
Mr. Khatami's choice of Kamal Kharrazi, Iran's representative to the United Nations, as Foreign Minister has also been attacked by hard-liners who question the revolutionary credentials of Mr. Kharrazi, who lived a long time in the United States.
Mr. Khatami was swept into power in national elections in May after winning wide support from Iranian youth, women and the middle class, who saw in him a leader able to inject social and economic freedoms into the stern Islamic state.
From his election victory to his swearing-in ceremony on Aug. 4, Mr. Khatami raised the possibility of changes in peoples' daily lives and that his administration could herald a change in Iran's foreign relations.
Mr. Khatami fought back against the attacks on his nominees with a televised nationwide address Wednesday night, saying that he was determined to press through his program, which was backed by a strong electoral mandate.
"I have a pact with the people to fulfill my plans," he said in his first major interview since taking office.
Mr. Khatami also used the address to call for the creation of an independent press and formal political parties, which have not been allowed by authorities since the years after the 1979 revolution.
Parliament is led by the speaker, Ali Akbar Nateq-Nouri, who was defeated by Mr. Khatami in the recent election.
Mr. Khatami said he would respect Parliament decisions and had a list of alternative names for Cabinet posts.
He also suggested that a woman would be in his Cabinet as a vice president, a position which does not need parliamentary approval.
Iran's economic health will also be of concern to Mr. Khatami as evidence emerges that Government revenues have fallen below budget forecasts and that prices continue to rise.
The President said that work would quickly begin on a new budget, which would be presented to the Parliament in November.

HEADLINE: 57 Towns Get $131 Million For Tourism On Erie Canal

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
The Federal Government will provide $131 million to 57 communities along the Erie Canal and connecting waterways in the most sweeping economic development initiative in upstate New York in decades, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Andrew M. Cuomo, announced yesterday.
The HUD loans and grants, coupled with $102 million in private funds and $57 million from local governments, will be used to build shops, housing, marinas, restaurants, recreational trails and other tourist attractions along the state's 524-mile canal system in an effort to revive the economies of towns that once relied on manufacturing. Officials said they expected the development to create 5,000 jobs. 
 "Once they move out of manufacturing, what do they do?" Mr. Cuomo said. "The answer for the nation has been tourism. San Antonio did it with the Riverwalk, Washington State did it with the Puget Sound and Baltimore did it with the Inner Harbor. Frankly, the Erie Canal has nicer geography and a richer history."
One of the most ambitious projects in the initiative involves a British boat company, Crown Blue Lines, which operates canal boats in Europe. The company hopes to draw European tourists to the Erie Canal. It plans to buy 26 European-style boats from Penn Yan Marine Manufacturing of Penn Yan, N.Y., a community in the Finger Lakes region. Its boats would ply the canal starting from Frankfort.
The mule-drawn barges of the Erie Canal, which extends from Buffalo to just north of Albany, opened the Midwest to commerce from the Northeast and the Atlantic Ocean 170 years ago. The canal waned as railroads were built and was eventually rendered obsolete by superhighways.
Yesterday in North Tonawanda and Rochester, Mr. Cuomo announced some of the 200 projects to be financed by the loans and grants. Today, as he announces more projects in central and eastern New York, he will be joined by the Secretary of the Interior, Bruce Babbitt, in Albany. He is expected to release the preliminary findings of a National Park Service study on making the Erie Canal a National Heritage Corridor.
HUD will provide $74.2 million in low-interest loans and $56.8 million in grants to the communities, which competed for the money by filing development proposals. The development is expected to rejuvenate the fading downtowns of upstate New York.
Perhaps no community did as well per capita as Holley, a village of 2,000 residents 20 miles west of Rochester. Holley was given $1.24 million in grants and $666,000 in low-interest loans. It plans to build shops, bed and breakfast inns, parks and restrooms along the banks of the canal.
"We're a good grant writer," said Holley's Mayor, Lewis R. Passarell. "We're trying to revitalize the whole area. We want to bring new businesses into Holley big time."
David Albanese, the Mayor of Albion, a village of 6,200 midway between Buffalo and Rochester, wants to erect a canal museum, restore an old building, renovate a waterfront park, build a gazebo, pave a parking lot, build a pump station and erect more tie-ups along the canal. Albion received $2.2 million in loans and grants. "We got a lot more than I expected," Mr. Albanese said. "This is hopefully going to be unbelievable. Everybody is enthused about it."
The Erie Canal initiative has received broad-based bipartisan support. The plan by Mr. Cuomo, the son of the former Democratic Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, was endorsed by Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Republican Senator who helped engineer Governor Cuomo's defeat, and by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

HEADLINE: A Golden Anniversary in Queens;
Indian and Pakistani Immigrants Honor 2 Homelands

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
Up a narrow flight of stairs in Jackson Heights, Queens, above the rich scents of curry and the high-pitched melodies of Indian pop divas that wash over the bustling sidewalk, two spare offices appear to house nothing more remarkable than a businessman and an accountant.
But the second-floor office of Kanu Chauhan, a concert promoter and developer from Bombay, is the headquarters for this weekend's 50th anniversary celebration of India's independence, while just upstairs, the office of Manny Beg, an accountant from Karachi, was the nerve center of Pakistan's 50th anniversary festival, held last Sunday. 
 Fifty years after Pakistan was carved from India at the moment of independence from the British Raj, this layering of celebratory efforts -- Mr. Chauhan, a Hindu who owns the building, rents to Mr. Beg, a Muslim -- is no anomaly in Jackson Heights. Thousands of immigrants from countries that have been enemies since 1947 live together peaceably in the commercial heart of New York City's South Asian population.
"It's not a perfect harmony," said Madhulika Khandelwal, acting director of the Asian-American Center at Queens College. "There are moments of misgiving, but what you see in everyday life in Queens is a lot of interaction among peoples from South Asia."
Indians and Pakistanis buy from each other. They work for each other. The belong to the same merchants' association. They share the same few blocks of commercial space along 74th Street. They idolize the same Indian movie stars and watch the same cricket matches. And, most importantly, they share a common story: they came to the United States in pursuit of a life better than what they left behind.
"Sometimes, people say money is the cause of evils," said Ramesh Navani, a part owner of the India Sari Shop and a Hindu with childhood memories of fleeing Pakistan for India 50 years ago in a noisy propeller plane. "But sometimes, money keeps you so busy you have no time to think of nasty things."
In the New York metropolitan area, a magnet for more Indian and Pakistani immigrants than any other urban region in the nation, nostalgia for home has blended with ethnic pride to produce a burst of independence celebrations that may be more festive than those on the subcontinent, where the daily drip of political venality and the ever-present tragedy of poverty have complicated the moment.
This past Sunday, the police estimated that 10,000 people gathered for the Pakistan Day festival in Battery Park to picnic on fragrant, spicy food, listen to singers from home and feast their eyes on Pakistani movie stars. This coming Sunday, the India Day Parade, billed as "unprecedented, spectacular, colossal," will sail down lower Madison Avenue, with the John Wayne of Indian movie stars, Amitabh Bachchan, in the lead as grand marshal.
But in the midst of the parades, banquets, concerts and conferences that are the public face of immigrant celebrations of independence, many of those who left home because they were dissatisfied with life on the subcontinent are in a mood that is more meditative than joyous.
Saeeda Qureshi, 43, who emigrated from Pakistan 21 years ago and has raised her children here, said she was glad to be Pakistani, but disgusted by the state of politics in her homeland. "I feel very good about independence," said Mrs. Qureshi, who lives on Staten Island. "But the politicians are very bad in Pakistan. There is too much corruption."
Indian immigrants, too, have complex feelings about their nation's progress. They say they take pride in being from the world's largest democracy, but abhor the corruption that has debased it. They take heart in the growth of the country's middle class and the loosening of state control over the economy, while mourning the high rates of illiteracy and poverty.
And some ponder the persistence of communal conflict between Hindus and Muslims. The Global Organization of People of Indian Origin, a nonprofit group based in New York, has invited experts to speak on that theme, among others, at a 50th anniversary conference on Aug. 30 at the New York Hilton and Towers.
The integration of Hindus and Muslims in neighborhood and civic life within India, which echoes in relations between Indian and Pakistani immigrants here, may well be the key to peace between them, said one of those experts, Ashutosh Varshney, an associate professor of government at Harvard University.
Professor Varshney has compared some of the most riot-prone cities in India, including Ahmadabad and Hyderabad, with the most tranquil, Lucknow and Calicut among them. He found that cities where Hindus and Muslims had everyday relationships at the neighborhood level and joined together in business, labor, professional and voluntary associations, were the most resistant to violent polarization.
And peace is actually far more prevalent than it appears, he said. His study found that from 1950 to 1995, 18 cities with only 8 percent of India's population accounted for two-thirds of the 7,300 riot-related deaths. "Peace does not make news," he said. "It's not good copy."
But coexistence, Queens style, is a visual feast. The daily pageantry of Jackson Heights, where women shop for brilliantly-hued saris ($29, $35 or $39 at India Sari Palace) and men thrust plump fresh chickens into tandoori ovens, is a show that runs free for the watching.
The first waves of immigration to New York from the subcontinent began after 1965, when United States immigration quotas that had favored Europeans were abandoned. Many Indians, who far outnumber Pakistanis here, came under rules that gave a preference to the highly skilled and educated. They, in turn, brought their wives and children, siblings and parents, in a chain of familial migration.
By 1990, United States Census figures show, the New York area had 199,010 Indian residents, about half of them living in the city, and 21,726 Pakistanis, two-thirds of whom lived in the city. From 1990 to 1994, 14,486 Indian immigrants and 7,465 Pakistani immigrants moved to the city, according to the City Planning Department.
Typically, Queens has been the newcomers' first home. But many immigrants, as they have become more prosperous, have scattered to New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester County.
And increasingly since the 1970's, Jackson Heights has become an ethnic marketplace for South Asian immigrants from all over the region. The everyday connections between Indians and Pakistanis here are everywhere evident.
The first Indian-owned store in the neighborhood, Sam and Raj, opened in 1973 to sell 220-volt appliances to immigrants for shipping home to relatives on the subcontinent, where that voltage is standard. The store hired a Pakistani salesman, Atif Hasan, in 1978. Mr. Hasan has since risen to be the store manager.
"They never made me feel I was hired because I'm Pakistani," Mr. Hasan said. And Nitin Vora, who is a part owner of the store, said Mr. Hasan was right. "We hired him because he's a nice person," Mr. Vora said.
Across 74th Street, at the New York Gold Company, Vasantrai M. Gandhi, 60, who emigrated 20 years ago from Bombay, was carefully weighing a ring, necklace and bracelet for sale to Raj Kanchwal, 37, who came from Karachi 12 years ago and runs his own health food store in Forest Hills. Mr. Kanchwal, hunting for gifts for his wife, found the shop in the Yellow Pages.
"I have a lot of friends who are Indian," said Mr. Kanchwal, whose parents were among the millions of Muslims who fled India for Pakistan in 1947, as millions of Hindus emigrated in the opposite direction. Mr. Gandhi, who advertises his gold store in the Pakistani ethnic press, piped in, "Here there is no difference except for politics."
Among the second generation, the remaining divisions may fade further. Ritika Chadha, a 26-year-old accounting student at the State University in Albany who emigrated from Delhi as a child, still cherishes her ethnic identity, but she is also influenced by American culture. She admires Mohandas K. Gandhi, the great Indian leader -- and tellingly, she gleaned some of her impressions of him from Ben Kingsley's depiction of Gandhi in the 1982 movie.
As she munched on french fries while window shopping along 74th Street one recent afternoon, she recounted her experiences from a January trip to Delhi. Her family had hoped she would find a husband while she was there. She was introduced to three or four young men, but none was quite right. "I was a little too picky," she said. "I wanted more of a choice."
Indeed, Ms. Chadha had a choice of her own in mind back in New York City: a Pakistani limousine driver. They are to be married this week, she said.
"My parents are really against it," she said. "I'm Hindu. He's Muslim. But if I married an American, they wouldn't like it either. I'm a rebel with a cause."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Positive News On Inflation Lifts Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury market took a big step yesterday toward regaining the momentum it had in July, as more economic data suggesting solid growth, but with little threat of inflation, eased investors' concern further.
Analysts said the reports were good news for bond market participants, who until favorable data were released in the last few days were pricing in what they saw as an increased risk of an interest rate increase by the Fed at next week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. 
 The 30-year bond surged 31/32 , to a price of 97 25/32 , pushing the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, down to 6.55 percent, from 6.62 percent on Wednesday; that was the lowest yield since 6.44 percent at the conclusion of the Treasury's quarterly refunding of the nation's debt last week.
Yesterday, the Labor Department reported that workers' average weekly earnings, adjusted for inflation, fell in July from the previous month. Real average weekly earnings fell one-tenth of 1 percent, after rising a revised eight-tenths of 1 percent in June.
There were no surprises in the Labor Department's other report, which showed the Consumer Price Index up two-tenths of 1 percent in July, as expected. The index is the widest measure of prices consumers pay for goods and services. Other data released included weekly unemployment claims, which increased by 12,000, to 316,000, in the week ended last Saturday, while the Commerce Department said business inventories rose an unexpected seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, its sixth consecutive monthly gain. And industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July, a slower pace than in June.
Stuart G. Hoffman, senior vice president and chief economist for the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, said yesterday's numbers made it virtually certain that the central bank would not have to raise rates next week in an effort to head off price increases. "July gave us a clean sweep on inflation numbers, leaving us with the same picture we have been seeing right along: low inflation pressures and moderate growth, the perfect recipe to keep the Fed on hold."
Mr. Hoffman said he expected third-quarter economic growth to be between the 4.9 percent of the first quarter and the second's 2.2 percent.
But Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, a Canadian investment firm, said that despite the signs of a moderate rebound in growth, the July Consumer Price Index confirmed what the Producer Price Index for that month, reported on Wednesday, suggested. "While signs continue to mount that the economy is regaining speed, the strong growth is causing absolutely no damage to the stellar inflation performance," she said.
But while one big component of the index, energy prices, have been benign and actually sank by one-tenth of 1 percent in July, the Government noted in its report that this moderation might be over. Next month's report will probably disclose a big jump in gasoline costs, as pump prices are already up sharply in August, in contrast with typical seasonal declines during the month, the Government said.
Rates at yesterday's Treasury auction of new one-year bills were a bit higher than in last month's sale, with the average rate at auction yesterday 5.28 percent, up 2 basis points from 5.26 percent on July 17 and the highest since 5.35 percent on June 19. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Analysts said the results were generally in line with expectations, with the bid-to-cover ratio, or the total number of bids compared with the total sale amount, at 4.33 to 1. Over the last 12 months, the average of the ratio has been around 3.98 to 1.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of a new one-year bill:

HEADLINE: U.P.S. Hints at Flexibility in Talks With Union

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Negotiators for the United Parcel Service and the teamsters' union resumed talks today with a Federal mediator as the company hinted at new flexibility in bargaining to end the 11-day-old walkout.
After the company insisted for days that it would not budge from its "last, best and final offer," James P. Kelly, the chairman of U.P.S., said today that it might be willing to change its offer if the talks made progress. 
 Mr. Kelly, calling today's talks "informal discussions," told reporters that "if those informal discussions lead us to believe that the negotiations could be concluded at some point in time, then the last, best and final offer would cease to exist."
Labor Secretary Alexis Herman persuaded U.P.S. and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to resume talks at a Washington hotel after talking repeatedly with each side on Wednesday, prodding them to show more flexibility and find a solution. Talks broke off last Saturday, and each side has spent much of this week denouncing the other.
"I urge them to stay at the table until they reach a settlement," Ms. Herman said.
Evidence is mounting that the strike by 185,000 drivers, sorters and loaders is squeezing companies and consumers around the nation.
The two potential deal-breakers in the talks, officials close to the negotiations said, are the teamsters' demand that the company convert 10,000 part-time positions to full-time jobs and the company's demand to start a U.P.S.-only pension plan and withdraw from the teamsters' multi-employer plans.
The union has proposed converting the 10,000 part-time positions into full-time ones over the next four years, while the company has proposed converting 800. On pensions, U.P.S. says retirement benefits would rise an average of 50 percent per worker in the proposed single-company plan, while the union calls that number exaggerated and says the withdrawal of U.P.S. would hurt the multi-employer plans.
In an another statement showing increased flexibility, Mr. Kelly said: "We think the pension issue is very important for both our people and the future of our company. But, as I said, there is no one or two single issues that will determine whether we're able to reach agreement."
Before the talks resumed, Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president, warned strikers and the public not to raise their expectations about a deal.
"While there is no reason for optimism at this point," Mr. Carey said, "we will be there, ready to negotiate a reasonable agreement that provides the good jobs that American families need."
On another U.P.S. labor front, the president of the union representing the company's 2,000 pilots announced today that they might walk out in December, the peak shopping and shipping season, because they were unhappy about not reaching a new contract with U.P.S. since the old one expired in December 1995.
A strike by the union, the Independent Pilots Association, could shut down the company even if a settlement with the teamsters is reached, because the teamsters have pledged to honor the pilots' picket line. The pilots' union is honoring the teamsters' current picket line, which began on Aug. 4.
"Unless there is a significant change in direction," said Robert Miller, the president of the pilots' union, "U.P.S. is facing back-to-back strikes."
