LENGTH: 635 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

With Growth and Prices In Control, Bonds Gain
Growth is solid, inflation is subdued and Federal Reserve policy makers will probably stand pat for now on interest rates -- at least, that was what analysts drew from the latest economic reports by the Government. 
 Consumer prices climbed by two-tenths of 1 percent in July, a touch higher than in the preceding four months, but still in line with expectations. Industrial production also rose by two-tenths of 1 percent, a slightly slower growth rate than in June. [Page D4.]
 
Helped by the economic data, the Treasury market took a big step toward regaining some lost momentum. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.55 percent from 6.62. [D15.]
 
But the stock market seemed directionless, with the Dow industrials ending 13.71 points higher at 7,942.03. [D8.]
 
Pepsico Board Approves Spinoff
Pepsico will get $4.5 billion in cash to pay down debt and buy back shares when its Pizza Hut, KFC and Taco Bell restaurants are spun off into a new company, Tricon Global Restaurants. [D2.]
 
Kmart Earnings Down 9%
Kmart said quarterly earnings fell 9 percent because of slow sales and markdowns in women's apparel, but the results still beat expectations. Other retailers posted mixed results. [D2.]
 
Travelers Hires Pension Expert
Thomas W. Jones, a top executive at the world's largest pension system, T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F., will join the Travelers Group, where he will oversee efforts to expand the fee-based asset management business. [D8.]
 
Indonesia Yields to Currency Attack
Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, fell sharply against the dollar after the Indonesian central bank allowed it to float, joining other Southeast Asian nations in bowing to market forces. In Indonesia it was quoted at 2,830 to the dollar, about 6 percent weaker than before the decision was announced; later, in New York trading, it recovered somewhat, to 2,745. [D6.]
 
Thailand, hit hardest by the currency crisis, will get $1 billion in emergency credit from China, which is demonstrating a new connection with other Asian nations. [D15.]
 
Possible Softening in U.P.S. Stance
The United Parcel Service hinted at new flexibility in bargaining to end an 11-day-old strike as talks with the teamsters' union resumed. [A26.]
 
While the strike has hurt many small businesses, some catalogue companies have been able to get packages to customers with only a few days' delay, mostly by diverting their business to the Postal Service, which they had often tried to avoid in the past. [A26.]
 
For the fourth time in 23 years, a textile workers' union has failed in its effort to unionize North Carolina plants owned by Fieldcrest Cannon, which has come to symbolize Southern resistance to organized labor. [A26.]
 
Another Stock Fraud Settlement
GKN Securities of New York and 29 of its brokers agreed to pay $2.125 million to settle regulators' charges that they overcharged customers on stock trades. [D7.]
 
Kodak Plans Retail Push
Kodak, whose sales of film and its new Advantix system have been sluggish, is poised to plunk its name on 300 to 500 photo specialty stores across the country within the next 18 months, in an effort to strengthen its brand image among consumers. [D8.]
 
Hugo Boss and the Nazis
Hugo Boss, the clothier now known for classic men's suits and flashy ties, made uniforms for the Nazis, a spokeswoman acknowledged. The company founder's name appeared on a list of dormant bank accounts released by Swiss bankers. [D15.]
 
Guilty Plea in Honda Bribe Case
Rick Hendrick, one of the nation's biggest auto dealers and owner of a top stock car racing team, pleaded guilty to mail fraud in a case in which he was accused of making bribes to Honda executives. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Tobacco Chiefs Oppose a Plan For Big Penalty

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Tobacco industry executives expressed concern today at the White House about demands for stiffer penalties if they failed to meet targets for reductions in smoking by teen-agers under the proposed tobacco settlement. They said the $15 billion annual payments under the plan were all they could afford.
But the executives signaled that they were prepared to accept broad Food and Drug Administration authority over nicotine and other cigarette components in exchange for partial immunity from state and private lawsuits, participants said. 
 The meetings were part of a series of talks between Administration officials and industry representatives over the proposal to change the way cigarettes are made and marketed in America. Under the plan, major cigarette makers would pay $368 billion over 20 years to settle lawsuits filed by 39 states and Puerto Rico and two dozen class-actions suits.
The President is expected to announce his conclusions on the proposal early next month.
As part of the Administration review, officials of the Treasury Department and the Office of Management and Budget assessed the impact of the deal on the companies' financial health.
They concluded that the cigarette makers would suffer little economic harm because they would pass on virtually all the costs of the settlement in the form of higher prices. Estimates of the price increases ranged from 60 cents to $1 a package, depending on how much consumption declined as a result of higher prices and on the profit margin.
The President and his advisers have already indicated that Mr. Clinton would not endorse the deal unless the F.D.A.'s power to regulate tobacco was strengthened and penalties for failing to live up to the agreement were stiffened.
Michael A. Moore, the Attorney General of Mississippi and one of the lead tobacco negotiators, said in an interview after today's White House sessions that the various participants were "close" on the question of F.D.A. jurisdiction.

HEADLINE: U.S. ACTS TO OPEN MINORITY PROGRAM TO WHITE BIDDERS

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today set in motion changes in one of its premier affirmative action programs that would make it easier for white-owned companies to qualify for Government contracts that have been reserved almost exclusively for minorities.
The planned changes in the Small Business Administration program, announced today, are part of the Administration's continuing effort to modify Federal affirmative action policies to comply with a 1995 Supreme Court ruling that restricted the use of race as a consideration in awarding Federal contracts. 
 Administration officials and others who follow the issue say the changes in regulations may mean that an additional 3,000 companies will become eligible to apply for contracts under the program. Most of them are likely to be owned by white women, a fact that distressed members of minorities who said today that they feared that the effect would be to give them a smaller share of Federal contracting dollars.
The program, known bureaucratically as 8(a), is the Federal Government's largest effort to use affirmative action in awarding Government contracts.
In the last fiscal year, 6,115 companies -- all but 27 of them owned by members of racial or ethnic minorities -- were awarded Federal contracts totaling $6.4 billion as a result of the program.
The changes in the program are expected to be put in place later this year after a period of public comment. Although significant in themselves, they are only the first step in a larger effort to revamp Federal contracting programs that are based on race.
This fall, the Administration intends to issue additional new guidelines for other contracting programs based on an industry-by-industry and region-by-region look at discrimination against minority companies.
Although the Administration's main purpose in devising the new rules was to comply with the Supreme Court's ruling in Adarand Constructors Inc. v. Pena, Administration officials say that by allowing more whites into the 8(a) program, they will increase the size of the political constituency supporting affirmative action at a time when such programs are under increasing attack.
Aida Alvarez, administrator of the small-business agency, said it was "fair to say" that the Administration "looked to strengthen the program by expanding the definition of who might be eligible."
A company can now enroll in the program if it meets several criteria: it must be small; its owner must have a personal net worth of less than $250,000; and its owner must be "socially disadvantaged," a designation the law automatically bestows on black and Hispanic people, Indians, Asians, Eskimos and Native Hawaiians.
Whites must prove they are socially disadvantaged by showing such things as a history of discrimination, or unfair denial of credit.
Under the changes planned by the business agency, however, whites can prove social disadvantage through a "preponderance of evidence," rather than the more stringent legal standard of "clear and convincing evidence."
Some students of the program say the main beneficiaries of the change will be white women who will be able to prove a history of discrimination much more easily than white men. "You still have to prove that you are socially disadvantaged," said Jeanie M. Barnett, executive editor of Minority Business Entrepreneur magazine. "I don't think this is going to allow an influx of white males into the program."
Others are not so sure.
"It's a big question mark," said an Administration official who has been involved in the review of Federal affirmative action efforts and who spoke on condition of anonymity. "It could mean that we find a lot of white women who make the claim they are socially disadvantaged and get in this program. But we could find a lot of people who are disabled, or who are white men in Appalachia. So as to what will happen, we don't have the foggiest idea."
Representatives of minority-owned businesses are concerned that whoever owns the newly eligible companies, fewer Federal dollars will be awarded to minority-owned companies through the program.
"My feeling is that although white, female-owned businesses historically have had disadvantages, it's very difficult to absorb them into that program without having a negative impact on minority businesses because the overall amount of resources has not been increased," said Sam Carradine, executive director of the National Association of Minority Contractors.
Administration officials say they hope to expand economic opportunities for small, disadvantaged businesses -- whether owned by minorities or whites -- even as they allow more whites into the program.
In one proposal for achieving that goal, the business agency is contemplating placing a ceiling of $100 million on the amount any participant in the program can receive in a Federal contract. Currently, there is no cap on the value of a contract an eligible company may be awarded. The agency is also considering allowing enrollees to bid jointly on Federal contracts, thereby increasing the number of companies that may be awarded contracts.
Ms. Alvarez said Administration officials were discussing the possibility of awarding more Federal contracts to small, disadvantaged businesses, including 8(a) contractors, increasing the percentage to 23 percent of all Federal procurement from the current 20 percent. In the last fiscal year, these companies accounted for $41.1 billion in contracts.
Businesses in the 8(a) program alone accounted for 3.2 percent of all Federal contracts in the last fiscal year.
But as the Administration expands eligibility for the program, some worry that it may increase the potential for fraud, especially the practice of husbands' setting up businesses in their wives names so they can qualify under the new looser standards for white-owned companies.
"The problem is going to be certification," Ms. Barnett said. "How are you going to keep fronts out?"

Ill-Fated Astronaut Happy To Be Back From Space
Vasily Tsibliyev said he was happy to be back from the Russian space station Mir after a seemingly relentless series of mishaps during his tenure as commander. But the dusty steppes of Kazakhstan, where his Soyuz capsule landed, promised to be more hospitable than Moscow, where President Boris Yeltsin proclaimed human error to be the cause of the troubles which plagued the technically sophisticated Mir. Pakistanis were hardly sanguine as they celebrated the 50th anniversary of their country's independence. Conservative opponents in Iran's Parliament have bluntly objected to President Mohammed Khatami's proposed Cabinet members, especially those who advocate greater cultural freedoms. All nominations must be approved by Parliament, which is led by the man who was upset by Mr. Khatami in May elections. Mr. Khatami suggested he would appoint a woman to his cabinet as a vice president. A3

Israel eased slightly the blockade it set up two weeks ago around the West Bank cities of Hebron and Ramallah, allowing Palestinians living in those areas to leave for the first time since a suicide bombing in Jerusalem. HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Company Lured Back

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
City, state and port officials have agreed to provide tax breaks and cash incentives worth $6.3 million, or nearly $29,000 per worker, to lure Exco Noonan, a British foreign exchange company with 219 employees, back to Manhattan after a six-year stay in an office tower on the Jersey City waterfront.
Exco Noonan, which left New York in 1991, will return and consolidate with Exco RMJ, another division of Exco International P.L.C., on two floors at One World Trade Center, in a 15-year lease from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Exco Noonan will move from 10 Exchange Place in Jersey City; Exco RMJ will move its 241 employees from 199 Water Street. 
 City officials provided $3.9 million in real estate tax abatements. State officials added $2 million in grants. And the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey provided $400,000 in sales tax abatements, according to a spokeswoman for the city's Economic Development Corporation.
As part of the deal, Exco Noonan, whose employees have an average salary of $125,000, agreed to add 80 jobs within five years. City and state officials justified the high price by saying the payroll and sales taxes the company would generate would pay for the incentives in less than a year. DAVID M. HALBFINGER

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Israel Opens Door a Crack; Arafat Says It's Not Enough

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 14

 BODY:
A day after the departure of an American special envoy, Israel took its first small steps today toward easing punishing measures against Palestinian areas, but Yasir Arafat called the moves inadequate and said the Israelis remained intent on wrecking the peace agreement.
The American envoy, Dennis Ross, left on Wednesday after four days of talks that, a senior American official said today, had persuaded both sides to take action toward resolving the current crisis. 
 But the tone of Mr. Arafat's remarks today indicated that Mr. Ross was less successful in diminishing the deep distrust of both sides, which remains the biggest obstacle to progress.
"We say: 'Is this Government really ready to work with us to preserve the peace process and protect it? Is it really ready to do so?' I am sorry to say the answer is no," Mr. Arafat said, referring to the Israeli Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a speech in Ramallah.
Among the steps Israel announced today was a slight easing of the blockade around two major West Bank cities, Hebron and Ramallah, allowing Palestinian residents there to leave for the first time in the two weeks since two suicide bombers killed 14 people in a Jerusalem produce market.
Mr. Arafat complained that the continued refusal by Israel to let tens of thousands of Palestinian workers from Gaza and the West Bank into Israel and to turn over money owed to the Palestinian Authority indicated that the Israeli Government was not prepared to pursue the peace agreement.
"They are allowing a few people to move from one home to the other, but they are not letting through cement, steel and vegetables," Mr. Arafat said in remarks to a delegation of Israeli-Arabs. "They are not permitting any economic life."
Press reports on both sides concentrated on predicting when Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright might arrive in the region. The Secretary announced last week that she would visit the region within the month in hopes of pressing for accelerated peace talks, if the Palestinians took action on security issues.
The American official said today that Mr. Ross had not succeeded in trying to re-establish the idea that the peace negotiations only really worked when they were treated as a partnership.
"As difficult as it is, both sides need to tone down the rhetoric, and I do mean both sides," the official said. "It may make good television, but it doesn't help the process."
Mr. Ross had also urged Israeli leaders to lift sanctions not directly related to security, arguing that measures like withholding money due the Palestinian Authority were counterproductive. Tax revenues collected by Israel continue accumulating, with at least $40 million owed to the Authority now frozen in a Tel Aviv bank account.
Israel continues to insist that it will not ease the most severe of its measures until the Palestinian Authority takes concrete steps to arrest those responsible for organizing suicide attacks.
"What we would like to see is action on the commitment to fight terrorists, and when we see action -- any action -- in this direction, we will modify and adjust the measures taken accordingly," Mr. Netanyahu said at a news conference in Jordan on Wednesday after talks with King Hussein. Today, Mr. Netanyahu started a four-day vacation.
Israel detained seven Palestinians in the West Bank overnight and its bulldozers tore down two Palestinian houses today that it said had been erected without permits, bringing the total of houses knocked down since the bombing to 18.
The closings around Bethlehem remained in effect, and Palestinians from the West Bank were not allowed into Jerusalem. Gaza is also sealed off.
The identity of those who carried out the market bombing still has not been solved. Today, Mr. Arafat again tried to distance the Palestinian Authority from any responsibility, indicating that Israel should be held responsible for the security of predominately Jewish areas.
"If they want me to be in charge of security in West Jerusalem, then I am ready to send my colonels," Mr. Arafat said today, grinning. Mr. Netanyahu has said repeatedly that the two bombers, even if they came from outside Israel, the West Bank or Gaza, must have had help from inside Palestinian-controlled areas.
But Palestinian officials have resisted any move toward a wide crackdown at a time when most Palestinian see the peace talks as stalled.
Under an arrangement worked out by Mr. Ross, the chief security officers from both sides are supposed to meet in the presence of the C.I.A. station chief in Tel Aviv, who is to act as referee.
United States officials have been reticent on exactly how the process would work or how the C.I.A. official would act as the final arbiter between the Israeli side, headed by Israel's secret service chief, and the Palestinians under their intelligence director.
The American official said that the security consultations would be kept confidential. But he said that the C.I.A. had already handed Palestinian authorities lists of suspects compiled by the Israelis and that it was dismayed that some suspects had been released by the Palestinians. He said the C.I.A. had not done any independent verification of the Israeli lists.
The official also said the issue of suspects was the kind that the Americans hoped the Israelis and Palestinians would be able to work out by themselves through consultations.
He added that the United States also hoped to see a greater Palestinian effort to root out arms caches as part of an overall effort to combat militant groups that had dropped off since the security arrangements for Hebron were reached last January.
But the American official noted that no matter what the American mediator ruled on whether the Palestinians were making a full effort to combat terrorism, the Israelis still controlled the bank account containing the money owed to the Palestinians and they would decide when to turn it over to them.

 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 21, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about American-brokered talks on the Middle East misstated an American official's comment about the United States Government's dealings with the Palestinians. The official said a list of terrorism suspects was handed to the Palestinian Authority by the United States Government, not specifically the Central Intelligence Agency. And the official said it was American officials, not specifically C.I.A. aides, who were dismayed that the Palestinians had released some of the suspects from detention.

HEADLINE: Montserrat's 'Settlers'

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Aug. 11 news article on Montserrat's erupting volcano refers to "Irish colonists who settled in the 1600's." By the mid-1600's, most Irish exiles on that Caribbean island had been forcibly removed from Ireland by Oliver Cromwell, who designated Montserrat as a penal colony. 
 The harsh treatment of political and military prisoners, as well as orphans, widows and the unemployed who were deported, left a bitter legacy.
The nickname "Emerald Isle of the Caribbean" is due not so much to a faded colonial past but to a distinctive Irish flavor that still pervades Montserrat.
Many residents, most of whom are black, boast of their Irish ancestry. Also, the island still recognizes St. Patrick's Day as a public holiday.
 
BRIAN C. CRONIN
Miami Beach, Aug. 13, 1997

HEADLINE: West Moves to Back Bosnian Serb Leader Against Hard-Liners

BYLINE: By MIKE O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The West's principal civilian authority here set the stage today for what some diplomats are portraying as the opening round of a decisive diplomatic showdown with the Bosnian Serb authorities.
The Western representative has decided to support a move by the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, to dismiss the legislature of the Serbian-controlled part of Bosnia and call new elections. 
 The Bosnian Serb Constitutional Court ruled today that Mrs. Plavsic's action was illegal. But the office of Carlos Westerdorp, who was appointed to oversee the civilian side of enforcement of the Dayton peace accords, announced tonight that it would overrule the court's decision.
Mrs. Plavsic is being enthusiastically courted by Western diplomats as the only Bosnian Serb in office who even marginally accepts key provisions of the accords, which ended the war in Bosnia. But she is confronting hard-core separatist politicians, who retain most of the power in the Serbian part of Bosnia and have successfully defied the West since the war began.
The West now seems to be supporting Mrs. Plavsic in what is likely to be a series of very difficult disputes with her opponents.
Her opponents could maintain the separate government they have now, ignore her dismissal of the legislature and, by refusing to cooperate with foreign election officials, make a new vote nearly impossible.
And even if the Western governments overcome those challenges, they will have strengthened Mrs. Plavsic, a person whose history seems just as nationalist and xenophobic as those of her opponents.
The legislative elections that she is seeking would take place in October after next month's municipal elections.
[In Washington, the Clinton Administration strongly criticized the Bosnian Serb court's ruling, saying the judges had come under political pressure from supporters of Radovan Karadzic, Mrs. Plavsic's predecessor and the person who still wields most of the power. "We are aware of specific acts of intimidation directed against court justices and their families and strongly condemn such outrageous attempts to flout the rule of law," the State Department's spokesman, James P. Rubin, said in a statement.
[The America reaction came as President Clinton met with his senior advisers to discuss policy toward Bosnia after the visit by his envoys, Richard C. Holbrooke and Robert S. Gelbard. Mr. Gelbard, the special coordinator for Bosnia, is to return to Bosnia on Sunday.]
A European diplomat put a slightly different twist on the day's events. "This is a very interesting position that we've gotten ourselves into," the diplomat said. "We have to support Madame Plavsic, because we have encouraged her to fight the forces who oppose the peace agreement. Once that is said, how do we make her opponents accept all of this, and how do we live with her if she turns out to be a bad investment?"
As American diplomats repeat when explaining their support for her, Mrs. Plavsic is the legally elected head of the Serbian-controlled portion of Bosnia. But it is not a real country -- representing only half of the area of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a country that is held together by international pressure and 32,000 foreign soldiers.
In her offices in the town of Banja Luka, Mrs. Plavsic commands a staff of four, plus a few advisers.
At 9:42 one recent morning, the electronic calendar-clock over the door of her main staff office said Aug. 28, 10:31 P.M. A handful of guards sat dull-eyed around a table drinking beer.
Just across from the presidential building, the leaders of the political machines that Mrs. Plavsic hopes will organize voters in her favor spend much of their day under the shade trees at a sidewalk cafe. But they are the chiefs of small opposition parties, and their forces in the last election were geared toward defeating her.
"We're not supporting Plavsic," said Milorad Dodik, an opposition leader. "We just support her call for new elections because we think elections will give us more seats in the legislature."
Mrs. Plavsic emerged as a serious critic of the politicians who run the Serbian area earlier this summer when she began attacking them for corruption. Until then, she had been one of their inner circle.
She said Dr. Karadzic, who has been indicted on war-crimes charges and is still regarded by many as the person who controls the government, ran a criminal organization that was stealing much of the government's revenue. That theme struck home with many ordinary Serbs.
Then, in speeches that brought increasing support, she said the economy remained moribund because her opponents in the Government refused to fulfill the peace agreement, prompting the West to refuse to give reconstruction assistance.
"There is no budget in the Bosnian Serb Republic," she said in one speech. "The police are smuggling, the people are in misery and the country is isolated."
The effect of her campaign is obvious, if difficult to measure. Recently, at a secret meeting of a few local leaders in a Bosnian Serb town, the men said they had changed their opinions and now considered some politicians they had followed during the war as obstacles to recovery.
The people at the meeting included the owners of small retail businesses and the manager of the local factory. In the United States they would be leaders of a small-town community organization.
But the heavy pistols in shoulder holsters hiding under some of their jackets gave evidence that they were frightened of the people who run their corner of Bosnia and serious about challenging them.
"In America the people keep an eye on their government," said one man, who like everyone else insisted that neither he nor the town be identified. "Here the government is watching us." In other towns, where local authorities are considered less brutal, Mrs. Plavsic has led large rallies.
Like the President, many Bosnian Serbs want only part of the peace agreement enforced: just enough to start foreign aid flowing, but not so much that all those who were expelled from their homes return or that the quasi-sovereignty of the Serbian-controlled area be jeopardized to unify Bosnia.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Western countries appear to be supporting the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, in her confrontation with hard-line rivals. Last month, surrounded by bodyguards, she greeted supporters at a rally in Banja Luka. (Reuters)

Worst One-Day Selloff In 6 Years Wallops Stocks
Was the stock market simply due for a pause? Or were rising interest rates in the bond market and a falling dollar to blame? Whatever the reason, the market plummeted. The Dow plunged 247.37 points, or 3.1 percent, to 7,694.66, its worst setback in percentage terms since November 1991. 
 Few on Wall Street seemed deeply troubled, even though the plunge came during a week in which the market was treated to healthy news on the economy and inflation. And interest rates edged a little lower yesterday, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond falling to 6.54 percent. [Page 1.]
 
The real question as to whether the stock fall will turn into something significant, or just mimic the swoon this spring when the Dow quickly recovered after falling almost 10 percent in a month, depends on individual investors. News Analysis. [37.]
 
No Progress on U.P.S. Pact
The gap between the striking teamsters' union and the United Parcel Service was reported as no smaller, even after the two sides talked for a marathon 16 1/2 hours on Thursday and more than 10 hours yesterday. [9.]
 
Tactics of the political battlefield have made their way to the bargaining tables. Both union leaders and U.P.S. executives show the discipline of political candidates in adopting and staying on a single message. Armies of representatives make their cases on the television talk shows. And both sides have developed sophisticated campaigns aimed at turning opinion in Washington. [1.]
 
Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman has a big stake in the outcome of the U.P.S. strike. Her ability to nudge the two sides toward a solution without involving the Clinton Administration too much -- or too little -- could well set the tone for the rest of her tenure. [9.]
 
Upping Ante on Teen-Age Smoking
Despite industry opposition, the Administration will demand that cigarette companies pay stiffer fines than the tobacco settlement proposes if smoking by teen-agers does not drop. As it stands, the fines could not exceed $2 billion a year. But Bruce Reed, the chief domestic policy adviser, said, "We are going to strengthen the penalties." [1.]
 
Yamaichi Executive Slain in Tokyo
Koichiro Tarutani, 57, customer relations manager at Yamaichi Securities, was stabbed to death, and the police were investigating whether the killing was linked to a scandal involving payoffs to a racketeer. [37.]
 
Tainted Hamburger Alert Spreads
The Agriculture Department said more than 1.2 million pounds, up from 20,000 pounds, sold across the country might have been contaminated with E. coli bacteria. The hamburger patties were made on June 4, June 5 and June 9 at a plant in Columbus, Neb., owned by Hudson Foods of Rogers, Ark., and were sold under the Hudson brand name. [1.]
 
U.S. a Bigger No. 1 in Arms Sales
The United States has pulled further ahead as the world's biggest weapons merchant, an annual survey showed. Its share of the market increased to 35.5 percent last year, with $11.3 billion in orders. Britain was No. 2 with sales of $4.8 billion, or 15.1 percent. [3.]
 
Hong Kong Interest Rates Rise
Interest rates in Hong Kong surged to their highest levels since 1995 as traders bet that the speculative attack on Southeast Asian currencies might cause officials to allow the Hong Kong dollar to float. Currency turmoil continued elsewhere in the region, too. [34.]
 
Supplies Up, Copper Prices Fall
Copper futures prices tumbled on continuing signs that rising world production and slowing demand were increasing inventories. And on other markets, coffee prices slid. [34.]

INTERNATIONAL 3-5
 
Mutant Seaweed Afflicts Mediterranean Waters
The luxuriant but toxic meadows spawned by Caulerpa taxifolia have defeated navies and ravaged eco systems all across the Mediterranean. Scientists now hope a Caribbean snail can stop the relentless progress of the weed, accidentally brewed in a German zoo from an exotic Pacific species. 1 

 U.S. Arms Sales Increase
The United States increased its lead as the world's No. 1 weapons merchant, according to an annual arms survey published by the Congressional Research Service. The American share of the world's growing arms bazaar grew by nearly 23 percent last year, to $11.3 billion of the worldwide $31.8 billion market. Britain was second in sales; Russia sank to third as clients worried about reliable support services. 3
 
Yeltsin Blasts Privatizations
President Boris Yeltsin of Russia publicly criticized the way a major mining concern and a telecommunications behemoth were privatized. Mr. Yeltsin attributed the disputes prompted by the auctions, which were won by the same bank, to the favoritism displayed by the man who organized them; that man has resigned. 4
 
Adoption Deadlock Continues
A year-old baby who had been scheduled for adoption by an American couple died late last month in an orphanage in the Republic of Georgia. Witnesses said the infant, who was born with a damaged central nervous system, could have been saved with proper medical attention. Her adoption had been impeded by the moratorium on foreign adoption for which Nanuli Shevardnadze, the wife of Georgia's President, has fought. 4
 
Ruling on Bosnian Assembly
The Bosnian Serbs' Constitutional Court ruled that President Biljana Plavsic had no right to dismiss the national assembly on July 3 and call for new elections. Ms. Plavsic had accused the country's former war leaders, her former comrades, of corruption. The West's main civilian authority in Bosnia, however, said it would overrule the court's decision. 3
 
Turkish Editor Leaves Prison
Ocak Isik Yurtcu, a newspaper editor, was released from a provincial prison on a limited amnesty passed by Turkey's Parliament. He urged pressure on the Government to free the more than 70 other journalists who remain in prison. Mr. Yurtcu was imprisoned in 1994 for publishing articles about Kurdish insurgents. (The New York Times)
 
DNA Tests in French Murder
A court has ruled that investigators into the murder of an English schoolgirl may test the DNA of all young men in Pleine-Fougeres, a village of 1,800 people in the west of France. The girl, Caroline Dickinson, was raped and killed while on a trip there in July 1996. Her parents had requested the tests, which will be voluntary. A man was convicted in Cardiff, Wales, for the murder of a 15-year-old girl after a mass DNA screening in December. (AP)
 
NATIONAL 6-10
 
Officials Broaden Warning On Tainted Burger Patties
The Agriculture Department issued a far broader alert about tainted hamburger patties, warning that more than 1.2 million pounds of ground beef sold across the country may have been contaminated with deadly E. coli bacteria. The hamburgers were sold under the Hudson brand name. 1
 
Challenge to Tobacco Deal
A top White House official said in an interview that the Clinton Administration would demand that cigarette companies pay stiffer fines than the tobacco settlement proposes if smoking by teen-agers does not drop. The industry fiercely opposes additional sanctions. The official's remarks set the stage for a confrontation between industry and Clinton Adminstration officials, whose support is deemed vital if the $368 billion tobacco settlement is to become law. 1
 
Ruby Ridge Inquiry Closes
The Justice Department said it would not bring more criminal charges against senior F.B.I. officials in the 1992 siege at Ruby Ridge, where a Government sniper killed the wife of a white supremacist as she clutched their baby daughter inside a mountain cabin in Idaho. After a two-year investigation involving 378 witnesses, a Federal prosecutor concluded that the bureau's criminal conduct in the case began and ended with one man: E. Michael Kahoe, chief of the bureau's violent crimes and major offenders section. In December, Mr. Kahoe pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice. 6
 
Elvis Fans Gather in Memphis
The faithful, the fans and the imitators are gathering in Memphis to mark the 20th anniversary of Elvis Presley's death. More than 50,000 were expected at Graceland, his former home, for a candlelight vigil. 6
 
No Progress in U.P.S. Talks
Ronald Carey, the president of the teamsters' union, said there had been no progress in talks with the United Parcel Service. Mr. Carey also said the teamsters were stepping up cooperation with transportation unions in Europe to crimp or shut down U.P.S.'s operations on the other side of the Atlantic. The strike of 185,000 workers began Aug. 4. 9
 
Waiting for the President
President Clinton is due to arrive on Martha's Vineyard on Sunday for a three-week vacation. While each of his previous three visits had generated much hyperventilating about Presidential dinner parties -- who was hosting them, who was invited, who was not -- this visit has not had any "buzz," local residents said. 8
 
Anti-AIDS Gene Identified
Researchers studying specimens from 3,000 people have confirmed a genetic mutation that inhibits disease progression in people infected with the virus that causes that AIDS. Researchers said that by pinpointing how these altered genes fight H.I.V., it may be possible to develop treatments that help people delay the onset of AIDS. (AP)

2d Police Officer Charged
A second New York City police officer has been charged with brutally attacking a Haitian immigrant inside a Brooklyn station house last weekend, officials announced, adding that the essential information used against the officer was provided by one of his colleagues at the 70th Precinct. The immigrant, Abner Louima, who had been arrested in a scuffle outside a Flatbush Avenue nightclub, remains hospitalized with internal injuries. 1
 
Economics Closing Camps
Soaring operating costs and declining government aid are forcing many nonprofit sleepaway camps for low-income families to close. These camps were a quintessential New York rite of passage, part of growing up in the city by getting away from its crowded subways and tenements on the Lower East Side or the South Bronx. But between 1985 and 1996, more than a quarter of the state's nonprofit sleepaway camps were closed, from 435 to 321, according to a study conducted last year by the New York State Camp Directors Association. 23
 
Slavery Auctions Revealed
A Dallas couple's arrest for harboring deaf, illegal Mexican aliens brought to light a Government investigation of auctions where immigrants are sold into slavery, then forced to peddle trinkets on the streets for their owners' profits. 25

Jobless Rate Drops Slightly

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate dropped slightly to 5.4 percent in July, one-tenth of a percentage point lower than in June but still above the national average of 4.8 percent, according to a report released yesterday by the State Department of Labor.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: THE SULLEN ZONE: A special report.;
As Gaza Stagnates, Arafat Is Blamed as Well as Israel

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: GAZA, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Gaza, long resentful of Israel, is afflicted by a new discontent this summer.
Three years after a nominal peace with Israel made possible the rule of Yasir Arafat, most of the one million residents still search desperately for some sign that their lives are improving. 
 Instead they encounter the life styles of the rich and close to Arafat -- the new cars with red Palestinian Authority license plates that skim through Israeli checkpoints, the nightclubs along the Mediterranean where belly dancers gyrate long into the night, the garish villas erected by exiles back from Tunis on plots selling for more than $1 million.
The rest of Gaza stagnates. The refugee camps remain mired in squalor. Businessmen who anticipated a peace dividend are awash in empty apartments. Work is scarce. Detention by any one of nine Palestinian security agencies can come swiftly, and if the arresting officer is powerful enough, the courts can do little to prevent beatings or extended jail time without charges.
The result is a new mood that damns Israel and Arafat in almost equal measure. While the special American envoy, Dennis Ross, and Israel demand that Mr. Arafat do more than ever to uproot any violent dissidents ready to wreak havoc with peace talks, the Palestinian leader's reputation among his own people in Gaza has only fallen since his return.
In the Jabaliya refugee camp, Mahar Abdullah and Shaaban Mustapha spend countless hours idling in plastic chairs on their rough cement porch, which overlooks two overflowing trash dumpsters and an open sewage trench. About 150 yards in front of them stands a military post built for Israeli troops that now houses the Palestinian police. A question about what else has changed prompts a bitter joke: "Before the peace we only had one garbage container in front of the house, but now, thanks be to God, we have two," said Mr. Mustapha, 29.
The two men reminisce briefly about the stone fights against Israeli troops they fought for six years, and about the night in July 1994 when they danced in the unpaved street to celebrate Mr. Arafat's return.
"Arafat promised us when he came that he would transform this place into Singapore," said Mr. Abdullah, 31. "What he forgot to tell us was that he meant the Singapore of 500 years ago."
 
Economics
The First Thing Gaza Wants Is Jobs
Mr. Abdullah and Mr. Mustapha, like so many here, know that the peace talks have been in full crisis since July 30, when two bombers blew themselves up in a Jerusalem market, killing 14 others. They do not care much. They and other Gazans like them feel that they have gained nothing, and thus have nothing to lose. They want first jobs, then freedom of movement, then their own state and eventually democracy.
Gazans are socially more conservative than the 1.2 million Palestinians on the West Bank and certainly more so than the Palestinian revolutionaries who, with Mr. Arafat, spent years of exile in Beirut and Tunis. So they are generally shocked by what they see as the wanton ways of the returnees. Gazans have a derisive name for them: "the Tunisians."
"The feeling is that 'If you can't deliver on the peace process, why are you here?' " said Ali B. Jerbawi, a political science professor and director of the Independent Commission for Citizens Rights.
The returnees say the talk of a gap between the new government and the Gaza residents is overblown, although they concede that the allegations of corruption will have to be addressed. "We did not come from heaven, nor did we come to heaven," said Ahmad Abdel-Rahman, an Arafat aide for some two decades and now the Cabinet secretary. "We know there are people in the Authority who do not belong."
There is no doubt among Palestinians that the Israeli Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is the larger problem for them. All those peace agreements trumpeted on the White House lawn only seem to have left Israel with a greater choke hold than ever over the gateways of Gaza -- gateways to trade with the outside world, and especially to Israel itself, a key source of private employment.
Palestinians are dismayed that so many aspects of their daily lives, including their food, their work and their travel, remain largely dependent on Israeli permits. Israelis fault repeated bloodshed by Islamic militants. In the wake of those attacks Israel's Government has drastically restricted the movements of both Palestinians and their goods.
The working poor often say they are the ones punished for the inability of leaders on both sides to coordinate police work. In 1996, Gaza was sealed in for 82 out of 277 working days -- 3 days out of every 10.
It does not help that the few jobs at home are open largely to those who know the right people. Supporters of Al Fatah, the largest party in the Palestine Liberation Organization, are privileged. Many Gazans say it takes a letter from Fatah headquarters verifying that a person is a member in good standing to get any government job. So far, 78,000 people are on the Authority payroll, according to United Nations statistics, including about 35,500 with the security services. Gazans point out ruefully that the official numbers do not include hundreds of paid informers.
Ordinary people like Gaza's 2,800 fishermen, who have been repeatedly blockaded by the Israeli Navy during closings, often say they feel that the agreement has served basically to shrink their horizons. When they first complained to the Authority, they were told that the final agreements would take only a year or two to negotiate and then the entire sea would be open, instead of just 20 miles along the Gaza Strip.
Rajab al-Hissi, 71, the dean of Gaza's fishermen, said of the negotiators: "They know nothing about our problems, and now we have no place to fish. Things are getting worse and worse."
In 1992, the year before the peace treaty, United Nations reports put per capita income at $1,713. Salem Ajluni, head of the United Nations monitoring unit, now puts it at roughly $1,300. While income fell, prices edged upward, a development traceable in part to the Palestinian Authority's monopoly on everything from cement to fuel to most staple goods. Overall unemployment is 28 percent, with 10 percent more no longer looking for work.
 
Leadership
Arafat's Standing Is in Trouble
Although he long ago eliminated any serious rivals for individual leadership of the P.L.O., Mr. Arafat cannot rule with the same ruthlessness as a Saddam Hussein or a Hafez al-Assad. Under occupation, and especially in the 1980's, Palestinians grew accustomed to taking to the streets to protest even if it meant facing arrest or bullets.
So public outcry can sometimes force his hand. In April, when his security forces arrested the leaders of a teachers' strike, for instance, the clamor quickly got them released.
And his is not the only Palestinian movement. Today there is a known alternative in Hamas, the Islamic movement with a network of social programs and fund-raising, alongside violent underground cells opposing Mr. Arafat's peace with Israel.
Many downtrodden Gazans depend on Hamas charity to feed their children -- a consideration for Mr. Arafat if he were to crack down hard against the movement's militant cells, as Israel demands.
Even without a direct confrontation with Hamas, though, Mr. Arafat's political standing is in trouble here. The aura of corruption around the entire peace enterprise has some local Palestinians suggesting openly that it might be better if Mr. Arafat left, taking with him the 10,000 exiles he brought home.
Criticism that once would have been considered astonishing is fairly common, even if people speaking out before strangers are reluctant to give their complete names. "Arafat should go live in France," said Abu Hassan, the owner of a small Gaza grocery. "He's too old. He should rest, retire."
The affectionate nickname Abu Ammar has been replaced by something more caustic -- Abu Khafiya, the father of the headdress.
 
Business
'Carpetbaggers' And Corruption
The dejection is not limited to the poor. Two months after Mr. Arafat came back, Hamad al-Sakka, a Gaza businessman, started building Mecca Tower, a 20-story edifice with 80 apartments, on the promise that many Palestinians would want to return to settle. He has sold 15 apartments. "Nobody is buying anything because there is no hope," he said.
With their living standards eroding, Gazans sharply resent the fact that the Palestinian Authority has been muscling into all kinds of business on top of its import monopolies.
Its most visible presence is Al Bahar Company, run by Hashem Abu Nada, a key financial adviser to Mr. Arafat. Its interests include a hotel, an advertising agency and real estate. Its centerpiece project is Zahra al Madain, or Flower of the Cities, a beach resort of chalet bungalows on the coast. It had been announced that the place would be awarded to the highest bidder, but no price was disclosed when Al Bahar moved in. This kind of murky dealing, combined with a Palestinian Authority audit released in May reporting that $326 million had been misspent, has left many Palestinians thinking that they are besieged by carpetbaggers.
An investigation by the Palestinian Legislative Council found that much of the suspected abuse was a matter of dubious accounting principles rather than outright misappropriation. Still, the Council demanded that ministers explain a catalogue of abuses. Although there have been allegations that officials have sought kickbacks for contracts, foreign diplomats bend over backward to stress that the $1.3 billion in aid disbursed so far was largely earmarked for specific projects and that no government has reported any abuse.
Businessmen and diplomats say private sector investment has not followed the foreign aid, largely because of the problems of operating in an unstable political environment where it is never clear when a business will be able to import raw materials or export finished goods. On top of that, they say, the Authority's financial mismanagement has served to deepen the qualms of the private sector and to prompt foreign donors to review their pledges for a total $2.5 billion in aid.
Mr. Arafat has not addressed the corruption issue himself. But he sent a top aide, Tayyib Abdel-Rahim, to speak in his name at the Legislative Council in May to promise a larger inquiry. "The Palestinian Authority will not keep silent on any violation and will work on ending any form of corruption," Mr. Abdel-Rahim said.
Some Palestinians say the fledgling government should be given credit for at least recognizing a problem ignored in most Arab states.
"The laws controlling investment and business and what is legal or illegal are nonexistent," said Jihad al-Wazir, the son of a P.L.O. founder, Khalil al-Wazir, who was killed by assassins thought to have been sent by Israel. Mr. Wazir, 34, left his life in a Rochester suburb to open an office in Gaza to encourage investment. "You have to take into account that we are not the U.S. Congress with a 200-year tradition of oversight and checks and balances," he said.
While the initial reports of financial mismanagement have been jarring, it is the clash of cultures that markedly alienates many residents. During Israel's occupation of the Gaza Strip, flouting Islamic moral rules was as rare as was flaunting wealth. Now a string of nightclubs offer belly dancing and Maccabee beer, an Israeli brand. The cost of two beers amounts to about a day's wages for a Gazan laborer.
Some relish the new freedom, despite thundering condemnations by Hamas leaders. "If you want to pray, you can go pray in the mosques," said a longtime Gaza resident in the Scheherezade nightclub. "You have to change with the times."
 
Policing
Professor Arrested For Work in Class
One change of the times has made Gazans suddenly more fearful, more hesitant to talk in public. They were ecstatic to get Israeli troops off their streets, but dismayed to find that the Palestinian troops who moved into the same barracks are eager to throw people in jail for even perceived slights against the Authority.
The police are supposed to report arrests to the attorney general's office within 48 hours, but the rule is often ignored. "Any system will not stop these people," said Fayez Abu Rahma, the attorney general appointed on July 18 after his predecessor resigned amid bribery allegations. "If I give orders, they will not follow orders."
Mr. Abu Rahma said that when he took over, he inherited 180 prisoners suspected of being Hamas members. "The fact that someone is a member of Hamas is not enough of a reason to jail them for this long," he said. He let 44 go and plans more releases.
But while the Authority may have avoided jailing militants on lists handed over by Israel, Gazans resent the ease with which others have been confined on charges that amount to criticizing the Palestinian Authority.
Take the case of Fateh Sobeh, a professor in Al Azhar's University's education department, who told 300 students sitting for their finals on June 21 to write nine short essays about the interplay between social and educational problems. Mixed in with questions about things like the influence of television, the professor asked his students to catalogue the effect of corruption in either the university administration or the Palestinian Authority.
He was arrested on July 2, and his family got to visit him only this week. He has yet to be formally charged with anything, and although 14 soldiers raided his house to seize the exam books, the branch of the security services that grabbed him hints darkly that he will be accused of spying for Israel and sexually harassing his students.
"They should release him because they have nothing on him," his wife, Fatima, said, enumerating his repeated arrests by the Israeli authorities during the occupation.
The case appears to be something of an embarrassment to the Authority. Mr. Abu Rahma had the professor's case file on his desk and said the charges were as yet incomplete. "It is very strange to have such a charge against a professor," he said. "I have never seen such a thing."
The professor's wife mused that she and her husband support the idea of peace, that they want to serve their country, but that it is proving difficult with the influx of outsiders as their leaders. "They think they are Westerners and advanced, better than us, that our minds are still influenced by religion," she said. "They look down on us."
Thus the basic problem edging Gazans toward despair: They feel hemmed in, neither free of Israel nor living under the kind of Palestinian government they envisioned.
"Palestinians might accept a little corruption if they felt the peace process was getting somewhere," said Mr. Jerbawi, the professor. "Or they might accept so little movement with the peace if the government was clean. But now Arafat doesn't have the cover he needs to crack down on anybody. He can't stand up and say he needs to do it or the peace process will derail. Everybody thinks it has already derailed."

HEADLINE: Waiting Out Communism

BYLINE: By James J. Sheehan; James J. Sheehan teaches German history at Stanford University.

 BODY:

THE LAST DIVISION
 A History of Berlin, 1945-1989.
 By Ann Tusa.
 Illustrated. 431 pp. Reading, Mass.:
 Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $25.
 
 DISSOLUTION
 The Crisis of Communism
 and the End of East Germany.
 By Charles S. Maier.
 440 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
 Princeton University Press. $29.95. 
 The postwar era began and ended in Germany. From the summer of 1945, when the participants in the Potsdam conference failed to agree about Germany's future, until the summer of 1990, when the Soviet Union accepted the newly unified Germany's membership in NATO, the German question was at the center of the era's most important conflicts.
In "The Last Division," Ann Tusa, the author (with John Tusa) of books about the Nuremberg trials and the Berlin airlift, examines some of the most dangerous moments in the history of East-West confrontations over Germany. The subtitle of her book is doubly misleading: it is neither "a history of Berlin" nor does it cover the entire period from 1945 to 1989. Instead, Tusa traces Berlin's role in international affairs, with particular emphasis on the period between Nikita Khrushchev's threat in 1958 to seek a separate settlement with East Germany and the construction of the Berlin wall in August 1961.
Although Tusa does not provide much new information, she tells this exciting story well. With a good eye for striking quotations and significant details, she sketches vivid portraits of her characters: Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany and President Charles de Gaulle of France, old enemies drawn together by their shared distrust of Britain and the United States; Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, frightened by the dangers of war and excessively eager for negotiations; President John F. Kennedy, at first overwhelmed by the responsibilities thrust upon him but gradually gaining self-confidence and a sense of direction. Whenever Khrushchev is on stage, he steals the show: crude, cunning, shifting unpredictably from conciliatory charm to abusive threats, he managed to maintain the political initiative from his ultimatum in 1958 until the debacle over the Cuban missiles four years later.
Throughout her book, Tusa is harshly critical of the "ineffectual and timorous behavior of the Western Powers." But while she can easily demonstrate the occasional ineffectiveness of Western policy toward Berlin, she does not succeed in showing what might have been done differently. The fate of Berlin, after all, was determined by the West's decision not to go to war to drive the Soviets out of Eastern Europe. Western strategy was essentially defensive; it was, in George Kennan's famous phrase, a strategy of containment. This meant that the Western allies might have been prepared to fight to maintain their hold on their sectors of Berlin, but not to prevent the Soviets from doing what they wanted in the East. The construction of the wall was the unavoidable outcome of allied acquiescence in Europe's division.
Charles S. Maier's "Dissolution" suggests that in the long run the Western powers' patience (which is so easy to mistake for timidity) paid off. Maier, the Krupp Foundation Professor of European Studies at Harvard, has written a historical synthesis of the economic crisis, popular unrest and diplomatic negotiations that disrupted and then destroyed East Germany and with staggering speed opened the way for its unification with the Federal Republic.
A major goal of his book, Maier writes, is to defend the importance of human agency by showing how "the East Germans, when they came to act collectively, had a decisive impact on their own history." Maier eloquently describes the Leipzig demonstrations throughout the fall of 1989, when ordinary men and women took to the streets to demand greater freedom, and the huge East Berlin rally in November, when some of the regime's most prominent intellectuals called for fundamental reform.
But did these expressions of popular discontent really bring about the end of East Germany? As Maier's own account clearly shows, collective action may have helped to precipitate the final crisis, but its causes and outcome were determined by developments over which neither the demonstrators nor their Government had much control: the steady decline in ideological commitment, even among some of the elite; the deterioration of the economy; and finally, the upheavals in European Communism that followed Mikhail Gorbachev's efforts to reform the Soviet Union.
Of these three changes, the collapse of the Communist bloc seems by far the most significant. The East German crisis began, not with the Leipzig demonstrations in the fall, but rather in the summer, when Hungary's Communist Government decided to allow East German refugees to cross its borders to the West. Once this door was opened, East Germany lost the capacity to save itself with either repression or stringent economic reforms, remedies that would have increased even more the westward flight of its citizens. As a leading Soviet expert on Germany correctly remarked, "The death sentence of the G.D.R. was signed in the moment when it was decided to open the border."
"Dissolution" is the best available one-volume account of East Germany's decline and fall. Maier recounts the complex and exciting events of 1989-90 clearly and concisely. He has mastered the growing literature on the subject, interviewed several of the most prominent participants and looked at some of the newly available archival material. Equally important, he puts these events into a rich historical context by comparing them with episodes in the German past (especially the revolutions of 1848 and 1918-19), with developments in the rest of Eastern Europe and even with trends in the capitalist West. The last of these comparisons is the most original and potentially the most important, since it points us toward a post-postwar history in which a now undivided Europe can begin to confront its common past.
Both Tusa and Maier end their books with cautious optimism about the future of Germany and Europe. They are right to do so. There is little reason to mourn the passing of East Germany. And there is every reason to celebrate the removal of the lethal military power that once was concentrated along the German-German frontier. Compared to the era that ended in 1989, the future, while not without challenges and dangers, is filled with promise and possibility.

LENGTH: 277 words

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Fiction

BYLINE: By William Ferguson 

 BODY:

FOUR DECADES
New and Selected Stories.
By Gordon Weaver.
University of Missouri, paper, $18.95. 
 Gordon Weaver's terrain is Middle America, and his protagonist is usually an unhappy middle-aged man. For many of these characters that unhappiness stems from the brutal contrast between what adolescence seemed to promise and the bitter realities that ensued in adulthood. Alcohol is a universal solvent in Weaver's stories, destroying marriages and careers with stupefying efficiency. Its major victim is memory, as characters are left wondering not only where the past has gone but whether it occurred at all. Thus in "Return of the Boyceville Flash," a bum named Teddy Pafko pleads with an old friend: "Could you possibly tell me anything about who I was, what sort of person I was, Jimmy?" In "Madness," two teen-age friends are estranged when one goes incurably insane; as the other desperately attempts to re-establish the old bonds, certain symmetries in the narrative suggest that the two characters are essentially one -- that a single disastrous life is being viewed from different perspectives. Playing a variation on this theme, the narrator in "Getting Serious" has an inexplicable need to keep in contact with Guy Roland, a hometown acquaintance who was thought to be a World War II hero but later proved a fraud. The narrator's domestic life, described as an idyll, crumbles to nothing, but the failure goes almost unnoticed. All that matters to him is to be with Guy, now an unemployed alcoholic but still strangely, fatefully attractive: "His blue eyes were still bright, like the eyes of a child after weeping." William Ferguson
