SECTION: Section 6; Page 32; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 7353 words

HEADLINE: The Heat Is Outside the Kitchen

BYLINE: By David Blum; David Blum is a writer based in New York. His last article for the Magazine was "Julia Ormond's Trip Through the Star Factory" in April 1995.

 BODY:

It is a few minutes away from sunrise on a Friday morning in early June. David Gregoire Bouley has been eating almost steadily since 11:30 P.M., when he sat down with eight others to a 12-course dinner in Chinatown at New York Noodle Town. That feast ended at around 1:30, shortly after Warner LeRoy, the 62-year-old owner of Tavern on the Green and Bouley's business partner, left for home. A walk through deserted lower Manhattan was followed by an hourlong stop for a drink at Cafe Fledermaus in the South Street Seaport. The group then proceeded to the Fulton Fish Market.
The visit to the market is the ostensible reason for this night on the town, a week after Bouley's 44th birthday. He used to show up there regularly before he closed his four-star French restaurant, Bouley, in June 1996. Tonight is his way of announcing to the fish purveyors that David Bouley (pronounced boo-LAY) is coming back. After 90 minutes of interaction with men in rain boots -- all of whom seemed thrilled to learn that their old customer Dave had his wallet out again -- Bouley and his entourage (which included two sous-chefs, one waiter, his director of operations and a French architect) marched back to Fledermaus. Bouley had originally intended to phone his friend Jean-Georges Vongerichten to congratulate him on the four-star review he has received in that morning's New York Times, but it is now too late to call. Walter Krajnc, the Austrian owner, has prepared platters of goulash, sides of salad, baskets of sliced baguettes and three different desserts, and has replaced the rock CD on the sound system with Johann Strauss' "Blue Danube" waltz. 
 The music suits Bouley's people, who in a few months plan to open their own Austrian restaurant, Danube, at the corner of Duane and Hudson Streets. When that day comes, Krajnc will leave Fledermaus to become the maitre d' at Danube. The executive chef will be Kurt Gutenbrunner, an Austrian chef who stood at Bouley's side cooking fish for five years in the famously intense TriBeCa kitchens and who now sits at Bouley's side eating goulash.
"This is great," Bouley says as he digs in with a fork, displaying a hardiness that belies the hour. In less than a week, he will open Bouley Bakery at 120 West Broadway, his first public venture since Restaurant Bouley closed its 18th-century French wooden doors. Its opening will mark the first step of Bouley's two-year, $16 million plan to transform himself from a mere restaurateur into a full-fledged retail entrepreneur and food mogul. In doing so, he hopes that the Bouley name will soon signify a top-quality food product available everywhere. Though the Connecticut-born Bouley has worked in the relative seclusion of a restaurant kitchen for more than 25 years, he now wants to be as famous as those who once dined regularly on his wonderfully simple food. He boasts to me of the time Michael Jordan came to his Duane Street kitchen with a request to collaborate on a health-food restaurant in Chicago; but he prefers not to share the marquee space on his planned establishments.
Bouley claims confidently that Danube will open by December. The schedule next calls for the summer 1998 opening of an 18,000-square-foot retail store called Bouley at Home. Soon after that, he says, the headquarters of Bouley International will open in the Mohawk Building, at the corner of Duane and Hudson Streets. The plan is for this building and the one adjoining it to be an extravagant temple of devotion to haute cuisine, housing a 110-seat International Cafe, an intimate, 75-seat version of Restaurant Bouley, two private dining rooms, a cooking school and a research institute with a test kitchen, laboratory and food library. Bouley says that he expects all of these ventures (each within two blocks of his original restaurant) to be finished before the end of 1998.
But at 5:15 on this June morning -- almost two years since the announcement of his partnership with Warner LeRoy and more than a year since I began talking with Bouley about his plans -- his comeback has yet to materialize. The Mohawk Building continues to be nothing more than a stack of blueprints in a dingy storefront office. Bouley at Home remains a raw space. Danube still looks like a boarded-up sandwich shop. Even the Bakery, which is supposed to be the site of a big opening-night party only four days from now, looks as if it needs at least another month of work. The windows haven't been installed; the chairs haven't come; the lights aren't fixed; the bathroom is a mess.
The food revolution that is now under way in America first surfaced 26 years ago in the kitchen of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., when Alice Waters began moving the boundaries of taste by using fresh herbs and natural flavors instead of butter and cream. It continued with the advent of American nouvelle cuisine in the 1970's. That approach to French cooking eliminated rich sauces, shrank portions and emphasized new flavors that were designed to astonish the taste buds rather than soothe them.
In the 1980's, a dynamic new group of chefs in their 30's came forward with their personal visions of this approach. While there had long been celebrity chefs (Julia Child, Paul Prudhomme and Andre Soltner are just a few), the 80's, when the money flowed and the media made the restaurant business look glamorous, seemed to manufacture them. These cooking stars weren't just restaurateurs -- they were entrepreneurs out to create potentially lucrative new markets for their work. They wanted to make millions, and frequently did; Barry Wine of the Quilted Giraffe sold the lease to his four-star restaurant to Sony for seven figures in 1992, at its peak.
The financial success of the celebrity chef-entrepreneurs gave them unparalleled freedom to experiment and expand. In 1992, Daniel Boulud left Le Cirque and went on to earn four stars at his own Restaurant Daniel, joining Gray Kunz at Lespinasse, David Waltuck at Chanterelle and Gilbert Le Coze at Le Bernardin as some of the most highly regarded chefs in America's restaurant capital. The recent, highly publicized opening of restaurants like Le Cirque 2000, Vongerichten's restaurant Jean-Georges and the revamped "21" signal a return to the era of expensive dining that first turned these young chefs into stars. In both 1995 and 1996, the Zagat Survey noted an increase in high-end restaurants for the first time since the late 1980's, as well as the first rise in average food prices since 1988. And it wasn't just a local phenomenon. The success of deluxe restaurants like Charlie Trotter's in Chicago, the newly reopened Spago in Los Angeles and the Blue Door in Miami Beach suggest a national trend toward high-priced eating, all the more remarkable in an industry where by some estimates only one in five restaurants lives beyond its first birthday. But the economy is booming for now, and so are industries that cater to people with money.
David Bouley wants to use his own celebrity status to become a powerful force in a continuing battle to improve the American palate. For five straight years, Bouley's innovative cooking earned his restaurant a No. 1 popularity ranking in New York by the Zagat Survey and effusive praise from food critics. His health-consciousness and his commitment to quality ingredients found a receptive audience right alongside the lobster-and-mashed-potato eaters. In 1991, when Zagat asked 7,000 diners, "Where would you eat the last meal of your life?" respondents overwhelmingly picked Bouley.
"They all use good ingredients," says Ruth Reichl, The Times's restaurant critic since 1993. "The thing I admire most about how Bouley cooked was that if you watched the evolution of the restaurant, he did change his style to depend more on the quality of ingredients, and to simplify. The food was left to stand on its own, in a way that is really American."
Beyond that, Bouley came to define a new kind of work ethic in the American kitchen. He believed deeply in the principle that to do better than your competitors, you have to work harder than they do. For the first three years at Bouley, he left work at 3 A.M. and returned, showered and shaven, four hours later. Some nights he never left at all. He interviewed the cabdrivers at the curb to find out what customers said about his restaurant. He went out front to sweep up the cigarette butts. All this separated him from many superstar chefs of the 80's, who moved too fast or too far away from their basic strengths. Jonathan Waxman, the young chef of the restaurant Jams, says of the cause of its closing in 1990, "If it was anything, it was going out to dinner too many times." Bouley shares more with a workaholic entrepreneur like Wolfgang Puck, whose ever-expanding empire of restaurants, cafes and frozen pizzas reveals a chef with similar ambitions.
"Bouley and Puck are probably the two top guys in the business right now," says Tim Zagat, a co-publisher of the best-selling series of restaurant surveys. "But Puck is franchising his name. Bouley aims at a higher level than anyone else in the business and won't allow his name to be used if he is not directly involved. In terms of creativity, he is No. 1." Puck has successfully staked out the mainstream realm of simple food served in a casual West Coast style; his pizzas sell in the frozen-food section of local supermarkets. Bouley is interested in haute cuisine; he wants his products to be found in gourmet food stores and top restaurants. They are likely to be affordable only to upper-income customers.
The darkly handsome Bouley, with wavy black hair flecked with gray and pale green eyes, has never focused his attention on pleasing everyone. In his 10 years on Duane Street, he earned a reputation as a difficult artist who had stormy relationships with many of his colleagues. He sees himself as incapable of failure and possessed of only brilliant ideas. Friends and detractors both attribute to Bouley the qualities of a cult leader: charm, arrogance and the ability to inspire loyalty. Last winter, when The New York Post ran a front-page photo of Marshall Applewhite, the Heaven's Gate cult leader, with the headline "Follow Me," Bouley staffers inserted the chef's picture and faxed it to Bouley in Paris. He laughed.
Bouley's ambitions are bold and invite intimations of disaster, yet Warner LeRoy willingly put up $4 million, and dozens of people have signed on to work for him. Still, critics openly wonder whether Bouley has correctly calculated the marketplace for his ideas. His first planned venture, the $1.5 million Bouley Bakery (which is both a bakery and a restaurant with a major bread fetish), has already inspired some skepticism. "He goes away for a year and what does he have to offer us?" asks Alan Richman, GQ's restaurant critic, who then answers with mock glee, "Rolls!"
Even those close to Bouley voice occasional doubts about the viability of his long-range vision. "When he sees the finished blueprints for the Mohawk Building, there's definitely going to be a big case of sticker shock," says Laurence Harman, an architect with the Harman Jablin firm who is doing some work on the Bouley International headquarters. "David's way of doing things costs a lot of money." Some of his closest employees also fight bouts of pessimism. "The guy has an amazing amount to do, and there are days when I walk in here and say, 'We're never going to pull this off,' " says Peter Kend, his 33-year-old co-director of operations who left a lucrative career as a currency-derivatives trader at Swissbank to work for Bouley. "But then I see David and all his drive and energy and optimism, and I figure, If anybody can pull this off, he can."
Perhaps no one sums up Bouley better than Herbert Wishengrad, a 61-year-old semiretired New Jersey businessman who was Bouley's business partner at the Duane Street restaurant until Bouley abruptly announced in 1995 that he would close his highly profitable restaurant at the pinnacle of its success. At the time, Wishengrad and Bouley were splitting more than $1 million in annual profits. But Bouley changed course and partners, leaving Wishengrad to speculate on the messianic drive of a man who would willingly fold a profitable business.
"Remember how they said the earth was flat until some guy came along and said it was round?" Wishengrad says. "That's who David Bouley thinks he is."
 'Motorcycles . . . denim jeans and black leather jackets . . . gum chewer . . . girls . . . culinary school" were the words that the editors of the yearbook for Edwin O. Smith High School in Storrs, Conn., used to describe Dave Bouley, a graduating senior in 1972. He had spent his childhood in deep thrall of his French-born grandmother, who raised pheasant, chickens and goats, grew fruits and was the host of an all-day marathon cooking session every Sunday at her Rhode Island farm, with a teen-age David at her side. He watched, learned and first came to his now passionate belief that this was the right way for food to be grown, prepared and eaten. "I was always the happy kid," Bouley recalls, though he has borne much family tragedy. Three of his eight siblings have since died -- one of cancer, one in a train accident and one in a plane crash.
When Bouley was 15, he went to work at the Willimantic Motor Inn in Storrs as a dishwasher, and he worked his way up through the kitchen ranks. At 19, he left nearby Manchester Community College and moved to Santa Fe, N.M. There he became the manager of the Pink Adobe, an American restaurant that survives today -- a fact that Bouley attributes, in part, to his overhaul of the kitchen.
In Santa Fe, Bouley made one of his first important connections in the food business. Michel Richard, now well known as the chef-owner of Citrus in Los Angeles, was then working at the Hotel La Fonda as a pastry chef. Richard moved to Los Angeles and Bouley eventually followed him, landing his first big-city cooking job -- making desserts at a pastry shop that Richard opened in Beverly Hills. After that and a brief stop as a waiter in Cape Cod -- "I waited on Tip O'Neill a lot," Bouley recalls -- he could no longer resist the pull to the gastronomic capital of the world.
"I knew I had to go to Paris," Bouley says. "I had $4,000, and I figured out how I could live in Paris on $5 a day." He took classes at the Sorbonne, and an introduction by Richard got him a job in the pastry kitchen of Gaston Lenotre, which led to another with the renowned French chef Roger Verge, who would become a crucial influence on Bouley. It was Verge -- the owner of Le Moulin de Mougins, the renowned restaurant on the Riviera -- who first took Bouley from the intricate architecture of French pastry into the wide-open canvas of nouvelle cuisine.
From that point on, Bouley's education took place inside the great kitchens of Europe and New York. He worked under Paul Bocuse in Lyons and Fredy Girardet of Switzerland and Verge, between stints at New York's top-rated restaurants -- including then-four-star Vienna 79, where he first got to know Austrian cuisine, and Le Cirque, where he spent two years as a sous-chef under the scrutiny of Sirio Maccioni, who recalls, "He never stopped working." Or moving. By 1984, he had worked as a sous-chef at more than a dozen restaurants, until he finally landed at Verge's Sutter 500, in San Francisco. It was there that he met a young, ambitious restaurant captain named Drew Nieporent, whose fantasy was to open a casual yet haute French restaurant very much like the one of David Bouley's own dreams.
In April 1985, the two men opened Montrachet on an almost deserted block of West Broadway in TriBeCa. Seven weeks later, Bryan Miller of The Times lavished three stars on their little boite and called its opening "ample reason to celebrate." But the relationship between the two men could not withstand the pressures created by Miller's rave, and within less than a year, Nieporent ended up packing Bouley's cooking equipment and loading it into a van. (Nieporent has, in the past, accused Bouley of discussing financing for a new venture while still working for him.) Nieporent now runs six other restaurants in the same neighborhood, including Nobu and TriBeCa Grill. The two men have not spoken to each other since their rift, which has only added to its legend. (Bouley made a special point of telling me that Robert De Niro, Nieporent's frequent partner, ate many meals at Bouley.) It is clear that time and success have not healed the wounds of their conflict.
By early 1987, Bouley had raised $815,000 for his own place from Herbert Wishengrad, who was a partner in a factory that made the wax-coated cups used by Dannon yogurt. When his son-in-law, who worked at the accounting firm of Deloitte, Haskins & Sells, told Wishengrad about a business plan that he had helped Bouley to prepare, Wishengrad agreed to meet the 32-year-old chef, then living in a walkup on West 55th Street, and eventually to commit the needed funds.
Restaurant Bouley opened in the late summer of 1987, built by a crew comprising chefs, cooks and Bouley's brother Martin, a builder. After only a few months, the restaurant got a two-star review from The Times -- "The ride can be delightful," Bryan Miller said cautiously -- but by 1990 it had earned its four-star rating. From then on, six nights a week for the next six years, Bouley almost never had an empty table. Warren Beatty, Woody Allen and Bill Cosby made repeated visits. Bouley dated Bernadette Peters and rode motorcycles with Lyle Lovett. In 1994, People magazine named him one of the "50 Most Beautiful People" of the year.
By the end, Restaurant Bouley was grossing an estimated $8 million to $9 million a year in revenue, with Wishengrad and Bouley each getting huge profit checks. Wishengrad had invested after-tax dollars to open the restaurant, which meant that he had to double his investment to recoup his original outlay. Once he did, it became a 50-50 partnership and then, when Bouley passed a specific revenue mark each year, 65-35 in Bouley's favor. Their annual profits eventually reached an estimated $1 million to $2 million.
But, like his falling-out with Nieporent, Bouley's relationship with Wishengrad ended badly. "From a business point of view, you're never happy if you have a successful business and it is terminated," Wishengrad says now. "It is not a game. You're dealing with people's lives. He had 67 people who were earning a living. A lot of this was done on an emotional basis." Bouley argues that Wishengrad made the partnership difficult. "It is hard having a partner who doesn't think the chef should be allowed to drink a bottle of wine in his own restaurant," Bouley said to me in exasperation one day, objecting to Wishengrad's insistence on controlling every penny spent. When Bouley's 10-year lease was up, he switched to a new partner whom he had met at a corner banquette in his restaurant two years earlier -- the one who said to him, "I've never had a partner, I've never wanted a partner, but I want you to be my partner." In less than a year, LeRoy and Bouley had worked out a deal that would help finance Bouley's business dreams.
 In search of a wide national audience, Bouley plans to go beyond anything yet attempted in this country. For example, his ideas for the overnight shipping of gourmet food will use a vacuum packaging process known as "sous-vide" that he spent weeks studying in France. When done properly, sous-vide sucks out the air from a food package -- keeping the food away from any bacteria in the air that could cause spoilage. The idea of sous-vide is to seal and flash-freeze cooked food so that chefs or customers can prepare a meal simply by reheating it. Some American food retailers have resisted sous-vide as impractical, and possibly hazardous when the food isn't stored properly, but Bouley says such problems can be overcome. Using the technique, Bouley claims that he can sell food that essentially matches his restaurant fare in quality. His fantasy is that through Bouley at Home he will sell four orders of Chatham Lobster With Oven Roasted Fennel and Organic Rhubarb Braised in Red Wine to a guy on the phone in Seattle and get it there overnight.
"He treats food like it is a religion," a competing restaurateur says, "and like he is the spiritual leader who must convert everyone in his path." That assessment would probably not disturb Bouley. The consistent vaulted-ceiling design of his restaurants brings to mind the architecture of a church.
There is a slight stumbling quality to Bouley's speech -- a lot of extra searching for just the right word -- but when the subject turns to food, an eloquence takes hold. What is his favorite spice? "Rosemary," he says and, as it often does, a crooked smile crosses his face. "That was the first spice I ever knew," he explains, and it becomes clear that if food is his one true love, then rosemary was his heart's first passion.
"He used to come to work and tell me he had a dream about scallops in a Pernod and fennel sauce," recalls Georges Briguet, the owner of Le Perigord, where Bouley worked for nearly two years beginning in 1979. "All he thought about was food, and how to make it better, fresher. He had the most amazing set of taste buds I've ever seen."
Bouley's own philosophy of food is simple. "I'm trying to take all the madness out of cooking and see what happens," he says. "Cuisine has a structure. This is what I learned from my grandmother. I don't do the elevated cuisine, the roux and the sauces. I do the flavor." One day I asked him to describe his idea of the perfect meal. "One where you don't look for rough edges or faults," he said, "where you're open to making it be anything. It'd probably be something really simple. I can remember the simple marriages of flavor, like Beethoven when he couldn't hear the notes."
In his year away from kitchen duty, Bouley had the chance -- for the first time in a decade -- to experience other restaurants firsthand and to reshape his philosophy around new ideas. He went frequently to places like Jean-Georges, Il Cantinori, Le Zoo (a village bistro owned by former Bouley waiters) and Bodega (a casual diner on West Broadway). He learned that it matters less what price you charge than what service you deliver. "I like a place that has good value for the money," Bouley says. "Somebody like Jean-Georges spends a lot of time and money making sure the ingredients are good, and so, yes, the customer pays for that. And it is nice when you go out to dinner to have as much time as you want to eat."
Bouley routinely spends four to five hours at a restaurant table (and doesn't mind when customers at his own restaurant do, too, creating long, infuriating waits to be seated). He loves nothing more than the company of his friends, a top-quality bottle of Bordeaux, unobtrusive service and a corner table. He likes a commanding view of every seat, yet can easily spend an entire evening looking at his dining companions as though they are the only people in the room. He has a cast-iron stomach that puts mere gluttons to shame. During one two-hour period together, we experienced a slice of pizza, a box of sushi, a turbulent plane trip and a bumpy cab ride; afterward Bouley showed no signs of ill health, except perhaps a little annoyance when I threw up on him in the cab.
The further away from food Bouley gets, the more difficult it is for others -- even his closest associates -- to comprehend the sum total of his vision. While the scope of his new endeavor may be groundbreaking in sheer size, most of its components resemble existing ventures elsewhere. Bouley is hardly the first chef to demonstrate a commitment to natural ingredients, or even to seek a more visible public platform than a restaurant kitchen to promote his values. Nor does the mere act of owning several different restaurants set him apart from his fellow top chefs. Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Charles Palmer of Aureole each run four restaurants. Cooking schools proliferate; one of the nation's largest, the Culinary Institute of America, is less than two hours away. The decision to open a bakery can hardly be seen as pioneering, either. His old boss Drew Nieporent opened TriBakery nearly two years ago just a few blocks away, and lately there's been critical praise for the new bakery at nearby Balthazar. ("Bread is a highly profitable food group," Alan Richman of GQ explains.) Large-scale retail gourmet-food operations have also been done in New York before; in 10 years, Dean & DeLuca has grown from a single store on Prince Street to three stores and seven cafes. Both Balducci's and Dean & DeLuca already have catalogue divisions that ship food around the country, though perhaps not to the extent that Bouley aspires. Still, as Dean & DeLuca's C.E.O., Dane J. Neller, concedes, "The gourmet-food business has plenty of room for someone like Bouley."
In some respects, Bouley is merely catching the wave at its crest. Farmer's markets crisscross the nation, and since 1989 the organic market has grown by more than 20 percent annually, becoming a $3.5 billion industry. "It is not just better for you, but it tastes better," Bouley says of pure, naturally produced food. "It is not how you cook it that matters but how it was treated before it got to your house that makes all the difference."
Bouley is determined to do it all, and to do it bigger and better than ever before. He insists that he is a reluctant celebrity, but in the end he is simply a clever one. "David doesn't like the limelight?" Sirio Maccioni of Le Cirque 2000 said to me incredulously one day. "David loves the limelight. You can tell him Sirio said so."
 'I can make lasagna that will make you cry," Bouley told me one night when I asked whether he had ever cooked Italian food. All of Bouley's revolutionary fervor about food filters through his righteous and passionate belief in himself. It is a habit that some see as fatally arrogant, while others view it as the key to his success. From the beginning of his career, Bouley has earned a reputation for a my-way-or-the-highway management style; he does not like to hear of the possibility that any of his ideas might be misguided, wrong or too expensive.
A still-embittered former colleague recalls the almost constant torture of working with Bouley: "I used to come to work and say to myself: 'It is your fault. I want you to walk in the door today like every possible problem you've ever had with this guy is your fault. And today is a new leaf. David's the greatest. He is the best. You're the one who made all the mistakes. Follow his lead. Let's make the thing work.' And he'd do something even then that was beyond belief, that was so meanspirited that I couldn't do it." What this colleague objected to most was Bouley's seemingly consistent knack for making his own mistakes appear as though they were someone else's.
Bouley can be maddeningly distant one moment and utterly charming the next. He uses a lack of eye contact as a weapon, and can ignore someone standing right next to him for several minutes. Even his closest staff members find the distance vexing; they are forever trying to track him down, and were delighted in late May when Warner LeRoy gave Bouley a cellular phone as a birthday gift. "And we have the number!" a staff member crowed. The 60-person Bouley staff (most of them paid between $500 and $1,000 a week) operates by what they call Bouley Time, which means that their boss will be late to all meetings by at least 45 to 60 minutes. He will get up from a meeting in midsentence and return in an hour with no explanation.
But for Bouley's friends and followers, Bouley is always late but never too late. Those who love him describe him as a man whose personality tests the limits of friendship but who just as constantly rewards those who remain in his circle. He has been financially generous to his most loyal employees -- at Bouley, he shared about 15 percent of each year's profits with them -- and is capable of enormous warmth.
Those loyalties will be tested further as Bouley rushes to build the rest of his food empire. Soon will come the 95-seat, $2 million Danube, for which Bouley and Gutenbrunner are planning a menu of Rieslings, low-fat green borscht and $22 to $28 health-conscious entrees. Gustav Klimt reproductions will hang on the walls of a turn-of-the-century-style room. About Danube there remain the most significant doubts. "Austrian food is the heaviest on earth," says Alan Richman. "The Austrians lost wars because of their food. After an Austrian lunch, you couldn't remount."
Bouley will oversee operations at Danube from his headquarters across the street -- a seven-story landmark building that was most recently the home of Mohawk Electrical Supply Co. More than $8 million will have to go into the renovation of the Mohawk by the time the doors open. Bouley says that the International Cafe, on the first floor, will be devoted to a rotating series of chefs who will cook primarily Asian food, with entrees under $30. For the 75-seat version of Bouley on the second floor, he envisions a lavish one-sitting-a-night, vaulted-ceiling extravaganza. The third-floor design calls for two private dining rooms with fireplaces.
Above that, Bouley promises his own cooking school, where many students will train to work in various Bouley restaurants. Bouley hopes that it will function as a training ground, in much the same way as his old Bouley kitchen did. Chefs formerly from Bouley now run kitchens all over New York, including those in such top restaurants as Le Bernardin and La Caravelle. It's a critical element of his operation because he won't be doing much of the cooking in any of his restaurants; he needs disciples who have internalized his methods. He has reserved the fifth floor for what he is calling the Organic Institute, which he wants to equip with a test kitchen to provide chefs with serenity and quiet in which to explore the complexities of taste. Though not a revenue-generating operation, he believes that the institute's work will translate into recipes that attract more customers.
Bouley at Home -- a two-story, high-ceilinged retail operation that will have 200 employees -- is likely to get much of Bouley's personal attention. The $4 million plan calls for wine and Champagne bars, huge cheese displays, vast offerings of organic produce, a wide spectrum of spices and gourmet coffees and teas. He expects to sell only organic meats, chicken and fish. Bouley claims that economies of scale will give him substantially more clout in the food business, and he believes that he has now established exclusive access to the nation's top farmers, growers and fishermen.
For the anticipated catalogue business, as well as his other ventures, Bouley already has a 10,000-name mailing list of old customers. Like his old restaurant, Bouley International is likely to benefit from proximity to Wall Street expense accounts (the World Trade Center is five blocks away) and TriBeCa itself (the top-floor apartment in the co-op building that will house Bouley at Home just sold for $3.7 million). Both neighborhoods have grown substantially as affluent residential areas in the past few years, with gourmet-food retailers scrambling to serve their needs. While an economic downturn could severely hurt the restaurant business -- particularly places that charge $28 for rotisserie chicken -- it's worth remembering that Bouley's last restaurant thrived during the 1991 recession.
"There's always going to be a market for whatever David Bouley does," says Danny Meyer, an owner of Gramercy Tavern and Union Square Cafe, which took over the No. 1 spot in the Zagat survey after Bouley closed. Meyer recently announced plans to open two more restaurants himself. "The profession used to be a lot of immigrants, opening one restaurant and living above the store. Now it's highly motivated Americans with an entrepreneurial bent. We want to create vast, diversified businesses. We don't want to live above our restaurants anymore."
Though Bouley, relishing as always his defiance of expectations, has designed the top two floors of the Mohawk Building as his next apartment.
 Four days after the Fulton Fish Market expedition, Bouley at last looks rested. The Bakery is to open in 20 minutes to a select gathering of journalists, friends and celebrities, and it is at moments of the most intense panic that Bouley appears to grow most calm. The last of the workers is still packing up his tools. Bouley has put on the traditional starched white jacket of his profession, with high collar and buttons down the middle, though he has left it open as he gulps down a last-minute beer.
The very presence of Bouley in the front of his restaurant marks a dramatic shift in his approach to business. On Duane Street, he rarely allowed his customers to see him and paid only infrequent visits to the dining room during business hours. But at the Bakery, Bouley expects to be cooking only a few nights a week. He will be, instead, the public face of his enterprises. He will break his self-imposed silence and actually talk to people for a while. He will sit for extended visits in the front rooms of his restaurants and even eat there occasionally.
"Let's change the music," Bouley says after finishing his beer and realizing that the same Lyle Lovett CD has been on endless replay for the last four hours. An underling is dispatched to Bouley's office to retrieve Miles Davis's "Kind of Blue." Cooks busily prepare canapes, and servers ready trays and glasses.
A few minutes later, at 3:30 P.M., the party begins. It continues until after 11. Most of the expected celebrities end up not showing. Sigourney Weaver called to say she couldn't make it; Bernadette Peters was traveling. Still, a steady stream of friends and associates -- chefs from other restaurants like Waltuck of Chanterelle; old Bouley regulars like the theater director and acting coach Harold Guskin, and business associates like Larry Harmon, the architect -- fills the room for hours with the sound of clinking glasses and crunching bread. By 10, Bouley has taken his new front-of-the-house role even more seriously, having conversations with party-goers and passersby while he leans up against the M10 bus stop outside the Bakery. He is drinking water and every so often takes a bite of a baguette made with imported French organic flour. "Tastes like it already has butter on it," he says.
 Bouley's business success will depend heavily on his ability to keep a smoother partnership with Warner LeRoy than he managed to with his previous partner. The two men come from vastly different backgrounds: Bouley is the son of a salesman and schoolteacher, while LeRoy hails from Hollywood royalty. LeRoy's father, Mervyn, was a director and the producer of, among other things, "The Wizard of Oz." Young Warner's grandfather, Harry Warner, was a founder of Warner Brothers Studio. One morning when Warner was 4, his father brought him to the Oz set; when Warner got there, he took off for a run down the Yellow Brick Road. No one had informed the young boy that Oz was merely a painted backdrop. And so Warner went crashing through the back of the set and quickly learned that there's no place like home, which is where he spent the rest of the shoot.
In 1965, after 11 years of work in the theater, LeRoy opened the restaurant Maxwell's Plum, a swinging-singles Art Nouveau palace that became a defining hot spot of its era. (It closed in 1988.) In August 1976, LeRoy reopened New York's best-located restaurant, Tavern on the Green, in Central Park -- a place that has been described as the inside of a wedding cake. The 900-seat tourist mecca has grown to become one of the city's biggest grossers, and until LeRoy and Bouley became partners it defined Warner LeRoy's role in the New York food world. Asked what he would do if he were put in charge of Tavern, David Bouley cracked a smile and said, "Get a bulldozer."
In 1995, shortly after LeRoy first raised the idea of collaborating with Bouley, he bought the Russian Tea Room. Bouley agreed to be its executive chef and to create a parnership with LeRoy to help him raise the necessary funds to achieve his own vision as well. Bouley owns 51 percent of the stock of Bouley-LeRoy L.L.C. -- the entity that covers all the downtown properties except Bouley at Home, which Bouley intends to finance independently -- while LeRoy owns 49 percent. This effectively gives Bouley final say over all business and creative decisions, though the two men will split the profits 50-50 after Bouley takes a salary off the top. Despite frequent references in the media to LeRoy as the sole financial backer, both men say that so far Bouley has kicked in $1.5 million of his own money. LeRoy has invested roughly an equal amount in cash, along with $2.5 million in notes, for the eventual renovation of the Mohawk Building.
So what, besides his investment, is LeRoy's role in the partnership?
"You can put in your story that you asked that, and that Bouley didn't say anything," Bouley responds, then decides to say something after all: "LeRoy's reaching for the big picture. I'm looking at this little spot. I don't have the financial means to do what he can do. By the same token, what I'm doing is still within my means. I don't need Warner LeRoy to do what I'm doing. And he knows that. When I say that to you, I'm not being disrespectful to Warner LeRoy, but I didn't need him. We understand, both of us. He knows I didn't need him. I know I didn't need him."
"This isn't about need," LeRoy responds evenly. "That's totally irrelevant. My role is to encourage David to grow as much as he can, which he wants to do. To make suggestions to him, some of which he takes and some of which he doesn't. But they are substantial suggestions, and some of them are creative and some of them are not. It's his call." Beyond that, LeRoy says, the two of them will work together to raise the additional funds necessary to complete the rest of the projects. "Some of it will be through mortgages and some of it will be through loans," LeRoy says. "And if we can't do all of it that way, which we would prefer, we will have to sell some equity. And that's it."
The Russian Tea Room project has been stalled for more than a year, largely owing to difficulties in raising the $30 million in investment capital needed to transform the space. At various times over the last several months, LeRoy has believed he was on the verge of getting the money -- "I'm supposed to get the check on March 30," he told me in early February, "and from that point it is 14 months till we open" -- but as of July the money had still not been raised. By late June, LeRoy was rethinking his strategy. While his original plan was to demolish the Russian Tea Room building and erect a new nine-story one in its place, LeRoy is now also considering the more modest approach of an interior renovation. When I asked Bouley what he thought of the Russian Tea Room as an investment, he took my tape recorder and hid it behind his back.
Meanwhile, LeRoy has been coaxing Bouley toward yet another joint project: he wants Bouley to help him run the Rainbow Room. LeRoy and Bouley are among several New York restaurateurs in quiet talks to handle the operation of the landmark Rockefeller Center location. "It is an amazing part of the New York scene," Bouley says, "so I'd be interested in being a part of that."
 'It is like taking your bike out of the garage after a long winter," Bouley is saying between nibbles of a Portuguese Sardine Tart with 24-Hour Cooked Tomatoes and Black Olive and Basil Dressing that he is preparing. "You can't wait to ride it again so you head right out. The first two miles are great, too. But then everything starts going wobbly, and you realize you forgot to fill the tires and they're going flat." That, at 10 minutes after 10 on the night of Bouley Bakery's opening to the public, is the chef's candid assessment of his cooking skills after 12 months off the bike and four hours back on.
Then, within seconds, Bouley's hands begin to move. They fly across the space between the prep table and the stove, stirring and tasting and arranging and tossing and wiping.
Every movement appears to be instinctive and confident. He measures impulsively with his eyes and tastes constantly with his fingers. "It is simple," he once said to me. "You take what is already in the food and you add to it." Every plate, every pot, every saucepan passes before Bouley. He considers each dish before it leaves the kitchen and adds a personal signature, whether it is a crescent moon of mashed potatoes or a sprinkle of marjoram.
It is dead quiet in here. Bouley encourages almost no conversation except as it relates to work. His cooking team tends toward expressionless faces as they prepare their materials.
When Chef asks for fennel, it must be found. When Chef wants garlic, it must be chopped. When Chef needs a laugh, it must be funny, short and to the point.
"Miguel," Bouley says to one of his prep cooks as the young immigrant puts some shrimp in the oven for roasting, "how long have you been working in my restaurant?"
"I was born here," Miguel says.
Funny. All right. Back to work.
"Cut these lengthwise, then like this, then like this," Bouley demonstrates to a young sous-chef as he rests a perfectly formed asparagus on his palm. His index finger marks the incision spots. The sous-chef nods and goes off to chop. Bouley swings around and. . . .
"Where's the tomato water?" he wonders aloud. Someone hands Bouley a bowl, and he gently ladles the water into a pot. Behind him, Kurt Gutenbrunner (who is pitching in here until the opening of Danube) grinds a healthy amount of fresh pepper on the sardines. Just as quickly, Bouley turns again to check the order slips posted against one wall. "Table 4 has two ducks, Table 7 has two chickens and a duck," he says, and those words prompt some quick carving. Tonight, the menu offers Organic Chicken With Rosemary, Local Asparagus, Morels and Fingerling Potato Puree, and Thyme-Honey Glazed Duckling With Fresh Artichokes, Cipollini Onions and Green Potato Gratin. There's also a special four-course menu for $65. At the top of the menu is the date, and also words chosen by Bouley to mark the night: Act I.
But if the last meal at Bouley was called Intermission, then shouldn't this one be called Act II?
"I'm starting fresh," Bouley says, as he puts a handful of organic fava beans into his mouth.
 The early reviews for the Bouley Bakery have been mixed. "Once again, we're in the money -- collectively, anyway -- so say 'Look who's here!' to the double-digit appetizer and 'They're baaaack' to the $30 entree," Hal Rubenstein wrote in New York magazine. "A scattershot dinner with M.I.A. service in a cafe bakery doesn't cut it." Alan Richman of GQ ate a 75-minute dinner ($165 for two people) at Bouley Bakery one recent Saturday night. "At the old place everything was about waiting -- for the reservation, for your table, for your food," Richman says. "Now he's cooking faster than any man alive." Richman found himself amazed at the transformation of the Bouley style.
"He's created a superbly simple menu for the small restaurant adjoining the bakery, with dishes that rely on great products left to speak for themselves," Ruth Reichl wrote in an enthusiastic Diner's Journal in late June. "His Chilled Tomato Terrine is sweet and almost meaty against the fromage blanc. The clams are simply extraordinary. The chilled soup is like gazpacho, only better, the pureed vegetables perked up with a little vinegar and the fine briny flavor of fresh Florida shrimp."
This first public report that the chef was finally back prompted 4,000 calls to the Bakery in one day. The next available 8 P.M. table is in early October.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2683 words

HEADLINE: Ready for Takeoff

BYLINE: By Claudia Dreifus; Claudia Dreifus is a contributing writer for the Magazine. A collection of her work, "Interview," was published last month.

 BODY:
 The chairman and C.E.O. of the Boeing Company, the world's largest space, defense and commercial jet-craft producer, occasionally talks about this or that piece of hardware with words like "neat," "awesome" and "golly." But Philip Murray Condit's Buck Rogers side is tempered by an aggressiveness that has helped him to make his huge company virtually indomitable. Since assuming the position of C.E.O. 16 months ago, Condit, a 56-year-old aeronautics engineer trained at Berkeley, Princeton and M.I.T., has navigated Boeing's absorption of Rockwell International's defense and aerospace divisions and, two weeks ago, McDonnell Douglas. Now Boeing has only two American rivals in the defense business -- Lockheed Martin and Raytheon -- when just a decade ago there were nine.
 But the $16.3 billion McDonnell Douglas merger would never have happened if Condit hadn't capitulated on a major issue. The European Union had threatened to start a trade war unless the consortium Airbus Industrie received greater access to American markets. In the end, Condit and Boeing agreed to ignore the exclusivity provisions of aircraft-supply contracts with several American air carriers. That leaves the Europeans feeling triumphant and Condit free to concentrate on new headaches, like the recent crash of the Boeing 747 in Guam, as well as on what he terms, with some awe, "building these huge birds." 
 Q: We are sitting here in the same Seattle hotel suite where last December you and Harry Stonecipher, the C.E.O. of McDonnell Douglas, negotiated your merger deal. There had been previous attempts to broker this marriage. Why did it work this time?
A: Over the past year we had some big wins. They had a couple of big losses. And consolidation in the industry was about to take another major step. Our reasons for the acquisition were strategic. This is a cyclical business. When the world economy is up, people buy civilian airplanes. And when the economy is down, they don't. Now, the military-defense-space sector has a different set of drivers: geopolitical
forces and rapidly developing technology in space. With the acquisition of Rockwell, and now McDonnell Douglas, we get some balance by having a better presence in the defense and space sectors. We'll have a ratio of 60 percent civilian aviation to a 40 percent defense-space business.
Q: The European Union fought the McDonnell Douglas merger down to the last moment. Even though the merger had been approved by our Federal Trade Commission, the Europeans threatened to place huge tariffs on Boeing products unless you agreed to concessions that gave your major competitor, Airbus, potentially greater access to American markets. There were hints that the White House urged you to capitulate.
A: We absolutely did not get any pressure to capitulate. All along, we kept thinking about what was best for our company, our shareholders. We gave in to them some in places where we needed to make a deal, and we got a lot from the European side. We were doing trades. They wanted us to divest of Douglas -- the civilian aircraft part of McDonnell Douglas -- and we argued that it should not be divested. And in the end that's what we came out with.
Q: Now that the merger has been completed, are you ready for a serious battle with Airbus?
A: My view is that the merger by itself doesn't change the situation at Airbus all that much. McDonnell Douglas doesn't bring a lot of strength on the commercial side. It brings a lot of strength on the military side.
The merger gives us power, but it is also a risk. Being big comes with a downside. There are parts of this business where agility is extremely important, and it's much harder to be quick and agile if you're really big. Part of the challenge is to build units that by themselves are agile inside that larger construct. You've got to give them the guidance to operate, but you can't micromanage them.
Q: Your company has been the target of a lot of criticism on safety issues. In promotional materials, Airbus executives often hint that their planes are safer than yours. They allude to T.W.A. Flight 800 and to the two 737 crashes, near Colorado Springs and Pittsburgh. How do you answer them?
A: I don't think it is beneficial to Boeing or Airbus to argue about who is safer in a world where both of us put safety at the very top of what we do. What we have is a very safe system. So why would you want to argue about who is safer?
Q: Federal authorities have been saying all summer that they're pretty certain that neither a bomb nor a missile took out T.W.A. Flight 800. They suspect, instead, an explosion in the fuel tank. Will you be recalling your 747 fleet to check the fuel tanks?
A: The first thing that has to happen is that you've got to determine what the cause was. You've got to fix the right thing, whatever it is.
Q: Early reporting on Flight 800 suggested that it had been downed by terrorists. As terrible as that would have been, did you almost hope for that -- as opposed to a mechanical problem?
A: One of the things I've learned is that you don't "hope" for anything. You try to find out the answer.
Q: But that would have been a better result for the company, wouldn't it?
A: I don't know how there can be a "better result" when people die.
Q: The Seattle Times won a Pulitzer Prize this year for a series investigating what it described as technical problems with the rudder system on the 737. Why haven't you recalled the 737 fleet while you've worked on that rudder problem?
A: Because there is zero evidence that that's where the problem is.
Q: But you did eventually make some adjustments in your 737's rudder. Why do it if there was no problem?
A: Because we do testing, and -- this is something I can't overstress -- whenever you do find something, whatever it is, you've got to fix it. What we found was that under a very different set of circumstances, if we did certain things, we could cause a problem. There's no evidence that this has happened. You do a microscopic analysis. You look for little tiny scratches that tell you if something jammed and didn't jam. But we did find a condition that could produce a problem. We went out to the fleet and said, Go check for this. We checked every single airplane and didn't find any of them with that problem. We changed the design so that won't happen.
Q: You've said that Boeing's mergers with McDonnell Douglas and Rockwell will strengthen your defense business. Why move so heavily into defense contracting at a moment when domestic military production appears to be drawing down?
A: Two reasons. One of them is the consolidation of defense producers. The second -- and this is where I have a strong desire that this is not true -- is that human beings have had a very poor record on keeping the peace. I believe that a strong defense industry is an important part of our Government. Every time we've let it grow weak, we had to hurry and build it back up again.
Q: So you view the post-cold-war defense downsizing as temporary?
A: We're doing our planning on the basis of relative stability, that it has come down and it will flatten out. Defense will be a relatively stable business, of which we can have a bigger part.
Q: Boeing was already a giant. With this merger, you're a colossus. Can you foresee a situation in which what's good for Boeing might not be good for America?
A: I don't think it's likely. On the other hand, if the U.S. said, We now have an isolationist policy, that would be a conflict with the Boeing view of the world. We sell to a world market.
Q: When U.S.-Chinese relations get rocky, do you fret?
A: Yes, absolutely. From a fundamental business standpoint, China's an important market. Beyond that, I have some pretty firmly held beliefs that commerce is an integrating factor. It brings people together.
I think we get very tangled up when we say, What is our human rights policy and how does it interact with our trade policy? On that I believe very strongly that we Americans tend to have a bit of a warped perspective. There's a need for recognition that we operate in a global market and that people have choices.
When we came out of World War II, the only strong industrial capability in the world was in the United States. Everybody had to come here for things. That's no longer true. Yet we still do things as if everybody has to come to us. That's why I think that we need broad international agreement on human rights principles by multilateral powers. It can't be just us.
Q: Are you saying that human rights should not be a dimension of American foreign policy?
A: I'm saying that I do not believe that human rights should be a key element of trade policy -- it should be part of fundamental foreign policy. Now, there are always places where you can't quite make that separation. But sometimes it seems as if we Americans are like the proverbial policeman chasing the fleeing criminal and pointing a gun to our own head and saying, "Stop or I'll shoot myself."
Q: Do you have personal feelings about human rights violations in China?
A: Oh, yeah, absolutely. And I'm going to put it in context: they are the same ones that I have about human rights violations in the United States.
Q: Wait a second. Americans do live in a democracy. We get to vote for our political leaders, and we aren't shot down in the streets, as the demonstrators in Tiananmen Square were.
A: Well, not in the same way. But viewed from the outside, some of the struggles we've had with civil rights don't look all that shiny. People have been shot. People have been beaten. I happened to be in China during the Rodney King beating. Now, there is a whole bunch of background that goes along with that. But watching that on CNN in China, their perspective was, what was that about?
The position that a number of Chinese leaders have put forward is that they believe that the Soviet experience was the wrong approach -- that you have to get your economy in order before you move to a more open political system. You have to make sure that you are seeing both sides. Can we move other countries in a direction that is positive in terms of civil rights? I believe that the answer is yes. I happen to believe that the most powerful way that you do that is by engagement.
Q: Last year the Chinese placed an order for some short-range passenger transports with Airbus. Was that their way of signaling that unless you can fix these squabbles we're having with your State Department, we'll trade with Europe?
A: In a word, no. I do think what it said indirectly was, We do have alternatives. If the U.S. decides to take a unilateral position, we need to be willing to acknowledge that our trading partners have other choices and that that has an impact on the United States.
Q: Returning to your merger with McDonnell Douglas -- most consolidations involve a certain amount of people losing their jobs. Is that going to happen here?
A: We have an advantage. We're making a lot of planes, and we've got growing markets -- and so normally we would be hiring a fair number of people. But one of the things that we're focused on is, How do we take advantage of the merger to not hire people? In other words, get the savings without having to lay off people. Now, that's going to mean that in some cases people will change jobs, and changing jobs is disruptive. But we should be able to get the kind of savings we're after without significant downsizing.
Q: A couple of years back, Boeing was the scene of an exceptionally bitter 69-day strike. Your contract with the machinists' union expires in 1999. Will there be another strike?
A: I see strikes as a failure of communication -- on both sides. People get set positions and they don't hear the other side. I'm not exempting management from this. We have had relatively aggressive company-union relationships. Every once in a while they have to demonstrate that they can stand up to us. And every once in a while we have to demonstrate that we can stand up to them.
Now, about the 1999 contract: I will personally try -- as will others -- to not let that happen again. Let me give you a specific example. Every one of our customers is a 24-hour-a-day, seven-day-a-week operation -- NASA, the airlines. We are a five-day-a-week, two-shift and a small-third-shift kind of operation. That means we leave the majority of the week where these very high value products are just sitting doing nothing. One of the things we've said is that we want to move into being a seven-day, 24-hour company. The union says, Oh, no, we don't want to do that. But that same union represents mechanics who work for airlines that work around the clock.
Q: So transforming Boeing into a seven-day, 24-hour shop will be an issue in the coming negotiations?
A: I have no idea, by the way, whether it will be a seven-day or if we move to that through a series of gradual steps. What we're headed to right now is a lot of conversation, as opposed to taking positions and then being in a contract negotiation. The real goal is to reach the negotiating table and have nothing to negotiate -- you have already dealt with those issues.
Q: One of your personal accomplishments at Boeing has been to revolutionize the way airplanes are made. Your newest model jetliner, the 777, for instance, is manufactured by small production teams, in much the same way that automobiles are made in Japan. You're now employing computer and modem technology throughout the design process. Workers and customers are encouraged to add their ideas. Did you go to Japan and study their methods?
A: Yes, in the late 80's. We read a lot and visited a number of companies, and they had some really good ideas. And these were things we could do.
The key phrase on the 777 was "working together." It was O.K. to cross boundaries. And it's fun, it's creative. But you have to be careful. It's a little like ordering people to like each other. It might not work.
Q: This is a company that used to be called "the Kremlin" because its culture was so secretive and hierarchical. Surely there's been some resistance to your opening up the Kremlin.
A: An easy phrase: change is always difficult. The thing that inhibits change most is fear.
Q: When you first came to Boeing as an aerodynamics engineer in 1965, you worked on the development of the SST, the supersonic transport. This jet was never built. Now that you head the company, might you revive the idea of an American SST to compete with the European Concorde?
A: We are working on an SST -- have been, well, virtually continuously. We never gave up.
There are technical and economic problems to overcome. Our SST's have to operate with airport noise levels that are equal to the best current airplanes. SST's tend to be noisy. I don't think you are going to have a big market for a plane that needs a noise-pollution exemption. The second problem is high-altitude emissions. The planes put out nitrous oxide, which tends to attack the ozone. The third problem is the sonic boom. That probably won't change, so the SST would be limited to flying over the water. If we can solve these technical problems and make a plane that gets you New York to London twice as fast when the costs are the same, I want to be there.
Those are big ifs. But I don't want the Boeing Company to be in a position where somebody else solves the equation and we miss one of those turns.
Q: A final question. The remains of one of your engineers, Benson Hamlin, were recently sent orbiting into space along with those of Gene Roddenberry, the creator of "Star Trek," and the LSD guru Timothy Leary. When the time comes, would you want such a funeral for yourself?
A: I don't think so. My perception of myself is as a fairly simple person. If I was to be asked, quick quick quick, what do you consider the perfect setting, it would be in the mountains -- maybe scattered in a mountain stream. But with interesting companions like Timothy Leary and Gene Roddenberry, I'd probably go off into my own little corner.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 746 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Cambodian Coup Leaves Tourist Sites Empty

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia

 BODY:
"IT'S zero," said Nongnuj Dobbs, Phnom Penh office manager for the East-West travel agency, describing tourism to Cambodia after last month's coup.
"It's nil," said Meng Hieng, managing director of the Pich Tourist Company. 
 Chenda Sophea Sok, Undersecretary of State in the Ministry of Tourism, agreed. "Those images of evacuation planes killed us, killed the industry," he said.
More than a month since political tensions erupted in fighting in early July, virtually no one is visiting Cambodia for pleasure. Although both the fighting and the evacuation flights have ended, it could be months before the industry recovers.
Hotels are nearly empty. Airlines have cut back on their flights. Restaurants and nightclubs have fallen dark, and casinos have closed. Tour operators, drivers, waiters, chambermaids, vendors, guides, hawkers and ladies of the evening are mostly out of work. The National Museum in Phnom Penh opens its doors each morning, stands empty all day, then closes on schedule in the evening. Almost no one travels to visit the great temples at Angkor Wat, where gunfire could be heard in mid-July.
Political instability and, in remote areas, persistent banditry have always been part of the landscape for visitors to Cambodia. But the country's small tourism industry had begun to grow in recent years.
Since the coup, security is in question again. The fighting of early July has ended in the capital, and Angkor Wat appears secure, too. But the possibility of renewed fighting remains in the country's western and northern regions. The most recent United States State Department warning, issued Aug. 8, recommends that United States citizens defer nonessential travel to Cambodia and that those who must go not travel outside Phnom Penh, specifically mentioning Siem Reap province, site of Angkor Wat.
Despite the uncertainty of the political situation, Mr. Chenda of the Ministry of Tourism said in an interview that he was optimistic about the future, and he may be right. "I don't worry, because by the end of the year everything will be normal," he said, "even better than before."
But tourism may not recover so soon.
"I think it is O.K. to go to Angkor Wat," Mrs. Dobbs said. "It is very quiet now. But as a tour operator we cannot guarantee that nothing will happen." Even though factional fighting has ended, she said, the possibility of banditry seems to have grown.
"My father wants to go there," she said. "I recommended to him not to carry money, not to carry anything valuable. Even a small camera -- if someone wants to take it, just give it to them." This advice is much the same as always. Cambodia has always been a destination for the adventurous, and much of its attractiveness has been its very underdevelopment. But it is a nation desperately in need of commerce; even the $20 visa fees paid by arriving tourists have been a significant contribution.
The shock of the coup, which has set back foreign aid and investment across the board, has been a severe blow to the economy. The halt in the tourism industry is being felt through much of the country. In an economy as primitive as this one -- where most of the population still toils in rice fields -- the tourism industry was disproportionately significant. Until the coup it accounted for about one-third of foreign investment, second only to infrastructure development.
Mr. Chenda said it had been growing fast, from a very small base. In 1993, he said, just 90,000 tourist visas were issued. By last year the number had risen to 220,000. This figure includes people who traveled to Cambodia for business as well as for tourism. The growing number of visitors led to a hotel building boom, and several new hotels, offering a total of 1,500 rooms, were set to open soon in Phnom Penh. Much of this construction has stopped.
Daily flights from Phnom Penh to Siem Reap -- the site of Angkor Wat -- had increased from two in 1993 to three in 1995 to seven since last November, Mr. Chenda said. Those have now been cut back to just one flight a day, which is still nearly empty.
Mr. Meng Hieng said that just before the coup he attended a conference of travel agents in China, where he signed contracts with companies interested in Cambodia's emerging tourist market.
"We were expecting an increase of 10 to 15 percent in our business this year," he said. "Unfortunately, Cambodia has this kind of fighting, and this has caused us a good deal of annoyance."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 12; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2361 words

HEADLINE: Making a Break For the Blues

BYLINE: By ALEX WARD; ALEX WARD is editor of special sections for The Times.

 BODY:
IT'S probably not often that what begins as a quick getaway trip turns into a pilgrimage. But when a friend called last October and suggested taking a few days off to go to a blues festival in Helena, Ark., that's more or less what happened.
Helena, 55 miles southwest of Memphis, is on the western edge of the alluvial plain known as the Mississippi Delta, where the blues were spawned by workers who toiled in the cotton fields by day and played the juke joints at night. Forming the region's spine is Route 61, the blacktop artery that carried the music north, along with throngs of black migrants escaping their sharecropper existences. 
 It was from station KFFA on Righter Street in Helena that "King Biscuit Time," the radio show that helped popularize the blues, originated in 1941. And Helena was home to one of the program's featured performers, Rice Miller, better known as Sonny Boy Williamson. The notoriously hard-living Sonny Boy died in 1965, but "King Biscuit Time" is still going, as is its longtime emcee, John W. (Sunshine Sonny) Payne.
About 65 miles east of Helena, in the hill country of Mississippi, is Oxford, the site of the University of Mississippi and the Center for the Study of Southern Culture, a sort of Vatican for worshippers of the region's literature (Faulkner is the Almighty), art, politics, economics, food and, yes, the blues.
The university also has what it boasts is the world's largest blues archive (some 32,000 blues and gospel records), a lure we considered irresistible. So Oxford was our first destination after landing in Memphis on a midday Friday flight.
The Center for the Study of Southern Culture has achieved full curriculum status at the university, offering undergraduate and postgraduate degrees and attracting students from all over the world. It is best known for high-profile literary get-togethers, particularly the Yoknapatawpha Faulkner Conference, which it sponsors each August with the English department. But the center has also produced notable books on Southern art and music, among them The Encyclopedia of Southern Culture, edited by William Ferris, the center's director, and Charles R. Wilson. The center also publishes Living Blues magazine, a bimonthly mix of interviews, album reviews and festival reports.
We sat for a while in Mr. Ferris's office, on the second floor of the 140-year-old Barnard Observatory on the Ole Miss campus, while he talked about the growth of regional studies programs throughout the country and about a dream of his, in which the growing interest in the Civil War, in the blues, in Southernalia generally, will lure more visitors to his part of the world.
He also talked us into remaining in Oxford long enough to visit the town square, a source of local pride, and trying the fare at City Grocery, a nouvelle Southern bistro not far from Faulkner's house. We had planned to be in Helena for that evening's festival program, but it was a warm, cloudless, lazy afternoon, and it seemed a shame to come this far and not see more of this seductive town. Besides, we were hungry.
Several hours later, stuffed full of cheese grits and shrimp, we drove to Tunica, Miss., about 20 miles northeast of Helena, where we were booked into a spanking new hotel-casino called Fitzgerald's, which was about the only place in the area where we could reserve rooms on short notice. We checked in, wandered down to the casino to watch men in bib overalls play blackjack, and called it a day.
The next morning, Saturday, we made straight for Helena, where the music was due to start at 10 o'clock and keep going until whenever. There were four stages set up for the festival, three of them at the foot of the town levee that runs along the Mississippi River and creates a natural sloped seating area. The fourth, the gospel stage, was in a parking lot at the north end of town.
Admission was free, so we roamed from one to another, stopping whenever someone caught our attention. We listened to a young Delta bluesman with the improbable name of Fruteland Jackson; to Candy Shines, a full-bodied belter with great moves, and to the guitarist Bob Margolin, a veteran of the Muddy Waters Band, who was paired with James Harman, a harmonica player from California. We also heard Junior Kimbrough, a local legend from Holly Springs, Miss., whose stark, plaintive wail is sometimes on key and sometimes off, but either way can make those little hairs on the back of your neck stand up.
At one point, in search of a drink, we wandered down Cherry Street, the town's main thoroughfare, which was transformed into a long outdoor food and souvenir bazaar. There, on a small stage meant for clowns or magicians or other performers who can keep children entertained, was Johnnie Billington, a 70-ish guitarist who was accompanied on a rolling electric blues song by a 12-year-old bass player and a drummer who looked even younger. Known as Mr. Johnnie, Billington runs an educational program through the Delta Blues Museum in Clarksdale, Miss., whose purpose is to perpetuate the blues by keeping youngsters off the streets and in the juke joints, where they belong. We were told this by a friendly woman who was passing a hat for donations. With pleasure, we anted up for the scholarship fund.
As afternoon turned into evening, and Robert (Junior) Lockwood and his band completed their set on the main stage, we broke for dinner at Kathryn's, a homey restaurant across the river on Moon Lake, Miss., that Mr. Ferris had recommended.
Over broiled catfish, we fell into conversation with two men at the next table, a liquor salesman who grew up in the area but who was living in New Orleans, and a former sheriff of Coahoma County. They told us about Uncle Henry's, an inn just down the road, which Tennessee Williams had often visited and is a setting, as Moon Lake Casino, in "Summer and Smoke."
We agreed we would stop by for a closer look at the place, but not until the next day. In Helena the Saturday night program, the festival's showcase, was in full swing. It was about 8:30 when we arrived back, just in time for Anson Funderburgh and the Rockets, a band whose lead singer is Sam Myers, a 60-year-old with a big, gruff voice, a sharp wit and a demeanor best described as stately. By the time he was finished, we decided he should be declared a national treasure.
There was more to come, and we stayed for much of it. By midnight, however, the schedule had slowed to a crawl, and Luther Allison, the headliner, had yet to go on. Glassy-eyed and music-logged, we headed back to Tunica, where Fitzgerald's, our Emerald City on the Delta, awaited.
Nine hours later, we pulled up at Uncle Henry's inn. The driveway was shaded by cedar, pecan and magnolia trees; Moon Lake sparkled across the road. Why hadn't we known about this place when we were scrambling to make reservations?
Sarah Wright, the proprietor with her son, George, greeted us politely and agreed to give us a quick tour and a capsule history of her quirky, charming little place. It was a casino in the 30's, but was shut down when the townspeople discovered that its profits were going to the mob in Chicago. Sarah's foster father, Henry Trevino, whom she called Uncle Henry, later bought it, and she eventually took it over, about a decade after his death in 1976. She showed us Jitterbug Hall, a room where dances were once held, and walked us out back, where the Yazoo Pass winds quietly by.
Yes, she said, Tennessee Williams came by occasionally, usually in the company of his grandfather, a minister in Clarksdale, but as far as she knows, he never stayed there. She declined our request for breakfast -- for guests only -- and said we were welcome to stroll around the grounds, and to come back and stay any time.
 WE thanked her, got back in the car and headed south for Clarksdale, a sleepy city of 22,000, where we wanted to visit the Delta Blues Museum. Recently re located on the second floor of Clarksdale's old Carnegie Library, the museum displays photographs, paintings, sculptures (a life-size, wax-and-resin Muddy Waters sits atop a tiny platform), videos, and exhibits explaining the history of the music. We passed a pleasant hour or two there, then checked out Rooster Blues Records, a combination record shop and recording studio devoted to the work of Mississippi bluesmen.
There was not an open restaurant in sight, so we sat on a shaded bench across the street from the museum, ate peanuts from a convenience store and tried to make contact with the town's ghosts. Clarksdale has been called ground zero of the Delta Blues, so we figured there had to be plenty of them in the vicinity.
That night, after driving up Route 61 to Memphis, we took in Beale Street, once bad and brassy and deservedly storied, but now a pedestrian blues mall where all the clubs look more or less the same, with much neon and ersatz funkiness. We retreated to the lobby of the Peabody Hotel a few blocks away, and raised a glass to Sam Myers.
Memphis is, of course, the city of Elvis Presley, who not only has a boulevard named for him, but whose home, Graceland, is its most famous landmark. On Monday we had a 2 P.M. flight back to New York, which left us the morning free, and I felt it should somehow be devoted to the King of Rock-and-Roll. He was, after all, a child of the region (Tupelo, Miss.), and musically a linear descendant of its bluesmen, from whom he borrowed both material and style.
The Graceland Elvis, with its images of a glitzy Vegas showman, doesn't interest me much. But the early Elvis, the Sun Sessions Elvis, is another story. The Sun recording studio, where, the story goes, in 1953 a lanky, self-conscious 18-year-old walked in and asked if he could make a vanity record for his mother's birthday, is at 706 Union Avenue, about a mile east of downtown. There are regular tours, though the space is so small they are pretty much confined to one room.
Ah, but what a room. Its official name in those days was the Memphis Recording Service, and it was run by a restless young producer named Sam Phillips. "Rocket 88," considered by many to be the very first rock-and-roll song, was recorded here (for the Chicago-based Chess label) in 1951; the singer was Jackie Brenston, who was backed on piano by one of Phillips's talent scouts, a young man named Ike Turner.
It was here that Howlin' Wolf first recorded, where Jerry Lee Lewis made "Great Balls of Fire" and "Whole Lotta Shakin' Going On," where Carl Perkins recorded "Blue Suede Shoes" and Johnny Cash recorded "I Walk the Line." And where Elvis Presley, whom Phillips invited back after hearing Elvis's demo tape, recorded "That's All Right (Mama)," and thereby changed the course of popular music.
In the four decades since, the Sun Studio has been a barbershop and a scuba diving store, among other things. But perhaps because there wasn't much to it to begin with, the place is remarkably intact, with the original acoustic tiles and control room equipment, even the same standup mike that Phillips's artists sang into. "You are standing on hallowed ground," the guide said.
Sometimes, the hackneyed phrase is the right one. I would swear I noticed some of our group, which included a pair of Dutch 20-somethings in black Sun Records T-shirts and a middle-aged couple who had arrived on a huge Harley, bow their heads. I know I did.
It turns out that Sam Phillips, now in his 70's and the owner of a group of radio stations around the country, still lives in Memphis. Why, I wondered as we headed for the airport, isn't a boulevard named after him?
 
Whole lotta music going on

Where to Stay and Eat
The five-room Uncle Henry's Place and Inn, 5860 Moon Lake Road, Dundee, Miss. 38626, (601) 337-2757, charges $65 a night for a double, including breakfast. Three of the rooms have private bath, two share a bath.
Kathryn's Restaurant is at 5765 Moon Lake Road; (601) 337-2962. The restaurant serves steak and seafood; an eight-ounce filet mignon is $14.95. The restaurant sells beer and wine coolers, but customers can bring their own wine and liquor. Open for dinner Wednesday through Sunday, starting at 6 P.M.
Though the mailing address for Uncle Henry's and Kathryn's is Dundee, the nearest town, for reference, is Lula, about two miles away.
City Grocery is at 152 Courthouse Square in Oxford, Miss.; (601) 232-8080. Lunch and dinner are served Monday through Saturday. The specialty is shrimp and grits ($17 at dinner). The restaurant has a full liquor license. A.W.
