HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
Not Just Dazzling in Their Time, but Dedicated

BYLINE: By Jack Anderson 

 BODY:
WITH THE DEATHS THIS YEAR OF Alexandra Danilova, in July, and Leon Danielian, in March, the ballet world has lost two great dancers of enormous flair. Although they appeared with several groups during their long careers, they were especially associated with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, the cosmopolitan touring company that after settling in the United States during World War II delighted countless Americans from the 1940's through the early 60's. The performances of Danilova and Danielian did much to convince newcomers to dancing that ballet could be exhilarating and inspiring -- and fun as well.
The Russian ballerina Danilova sparkled on stage. Offstage, she was always glamorous and she spoke a vivid but idiosyncratic English with a grammar of her own invention. The American-born Danielian was a brilliant technician, and a wit as well. Both his dancing and his conversation had brio. The stage personalities of these dancers were inimitable. And we can still learn from their example, even though they cannot be copied. 
 Danilova, who was 93, and Danielian, 75, were remarkably versatile. Audiences found Danilova a noble and passionate Swan Queen in "Swan Lake." She had a worldly charm as the Glove Seller in "Gaite Parisienne" and the Street Dancer in "Le Beau Danube." But she was a spectral Sleepwalker in "Night Shadow." And although she preferred narrative ballets, she was also effective in abstract pieces like George Balanchine's "Danses Concertantes" and Bronislava Nijinska's "Chopin Concerto."
Danielian took to the air in the Bluebird pas de deux from "The Sleeping Beauty" and scurried amusingly along the ground in "Gaite Parisienne," in which he portrayed a bumbling Peruvian tourist eager to sample Parisian night life. He strutted as a vain matador in "Madronos." In "L'Apres-Midi d'un Faune," he was an amorous faun; in "Carnaval," a whirling Harlequin.
Both dancers had limitations. Tragic roles did not suit Danielian's temperament. Critics thought Danilova unconvincing as Giselle, possibly because she seemed too inherently sophisticated to persuade them that she was a vulnerable peasant girl. She triumphed, however, as another peasant lass: the clever and strong-willed Swanilda in "Coppelia."
Danilova and Danielian defied typecasting. Today, dancers are sometimes much too readily classified by their companies as lyrical, noble or dramatic, making it difficult for them to develop a range.
Danilova, Danielian and their contemporaries may have found it easier to achieve versatility simply because the companies of their time were smaller. While ballet troupes now often boast 80 or more dancers, those of the 40's and 50's usually had about 40, and every dancer had to perform in many sorts of ballets. Principal dancers, therefore, had opportunities to play unconventional roles. Danilova surprised and delighted audiences when she danced (and spoke lines of dialogue as well) in Ruth Page's "Billy Sunday," a comic ballet telling Bible stories in a choreographic style that tried to capture the flamboyance of the evangelist's sermons.
Danilova and Danielian had lively minds, as well as agile bodies. Although neither received much formal education, both were intellectually inquisitive. Danilova, a product of the Imperial Ballet School in St. Petersburg, was an authority on the 19th-century classics. But those were not her only choreographic loves. As a member of Serge Diaghilev's often experimental Ballets Russes of the 1920's, she danced with the most innovative troupe in 20th-century ballet. She once said in an interview: "I have been so lucky. All my life I have worked with the avant-garde. That developed me enormously as an artist, much more than if I had danced just 'Swan Lake' and 'Giselle.' "
DANIELIAN, A WELL-READ MAN, WAS interested in theatrical history and could discuss poetry and painting with considerable authority. Although a high school dropout, he was a professor of dance at the University of Texas in Austin from 1982 until he retired in 1991. The breadth of his knowledge surely helped make him an effective teacher.
But perhaps the greatest artistic virtue that Danilova and Danielian shared was a total dedication to dance. Such dedication is typical of many of their contemporaries: an example is Frederic Franklin, Danilova's usual partner at the Ballet Russe, who today, at the age of 83, goes around the world teaching classes and staging productions with undiminished energy. His bubbly version of "Coppelia" was one of the delights of American Ballet Theater's spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House.
Dancers are, for the most part, more secure in their professions today than they used to be, although some ballet companies still teeter on the edge of economic catastrophe. In the more uncertain times of the 40's and 50's, when no one quite knew what the next season might bring (or if there would be a next season), members of the Ballet Russe and the early Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet lived for the moment on stage. Many came to regard ballet not simply as a job but almost as a religious calling.
Danilova once said, "I never danced for an audience that I thought was unworthy of my performance." And in her autobiography, "Choura," she wrote: "Every woman has an image -- mother, princess, ballerina -- that she must uphold. I was privileged to be a ballerina and I, therefore, had a duty to my audience."
An awareness of artistic responsibility guided Danilova and Danielian first as dancers and then as teachers and stagers of ballets. If their spirit and sense of mission live on in young performers, the world of dance will be enriched.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Fairy Tale Without An Ending

BYLINE: By ANN KOLSON 

 BODY:
FROM THE OPENING MOMENT, WITH ITS thunderous chords of the Ronettes' "Be My Baby" and its close-ups of ecstatic young people's flashing thighs, arching backs and grinding hips, the movie "Dirty Dancing" pulled audiences into its rhythms and back to a time when everything seemed possible.
This little musical romance, made for $5 million and starring two near-unknowns, Patrick Swayze and Jennifer Grey, was released exactly 10 years ago and quickly became a phenomenon in a way that no one associated with it quite understands, even to this day. A modern-day Romeo and Juliet story set in the Catskills, it earned more than $170 million worldwide, was the source of two top-selling soundtrack albums, inspired a group of particularly crazed fans to sit through 100 showings apiece and still has videotape sales of about 40,000 copies a month. 
 "When you find that you have lightning in a bottle, you don't waste time trying to explain it," Jimmy Ienner, the music executive who acquired rights to many of the songs for "Dirty Dancing," said recently.
Will that lightning strike twice? On Friday, Live Entertainment is re-releasing a musically re-mastered version of the film in 25 American cities, with plans to open the movie more widely the following weekend. There will be a flashy Hollywood "premiere," and Mr. Swayze, who plays the dance instructor Johnny Castle, the poor but sensitive heartthrob, will get his own star on Hollywood Boulevard. (Members of Perfectly Patrick, a group of Mr. Swayze's fans, will polish that star monthly; he suggested that weekly might be overdoing it.)
Talk of re-releasing the movie began in March, said David Bowers, Live's executive vice president for publicity. In fact, it's being promoted more as a first release, with a blizzard of television and print advertising, a campaign that Mr. Bowers says will cost a few million dollars. "We'll introduce it to a whole new generation of people," he said, "those who haven't seen it before in theaters."
At the center of this unusual effort is a belief that women still love this fairy tale of a movie. "Women really want to fall in love with a handsome man," Mr. Bowers said. "We all had a wonderful summer romance in our life. You never forget your first time."
Which brings us to the movie's creator, Eleanor Bergstein, a novelist and screenwriter. Loosely autobiographical, "Dirty Dancing" takes place during the idyllic summer of 1963 at Kellerman's Mountain House in the Catskills, a playground for the well-to-do. John F. Kennedy was President, the Peace Corps beckoned the idealistic young, and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King boomed, "I had a dream."
Into the Borscht Belt Eden comes 17-year-old Baby, bookish, slightly awkward and earnest (played by a luminous Ms. Grey), her more beautiful princess of a sister, Lisa, and their doctor father and housewife mother. When Baby stumbles into the off-limits, smoky staff quarters late at night, she discovers an erotic world of pounding music, heart-stopping dancing and heartbreaking romance in the form of Johnny, who with the crook of a finger and some sweltering dance moves mesmerizes her.
Ms. Bergstein, too, was the daughter of a Brooklyn physician, with a sister. They spent some summers at Grossinger's, the legendary resort. Her parents golfed. She still has snapshots of herself from that time. "I was a teen-age mambo queen," she said recently, "a little nymphet."
During the school year, she tutored underprivileged children. At night she went dancing to raunchy rock-and-roll in basements and rec rooms with boys from the wrong side of the tracks. "I have dirty-dancing trophies that will turn your hands green if you touch them," she said, speaking over the telephone from a house in Tuscany.
Like Johnny, she once taught ballroom dance at Arthur Murray. Was there a Johnny Castle in her life? "I think there's one in everybody's life," she said.
It was over lunch with Ms. Bergstein in a restaurant on the Upper West Side of Manhattan in early 1985 that Linda Gottlieb, then a producer for MGM, first heard the term "dirty dancing." "Eleanor, that's a million-dollar title!" Ms. Gottlieb remembers exclaiming.
MGM financed development of the movie, but when the studio changed management, it dropped the project. Ms. Gottlieb began soliciting studios. "I was turned down by everyone who could say no," she said. "I kept hearing the same responses: it's small and it's soft."
When Vestron Video chose "Dirty Dancing" to be its first venture into feature films, Ms. Gottlieb agreed to pare her proposed budget by nearly half. To economize, she and the director, Emile Ardolino, recreated the Catskills in Virginia and North Carolina, two states where labor unions were not a factor. Rain and cold prevailed in September 1986 at the Mountain Lake Hotel in Giles County, Va., where the cast and crew were ensconced -- along with a convention of bird-watchers -- at the start of the 43-day filming. As the leaves began to turn yellow, crew members spray painted them green, Ms. Gottlieb recalled.
Mr. Ardolino, who died of AIDS in 1993, had read the script while on jury duty in Manhattan. It was the first feature for the director, who in 1984 had won the Academy Award for best documentary with "He Makes Me Feel Like Dancin' ," about the ballet dancer and teacher Jacques d'Amboise.
A Queens native, Mr. Ardolino had never heard the term dirty dancing. When Ms. Bergstein invited him and the choreographer Kenny Ortega to her apartment to play her old 45's and demonstrate the moves, she served red wine and grabbed a startled Ortega for a steamy, impromptu performance. Mr. Ardolino was so embarrassed, he had to leave, Mr. Ortega recalled recently. But, Mr. Ortega added, "Emile had a very strong vision for the film." When the actors danced, Mr. Ardolino's camera was right in their midst.
"I really wanted the audience to feel what it was like for Baby to be in that room," Mr. Ardolino said in a 1987 interview. "It's exciting, it's sexually charged, and I certainly wanted that on the screen."
In retrospect, Ms. Bergstein said, "So much of the movie is about the inner life of dance and how it makes you feel." During auditions she wore what she calls "sleazy, tarty clothes," as she and Mr. Ortega showed the young cast members the gyrations.
But what "Dirty Dancing" is really about goes well beyond dance. Ms. Bergstein still receives letters from people describing how "Dirty Dancing" affected their lives. What people refer to again and again, she says, is the scene in "Dirty Dancing" when Baby goes to Johnny's room and says that she's afraid of walking out of the room and never feeling the same again. "I think this is the dead center of the movie," Ms. Bergstein said, "that moment in your life when you move one way or another. If you focus your heart and your spirit, you can hold your life in your arms and make it do anything."
For most people associated with "Dirty Dancing," the film was a career-defining project. " 'Dirty Dancing' was what sent my career into hyperspace," said Mr. Swayze, a classically trained dancer who had made his film debut in "Skatetown U.S.A." in 1979 and had been featured in the epic Civil War mini-series "North and South" in 1984. He went on, of course, to break even more hearts in the hit 1990 film "Ghost."
BEFORE "DIRTY DANCING," Ms. Grey was best known as the malevolent sister in "Ferris Bueller's Day Off." Afterward, she was known everywhere as Baby, and that became both a blessing and a curse for her. "I became recognizable, known and loved by so many people," she said. "I didn't look like a movie star. I had a Jewish nose. People loved seeing that."
"But I was never that character," she continued. "I was not a virgin; I hate to admit it. I also could dance. I was kind of a daddy's girl, though. The curse was that people think I was that character, and I'm not."
As sexy as "Dirty Dancing" is -- "I've had mothers from all over the world happily say, 'You're the reason my daughter lost her virginity,' " Mr. Swayze said -- earlier versions of the film had more nudity and sex. But test screenings of those versions did not go that well, Ms. Bergstein said: audiences were "a little uncomfortable." The first two times the Motion Picture Association of America panel saw it, the film was rated R, even after the nudity had been cut. "Even with the actors' clothes on, the movie aroused people, because dance is arousing," Ms. Gottlieb said.
The filmmakers also excised one profane exclamation and another line of dialogue, and on their third try, they won a PG-13 rating.
The film's sexual electricity was certainly important to its success, but today most of the principals don't believe that it was sex that made "Dirty Dancing" such a phenomenon. Mr. Swayze has a theory that he posits in this way: "The folkie Jewish girl gets the guy because of what's in her heart."
Ms. Bergstein thinks along the same lines, but phrases it in a broader way. "You can see it as a girl's fairy tale," she said. "You see a boy across the room, you get to dance with him, you get to make love with him, then you get to dance with him in front of your parents."
And, naturally, there was the music. Among a couple dozen songs, there was Otis Redding's "Love Man," Bruce Chanel's "Hey Baby" and the Contours' "Do You Love Me?" Ms. Bergstein, who wrote the script as she listened to music, sent out cassettes along with her screenplay.
Several songs were written for the movie, including the Grammy-winning "(I've Had) the Time of My Life," sung by Bill Medley and Jennifer Warnes, and "She's Like the Wind," written and performed by Mr. Swayze. In November 1987, the soundtrack surged to No. 1 on Billboard's pop-music chart, ahead of Bruce Springsteen's "Tunnel of Love" and Michael Jackson's "Bad." The first album has sold nearly 35 million copies, and "Dirty Dancing II," an album of more songs from the soundtrack, has sold 9 million; neither has been out of release.
There has long been talk of a "Dirty Dancing" sequel, with more scripts than Mr. Swayze can recall. Most unfortunate, he says, is one that has Johnny Castle working on a cruise ship. To Mr. Swayze's mind, that and other proposed ideas "miss the boat entirely."
"Now that Emile's dead," he said, "we would have to do something that could touch people in a new way."
Ms. Grey said of a sequel, "I would love to do one, but only if it made sense."
Nobody has any idea how the re-release will fare. But then, 10 years ago, nobody had any notion that they had a major hit on their hands. "With the re-release," Mr. Swayze said, "I wonder again, Do you think it really could do anything at the box office?"

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Elizabeth, Once Retail Wasteland, to Get Huge Mall

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
ONCE a retail no man's land, the northeastern corner of Elizabeth will by the turn of the century get a large mall that will be a neighbor to what will by then be an expanded existing shopping center anchored by Ikea, the Swedish home-furnishings chain.
When the projects are completed, the area will have more than 2 million square feet of retail, entertainment and hotel space, including the expanded center, covering more than 200 acres of former industrial land and a municipal landfill. 
 "These projects have all the makings to turn the area into a retail metropolis," said Donald E. Goncalves, a Union County Freeholder as well as project coordinator at the Elizabeth Economic Development Corporation.
The private, nonprofit organization helps the city in its development efforts.
Ikea was the first to prove the area's retail potential. It opened a 268,244-square-foot store on 21 acres there in 1990, betting that the site's visibility from and access to Exit 13A of the New Jersey Turnpike, along with its proximity to Newark International Airport, would pay off.
It did. The store draws more than two million visitors a year.
Since then, Ikea has bought 25 acres of adjacent land and built 285,000 more square feet of space, which was leased to retailers that complement its store. The complex, called Elizabeth Center, also contains a 100,000-square-foot building occupied by a Toys "R" Us Kids World.
Another building, with 185,000 square feet, housed an Incredible Universe store until last April built by the Tandy Corporation, parent of Radio Shack. The space is now being marketed.
Earlier this month, Ikea acquired a 38-acre parcel, of which 12 are developable, with the intention of increasing its store by 80,000 square feet and Elizabeth Center by up to 250,000 square feet, possibly including a multiscreen movie theater and a hotel. With the $55 million expansion, the center will sit on 58 acres and have more than 800,000 square feet of space.
Ikea purchased the latest parcel, as it did the earlier ones, from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The bistate agency took control of the entire 96-acre industrial site, once a municipal landfill, in 1981 and planned to develop an industrial park there. The remaining 12-acre parcel is dedicated to that use.
Next month, construction is to begin on a 1.2-million-square-foot mall just south of Elizabeth Center on some 110 acres near Newark Bay that also was a municipal landfill until 1972.
The project, called New Jersey Metromall and conceived three years ago, also has a new lead developer, the Glimcher Realty Trust of Columbus, Ohio, a national mall developer.
Glimcher, which became a real estate investment trust in 1994, reached a development agreement with the City of Elizabeth that was approved in June to build the $215 million mall.
An affiliate of the Southern California and Arizona Glaziers, Architectural Metal and Glass Workers Pension Plan -- which worked with the original land developer, OENJ Corporation of Elizabeth, to get the project to this point -- remains a limited partner in the venture.
All the necessary state and local approvals are in place and the environmental cleanup should be completed by next month. OENJ, which started in 1992 to redevelop the site, has sold its interest in the mall project.
But the company still owns 40 acres along the Newark Bay that it will develop, possibly with a marina, hotel and restaurants, among other uses, said Peter Aagaard, a principal.
Supporting the area's transformation, officials said, is the fact the projects sit within Elizabeth's Urban Enterprise Zone. Businesses in the zone get tax benefits and retailers can charge a 3 percent sales tax, instead of the normal 6 percent.
FOR Elizabeth, which missed the economic growth that took place in other urban areas during the mid-80's, the projects are good news.
"Elizabeth sat idly by in the 80's, but now it's our turn," Mayor J. Christian Bollwage said. The projects have already begun to spur other investment, he said, pointing out that 23 market-rate two-family homes have gone into construction near the retail projects in a neighborhood that has not seen such development in the past.
The retail projects will also bring jobs and tax revenue into the city. The mall alone is expected to create 1,600 construction jobs and 5,200 permanent jobs, as well as $4.6 million in annual tax revenue.
Each of the projects is moving ahead when New Jersey's economy is improving and the retail market is healthy, said Ted Kraus, who heads TKO Real Estate Advisory Group, a retail consulting firm in Mercerville. Rental rates have inched up, and the overall retail vacancy rate in the state is less than 5 percent, he said, cautioning, however, that with retailers continuing to open new stores there was the potential of a glut should the economy sour.
Mr. Kraus is optimistic about the Elizabeth projects. He cited the presence of Ikea as a huge anchor in a now proven location and the addition of Glimcher as a strong developer for the mall.
"They will have to work not to make the projects work," he said. "The biggest problem is traffic."
But road improvements to the Ikea site, on Center Drive and North Avenue, have been made to accommodate the expansion. Additionally, about $100 million in traffic improvements -- from ramps to an elevated roadway -- are to be made to link the mall site, off Kapkowski Road, to Exit 13A of the turnpike. Financing for that work will come primarily from the sale of taxable and tax-exempt bonds by the semi-autonomous New Jersey Economic Development Authority.
The bonds will be repaid through $8 million in annual payments in lieu of taxes the mall site is expected to generate, $53 million in equity from the developer and a special franchise fee on tenants who locate there. The bonds are expected to be sold by early this fall, when construction on the improvements will begin.
Work is under way on the expansion of the Ikea store and is to be completed in the fall of 1998, said Roy Perez-Daple, president of Ikea Center Urban Renewal Inc., the development arm of the international retailer, which is based in Denmark.
Mr. Perez-Daple said construction also would start next August on the 250,000 square feet of space planned for Elizabeth Center. He said plans called for three or four stores, with 35,000 to 40,000 square feet each, or smaller shops plus the movie theater and hotel.
"The idea," he said, "is to make the center a natural place to shop where people want to stay for longer periods of time and come back more often."
Mr. Perez-Daple said the Metromall project, which he believes will complement Elizabeth Center, would enhance that concept and increase the appeal of the region as a shopping destination.
 HERBERT GLIMCHER, chairman of Glimcher Realty Trust, said that the New Jersey Metromall was being designed as a fashion- and value-oriented outlet center with a strong entertainment component, including a movie theater. The company became involved in the project because the site was in a prime location in a densely populated area within the New York metropolitan region, Mr. Glimcher said. Some 63 million cars are said to pass the site each year.
Glimcher Realty Trust has a $1 billion line of credit for various projects, including New Jersey Metromall, with Nomura Capital Asset Management in New York.
When it opens in 1999, the mall as now envisioned will include 12 anchors and up to 200 smaller stores. Mr. Glimcher said leases had been signed with all the anchor stores, but declined to identify them.

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
A Renaissance, One Blossom at a Time

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
FANCY new road signs at the borders proclaim that you have just entered Newark: "Renaissance City." Frankly, this Renaissance allusion puzzles me, given the gap-toothed leer of junk-strewn lots and the fool's-gold flash of broken windshield glass that greet the eye.
A Newark-basher might crack that this Renaissance notion could only be an inside municipal joke, alluding to the fact that while schools wither and city officials are led from office with raincoats over handcuffed wrists, some City Council members are behaving like the Renaissance Medicis, in that they have commissioned artists to paint their portraits, to hang in the gallery among the generations of greats who preceded them in helping make Newark the city it is today. 
 But let's look beyond that. Let's note, for starters, that Newark still maintains a fine public library staffed by people who care about books and carry history in their heads. It should also be noted that that there are few Gothic cathedrals in America more beautiful than Newark's Sacred Heart. To see it in winter, with snow sifting through light off its great stone towers, or in spring, with a lake of cherry blossoms at its feet, is to think more kindly about Newark, butt of jokes, repository of so much that has gone utterly wrong with our cities, from within and without.
Because here and there, 30 years after the awful riots that burned so much hope and dignity out of Newark, a sonata sometimes does waft above the din. Sometimes, beauty and boldness manage to transcend the gloom. Here and there, flowers bloom.
This is a small account of one otherwise insignificant place: an acre of vacant land on which arsonists torched two houses many years ago on Halleck Street, just north of Broadway. A place where the word renaissance is not a joke, but a breath of life that comes out of rubble.
It's only an urban garden that some determined neighbors and schoolchildren brought to life from a dirty, junk-filled lot that had been used as an illegal dump site near their homes. It is one of many such gardens now blossoming on formerly vacant city lots, thanks to gardening experts who work with a Rutgers University urban program to supply the expertise. But some say the Halleck Street experiment is the among the finest. And attention should be paid.
On a hot Saturday morning in late summer, Nazly Lopez, who lives next door to this lot that neighbors now rent from the city for $1 a year, wiped her hands and showed a visitor the abundance that flourished in beds, clumps, rows and mounds at the feet of a small crowd of urban farmers. "Here we have three kinds of lettuce: iceberg, romaine and butternut," she said. "We have broccoli. There's four kinds of tomatoes. Hot peppers and regular peppers. Eggplant, watermelon, cantaloupe, sweet potatoes . . . "
"And corn," put in her daughter, Christina, 19, who was in charge of the corn patch, which she tends like a rose garden.
"Don't forget the flowers," added her husband, Carlos, a Newark illegal-dumping officer who cruises the city and works his sources like a modern Eliot Ness, tracking down people, many of them out-of-towners whose contempt for Newark is such that they regard it as a literal dump to dispose of household or industrial debris.
A firm believer that a lot strewn with debris causes neighborhood indifference toward crime, Mr. Lopez got the ball rolling. He and his neighbors pulled the land into shape, hauling out an amazing collection of junk, leveling the ground, cadging lawn mowers and supplies from local stores, and installing work tables, a hammock, some playground equipment, lights, an old drum barbecue, and a sound system that softly throbs with salsa music while the tomatoes redden in the sun and the mums and pansies blaze in weedless beds.
Mrs. Lopez and Elena Zanzo, both teachers at nearby Broadway Elementary School, enlisted 25 second- and third-graders as apprentice farmers. Skeptically, they planted seed. As they came back week by week, sprouts soon poked from the ground. The lesson, Mrs. Lopez explained, was that persistence, taking one firm step after another, brings results, in a garden and in life.
"Before, when you asked them where a tomato comes from, they said Pathmark," she said. "They never saw anything grow before and really didn't believe it would work. When things did come up, you could see in their faces a realization -- an accomplishment."
Her husband wiped his brow and brushed past a stuffed scarecrow that had a sign around its neck saying: "Just one person makes a difference." A little sheepishly, he said, "I never liked to get my fingernails dirty before."

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:

Heart in White Plains?
What do White Plains and San Francisco have in common? Plenty, according to a survey of 145 cities. 
 In terms of cost of living for a businessman, the Corporate Resources Group of Geneva placed the City of a Thousand Stores almost on a par with San Francisco.
Comparing food, clothing, beverages, household supplies and equipment, personal care, automobiles, leisure and entertainment and housing costs, the two cities are similar, with White Plains ranking as the 75th most expensive in the United States and San Francisco as the 71st.
Rehan Mustafa, an analyst for the consultants, said the two cities were almost identical when the costs of home services, like cleaning and baby-sitting, are compared. The cost of housing in San Francisco, however, was much higher.
Comparing costs in cities throughout the world, the survey found that White Plains and Nairobi, Kenya, were the same -- just after Guatemala City.
Tokyo topped the list as the most expensive city, with Hong Kong, Moscow and Osaka close behind.
New York City ranked 31st -- up from 38th six months ago. Elsewhere in United States and Canada, low inflation and no exchange rate variation resulted in North American cities remaining steady and among the most affordable.
 
Not Judge O'Rourke Yet
The State Assembly earlier this month pushed aside Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to create 14 new judgeships -- on the surface thwarting County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's most recent chance for a career move. But there is still hope, according to the latest word out of Albany.
The State Senate approved the measure, but the Assembly chose not to vote on it at the close of the Legislative session early this month. But as Charles Carrier, a spokesman for State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, said, "It ain't over, as they say."
Mr. Carrier added: "There is still time to do this. It's under discussion."
Mr. O'Rourke, who has decided not to run again for County Executive after 15 years in office, acknowledged in an interview last spring that he was stepping down, in part, because he wanted to be a judge.
It has been an elusive goal for the Republican politician. In 1991, Mr. O'Rourke was nominated by President Bush for a seat in Federal District Court in Manhattan, but the nomination stalled in the Senate as Democrats sensed a Presidential victory by Bill Clinton. In 1993, the nomination was revived by Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, but Mr. O'Rourke, at his party's urging, said he would run once again for County Executive.
 
Sex-Abuse Acquittal
Randall Forrest, a former dean at Woodlands High School in Greenburgh, has been acquitted of sexually abusing a 17-year-old student. In a non-jury trial, Justice Harold Klein of Greenburgh Town Court ruled earlier this month that there was insubstantial evidence to convict the former high school administrator.
Mr. Forrest, a well-respected educator who had been with the district for 24 years and who was in charge of disciplining students, was charged in February 1996 with molesting the female student and threatening to suspend her if she did not comply with his sexual demands. The student had allegedly been sent to Mr. Forrest's office for cutting classes.
John Mangialardi, Mr. Forrest's lawyer, said after Mr. Forrest was arrested that he was the victim of "unsubstantiated allegations by an unhappy student."
The plaintiff had twice tried to tape record the dean, but the pause button was on the first time and voices were muffled the second time because the recorder was in her purse, the court was told.
Mr. Forrest of New Rochelle is the father of two grown children and is also a grandfather. He was reassigned to another job after his arrest. He retired seven months ago.
 
Gun License Law
Under a measure approved by the State Legislature this month, owners of pistols and revolvers in Westchester must renew their permits every five years, and new handgun owners must take a safety course.
"Car owners have to re-register, so why not gun owners," said State Assemblyman James G. Pretlow, who sponsored the measure. And he said that drivers also have to pass a competency exam to qualify for a license.
Under the current permit system, owners are issued licenses for life. Mr. Pretlow said that because there are no renewal requirements, the County Clerk's office does not know which gun owners have moved away or died.
Last year's murder of Michael Frey, an Eastchester policeman, by a gunman was in part responsible for Mr. Pretlow's most recent efforts on behalf of the permit-renewal law, even though the sniper used a rifle.
If the bill is signed by Gov. George E. Pataki, Westchester will join New York City and Suffolk and Nassau Counties in mandating permit renewals. Currently, such laws are passed on a county-by-county basis.
 
Patrick McNeill Fund
The parents of Patrick J. McNeill, the Fordham University student who was found dead in the East River on April 7, have established a scholarship fund to help college-bound students from Port Chester High School, especially those planning to major in criminal justice.
The fund, supported by individual donors, families, municipal employees and service clubs, is being administered by the nonprofit Westchester Community Foundation in White Plains.
The student, who was nearing his 21st birthday, was last seen alive on Feb. 16, leaving the Dapper Dog bar in Manhattan, where he had gone with friends. He was a junior at Fordham, studying accounting. He grew up in Port Chester, the second of three children, and was captain of the Port Chester High School football team.
"Patrick's values and aspirations and our appreciation for the community can and will continue through this fund to help other young people's lives," said Patrick McNeill Sr., a Highway Department foreman for the village of Rye Brook, who organized teams to knock on doors, visit shops, stop in hospitals and check out subway stations and homeless shelters in an effort to find his son.
Tax-deductible donations may be sent to the Westchester Community Foundation/Patrick McNeill Scholarship, 470 Mamaroneck Avenue, Suite 304, White Plains, New York, N.Y. 10605.
The number to call for more information is 948-5166. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: GALLERY;
Two Sides of One Mind: Works in Wood and on Paper

 BODY:
STUDIES . . . consistently show that young women receive higher average grades than young men in every subject area in high school and college, but lower average S.A.T. scores by approximately 60 points. The S.A.T. has only one major purpose -- the prediction of first-year college grades. . . .
Although the score gap between the sexes has been called a "slight underprediction" by the test publisher, it limits women's educational opportunities in three important ways. By underpredicting their academic performance, the S.A.T. affects their chances to gain entrance to nearly 1,600 colleges and universities which require S.A.T. scores or use them as cut-off scores. Unfairly low test scores also become a self-fulfilling prophecy, causing young women to lower their expectations and apply to less competitive colleges and universities than their grades would warrant. . . . 
 Lower test scores also exclude high school girls from academic enrichment programs and accelerated courses where S.A.T. scores determine admissions. . . .
Using biased tests has a severe economic impact on women who lose millions of dollars in merit scholarship awards. . . . The National Merit Scholarship Corporation, which offers the most prestigious awards for academic excellence, selects its semifinalists solely on the basis of P.S.A.T. scores, which have a gender gap similar to the S.A.T. In 1989, only 32 percent of the National Merit semifinalists were women.
All these factors contribute to a real dollar loss for women in later life as they get less prestigious jobs, earn less money and have fewer leadership opportunities. Of course, their loss of self-confidence cannot be measured in financial terms.
-- From Phyllis Rosser's introduction to "The Young Women's Guide to Better S.A.T. Scores: Fighting the Gender Gap," by Kathleen Kelly-Benjamin (Bantam, 1990)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
Floating Hospital Is at Sea in the Search for a Pier

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
The Floating Hospital is a New York institution that has provided the city's poor and sick with medical and dental treatment as well as sunshine and fresh air for 130 years. It is also an institution with a problem: Facing eviction from its East River berth, it has nowhere to go.
Moored at Pier 11, just below Wall Street, the barge Lila Acheson Wallace is the fifth vessel to be called the Floating Hospital. Despite its name, it is actually an outpatient center, offering health care and other services to roughly 15,000 poor and homeless people annually, on the boat and at outreach centers, said its executive director, Kathleen Lopez. Every summer Friday, the Wallace, which has no engine, is pulled by a tugboat around New York Harbor, a respite for needy families from the city's heat. 
 But Pier 11, structurally unsound, is soon to be demolished by the city and rebuilt as a commercial ferry site. The barge has to move, and its choices are limited. On the West Side, the Hudson River Park Conservancy has identified Pier 54, at West 12th Street, as a possibility, but that would require approval from Community Board 2, which could take years. And Ms. Lopez said the hospital, with a $2.8 million annual budget, cannot afford to install electricity there.
While the hospital might return to Pier 84, at 44th Street, where it was docked in the 1980's, Ms. Lopez said that location is too crowded. She prefers that the barge remain right where it is. "I'd love to stay at Pier 11," she said. "It's like home." Many of its major supporters, like the New York Stock Exchange, are nearby.
A spokeswoman for the city's Economic Development Corporation, Bernadette O'Leary, said her agency is "making every effort to find a suitable spot for this very important facility," but she would not guarantee its return to the rebuilt Pier 11.
So Ms. Lopez keeps looking, and hoping.As do clients like Marie Ocasio, 35, of Flushing, Queens, who went to the Floating Hospital after she took 10 nieces and nephews into foster care. Now she calls the barge her "second home." The children, she said, had been neglected by their parents and needed extensive medical and psychological help, which the hospital provided. Ms. Ocasio could not be more grateful and dreams of becoming "a rich woman, so I can give the hospital everything it needs." Perhaps even a pier of its own. BERNARD STAMLER

GRAPHIC: Photos. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "TIMELINE: All Aboard for Aid"
Major moments in the Floating Hospital's history:
 
1866 -- First cruise, sponsored by editors of The New York Times for newsboys living in Lower Manhattan slums.
 
1875 -- Barge "Emma Abbot," is launched as the Floating Hospital by St. John's Guild, a nonsectarian charity. It is the first pediatric hospital in the city.
 
1889 -- "Helen C. Juilliard" replaces "Emma Abbot," after nearly a million mothers and children have sailed on the Abbot.
 
1997 -- Hospital has served more than 5.5 million people. It provides medical and dental treatment, summer sails, and aid to the homeless and domestic volunteer victims.
 
Source: Floating Hospital

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Labor Showdowns: The Effect on Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THE United Parcel Service is a private enterprise, but the strike there may lead some investors to wonder whether any public companies might also soon square off with labor -- and if so, what such disputes might do to their stocks.
There is no way to predict the future, of course, but after looking at the calendar of companies' contract negotiations with organized labor, economists and other analysts say that another serious strike is highly unlikely for at least the remainder of the year. 
 Although some labor contracts remain to be negotiated this fall -- a number of airlines have to come to terms with machinist and pilot unions, for example -- most private-sector collective bargaining has already been done. Further, 1997 was not a very active year: the U.P.S. contract, which covers more than 180,000 workers, is by far the largest.
And a number of heavily unionized industries, including steel, automobiles and railroads, are under contracts that run for another two to three years.
Still, as U.P.S. and representatives of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters ended the week with a marathon negotiation session, the dispute has given organized labor an issue that resonates with the American public: the plight of part-time workers. And the strike, involving more workers than the 156,000 who walked off their jobs at AT&T in 1986, has raised a threat in the minds of the investing public for the first time in years, if not decades.
"For the most part, private-sector investors haven't had to pay much attention, because organized labor's strength has been declining for the past 25 years," said Lawrence Katz, an economist at Harvard University and a former chief economist at the United States Department of Labor.
Last year, according to Labor Department data, private industry employed 9.4 million unionized workers, just over 10 percent of the nation's work force.
"Increasingly, it is state and local governments that are unionized, not the private work force," said David Wyss, director of research at DRI/ McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting service.
Nevertheless, contract negotiations "are always something to worry about," Mr. Wyss added.
"Currently, with labor markets so tight, the questions have more to do with what the agreements will contribute to wage pressures, not other union concerns," he said.
WHATEVER the general outlook for labor disputes, what about the specific issues in the U.P.S. strike? Analysts said the two major bones of contention -- the company's desire to leave the teamsters' multi-employer pension plan and the teamsters' goal of converting 10,000 part-time positions to full-time ones -- were not likely to loom large in other labor negotiations.
"Many of the aspects of the U.P.S. strike are not going to be replicated elsewhere," Mr. Katz said. "Most companies are not involved in multi-employer pension plans, for example."
Representatives from organized labor disagree that the concerns are specific to U.P.S. And according to Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University, the unions have scored public relations points by highlighting the issue of part-time workers at the delivery service.
"Labor is getting some good press," he said, "and that could bolster their resolve in upcoming negotiations."
But as a practical matter, Mr. Ratajczak said, the issue of part-time workers is likely to be limited. "In general, unions are active in industries that have been shrinking their work forces, which means they have to protect those who are full-time employees," he said. Moreover, much of the growth in part-time work has been in industries that are not unionized, like high technology.
Thomas A. Kochan, a professor of industrial relations at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management, said the symbolism of the part-time employment issue may be what is important.
"Workers and managers are learning from the public's reaction to the part-time issue that this is a source of tension," he said. "I think we will see companies begin to take another look at that issue, and ask themselves if they have as much to worry about in terms of a negative reaction, whether the workers are unionized or not."
And Deborah Dion, a spokeswoman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., made it plain that organized labor plans to push the issue further.
"We do not speak just for the union member," she said. "The part-time work issue will be a big one for us, regardless of whether our members are full-time or not."
In addition, Ms. Dion said, the A.F.L.-C.I.O, which has 78 affiliate unions and 13.1 million members, many in state and local government, plans to fight against any erosion in health care benefits, to "hold the line" on pensions, and to fight for what she characterized as "decent" wages.
IF push comes to shove on any of those -- or on any other -- issues and a labor strike ensues, the effect on a stock price can be hard to forecast.
In 1986, for example, AT&T's shares rose modestly during the communications workers' strike.
And since Aug. 1, the last day of trading before U.P.S. workers walked off the job, the price of Federal Express stock has increased less than 4 percent, to $65.3125 at Friday's close, despite a huge increase in the competing delivery company's business.
"A strike is not going to cause a company's stock price to plunge," said Laszlo Birinyi, who runs his own stock market advisory firm. "Nor is a settlement necessarily going to be a plus. Issues like strikes, and sales or purchases of shares by management, are way down the list in determining a stock's value."
But Byron Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said investors should be concerned about the impact a U.P.S. settlement might have on wage costs throughout the private sector.
"Since the recession ended in 1991, management has gotten a disproportionate share of profit growth, because workers have been concerned about job protection," he said. "Markets have been looking for signs of higher inflation, and since labor represents about 70 percent of manufacturing costs, the importance of this strike will be if it is the first in a series of efforts by labor to be better compensated."

PUB-DATE: August 17, 1997

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3331 words

HEADLINE: The King of Posh

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
IF he were the head of an American company, many business school students would aspire to be him. As it stands, many of them probably do not even know his name.
Still fewer are familiar with the complex stories of how Bernard Arnault took control of an international chain of luxury goods stores, cowing his rivals in the process; got in the way of a merger of two British beverage giants; inserted himself into an ugly family battle for the heart of France's wine legacy, and weighed in on whether feathers and fake blood were proper ingredients in haute couture. 
 And that was just this year.
Mr. Arnault is the chief executive of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the largest luxury products company in the world. Its brands range from Christian Dior to Moet & Chandon, from Louis Vuitton to Veuve Clicquot, to name just a few units of the $6 billion company.
As conversant in complicated balance-sheet maneuvers as he is in the nuances of French fashion, Mr. Arnault, 48, has built his business largely by mastering two worlds that few executives straddle comfortably. There are the products -- and all the silk, scents, celebrities and advertising that go into them -- and then there are the hardball negotiations that make the products his.
Consider the tie test.
When interviewing prospective LVMH executives, Mr. Arnault takes the candidates into a room with 100 neckties, some of them Dior, some of them from competitors -- some of them, at least in Mr. Arnault's opinion, downright gauche. They are told to choose 10.
"It is very interesting," Mr. Arnault said. "Some choose 10 ties that are really the worst. If he does that, then we move on to the scarves. If he is bad with the scarves, well, then he is really in a difficult position."
Should bad taste in neckwear really count against a man brought in to, say, crunch numbers for a multinational corporation? "It is like when you send someone to listen to a concerto and they don't feel anything," said Mr. Arnault, whose mother was a concert pianist and who still practices Chopin himself. "It is as if they can't tell the difference between the Berlin Philharmonic and the orchestra of Columbus, Ohio."
Given the juicy names in his portfolio and the controversial ways he acquired many of them -- his current attempt to out-duel Guinness and Grand Met in reshaping Europe's liquor industry is only his latest obdurate move -- the fact that Mr. Arnault is largely unknown in the United States reflects just how differently the French and Americans view their business elite.
In the United States, Bill Gates manages in certain circles to exude the sex appeal of, say, Brad Pitt, simply by virtue of his fat bank account and financial acumen. But in France, Catholic and Socialist tradition are the odd bedfellows that have joined in fostering disdain for the business class. And Mr. Arnault's hardball ways are particularly out of keeping with French hauteur, which has contributed -- along with decades of Government micro-meddling in industry -- to France's sluggish growth, high unemployment and squeamish participation in a globalizing economy. Only slowly are the French coming around to his ways.
"For a European, I have a U.S. approach," Mr. Arnault said in a recent interview -- one he resisted for several weeks. "That is, I face reality as it is and not as I would like it to be. I build for the long term."
Between his many acquisitions over the years and his recent overhauls of the French fashion houses of Christian Dior and Givenchy, Mr. Arnault has built himself into one of the most formidable forces in the world of luxury, a business that draws the lusting attentions of people across many slices of society.
The headline-grabbing bankruptcy of Barney's Inc., the crush of Japanese tourists searching Hong Kong for Gucci lug-soled shoes, the obsession with what celebrities wear to the Academy Awards and the cottage industry built around knocking off anything brand-named -- no matter how objectively unattractive the product -- all this underscores one thing: the toys of the rich fascinate. And they have made Mr. Arnault a very wealthy man.
In the last 13 years, he has built an empire out of companies he pried, for the most part, from the resistant grasps of others, one by one. But now has picked one of its most audacious fights, against bigger and tougher foes. This time, the furor is over Mr. Arnault's efforts to pare down his holdings in alcoholic beverages, LVMH's slowest-growing product line, rather than to add to his stable.
WHILE LVMH's liquor brands are patently luxurious -- names like Veuve Clicquot Champagne and Hennessy Cognac have graced honeymoons and power lunches for decades -- they are not nearly as profitable as bottles of perfume, which are cheaper to make and distribute.
Nor do they have as much potential for growth. The company's liquor sales shrank by 13 percent from 1992 to 1996, while sales of perfume and beauty products skyrocketed 65 percent and sales of luggage and leather goods almost doubled. The trend is continuing this year. Although LVMH's sales rose 55.4 percent in the quarter that ended on June 30, compared with the corresponding period a year earlier, those gains were largely from acquisitions and sales of leather goods; sales of Cognac and spirits, excluding Champagne, fell.
So it appears that Mr. Arnault's strategy is to tap the cash flow of his spirits business for acquiring new toys.
To meet that objective, he first must block the planned merger of two of the largest drink companies in the world, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Guinness P.L.C., which in May announced their intent to combine into a $19 billion wine and spirits giant. Mr. Arnault, who has longstanding joint ventures with Guinness and is a shareholder in both companies, has no intention of letting the two marry and leave him at the altar, a lesser competitor.
What Mr. Arnault proposes instead is that Guinness, Grand Met and LVMH merge their drink businesses, with Grand Met spinning off its food entities -- including Burger King and Pillsbury -- and Guinness doing the same with its breweries. He would hold a 35 percent stake in the three-way merged company (which he refers to as Drinksco), in one stroke becoming a leading shareholder in the world's largest spirits company, eliminating some of his most fearsome competitors and removing the liquor monkey from LVMH's back.
"This is an investment he has had for a considerable time, and I suspect this particular one is closer to the end game," Mark Francis, a managing director in New York for UBS Securities, said of Mr. Arnault's liquor holdings. "Under this proposal, he will have a smaller investment in a much stronger and larger company, and have an elegant exit. Meanwhile, he is investing in other things."
So far, Guinness and Grand Met have officially told Mr. Arnault to buzz off, but the battle is far from over. Mr. Arnault has increased his holdings in Grand Met to 11.1 percent and decreased his position in Guinness to 11.47 percent -- enough to give him the 10 percent stake needed to call a special shareholder meeting in each company. He has also resigned from the Guinness board, threatened to end his many joint ventures with the brewer and begun lobbying Guinness and Grand Met institutional investors in London to look at the cost savings he says will follow from doing things his way.
In a recent telephone interview from the south of France, where he has holed up with his fax machine for August, Mr. Arnault stated his plans for LVMH in blunt, if broad, terms.
"We will have more brands five years from now," he said. "Luxury products, obviously, and also in the area of the distribution of luxury products."
And liquor? "I do not think you can get the same type of growth in wine and spirits that you can get in the luxury products," Mr. Arnault said. "But they have a good cash flow, and they give us stability in earnings." While luxury goods and fashion are growing faster, he said, they "are also a little bit more risky."
Many analysts question Mr. Arnault's ability to pull off the liquor merger. But all agree that he is unaccustomed to losing.
Mr. Arnault grew up in Roubaix, in northern France, where his family owned a construction company. He learned business at the knee of his grandfather and his father, but his passions were reserved for design and the arts.
"I have always been very interested in creativity," he said. "Even when I was working in construction, what I liked was to work with architects. I have always liked very much creators, and in luxury you are in a sense working with artists, those who have the capacity to transform creative ideas in reality."
Like many French business people, Mr. Arnault left France in the early 1980's, as the Socialist administration of President Francois Mitterrand came to power. In 1984, after a four-year year stint in New York running a real estate concern, Mr. Arnault returned to France. There, he soon brought one company after another under his hegemony, often by means similar to that of the snake in "The Little Prince" of Saint-Exupery: He charmed, seduced and, eventually, took a fatal bite.
With $15 million of his own cash, raised mostly through his real estate ventures, Mr. Arnault hooked up with Antoine Bernheim, a managing partner of the French bank Lazard Freres, to create the $80 million purse needed to buy Boussac, a bankrupt textile company.
(His relationship with Lazard may be cooling, some analysts surmise: the French bank is now representing Guinness in the merger with Grand Met.)
Although Mr. Arnault pledged to revive the ailing Boussac and keep its employees working, he ended up dismissing 9,000 workers and eventually unloaded its diaper and textile units. He retained the Boussac fashion house, Christian Dior, which lost money but which possessed Mr. Arnault's favorite quality: a name known around the world.
The next victim was Henri Racamier, then the chairman of LVMH. Mr. Racamier had invited Mr. Arnault to invest heavily in LVMH in 1987, largely as a way to get rid of a partner who ran the beverage side of the business.
Investing through a joint venture with Guinness, Mr. Arnault indeed disposed of the partner. But after accumulating a majority stake by exercising previously purchased warrants -- a first glimpse at his creative financing, which was unsuccessfully challenged in court -- Mr. Arnault got rid of Mr. Racamier, too.
That was a bitter blow to the man who had turned Louis Vuitton from a small family business into an international brand. In fact, many of Mr. Racamier's principles were adopted by Mr. Arnault for LVMH's growth: Keep products exclusive. Tap Asian markets, with their wealthy consumers. And never become No. 2.
Those rules guided Mr. Arnault as he swept up companies that had clear synergies with LVMH: the fashion houses of Christian Lacroix, Givenchy and Kenzo; the leather goods companies Loewe, Celine and Berluti; the jewelry company Fred Joailler; and retailers of luxury goods like DFS Group, the world's biggest duty-free chain, and Sephora, a recently acquired French chain of perfume stores. The retailers hawk his perfumes; his fashion companies share production and distribution facilities.
He finds financial synergies, too. Analysts say Mr. Arnault has created several holding companies for the brands and has floated debt and equity alike off various units to fuel the interests of others.
DIVIDING and conquering is not his favorite mode of business, Mr. Arnault said, but it is clear that he is willing to resort to it.
Last spring, he acquired a majority share of San Francisco-based DFS against the furious and litigious opposition of two of the four owners -- Anthony M. Pilaro, an American lawyer, and the flamboyant financier Robert W. Miller. The two men's partners wanted to sell out; they didn't, and they lost. Mr. Miller still holds more than 38 percent of the company.
Not missing a beat, Mr. Arnault recently took up with one set of feuding cousins divided over the fortunes of Chateau d'Y'quem, perhaps France's finest maker of white wines. While family members argued and literally came to blows over the future of the business, Mr. Arnault acquired the majority position in the company. That acquisition is now tied up in court.
Elegant perfumes, supple leather handbags, expensive gowns that are worn but once -- this is the stuff that thrills Mr. Arnault. He is deeply interested in how such goods are packaged and advertised, and where and how they are sold. While his divisional presidents are all quick to commend Mr. Arnault for granting them autonomy, it is clear that he is also a keen observer of the minutiae.
Robert L. Brady, the president of LVMH's Parfums Givenchy U.S.A., recalled a recent trip Mr. Arnault made to New York. The two men visited the cosmetics section of a store that Mr. Arnault had seen six months earlier.
"He looked at the space and location that my company had in this store, and then looked at a sister company's space and location," Mr. Brady said. "He immediately recognized that we had picked up more space and the sister company had not. I mean, it was a matter of feet.
"To me that was incredible," Mr. Brady added. "This man is all over the world and only visits periodically, is not engaged on a daily basis, but he recognized something that was very subtle."
Mr. Arnault's acumen is not perfect. Some people close to LVMH recall that Mr. Arnault took a hard look at Gucci before Investcorp, a Bahraini investment bank, began acquiring it in stages in 1991. "Arnault did tons of due diligence," one person close to the situation said. " But he backed off. He said the brand would never go anywhere."
Oops. Gucci brought in the American designer Tom Ford to freshen its image. Distribution was severely rolled back to restore the brand's exclusivity. Investcorp took the company public at $22 a share in October 1995, and made a bundle in a secondary offering in March 1996; it closed on Friday at $59.75.
Mr. Arnault said he did not want to comment on Gucci, but it is clear that he followed a brand restoration similar to Investcorp's with Christian Dior, Givenchy and Louis Vuitton.
Last year, for example, French runway-watchers wilted into their fluttering fans as Mr. Arnault installed Alexander McQueen -- a 27-year-old British designer celebrated as much for design tricks like striping jackets and shirts red to resemble bloodstains as for his fine cutting abilities -- at Givenchy's helm.
Dior was placed in the hands of John Galliano, another Briton, who once stood up the Queen for dinner and whose eccentric designs -- and personal eccentricities -- are a far cry from the stuffy traditions of French fashion.
And Mr. Arnault has enlisted yet another foreigner -- the American sportswear designer Marc Jacobs -- to create Louis Vuitton's first ready-to-wear collection.
Vogue's editor in chief, Anna Wintour, said of Mr. Arnault: "He is backing designers from everywhere, and God knows he is a force to be reckoned with. He has taken the most incredible risks in the designers he hired for what were very conservative houses. And he has brilliantly understood the power of their magnetism with the press."
But Mr. Arnault, a slight man who wears fine suits but will never be the subject of a men's fashion spread, wants no part of the press crush for himself. He attends fashion shows, but sits quietly, inviting the paparazzi to focus elsewhere. While he has homes in St.-Tropez and one of the best neighborhoods in Paris, he does not offer celebrity-encrusted parties. In photographs, he often appears grim and slightly unnerved.
"I like the attention on my products, not on me," Mr. Arnault said. Indeed, he seems to understand that getting Nicole Kidman into a Dior dress is as crucial, in its way, to his company's success as successfully bringing off the most complicated convertible bond offering.
"What is very important is the image of our brands," Mr. Arnault said. "Our products are about making people dream. We take it really seriously."
AMONG the places Mr. Arnault has taken those dreams is Asia, where he has heavily marketed his spirits businesses for years. In 1996, LVMH bought Celine, the French leather goods company, in part because he was impressed with the locations of its stores in Japan. Growth plans for Sephora, too, in large part focus on the Pacific Rim.
In all this, he has been a pioneer among French executives. "More and more the French are trying to get to Asia, but they still have a pathetically small presence there," said Paul Horne, chief international economist in Paris for Smith Barney. "It is a long way away, and they don't speak French there."
Mr. Arnault's role as renegade entrepreneur has its contradictions. He has breathed life into French luxury brands, but installs etrangers to manage many of them. He raids American-style, but he hews to the French executive's way of life, in which the arts and leisure are as important as business.
"He is 100 percent capitalist in a country that has never accepted capitalism," said one person who worked for several years with Mr. Arnault in Paris and spoke on the condition of anonymity. "And he has rubbed everybody in the wrong way. He comes across as guy who is torn over being nice and being awful."
Mr. Arnault's enemies have complained bitterly -- and, for the most part, not for attribution -- that he treats those who get in his way with little compassion. His divisional managers acknowledge his toughness, but say he is swift to reward good performance.
"He has always been a gentleman and courteous to me," said Mr. Brady, the perfume executive. "But I have always made my numbers. Do you think there is a correlation?
"One man's perspective on ruthlessness," he added, "is another man's perspective on efficiency."
Mr. Arnault denies that he is ruthless at all. "I don't fire people quickly," he said. "On the contrary, I try to keep my people motivated."
Most shareholders probably could care less if he is nice, as long as the stock rises.
For the last 18 months, the company's American depository receipts have hovered between the mid $40's and the mid $50's on the New York Stock Exchange. Each A.D.R. represents one-fifth of a share on the Paris Bourse; the A.D.R.'s closed on Friday at $47.25, or 17 percent below their 52-week high, as the market has punished his increased position in Grand Met. At a price-to-earnings ratio of 27, many American and European analysts agree that the securities are expensive.
LVMH faces risk on all fronts, from the softening spirits business to a slowdown in luxury sales as weakness persists in the Japanese yen. And many in the markets doubt that the menage a trois with Guinness and Grand Met will ever come to fruition: there are huge tax implications, the British companies are not likely to cotton to Mr. Arnault's big ownership stake and, so far, other big holders are not lining up behind him.
"What he has done makes no sense," complained one institutional investor, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "If he is not interested in the food business, why has he taken such an interest in Grand Met? It doesn't fit, other than he thought it would force the hand of Grand Met and Guinness. But he is appearing more like a financial operator driving a hard bargain than a man with a vision for LVMH."
Yet according to John Ford, portfolio manager and vice president of the T. Rowe Price International Stock fund, which owns LVHH shares, any move that focused LVMH on luxury products and companies that distribute them would ultimately be advantageous.
"From shareholders' perspective, the more capital they put in luxury, the better," he said. "Arnault is trying to address the returns on a lower return area, which is good news. And if he extricates himself from that area, well, that would be good news, too."

LENGTH: 854 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
As Inventories Rise, Will There Be a Ripple Effect?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LARGELY ignored in the latest blizzard of economic figures was one indicator that is notoriously hard to interpret but that by autumn could be on every investor's lips. Inventories.
After rising a hefty $64 billion in the January-to-March quarter, the Commerce Department initially estimated that inventories jumped another $67 billion during the spring. But now, because of a huge upward revision for June, inventories appear to have swelled far more, enough to raise the economy's growth rate for the quarter to perhaps 3 percent from the 2.2 percent the Government estimated at the end of July. 
 The sum "will be upped to about $95 billion, which would be a record rate of inventory accumulation" for a quarter, said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. And this, he contended, has "crucial negative implications" for the economy for the rest of 1997. Stock market implications, however, are less clear, even if he is right.
The theory is straightforward. When goods pile up excessively on store shelves -- and in warehouses and factory yards -- this costly situation must be redressed sooner or later. This, by ripple effect, means production is cut back and economic growth sags -- or even disappears.
Often, a huge stockpile "eventually sows the seeds of a slowdown," said Richard D. Rippe, senior economist at Prudential Securities.
In practice, though, it is often difficult to tell to what extent mounting inventories reflect a retrenchment by consumers or justified confidence by companies that they will be able to sell larger volumes of goods.
Or, for that matter, if inflation is in the air, inventories may rise because businesses are buying heavily before prices go up.
A significant clue, of course, is how well sales are keeping up with inventories, which now total a cool $1 trillion, or about 15 percent of the country's total annual production, including services.
By this gauge, there may be little to worry about so far. The inventory-to-sales ratio was 1.37 in June, the same as in May, and down slightly from the 1.39 that prevailed a year ago. The trouble is, this ratio -- telling how many months it would take to exhaust stockpiles at the current level of demand -- is officially designated a lagging indicator, meaning that it tends to move only after the economy does.
And some analysts suspect that production curtailments have already started. Industrial output has risen at an annual rate of just 1.6 percent over the latest three months, less than one-third the pace of the three months through April, according to the Federal Reserve.
Another clue to the meaning of rising inventories: the type of inventories involved.
In June, stockpiles of retailers and manufacturers expanded by small fractions of 1 percent while those of wholesalers, which account for about one-quarter of the total, soared 1.9 percent, the biggest advance in 15 years.
This increase may reflect a surge of imports, spurred by the strong dollar, since imported goods tend to enter the country through middlemen. Except for foreign goods that compete directly with domestic ones, such inventories have a relatively small effect on the American economy. Cars, though, are imported in vast quantities.
For the retail sector, where June's overall inventory-to-sales ratio of 1.51 was the same as in May, the only businesses with possibly overstocked shelves are clothing stores and outlets selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes. Each averaged inventory increases of eight-tenths of 1 percent for each of the latest two months.
Some observers profess little concern about the inventory growth. "I see the inventories as a transitory phenomenon," said Richard B. Berner, economist at Mellon Bank.
Or as Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers put it, noting this summer's economic rebound: "With consumers bullish and interest rates stable, individual companies may not see any signal that the aggregate inventory situation is unsustainable."
But Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch frets that these mountains of unsold goods may act as a "drag" on the economy during the balance of 1997. And some evidence, like the apparent slowing of the increase in industrial output in the second quarter, might heighten such fears.
But even if high inventories do curtail economic growth, this doesn't mean the stock market will suffer. Stock prices, a component of the index of leading indicators, traditionally have predicted the economy, not the other way around. Also, if the economy slows interest rates would likely come down, providing that inflation doesn't rise. That would be good for stocks.
Still, for those concerned about an overhang of inventories, there are certain things to do. One is to invest in industries whose output can't be stockpiled, such as banking or airlines. Another is to pay more attention to the top line of corporate reports, which shows total revenue, while keeping a close watch on the bottom line.
When a company is about to be buried by inventories, Mr. Rippe said, "the first hint is that sales disappoint."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Let's Just Close the Market On Fridays

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Maybe there was pent-up selling, just waiting for lower tax rates.
Or maybe valuation suddenly matters. 
 Or maybe only the bulls can afford to take long summer weekends, leaving the bears in charge on Fridays.
The most remarkable thing about the slide in stock prices that began a day after President Clinton signed the tax bill is that it has been accompanied by an unrelenting stream of good economic news. Is the market worried about inflation? The latest inflation reports are the best in memory. Is it worried about a recession? All the economic news looks good, but not so good that the Federal Reserve is likely to raise long-term interest rates. And bond prices actually rose last week.
Those looking for fundamental reasons for the market turmoil can point to the currency market, where the collapse of the Thai baht had roiled Asian markets this summer and increased volatility around the world. But it is not easy to explain how that has hurt American stock prices.
So why sell?
David Shulman, Salomon Brothers' chief equity strategist, points out that the latest tax cut is the largest since 1981, when capital gains taxes were also cut. And, he notes, the stock market swooned in the days after President Reagan signed that bill, falling almost 10 percent in less than a month. The performance after the signing of this year's tax bill is similar so far. Of course, there were far fewer profits available for taking in 1981, when the Dow was lower than it had been five years earlier.
This column, we note with humility, had opined that this time would be different, because even a 20 percent capital gains tax rate would not be attractive to a new crop of investors who have learned that prices can only go up, at least in the long term. Now we will see whether proof that prices can go down, at least in the short term, will stimulate selling. Or whether the public will once again buy on weakness, as it has done repeatedly in the last seven years.
The Dow's performance -- a fall of 4.2 percent in a week and 6.8 percent since the Aug. 6 peak -- badly overstates the damage that has been done so far. Just as most investors did not do as well as the Dow on the way up, few have done as badly as the Dow on the way down.
Across all American markets last week, about three stocks rose for every four that declined. Not exactly a rout. And far more stocks hit 52-week highs than reached annual lows.
The selling has been concentrated in some of the stocks that went up the most. Coca-Cola is down 19 percent from its peak, but is still selling at 36 times its historical earnings. Gillette, Friday's disaster du jour, is at 46 times earnings even though it, too, is off 19 percent from its peak. Clearly, if valuation concerns start to become important, as they have not been lately, some stocks could have a lot further to fall. But there have been earnings-related selloffs in many stocks over the last year, even as stock indexes zoomed higher and higher.
The summer Friday theory is the most attractive one, if only because there are just two more Fridays before Labor Day ends the summer vacation season. The Dow is down 201 points, or 2.5 percent, since July 4. But that is because it has slumped on five of the six Fridays in July and August, losing a cumulative 528 points on Fridays -- almost half of which came this week. Perhaps all would be well if stocks were not allowed to trade on Fridays.
