HEADLINE: The Nation;
Why Labor Feels It Can't Afford to Lose This Strike

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
FOR years American workers have grumbled about downsizing, the rise in part-time and temporary jobs, and the trend toward businesses offering fewer workers health insurance and pensions. But they did little to protest that cost-cutting -- until now.
The mighty International Brotherhood of Teamsters, in its strike against the United Parcel Service, has mounted the first crusade against what many economists call "the contingent economy," and what many business critics call corporate America's scaling back of its responsibilities to employees. 
 But while the teamsters' labor allies praise the union for fighting for more full-time jobs with full benefits at U.P.S., some labor experts say that if the teamsters win big, victory could be a mixed blessing.
On the one hand, a union victory would be an important signal that John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, has re-energized the labor movement, encouraging some of the 85 percent of the work force that isn't unionized to think more about joining.
On the other hand, even with a teamster victory, the strike could ultimately hurt job opportunities and job security at U.P.S., the world's largest package deliverer, and one with a good record in dealing with organized labor. If the teamsters achieve a big victory in terms of higher wages and greater restrictions on U.P.S.'s use of part-timers, that could push up the shipper's costs, pushing business even after the strike to competitors that are largely non-union (the major exception is the Postal Service) and that also rely on lots of part-time workers.
U.P.S. executives have repeatedly boasted that the company has been a job-creating machine over the last four years, adding 46,000 unionized jobs. But the teamsters complain that 38,000 of those new jobs were part-time, paying too little to support a family.
Last week, U.P.S.'s chairman, James Kelly, warned that the company would have to lay off 15,000 of its 185,000 teamster employees because of business lost from the strike. While teamster officials angrily called that warning an exaggeration and "intimidation," economists say that lost market share, and the accompanying loss of some jobs, is a result of many strikes.
"Every customer whose life has been turned upside down by the U.P.S. strike might think about using a shipper where there won't be strikes," said Paul Schlesinger, a transportation analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "If the strike slows the growth of the U.P.S. job machine, it's going to hurt the teamsters."
In addition, the increased wages and the restrictions on part-time jobs sought by the union could make U.P.S. less competitive against Federal Express, DHL Worldwide and other competitors, particularly in the overnight shipping business that U.P.S. has fought so hard to enter, and which is so dependent on part-timers.
Ever since U.P.S.'s teamster members walked out on Aug. 4, company officials have said that the union's demands would make the company uncompetitive and cost it customers. That suggested an analogy to the high wages of auto workers helping Japanese car manufacturers make huge inroads in the 1970's and 1980's, causing the loss of many auto workers' jobs.
 
Offering Part-Timers Hope
 In their defense, teamster officials say their wage demands are modest and should not cause U.P.S. to become uncompetitive, especially since the company's relatively high profit margins give it room to lower prices. In addition, teamster officials contend that their demands to restrict the number of part-time jobs shouldn't make the company less competitive than a prime rival like Federal Express, because while two-fifths of Federal Express workers are part-time, three-fifths of U.P.S. workers are.
Mr. Sweeney of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said the teamsters' focus on improving working conditions for part-timers might pressure other employers, unionized or non-unionized, to treat them better. Not surprisingly, he also said that the teamsters' fight, especially if victorious, would make more part-time workers interested in joining unions -- and more unions interested in organizing them.
"This has raised the level of focus on part-time workers and that's why companies that use a lot of part-timers, like Sears Roebuck, have been urging U.P.S. to hang tough," he said.
But some labor experts say Mr. Sweeney is overly optimistic if he thinks legions of part-timers will join unions in response to the strike. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 23.2 million Americans -- 18.3 percent of the work force -- work part time.
"Certainly a teamster victory would encourage part-time workers to be a little more interested in unions," said Richard Hurd, a professor of labor relations at Cornell University. "But part-time workers have a high turnover and have been very hard to organize historically. Even though the strike could improve labor's image, I wouldn't imagine many major incursions into the part-time market."
Another hope of labor is that a victory would encourage workers at Federal Express and other shippers to think that a union could help them. A big obstacle to organizing Federal Express, however, is its successful lobbying last year to be placed under the Railway Labor Act, instead of the National Labor Relations Act. Under the railway act, which generally covers airlines and railroads, a union can organize workers only by having representation elections for all of a company's workers at once, instead of conducting separate elections at individual sites. It would be a tall order to organize Federal Express's 110,000 workers all at once.
"I'm not sure precisely how a victory at U.P.S. would enable the teamsters to conquer Federal Express or U.P.S.'s other non-union competitors," said Melvyn Dubofsky, a labor historian at the State University of New York at Binghamton. "Symbolically, a teamsters victory would be very very important because so many of the other major labor battles of the past five or six years, like Caterpillar, were largely defeats."

HEADLINE: Arrest of Gang Gives Albanians Hope That Chaos Is Ending

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The last of the foreign troops who came to Albania to contain nationwide violence have now sailed off, leaving the country's new Government this week to fend for itself against armed gangsters and the effects of an economic meltdown.
So far so good, it seems. 
 The new Prime Minister, Fatos Nano, announced on Wednesday that 100 police commandos who descended on the port town of Vlore on Monday had arrested 30 members of an armed gang and had the gang boss, "Zani," cornered. Another 100 soldiers, about the only intact unit of the Albanian Army, have taken control of Vlore's harbor, the transit point to Italy for smuggling drugs and people, he said.
Since Vlore was the heart of a rebellion against the Government of President Sali Berisha, which was turned out of office in elections in June, Albanians are taking the restoration of order in the town as a harbinger of better times.
The State Department declared on Tuesday that Albania was safe enough for the return of embassy staff and other officials who were evacuated in mid-March. Even so, Mr. Nano, 45, the leader of the Socialist Party, acknowledged in an interview on Wednesday that it would not be easy to bring Albania even to a tenuous hold on normalcy, which it was struggling to achieve after the collapse of the grim Communist system seven years ago.
"To rebuild this country will take a long time but we have the mandate and the people support us," he said in the Prime Minister's office, a rare oasis of polished wood and soft carpet in a corner of a scruffy Government building. "People didn't vote left or right in the election. They voted for putting an end to all the primitive political history."
Albania erupted into armed chaos in March over the collapse of fraudulent pyramid investment schemes, which caused heavy financial losses for most households. More than 7,000 European troops were dispatched here to help calm the country and discourage Albanian refugees from pouring into Italy. The United States, in particular, was concerned that a weak Albania with a heavily armed population could be a destabilizing force in the rest of the Balkans.
The last of those troops pulled out early this week, but Italy plans to send back some 600 to help Albania with police and military training.
The worst fears -- that the chaos here would spread to Albanian communities in neighboring Macedonia and Kosovo, a part of Serbia -- have not been realized.
But the legacy of the violence and the economic losses has left Albania, Europe's poorest country, much poorer.
The pillaging went so far that gangs pulled up the rail track in northern Albania, loaded it onto trucks and sold it as scrap metal in neighboring Montenegro. Mr. Nano said he was staggered to learn from the Defense Ministry that 10.5 billion bullets had been stolen from Albania's armories, which were all now empty.
To receive financial support promised by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, Mr. Nano said, his Government first had to restore a semblance of order. In addition, he said, the international community was demanding that the failed investment schemes be audited by a Western accounting firm to determine what happened to depositors' money.
Many financial experts have suspected that the schemes were fronts for criminal activities, and Mr. Nano said the auditors would try to find out whether there were "money laundering, illegal drugs or prostitution connections."

HEADLINE: Study Links Violence Rate To Cohesion In Community

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
The largest study ever undertaken of the causes of crime and delinquency has found that there are lower rates of violence in urban neighborhoods with a strong sense of community and values, where most adults discipline children for missing school or scrawling graffiti.
In an article published last week in the journal Science, three leaders of the study team concluded, "By far the largest predictor of the violent crime rate was collective efficacy," a term they use to mean a sense of trust, common values and cohesion in neighborhoods. 
 Dr. Felton Earls, the director of the study and a professor of psychiatry at the Harvard School of Public Health, said the most important characteristic of "collective efficacy" was a "willingness by residents to intervene in the lives of children." Specifically, Dr. Earls said in an interview, this means a willingness to stop acts like truancy, graffiti painting and street-corner "hanging" by teen-age gangs.
What creates this sense of cohesion is not necessarily strong personal or kinship ties, as in a traditional village, said Robert Sampson, a professor of sociology at the University of Chicago and a co-author of the study. It does help if many residents in a neighborhood own their homes or have lived there for a long time, Mr. Sampson added.
But cohesion, or efficacy, seems to be still another quality, Mr. Sampson suggested, "a shared vision, if you will, a fusion of a shared willingness of residents to intervene and social trust, a sense of engagement and ownership of public space."
The finding is considered significant by experts because it undercuts a prevalent theory that crime is mainly caused by factors like poverty, unemployment, single-parent households or racial discrimination.
These problems do play a role, according to the new study. But some neighborhoods in Chicago are largely black and poor, yet have low crime rates, it found -- so some other explanation is needed for the causes of crime.
The study has been conducted in all areas of Chicago since 1990 as part of a major continuing research program known as the Project on Human Development in Chicago Neighborhoods. It was financed at first by the MacArthur Foundation and the National Institute of Justice, the research arm of the Justice Department, and now also has financing from the National Institute of Mental Health and the United States Department of Education. The study, which has so far cost about $25 million, is scheduled to continue until 2003.
The research team selected Chicago as a site because its racial, ethnic, social and economic diversity most closely match those of the United States as a whole, Mr. Sampson said. For the study, Chicago was divided into 343 neighborhoods, and 8,872 residents representing all those areas have been interviewed in depth.
Among those neighborhoods with high levels of cohesion, the authors said, are Avalon Park, a largely black neighborhood on the South Side; Hyde Park, a mixed-race area around the University of Chicago, and Norwood Park, a white neighborhood on the Northwest Side.
The study at least indirectly contradicts the highly acclaimed work of William Julius Wilson, a professor at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, who in a series of books, most recently "When Work Disappears: The World of the New Urban Poor" (Knopf, 1996), traces many of the troubles of poor black families in Northern cities to the disappearance of factory jobs as industries moved to the suburbs or overseas.
Both Dr. Earls and Mr. Sampson said they thought that the results of their study suggested that Mr. Wilson's argument was too narrow and did not account for the differences in crime they found in largely black neighborhoods. Still, Professor Sampson acknowledged, concentrated poverty and joblessness "make it harder to maintain" cohesion in a neighborhood.

HEADLINE: Chinese Happily Break the 'One Child' Rule

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

DATELINE: DAZU, China

 BODY:
At the end of a summer's day, as a dusky light tinged the old wooden stools scattered around his open doorway, Li Feng gazed affectionately at his young daughter and son playing outside.
"I wanted at least two children," said Mr. Li, a soft-faced man whose work at a thriving cement-maker down the road now fills his day, and his pocket. "For eight years, we only had one. Now, if you can afford the fine, you can have an extra child." 
 Like untold millions of other parents, Mr. Li and his wife, Chu Lanping, are bending the rules of population control in China by having a second child. As townspeople, they were supposed to be content with one, but a little determination and a little more cash now win permission from local officials for one more.
In many parts of China, the one-child policy is melting away. The country's strict population control program, begun in the late 1970's and by no means gone, is becoming significantly looser in many places because -- as with so much in China today -- relentless economic growth is eroding the old system of control over ordinary people's lives, creating loopholes large and small.
Rather than spurring an explosive increase in the country's overall population, however, economic growth seems also to be reducing the number of children born to millions of other families, as they break out of the poverty that has traditionally encouraged childbearing. For every family like the Lis that has two children instead of one, there are other families in the countryside choosing to have two children instead of, say, five, and urban couples who are having none at all.
China's total population of 1.22 billion, the largest in the world, appears to be growing steadily each year at just over 1 percent, or about 13 million, and officials express confidence that they will stay well within their target of 1.3 billion by 2000. At the same time, demographers say that an unknown number of births go uncounted, leaving official statistics slightly unreliable.
In the past, local family-planning goals were sometimes enforced brutally. Forced abortions and sterilizations, while not the norm, were frequently reported in the early 1980's, especially in small villages where a local official wanted to show who was in charge.
It is that image of China that has provoked strong objection from religious and political groups in the United States, where thousands of Chinese apply for political asylum each year by asserting that being limited to one child is a form of political persecution.
 
Millions Now Having Multiple Children
Yet the worst excesses of local officials seem to have diminished in recent years, and millions of Chinese who want multiple children are now having them.
In a country where baby girls have traditionally been neglected or abandoned in favor of boys, reports that the one-child policy spurred the abandonment or even murder of baby girls caused great concern. Yet the current ratio -- 106.6 males for every 100 females in China -- is still lower than in 1930, when the ration was 108.5 males, or in 1953, when it was 107.6.
Worried that modern technology would allow couples to learn the sex of a fetus and abort females at a greater rate than males, Chinese officials banned the practice, though it may occur in some cases anyway.
The one-child policy is still strictly enforced in the nation's largest cities like Shanghai and Beijing, where penalties for having a second child remain onerous, like loss of a job and a fine equivalent to three years' salary for each parent.
It is in the medium-sized cities and towns like Dazu, tucked deep in China's interior in Sichuan Province, where things are changing.
Not long ago, local Communist Party officials wielded wide power over people's private lives, telling them when to marry, procreate or use contraception. Although local officials were judged in part by how well they adhered to family-planning goals, residents say the way they instilled fear and respect was at least as much about exerting personal authority as about enforcing national policies.
Nowadays, people like Mr. Li, who earns $100 a month at a private company instead of the $25 he used to make at a state-run factory, can deflect and ignore officials more easily because they no longer control his job, or his grain rations.
At the same time, as state subsidies to local governments dwindle, many local officials have turned to money-making and found it a better route to influence than the old way of cowing residents with threats and pressure. As a result, in countless towns and provinces, officials now accept a flat fee in exchange for permission to bear an extra child.
In the case of Mr. Li, a second child brought a fine of $1,200, a large but affordable sum because he borrowed from family members. Mr. Li, who said part of his desire for a second child was a wish for a son, said he faced none of the other pressure that used to accompany official efforts to discourage extra childbearing.
"They didn't try to talk us out of it," said Mr. Li, 32, referring to the local family-planning officials. "They just wanted to be sure we would pay the fine."
In other places, officials have aggressively encouraged residents to have a second or third child so fines could be imposed. The money collected belongs to the local government and so may sometimes be spent by the same officials who levy the fines.
In Mizhuang, a village in Henan Province, local officials encouraged several residents to have extra children so fines could be collected and then helped the pregnant women hide when national inspection teams came to check the population, a Chinese newspaper reported
"The town's family-planning association often told villagers to act this year because the fine might be increased in the future," said the newspaper Fortnightly Talks. "The phenomenon occurred not only in Mizhuang but in many other places, and the reason was simple: money."
 
A Shift in Enforcement Conceded by Officials
Officials at China's State Family-Planning Commission insist that the broader policy of strongly encouraging population control has not changed and that "money for children" cases are discouraged. But they say the Government's approach to enforcement has shifted over the last five years.
"You can't simply threaten people anymore; you have to try to persuade them," said Wang Guoqiang, director of the Policy Legislation Department at the State Family-Planning Commission in Beijing. "Relations between the local government and the people are changing greatly, and this is precisely why we are changing our methods."
Chinese leaders recognize, Mr. Wang said, that rural families producing the most children -- traditionally, the only form of social security -- are often farmers who would benefit from low interest loans and other economic assistance.
"Only economic development is going to control population growth," Mr. Wang said flatly. "Even if we wanted to make every family have only one child, it would be impossible."
The hordes of migrant workers who travel to find work outside their home areas also pose a tremendous challenge to China's population planners. Living outside the old Communist social system, these migrants -- officially estimated at more than 100 million -- are difficult to keep track of.
Although most migrants are men who leave home with the sole purpose of making money, untold numbers are couples who have extra children away from the prying eyes at home.
"So many people know how to work around the system that it's impossible to block them from having children if they really want to," said an American academic who has studied population control in China for more than 10 years. "The system cannot keep up with all these people."
He Gong, who runs a fruit stand with his wife and five children in the southern city of Haikou, on Hainan Island, said he left his home in a nearby province eight years ago after being fined and punished there, but had never had any dealings with family-planning officials in his new home.
"We wanted more children," said Mr. He, a balding man with a wide smile. "Even if we had to move, it was worth it."
It is impossible to measure how much families like Mr. He's migrate for the purpose of having extra children, because most are technically living illegally in their new residences -- another sign of the old system breaking down.
Yet the notion of traveling families gained wide currency a few years ago when a skit was performed on the Chinese New Year celebration on television, the most-watched program of the year, with 600 million estimated viewers.
The skit coined the term "population guerrillas" for a family that moved all over China to avoid family planning officials, naming each child after a different residence. True or not, many Chinese seem to believe that there are millions of "population guerrillas" at work.
In fact, enforcement of China's population control program varies from province to province and town to town. Many rural areas have never been able to keep families from having two, three or four children, while in others officials have been quite strict.
Typically, however, women have been encouraged to get an intra-uterine device after giving birth to a first child, and to be sterilized after a second birth. Many exceptions are made, for ethnic minorities or fishing families claiming they need many hands or families whose first child is handicapped.
Judith Banister, who until recently headed international programs at the United States Bureau of the Census and now teaches at the University of Science and Technology in Hong Kong, argues that urban areas can afford some relaxation of the one-child policy precisely because they have been so successful since 1980 that the population has become distorted, with many more people in their 20's than in their teens.
"The one-child policy in general has worked very well in large cities," Dr. Banister said. "China can afford some loosening."
In Shanghai, where the penalty for an unauthorized second child is a fine three times the annual salary of the father and mother, more residents have died than have been born in the last three years.
This negative population growth spurred some officials to suggest abandoning the one-child policy, though that option was rejected, said Jin Xuegong, a senior official at the Shanghai Municipal Planning Commission.
For one thing, it is only negative population growth on paper, since in the same period the migrant population of Shanghai has swelled to nearly 4 million, none of them counted among Shanghai's 14 million legal residents.
But in Mr. Jin's opinion, since many young urban couples are choosing not to have any children at all, it is unlikely there would be a huge population surge even if the policy was loosened more.
"Even I wonder if it's worth having a single child," said Mr. Jin, who explained that he was having a hard time at home with his 15-year-old son. "He doesn't do any housework, he won't obey orders, he doesn't study."
 
So Routine a Matter, Couples Know the Fines
In many other cities and towns, however, having a second child is becoming so routine that residents know exactly what the fine is in different areas.
In Anhui, a populous province in central China, couples who have a second child are typically fined $400.
In Guangdong, the only province where everyone living in the countryside is automatically allowed to have a second child, the fines are higher. In Guangzhou, a prosperous city near Hong Kong, the current fee is $1,500. In nearby Dongguan, a medium-sized city, it is $1,000.
Mr. Wang, the family-planning official in Beijing, acknowledged that there are many known cases, especially in southern China, where rich businessmen deliberately have second, third and fourth children by different women, as a way of displaying wealth and position through traditional means.
All of this raises the question of how accurate China's population statistics are. Demographers like Dr. Banister say that unreported births represent a small percentage of the overall population growth each year, but some longtime residents of China are skeptical that anything can be measured accurately.
"They say 1.2 billion, but it may be far more because there's no reason to register," said Sid Engst, an American farmer who has lived in China for nearly 50 years. "We like to say in America, 'Only God knows.' But how many children are out there in China's countryside, even God doesn't know."

HEADLINE: Writings by Iran's New President Due to Be Published in U.S.

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

 BODY:
In a move that is generating unusual excitement among Middle East scholars and policy makers, two American research institutes this week will co-publish the first English-language translation of writings and speeches by Mohammed Khatami, the new President of Iran.
Mr. Khatami, 54, won a surprise election victory last May that was widely interpreted as a protest vote against the Islamic Republic's repressive policies and continuing economic stagnation. 
 Mr. Khatami was largely unknown in the West before his election, and Middle East scholars and American officials have been seeking to learn more about the senior cleric, who was forced out of his post as Minister of Culture and Islamic Guidance in 1992, reportedly for his liberal views.
The Iranian-born scholars who organized the publishing venture say they hoped that permitting Mr. Khatami's political views to be heard in his own words might encourage better relations between Washington and Teheran.
The decision to publish the book now seems aimed at strengthening Mr. Khatami's political base at home, where he has met considerable resistance from Iran's conservative Parliament.
"Given Iran's preoccupation with what Americans think, if his image is good in the West, it will make it easier for him to maneuver," said Roy P. Mottahedeh, a professor at Harvard's Center for Middle Eastern Studies.
Scholars who have read the manuscript said it contained highly unorthodox views for someone who ranks among Iran's senior clergy.
While his book contains the usual denunciations of the West for imperialism, neo-colonialism and a desire for cultural dominance, Mr. Khatami warns against confronting the West though violence or military struggle.
"We must confront the thought of the opponent through reliance on rationality and enlightenment, and by offering more powerful and compelling counter arguments," he writes in one passage.
The book indicates that he finds much to admire in the West, and not just its science and technology.
"We have to keep in mind that Western civilization rests on the idea of 'liberty' or 'freedom,' the most cherished values of all mankind," he writes. "To be fair," he adds, the West has cast aside the "regressive thinking that had been imposed on the masses in the name of religion," and "broken down subjugation to autocratic rule." All these things he calls "positive steps."
He warns that "dogmatic believers," who in the name of Islam project "the aura of religious legitimacy," are seeking to return to a vanished Islamic golden age by trampling religious and intellectual freedom.
"When confronting the enemy in the name of rejecting the West and defending religion, if we step on freedom, we will have caused a great catastrophe," he concludes.
The book is being published jointly by research centers at the State University of New York at Binghamton and at Brigham Young University.
Richard Bulliet, the director of Columbia University's Middle East Institute, said the book presents an "enlightened and cohesive image of Islam and an Islamic revolution which is much more open to the West and new ideas than we've seen before."
The book, with an initial printing of 5,000 copies, is to be sold through the two institutes. While aimed at scholars and policy makers, it is priced at $12 to make it accessible to a broader audience. Iran had no part in financing the venture.

HEADLINE: Praise and Criticism for Clinton Education Policy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton advised parents today to telephone the Education Department's toll-free telephone line to find out how their children could take advantage of new school initiatives, but he was criticized by the Republicans for not supporting public vouchers for private school tuition.
"In the new economy of the 21st century, what our children earn will depend more than ever on what they can learn," Mr. Clinton said in his weekly radio address. "Almost 90 percent of the new jobs being created today require more than a high school level of literacy and math skills. Yet more than half of the people entering the work force are not prepared with these skills, so we still have a lot of work to do." 
 The President listed the Administration's education initiatives, including tax credits for college, access to Individual Retirement Accounts for tuition payments and more Pell Grants. The Education Department telephone number is (800) 872-5327.
But in the Republican response, Gov. Arne Carlson of Minnesota criticized President Clinton for his refusal to support the idea of using public money for private school tuition.
"We want every child in America to have the same choice as Chelsea Clinton," Governor Carlson said. The President's 17-year-old daughter recently graduated from Sidwell Friends, a private prep school in Washington.
The Governor said Democrats were not doing enough for the nation's schools.
"What are Democrats so afraid of when it comes to choice, competition and accountability in our schools?" he asked. "Democratic answers include a few national tests, a few more summits and a truckload of dollars, which will not solve the problem."
The governor said Minnesota gave tax deductions for tutoring, summer enrichment camps, private or parochial school tuition and other educational purposes.

HEADLINE: BATTERED PRIDE -- A special report.;
For Old South Boston, Despair Replaces Hope

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

DATELINE: BOSTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Kevin Cunningham, 17, was buried last month, four days after he hanged himself from the porch of his family's house, leaving no note.
He was the sixth young man from fiercely proud, mostly white, mostly Irish South Boston to commit suicide since the end of December. 
 His name was added to the roll call that echoes from the rows of tidy three-decker houses to the low-rise brick housing projects, from the saloons to the street corners, where groups of sad teen-agers remember their lost friends: Duane Liotti, 21; Kevin Geary, 17; Jonathan Curtis, 16; Tommy Mullen, 15; Tommy Deckert, 15. They all died the same way, by hanging.
The priest at St. Brigid's parish, the Rev. John Culloty, was at a loss as he began the funeral Mass for Kevin Cunningham. Kevin's older brother, Christopher, is in jail, charged with robbing Father Culloty at gunpoint last year of the church bingo receipts.
"There is something unreal, unnatural about all of this," Father Culloty told the mourners who filled the church. "We seek answers, we seek explanations, but there really aren't any answers."
What is clear is that there is a contagion of despair among many of the young people of South Boston. It is not only the six suicides that have staggered the neighborhood. Since January, city officials say, about 70 teen-agers -- most of them male -- have been hospitalized for attempts at, or thoughts of, suicide.
The despair runs like an electric current through a community once celebrated for its dynamic ability to overcome any obstacle. For well over a century, Southie, as it is called, was a place where Irish immigrants, and later Italians, Lithuanians and Albanians, too, could climb the ladder from poverty to middle-class success.
Bordered on three sides by Boston Harbor, Southie was a self-contained world that could educate its children, instill in them spiritual faith and community loyalty, and provide them with the certainty of decent jobs.
Southie was especially proud of its men. They were known as priests and politicians, as policemen and firemen, as longshoremen, fishermen and factory workers. They were hockey stars and football players, and a few of them were organized crime leaders.
Now, the priests of staunchly Roman Catholic Southie have said funeral Masses for six young men in seven months.
For decades, the neighborhood fought to protect its children by raising barricades against outsiders and change. When change arrived, in the form of court-ordered busing in the 1970's, Southie waged war against it, becoming a national symbol of Northern resistance to school desegregation, its motto of Southie pride hardening into a battle cry.
The threat was always viewed as from the outside: from Protestant Yankees, the Federal courts, minorities and suburban liberals. Outsiders could be blamed for even a relatively recent plague of drug abuse, and a string of fatal heroin overdoses that immediately preceded the suicides.
"People could say, 'Oh, it's the drug dealers' fault, it's outside,' " said Kathy Ahern, a 26-year-old native of South Boston, who works with teen-agers at the South Boston Neighborhood House. But the suicides were a thundering declaration that there was an enemy within. "Kids killing themselves," Ms. Ahern said. "Who do you pin that on?"
The suicides have prompted an extraordinary public self-examination in a neighborhood that has long maintained a code of silence around private troubles. Southie residents are talking about the area's problems, which are not all that different from other Boston inner-city neighborhoods: poverty, drug abuse, broken homes, too many high school dropouts, lack of jobs.
They are also beginning to say that South Boston's legacy of anger over busing may have hurt the children they were trying to protect.
For Southie, the ground has shifted. The blue-collar jobs that once bought houses and security for men and women with high school educations are disappearing.
And with the waning influence of Southie's politicians -- after six decades of Irish rule Boston has its first Italian mayor -- the political patronage that once assured jobs as court officers and bus drivers for Southie residents is no longer certain, either.
In the aftermath of busing, the public schools, as well as the church, which supported desegregation, no longer command the same respect they once did. South Boston High School, where today most of the students are bused in from other neighborhoods, is regarded as the lost secular shrine.
There are many South Bostons, and there are many young people from the neighborhood who are succeeding in some of the city's most academically demanding schools, and whose prospects are bright.
But for many of Southie's young people, the once-thriving ethnic enclave has turned in on itself, and become a trap.
Michael MacDonald, 30, who grew up in a housing project in South Boston and is now a neighborhood organizer, sees a horrible symbolism in the method of suicide. Statistically, hanging is relatively uncommon among teen-agers.
"Who hangs themselves?" he asked. "People in prison hang themselves."
 
The Mood
The Shared Grief Of a Small Town
They call South Boston "the town," and with 29,000 residents, it still feels like a small town. People sit on their stoops at night and call hello to their neighbors. The streets are relatively safe. Every few blocks there is a community center, a gym or a park. It is not surprising that in this tight-knit world the six suicide victims all knew each other.
Kevin Geary wanted to be a state trooper. He lived with his mother in the Old Colony development, a housing project that some demographers have rated one of the poorest white neighborhoods in the country.
Kevin hanged himself on Dec. 30 after getting an $85 traffic ticket for running a blinking red light.
"Kevin was the first," said his mother, Linda Reid, who cut her youngest child down and spoke through a haze of inconsolable grief. "It's like he showed a way out."
Duane Liotti was the second, in February. He was also from Old Colony, where he lived with his mother, an administrative worker in a nursing home. The teen-agers at Old Colony looked up to him.
Mr. Liotti, a high school dropout who had earned his equivalency diploma, had been a campaign precinct captain for Southie's new State Senator, Steve Lynch. Shortly before Mr. Liotti's death, Mr. Lynch had helped him get a $14.65-an-hour apprentice's job with the electrical workers union.
Tommy Mullen, gregarious and popular, was drunk the night before St. Patrick's Day, when he and a friend each wrapped a belt around his neck at the West Broadway housing project. Tommy's friend, also 15, changed his mind in time.
Tommy lived at the project with his mother, a produce clerk at the Stop and Shop supermarket, and his four sisters. Tommy had been suspended from South Boston High School for a fight not long before his death.
Jonathan Curtis was the cut-up of his crowd. Turf is important in South Boston, and Jonathan and his friends owned the corner of I and 8th Streets, two blocks from the water. Jonathan, who had dropped out of South Boston High School, was trying to get his high school equivalency diploma.
He lived a few doors up from the corner with his mother, a nurse, and his stepfather. His father had died several years earlier. Jonathan killed himself in April, the day after one of his close friends, 23-year-old Shawn Austin, died of a heroin overdose. The whole corner, 40 to 50 teen-agers, went to Jonathan's funeral.
Tommy Deckert, a former altar boy, was taken to the hospital after attempting suicide on June 8. Never regaining consciousness, he died of his injuries five days later. His bereaved mother has asked friends and neighbors not to talk about her son, or his death.
If the first five suicides seemed to fit a pattern of young men trying to cope with financial struggles and absent parents, the death of Kevin Cunningham did not. He lived with his mother and father in the coveted City Point section, with its stately homes and ocean views. His father, Lawrence, a supervisor for the city's water and sewer department, had worked extra jobs to put his five children through parochial school.
The Cunninghams had been shaken by the arrest of Kevin's older brother. The code of ethics in Southie holds that robbing the church is unthinkable and unpardonable.
Kevin, an honor student who had a job parking cars at Fenway Park, was the pride of his family. But in June he had wrecked his father's pickup, and was charged with drunken driving in the accident.
Each of the suicides may be inexplicable in its own way, shrouded by the mystery of each young man's personality and family history. Collectively, the suicides have become a statement by a group of confused, inarticulate teen-agers for whom death has brought a recognition unknown in life.
Karen Powers's two daughters, Katelyn, 15, and Heather, 17, knew all the victims, but were especially close to Jonathan Curtis. Ms. Powers says she has tried to emphasize to her daughters the senselessness of the suicides. "I told them, 'Jonathan made the front page of The Herald, but he wasn't around to see it,' " Mrs. Powers said.
Nor is Jonathan here to listen as the suicides have reverberated in the community and beyond, signaling unmistakably that many young people in Southie do not think life has much to offer them. Many of those from the poverty and drug-plagued projects view the future as especially grim. And yet Katelyn and her sister still pledge their loyalty to their neighborhood.
"My mother always said 'Southie pride,' " said Katelyn, who wears green streaks in her hair and wants to be a marine. "You have to have Southie pride. It's who you are, it's where you're from."
Heather, who has a part-time job at a CVS drugstore, held out her left wrist to show the black dot tattooed there. It is the Southie dot, the badge of one of the neighborhood's own.
Heather's friend, 14-year-old Joelle Riley, declared, "You're proud of your neighborhood, no matter how bad it gets."
Robert Coles, the child psychiatrist and Harvard professor, studied the effects of school desegregation on Southie in the 1970's, and more recently he has been visiting the neighborhood with his students, who do community service work in Southie's projects.
"There are bleak prospects for these kids, socially, economically and culturally," Professor Coles said. "It used to be they could knock on the door of a politician, or the church would look after them and get them good jobs. That's all closed off now."
Southie, he added, has become a victim of its own history. "You've got a frustrated, isolated, scorned and rebuked community."
It was not always that way. Once, Southie was king. Thousands of poor and half-starved Irish immigrants had begun flooding Boston in the mid-1800's. Shunned by the Brahmin Boston establishment, many of them retreated to South Boston. They created an ethnic neighborhood out of necessity.
By the 1920's, there was a pipeline to jobs, and they were in it. James Michael Curley was the Mayor, and eventually became Governor. Though he had risen from the Irish slums of the Roxbury neighborhood, South Bostonians saw him as their adopted son.
They were rewarded for their loyalty with jobs as policemen, firemen and street car conductors. They also worked as longshoremen, as pipe fitters, plumbers and carpenters at the gas and electric companies and in neighborhood factories.
The Catholic Church wielded complete authority. So did the police. There were neighborhood schools. The neighborhood even got its own anthem, "Southie Is My Hometown":
There's something about it,
Permit me to shout it,
It's known for miles around.
 
The Fight
Still at War, Feeling Betrayed
At St. Augustine's Church, where he has been preaching his message of love and hope for 18 years to a dwindling and ever poorer flock, Father Thomas McDonnell quoted an Irish proverb the other day: "A man becomes the song he sings."
"What song are we singing?" he said, his sorrow as thick as the heat in his un-air-conditioned rectory. "Despair or discouragement, anger, escapism."
South Boston began declining after World War II, when people started moving to the suburbs. The banks had cut off home mortgages in South Boston, and also redlined many of the other poor neighborhoods.
But the real turning point, when the walls of the fortress began crumbling, was busing for school integration. A siege mentality developed, encouraged by South Boston's political leaders. Parents hurled stones, and racial epithets, at school buses carrying the outsiders -- terrified black school children from Roxbury. And many Southie children were bused to schools in Roxbury. Those people who could afford to moved to the suburbs, or paid for private and parochial schools.
Many of the neighborhood children stopped going to school. Dropping out was an act of loyalty to the neighborhood. The dropouts were known as Garrity's children, after the Federal judge, W. Arthur Garrity, who ordered the busing. Some say that today's dropouts are Garrity's grandchildren.
"We lost an entire generation," said Thomas Crowley, a South Boston police captain.
The violence had eased by the end of the 1970's. What was left for those who could not afford the alternatives was a poor and overwhelmingly minority school system. With some school choice allowed, busing continues today.
Southie never got over the fight.
"They felt betrayed," said Thomas H. O'Connor, a historian who grew up in South Boston and is the author of "South Boston: My Home Town, the History of an Ethnic Neighborhood" (Northeastern University Press, 1988). "The church betrayed them. The priests betrayed them. The justice system betrayed them. The cops betrayed them. Ted Kennedy betrayed them."
Many people say it is Southie's history that accounts for the lack of respect for authority, and education, among many of the neighborhood's young people.
"After busing, everybody saw authorities as the enemy," said Michael MacDonald, whose mother was among those who marched against the court-ordered busing. "We became outlaws."
The South Boston Tribune, a widely read weekly, is still rehashing the fight; in a recent issue it blamed "dumb white liberals," among others, for ruining the schools, and the lives of thousands of residents.
Asked about busing, Katelyn Powers said: "I hate it, I hate it. There's a lot of people from Southie who want to go to Southie High, but people from Roxbury and Dorchester get in before we do."
Captain Crowley hears that sort of anger frequently. "I tell these kids, 'You weren't even born, get on with your lives,' " he said.
 
The Change
Disappearing Jobs, Rising Costs
 Billy Coleman, an 18-year-old dropout who grew up in the West Broadway project and called Tommy Mullen his best friend, was giving a driving tour of his neighborhood.
"No other town looks like our town," said Mr. Coleman, who wants to become a youth counselor. He pointed out the flower pots hanging from the porches, the grid-like pattern of Southie's streets, the miles of beaches. "This is my town. I feel important here."
And yet Southie does not belong to Billy Coleman. While it remains the most distinctive of all the city's neighborhoods, even Southie is changing. Young professionals who work in Boston's nearby financial district are moving in. With real estate prices spiraling, longtime residents worry that their children will be priced out of the neighborhood. Cappuccino cafes are opening beside the Irish saloons.
While South Boston is 95 percent white, the project where Billy Coleman grew up is about 50 percent minority, the result of a 1989 Federal court order that it be desegregated.
Like many South Bostonians, Billy is still furious about it. "They were trying to take over our town," he said, describing the fights that broke out among the project's teen-agers in the beginning. "They should have their own town. This was our town."
None of the old paths are certain for Billy and his friends.
To illustrate how things have changed, Kathy Ahern talked about her father, Bill Ahern. He graduated from South Boston High School in 1964. He was the captain of the hockey team. It hardly mattered that he was not a star in the classroom.
"By the time he was 24, he was married and had four children and was working at Boston Gas," Ms. Ahern said. Eventually, he bought a house on East Seventh Street for his family. Today he is a supervisor at Boston Gas, earning about $70,000 a year.
But now Boston Gas is laying people off. The neighborhood factories have closed. Computers have gobbled up the old jobs at the utilities, and computer training is needed for the jobs that are available.
The other day Mr. Coleman and his friend from the project, Jimmy Connolly, 20, and also a dropout, talked about the future. "Around here you don't hear no one talking about college," Mr. Connolly said. "Half my friends didn't even finish high school."
Mr. Connolly, who spent six months in jail recently for aggravated assault with a weapon, said he knows of one man in the project who has gone to college. That man had an advantage, Mr. Connolly said, explaining, "He had a mother and father his whole life."
Mr. Connolly was 10 when his stepfather, whom he considered his father, hanged himself. Mr. Coleman was 3 when his father, who was 19, died of a gunshot wound to the chest. The authorities ruled it a suicide.
 
The Struggle
Pulling Together, Hoping for Revival
In the spring, Steve Lynch, the State Senator, a former ironworker, persuaded the ironworkers union to hold a job fair for the neighborhood young people. The turnout was disappointing. "There's a weakness of spirit inside some of these kids," Mr. Lynch said, adding that he sees the roots of that weakness in missing parents, and in the absence of the church in their lives.
Mayor Thomas M. Menino has pledged to help South Boston. The city has opened a health center in the Old Colony project and promised to refurbish gyms and community centers. Teams of mental health workers have been dispatched to the neighborhood.
Southie has been pulling together to stop the suicides. A neighborhood women's group has been formed, a first for Southie. Mary Ulrich, a mother of eight who helped start the group, said, "The Irish have this thing: If something happens, you suck it up, and march along, you keep it to yourself."
Jack Leary, the chief probation officer at the courthouse, who has devoted himself to South Boston for 18 years, has been spending his free time getting teen-agers who need it into treatment, and finding summer jobs and training programs for others.
Southie's residents have been reaching out to other neighborhoods, inviting black mothers from Roxbury and Dorchester to tell them of the sons they have lost to violence.
A community meeting in May drew more than 500 people trying to help themselves.
Michael MacDonald, the community organizer, says the challenge is clear. "We know what we're against," he said. "But what the hell are we for?"

HEADLINE: In Shift to Labor, Public Supports U.P.S. Strikers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Standing alongside his wife in their cramped kiosk in the Chicago Loop, Mark Wier complains that the strike against the United Parcel Service has delayed the arrival of some watchbands that he is eager to sell, but that has not stopped him from siding with the people who shut down U.P.S.
"I agree with the teamsters," Mr. Wier said on Friday. "U.P.S. has 80 percent of the market. They are a successful company, and they can afford to pay full-time jobs. Those workers work hard and they deserve full-time pay and full-time benefits." 
 Even though the 13-day-old walkout by the teamsters is inconveniencing far more Americans than most strikes have, the American public strongly agrees with Mr. Wier and supports the workers in this high-stakes showdown, the largest strike in the nation in two decades.
That is a surprising switch because the public sided with management in most other recent work stoppages that grabbed the nation's attention, including the 1994 baseball players' strike, the 1982 football players' strike and the 1981 air controllers' strike.
To be sure, many Americans have warmer feelings toward their friendly U.P.S. drivers, whom they often see lugging around 75-pound crates, than toward baseball players making $2 million a year. But, public opinion experts say, several factors far more profound than that help explain why Americans are siding with the U.P.S. strikers.
"There's been a pendulum shift that's led people to support unions in disputes with management because Americans have gotten a much more jaundiced view of how corporations treat workers," said Geoffrey Garin, a pollster who does some work for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "There's a very strong perception that management is less fair and less loyal to workers than it used to be."
According to a CNN/USA Today Gallup poll, 55 percent of Americans back the teamsters in this dispute, while 27 percent support management. The poll of 819 adults was taken last Wednesday and Thursday and had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
In dozens of interviews conducted in the past two days in cities around the country, support for the teamsters came through strongly, though many people backed U.P.S. Some people said it was wrong for a company with such high profits to insist on hiring so many part-timers, instead of full-timers. But others opposed the strikers, saying they were hurting the economy and putting a gun to management's head.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters has insisted that the main issue in the strike is U.P.S.'s widespread use of part-time workers, who the union says earn too little to support a family. That issue has apparently struck a chord with a public sensitized to workers' issues by years of downsizing and stagnant wages.
The union has repeatedly attacked U.P.S. because more than four-fifths of the 46,000 new jobs the company has created since 1993 have been part time. U.P.S. officials have insisted that the principal issue in the dispute is the company's demand to set up a new pension plan, but that issue has not resonated with the public the way the issue of part-time workers has.
"This is a popular strike because it involves issues that many workers all across the country identify with," John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, said in an interview. "People understand when you talk about the transition from full-time, middle-income jobs to part-time, low-income jobs. People sympathize when they see a company that makes a billion dollars and is taking it out of the workers and is not giving them their fair share of the profits they create."
Sixty percent of the company's 185,000 unionized workers are part time, and the union wants 10,000 of the part-time positions converted to full time over the next four years. U.P.S., which has offered to make 800 of the part-time positions full time, says it needs so many part-time workers because its average day contains several short bursts of intense sorting and loading. Part-timers earn an average of $9.50 an hour after two years while full-time drivers earn $19.95 an hour.
While eating his lunch on the 16th Street Mall in downtown Denver, Greg Callaghan, a government employee, voiced clear support for the teamsters, even though it is a union toward which Americans have traditionally felt scant sympathy. "If it's true they've made billions, then they ought to take that money and put it into the employees," Mr. Callaghan said. "That's an awful lot of money to have in profits and not be able to pay the workers what they want. A part-time job just isn't going to get people off of welfare."
But in Atlanta, where U.P.S. has its headquarters, Robert Schochet, owner of a flower and gift shop, was firmly in management's camp. "Unions will be able to hold large corporations for ransom," he said. "I hope U.P.S. holds out, otherwise you give into unions just like a terrorist.'
Those who sympathize with U.P.S. management predict that the public's support for the workers will diminish as the strike drags on.
"Let's see what happens when people get tired of the response from ordering things by catalog taking longer and longer," said Karl Rove, a Republican pollster in Austin, Tex.
He said this strike was far different from the air controllers' strike in 1981, when President Ronald Reagan dismissed 11,500 strikers. Mr. Rove asserted, "Then, the air controllers said, 'Let's inconvenience everyone in the nation,' and there was no sympathy for them because those guys were making $100,000 a year."
The public's attitude toward the teamsters is far different from its views toward the air controllers. In a Harris survey in 1981, 51 percent of the public backed President Reagan and 40 percent the controllers. The public's pro-teamsters view also contrasts with attitudes toward the baseball strike, in which, according to a CBS News/New York Times poll, 43 percent of the public supported the owners and 22 percent the players.
In Brooklyn, Michael Rodriguez, owner of Open Road Cycles, said he sympathized with the teamster strikers partly because he was so fond of his brown-suited U.P.S. driver. "The workers do work hard," he said. "I have some feeling for my regular guy. They do deserve something."
Leonard Feldman, a Manhattan lawyer, said: "I go with the workers. Management is trying to enforce a conservative push, something happening across the nation, which is not in the interests of middle- and lower-income people."
A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials say the public has not suddenly warmed to labor because of the U.P.S. strike, noting that the pro-labor trend has been a decade in the making. In a Los Angeles Times poll in 1984, 34 percent of the public said they supported labor and 45 percent backed management when they were asked which side they generally supported when they heard about a labor dispute. Asked an almost identical question last year in a poll done by Peter D. Hart Research, 44 percent said they favored the workers, and 24 percent backed management.
U.P.S. officials insist that the union has mischaracterized the part-timers' working conditions, asserting that this had wrongly led many people to back the union.
"The part-time job at U.P.S. is a great job," said James Kelly, chairman of the company. "The average wage is $11 an hour. They receive a full level of benefits. They have 25 paid days off."
That type of argument resonated with Richard Arzola, a commercial printing salesman, in East Austin, Tex. "I don't support the strike at all," he said. "We don't need unions. At one time, maybe back in the '40's or '30's, but now, you don't need a union. Those guys are getting a pretty deal to work."
In Atlanta, Joni Roberts, a clerk at Stacy's Pharmacy, agreed, saying, "I think with the amount of money they're getting and all the benefits, they should be happy."
U.P.S. took solace in the response to one part of the CNN/USA Today poll: by 65 to 28 percent, the public said it backed the company's demand that the union should hold a vote on the contract even though its negotiators had rejected it. But in a rebuff to the company's position, only 21 percent of respondents said the Clinton Administration should intervene to settle the strike, while 75 percent said the company and workers should settle it themselves.
Milly Kaslov, who owns a psychic shop in Los Angeles, said she supported the strikers -- and she predicted that the strike would end soon. She said her U.P.S. delivery man was always courteous and prompt, and she insisted that his $20-an-hour wage was not too high.
"What's $20 an hour today?" she asked. "Prices are going up. In my day, $20 was a lot, but not anymore."
Even many people who supported the strike acknowledged that they were unhappy with how it was hurting their business. Voicing support for the teamsters, John K. Kim, manager of the Two Brothers clothing store in Chicago, said: "They are not being treated fairly and so they are doing what needs to be done to get what they want. However, my business is being hurt, so I just hope it is over as soon as possible."

HEADLINE: For National Parks Workers, a Housing Crisis

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Aug. 13

 BODY:
"Water would be a big improvement," said Harold Rudd, assessing the wood and canvas shack that the Government gives him to live in as he works, wearing the uniform of the National Park Service, along the spectacular ridges that adorn one of the most precious tracts of real estate in the world.
"Maybe if we had more showers, or two or four more toilets," he said yanking a thumb toward the communal bathhouse at one end of the row of tent-cabins, occupied by seasonal employees who pay $10 every two weeks to live under canvas roofs. "But just having water in there would make it so much more convenient," he said. 
 More than an hour's drive away, in the village of El Portal on the park's fringe, the employees-cum-tenants had no such complaint.
"This is the best house I've lived in, in my whole Government career," said Dean Clark, who manages the National Park Service's program of controlled fires within Yosemite.
The Government built his two-bedroom home a few years ago at a cost of $400,000. He pays $550 a month, which he called "equitable," for the 1,200-square-foot house, which has energy-saving features, a two-car garage and nearby tennis courts and ball fields.
The contrasting living situations of the two Park Service employees illuminate one more festering problem for an agency plagued by years of tight budgets and booming tourism. Substandard housing for Government workers -- and for employees of park concessionaires as well -- is a problem all across the national park system, one the Park Service is struggling to address as it tries to provide appropriate shelter for some 5,000 employees in areas where commercially available housing is too remote, too expensive or both.
The new housing project at El Portal was criticized by the Interior Department's inspector general last year because its 19 single-family homes and 37 apartments cost, on average, $580,000 per unit -- two to four times the going rate for local housing. A similar situation was found at Grand Canyon National Park, where there is also an acute housing problem.
In part that is because the expenses included a share of the costs of road building, architectural design and environmental studies.
"The Park Service decided to build high-quality, energy-efficient, single-family homes, which resulted in high-cost employee housing and unmet housing needs," the inspector general for audits, Robert J. Williams, concluded in his report. "At least 70 seasonal employees at Yosemite National Park will still be living under the same conditions that prompted the funding for the employee housing."
As career employees mature, the agency's managers worry about losing some of the best of them because they will not put up with decrepit housing or because they are tired of moving from one Government house to another without ever building up any home equity.
In the most rugged reaches of Yellowstone, some workers live in dilapidated trailers, tucked under sturdy freestanding snow roofs to protect them from crushing blizzards. On seashores like Cape Hatteras, N.C., summertime rents are far beyond the means of seasonal employees.
The Park Service, a branch of the United States Department of Interior, estimates its backlog of maintenance, repairs and replacement for housing at $300 million, said Donna Compton, the official in Washington who is responsible for housing programs. Its annual budget for the programs is $12 million.
The highest priority, she said, is to replace old, supposedly temporary, trailer homes, which often present safety problems for the occupants. The overall goal is to replace 35 percent of all substandard housing by the year 2002.
Last year, in the Omnibus Parks and Public Lands Management Act of 1996, Congress ordered the service to assess its overall housing needs, including who qualifies for government-owned housing and what it would cost to bring the entire housing stock up to acceptable standards. The review is under way.
At the same time, Congress authorized the Interior Department to enter contracts with private housing developers to build and manage housing, on either public or private lands, that would be leased to eligible employees. The Government could provide subsidies in cash payments, occupancy guarantees or below-cost leases of Federal land.
The service is pleased with the new entrepreneurial spirit, but any such arrangement would require further Congressional appropriations and raise complex issues of fairness and practicality, according to Government and private experts.
"There are things the National Park Service does well -- educational programs, search and rescue operations," said Palmer Jenkins, chief of strategic planning at Yosemite. "And there are things we probably don't do particularly well. Being in the housing business is a necessity for us, but it has not necessarily been a core competency."
The park has enlisted the assistance of Joshua D. Hannah, a graduate student in business at Stanford University who is working as a volunteer to examine the economics of the idea. He has sounded out developers and found them enthusiastic, but he thinks financing the projects will require careful analysis.
"They are all very enthusiastic that public-private partnerships are the answer," he said of his talks with developers. "But that is before they run the numbers. Any way you slice it, it is going to cost lots of money."
Meanwhile, the Park Service is trying not to repeat the mistakes of Yosemite, a park that is struggling to move as many workers as possible out of the spectacular valley to enhance its natural appeal.
"We are trying very, very hard to contain the costs," said Ms. Compton, citing a standardized housing design that can be modified slightly and built at one park after another.
Some costs are unique to the Park Service, like the need for extensive environmental impact studies of each housing development. But the high-cost homes at Yosemite also have solar water heaters, commercial grade flooring and other features. Although these amenities might hold down operating costs and wear and tear, they have added to the up-front costs.
On one thing, the Park Service and the inspector general agreed: the housing conditions at the park were not solved by the development at El Portal. Park Service officials maintain, however, that seasonal employees often climb the housing ladder, into trailers and other homes that permanent employees leave when they move into the new houses.
But the men and women living in tent-cabins along the park's high Tioga Road could not afford the rents in the new housing.
"They are pulling people in here that are just making a few dollars over minimum wage," said David McCarl, a seasonal maintenance worker who returns each year. He added, "We push ourselves by saying we get paid in views."
Their home improvement is accomplished by their own hands, as when they sheeted in the walls of their tents with plywood.
Steven Lusch, who makes $11.44 an hour operating road equipment for the park, helped the crew build a barbecue pit. The crew also installed water lines closer to their tents, saving the walk to the bathhouse.
"We haven't got the sinks in yet," Mr. McCarl said. "They keep promising us sinks."

HEADLINE: Union and U.P.S. Officials Negotiate Through the Night

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Representatives of the United Parcel Service and the striking teamsters' union continued negotiations today after holding all-night talks in an effort to end the 13-day-old strike by 185,000 workers.
Teamster officials played down the chances of an imminent agreement, but some union officials said there just might be a settlement this weekend, although one official said it was possible the talks could still collapse. 
 Labor Secretary Alexis Herman occasionally joined the talks, which began at 9 A.M. Friday and continued for more than 30 hours. The two sides took a short break early this morning to wash up and nap.
"The two sides are hunkered down," a Labor Department official said.
On Friday afternoon, Ronald Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, gave a pessimistic prognosis in his one public appearance since the marathon negotiations began. He said no agreement had been reached on any of the main areas in dispute, namely subcontracting, the size of a pay increase, company plans to set up a new pension plan and the widespread use of part-time workers.
Urging the strikers to maintain their solidarity, he said: "A contract that provides good jobs for working families certainly won't be won at the bargaining table. The only way you can win that is either on the picket lines or in the community."
To step up pressure on the company, the teamsters are organizing rallies in 30 cities Thursday, which the union has designated "Action Day for Good Jobs." Teamster officials said the community rallies were an important way to maintain the strikers' spirits and to show U.P.S. that most of the American public sides with the strikers.
U.P.S. officials continued to argue on Friday that teamster leaders should let their rank and file vote on what the company calls its "last, best and final" offer. But union officials say such a vote is unnecessary, because the rank and file voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike.
Showing the business community's growing impatience with the strike, Thomas J. Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, wrote President Clinton on Friday to say that the union should let its members vote on the U.P.S. offer and, if that does not happen, the president should seek an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act to end the strike. Under that law, presidents can seek an injunction to end work stoppages that imperil the nation's economy or security.
"I am urging you to use the powers of your office to end this intolerable situation," Mr. Donohue wrote. "You are the only person who can help thousands of struggling employers and employees all across the country. By stepping in today, you can send a message to the entire country that you represent the interests of all Americans."
The teamsters and their labor allies oppose use of a Taft-Hartley injunction because they say it would strip the teamsters of their strongest weapon against U.P.S.: the strike. They also say the strike does not endanger the nation's economy.
A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials released a letter today that John J. Sweeney, the federation's president, sent to all members of Congress, asserting that Taft-Hartley should not be invoked because the economic damage caused by the strike does not satisfy the high standards set by that act. The letter was in part a response to a letter that U.P.S. sent lawmakers last week urging them to press the President to invoke Taft-Hartley.
"Strikes and lockouts may cause inconvenience and location," Mr. Sweeney wrote. "But the economic impact of collective bargaining is not ground to have the government intervene by executive fiat and and cast aside the free system of collective bargaining which has been the foundation of our nation's labor laws since the 1930's."
The talks were being held at the Hyatt Regency Washington Hotel, and aides to Secretary Herman said she was staying at the hotel to make sure that she was readily available if the parties needed her. John Calhoun Wells, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, has also joined the talks.
The strike has largely shut down the domestic operations of the United Parcel Service, the world's largest package delivery company, which handles 12 million parcels on an average day.
The company's competitors, including Federal Express and the Postal Service, have struggled to fill the gap left by U.P.S.
