HEADLINE: How New York State Walked Into a Veto of Its Medicaid Item

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, learned long ago how to grease the legislative machinery by helping colleagues with provisions of special interest to them.
So when Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, approached him last spring with a favor he wanted included in this year's huge budget bill, Mr. Roth agreed, especially since the Finance Committee's senior Democrat, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, also supported it. 
 Mr. D'Amato's seemingly obscure and parochial provision -- resolving in New York's interest a long-running and complex dispute over Medicaid financing -- became the center of a national political debate last Monday when President Clinton used his line-item veto power for the first time to excise it from the budget bill he had just signed into law.
Mr. Clinton characterized the provision as an unjustified and inequitable handout to New York that would set an unacceptable precedent for settling similar disputes with as many as 14 other states. Mr. D'Amato and other supporters of the measure, including Gov. George E. Pataki, denounced Mr. Clinton for vetoing a measure that was part of an intensively negotiated, bipartisan balanced budget package.
A look back at how the provision evolved shows that Mr. D'Amato calculated that it would be better to push for a full victory rather than accept the half loaf offered by the White House. The White House, for its part, gambled that it could withstand the political heat of using its new line-item veto power against a provision backed by nearly the entire political establishment of the nation's second-most-populous state.
"This is politically painful to us in a state that we care about," said Gene Sperling, the White House's economic policy adviser. "But we felt it was good policy and that it sends the right signal nationally that we're changing the rules on impermissible government spending."
But the veto, in fact, may have given a boost to Mr. D'Amato. As he prepares for a tough re-election battle next year, the Senator has been handed an opportunity to portray himself as the protector of his state's neediest people against the Washington bureaucracy.
The issue behind all the political sniping -- whether New York and other states should be allowed to tax health care providers in a way that increases the level of Medicaid money the state receives from Washington -- has been festering since 1991, when a new Federal law strictly limited use of such taxes.
The intent of the 1991 law was to keep states from increasing their eligibility for matching Federal Medicaid funds by assessing taxes on health care providers, labeling the revenues as state Medicaid funding that would be matched by Washington, and then effectively refunding the taxes to the health care providers. Critics of the practice said it was a scheme to milk more Medicaid financing from Washington.
But the 1991 law recognized that some states were levying taxes on health care providers for legitimate purposes that would expand access to health care for the poor. So the law allowed states to apply for waivers. Fifteen states, including New York, and the District of Columbia eventually applied for waivers.
But the waiver process by all accounts moved very slowly. Because it had to wait for the Federal Government to complete its detailed regulations for enacting the new law, New York was unable to file its waiver request until 1995. In the meantime, believing that its provider taxes would be found allowable by Washington, New York continued to levy them.
New York's waiver requests covered a variety of provider taxes. The Clinton Administration told state officials that it was sympathetic to its request for a waiver for one of the taxes, known as a regional pool. The tax was levied primarily on hospitals, with the revenues paid back out to those hospitals that accepted a disproportionate share of poor patients unable to pay the bill. Although the tax did not meet the criteria laid down in the 1991 law that all provider taxes be "broad-based and uniform" because hospitals in different regions were taxed at different rates, the Administration agreed that the tax was being used to improve health care for the poor and should be allowable.
But the Administration still did not issue the waiver. And it continued to offer New York and other states little guidance on whether other provider taxes would be deemed acceptable. Between 1992 and May 31 of this year, New York received $2.6 billion in matching funds from the Federal Government for Medicaid based on provider taxes that remain in dispute, and state officials said they were growing impatient about removing the uncertainty that the unresolved issue had created around the state's finances. The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the state actually had no more than $200 million at risk, a figure that state officials said they cannot explain.
"The issue was not moving, period," said Robert R. Hinckley, a spokesman for the New York State Health Department. "It's 1997 and we're still waiting for the waiver. Our concern was that we didn't want to be preparing a budget two or three years down the road and have the Federal Government act and require reimbursement from the state."
Mr. Pataki took his concerns to Mr. D'Amato, his political mentor. They decided to try to sidestep the regulatory process through a legislative provision that would, in essence, do an end run around the Federal Department of Health and Human Services and declare New York the victor. And because both of New York's Senators serve on the Finance Committee, which oversees spending for entitlement programs like Medicaid, Mr. D'Amato, along with Mr. Moynihan, had considerable leverage with Mr. Roth to insure that the provision would be included in this year's spending bill.
"This was an effort on our part to deal with an inequity and to allow the state's health care system to continue to provide the necessary care for the uninsured and the poor," Mr. D'Amato said in an interview on Friday. "Otherwise the burden could become one that could pose serious threats to our health care system."
The provision had a close call even before making it into the final legislation. During a Finance Committee hearing in mid-June, Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican, offered an amendment that would have banned in all states the very Medicaid-financing practices that Mr. D'Amato wanted approved for New York.
Saying that states were using the taxes on providers to "game the Medicaid system" through a "ruse" that put a bigger burden on the Federal budget, Mr. Gramm called on the Finance Committee to end a practice "that we are all against."
Mr. D'Amato ripped into Mr. Gramm's proposal during the hearing as "ridiculous" and "mean-spirited," prompting Mr. Gramm to withdraw his amendment. Mr. D'Amato said his provision was placed into the spending bill on the Senate floor in late June with the approval of the Republican leadership and the knowledge of the White House.
Indeed, while many special interest provisions are slipped into legislation at the last minute and therefore get little scrutiny, this one got a prompt response from the White House.
"It would have been a classic Washington-based rifle shot provision for one state and one state only," said Chris Jennings, the White House's health policy adviser. "And it would have been impossible for us to say no on provider taxes in other states that we believe to be impermissible under current law and statute."
Mr. Jennings met with staff members from the House and Senate to offer a compromise. Mr. Jennings said the Administration would agree to legislative language approving New York's regional pools, but not the other provider taxes it had been using. Mr. Jennings said the compromise would have freed up about half the money in dispute.
The offer was transmitted to Mr. D'Amato, who passed it along to Mr. Pataki's office. State officials rejected the compromise, saying it would not remove the financial uncertainty hanging over the state's Medicaid system.
"For the state to get one waiver, even for a significant chunk of the money, would not resolve the issue and would leave the other pools at risk," Mr. Hinckley said.
The issue then went unaddressed until after the budget bill was passed by Congress last month and signed by the President early this month. Mr. Clinton's budget and economic advisers said they quickly identified the provision as one that they considered bad policy.
Although they said they knew that vetoing the provision would bring protests from New York, they said there was a compelling case to be made that New York should not be allowed, because of its political muscle on the Senate Finance Committee, to receive a break that no other state would enjoy and that could undermine the Administration's efforts to toughen on abuses of the Medicaid system.
Mr. D'Amato said he believes Mr. Clinton did not fully understand that New York was only intending to shore up its Medicaid system.
"I don't believe that people gave the President the right information," Mr. D'Amato said. "I believe he was misled."

HEADLINE: Clinton Looks for Inspiration From the Left

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton, searching for new intellectual energy and vigor for his White House, has brought two longtime partisan loyalists into his inner circle and given them broad latitude to work on political strategy and Presidential themes.
Mr. Clinton has turned to outside tacticians at critical turnings before. In 1993, after a rough first six months in office, he tapped David Gergen, the Reagan-era message meister, to court the Washington establishment. In 1995 after the Republican ascent in Congress, he turned to Dick Morris. 
 Those two men had strong Republican ties, but the two who began work this week are decidedly Democrats: Paul Begala, 36, one of the political consultants who was at Mr. Clinton's side in 1992, and Sidney Blumenthal, 48, a former journalist who as early as 1987 heralded Mr. Clinton as one of a new generation of Democratic leaders.
Most of Mr. Clinton's confidants contend that advisers exert little gravitational pull on the President these days. Mr. Clinton, they say, is charting his own moderate course, one that embraces once-Republican ideas like balanced budgets and free trade, yet includes Democratic grace notes like a children's health care program, environmental activism and tax cuts for higher education.
"The debate about the vital center versus the invigorated left is over," said Rahm Emanuel, Mr. Clinton's senior adviser, insisting that Mr. Clinton will not make a leftward surge. "He has chosen the course he enunciated both in 1992 and 1996."
But White House aides acknowledged that having checked the self-proclaimed Republican revolution of 1994, Mr. Clinton now hopes to push public opinion slightly leftward toward a greater acceptance of activist government.
As an example, White House aides noted, two years ago Mr. Clinton was fighting simply to stop Republicans from turning the Federal Medicaid program of health insurance to the poor from an entitlement program into a block grant. But this year the Republican Congress agreed to create a new $24 billion entitlement program as part of the budget deal to give health insurance to five million poor children.
The President is also determined, his aides say, to win the House of Representatives back for the Democrats next year, despite historic trends that have seen the President's party lose seats in midterm elections.
Mr. Begala and Mr. Blumenthal, both of whom are expected to include speech writing in their duties, could help set a tone. Mr. Begala was known in 1992 as an aggressive populist who believed in using themes of class struggle against a corporate elite. He argued in favor of investments in training and education programs in 1993 and against a strict emphasis only on deficit reduction.
Mr. Blumenthal most recently wrote in the World Policy Journal that deficits had become a tool for causing a paralysis of social policy and he accused the Republican right of seeing tax cuts as "a fiscal weapon to regain insolvency and thus political dominance."
In some ways, Mr. Clinton could simply coast right now, with the roaring economy washing away the nation's discontents. A new poll by the Pew Research Center found this week that Mr. Clinton's 59 percent approval rating was coming close to Mr. Reagan's in the summer of 1986. The figures were even more remarkable because Mr. Reagan was re-elected in a landslide while Mr. Clinton did not even get 50 percent of the vote.
Moreover, the Pew poll found that for the first time since the the victory in the Gulf war, most Americans are happy with the country's direction.
But officials say that the President and Mrs. Clinton, who still has substantial behind the scenes influence, want new energy and ideas in the White House, which is still living off the small idea-a-day style of the 1996 campaign.
The President himself is said by his aides to be tired and sorely in need of a vacation. And more members of the first term staff are leaving. Mr. Blumenthal is taking the place of Donald A. Baer, the just-departed communications director, and Mr. Begala will eventually take the place of Doug Sosnik, counselor to the President, who is expected to leave soon.
While Mr. Clinton is in Martha's Vineyard for the next three weeks, the White House will be preparing for what is expected to be the new, post-balanced budget phase of the political debate.
White House officials say that the balanced budget agreement served Democrats by erasing their tax-and-spend image while also giving them distinct programs to call their own, like the tax credits to pay for community college tuition.
Across the White House, officials are engaged in a policy review to identify new initiatives for the President in such areas as health care, child care and education. None of them are expected to be vastly ambitious. There are still the realities of a Republican Congress facing Mr. Clinton and the fiscal constraints of the balanced budget agreement.
But such measures could form a campaign platform for the midterm Congressional elections of 1998 and the Presidential race of 2000, when Vice President Al Gore is expected to run. Such issues allow the Democrats to continue to distinguish themselves from Republicans by pointing to small, activist government programs that they endorse. They are also designed to help Democrats expand their potential electoral base to suburban swing voters.
Mr. Begala, officials say, is expected to write speeches, advise on political tactics and work with the Democrats as next year's elections near. He was recommended by Mr. Emanuel and is expected to work with him.
For Mr. Begala, the White House job is a type of resurrection. He had fought against Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction emphasis in 1993 and eventually fell out of favor when a new chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, decided to bring more order to the White House by ending the free access given to the 1992 campaign consultants, including Mr. Begala.
Mr. Blumenthal -- who is expected to work on speeches and high-profile projects like the White House's newly announced emphasis on the millennium -- is a more controversial figure. He is friends with Mrs. Clinton and his hiring caught several high-ranking White House officials by surprise. Some of his new colleagues express skepticism that a career in opinion journalism is the requisite background for a White House staffer.
One thing Mr. Blumenthal will not be is a a Gergenesque image polisher. A former writer for the New Yorker, Mr. Blumenthal has had notoriously bad relations with many of his former colleagues in the Washington press who saw him as too close to the Clintons. When his job was announced by the New Republic, for whom he used to write, the magazine sniffed that perhaps "he'll get his back pay."
"A beat is just an assignment but a slut is who you've become maybe," the magazine said.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 19, 1997, Monday

 CORRECTION:
 An article yesterday about Presi dent Clinton's search for new intel lectual energy and vigor in the White House focused on the recent hiring of two political advisers, Paul Begala and Sidney Blumenthal.
The last paragraph, a quotation that appeared to be a cynical and uncomplimentary allusion to Mr. Blumenthal, a former journalist, was truncated and misattributed because of an editing error. One word was incorrectly transcribed, compound ing the misimpression.
The quotation, as it appeared in The Times, said, "A beat is just an assignment but a slut is who you've become maybe." It did not appear in The New Republic, which wrote about Mr. Blumenthal's appoint ment.
It was, in fact, a line from a play by Mr. Blumenthal that lampooned the White House press corps in which a reporter is bemoaning his career, and should have read, "A beat is just an assignment but a slot is who you've become maybe after being on a beat so long it becomes your life."
The article made the point that Mr. Blumenthal has had tense relations with some of his former colleagues, and the quotation was intended to serve as an illustration of the au thor's observations about some White House reporters.
The word "slot" was incorrectly transcribed from an audio tape of the play as "slut."

HEADLINE: Where Have All the Antiques Gone?

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
DEALERS in American antiques could hardly contain their excitement at an auction last May in Austerlitz, N.Y., not far from Stockbridge, Mass.
At the center of all the buzz were four pieces of 18th-century Connecticut furniture by the same maker, pieces that had been in one family for 200 years and that had never been on the market before, according to Maine Antique Digest. The collection attracted just about every major dealer in the country who specializes in formal American furniture. Robert Herron, an auctioneer since 1953, sold a highboy that was among the four pieces; it was the most expensive item he ever handled, he said, and a dealer from Ohio bought it for $418,000. 
 William Hosley, curator of American decorative arts at Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, said the highboy, bookcase desk, serpentine-front chest and tall clock were "one of the few major discoveries of the year." The keen interest in the sale reflects a demand for American antique furniture that is exceeding the supply, dealers say. Coveted pieces like those at Austerlitz are at a premium and sell at prices beyond the reach of many lovers of Americana.
That is why reproductions, which, of course, cost considerably less, are increasingly popular. A young couple unable to afford a $20,000 antique may be happy to take home a reproduction, just to be able to live with the Early American look. But they cannot expect to recoup their investment, as they can with antiques, warned Zeke Liverant, whose family has bought and sold American antiques and art in Colchester since 1920.
Where have all the treasures gone? A lot of them are being sold to collectors and dealers in other states. Thomas Schwenke, an appraiser and antiques dealer in Woodbury, explained that 18th- and 19th-century craftsmen made a limited amount of furniture, some of which found its way into 25 major collections formed over the last 50 years. In addition, the market is no longer confined to New England, as it once was.
"We're in the information age, the travel age, the age of the fax machine. Someone living in California can bid by fax on something at an auction in New York and have the item shipped to California," Mr. Schwenke said. "Once an estate is disbursed, the antiques go somewhere else. It's like dandelion seeds."
In 1955, Mr. Schwenke recalled, dealers at an estate sale would find more merchandise than they were able to handle. "Now, we spend hours, days and months trying to search out things to buy and can't find anything," he said. "If there are 300 items in an estate, 290 of them are garbage."
Connecticut farmhouses are cleaned out, and many family heirlooms were sold years ago, Mr. Liverant said. Antiques from Connecticut are more apt to turn up in places like Ohio and Missouri, where the economy is stronger, or in spacious apartments on Park Avenue in Manhattan. Two of the four pieces of cherry furniture auctioned at Austerlitz, however, were bought by dealers from Connecticut.
Mr. Liverant's son, Arthur, paid $77,000 for the secretary desk, and the chest was bought by Marguerite Riordan of Stonington for $57,200, according to Maine Antique Digest. Ms. Riordan said she added the chest to her stock. When asked where the secretary desk ended up, Zeke Liverant would say only that it was placed in a collection in Connecticut.
New England was the center of the antiques market in the 1930's and 40's. In fact, it was unusual before World War II for anyone outside New England to collect antiques seriously, Mr. Hosley said. In the 1950's and 60's, Connecticut was famous for its antiques and collectors.
There was little antiques buying in the 1970's, when Wall Street was a dim place and real estate and art failed to draw investors. Then the Bicentennial sparked tremendous interest in Americana that continued into the robust economy of the 1980's. Today, investment in art and antiques remains lively, and museums are unable to buy a significant piece of American furniture for less than $100,000, Mr. Hosley said.
Tim Mallon, a wholesaler and manufacturer of reproductions in Danbury, said he got out of the antique business because few people were able to afford the high prices. "With the economy the way it is, Joe Schmo can't go out with his family on a Sunday and buy antiques anymore," he explained. "Five or seven years ago, I could buy a dresser for $300. Those days are gone. That traffic isn't there. A dresser with a marble top probably costs $1,500 to $2,000 now."
Mr. Mallon imports reproductions from Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, China and Mexico. His customers like the fact that the decoration on the furniture is carved by hand, no two items are the same and the furniture is solid mahogany and teak.
Distressed painted furniture from Indonesia is a hot item, Mr. Mallon said. The armoires, small tables and cupboards, which resemble French country furniture, are finished in pastel paints that appear to be cracked and worn. The process used to create the appearance of age is a secret, he said.
There are also many well-made 19th- and 20th-century reproductions around.
Buyers are still able to afford the real thing if they make a commitment to it, said Ms. Riordan. "Buy the best example of any category that you can afford. There are good values, if you take the time to learn," she adfvised.
The rule is beware, because the tag on a piece of furniture does not always indicate whether the item is an antique or a reproduction.
In most cases, a thorough inspection with an eye sharpened by a number of authenticated examples of the style is all that is needed. The furniture should be examined from every angle as well as inside and out. There may be a reason it is stuck in the corner of the shop or backed up against a wall.
June Neal, director of communications for the State Department of Consumer Protection, learned a hard lesson. She bought five pieces of furniture she thought were made in the Victorian period. When she sold four of them a few years later to the same dealer from whom she bought them, she was told that they were reproductions. "I was heartsick. I paid $1,000 for a sofa and sold it for $300," she said. "I lost a couple of thousand dollars on the four pieces."
But Ms. Neal had no recourse. "I didn't have the proverbial leg to stand on, because I didn't have the receipt," she said.
A dealer should always be willing to write a receipt that states the approximate age of the piece, its condition, where it came from, where it was made and any additional history associated with the furniture, if it is available, Mr. Liverant said.
He also advised buyers to get help from a trustworthy dealer. "The reputable dealer is not necessarily the dealer with the full-page ad," he added as he flipped through a magazine about antiques and held up various advertisements as examples. "Go to a museum and ask them to recommend someone."
One way of detecting repairs, replacements and fakes is to look at the patina on the furniture. Almost as soon as wood is exposed to light and air, it begins to change color. This is especially true of unfinished wood, although stains and paint will also fade or discolor to some degree. Generally speaking, identical woods exposed to the same conditions will color identically. If they have not, something is wrong, and it usually indicates replacement of some sort, wrote Harold L. Peterson, author of the book, "How Do You Know It's Old?"
Patina is usually most noticeable on the unfinished surfaces, like the sides and bottom of a drawer, the backs of chairs or the underside of a tabletop. Various areas of a piece of furniture are more exposed to light and air than other areas, so there will be some differences in patina.
Mr. Liverant pointed out variations in color on the drawers of a 1780 tiger maple desk in his shop. The drawers of a secret compartment inside the desk were lighter than the drawers facing the outside.
"There's nothing like the patina that comes from time and use. Look at the mellowness and softness of the wood," he added. Mr. Liverant, a man who uses all his senses in appreciating fine antiques, noted that reproductions smell new.
Copies of antique furniture have not surpassed the work of 17th- and 18th-century cabinetmakers, who designed and made furniture that expresses simple elegance, Mr. Liverant said. "Show me some new furniture that has survived 200 years."

HEADLINE: Keeping Score;
Big Social Changes Revive the False God of Numbers

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, after a furious debate within his own party and even among his own advisers, President Clinton signed the most radical revision of the nation's welfare policy in history. Last week the President declared the change an unqualified success.
"I think it's fair to say the debate is over," Mr. Clinton said in St. Louis on Tuesday. "We know now that welfare reform works." 
 His evidence? A 1.4-million-person drop in welfare rolls nationwide over the past year.
But that figure proves only that the number of people on public assistance fell, not that welfare reform "works" to foster self-sufficiency. There are a score of possible explanations for the decline, some attributable to government policy, many wholly unrelated.
President Clinton is not the first chief executive to draw categorical conclusions from scanty data. But his declaration of victory in the war on welfare based on a single statistic illustrates the political pressure to keep score on complex issues of public policy. This pressure is especially evident now with so many hotly contested social and economic transformations under way, some only in their early stages. Although Washington places talismanic power in numbers as it tries to judge the good or bad of such changes, statistics have often proved a false god.
Who are the winners and losers in the new budget agreement? Who benefits most from the North American Free Trade Agreement? What are the social costs of affirmative action? Has the quality of health care deteriorated under managed care? How bad is corporate streamlining in a dynamic, competitive economy? Or wage stagnation at a time of low inflation and technology-driven improvements in the lives of ordinary people?
In the national obsession with market statistics, quarterly profits and the won-loss column, Government and private experts find themselves trying to measure the largely unmeasurable. They attempt to apply the scientific method to questions that do not lend themselves to simple quantification. In the name of accuracy or advocacy, they fashion a veneer of seeming numerical certainty over what are fundamentally questions of belief.
 
The What, Not the Why
 Americans love to keep score -- look at how much newsprint is devoted each day to the stock tables and the small-type charts in the sports section. But is it possible to reduce to numbers such questions as the success of a major shift in welfare policy or the social value of new pollution rules that will cost industry billions of dollars?
Governments try, every day. Whole bureaus are devoted to assessing the costs and benefits of programs based solely on numbers. Thus welfare reform is declared a success because the rolls are dropping by more than 100,000 people a month. New air-quality standards are justified at any cost because they will supposedly prevent precisely 15,000 deaths a year from respiratory ailments.
"This is the glory and the curse of the one-number summary," said Bruce Levin, a statistician at Columbia University's School of Public Health. "You take a hundred-dimensional problem like welfare reform and reduce it to one number."
While numbers have long been used to deceive and to manipulate public opinion -- Vietnam War "body counts" come to mind -- the more frequent problem is that they tell only part of the story. Statistics can sometimes describe the "what"; they seldom illuminate the "why." Of course, the alternative -- reliance on anecdote or the unsupported testimony of "experts" -- is even less useful.
Robert Reischauer of the Brookings Institution, an economist who oversaw the Congressional Budget Office from 1989 to 1995 and was thus Capitol Hill's chief scorekeeper, said that today's obsession with numbers is an overreaction to the past, when public officials were not held accountable for the results of their actions.
 
Tyranny of the Sound Bite

 In the search for precision in assessing policies, Washington has stepped off into the realm of the unknowable, he contended.
"We live in a society where policy evaluations have to fit into a sound bite, so there is a tendency to focus on quantitative measures even when they may not be measuring the most important dimensions," he said. "A full evaluation of most policies would be multi-dimensional and include both quantitative indicators and more subjective measures of success and failure."
Mr. Reischauer cited as an example studies that show that commuters spend more time in their cars getting to and from work because of traffic congestion and business relocations. According to a 1996 study, the average one-way commuting time lengthened by 40 seconds between 1986 and 1996, to 22.4 minutes. The widely reported conclusion was that since time spent on the freeway is wasted, the American quality of life was diminishing.
But what the survey doesn't reflect is that many of these commuters voluntarily moved farther from their jobs to bigger homes, greener lawns and better schools. And many say they enjoy the added time in their four-wheel-drive, air-conditioned, six-speaker capsules away from the pressures of home and office.
Similarly, raw statistics on divorce and labor force participation of women have been used to support wildly differing interpretations. Soaring divorce rates are cited to "prove" a breakdown in the family and worsening conditions for children. But are women in abusive relationships always better off staying married? Does that improve their children's lot?
And do the growing numbers of women in the work force mark the American family's effort to stay afloat in a time of falling wages -- or the professional liberation of millions of women?
Depends on your point of view.
Meaningful evaluations of public actions and social trends take years, sometimes decades. Only now are the mixed results of President Lyndon B. Johnson's anti-poverty programs becoming clear. Sorting out the effects of the 1996 welfare bill and several years of state welfare experiments that preceded it will similarly take years.
"You can't tell whether welfare reform is working simply from caseload numbers," said Wendell Primus, a welfare expert who quit the Administration in protest last summer over Mr. Clinton's signing of the welfare bill. Those figures do not tell how many former recipients moved from welfare to work, or simply from dependency to despondency, he said.
"You have to look at where these people went," Mr. Primus said. "In the short run, a year later, we just don't have the measurement tools to really assess the impact of all of this."
While Clinton Administration officials admit that there is a paucity of data to explain why so many people are leaving welfare rolls, they nonetheless say the falling number of recipients represents a stunning success.
"Certainly some of the success is due to a booming economy and very low unemployment," said Bruce Reed, the President's chief domestic policy adviser. "But there's also something else going on, which is, for the first time most states are taking welfare reform seriously and putting in place impressive programs to move people from welfare to work."
Analysts are employing ever-more-sophisticated models to measure the behavior of the economy and the consumer, but there will always be things they can't measure in a rapidly changing workplace.
As the United Parcel Service strike has dramatized, more employees are working part-time or on a contract basis than ever before. Has the United States become a nation of temps doing piecework for heartless corporations for want of better jobs? Or do the figures reflect decisions by a growing body of workers to trade full-time work and benefits for more freedom and family time? Do both situations coexist? And is the current state of the work force only a temporary phenomenon as the global economy undergoes seismic shifts based on new technologies?
Again, statistics can describe what is happening. They cannot necessarily explain why.
Professor Levin said that politicians labor in vain to apply the discipline of the hard sciences to matters of conjecture and opinion. The physical sciences like chemistry and physics proceed by controlled experiment, biology and medicine by longitudinal studies and clinical trials. In scientific inquiry, a statistician can locate sources of bias and error and try to correct for them.
But how does one measure the success of crime-control programs, or pre-kindergarten education or immigration policy? Statistics are tools of the scientist, Mr. Levin said. But when numbers are crunched in politics, axes are usually grinding, too.
DREAMS OF MY RUSSIAN SUMMERS
 By Andrei Makine
 Translated by Geoffrey Strachan
 241 pp. New York:
 Arcade Publishing $23.95.
ANDREI MAKINE's moving novel impressed me when I read it in the original French, and it has lost none of its qualities in Geoffrey Strachan's attentive translation. Upon its appearance in 1995, "Dreams of My Russian Summers" received both the Prix Medicis and the Prix Goncourt, the first time this double accolade had ever been awarded. The novel's Russian-born author, who sought asylum in France a decade ago at the age of 30, is a master of limpid French prose. It is therefore ironic that in order to have his first books published in Paris he had to pretend they were translations from Russian manuscripts. French publishers simply could not believe that a recently arrived emigre could write so well in their language.
In "Dreams of My Russian Summers," Makine employs a highly poetic voice to blend memory and imagination, merging the particular realities of Soviet life with a timeless evocation of a sensitive adolescence. Skillfully constructed and elegantly written, the novel records a series of eventful recollections that never descend to the trivial or the strictly anecdotal. Rather, everything contributes to a total effect -- even the dramatic ending, when the true meaning of a mysterious old photograph is revealed.
Makine has special gifts, but he also has a special story to tell. It is the story of Carlotte Lemonnier, born in France at the turn of the century, who as a child moved to Russia, where her father practiced medicine. Traveling back and forth over the years, she found herself in France on the even of World War I, only to return to Russia with a Red Cross mission during the Revolution. There she remained to see the horrors of civil war and famine, and later witnessed the Stalinist purges, the war with Germany, the dehumanizing industrialization of the country and ultimately the fall of Communism's idols. By the time her grandson, the novel's narrator, begins visiting her for his summer holidays, she has been long settled in the sleepy Siberian town where her Russian husband lies buried. Her story is that of a double allegiance: to her French past, for which she feels a sensuous nostalgia, and to her Russian destiny, which she accepts without flinching. Between these two worlds hangs an iron curtain.
Charlotte's grandson grows up loving and admiring the infinite compassion of this remarkable woman, her buoyant spirit, her moral strength. But what he loves above all is the splendor of the "grandmaternal tongue" in which she teaches him and his sister unforgettable lessons about poetry and freedom. The narrator is entranced by the stories Charlotte tells about the fabulous city of Paris during the belle epoque, stories she shares during long summer evenings on her balcony. In the process, she instills in the boy a sense of the beauty of the French language. Quoting Baudelaire, Nerval and Hugo, she introduces him to a world of dreams and hints at the secret meanings of words -- the way that subtly, often by indirection, they can succeed in saying the unsayable.
As Charlotte sits on her balcony under the halo of a turquoise lampshade, she creates a hypnotic mirage of memories, making France appear to the boy like a resurgent Atlantis. But for the narrator Russia has its own poetic associations. Makine vividly captures the dry air and silent vistas of the steppe, the smell of wet earth on the evening wind, the excitement the boy feels when fishing through the ice of a frozen river. There is also the special poetry of growing up: the pain, yearnings and loneliness of the vulnerable adolescent.
Viewed from the industrial city on the Volga where the narrator lives with is parents, Charlotte's France seems like another planet, a terra incognita whose singularity and unreality make him feel like a stranger in his own country. His grandmother's influence leads him to see Russia from a French point of view, which alienates him from the society around him. As his schoolmates taunt and bully him, he is increasingly isolated, ashamed of his eccentric thoughts, which he attributes to the implant of French culture. And indeed his Frenchness does seem a blemish at a time when "cosmopolitanism" is considered almost a crime in the Soviet Union. As he grows up, his French sensibility comes into conflict with what he considers the maleness of Russia. Feeling like a "strange mutant" unfit for the real world, he tries to erase his French identity and become like other youngsters, who are passionate about soccer matches and dream of driving tanks, who enjoy their paramilitary training and excel at dismantling and reassembling automatic rifles, at hurling practice grenades.
Yet even in the darkest moments of the struggle between his two identities, the narrator knows that alienation has its virtues, that perhaps one needs to be a foreigner to understand the country in which one lives, that his French illusion can become a form of protest against tyrannical encroachments and thus an instrument of liberation and survival. This is no doubt one of the meanings of the novel's original title, "Le Testament Francais," which is betrayed by the bland one chosen for the American edition. In French, a "testament" is a last will, a legacy, a posthumously revealed secret -- all of which are relevant to the essence of the story. "Testament" also connotes a linguistic legacy, one that confirms for the narrator the overwhelming power of literature.
But the American title is, in its way, appropriate too. For "Dreams of My Russian Summers" is not about France but about Russia: the Soviet Revolution, the ensuing massacres, the police state of Stalin and Beria, the enormous human sacrifices of the years following the German invasion of 1941, the bankrupt utopias of an empire surrounded by barbed wires, the drabness and vulgarity of daily life under Communism.
It is difficult to forget the novel's scenes of mutiliation and rape, its depiction of the brutish stupidity of officials and bureaucrats. Makine manages to suggest volumes in the silent glances that are exchanged after a black car has whisked away an entire family -- or in the manner by which the authorities eliminate people crippled in the war, who are grimly referred to as "samovars" because their stumps resemble the feet and handles of the familiar copper vessels used for preparing tea. At one point, Charlotte recalls a gruesome fight among these maimed survivors, who wield knives clenched between their teeth.
At times, it seems as if Makine is at his most effective when he sketches moments so painful that there appear to be no words to describe them, as when Carlotte's hideously scarred husband returns from the war and silent tears stream down her face after she sees the wounds on his naked body for the first time. Nonetheless, the power of words is always at the heart of the novel -- because the unspeakable requires a special language. Charlotte is most often portrayed in the act of reading, reciting, telling. Her mythical France is a bookish country. And so the circumstance of finding oneself between two languages is related to the magical displacements, the mediating authority, of literature.
For "Dreams of My Russian Summers" is also about a budding writer's need to invent a new language in order to reveal his secrets. And such a language, committed to changeless beauty and giving permanence to the fleeting moment, represents at its deepest level a struggle against death. Makine is telling a story about the apprenticeship of a writer as well as about the making of a book. It is a book about death and rebirth, about rescuing fragments of memory and not allowing them to disappear. If the epic background of war and revolution brings Pasternak to mind, it is also true that Proust's esthetic quest in search of a timeless time can be perceived subtly woven into these pages. Andrei Makine has given us a major novel.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:

THE MARKETS
Worst Slide for Stocks In Nearly Six Years
Stocks plunged late Friday as investors worried that equities may be overvalued, given the outlook for corporate earnings. Gillette, whose Braun unit had disappointing results in Germany, fell 4 1/8, to 85 15/16. Other large multinationals, including Procter & Gamble and General Electric, also fell, as traders began taking profits after the big run-up in recent months. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 247.37, or 3.11 percent, to 7,694.66 on Friday. In points, the drop was the steepest since a plunge of 508 points on Oct. 19, 1987. In percentage terms, it was the steepest decline since November 1991. With the loss, the Dow has fallen 6.8 percent from its record closing of 8,259.31 on Aug. 6. But the average is still up 19.3 percent for the year to date. The Nasdaq composite index fell 24.66 on Friday to 1,562.03.
 
THE ECONOMY
A Machine Keeps Humming
An avalanche of fresh economic data did little to change the prevailing view that growth is solid, inflation is subdued and Federal Reserve policy makers will stand pat on interest rates at their meeting this Tuesday. "Why fool with an economy so balanced?" asked Cliff Waldman, economist for the National Federation of Independent Business. Consumer prices climbed 0.2 percent in July, as expected, but producer prices fell for an unprecedented seventh consecutive month. Industrial output also expanded by only 0.2 percent last month. Retail sales, however, climbed 0.6 percent. The Labor Department reported that productivity rose at an annual rate of 0.6 percent in the second quarter, but several economists and business people -- in a view that was far from universal -- insisted that the official data understated a flourishing efficiency. 

U.P.S. STRIKE
Unions Help Teamsters Dig In
Ratcheting up the stakes in the strike against United Parcel Service, John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., announced that the nation's labor unions would lend the International Brotherhood of Teamsters $10 million a week for "many, many weeks" to provide benefits of $55 a week for the 185,000 striking workers. The move indicated that labor leaders, increasingly assertive, viewed the dispute as a pivotal showdown. With businesses and consumers feeling pressured, Labor Secretary Alexis Herman persuaded U.P.S. and the teamsters to resume talks with a Federal mediator, as the company hinted at new flexibility.
 
SHONEY'S SETTLEMENT
A Happier Son, for Now
Shoney's Inc. and Raymond D. Schoenbaum, a dissident shareholder whose father, Alex, founded the company 50 years ago, settled their differences, at least temporarily. Shoney's, which has lost 70 percent of its market value over the last three years, amended its bylaws to increase the number of its directors to 11 from 7, and named Mr. Schoenbaum and his ally, Michael J. Bodner, to the board. In return, Mr. Schoenbaum put aside plans for a proxy fight to replace the restaurant company's management, at least until May 1, 1998.
 
HOUSING PRICES
A Seller's Market, Again
For the first time in a decade, housing prices are rising nearly everywhere, helped by rising employment and a strong stock market. Indeed, 80 percent of the nation's metropolitan areas are showing an increase in home prices that exceeds the inflation rate. Bidding wars are no longer uncommon, particularly in affluent areas of northern New Jersey (where the median home price has risen to $203,600, up 4 percent from a year earlier), Los Angeles, the San Francisco Bay area and Boston, as competing buyers push selling prices well beyond the asking price. The last time that happened was just before the stock market crash of 1987.
 
THAI BAILOUT
Japan Leads a Rescue
The International Monetary Fund and a group of Asian nations, led by Japan, agreed to a $16 billion rescue of Thailand's troubled financial system. And China, in a show of solidarity, said that it would extend $1 billion in emergency credit to Thailand. A currency crisis set off by a plunge in the baht has spread through South and Southeast Asia, threatening the region's rapid growth. The loan package is the second-largest international bailout, behind the $50 billion rescue of Mexico from the peso collapse of 1994-95. Thailand will use the money to help shore up its foreign reserves, depleted by a futile attempt to save the baht from devaluation last month.
 
A.M.A.'S DEAL
Selling a Seal of Approval
The American Medical Association, in a deal with Sunbeam, agreed for the first time to allow its name to be used in endorsing a line of products, including blood-pressure monitors, heating pads, thermometers, humidifiers and vaporizers. Royalty payments from Sunbeam, potentially millions of dollars, will provide the 150-year-old medical association more money for health, educational and research programs covering smoking, family violence, women's health and other health topics. Nevertheless, critics saw a potential conflict of interest that could compromise the association's objectivity.
 
ACQUISITIONS
An Exit From Packaging
W. R. Grace, seeking to focus on its main business of specialty chemicals, plans to divest itself of its packaging business. Essentially, Sealed Air, another big packaging company, will buy Grace's Cryovac packaging business in a complex deal valued at $5 billion. In the media industry, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the Texas buyout firm that is already has a big presence in radio, agreed to acquire the Lin Television Corporation for $1.45 billion and to assume $260 million in debt. The acquisition, the firm's biggest, is its first major venture into television. Lin Television is 45 percent owned by AT&T, which announced in December that it planned to sell. And as expected, the F.C.C. approved the $25.6 billion merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex.
 
GAS GUZZLING
Big Cars, Bigger Oil Imports
Americans are driving ever-larger vehicles and consuming record quantities of gasoline this year, with about half of it coming from imported oil. Indeed, the nation's dependence on imported oil -- an average of 9.9 million barrels a day in the first half of the year -- is also setting records, as domestic oil production slowly declines. And that could make the economy vulnerable to any unexpected surge in oil prices. Imports were less than two-thirds as large, about six million barrels a day, during the last two oil crises, in 1973-74 and 1979, both of which provoked recessions after prices soared.

LENGTH: 1619 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Montclair, N.J.;
Culture, Parks and Broad Social Diversity

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
MONTCLAIR is a magnet for young urban professionals seeking to raise their children in the suburbs but still thirsting for the culture and diversity of city life.
Although just 6.2 square miles in area, it has safe streets, abundant parks, 50 houses of worship, a well respected art museum and the 13,000-student Montclair State University. It also has some of the oldest local theater groups in the country, vibrant business districts and 38,000 trees, one for each resident of the township. 
 Its housing ranges from tiny colonials in low-income areas to $2.5 million mansions set back far from the road and hidden behind thick foliage. Many of the mansions lie along the eastern slopes of the Watchung Mountains, which form the western boundary of the town.
Perhaps one of the more unusual draws for newcomers is the racial situation. With a population that is roughly two-thirds white and one-third black, Montclair's residents take pride in the way the races get along. The residents often use the term "lighthouse" to describe the school system's policy of allowing liberal school choice as long as each school maintains a racial balance.
"We moved here because we wanted our children to grow up in a diverse, integrated town with a fully integrated school system," said Robin Ross, a lawyer, who with her husband, Dr. David Marks, a neurosurgeon, bought a four-bedroom colonial on Highland Avenue three years ago, moving from Hoboken. "At the time, we had a one-year-old daughter and were expecting twins," Ms. Ross said.
But a dispute that the couple is having with the public school system shows that the search for fairness has its price. Historically there have been sharp public disputes in Montclair over school integration, urban renewal and transportation, which often have divided people along racial lines. They are generally resolved through compromise, but sometimes they go to court.
Ms. Ross has filed suit against the school system protesting her daughter's exclusion from a pre-kindergarten program that starts in September. Although all students were being admitted three years ago when the Rosses moved in, just 175 of 285 applicants were accepted this year because of budget cuts. They were chosen on the basis of their presumed need to be prepared for kindergarten by the school system.
But Ms. Ross maintains that the effect of this was to discriminate unfairly against children from higher-income, better-educated families. "We feel cheated," she said.
The school system has a total of 6,722 students in seven elementary schools, two middle schools and Montclair High School. The system is based on "magnet" schools, each of which stresses different subjects and learning systems. For example, the kindergarten-grade 5 Bradford Academy is an information technology magnet that offers a core curriculum enhanced by courses on information gathering.
Other schools offer curriculums for the gifted or courses in science, technology and the environment. Parents may choose the magnet school, based on ability and interest of their child, with the proviso that racial balance is maintained.
According to statistics posted on the Montclair Chamber of Commerce Worldwide Web page, 10 percent of students from Montclair go to private schools, twice the New Jersey average.
EDNA Harris, interim Superintendent of Schools, called both middle schools and the high school as excellent. One middle school is a magnet for the arts; the other is oriented toward science and technology.
Of this year's graduating class of 348 in the 1,417-student Montclair High School, 85 percent went on to higher education. The high school offers advanced placement courses in biology, physics, mathematics, computer science, foreign languages, English and history.
The system is entering the final year of a $1 million, two-year technology overhaul that has already placed computers in every classroom. By the end of the next school year, all classrooms are expected to be networked together and have Internet availability. Montclair State University sends student teachers into the classrooms for experience and helps the school develop new teaching strategies.
Another town issue is transportation. Lately there have been rumblings in the black community over perceived discrimination in transportation planning. Charles L. Smith, town councilman from the mostly minority Fourth Ward, is angry about N.J. Transit's plans to link two lines that are three blocks apart in the Pine Street area. The plan, known as the Montclair Connection, has been under discussion for more than 30 years and still lacks final approval.
"The connection would save time for the passengers, but would go through 17 properties in a working-class neighborhood that doesn't use the train to go to work in New York City," Mr. Smith said.
Claims of discrimination are part of the dynamics of an unusually diverse community, in Township Manager Terence Reidy's opinion. "We have 38,000 people, with 38,000 viewpoints, and each feels it is his civic duty to express his viewpoint," he said.
One of the best-known figures in the black community, 77-year-old Rose Catchings, a Montclair resident for 44 years, said she had seen the town "open up" to minorities in housing, education and local government.
She noted that her late husband, the Rev. Dr. L. Maynard Catchings, was the first minority president of the local school board. But not enough is being done to combat crime and the drug problem in low-income areas, she said.
Disputing this, Police Chief Thomas J. Russo said that crime of all kinds has been reduced by 20 percent over the last five years to a rate of 48 reported incidents per 1,000 residents annually. There are 112 officers on the Montclair force -- 23 of them black, Chief Russo noted -- and a special task force of 9 deals with street crime. Seven officers work in the Drug Awareness Resistance Education program in the elemntary schools.
Montclair's early history foreshadowed its current diversity. The first Europeans settlers were the Speers, a Dutch family that in the 1660's built their houses on the mountain slopes in what us now Upper Montclair. Thirty years later two Englishmen, Jasper and Azariah Crane, left the overcrowded settlement of Newark and built their home two miles to the south.
The Dutch Speertown and the English Cranetown both prospered, sprawled and eventually met at the current Watchung Avenue. Although no Revolutionary War battles were fought in Montclair, General Washington had headquarters in Cranetown and General Lafayette had headquarters on the heights at Speertown.
In 1868, when the combined towns known as Montclair were part of Bloomield Township, the section seceded and formed the Township of Montclair. Five years later the Greenwood Lake Railroad, now part of the N.J. Transit line, arrived to link Montclair to Newark and New York and from 1880 to 1930 the population soared from 5,100 to 42,000. By then, most of the existing housing had been built.
ADRIANA O'Toole, a broker with Remax Professionals Realty, said that her current single-family listings ranged from $78,000 for a tiny, 2-bedroom ranch on Pine Street to $1.65 million for a 5-bedroom Tudor with a Manhattan view on Lloyd Road.
There are 6,410 rental units in 161 apartment buildings, garden apartment complexes and private homes. The largest apartment building is the 135-unit Hawthorne Towers, where rents start at $710 for some studios and go up to $1,300 for the largest 2-bedrooms, for which the building has a long waiting list.
Montclair has 10 condominium complexes with close to 500 units. Recent sales range from $15,600 for a 2-bedroom on Pine Street to $156,000 for a two-bedroom unit on the more prestigious Union Street.
Montclair has been known as a cultural center since the 1870's, when landscape artist George Inness began coming out from Manhattan to paint. Today, it is home to hundreds of artists, writers, actors and dancers. Olympia Dukakis, the actress, lives in town and is the artistic director of one of the four local theater companies.
The Montclair Art Museum, a colonnaded Greek Revival structure built in 1914, has a collection of more than 1,100 American art and relics, with a heavy emphasis on Indian items. It is open from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday and 1 to 5 P.M. Thursday and Saturday. Admission is $4 for adults, free for children 12 and under.
Montclair has seven shopping districts, four movie theaters and five supermarkets. One of the best-known local restaurants is Blue Sky on Bloomfield Avenue, with an eclectic cuisine that employs exotic spices and mushrooms and goat cheese.
The town has 18 public parks and 152 acres of parkland. There are 21 tennis courts, 7 playgrounds, 3 public swimming pools, 6 baseball diamonds and 4 basketball courts.
Among the more unusual public facilities is the Presby Memorial Iris Gardens in Mountainside Park on Upper Mountain Avenue. Dedicated in 1927, it has more than 4,000 varieties of irises and is on the National and State Registers of Historic Places.
It has two nature reserves -- the 20-acre Alonzo F. Bonsal Wildlife Preserve off Alexander Avenue and the 408-acre county-owned Eagle Rock Reservation, off Gates Avenue, known for its extensive network of nature trails.
 The Gazetteer listing with the article misstated the tax paid on a median-priced house. It is $9,500, not $5,940.
 The article also misstated the selection basis for the program. Of 172 children selected, 52 were picked based on the need to be prepared for kindergarten. The rest were chosen by what the Board of Education described as a racially balanced lottery.

AN ART COLONY'S FOUNDER: George Inness, considered one of the finest landscape artists of the late 19th century, settled in Montclair in 1884, after frequenting the area and painting there for six years. Inness, his son, George, Jr. and his son-in-law, the portrait sculptor Jonathan Scott Hartley, formed the core of Montclair's early art colony. Inness's work, which combined scenery with signs of civilization, such as trains, houses and mill dams, was a departure from the wilderness scenes painted by the Hudson River School artists. At the Paris Exposition of 1900, an important international art event, Inness was hailed by critics as the father of the new American art.

HEADLINE: Tomorrow's Gossip Today

BYLINE: By Mark Katz; Mark Katz is a speechwriter, humorist and author.

 BODY:
Matt Drudge freely admits it: sometimes he's dead wrong. "I have no editor," the 30-year-old writer says. "I can say whatever I want." But his on-line gossip sheet, the Drudge Report, is rapidly becoming a must-read for the political and entertainment elites on both coasts. -- Newsweek

THE GRUDGE REPORT
Good morning, shameless gossip addicts and on-line character assassins! Rather than ruin my entire weekend waiting for actual tattles and tidbits from Barbra Streisand's nuptials to muddy my modem, I transmit this detailed report of the wedding -- before it even happened!
Remember, you heard it here first.
 
 BARBRA-PALOOZA'S MOSH PIT
THE GRUDGE REPORT has learned the names of the lucky few who sat on the dais with the bride and groom. Those honored include: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton; Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and her date, Senator Jesse Helms; Robert Kuttner, economics columnist; Stephen B. Hawking, physicist; Donna Karan, designer and gal pal; Prof. Anita Hill, and a furloughed Susan McDougal wearing either too-much jewelry or very tasteful manacles.
The presence of the Republican Senator from North Carolina kept the politically correct audience on edge all day.
The day's most tense moment came during the wedding vows when the room was asked: "If any one person wishes to hold up this entire wedding with a petty, personal objection, let him speak now or forever hold his peace."
Capitol Hill sources tell the GRUDGE REPORT that a subpoena will be issued to a wedding guest, the novelist Joyce Carol Oates, to answer allegations that President Clinton placed his hands on hers during a festive line dance immediately following dessert.
THE GRUDGE REPORT has learned the wedding was originally scheduled for the weekend of July 12 on Long Beach Island, N.J. But it was delayed until Mr. Brolin agreed to a prenuptial agreement that gave Ms. Streisand a line-item veto and the authority to subject him to means-tested Social Security benefits beginning in 2005.
Other sources close to Ms. Streisand said she was too involved in the recent budget negotiations to concentrate on wedding arrangements at that time.
 
SEEN & HEARD
. . . All nine of the Baldwin brothers were on hand, including the previously unknown Zeppo. Their attendance was conditional on a promise to be "poster boys for good behavior."
. . . The groom's agent at I.C.M. is confident his client can now demand double scale for all future Aamco commercials.
 
WOMEN IN BROWN
At the last minute, Donna Karan outfitted the bridal party in gowns of chocolate brown in an expression of solidarity with striking United Parcel Service employees. Her decision to wear only a single spaghetti strap across the left shoulder symbolized the insufficient support provided by part-time work schedules.
Other guests, including Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sandra Feldman and Goldie Hawn were seen sporting brown ribbons and digital tracking codes.
 
ONE ENCHANTED SEMINAR
Sources reveal that Ms. Streisand and Mr. Brolin met for the first time in 1994 at a Hollywood Political Action Committee panel discussion of the Clinton Health Care Proposal.
Ms. Streisand was there to testify about the economies of scale that might be achieved under managed cooperative insurance groups while Mr. Brolin reprised his role from the popular television series "Marcus Welby, M.D." to offer insights from the medical community.
The chemistry between the two was obvious when Mr. Brolin announced, under oath, "Well, you look plenty healthy to me."
 
BRIDE COVERS THE ANGLES
The GRUDGE REPORT has learned that in addition to serving as musical arranger, choreographer, floral arranger and chief of protocol, the multi-talented Streisand also served as the wedding's director.
Guests report that the entire right half of the chapel was cordoned off so photographs of the bride could only be taken from the left side, which she prefers. However, the seating arrangement embarrassed the groom's family members, because it appeared as if they did not attend. Guests on the left side complained of the room's diffused lighting and a hazy, eclipsed view of the couple created by excessive use of gauze around the huppah.
 
AWKWARD MOMENTS
. . . Secret Service agents were visibly confused when the Marine Corps Band struck up "Hail to the Chief," after the President was already seated. No one informed them it was also the wedding's bridal march. Mr. and Mrs. Clinton later exited the room to the theme to "Hello, Dolly!"
. . . A momentary scuffle ensued when Ms. Streisand yelled at her own photographer for hounding her relentlessly throughout the wedding. Ms. Streisand's manager later agreed to pay for the damage to Ms. Leibowitz's camera.
 
GRUDGE REPORT EXCLUSIVE
The couple will honeymoon at Pocono Pine Inn, 5228 Independence Highway, East Stroudsburg, Pa., Cottage #4.

HEADLINE: P.L.O. Feels Pinch as Talks Open on Security Strategy

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Israeli and Palestinian officials alike said today that a closed-door meeting tonight could serve as an important test of the other side's willingness to ease tensions after a July 30 bombing in Jerusalem that killed 16 people.
The meeting of intelligence officials, with the United States serving as referee, marks the first under an arrangement worked out last week to share security information in a way designed to rebuild trust between Israelis and Palestinians. 
 The session was convened at a time of increasing international concern about the economic plight of the Palestinian Authority. Israel cut off nearly $40 million in payments to the Authority after the Jerusalem bombing on the ground that it was not doing enough to curb terrorism.
Under the peace accords, Israel is obligated to transfer to the Palestinians each month most of the tax, customs and other revenue it collects from Palestinian workers and consumers. This year, projected payments of more than $500 million amounted to nearly two-thirds of the Palestinian Authority's budget.
The Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and his Government have managed to pay about 60 percent of the Authority's 80,000 employees the salaries they were owed for July, American officials said today. But Mr. Arafat has been able to do so only by persuading local banks to lend the Authority tens of millions of dollars, creating what Salam Fayyad, the International Monetary Fund's representative in the West Bank and Gaza, described as a "situation that is quite worrying."
Israel has said it would resume the payments only if the Palestinians crack down on militants, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has demanded since the bombing. Aides to Mr. Netanyahu said they hoped that Palestinian officials would present evidence at tonight's meeting that such an operation had begun.
"We have reason to believe that something concrete will come out of it, but we just don't know for sure," said David Bar-Illan, the Prime Minister's communications director.
American officials have said they do not intend to comment publicly about the information shared in the meetings, and it appeared unlikely tonight that any of the other participants would do so.
It was at the urging of Dennis B. Ross, President Clinton's special envoy to the Middle East, that the Israelis and Palestinians agreed last week to share any information they have gathered about the bombing and about the measures each side has taken in response. Having an American intelligence officer on hand as an arbiter is intended to mute the bitter debate that has raged between Israelis and Palestinians since the bombing as to whether the Palestinian Authority is doing enough to combat terrorism.
Both in public and private, Mr. Ross has told the Palestinians the United States believes more should be done. But he also raised strong objections to Israel's resort to economic sanctions against the Palestinians. On Friday, the State Department spokesman, James B. Rubin, called them "counterproductive."
The United States was being represented by the C.I.A. station chief in Tel Aviv, whose identity is being withheld by American officials. Others attending tonight's meeting in the West Bank town of Ramallah were representatives of the Israeli domestic intelligence service, Shin Bet, whom Israeli officials have similarly declined to identify. The Palestinian side was to be represented by Mohammed Dahlan and Jibril Rajoub, who head the Palestinian Preventive Security forces in Gaza and the West Bank, respectively.
In one sign that the two sides have resumed some security cooperation, Israeli officials said that on Saturday night Mr. Netanyahu dispatched an envoy to thank Mr. Arafat in person for the help provided by Palestinian forces over the weekend in tracking down the killers of an Israeli taxi driver. The driver disappeared late Thursday night, and after close coordination between the two sides, his body was discovered by Palestinian police late Friday in the West Bank.
By Saturday afternoon, three young Palestinian men, who said their plan was merely to steal the man's car, had been arrested, tried and convicted of murder in a Palestinian court. All were sentenced to prison, two of them to life terms.
But for the most part, the Israelis and the Palestinians continued all weekend to display the mutual mistrust that has characterized their relationship since the July 30 bombing. Indeed, some Israeli officials suggested darkly today that, far from a gesture of goodwill, the swiftness shown by the Palestinians in convicting and sentencing those it held responsible for the slaying of the taxi driver may have been motivated mostly by a desire to prevent what surely would have been an Israeli request to extradite the men for trial in an Israeli court.
For now, Mr. Bar-Illan said today, the Government is withholding judgment about the Palestinians' handling of the case. What was most important, he said, is that the Palestinians employ the same kind of dispatch in reining in the Islamic extremists whom Israel has accused of carrying out acts of terrorism.
Israel's refusal to release money owed to the Palestinians is a clear violation of the peace accords signed by the two sides, and Mr. Arafat condemned it over the weekend as an attempt "to steal money" that "belongs to the Palestinian people."
After using similarly harsh language against the Palestinians, Mr. Netanyahu has taken a four-day vacation this weekend, and he has remained mostly out of the public eye. But other Israeli officials have continued to defend the move as necessary to persuade the Palestinians to cease their own violations of agreements under the accords to provide full security cooperation with the Israelis and to combat terrorist organizations.
One new source of friction that has emerged in recent days is a plan by Mr. Arafat to bring together most Palestinian factions for what he has called national unity meetings this week. Among those invited to the gathering are officials from two militant Islamic groups, Hamas and Islamic Jihad, regarded by Israel as terrorist organizations. Mr. Arafat has held such gatherings before, and he defended the plan today as necessary to maintain dialogue among all Palestinians, even those who are his rivals. But Mr. Bar-Illan, the Netanyahu aide, criticized the decision as amounting to "a kind of appeasement."

HEADLINE: Europe's Late Converts to Reform

 BODY:
Earlier this month, the Romanian Government shut 17 money-losing state factories, relics of the Communist era. The closure is the latest sign that Romania is braving worker protests to stick to harsh but necessary free-market reforms. Until a few months ago, Romania and Bulgaria clung to Socialist subsidies and state enterprises while other Eastern European nations liberalized their economies. In both nations, economic devastation forced a more responsible course, including the election of more democratic and competent leaders.
Until April, Bulgaria was led by former Communists hostile to reform or by conservative leaders so distracted by infighting that they did almost nothing to modernize the economy. Last winter 90 percent of the people fell below the poverty line. In 1989, Bulgaria was richer than Poland. Last winter Poland lent Bulgaria 100,000 tons of wheat. 
 After public protests forced aside the Socialists, an interim Government signed an agreement with the International Monetary Fund to end the wanton printing of money, privatize banks and state enterprises and liberalize markets. The coalition of rightist parties that won elections in April seems chastened by its past failures and has continued with reforms. Last month it introduced an austere budget and pegged its currency to the German mark. Bulgaria's politicians have seemed refreshingly willing to work together, but this political maturity may be tested because Bulgaria will probably show no substantial growth until 1999.
In Romania, reform was slowed for seven years by President Ion Iliescu, a former Communist who led a corrupt and authoritarian regime. He was defeated in November by Emil Constantinescu, a geology professor. He and his impressive Prime Minister, Victor Ciorbea, are modernizers committed to Western-style liberalism. They have improved relations with Romania's neighbors, Hungary and Ukraine, and have included the party of the Hungarian minority in the Government. Both measures were taken in part to enhance Romania's chances of joining NATO. Mr. Constantinescu also seems to have dropped Mr. Iliescu's practice of suing or prosecuting critical journalists.
The Government talked about reforms for several months and received large loans from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, but, distracted by its campaign to join NATO, it did little until the privatizations this month. The reforms will likely face serious opposition, not only from Romania's powerful labor unions, but also from politicians in the Government coalition.
The pain of subsidy cuts and closure of inefficient state enterprises will try the commitment of both nations to reform. They will need support from the West, strictly conditioned on adherence to their reform plans. The United States and Europe can also encourage the foreign investment both nations desperately need. The temptation to flinch will be great, but the two nations should not forget the misery brought by their reluctance to shed old habits.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Reborn Erie Canal

 BODY:
Historically, New York State has done a poor job of opening up its extensive marine environment for commercial and recreational use, shortchanging its citizens and economy. That may be changing. On Thursday, the Federal Government threw a lifeline to a faltering upstate project to transform the Erie Canal from a marginally useful ditch into a vibrant recreational waterway for boaters, hikers and tourists. That followed an agreement a few days earlier in which the state and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad promised to provide fishermen and boaters easier access to the Hudson River.
A rejuvenated Erie Canal could well provide the economic stimulus that upstate New York has been looking for, and lead to the resurrection of many small communities that time has passed by. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Andrew Cuomo, had just that goal in mind when he announced that his agency would provide $137 million in loans and grants to 57 cities and towns along the 524 miles that make up the Erie canal and three linked canals that stretch from Buffalo to Albany and up to Lake Champlain. Combined with funds from private sources and from the Canal Corporation, a subsidiary of the New York State Thruway Authority, the Federal funding should be enough to return life and commerce to a historic waterway that was all but abandoned a decade ago. 
 There was some interesting historical symmetry in Mr. Cuomo's announcement, as well as obvious long-term political benefits for his own career, The idea for reviving the Erie Canal first took wing during his father's tenure as Governor of New York, and the man who did more than anyone else to carry it forward was Peter Tufo, whom Mario Cuomo had named to run the New York State Thruway Authority. Mr. Tufo, well aware that the Thruway itself had helped render the 170-year-old canal obsolete, decided that one way to make amends was to create a riverine playground and, with it, a bustling waterfront economy along the canal. The Federal money will be used to help create important parts of that economy -- housing, marinas, shops, restaurants, museums and other tourist attractions.
It is also nice to see some of those tax dollars that flow in such profusion from New York to Washington flow back. Further, with the Federal money in hand, the canal project will require little from the state budget -- which is just as well, since Gov. George Pataki and his administration have never been wildly enthusiastic about an idea they felt was foisted on them by their Democratic predecessors.
Still, there is plenty that Mr. Pataki can do to demonstrate that he, too, has an interest in exploiting the state's abundant waterways for the public good. First, he can follow through on his pledge last April to add $100 million in state money to a like amount already pledged by New York City to create a waterfront park stretching from 59th Street in Manhattan to Battery Park -- a stretch once occupied by the old West Side Highway and now dominated by rotting piers. He has supported the restoration of this area, but the project needs his continuing attention.
Second, he can think anew about a controversial but useful proposal to create a 23-acre riverfront park on Manhattan's Upper West Side, adjacent to the old Penn Central railroad yards where Donald Trump plans to build high-rise apartments. Creating public access to the river would involve moving part of the existing West Side Highway inland and covering it with an ample lawn sloping to the river.
There is little enthusiasm for this idea among the Governor's associates and in the Giuliani administration, where it is seen as a luxury. Our own view is that it constitutes a rare chance to recapture a big chunk of the riverfront for recreational purposes. But it will never happen without the political will that the upstate mayors and a few of Mr. Cuomo's officials brought to an idea that seemed equally remote 10 years ago -- the rebirth of the Erie Canal.
