HEADLINE: China Considers U.S. Suggestions for Summit Harmony

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Visiting China last week, President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, made his best case to President Jiang Zemin about how to produce a substantive and image-enhancing summit meeting here at the end of October. But the Chinese are still debating necessary steps on human rights and the export of weapons and other dangerous materials, senior American officials say.
Chinese leaders, at their summer retreat of Beidaihe, are hammering out major personnel changes before next month's Party Congress, which is held only once in five years. They must decide who will replace the conservative Li Peng, who has completed his terms as Prime Minister, and what job Mr. Li will receive. 
 But the Chinese are also discussing summit meeting issues, American officials say. They add that Mr. Jiang is eager to have a useful and substantive but noncontroversial state visit to the United States to help seal his supremacy at home after the death of Deng Xiaoping.
"We're throwing ideas at them and suggesting how to bridge the gaps toward some real agreements," one senior official said. "They've got some things to think over."
In public, Mr. Berger is playing down the prospect of "dramatic breakthroughs" during the long-anticipated summit meeting, scheduled for Oct. 28. But in China, he laid out various initiatives Mr. Jiang could take to make the meeting more substantive, attract fewer protesters and reduce Congressional criticism.
Those steps include the completion of a "road map" on human rights issues, which would include the release from prison on medical grounds of noted dissidents like Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng and an agreement to let the International Committee of the Red Cross make prison visits in China. The United States also wants China to resume serious human-rights discussions with American officials and nongovernmental organizations, to invite noted American religious leaders to visit China, and to sign a United Nations Covenant on social and economic rights.
China's imprisonment of political dissidents and leaders of religious groups not sanctioned by the Government has drawn considerable anger among both human rights groups and members of Congress. And the F.B.I. is investigating charges that the Chinese funneled money into the 1996 election campaign.
"Berger made crystal clear the difficulty Jiang will face in the U.S. in terms of public, media and Congressional reaction, especially about human rights and religion," said another senior official. "He pitched it in terms of things they should be thinking about now to make the summit better, arguing that they should think of the summit as starting now and ending Oct. 30."
The Chinese leaders engaged "in great detail" in "a clear, candid discussion, with questions," another official said. "I think Jiang gets it."
The Chinese complained to Mr. Berger about pervasive anti-China sentiments in Congress, the officials said, and again denied that the Chinese Government illegally funneled money into the 1996 American elections. They also urged Mr. Berger to stem support in Washington for a more independent Taiwan.
For the summit meeting, President Clinton would like to be able to certify that China is now careful enough about nuclear exports that a 1985 nuclear cooperation agreement can finally go into effect. The pact would allow American companies like Westinghouse and General Electric to sell commercial nuclear equipment to China, including reactors.
American officials say much progress has been made on the nuclear issue, especially during Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's fourth meeting this year with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China, last month in Malaysia.
But snags remain. The United States first wants to insure that China will not share any nuclear equipment, technology or training with Pakistan or Iran. A combination of American pressure and a poor Iranian payment history led China recently to suspend a sale of two nuclear reactors, and it appears to have canceled the sale of a uranium-conversion plant that particularly worried Washington.
China has kept to its May 1996 deal with the United States not to assist any unsafeguarded nuclear program, meaning that of Pakistan. But China has not yet put into place effective export controls for nuclear materials, components and especially dual-use materials -- which could be used either for peaceful purposes or a weapons program.
In August, the Chinese State Council approved a national export control program in priniciple, the officials say, but the Americans are pressing China hard to put the program into effect and to develop a similar set of controls on dual-use items.
Finally, the Americans want China to take part in a nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty committee of equipment suppliers, known as the Zanger committee, that prepares lists of equipment that should not be exported. Mr. Qian told Ms. Albright last month that China would join and attend its first such meeting in October, the officials said.
In the past, the United States has imposed sanctions on China for nuclear and missile sales to Pakistan and Iran. On May 21, after many warnings, the United States imposed sanctions on some Chinese chemical companies for knowingly selling Iran materials that can be used to make chemical weapons. The Americans are also concerned about the ongoing sales to Iran of Chinese anti-ship cruise missiles, C-801's and C-802's, fearing that Iran's acquisition of such weapons would raise tension in the Persian Gulf.
But at a time of such political transition and uncertainty in China, American officials say, they do not expect China to make a serious offer of economic reform that would ease their way into the World Trade Organization, though the two Presidents will discuss those issues as well.

HEADLINE: Little Shaken, Small Investors Say Stock Plunges Are to Be Expected

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Bud Sadoff was sitting in front of his computer terminal last Friday when the big stock market plunge began. And his television set, not too far away, was tuned to CNBC financial news.
As he watched, the Dow Jones industrial average fell sharply, culminating in a 247-point loss, the biggest one-day selloff in almost six years.
But the 64-year-old retired engineer, who has made a hobby of tracking the market's every move, was unshaken by the news. 
 "I don't think it's all that surprising," Mr. Sadoff said in a telephone interview from his home in Chevy Chase, Md. "It'll go down another 100 or 150 points, but I'm not that nervous."
Mr. Sadoff is unfazed because market adjustments like this have repeatedly occurred in a long bull market that many analysts say began in 1982. He remembers October 1987, when the Dow plummeted 508 points in a single session, to 1,738.41. Yet just 12 days ago, the blue-chip index reached 8,259.31, a fourfold gain.
It is that kind of return that has drawn millions of first-time investors into the stock market in the last decade. And it is that kind of investor attitude that has kept the market upbeat, even in sharp downturns like the current one.
Of course, no one is willing to say that the Dow will not fall further this week, but few of the dozens of investors interviewed this weekend believe that the market is seriously ailing, or about to collapse. Indeed, many displayed a degree of self-assuredness that seemed to border on arrogance.
"Yes, a 247-point drop is a big number," said Lou Methner, 70, of Denver. "But out of how many Dow points?"
7,942.
"And what was the Dow at six months ago?"
6,988.
"Well, there you go. It's been a good run this year."
This is much the same sentiment that was expressed in March and April, when the Dow tumbled 9.8 percent over several weeks after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to slow what appeared to be an overheating economy.
But then, as now, confident investors said they considered the downturn in market prices to be a good buying opportunity.
Still, with the Dow off 6.8 percent in the last seven sessions, some people on Wall Street wonder whether the market will now see its first 10 percent decline since 1990. This is the longest stretch that the Dow has ever gone without such a drop. And some Wall Street analysts wonder whether reaching that level might depress investor sentiment.
On the whole, though, analysts are unshaken by the market's recent slide, partly because they had been calling for such a pullback. After all, the Dow was up nearly 29 percent in little more than three months, and that kind of pace cannot be sustained, they said. Broader market gauges, like the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, have also risen sharply.
To those analysts, the selloff might have been sparked by any of a number of reasons: the United Parcel Service strike, for example, which created fears of rising labor costs. Or a spurt of selling linked to the recent reduction in the capital gains tax rate. Or warnings of profit slowdowns from Coca-Cola and Gillette, which had been two of the steadiest performers.
But many individual investors pointed out that the market had been spooked before by similar concerns, only to rebound. In other words, the decline is only a mild correction, they said over and over, using the Wall Street lingo for a sharp, but temporary, price decline that interrupts a longer, upward trend. Some called it a buying opportunity, and others suggested that a short-term slump was healthy for the market.
This is the individual investor as stock market guru. And why not? While some of Wall Street's best-known strategists have been bearish for years, Americans have been piling into the stock market in droves. The explosion of money invested in mutual funds, notably in 401(k) retirement plans, is what has given the bull market its momentum.
Besides, they say, the economy is humming along, inflation seems to be absent, interest rates are stable, the dollar is king and corporate profits remain strong. There is even talk that the economy has entered a qualitatively new era, one in which all these market-friendly trends converge and can be sustained.
Of course, last week -- as the market was sliding -- mutual fund companies began reporting that the big inflows of July had slowed, and even turned around, according to Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, a tracking service. About $3.2 billion was redeemed from stock funds last week, the biggest pullback since the late-winter selloff. But many investors interviewed this weekend said that they had sold some shares simply to take profits after the recent gains and to wait out the current downturn -- not to flee.
Indeed, it is that kind of investor -- investors like Robert Boisselle -- who are powering the bull run. Mr. Boisselle, a retired real estate broker in Redding, Calif., tunes in to financial news every day, and calls up his stock portfolio on the Internet each evening. His advice to friends: stay the course.
"We had a pretty fat correction on Friday," he said. "But I've been through corrections before. In fact, I look forward to them as a cleansing of the market."
Vince Capurso, a tax lawyer in New York, also sees therapeutic effects in a quick, sharp downturn. In fact, for more than a year, he has been slightly bearish on the market, worrying that his fellow investors were too euphoric.
"I've got a friend who, at 50 years old, retired and got a severance package," he said. "He took that money and invested it, and he's been making 30 or 40 percent a year. Now he has a couple million in the stock market, and he wants to be a money manager. He thinks it's so easy to make money, but the fact is, these are the golden years."
In fact, Mr. Capurso said, four of his six closest friends all want to quit their jobs to become money managers. A nice correction, he said, might temper such exuberance.
While Mr. Capurso frowns on overly optimistic market sentiment, he believes that the heightened interest in the market will help buoy its long-term prospects and prevent a small downturn from becoming a collapse. Ordinary investors, he reasons, are more sophisticated than ever, aided by technological advances that bring Main Street and Wall Street closer.
Throughout the country, investors are trading shares over the Internet, tuning in to financial news networks and even wearing beepers to track companies that plan to split their stock; these investors believe that splits augur well for a company's future, and they quickly buy those shares on such news.
Indeed, market news just will not go away. CNBC superimposes minute-by-minute Dow industrial figures, allowing viewers access to every uptick or downtick. CNBC can also be seen by passersby in Times Square, on a gigantic outdoor television screen.
But that is not all. Customers at Brooks Brothers, while hunting for a nice new blazer, can check stock quotes at a Bloomberg financial news terminal. The Regency Hotel in New York also has a Bloomberg terminal, in its restaurant.
There are also scores of Internet sites devoted to the markets, like Wall Street City, or the Silicon Investor for technology-stock buffs. And on the World Wide Web, stock talkers were debating over the weekend whether the market was primed for a full-fledged crash.
On a Web site devoted to the market, one disturbed investor posted a message that read: "In the past two weeks, the Dow is down 7 percent. I am sick and tired of people calling this a technical correction. The fact is the market is crashing."
But another replied: "I think it is a normal (probably overdue) correction. Why do you think we will have a crash? What economic/political/financial event has given you this belief?"
As for Mr. Sadoff, the unperturbed engineer, he said he would wait out the downturn and then sink more cash into the market. "I've been lightening up on stocks a little in the past few weeks," he said. "But when the charts start to show it's safe, I'll start sticking my toe in the water again."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Dark-Horse Albanese Seeks His Stride

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Sal F. Albanese spent just three minutes the other day discussing his mayoral candidacy in the basement of a Greenwich Village church, finally giving up after trying to compete for attention in a clamorous room filled with elderly New Yorkers more interested in the 75-cent plates of chicken, corn and watermelon than in a serving of mayoral politics.
"Does anyone have a question for our mayoral candidate here?" asked Caryn Resnick, the moderator of the "Ninth Annual Political Picnic" at Our Lady of Pompei Church on Carmine Street. She scanned the steamy basement, filled with delegates from three local senior-citizen groups, most of them Democrats and more than a few wearing Giuliani buttons. 
 "We have no questions for our mayoral candidate?" Ms. Resnick continued. She paused again. "Are there any questions?" There were not, so Mr. Albanese smiled cordially, thanked his audience, and gamely proceeded to work the room before heading for the stairs.
Six months ago, Mr. Albanese, a personable Councilman from Bay Ridge with an iconoclastic voting record and some definite ideas about ways to defeat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, loomed as potentially the most unpredictable force in the mayoral contest.
He appeared, on paper at least, the perfect challenger to Mr. Giuliani: an Italian Catholic from a working-class Brooklyn neighborhood, a former public-school teacher, a liberally inclined Council member who had represented one of the most conservative districts in the city for 15 years. So it was that Mr. Albanese seemed to be in the best tradition of the dark-horse candidate: the unconventional scrapper, poised to topple first the Democratic front-runner, Ruth W. Messinger, and then the Mayor himself.
Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party leader and one of Mr. Giuliani's main political advisers, said that he had long feared that Democrats, tepid at the prospect of a Messinger candidacy, would surprise Mr. Giuliani and select Mr. Albanese in the Sept. 9 primary. "Albanese would be the stronger candidate," Mr. Harding said.
But in politics, what looks good in the script often does not look quite as good on the stage -- and particularly, it seems, when it comes to the understated and underfinanced Mr. Albanese.
With just three weeks to go until the primary, Mr. Albanese's candle remains unlighted. He is still the little-known Councilman from Brooklyn, trailing in polls and, to his constant irritation, struggling to break into the pages of the city's newspapers or onto the television news shows with his singular message: a dramatic curb in campaign contributions and a warning that New York is in danger of becoming a city of two economic classes, the rich and the poor.
 Mr. Albanese's best hope may be a burst of late television advertising. But he cannot afford it: fund-raising efforts have been so lackluster that he will be forced this week to head to Buffalo to produce advertisements -- it is cheaper to film there than in the city where he wants to be mayor.
New York primaries are always unpredictable, and Mr. Albanese said that a combination of factors could thrust him into the lead after Labor Day. Those factors could include the lack of enthusiasm for Ms. Messinger, a strong showing by the Rev. Al Sharpton -- particularly after the attention he received in the days following the allegations of police brutality in Flatbush -- and what Mr. Albanese described as the compelling rationale of his own candidacy.
"We're beginning to climb and she's beginning to decline," Mr. Albanese said, referring to Ms. Messinger. "I happen to believe that even though we're working hard -- we're working seven days a week -- the bottom line is people still aren't paying attention. I believe the last three weeks will be critical.
"I'm very happy with the way our campaign is being conducted," he said. "We're raising some very important issues that the other candidates aren't raising."
But as the primary approaches, Mr. Albanese may be almost alone with that perception. "Potentially, it is there: but it would take a massive, massive Messinger mistake at this point," said Hank Morris, a Democratic consultant. Indeed, talk about Mr. Albanese has shifted -- if unfairly -- from what might have been to what went wrong.
"He was fresh," said Henry A. Sheinkopf, a consultant who worked for the now-ended mayoral campaign of Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President. "He was entirely candid. He was certainly the least disingenuous quantity I've seen in politics for along time, and he was an outspoken ethnic who appeared to relate to people in the outer boroughs. But it never jelled."
Mr. Albanese has heard these tidings, yet pushes ahead optimistically, alternating between bursts of frustration and wry humor. So when the sound system failed in Brownsville after he had waited 30 minutes for the chance to speak for 30 seconds (someone had stepped on the plug), Mr. Albanese just grinned, if tightly. "A bad omen," he said. And when State Assemblyman William F. Boyland of Brooklyn introduced him as someone with the "dubious distinction of running for mayor," Mr. Albanese hiked an eyebrow and muttered to himself: "Did you hear that? Dubious distinction?"
The other morning at Times Square, Mr. Albanese even seemed unfazed as many people rushed past him, ignoring his pleas for them to stop so he could register them to vote. He did not even seem to mind that a young aide in aviator sunglasses kept bellowing at his back, "This is your last chance! This is your last chance!" -- a reference not to Mr. Albanese's electoral prospects but to the voter registration deadline.
"Here's my analysis, and I know the city pretty well," Mr. Albanese said as his campaign van bounced along the Belt Parkway. "If you got problems in your own base -- which Ruth has -- and then she doesn't have a real appeal in the outer boroughs, and to top that off, she was banking on a heavy African-American vote, which isn't going to be there . . . " Mr. Albanese ended the sentence with a "Well-what-do-you-think-is-going-to-happen?" shrug of the shoulders.
Still, a few hours later, Mr. Albanese let his poise slip for a moment, turning in his seat to inquire, "Will you be shocked if I pull it out?"
A number of things are working against him. He is not a particularly accomplished campaigner; on the stump, his words come out in a quick and mumbled monotone. Mr. Albanese's lack of campaign funds reinforces his indistinct image. While Ms. Messinger drives in a van filled with six aides, Mr. Albanese travels with a single assistant, who drives the car, guides the candidate from apartment complex recreation rooms to street fairs, and hands out literature.
To succeed, observers say, Mr. Albanese has to find a way to emerge from two shadows at once: Ms. Messinger's and Mr. Giuliani's. And he has to do that as a City Councilman who is barely known outside his own neighborhood.
In truth, Mr. Albanese has distinguished himself with the kind of explicit and contrary campaign themes that are rarely heard from Ms. Messinger (though such ideas are often floated by Mr. Sharpton).
His central argument is that campaign contributions should be sharply reduced. "It's one of the big issues in the campaign," he said. "The system is polluted. The system is being driven by big money so that what happens is when you get there, you simply can't run the city properly."
Mr. Albanese has said he would support some tax increases -- like a change in the city's tax structure that would increase the tax rate on the wealthy. "People are willing to pay a little more if they can get something in return," he said.
And Mr. Albanese's style, if low-key, can be endearing to voters more accustomed to the higher-voltage breed of politician. "I wish he were running for another office so I could vote for him," said Anita Schmidt, a Democrat from Manhattan, who plans to vote for Mr. Giuliani. "He seems like a fine, decent man."
Not surprisingly, Mr. Albanese has his dark moments. He refers to Ms. Messinger as the "alleged front-runner," and complains that Ms. Messinger's excitable and quotable press secretary, Leland T. Jones, gets more public attention then he does.
He is most displeased with the media, which he describes as biased in favor of the Mayor. "I happen to believe that Messinger is the weakest candidate against Giuliani and I think there are some in the media who are trying to prop up Messinger so she can be Giuliani's opponent," Mr. Albanese said. "I just don't think we're getting a fair shake."
But Mr. Albanese endures, and people seem to notice that -- though it remains to be seen if that will count for much on Election Day.
"Giuliani is a shoo-in," said Sylvia Seidman, a Democrat and a retired school teacher who lives in Chelsea, after shaking Mr. Albanese's hand at the Greenwich Village church. "But this guy is trying so hard, I have to give him credit. He may not win, but maybe next time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sal F. Albanese, a mayoral candidate, marching during the recent Puerto Rican Day parade. With the Democratic primary approaching, Mr. Albanese, who trails Ruth W. Messinger in the polls, is having trouble rousing enthusiasm among voters. (Frances Roberts)

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Dr. Doom Becomes Dr. Pangloss

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Every economist gets used to the ridicule. We peddle the "dismal science." We know the price of everything, but the value of nothing. Two economists produce three conflicting opinions. But now, courtesy of researchers at Harvard, comes news that it is the economists who think the nation is in fine shape and everyone else who predicts doom and gloom. To a practitioner, this turnabout feels good.
The dismal science crack came from Thomas Carlyle, reacting in part to the late-18th-century nostrums of Thomas Malthus, who predicted that population growth would eventually drive wages down to starvation levels. In the process, rents would rise, making landlords rich and planting the seeds of ferocious, unending class warfare. It was definitely a dismal vision. It was also spectacularly wrong. Yet every few years another group of economists resurrects the Malthusian vision, re-establishing economists' reputation as doom-sayers. 
 But the economists' gloomy reputation goes beyond these Malthusians. We compulsively remind people to eat their spinach. Where others fantasize about the benefits from this or that government subsidy or regulation, we wallow miserably in contemplation of the costs. Ordinary human beings ponder the beauty of perfectly clean air over the Grand Canyon. Economists calculate the extra dollars it would cost to remove 1 percent of the ozone that fouls the air. The profession, in short, is methodologically small bore, and rarely exhilarating.
But perhaps all that is changing. The poll by Harvard, the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation and The Washington Post shows massive role reversal. Almost 30 percent of the ordinary public thinks that living standards will fall over the next five years. But -- and pay attention here -- less than 10 percent of economists agree. In the survey, no economists believe that technology hurts the economy. (Who says no two ever agree?) By contrast, nearly one-fifth of the general public thinks that technology actually hurts.
Indeed, economists nowadays seemingly see good everywhere. Almost 90 percent think trade makes us richer, and over half even think downsizing is good for the economy. Almost a third of the public fears trade and a large majority condemns downsizing.
One possible explanation for this odd switch is that the public is often misled by gloomy and outdated information. At the time of the survey, 1996, unemployment was at a 7-year low and inflation at a 30-year low. But many citizens did not know these facts. Less than a third of the public knew that the economy had been recovering and adding jobs. Seventy percent of the public, but only about 20 percent of the economists, believed, incorrectly, that family living standards had been on the decline.
I have to admit, however, that an alternative explanation of these figures strengthens the canard that economists know the price of everything and the value of nothing. Economists take solace from the numbers: average incomes are rising. But because of soaring inequality that concentrates winnings in relatively few hands, many families see little or none of the gain. The economists are right on the numbers, but the families may be right on the facts. O.K., so we may have made another mistake. At least this time, we are the ones who are smiling. MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

This proposal and a similar one between the Evangelical Lutherans and the Episcopal Church are regarded as the most significant efforts in ecumenical cooperation in years. A10

HEADLINE: Israelis Turn Military Skills Into Software Export Boom

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: GIVATAYIM, Israel

 BODY:
Sharon Carmel and his old army buddies used to work on computerized battlefield simulations when they were in the service. Now heading their own software company in this Tel Aviv suburb, they plan a multimedia blitz on the Internet, hoping their software will be the underpinning of a new generation of sites on the World Wide Web.
In Ramat-Gan, another of the suburbs ringing Tel Aviv, Gil Shwed will not say much about where he served in the army, but he does allow that he learned there about linking computer networks with different levels of security clearance. Now he presides over Check Point Software Technologies Ltd., a software company that is the world market leader in creating the corporate firewalls that are an essential element of Internet security. 
 People like Mr. Carmel and Mr. Shwed are the reason why the software industry has boomed in Israel in recent years, fueled by the skills of army-trained computer engineers. Along with Russian immigrants and native Israeli graduates of top-flight schools, engineers who learned their trade in military jobs -- which they won't discuss -- are bringing a combination of discipline, obsession and anarchic inventiveness to a business that thrives in that kind of environment.
Software is Israel's fastest growing export industry, the engine of an expanding high-technology sector that in turn has powered the Israeli economy's 6 percent average annual growth rate in the 1990's.
And the software industry not only gets a good share of its manpower from engineering divisions of the Israeli military; the technology at some Israeli-run companies was developed in the defense industry.
Sales figures for other American software companies with Israeli roots -- a growing group that includes Net Manage, based in Cupertino, Calif., Tecnomatix Technologies Ltd., of Herzliya, Israel, and Novi, Mich., and Geotek Communications Inc. of Montvale, N.J. -- have climbed over the past three years, although their share prices have been volatile.
Software is still no rival to the largest of Israel's traditional exports. (Polished diamond exports earned $5.2 billion last year.) But high-technology exports as a whole are $5.5 billion, more than a quarter of the $20.5 billion total Israeli exports in 1996, according to the Israeli Trade and Industry Ministry. Software exports totaled $198 million in 1994, $287 million in 1995 and $413 million in 1996.
The software produced by the new Israeli companies ranges from applications suited to new media games to highly specialized software development tools. But no matter what the product, it often owes its origins to the Israeli military.
For instance, Mr. Carmel and two friends from a high-technology army unit formed their company, Geo-Interactive Media Group, three years ago along with a veteran business executive. Mr. Carmel says the bonds forged during military service have given them a competitive edge.
"We have a soul, not only structure," he said. "We worked together on the same projects in the army, often under pressure, and we're very close-knit. We're very fast, and interest in our products is accelerating."
Mr. Carmel, 26, and his partners also gained vital expertise during their army service in a unit that specialized in simulations of combat zones. After their discharges in 1993, they went into separate business ventures but joined forces in 1994.
They began by producing multimedia CD-ROM titles, working out of an apartment in Tel Aviv. Later they used their knowledge of data compression and transmission technology to create software that would allow people creating Web sites to make their multimedia features more easily accessible to the average Web surfer.
Geo-Interactive nearly doubled its sales last year. to $1.4 million. Its 1996 public offering on the AIM London Stock Exchange -- which specializes in small-capitalization issues -- brought in $19.2 million.
Geo-Interactive's flagship product is called Emblaze Creator -- a program unveiled last March that enables people to send interactive multimedia over the Internet that can be seen and heard in real time with no more than a standard Web browser. Video, animation and audio can be received directly without downloading the materials or installing special software.
Other Israeli companies tend to follow the strategy of trying to spot and mine niches not filled by large international companies.
Vocaltec Communications Ltd., also based in Herzliya, produced the first Internet phone in 1995, making it possible to conduct international and long-distance calls for the price of an Internet connection. Its 1996 sales revenue, however, was still less than $10 million.
Another Israeli company, VDOnet, based in Herzliya with offices in Palo Alto, Calif., specializes in live video broadcasts on the Internet. And earlier this month, the Microsoft Corporation selected VDOnet to help it provide live video capabilities for networks carried over cable modems or other broadband delivery systems.
In the area of Internet security, Mr. Shwed's Check Point has about 40 percent of the world market in internet firewall programs, which protect corporate networks from outside intruders.
The secret of Israel's software successes, however, does not lie entirely in military connections. The country has a reservoir of skilled computer engineers and programmers who have studied in schools like the Technion, Israel's leading technology institute.
In addition, the arrival of more than 700,000 immigrants from the former Soviet Union since 1990 has increased the pool of computer experts. Another core of expertise is provided by returning Israelis who have studied in the United States and worked in Silicon Valley.
Israel has the world's highest percentage of scientists, with 135 engineers per 10,000 citizens, according to the Israel Yearbook and Almanac. The United States has 85 per 10,000.
Israel's small size and population permit easier links and more familiarity between people who can form working teams to design software, while the Internet bridges the distance to foreign clients, serving as both a marketing tool and technical support system.
"Israel is almost exactly the right size," said Ed Mlavsky, president of Gemini Capital Fund Management, an Israeli venture capital group. "If a country's too small, there's not enough diversity, and if it's too big, there aren't enough connections between people. There's also an innovative attitude here, a nonconformity in methods which in some senses is undisciplined."
Mr. Shwed, who, with two partners, founded Check Point, agreed that there was an Israeli tendency for unorthodox experimentation.
"Israelis have a tendency to work fast, to improvise and find solutions," he said. "That's the way the state was created here from zero. There's also a lack of business culture here. People don't do things by the book and they're willing to break the rules, which can be an advantage. The lack of a local market has forced people to think globally and create universal products."
Mr. Shwed's own story is a case in point. A computer whiz-kid who during his army service set up and linked computer networks with different levels of security classification, he spotted a golden market opportunity with the growth of the Web in 1993.
Closeting himself with his colleagues in an apartment for three hot summer months, he worked with them to develop a prototype of a firewall security program that served as a basis for their company. In 1996, Check Point's sales totaled $32 million, Mr. Shwed said.
The software boom in Israel has its parallel in the growing Israeli presence in the United States.
The Mercury Interactive Corporation, for example, an Israeli company that makes automated software testing tools, has located its corporate headquarters in Sunnyvale, Calif., while maintaining research and development operations in Israel. Aryeh Finegold, Mercury's founder and chief executive, divides his time between Israel and Silicon Valley. The company reported $54.6 million in sales in 1996.
Geo-Interactive has a U.S.-based subsidiary, Geo-Interactive Publishing Inc., handling sales, marketing, distribution and technical support, as well as advertising and public relations. Check Point has its United States headquarters in Redwood City, Calif.
One of the biggest of the American offshoots of Israeli companies, Geotek Communications, is working with I.B.M., which announced in June it would provide $200 million in equipment for Geotek's wireless networks and would jointly market Geotek's services.
Geotek's specialty is communications software that allows small companies with fleets of vehicles, like local delivery services or even hotel chains with airport shuttles, to communicate with drivers and track fleets using satellite tracking technology.
The products, which helped bring the company $93 million in sales in 1996, are based on software licensed to Geotek from Rafael, the research and development arm of the Israeli Defense Ministry.
The reaction of American high-technology companies to these emerging companies has been threefold: In some cases, Microsoft and I.B.M. have invested in or underwritten their technologies, in others, they have eclipsed Israeli companies by coming out with competing products, and both companies now operate research and development facilities in Haifa, Israel.
Marketing may be the weak point of Israeli software companies. "The commercial successes of Israeli software firms are smaller than they seem," said Nisso Cohen, who heads the Israeli office of the International Data Corporation, which conducts market surveys.
"Israel is a significant world player from a technological point of view, but in revenues its share is very small," Mr. Cohen said. "In 20 years, virtually no Israeli start-up company has succeeded in reaching $100 million in annual sales. They haven't invested enough in marketing."

HEADLINE: Congress Whittles Away Power of Capital's Mayor

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
In these financially strapped times for the District of Columbia, this was a rare moment for celebration. Officials from a group of private health care organizations gathered at a city clinic the other day to announce programs that would provide medical insurance for 1,000 children.
Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. was the scheduled guest speaker, but he had not arrived for the start of the ceremony. "We'll go ahead, anyway," said a woman at the lectern. "It's too hot to wait." He never made it. 
 The event seemed emblematic of the plight of a mayor who has served 15 of the last 19 years yet now presides as little more than a titular leader whom many District residents blame for the city's downfall.
The real power now belongs to Andrew F. Brimmer, an economist and former board member of the Federal Reserve who heads the financial control board created by Congress two years ago to correct decades of inefficiency in the city government.
Through a swirl of legislative action since Republicans won control of Congress in 1994, powers of the Mayor have steadily shifted to the board, which is to remain in control until the District has a balanced budget four years in a row. In the latest measure, the budget bill signed by President Clinton this month included a provision that gives the board the right to reject anyone the Mayor appoints as head of a major municipal agency.
While Mr. Brimmer's schedule last week included a meeting with parents who were outraged about an announcement that the public schools would open three weeks late because of roof repairs, Mr. Barry greeted National Black Deaf Advocates, the Fishing Buddies and students from the Pure Love Alliance, a group of young people who advocate no sex before marriage.
Even so, the Mayor has begun using his weakened state to political advantage, denouncing legislation that he says has "raped democracy and freedom" and criticizing anyone who would deny District residents the basic right of representation.
Many of his supporters think the power shift will only make him a martyr, catapulting him to a fifth term next year if he seeks re-election. He has steadfastly refused to say whether he will, and at his weekly news conference on Wednesday, someone asked, "With no powers, what is the point of even holding elections next year?"
Mr. Barry did not answer the question. But other remarks suggest that a re-election campaign is well under way, with a little something for everybody. At his news conference, he carefully explained how he would fight further Congressional intrusion in the city, a strategy that plays especially well to blacks, while cooperating with the control board to improve the local government, a promise intended to blunt criticism that he had caused the city's ills.
"I can do both," he said.
Whether he can or not, the promise is providing Mr. Barry a rather large soapbox, one he uses liberally to lambaste the budget bill provision that removed his remaining powers, and its Republican sponsor, Senator Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina, who heads the District appropriations subcommittee. The Mayor accused Mr. Faircloth of using the provision "to cover what he really wanted to do: promote the Republican agenda to take away power in the District of Columbia."
As evidence, Mr. Barry cited a House ruling in 1995 that stripped the vote of Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District Representative, a Democrat; the control board's appointment of trustees to assume the powers of an elected board to run the public school system; and the right of the control board to approve all city contracts.
"The Faircloth amendment," Mr. Barry said, "takes democracy further down the drain."
Mr. Faircloth, in an interview, strongly defended the need for management reform in the city government, saying, "It was glaringly evident the city was spiraling into a catastrophic state."
He also dismissed Mr. Barry's criticism, including his oft-repeated assertion that the provision "has raped democracy and freedom" in the city.
"I've heard so many meaningless statements from Marion Barry that one more doesn't matter," Mr. Faircloth said. "It's airy persiflage."
By now, it almost does not matter which of them might be more persuasive in such a dialogue. The mere engagement has given Mr. Barry what some residents perceive as the moral high ground in fighting for home rule, the limited self-government that Congress granted the city almost 25 years ago.
"In terms of the big picture, he's got the right platform in home rule," said Clifford E. Barnes, a lawyer who attended the clinic ceremony. "That plays pretty well around the city. It's an issue that many folks can sympathize with."
During the week the budget bill passed, more than a dozen people in the District were arrested protesting the shift of power from elected officials. Others disrupted a control board meeting.
As reporters entered the room where Mr. Barry's news conference was held last week, fliers were stacked on a table. On one side, the words "War Zone" were written over a map of the District; the other side promoted Friday night rallies to protest actions by Congress.
"I didn't pass them out," Mr. Barry said when asked why the fliers were at his news conference.
In playing to those who regard him as the core of the problem as a former drug user who lost control of the city in the 1980's and spent six months in prison for cocaine possession, Mr. Barry has been quick to deflect blame for the city's current problems. They have included a lack of money to pay for better human services, to fix school buildings in shambles, to add police officers and to fill potholes in the streets.
His argument has always been this: Despite his personal drama, he returned to office in 1994, inheriting a $335 million budget deficit from his predecessor, Sharon Pratt Kelly, whom he defeated soundly in the Democratic primary.
"I've been asked about this a dozen times," Mr. Barry said, referring to his role in the District's financial problems. "I initiated a management reform plan on Day One. It was Senator Faircloth who had an agenda, long before he took over. He's using me as cover, as an excuse."
Some residents are not swayed. Sandra Seegars, coordinator of the Committee to Recall Mayor Barry, said the budget bill had only helped her group collect more voter signatures. The group needs about 30,000, 10 percent of the number of registered voters, for a recall vote, and so far has about half that number. Ms. Seegars, who lives in Mr. Barry's ward, said the tide was turning against him, for many of the reasons the committee lists on its Web site under "50 Reasons to Dump Barry."
"If the election were held today and he was on the ballot with Carol Schwartz," she said, referring to the Republican Mr. Barry defeated by 55 to 41 percent of the vote in the 1994 general election, "she would win."
In any case, the conflict is attracting interest well beyond the city as a sad tale of a national capital. In addition to the usual reporters who cover his weekly news conferences, journalists from England, Canada, Australia and Japan attended the latest. All were eager to learn how Mr. Barry was dealing with political emasculation.
With the election more than a year off and dozens of problems yet to be solved, it is not entirely clear whether Mr. Barry can ride his carefully planned strategy into another term. Many city voters, like Rosie Faulkner, a 20-year-old student at Johnson C. Smith College in North Carolina, have mixed feelings.
"I still love him," Ms. Faulkner said. "He gave me my first job, as an assistant to an elementary-school teacher when I was 14, and I appreciated that. But he's the Mayor. The city's going downhill now, and he should be held accountable."

HEADLINE: CLINTON PRESSING 2 SIDES TO SETTLE THE U.P.S. STRIKE

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Monday, Aug. 18

 BODY:
President Clinton, making his strongest comments so far about the importance of reaching a settlement in the United Parcel Service strike, on Sunday called on the teamsters' union and the company to end a 14-day walkout that has hamstrung the delivery of packages nationwide.
"This strike is beginning to hurt not only the company but its employees and the people who depend on it, and I think they ought to redouble their efforts to settle the strike and they ought to do it today," Mr. Clinton said before heading to Martha's Vineyard for a vacation. 
 After more than 60 hours of nearly nonstop talks, the two sides recessed their negotations shortly after midnight, and agreed to meet again at noon today.
Several Government, union and company officials said Sunday was a crucial day for the negotiations.
The officials said that after the nearly nonstop talks, the two sides were exhausted. Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president, has slept four hours since talks began at 9 A.M. on Friday, an aide said.
After arriving at Martha's Vineyard, Mr. Clinton suggested that an agreement might be reached soon.
"It's my gut feeling they'll settle," he told a reporter. "It's a good deal. It will set a precedent for unions."
He said that the teamsters had public sentiment on their side but that the support would turn with time. Holding his thumb and forefinger close together, he said, "They're that close."
Some Administration officials say they fear that Mr. Clinton will face far more pressure to intervene to end the strike if the walkout drags on for several more weeks. A protracted strike could present numerous economic and political problems for the White House by slowing economic growth and creating tensions with organized labor, which does not want the President to intervene.
The leaders of U.P.S. and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters said on Sunday for the first time since the strike began on Aug. 4 that progress had been made at the bargaining table. But both sides also said they had a distance to go before reaching a settlement for the company and its 185,000 drivers, loaders and sorters.
"There has been some movement," Mr. Carey said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
Mr. Clinton was briefed on Sunday on the negotiations by the White House deputy counsel, Bruce R. Lindsey, and by Labor Secretary Alexis Herman. Ms. Herman has sat in at the talks and has repeatedly urged the two sides to keep talking at the Hyatt Regency Washington Hotel until they agree on a new contract.
The strike involves more workers than any other walkout in over a decade and has largely shut down U.P.S., the world's largest parcel delivery company, which handles 12 million items on a normal weekday.
The effects of the strike have been widespread. Blood banks have complained of being forced to destroy blood because they have not been able to ship it quickly enough.
Some factories have laid off workers because components they need have not been delivered. Many school systems are worried that they will not receive books before the school year begins.
Also appearing on "Meet the Press," James P. Kelly, the chairman of U.P.S., said the company had made a generous offer to the workers. Mr. Kelly insisted that the strike was unnecessary and had severely damaged the company's customers.
Mr. Kelly repeated his plea that Mr. Clinton seek an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act to end the strike. The act allows Presidents to seek injunctions when a strike imperils the nation's health or safety -- a standard that White House officials have said has not yet been met.
"This strike," Mr. Kelly said, "has had a devastating impact on many of our customers."
Mr. Carey again insisted that the main issue in the dispute was U.P.S.'s widespread use of part-time workers, a group the union says earns too little to live on. Mr. Kelly, on the other hand, boasted that the company's part-time workers, who he said earn $11 an hour on average, made more money than the average full-time worker in the nation.
Other subjects in dispute are pay, subcontracting and the company's demand to pull out of the teamsters' multi-employer pension plans and start a new pension plan.
In recent days, business organizations have stepped up calls for President Clinton to seek an injunction.
"The President's comments today," said Frank Coleman, a spokesman for the United States Chamber of Commerce, "show that he is beginning to recognize what small business has known for at least a week or longer, that this strike is having a devastating impact on their ability to do business."
John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, argued vigorously against invoking Taft-Hartley.
"It's still not a national emergency, and it's not a safety and health issue," Mr. Sweeney said on Sunday on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." "I believe that the President is committed to the right of workers to bargain collectively and also their right to strike. And I think the fact that the parties have been meeting so intensely over the past couple of days is an indication that the collective bargaining process can work."
Thomas E. Mann, the director of government studies at the Brookings Institution, said in a phone interview, "My reading is that we're still some time away from sufficient pressure from the economy and the business community that would lead the President to reconsider his decision to basically stay on the sidelines."
Mr. Mann said that at least in the short term, it was an easy decision for the President, especially with the American public so solidly supporting the strikers.
Former Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, on "Fox News Sunday," offered this view of the U.P.S. strike: "What's happening here -- and it's happening in a lot of other companies as well -- we have now very high corporate profits. We also have very tight labor markets and we have a long expansion in which many blue-collar workers have not seen their pay and benefits go up, and this is an incendiary combination."

HEADLINE: Hopeful, Poignant Mood at India-Pakistan Border

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: WAGAH BORDER CROSSING, India, Aug. 14

 BODY:
At dusk every evening, crowds of Indians and Pakistanis gather on either side of a painted line across a narrow road here in Punjab, a region that was divided when British India was partitioned into the separate countries of India and Pakistan.
The line, about a foot thick, is called Zero Point, and it marks a frontier that stretches north and south from here for 1,250 miles. 
 Because of the bitter legacy of Aug. 14, 1947, when 200 years of British rule ended with a bloodbath among Hindus, Sikhs and Muslims enraged by the partition, this is the only road crossing point between countries with a combined population of 1.1 billion. Sometimes, people try to cross on foot between the watchtowers visible across the wheat fields, and sometimes frontier guards shoot them dead.
Zero Point is a place of perplexing ambiguities, and they tell something about how relations between India and Pakistan are changing as the two nations celebrate their 50th anniversaries.
The crosscurrents are most evident at dusk, when the two armies stage a flag-lowering ceremony that reflects the defiance and nostalgia, as well as the official rigidities and popular yearnings, of two peoples sundered from each other when independence half a century ago created Pakistan as a homeland for Indian Muslims unwilling to chance life in an India dominated by Hindus.
These crosscurrents in the two countries are attracting fresh attention, and not only because of the anniversary. India and Pakistan have new Prime Ministers -- I. K. Gujral in New Delhi and Nawaz Sharif in Islamabad -- and they have begun a new effort at detente.
Both have used the anniversary to say they want peace, more relaxed borders, arms reductions and increased trade.
But in almost the same breath, the two leaders, in separate interviews in their capitals this week, set conditions that seem likely to thwart their efforts.
The main issue, now as it has been for 50 years, is the divided territory of Kashmir, the Himalayan region of snow-capped mountains and lakes just north of here. Two of the three wars between India and Pakistan were fought over Kashmir.
Mr. Gujral said that while he wanted the border between the countries to become "very soft, like Canada and the U.S.A.," there could be no territorial changes, because "we must respect that partition was final."
But Mr. Sharif was emphatic that progress hinged on concessions on Kashmir. "We would like to repose trust and confidence in each other," he said. "This is possible, but outstanding problems have to be resolved first."
Something of the conflicting attitudes is apparent at Zero Point. First, soldiers from the two countries engage in a mirror-image minuet that involves members of the flag parties marching at high speed to the frontier strip, with a high-stepping, stamping gait, then pausing inches from each other, hands on hips, exchanging haughty stares.
As crickets chirp in the trees, the Indian flag of white, orange and green, with its spinning-wheel emblem, comes down inch by inch, precisely in tandem with Pakistan's dark green banner with its crescent moon and star.
But then, after buglers from the two sides sound the retreat, another mood takes over. As the steel gates on either side of Zero Point are closed, Indians and Pakistanis who have gathered to watch the ceremony rush forward to stare at each other across a space of about 15 feet. Since most Indians and Pakistanis who get visas are required to travel by rail or air, leaving Zero Point to be used mainly by foreigners and freight traffic, this is as close as the two peoples get.
Some wave, some take photographs, but most remain silent, as if mesmerized by being so close yet so far.
For those with a sense of history, there is also the memory of the tragedies that unfolded along this stretch of road in 1947. Then, it was choked with bullock carts and migrant families on foot, struggling to escape the slaughter by frenzied mobs that eventually killed at least half a million people in Punjab and Bengal, the other region split at partition.
For a few moments after the flag-lowering, the Indian and Pakistani military commanders at Zero Point relax together between the gates, chatting, laughing and at one point even holding hands.
Then the soldiers move forward again, shouting in Hindi and Urdu, the predominant languages of India and Pakistan. "Move back!" they say. "Move back! This is a border!" The crowds melt back into the darkness settling over the two separate Punjabs, each now a province of its respective country.
For Paramjit Singh, 37, a Sikh who is a cloth trader in Amritsar, an Indian city 15 miles east of Zero Point, being at the flag ceremony was a chance to reach out to his family's past in Lahore, a Pakistani city 15 miles west of the border.
"What is Lahore now?" he asked wistfully.
On the other side, Altaf Rashid, 50, an electronics merchant from Lahore, had a similar curiosity about Amritsar.
"Are they richer than us over there?" he asked.
If the bid for a new relationship founders, there will be a special irony for Mr. Gujral, 77, and Mr. Sharif, 47, who, though far apart in age, are in one respect each other's mirror image. Both come from among the millions of migrant families who lost their homes and properties in the vast and often violent exodus that accompanied the partition -- Mr. Gujral's in what is now Pakistan, Mr. Sharif's in India.
Although the property issues have long since passed into history, each of the two leaders spoke of the special emotional stake that this gave him in the new talks.
Mr. Gujral recalled that anti-Hindu rioting in Karachi in February 1948 drove him out of Pakistan, where his family had lived for generations. But he also spoke of an affection for Muslims that he said had deepened as a result of his experiences at the time of partition. These include the mood in Karachi on Jan. 30, 1948, the day a Hindu nationalist in New Delhi assassinated Mohandas K. Gandhi, a fellow Hindu.
"There wasn't a Muslim in Karachi with a dry eye," Mr. Gujral said.
Mr. Sharif, who was born in Pakistan two years after partition, recalled that his family, originally Kashmiris, had settled in Amritsar, where they owned land as well as a home. These were lost when his father, an industrialist who had started engineering and steel businesses in Lahore in the 1930's, chose to move the family there in 1947, he said.
In the interviews, Mr. Gujral's relaxed demeanor contrasted with the stiff approach of Mr. Sharif, who hesitated while finding his words.
This appeared to reflect something that many experts in India and Pakistan have said about the new dialogue: that India, with a population and an economy that dwarfs those of Pakistan and an increasingly outward-looking approach born of its adoption in recent years of free-market economics, is less anxious about Pakistan, while Pakistan, with a national consciousness rooted in its founders' rejection of India, is finding it harder to abandon old enmities.
Mr. Gujral spoke enthusiastically of his vision for a new relationship in which families divided at partition would be able to move freely back and forth to weddings, funerals and other occasions. That has often been impossible because of visa restrictions, but India has begun to relax them without waiting for Pakistan.
The Indian leader also said he saw virtually unlimited potential for trade, now $1 billion a year, a fraction of the two countries' commerce with the United States.
Mr. Sharif said he, too, would welcome these changes if the Kashmir issue could be settled, but his tone seemed defensive compared with Mr. Gujral's.
Even on the issue that has dominated many of the 50th anniversary commemorations, the human suffering involved in the partition, Mr. Sharif was cautious, as though admitting to a legacy of sadness might undermine the self-confidence of Pakistan.
"There's no sadness in Pakistan," he said. "Everybody's happy. Independence was a great achievement as far as Pakistan is concerned."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 7, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 18 about observances of the 50th anniversary of India's independence from Britain referred incorrectly to the emblem at the center of the Indian flag. It is the dharma chakra, the wheel of the law, an ancient symbol associated with duty and piety. It is not the spinning wheel adopted as the symbol of the Indian National Congress, the nationalist movement that led the campaign for independence. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Mark, Aided by Remarks on Rates

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday, buoyed by an impressive recovery on Wall Street after Friday's plunge. The dollar was also helped by remarks from a member of Germany's central bank that cast doubt on prospects for higher German interest rates.
The dollar rose to 1.8305 German marks from 1.8245 on Friday. But it edged down slightly against the Japanese yen, falling to 117.82 yen from 117.90, though that was up considerably from the level at which it had been trading earlier in Tokyo, before the opening of the American financial markets. 
 The dollar's rebound against the mark was aided by remarks from Hans-Jurgen Krupp, a member of the German central bank's policy-setting committee, who said that a rise in German interest rates at the present time would be "very damaging" to the German economy.
Mr. Krupp added that recent weakness in the mark was worrisome but that he saw little evidence that the weaker currency was fueling inflation by making imports more expensive.
Traders had feared that the central bank might nudge interest rates higher this week to try to curb the mark's fall and ward off inflation pressures, but Mr. Krupp's comments suggested such a move was unlikely.
"The comments highlight the fact that Germany's economy is not running away and that they are not importing inflation, so there is no real reason to hike rates," said Robert Sabia, a vice president at ING Barings Capital Markets.
Dealers said dollar activity was kept in check by caution before the meeting today of the Federal Reserve's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee.
But like the German central bank, which will meet on Thursday, the Fed is not expected to change interest rates at its regularly scheduled gathering.
The dollar's decline against the yen came despite a report from the Japanese Ministry of Finance showing that the rise in Japan's trade surplus in July was less than had been expected. The customs-cleared surplus rose 70 percent in July, to 849 billion yen, but some analysts had expected a 100 percent increase.

HEADLINE: Israel Releases Some Palestinian Funds, but Sticking Points Remain

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Rewarding what it called "partial cooperation" from the Palestinian Authority, Israel said today that it would pay part of the money owed to Palestinians that was frozen as punishment after the suicide bombing last month in a Jerusalem market.
But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said Israel would not call a complete halt to the financial blockade until Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, heeded Israeli demands for a widespread crackdown on Islamic militants. 
 "The main thing has not been done: unconditional, systematic, and incessant Palestinian Authority action against terror groups," said Israel's Cabinet Secretary, Danny Naveh.
The decision to hand over $12 million of the $40 million that Israel owes to the Palestinian Authority was announced this morning after a Sunday night meeting of intelligence officials that included senior C.I.A. officers.
During the meeting, Palestinian intelligence officials shared with their Israeli counterparts samples of explosives seized last month in a raid on a suspected bomb-making factory near Bethlehem. The Israeli authorities have been eager to determine whether there were similarities between the makeup of those explosives and the ones used in the bombs that killed 16 people on July 30.
But accounts from both sides indicated that they were continuing to bicker over Israeli calls for the arrest of more than 200 suspected Islamic militants.
An aide to Mr. Arafat, Nabil Abu Rdainah, called Mr. Netanyahu's decision to release the money, which is to be transferred on Tuesday, "a positive first step." But Palestinian officials have continued vehement objections to Israel's demand for further Palestinian action as the price for unfreezing any more of the taxes and customs fees still being withheld. "It's not his money," Saeb Erekat, a top Palestinian negotiator, said of Mr. Netanyahu. "It's our money."
The Israeli action went only partway toward addressing a similar complaint from the United States, which has criticized the withholding of the payments -- on which the Palestinian Authority relies heavily -- as counterproductive.
Senior Israeli officials conceded tonight that Palestinian security officials were now cooperating fully in the investigation into who might have carried out the Jerusalem market bombing.
But an aide to Mr. Netanyahu, David Bar-Illan, said it was not enough for the Palestinian authorities to cooperate in that investigation alone, calling the bombing "a symptom of the broader problem."
From the Palestinian side, there was no indication that security forces were preparing to round up the suspected Islamic militants, a demand that Mr. Arafat has rejected as "an Israeli dictate."
Instead, senior officials of the Palestinian Authority said that they were preparing a plan to boycott all but essential Israeli goods and that they were drawing up lists -- including Coca-Cola, Israeli-made cigarettes, televisions and other items -- that they said they intended to bar from being imported into Palestinian-governed territory.
"We have economic weapons that we can use, too," a senior Palestinian official said tonight.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 590 words

HEADLINE: A Timely Message to China

 BODY:
American diplomatic design and the luck of Beijing's political calendar have given Washington its best chance in years to press for constructive change in Chinese policies at home and abroad.
The Clinton Administration has invited President Jiang Zemin to visit Washington in late October, enhancing his prestige at the very moment Chinese leaders are sorting out the succession to the late Deng Xiaoping. As that visit approaches, Mr. Jiang is eager to assure a harmonious meeting with President Clinton and to mute Congressional and public criticism over China's abuses of human rights and religious freedom. 
 Mr. Jiang's concerns give America the kind of leverage it has not enjoyed since Mr. Clinton abandoned his abortive early attempt to link China's trade status to progress on human rights. The Administration should make the most of this new opportunity, presenting Mr. Jiang and other Chinese leaders with a list of realistic and consistent steps Beijing could take to improve relations and avoid the repeated crises of recent years.
Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel Berger, have already made a good start. Mr. Berger met Mr. Jiang in Beijing last week and suggested ways that China can contribute to a successful summit meeting. These include releasing jailed democracy advocates like Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan, allowing Red Cross visits to Chinese prisons and inviting American religious leaders to visit China. Last month Ms. Albright reminded her Chinese counterpart of the importance Washington attaches to restraining Chinese nuclear exports, especially to Iran and Pakistan.
Improving relations also depends on wise American conduct. But most of the recent problems have resulted from provocative Chinese behavior. Although China is becoming an increasingly important economic and military power, its Government remains hypersensitive about its standing in world affairs and responds belligerently to perceived slights. Beijing particularly worries that Washington is trying to contain Chinese power. On the contrary, the Clinton Administration until recently acted as if maintaining good relations required Washington to ignore Chinese human rights abuses and dangerous weapons transfers.
Both sides now appear to be learning from past mistakes. Mr. Jiang knows that he is considered inexperienced in foreign affairs and that he could burnish his reputation by leading the way to less acrimonious relations with Washington. The Clinton Administration now seems to recognize that trade, human rights and restraining the spread of nuclear and missile technology need not be conflicting objectives. Rather, Washington's ability to expand American economic relations with China is directly related to how well Beijing respects its treaty commitments abroad and the rule of law at home.
Beyond the immediate political calculations in Beijing, this is a particularly appropriate moment for Washington to take a more active stance on human rights issues in China. The Chinese political system is plainly evolving from a Leninist totalitarianism that tried to control all aspects of human life toward a dictatorship more narrowly focused on political repression. As economic reform progresses, social controls on ordinary people tend to diminish, even as the regime tightens its grip on political dissent.
American policy should be aimed at consolidating these gains while encouraging the Chinese to extend them to the political sphere as well.

TYPE: Editorial

COUNTRY: CHINA (99%); UNITED STATES (94%); IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF (79%); PAKISTAN (79%);

HEADLINE: Fred C. Galda, 79, Retired Judge

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Fred C. Galda, a retired New Jersey Superior Court judge and former prosecutor and Mayor of Paramus, N.J., died on Thursday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 79 and a resident of Saddle River, N.J.
He suffered a long illness, his family said. 
 He was a key figure in two noted criminal cases that reverberated well beyond the New Jersey state line. He was a prosecutor in the trial and conviction in the 1963 killing of two Lodi police officers and was also one of the first judges to allow the battered-wife defense in a case of a woman accused of killing her spouse.
His six-term tenure as Mayor of Paramus in the 1950's and 60's witnessed a building boom that left modern shopping centers as reminders of a thriving economy. Most recently, he was with the law firm of George A. Vaccaro in Paramus, a practice from which he retired in 1995.
He grew up in Cliffside Park, N.J., where he excelled in football and basketball. He was place-kicker on the football team while studying at Michigan State University.
Known for his outspokenness, Mr. Galda turned from law to politics, and the voters of Paramus chose him as their Mayor in 1952, the first Democrat at City Hall in 17 years. Voters kept him in the job until 1964.
He served as first assistant county prosecutor in the case of Thomas Trantino, who was sentenced to death in 1964. Mr. Trantino was found guilty in the slayings of a police sergeant and a trainee responding to a noise complaint at a bar on Route 46 in Lodi, N.J.
Mr. Trantino remained on death row until 1972, when his sentence was commuted to a life term. He asked for parole eight times, more than any other current inmate in New Jersey, was denied eight times and was most recently at Riverfront State Prison in Camden, N.J.
Gov. Richard J. Hughes appointed Mr. Galda to Superior Court in Bergen County in 1967 and he served as presiding judge of its criminal court division until his retirement in 1983. Two years before that, he allowed a defendant, Dorothy Rapp, to testify that she shot her husband, William, in self-defense in 1981 in their backyard in Fair Lawn, N.J.
She told the court that her husband had dragged her from bed, pulled out clumps of her hair, savagely beat her and vowed to kill her before she picked up his loaded rifle and turned it on him. It took the jury less than two hours to acquit her. Judge Galda was the state's first judge -- and one of the first in the nation -- to allow such a trial defense.
Judge Galda is survived by his wife, Ellen Molloy; five sons, Dwight, of Forth Worth, Fred Jr., of Montvale, N.J., Thomas, of North Bergen, N.J., William, of Ramsey, N.J., and John, of Saddle River; a sister, Ester Lansdowne, who lives in Texas; a brother, Karl, of New York City; eight grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Gain Amid Stock Turmoil

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday, amid continued turmoil in the stock market.
The volatility in stocks has bolstered shorter-maturity securities as investors move from stocks to the relative safety of the bill market. Indeed, yesterday's regular weekly auction of Treasury bills was well subscribed from investors still reeling from Friday's tumble of 247 points in the Dow Jones industrial average. 
 The longer maturities were also higher yesterday, lifted by expectations that Federal Reserve policy makers would leave interest rates unchanged at today's meeting.
Even as stocks rallied late yesterday, with the Dow gaining 108.7 points, bond prices held to their gains. The price of the 30-year bond increased 10/32, to 98 5/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.52 percent from 6.54 percent on Friday.
The gain in bonds came on the eve of a one-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making panel.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said none of the chief economists at the 39 primary dealers in United States Government securities expected the Fed to raise short-term interest rates at today's meeting.
"The really interesting question is what happens next," Mr. Harris said. "While one in every four Wall Street economists foresees the Fed tightening at the following F.O.M.C. meeting on Sept. 30 and around three-fourths expect some tightening before year-end, we still see the Fed on hold for the remainder of 1997. This is because we still expect continued low inflation and real G.D.P. growth near our longstanding 2 percent forecast."
Because little data are due this week, Jack Ablin, executive vice president and head of fixed-income securities at Barnett Capital Advisers, said he expected a week of consolidation for the bond market. "Our sense is that we are in slightly bullish positions, and if we can get rates back to 6.40 percent on the long bond we can bring our portfolios back to neutral," he said.
Doug Burtnick, managing analyst at Technical Data of Boston, said that the fact that the market continued to trade nearly tick for tick against equities proved that some of the factors supporting the bond market had dwindled.
"Actually the bond market doesn't have that much to look forward to in the next few weeks, so it's not surprising it has taken its cues from stocks and other related markets," Mr. Burtnick said. "I don't expect a tightening at Tuesday's F.O.M.C meeting and frankly nobody does either. The real question boils down to whether or not the investment community will get involved and start buying the market on pullbacks. With the summer vacations in full swing, it may take a week or two to find that answer."
At yesterday's Treasury auction, the rate on the three-month bill came in at 5.08 percent, down from 5.17 percent last week, and the rate on the six-month bill was 5.12 percent, down from 5.23 percent. Following are the results of the auction:

HEADLINE: New Ferry Terminal Is Planned on Hudson

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The largest operator of Hudson River ferry boats, New York Waterway, is planning a new glass-enclosed ferry terminal at the foot of West 39th Street.
The plan, which the company has described privately to government officials and civic groups, is to replace what is now a blighted, city-owned parking garage that juts 100 feet into the Hudson and surrounds ventilation towers for the Lincoln Tunnel. 
 In its place, New York Waterway would build a terminal with six slips for ferry boats -- double the number it now has at a neighboring Hudson River pier at 38th Street -- and a building with public walkways, seating and viewing areas.
"We see this as the Grand Central Station of ferry terminals," said Arthur E. Imperatore Jr., the president of New York Waterway, which estimated that the project would cost $10 million. "Some of the greatest public buildings have been transportation buildings, and that is what we hope for here," he said.
The plan won a generally favorable response from members of Community Board 4, who learned about it last week.
"We have mixed feelings, but this plan is probably as good as we are going to get," said Edward Kirkland, a member of the board's waterfront committee. "It has a handsome, open design, which we like very much."
Charles Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency, said, "Both the concept and the location make sense to us, and we are very much on board."
New York Waterway is negotiating with the city on a long-term lease for the use of the 39th Street garage. Advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said they had not been given details of the proposal, but were inclined to favor a plan that would accommodate more ferry boats.
"The Mayor is proud of the increase we've seen in ferry service and would like to see more," said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
The terminal plan has attracted broad interest from community groups, because it would be the first structure to be built along the river between Battery Park and 59th Street under guidelines approved by the city and state last year that call for preserving the area as a river park.
Although the park would be little more than a sliver of public walkways and greenery between the river and a newly rebuilt West Side Highway, the intent is to give pedestrians, cyclists and skaters access to the shoreline. The guidelines have challenged developers and architects who hope to find new commercial uses for several blighted piers, including the one that New York Waterway wants to rebuild at 39th Street.
Mr. Kirkland said members of Community Board 4 had hoped New York Waterway would obtain rights to rebuild another pier farther south, thereby freeing up the 39th Street pier and other property near the foot of 42d Street for open space and recreation.
In its plan for the pier, by the architecture firm Skidmore Owens & Merrill, New York Waterway said it would erect a glass-enclosed terminal building that would be 30 feet high and would occupy the entire space of the existing garage, which is 400 feet long and 100 feet wide. Since the new building would be the same size as the old, approval by the City Planning Commission would not be required.
The terminal would include a public walkway along the shore, beside the eastern side of its main entrances. Since those entrances are likely to be crowded during the morning and afternoon rush hours, an alternate shoreline walkway would be provided, a promenade along the roof that would be accessible by stairways or elevators.
New York Waterway has been operating ferry service between Weehawken, N.J., and its 38th Street dock since 1987, and it now carries 9,000 passengers each weekday. It said it needed the new terminal to meet growing demand, and expected to be carrying more than 17,000 passengers each weekday by 2000.
The company, anticipating a city requirement, said it would make docks available to competing ferry operators. One of them, New York Fast Ferry, is known to be searching for docking space along the Hudson in midtown Manhattan.
New York Waterway said it hoped to obtain a lease on the 39th Street garage by the end of the year and to complete construction of the new terminal by the end of 1998. The company plans to rebuild the dock it uses in Weehawken at the same time.
