HEADLINE: To Argentines, Judges Are Often Biggest Lawbreakers

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17

 BODY:
At first, Judge Hernan Bernasconi seemed courageous last year when he jailed the agent of the soccer star Diego Maradona for drug trafficking after the police discovered a large stash of cocaine in his apartment.
The agent, Guillermo Coppola, is a close friend of President Carlos Saul Menem, and in Argentina, under a legal system that critics say is corrupt, grossly inefficient and highly politicized, corruption cases involving top officials or their associates are usually not resolved. 
 But Mr. Bernasconi's valor is now in question: Government investigators said they had found that the judge concocted the entire scandal. They said he had hired police officers and a woman to put the cocaine in a vase in Mr. Coppola's apartment, which was in the judge's jurisdiction.
Investigators said Mr. Bernasconi, who denies any wrongdoing, was trying to supplant Mr. Coppola, who United States drug enforcement agents said was on their list of suspected drug dealers, with his own group of traffickers. The judge is now facing impeachment charges before Congress.
To many Argentines, Mr. Bernasconi epitomizes all that is wrong with their ailing justice system.
"In most countries, judges try to avoid the appearance of impropriety, but in Argentina it seems to be the exact opposite," said Domingo Cavallo, a former Finance Minister in Mr. Menem's Government. "Those who are responsible for administering justice are themselves breaking the laws, and they make no attempt to hide it."
The country's Roman Catholic bishops warned recently that widespread corruption and growing public distrust in the judicial system "threaten to disintegrate Argentine society."
The Archbishop of Resistencia, Carmel Giaquinta, said inequity in the justice system had become so acute that the bishops had placed it at the top of their social agenda along with poverty and unemployment.
"We have a judicial system that does not dispense justice," the Archbishop said.
Argentina's judicial system is administered by federal, national and provincial judges, who respectively handle cases involving the federal Government, the capital district of Buenos Aires, and the provinces and municipalities. Judges typically specialize in one of three areas: criminal, civil or commercial cases. There are courts of appeals and a supreme court for each level of the judiciary.
In recent years, dozens of judges have been secretly videotaped demanding or accepting bribes. In March, for example, prosecutors filed impeachment charges against a federal judge, Juan Carlos Branca, after a television station videotaped him agreeing to provide smugglers with protection from prosecution for a fee.
Many federal judges, who earn $5,000 a month, have luxury apartments, country homes and imported cars.
Last year, another federal judge, Francisco Trovato, was charged with accepting a $25,000 wardrobe for dismissing a case involving the death of a 4-year-old. Prosecutors are still waiting for Mr. Trovato to explain how he acquired his $700,000 apartment in the fancy Recoleta district, and the lower house of Congress is considering impeachment.
In the last 18 months, scandals have forced the resignation of two justice ministers. The first, Rodolfo Carlos Barra, stepped down after a news magazine disclosed that he had lied about his participation in Nazi groups as a young man.
The second, Elias Jassan, resigned after he was shown to have had daily telephone contact with a tycoon who was under investigation for the killing of an investigative journalist.
Not surprisingly, public confidence in the judiciary is very low. In recent public opinion polls, Argentines have consistently ranked the justice system as the public institution having the least credibility.
In a recent survey of 1,400 people in Buenos Aires, 39 percent said they had no confidence in the justice system, 16 percent said they had very little confidence and 34 percent said they had little confidence. Only 9 percent said they had some confidence in the justice system, while just 1 percent indicated they had a lot of confidence. The poll was taken by Guzman Heredia and Associates.
"This feeling of wanting to live outside the law, or to change it to serve narrow interests, encourages private and public corruption and creates a state of widespread skepticism, fear of others, impotence, and anger," the Catholic bishops noted in their statement.
Justice Ministry officials maintain that despite the recent scandals involving judges, Argentina's justice system is sound and that judges who commit crimes are being punished.
The officials said that Congress is now considering 181 impeachment petitions for national and federal judges. While anyone can file an impeachment petition against a judge with the lower house of Congress, only about 20 percent of all petitions are ever seriously debated. If the lower house decides to remove a judge, the case then goes to the Senate.
So far this year, Congress has removed 10 judges, compared with an average of 3 or 4 judges in past years.
Many lawyers and legal experts say the main problem with the country's judiciary is that it is controlled by Mr. Menem's Government. They say the Government has exercised considerable influence over judges through appointments and bribery.
Mr. Cavallo, the former Finance Minister who is now running for Congress as an independent, said that during his six years in the Menem administration he saw officials conceal corruption and manipulate judges.
"Cabinet members regularly called judges and prosecutors to give them instructions on how to handle important cases," said Mr. Cavallo, who was sentenced to a four-month suspended prison term last month for slander after he accused a customs official of corruption.
Mr. Cavallo said he was convicted of slander because the judge overseeing the case was controlled by Mr. Menem. But as Finance Minister, Mr. Cavallo benefited from the Government's sway over the judiciary when Menem officials convinced the Supreme Court not to issue a ruling that would have ordered the Government to pay billions of dollars to settle lawsuits. Mr. Cavallo had publicly opposed settling those suits because the Treasury was broke.
Officials of the Menem administration deny that they control the country's judges, and Mr. Menem accused Mr. Cavallo of making "unsubstantiated accusations."
One judge, who spoke on condition that she not be identified, said officials of Mr. Menem's administration had approached her several years ago to determine if she was a "proper candidate" for promotion to federal judge. "They told me that the job included a $10,000 a month bonus, but I told them I was not interested," the judge said.
Adrian Ventura, who writes a column on the law for the newspaper La Nacion, said the first step toward eliminating corruption in the judiciary is to change the process by which judges are selected and appointed.
Mr. Ventura said the Government has yet to carry out a 1994 constitutional reform that called for the creation of a council of lawyers, judges and academics who would select candidates for the judiciary.
But the creation of such a council has been delayed in political gridlock and seems unlikely to take place anytime soon. In the meantime, lawyers and legal experts said Argentines who feel that they are being forced to pay a bribe to get justice should resort to a new defense: the hidden video camera.
Indeed, Argentina's largest and most prestigious law firm -- Marval, O'Farrel & Mairal -- said recently that it had videotaped two men claiming to be lawyers, who said they could arrange a favorable ruling for one of their clients, a private electric distribution company, for $2 million.

(El Grafico magazine via Reuters); Mr. Coppola was jailed by Judge Hernan Bernasconi, right, on drug charges, but the judge himself was later accused of having evidence planted in Mr. Coppola's home. (Clarin)

HEADLINE: Developer Chosen to Build F.D.A. Center in Queens This Fall

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
A developer based in Houston has been awarded a contract to build the Food and Drug Administration's new, $85 million regional headquarters on the York College campus in Jamaica, Queens, officials announced yesterday.
With the selection of Hines GS Properties, construction is scheduled to start in the fall on what will be the F.D.A.'s largest laboratory outside its headquarters in Rockville, Md. When it is completed in 1999, the 230,000-square-foot center will test pharmaceutical, cosmetic and food products for Government approval, including samples arriving at nearby Kennedy International Airport. 
 Claire L. Shulman, the Queens Borough President, said the project, which will create 400 construction jobs, was another major step in revitalizing downtown Jamaica. Over the last two decades, the area has been pulled from the edge of urban decay by government investments totaling more than $1 billion, including the construction, in the 1980's, of a local Social Security office and the York College campus, part of the City University of New York.
According to the agreement between Hines and the United States General Services Administration, the company will finance, build and operate the building at Liberty Avenue and 158th Street, and lease it to the Government for $9.4 million a year over 20 years.
The new building will allow the F.D.A. to move from the center that it has outgrown in Sunset Park, on the Brooklyn waterfront, once a major port of entry for the products it tested, and expand its research programs and staff. The F.D.A. currently employs nearly 300 people at the lab in Sunset Park, and it expects to add more than 100 jobs when it moves into the new building.
At a news conference yesterday at Queens Borough Hall, George Boone, the F.D.A.'s regional laboratory director, and Dr. Charles C. Kidd Sr., the president of York College, said they expected close ties between the researchers and the college.
United States Representative Floyd H. Flake, who has been enormously successful at directing public funds to his district in southeastern Queens and who recently announced that he would resign from Congress in October, said the F.D.A. center was one of his proudest achievements. "This is probably the best kind of retirement present one can have," Mr. Flake said.
In 1993, Mr. Flake slipped a stipulation into a Federal appropriations bill to build a new regional headquarters for the F.D.A. -- but only at York College. The move angered officials in other boroughs, especially the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, who said Queens was "stealing jobs from Brooklyn."
In a statement yesterday, Mr. Golden said: "It is irresponsible to take jobs out of a community much in need of employment opportunities. I maintain that the relocation of the F.D.A. labs is a misguided move that will be detrimental to the Sunset Park community, to Brooklyn and to the city."
Yesterday, Mr. Flake let Ms. Shulman answer Mr. Golden's criticism. "It is the same region and it is the same city," she said.
Mr. Flake has also been pressing the Federal Aviation Administration to build a new regional office in his district. Karen R. Adler, the regional administrator of the General Services Administration, said the contract to build the F.A.A. office, most likely in Queens, would be awarded next month.

HEADLINE: Life Gets Harder on the Already Mean Streets

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
Carolyn, a prostitute who many years ago abandoned her young son to the care of her churchgoing mother, works a "crack stroll" in Harlem, where men come to buy fleeting sex along with their drugs.
"The best thing to do is be where the crack is, because that's where the money is," she said. "When they buy crack, once they take that pull, they want a woman." 
 But because of crack, Carolyn, 40, has also found herself working harder to make the same amount of money. Commercial sex is one of the few commodities in New York whose street value has plummeted over the last decade, with crack-addicted women, desperate for the next fix, driving down the price from $20 or $30 for oral sex to as little as $2 or $3.
"Before, they used to pay you $50 or $100," complains Carolyn, who often fortifies herself for her long nights with crack or heroin. "Now they're telling you $5."
Crack, whose use is declining in the wider society, has left most of the 4,500 to 5,000 prostitutes walking New York's streets earning less and hustling harder, with few prospects beyond police arrests, assaults by customers and sexually transmitted diseases like AIDS.
A survey of 4,200 street prostitutes by researchers for Frost'd, a nonprofit organization that helps prostitutes, showed that about 26 percent of those interviewed were homeless or on the verge of becoming so. Ninety percent reported having children taken away and assigned to relatives or to foster care.
While crack's appeal has declined among younger, newer drug users, crack remains entrenched in the subculture of street prostitution, where the women who took to smoking crack a few years ago for its cheap, fast jolt often find themselves unable to break their addiction. More than two-thirds of those surveyed said they smoked crack and nearly 40 percent injected heroin or cocaine.
"There's a complete feeling of hopelessness," said Dr. Joyce I. Wallace, the founder of Frost'd, an acronym for From Our Streets With Dignity, "and there's such a lack of self-esteem that they don't feel they're going to get out of it."
Her organization provides not only AIDS tests, clean syringes and free condoms, but also sustenance as simple as peanut butter sandwiches and the counseling that many woman need and few can afford.
"Half the time, they're on the street because they had a drug problem and got thrown out of whatever homes they came from," said Dr. Wallace, who gave up a Greenwich Village medical practice to work with prostitutes. "But half are on the street because it's less violent than home. They turn to drugs to make life tolerable."
While drugs and alcohol have long been a factor in the trade, interviews with outreach workers and 20 prostitutes throughout the city confirm that crack has hurt profits in the trade and made the lives of the prostitutes even more miserable. The women spoke only on condition of anonymity for fear of attracting the police and embarrassing relatives.
A Brooklyn prostitute named Thea said that, with earnings down, she was homeless and relied on men she met to give her somewhere to sleep. Thea, who is 34 and trying to quit heroin, said she wants to become a hairdresser, but "I can't get a normal 9-to-5 not knowing where I'm going to rest my head."
With competition from crack-addicted women, a 30-year-old Bronx prostitute named Tracy said, "The johns are bargaining now."
"I ask $15, but the johns want $10," Tracy, a heroin user, said. "I won't say I haven't done it for $10 when I need the dope."
There have been reports of some pimps, eager not to see their profits eroded, relocating the prostitutes they control to neighborhoods less affected by crack. On Caroline's stroll, which is linked to crack, the pimp's protective role has passed to the traffickers.
"The drug dealers look out for us, and we look out for them," she said. "We don't need no pimp."
While they complained that crack created more competition, most of the working or former prostitutes interviewed admitted to trying it themselves. Only two denied using hard drugs, saying they smoked marijuana.
Priscilla Alexander, the research director for Frost'd and a veteran of Coyote, an early prostitutes' rights group, estimated that crack first influenced the trade in 1988 or 1989. By 1993, she said, crack exerted "a profound impact" on how much prostitutes could charge.
Crack differed from other street drugs, Ms. Alexander said, "because it's a frequency drug," driving addicts to binge rather than space out their highs. As more women became homeless, they took to selling "survival sex" at cheap prices.
Street hookers represent the most visible part of an underground economy in New York that may employ as many as 50,000 sex workers. In a study for the Midtown Community Court in Manhattan, Rick Curtis, a sociologist at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, identified three levels of prostitution.
At the higher level involving call girls and hotels, he said, drugs do not play a role. At the middle level, in brothels and massage parlors, drugs are used, sometimes recreationally. At the lower street level, Mr. Curtis found that street prostitutes generally need drugs to function.
Tracy Quan, a member of Prostitutes of New York, or PONY, a local advocacy group, said that drug use is "not necessarily representative of the industry" as she witnessed it at the higher level. "There are health freaks who take care of their bodies and don't use drugs," Ms. Quan said.
Ms. Alexander said that there were more drugs in street prostitution because the work was more stressful. "Street prostitutes are also more likely to use drugs because they started as runaways," she said.
Brenda, a former prostitute in Chelsea, said that she began using cocaine more than 20 years ago. "There were a couple of months I didn't use at all, but I started using again because that was the only way I could stand the tricks," she said, alluding to her customers. "And they had the drugs, so why not use it?"
"If you're miserable and very unhappy in life, it's very easy to talk you into something," said Brenda, who asked that she not be identified because her former pimp was searching for her.
"I was tired of being abused and mistreated when I was making all the money," said Brenda, who is 36. "It was cold, and I was freezing and he wouldn't let me buy a coat. I took his $2,000 and I took off."
Brenda found refuge in a drug treatment program run by Project Return, an organization that helps women overcome substance abuse.
Street prostitution, the prostitutes say, can still be lucrative if customer turnover is high enough. Carolyn aspires to earn $400 a night, of which $120 goes to finance her need for heroin and crack. John Megaw, the clinical director at the Midtown Community Court, which processes many of the prostitutes arrested in Manhattan, said that the first step for getting prostitutes out of the trade was breaking the link to crack and other drugs.
After Michelle was arrested last September, she joined a program at the Midtown Community Court. "The excitement and money was not there anymore," she said of her old trade. "But I kept doing it because I didn't think I could do anything else."
Though depressed prices have made more prostitutes willing to consider an alternative, the alternatives are not easy to find or create. Dr. Wallace's attempt to open a halfway house in SoHo for recovering prostitutes was blocked by irate neighbors. Without such programs, such women say they have little option but to continue earning their drugs with sex. Some have no interest in changing.
"I like being high," Carolyn said. "I'm not going to stand here and lie. This is a real job because I'm getting paid. Through this I pay my rent, I buy my food, my clothes -- and my highs."

Mir's Problems Continue As Crucial Computer Fails
The space station Mir's turbulent odyssey continued, as the main computer for the craft failed and sent the station spinning out of control as it was docking with a cargo ship. Mir's new commander managed to steer the supply craft into its berth, but the crew was forced to retreat to the Soyuz space capsule. A1 

U.S. May Lift Cuba Ban
The Clinton Administration is strongly considering a temporary easing of the United States' restrictions on travel to Cuba for the duration of the Pope's scheduled visit there in January, officials said. The suspension of the restrictions would allow American Catholics to make religious pilgrimages to Cuba to witness the Pope's visit. A4

President Aslan Maskhadov of Chechnya and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia met in Moscow to forge a more workable relationship between their wary and hostile governments. At the same time, three well-known Russian television journalists held hostage in Chechnya were freed. Little progress in peace efforts has been made since the two leaders signed a treaty last May. Attacks on Lebanon Resume
In the deadliest attack against Lebanese civilians in more than a year, militiamen commanded by a key ally of Israel shelled the port city of Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut, killing at least six people and wounding more than three dozen. The bombardment was the first upon Sidon since Israel's air and artillery assault into Lebanon in April 1996. A3

Israel said it would pay part of the money owed to Palestinians that was frozen as punishment after last month's suicide bombing in a Jerusalem market. But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said Israel would not call a complete halt to the financial blockade until Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, heeded Israeli demands for a widespread crackdown on Islamic militants. British soldiers and United Nations workers searched a five-story Bosnian Serb police headquarters for evidence of electronic eavesdropping on President Biljana Plavsic by her political rivals, and found extensive and sophisticated listening equipment, many boxes filled with audio tapes, and copies of faxes sent to and from Mrs. Plavsic's office. Paris Gets Ready for Pope
More than 300,000 young people are expected to come to Paris this week for the 12th World Youth Day, a gathering in which youth from about 130 countries congregate to meditate on Christianity at the invitation of Pope John Paul II. Some Parisians have criticized the use of public services for the event, as well as the Pope's plans to pray privately over the grave of a friend who was a militant in the French movement opposing abortion rights. A state jury in Louisiana found that Dow Chemical had knowingly deceived women by hiding information about the health risks of silicone used in breast implants. The jury, which is hearing the first class-action lawsuit brought against a company involved in the breast implant industry, also found that Dow Chemical had failed to properly test silicone before its use in humans. HEADLINE: U.S. Considers Easing Travel to Cuba During Visit by the Pope

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Weighing its aversion to Fidel Castro against its regard for Pope John Paul II, the Clinton Administration is leaning toward easing restrictions on travel by Americans to Cuba during the Pope's scheduled visit there in January, officials said today.
The temporary easing would allow hundreds and perhaps thousands of people to go to Cuba for the Pope's visit, now scheduled to last five days, starting Jan. 21, the officials said. 
 The Administration also wants to allow Catholic churches and charities to ship supplies and equipment to help Catholic officials in Cuba organize the visit.
While measures being considered would mark a significant relaxation of the restrictions against Cuba, which the United States has maintained for more than three decades, the officials insisted that the Administration was in no way proposing a more general lifting of the economic embargo, which the United States has tightened in recent years.
"The Secretary of State views the Pope's visit as an important development in bringing to the Cuban people a message of hope and faith and the importance of respecting human rights," James P. Rubin, a spokesman for Madeleine K. Albright, said today. "And therefore out of respect for His Holiness, we are facilitating travel and the delivery of certain goods for the purpose of that trip."
The officials could not yet say exactly how many people would be allowed to go or whether Cuba would grant them visas. But they said the Administration was prepared to grant special licenses to large groups, presumably Catholics, which would be organized by the Church.
Currently, the embargo does not ban travel and the sending of relief supplies outright, but severely restricts citizens or even residents of the United States from spending money in Cuba, with few exemptions. It also requires that anyone who receives permission to travel to Cuba do so by flying there from a third country, a rule that the Administration is also considering easing. Although no final decisions have been made, the Administration has been quietly reviewing the matter for months.
It is working in consultation with the United States Catholic Conference in Washington and Archdioceses from around the country, including those in New York, Newark, Philadelphia and Boston.
The Archdiocese of Miami, which includes a large population of Cuban Americans, has requested permission to dispatch a cruise ship to carry more than 1,000 people to Cuba for the visit, according to other Administration officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Peter D. Coats, a special assistant to Bishop Thomas G. Wenski, auxiliary bishop of Miami and director of Catholic Charities there, welcomed the Administration's consideration, noting that the Pope's visit would have major reverberations for Catholics in the United States and Cuba.
"This is going to be a historic visit," he said. "The interest is going to be very high, not just in the Cuban-American community, but in the community at large."
Reflecting the political sensitivities of anything to do with Cuba, Administration officials have also discussed the easing of the restrictions with members of Congress prominently involved in policy toward Cuba. They include Representative Robert Menendez, a Democrat from New Jersey, and Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican from Florida.
Ms. Ros-Lehtinen, whose district includes a politically potent population of Cuban-Americans, expressed some reservations. While she supported the Pope and his message, she said she opposed allowing pilgrims from the United States to travel there for the visit.
"This is an end run on the embargo," she said, suggesting any easing would lead to further attempts, despite the Administration's insistence otherwise. "If you want to listen to the Pope, buy his tapes or visit him somewhere else."
The Pope, who is credited by some with accelerating the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, accepted an invitation to Cuba last fall when he met with President Fidel Castro at the Vatican. A visit by the Pope anywhere carries enormous significance, but the trip to Cuba, which has evoked memories of his visit to his native Poland in 1979, offers a chance to bolster the Church's revitalization in Cuba after years of repression.
After seizing power in 1959, Mr. Castro's Government nationalized church property and closed Catholic schools. In recent years, though, the Government has eased restrictions and allowed Cubans more freedom to worship. For Mr. Castro, the visit appears to be a way to win greater international recognition, despite Washington's efforts to isolate him. The visit could also highlight the embargo, first imposed by President Kennedy on July 8, 1963, which the Vatican has opposed on grounds that it hurts Cuba's people more than its Government.
The embargo also forbids all commercial trade and restricts relief assistance, like gifts of medicine. For the Pope's visit the definition of relief assistance could be broadened to include such things as fax machines.
The prohibition on spending money in Cuba allows exemptions for people with close relatives there, journalists and others with "clearly defined educational or religious activities."
The Administration now reviews applications to visit Cuba on a case-by-case basis, but for this visit only it would grant permission in blocks.
The embargo was tightened last year after Congress enacted legislation known as the Helms-Burton Act that extended the restrictions on trade to foreign companies using property confiscated by the Communist Government.

HEADLINE: Will U.P. S. Strike Draw Workers to Unions, or Scare Them Away?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Mark Levinson (Op-Ed, Aug. 17), an economist for the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, believes that the strike by the teamsters' union against United Parcel Service can be a pivotal event. It can define the balance of power between unions and management, change that power through its outcome and thus take on greater meaning than the specific issues at the bargaining table. 
 The widespread public support for the strikers does reflect the public's fear of downsizing, sympathy with the part-timers and anger at apparent corporate greed. But the wider significance of the strike won't be felt in the outcome of negotiations, which will almost surely be a technical compromise.
Rather, look for the impact on union organizing -- the ability of the unions to replace the nearly five million members lost since 1980. Will more part-time workers seek union representation, seeing greater strength through solidarity with each other and with full-time workers? Or will they reject unionism, fearing a U.P.S.-style conflict with management that could jeopardize their already insecure jobs?
Last week workers at Fieldcrest Cannon, a large textile manufacturer, voted against representation by Mr. Levinson's union after management pointed out how strikes like the one at U.P.S. can jeopardize job security (news article, Aug. 15). Will U.P.S. now become the centerpiece in employers' anti-union litany during organizing campaigns? How can unions counter it?
 
GARY N. CHAISON
Worcester, Mass., Aug. 17, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of industrial relations at Clark University.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Deal Is Reached to End Strike Against U.P.S.
Teamsters' union officials said that they and the United Parcel Service had reached an agreement to end the 15-day strike by 185,000 workers that largely crippled the world's largest package delivery company.
The officials said they expected the strikers to return to work tomorrow. First, however, two union committees -- including the bargaining committee -- must approve the agreement. [Page A1.] 

Texaco in Billion-Dollar Deal
Texaco has agreed to acquire Monterey Resources, the oil assets of the former Santa Fe Railroad, for $1.12 billion in stock. The deal, which bolsters Texaco's reserves in California, builds on the company's strategy of increasing its domestic fields because of concerns about possible political obstacles overseas. [D4.]
 
Hewlett-Packard Below Forecasts
Hewlett-Packard's quarterly earnings came in below expectations, driving the stock price down sharply, even though the company reported strong growth in orders and revenue. Analysts said it was apparent that the company was accepting lower profit margins to gain market share from weaker players in the PC industry. [D2.]
 
Court Setback for Dow Chemical
A jury in Louisiana found that Dow Chemical had knowingly deceived women by hiding information about the health risks of silicone used in breast implants. Dow Chemical, which owns half of the implant maker Dow Corning, has always maintained that it was never itself involved in the testing or manufacture of the devices. [A1.]
 
Mexican Economy Back Strongly
Mexico said its economy surged by 8.8 percent in the second quarter, compared with a year earlier, surpassing economists' most optimistic expectations. The figures showed that Mexican consumers, after more than two years of crisis prompted by the bungled devaluation of the peso in December 1994, are finally going out to shop. [D4.]
 
Strong Results for Big Swiss Banks
Despite an international black eye for their handling of the accounts of victims of the Nazis, the big three Swiss banks are staging a remarkable financial recovery from the worst year in their history. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Stock Turbulence Helps Bonds
The volatility in the stock market -- shares closed sharply higher yesterday after bouncing around all day -- has bolstered short-maturity Treasury securities as investors move from stocks to the relative safety of the bill market. In the longer maturities, the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.52 percent from 6.54. [D18.]
 
The dollar rose against the mark, buoyed by the gains in stocks and by remarks from a member of Germany's central bank that cast doubt on prospects for higher interest rates. But the dollar slipped against the yen. [D15.]
 
Labor Sees Chance For Strong Harvest
In what may be the largest unionizing effort under way in the nation, the teamsters -- with a former rival, the United Farm Workers of America -- are aiming at a class of workers they used to ignore: the armies of low-wage workers who pick and pack apples in Washington State. [A10.]
 
Utne Reader Seeks Investor
The Utne Reader, the Reader's Digest of the alternative press of the left, has retained an investment bank, Veronis Suhler, to help it find an investor or a buyer. [D6.]
 
New Looks for Fall
Three major fashion retailers -- Bergdorf Goodman, Barneys and Henri Bendel -- have reinvented their private-label collections to cater to women's changing tastes. [A20.]

HEADLINE: A Clean, Well-Lighted Place for Loans;
Pawnshop Chains Grow As They Remake Image

BYLINE: By SARAH JAY 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
When Misty Jones, a 23-year-old mother of three, fell behind on a nagging bill this summer, she knew just what to do. She brought a battery charger for the family car to Cash America, a local pawnshop, to ask for help. "It rained for, like, two weeks," said Ms. Jones, whose husband, a house framer, depends on good weather for his work. "We knew that if we came to a pawnshop, they would give us a little loan."
Not long ago, Ms. Jones returned to the shop, which is in a strip mall in Riverdale, Ga., a suburb of this city that has long been a Mecca of pawnshops, to pay back the loan -- $50 plus $12.50 interest. She unfolded her pawn ticket, and not only was she greeted warmly, but an employee even volunteered to carry Ms. Jones's battery charger out to her car. 
 That treatment, such a contrast to the traditional image of pawnshops, was no accident. Indeed, it fit right in with the bright and spacious appearance and the young, efficient and affable employees. The merchandise on display was clean, well marked and easy to find. Signs directed customers to appropriate areas, whether they were asking for a loan on a pearl necklace or looking for a bargain on a used lawn mower.
"Cash America looks more modern," Ms. Jones said cheerily, "and I prefer the ones that don't have guns."
Ms. Jones is precisely the sort of customer who has made an unexpected success of a new breed of pawnshops that swept across the South in recent years and is now just beginning to extend its reach elsewhere. Led by Cash America International, which is based in Fort Worth and is the first and largest of the new wave, these modern chains have been simultaneously consolidating this age-old industry and sprucing up its seedy image. In the process, they have changed the landscape of the trade, perhaps one of the last mom-and-pop businesses in America to be brought into the contemporary era.
"All of us are consolidating the industry," said John Thedford, president of Value Pawn and Jewelry, which has opened 22 pawnshops throughout Florida in the last three years. "We're putting a fresh coat of paint on these locations. Our employees wear shirts and ties and name tags. We're cleaning up the image of this industry."
And the customer-friendly approach of the chains has been contagious. On Peters Street in Atlanta, once known for its many old-style pawnshops, those that remain have more or less mimicked the new wave. As a general manager at one of them said, "You have to treat it like a business: be nice to customers, send out flyers and treat people with respect, as opposed to saying, 'Here, I'll give you $2 for that,' the way some shops used to do."
Until recently, nearly all local pawnshops lived up to their reputation as dingy, cramped outlets -- with merchandise piled to the ceiling -- and used on occasion as a dumping ground for petty thieves. But that scene has ceased to be the norm, thanks to a handful of visionaries who saw the industry as ripe for a revolution. Inspired by a sagging economy, a rash of personal bankrupcies and a growing segment of the population that had bad credit and limited access to the banking system, these entrepreneurs gambled that the pawnshop trade was primed to grow.
And it has. In 1988, when the National Pawnbrokers Association was formed, there were an estimated 6,800 pawnshops nationwide. Now there are more than 15,000. Some of them are owned by Cash America and three other publicly traded chains, Ezcorp of Austin, Tex., First Cash Inc. of Arlington, Tex., and U.S. Pawn in Westminster, Colo. As investments, though, none of the companies has done particularly well; U.S. Pawn is even embroiled in a fight with a group of stockholders who want to oust management because of its poor stock performance.
While the chains have taken the the lead, scores of others are also owned and operated by individuals who have followed Cash America's formula of acquiring new shops, improving customer service, computerizing operations and remodeling the stores in a conscious, deliberate effort to dispel the old perceptions.
These new leaders are shaping the industry in several ways, from pressing state legislators for more regulation to distancing themselves from the old icons. In Florida, for example, the traditional symbol of three balls -- which hails from at least the days of the Medicis -- is absent from all Value Pawn and Jewelry signs. In New York, the trade group for the industry changed the very name of the business, from pawnbroker to "collateral loan broker."
The vast majority of pawnshops are clustered in the South, mostly because state regulations allow them to charge more favorable interest rates. For example, in Florida and Texas, which each support more than 1,000 pawnshops, interest rates and service fees can run to 20 percent a month, and Georgia pawnshops can charge as much as 25 percent. In contrast, New York City's rates are held at 3 percent, which explains why the city has only about 70 licensed pawnshops, down from 150 in the 1960's.
There is no Federal pawnshop law, so it will fall to state legislators to determine the future growth of the industry, according to John P. Caskey, an associate professor of economics at Swarthmore College who studies the pawnshop industry. "There's a huge potential market," Mr. Caskey said. "The key is to change the regulations. If they can effectively change state laws, then there can be a lot more growth."
A typical pawnshop transaction usually proceeds as follows: An individual in need of cash enters the store with an item to be pawned, often a piece of jewelry. The pawnbroker appraises the item and offers a cash loan, usually for less than the full value. If the customer accepts, he or she leaves the merchandise in exchange for the cash and a pawn ticket. In most states, the loan matures within 30 days but can be refinanced for another two months. If the customer does not repay after 90 days, the store may put the item on its retail shelves. In some states, like New York, the item is put into foreclosure and is sold at public auction.
For pawnbrokers in states with high interest rates, the profit potential is obvious. For the borrower, who may have bad credit, no bank account and an urgent need for cash, the pawnshop is one of the few safe and palatable short-term financial solutions.
People may gravitate toward the chains because of their easy loan policies, their retail feel or perhaps simply because they seem more credible.
"Any time you deal with a chain, it's better," said Eddie Johnson, an unemployed construction worker who pawned $400 in jewelry at a Cash America in Atlanta last week. He compared the operation to a regional supermarket. "It's better to go to a Winn-Dixie than a mom-and-pop grocery store. It's more organized."
Still, going to a pawnshop, even the up-to-date ones, means acknowledging financial difficulty and few people are comfortable with that.
"I hate pawnshops," said one woman at a Cash America store where she was pawning a laptop computer for $350 in cash. "But I'd rather walk in here than some place dirty. It's the atmosphere. They have friendly people and it feels safer."
And that's what the industry is counting on as it enters the mainstream.
"It is so fast, so easy and there are no questions asked," said Tom Horn, executive director of the National Pawnbrokers Association, which is based in Dallas. "You don't have to give your life history."
You do, however, have to provide a state driver's license or other photo ID. In most cases, fingerprints are required, which pawnbrokers say helps deter thieves from coming to them to unload stolen goods. They say that those crooks who do show up run a good risk of being caught since copies of the pawn tickets are forwarded to the local police. It was just such an incident that helped the Miami police link Andrew Cunanan to the murder of Gianni Versace last month.
Proprietors of the smaller independent stores, which still make up more than half of all pawnshops, say they do not mind the encroaching chains. Some even seem grateful for the nudge to change their ways.
"I used to be afraid of the way chains were coming in, but now I see who they are and what they're providing," said Chip Hurd, president of National Pawn and Jewelry in Plantation, Fla. "From a competition standpoint, I'll know who I'm competing against, as opposed to whole bunch of independents."
Morgan Jones, president of American Pawn in Dallas, agreed. "They've done a lot to give an air of real legitimacy to our industry," he said. "I don't look at Cash America, EZ Pawn or First Cash as companies to be scared of. It's friendly competition."
Mr. Jones noted that he has sold seven of his stores to First Cash. Mr. Hurd also seems to have an "if you can't beat them, join them" attitude about the chains, and imagined a day when he might consider merging his company with a larger one. Both pawnbrokers said they appreciated the arrival of the big chains if only because they have spearheaded the campaign to improve the industry's image and lobby for state regulation.
Yet even as the industry reinvents itself, it may never completely shed its unsavory reputation. "The pawnshop industry is constantly battling its image," Mr. Caskey, the Swarthmore professor, said. "Even if you change reality, you'll still notice that really bad things happen in pawnshops in Hollywood films."

Chart: "Money in a Hurry"
 
Pawnshops offer people a way to raise money quickly by using valuable items they own as collateral on loans. Here is how a transaction at a pawnshop works.
 
A person needing a quick loan goes to a pawnbroker with an item to be pawned, often a piece of jewelry.
 
The pawn-broker appraises the item and then offers a loan, generally much less than the item is worth.
 
If the person accepts -- at interest rates from 3 to 25 percent a month, depending on the state -- the borrower takes the cash and leaves the item behind with the pawnbroker.
 
Most loans are due after 30 days, although many are refinanced for an additional two months.
 
If the loan is not repaid, the broker sells the pawned item to recoup the loan. In some states, the loan is foreclosed and the item auctioned. (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: TEAMSTERS AND U.P.S. AGREE ON A 5-YEAR CONTRACT PLAN TO END STRIKE AFTER 15 DAYS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Aug. 19

 BODY:
After more than 80 hours of intense negotiations, teamsters' union officials and the United Parcel Service said early this morning that they had reached a tentative agreement to end the 15-day strike by 185,000 workers that largely crippled the world's largest package delivery company.
Ron Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said the agreement called for the first increase in the starting pay of part-time workers since 1982 and the conversion of 10,000 part-time jobs into full-time jobs over the five-year life of the new contract. Under the agreement, union workers at U.P.S. would remain in the multiemployer pension plans, with benefit increases for most workers. In addition to the 10,000 new full-time positions, the two sides agreed that five-sixths of all new full-time openings created though attrition or expansion, would be filled by current part-timers, up from the four-fifths in the contract that expired July 31. 
 Mr. Carey, hailed the agreement as a "historic turning point for working people in this country."
"American workers have shown they can stand up to corporate greed," he said.
David Murray, the chief U.P.S. negotiator, said, "We believe it's an agreement that we'll be able to remain competitive with."
Teamster officials said they expected the strikers to return to work on Wednesday. Before that can happen, however, two teamster committees must approve the agreement. One is the 50-member bargaining committee. The other is a committee made up of two representatives from each of the 206 locals representing U.P.S. workers. Both of the committees are expected to act on the tentative settlement today.
Final ratification by the membership will be by mail ballot, which is expected to take three to four weeks.
Mr. Carey said a news conference called to announce the settlement was delayed for more than two hours because the agreement almost fell apart at the last minute.
The company and the union clashed over language on subcontracting and other issues.
Mr. Carey acknowledged that the union made what he considered a major concession -- it accepted a five-year contract, when he would have preferred a three- or four-year accord.
President Clinton thanked representatives of United Parcel Service and the Teamsters union for their "hard work and determination" in reaching a settlement.
 "I am pleased that the parties negotiated in good faith," Clinton said in a written statement read to reporters shortly after the settlement was announced.
The company and the union had been narrowing their differences since the President pressed them to redouble their efforts.
The strike carried high stakes for labor and business. It was a pivotal test for the re-energized labor movement, which strongly backed the teamsters while saying its goal was to insure that a company with more than $1 billion in profits treated its workers fairly.
For corporate America, the strike was a test to see whether one of the nation's biggest and most admired companies could stand up to a revived labor movement and preserve the flexibility and cost structure it said it needed to compete in the global economy.
The settlement came as the strikers, at hundreds of U.P.S. sites in all 50 states, were growing increasingly restive about not working and living on $55 a week in strike benefits. Because of the strike, the workers missed tens of millions of dollars in wages, while the company lost more than $600 million in business.
The strike created myriad inconveniences, large and small, for companies and consumers across the nation. Small businesses complained they were having a hard time restocking their shelves, while hospitals said it was hard to obtain needed supplies.
Among the main issues in the strike was the union's demand that the company convert 10,000 part-time jobs to full-time jobs over the next four years. The company offered to convert 800 workers from part time to full time over that period. As part of a public-relations offensive, the teamsters noted that four-fifths of the unionized jobs U.P.S. created since 1993 were part time, and the union complained that those jobs did not pay enough to support a family.
At U.P.S., part-time workers, for the most part sorters and loaders, average about $9.50 an hour after two years, earning about $10,000 a year.
Full-time workers, largely drivers, average $19.95 an hour, earning more than $40,000 a year.
Mr. Carey said the increases amounted to $3.10 an hour for full-time workers and $4.10 workers.
Another major issue was the company's demand to withdraw from the teamsters' multiemployer pension plans and start a new U.P.S. pension plan. The company promised that pensions would rise by an average of 50 percent, but the union's negotiators opposed that proposal because they feared that U.P.S.'s withdrawal would jeopardize the financial health of the multiemployer plans.
Other issues included pay increases, subcontracting and the company's demand to scrap language in the contract that allowed the teamsters to honor other unions picket lines.
The agreement was a triumph for the new Labor Secretary, Alexis Herman, whose behind-the-scenes work persuaded the union and company to return to the bargaining table last Thursday. For the past five days she stayed in the Hyatt Regency Washington Hotel, where the talks were held, to help keep the two sides at the bargaining table until they reached a settlement.
Sunday was a make-or-break day for the negotiators on both sides, a Labor Department official said. Ms. Herman arrived at the hotel before 8 a.m. and spent most of the day and night going from room to room, helping each side focus on the issues at hand. When she wasn't needed, she paced the corridors and her own private meeting room.
Sunday "was crucial," the official said. "There was a sense it had gone on for a long time and they wanted to bring it to an end. It was clear we would know. They would either be able to cut a deal or not cut a deal."
The rooms on the second floor where each side gathered and both sides met, started to look lived in, with used coffee cups, newspapers, and half-eaten club sandwiches strewn across tables.
"There were real roller coasters," the official said. "More times than I can count, I thought it was coming to a conclusion."
By this morning it was clear they would need another day, so Ms. Herman canceled her appearance on a morning news show. She had a string of private conversations with the mediators throughout the day and the sense of urgency seemed to mount.
Both sides say the main challenges now are to heal the wounds the strike created between management and workers and to regain the business that U.P.S. says it lost to competitors, most notably the United States Postal Service and Federal Express.
The strike hobbled package deliveries around the nation, cutting U.P.S.'s volume to less than 10 percent of normal and nearly overloading the post office and Federal Express, which said it could not guarantee overnight delivery during the strike.
U.P.S. officials said they feared that shipping customers who used to rely exclusively on U.P.S. might have developed some loyalty to the company's competitors during the strike or might have decided it was unwise to rely on just one shipper.
The settlement came on the same day that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. told the White House that it was unhappy with the President's comments on Sunday that the teamsters had been offered "a good deal" in negotiations with the United Parcel Service.
Gerald Shea, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. official in charge of governmental affairs, said he protested to the White House and the Labor Department that the President's statement placed improper pressure on the teamsters to accept U.P.S.'s offer.
"People here were very unhappy that the bully pulpit was being use in a one-sided way," Mr. Shea said in an interview.
On Sunday, President Clinton had voiced optimism about the talks, saying, "It's my gut feeling they'll settle. It's a good deal. It will set a precedent for unions."
Mr. Toiv, the White House spokesman, said, "We understand that both sides in a difficult negotiation sometimes perceive even-handedness as something other than that."
Administration officials said they were surprised that A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials criticized Mr. Clinton for not being even-handed, because for the past two weeks many business leaders have accused the White House of siding with the strikers by not seeking an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act to end the strike.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Teamsters and Ex-Rival Go After Apple Industry

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: WENATCHEE, Wash.

 BODY:
The apples from one of the world's most bounteous fruit-producing regions are nearly ripe. The economy is flush. And an army of low-wage workers who pick and pack the crop is stirring for change. For organized labor, it all adds up to the kind of membership drive that would have been unheard of in previous years.
In what may be the largest unionizing effort under way in the nation, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is aiming at a class of workers it used to ignore and, with its former rival, the United Farm Workers of America, is trying to revive a sagging union presence. It is part of a national drive to increase membership and court public support for people left out of the economic boom. 
 In the 40,000 fruit pickers and 15,000 warehouse workers who are the backbone of Washington State's $1 billion annual apple crop, labor leaders say they have perfect candidates for the new campaign. Most of the apple workers earn barely a few dollars above minimum wage.
After years of shrinking membership in a farm workers union built primarily in California, most of the nation's two million farm workers and packing house employees are not affiliated with unions. But labor leaders have opened two fronts in their new drive. They are trying to unionize 20,000 workers in the California strawberry industry at the same time they move into Washington's apple orchards.
Both efforts are part of a broader campaign symbolized by the strike at United Parcel Service to enhance labor's influence with low-end workers.
"We have a whole new attitude about organizing," said Rich Trumka, the secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., who is in Washington State this week to assist the unionizing effort in the apple orchards and packing houses. "We're reaching out to everyone from the top to the bottom."
In the West the teamsters have taken charge of the effort to unionize warehouse workers, who sort and ship the fruit, while the farm workers are trying to bring the pickers into the union fold. The top ranks of the labor movement, from the farm workers union president, Arturo Rodriguez, to the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, John J. Sweeney, have led rallies in the apple country.
The growers say their business is largely a family industry, reliant upon low-wage entry workers, with a narrow profit margin and variables of climate and price. A large-scale unionizing effort, like the one under way here this summer, could radically change the industry and hurt many orchardists, they say.
A boycott or strike could cripple the growers in the brief season when a harvest of 40 billion pounds of apples is picked in Washington. But the strongest leverage, for labor, may be the fact that the state best known for producing software and airplanes now has an acute labor shortage, especially at the low end of the wage scale.
"We have record-low unemployment in this state and it has become a very competitive business trying to hold on to the best people," said Mike Gempler, executive director of the Washington Growers League, which represents the orchard industry.
The very threat of union membership may already have had an effect. A recent memorandum to growers from the Washington Farm Bureau, which represents agricultural interests, suggested paying as high a wage as possible as one way to thwart union activity.
"Praise employees for their work," it said. "If necessary, increase wages and benefits."
Competitive it may be, but the business of picking and processing fruit has remained a low-wage industry. On average, warehouse workers work about 10 months a year and make about $7.50 an hour, a wage that, adjusted for inflation, has not changed in more than 10 years. In the fields, apple harvesters make $8 to $9 for picking a 1,000-pound bin of fruit, and work pruning the trees in the off-season. A fast worker can fill five or so bins in a day.
Though the unions have not asked for a specific contract, one goal is to increase wages by as much as 50 percent, an increase that growers say would devastate them.
Labor leaders are taking an unusual tack in trying to organize the apple industry. They have not specifically requested that packing houses or farm fields hold a vote on whether or not workers can join a union, as is usually done. Instead, they are asking for a contract first, and will then ask for a Federally sanctioned vote on union membership.
The unions are afraid to call for open elections, the growers contend, saying that most field and warehouse workers do not want to join unions. They accuse labor of taking a backdoor approach at gaining a huge number of new, dues-paying members.
For the United Farm Workers, for example, bringing the apple pickers into the union would more than double the membership, now around 20,000 workers, most in California. The teamsters, with 1.8 million members, would gain a new type of worker, but the addition would not greatly increase membership, at first.
For the teamsters, the apple campaign is also an opportunity to make inroads into the Hispanic community. An overwhelming majority of farm workers in this state are from Mexico, though most now live year round in Washington State. Nationwide, women and members of minorities are the fastest-growing segment of new union membership.
The national teamsters leadership has included several Spanish-speaking members among the dozen or so representatives sent to Washington.
"We want all of our organizations to reflect the new work force of America," Mr. Trumka said.
It is a long way from the early 1970's, when the A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders said they did not want low-end agricultural workers in their federation, and they feuded with the farm workers, then led by Cesar Chavez, who died in 1993. Now the two unions are working closely together in the apple campaign, joined by members of the Roman Catholic clergy and some Democratic politicians.
The apple growers say the union effort is driven by outsiders, and is little more than an effort to flex union muscle after years of decline.
"This is not something that's home-grown," Mr. Gempler said. "It is a pretty classic campaign from the outside."
Inside some of the bigger fruit-packing warehouses, where apples are stored in year-round compartments, it is difficult to gauge sentiment, because no votes have been taken. Pedro Navarrete, a 46-year-old father of seven children, works at two jobs, sorting fruit during a swing shift, then getting up early during the harvest to pick. After 25 years in the industry, Mr. Navarrete said he made less money now than when he started, and for that reason, he favors the union.
"I get home at 1 A.M. and then get up at 4 A.M.," Mr. Navarrete said. "I would like to see us at least get a raise and some benefits."
Only a handful of the packing plants offer medical benefits; the employees usually have to pay part of the cost of insurance, not an uncommon arrangement but in this case few workers can afford it. Workers also contend that plants are unsafe, and they point to a recent carbon monoxide leak at a packing house in the small town of Brewster, north of here. The leak sent nearly 100 people to a hospital.
After 10 years at the same fruit-packing plant here in Wenatchee, Jorja Starr said she made only 90 cents an hour more than someone hired this year.
"In 1988, I grossed $11,770," Ms. Starr said. "In 1996, I earned $14,000 and this increase was mostly due to increasing full-time work. Not a lot to look forward to."
At the same time, revenues in the apple industry have tripled over 10 years, to $1 billion for the state. Growers attributed the increase to more farmers growing more apples. The profit margin has not increased in most years, they say. The big money being made in the apple industry, both sides agree, is by retailers, whose share is better than 50 percent of the consumer price of an apple. Washington provides 60 percent of the nation's apples.
Granting apple packers a 50 percent raise, said a teamster spokesman, Patrick Lacefield, would add only 2.4 cents a pound to the price of apples to consumers.
Growers say wage increases would come from their revenues, forcing many of them to lose money.
If labor leaders succeed in their apple campaign, they plan to apply the tactics used here and in the California strawberry fields to other agricultural sectors. But Washington is different from other regions; it is a state with a long labor tradition and an economy that was booming well before the rest of the country recovered from economic downturns.
Labor leaders say they do not plan, at this time, to call for a strike or a boycott of Washington apples. Instead, they are courting public opinion.
At the same time, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has started running television advertisements intended to improve the public perception of unions.
The $5 million advertising campaign, which began in Seattle this week and will run in selected cities around the country, shows women and members of minorities, amid patriotic trappings, espousing the benefits of union membership.
Union membership, nationwide, hit a high of 36 percent of the work force in 1945, and fell to a low of 14.5 percent last year.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
NOT many years ago, the Far East was a booming market for Cognac and wine was mostly an afterthought. Since then, Asia has become the newest market, and potentially one of the most lucrative, for fine wine, apparently at Cognac's expense. Cognac is in trouble around the world, but particularly in the Far East.
Wine makers from all over the world have been flocking to Japan, China, Singapore and Thailand and have been received with open arms. Part of this new enthusiasm stems from the perception that wine, particularly red wine, is good for you, and part of it from the ever-growing demand for Western consumer goods. What does it matter, as The Wall Street Journal reported recently, that some Asian wine drinkers cut their Chateau Lafite-Rothschild with Coke and 7-Up? Customers are customers. 
 In 1988, Joseph Seagram & Sons bought Martell & Company, one of the four top Cognac producers. Martell was a big player in Asia and it seemed to Seagram like a good way to gain a foothold in that market.
But a decline was about to set in. Last year alone, Cognac shipments to Hong Kong were off 26 percent, to Singapore 18.9 percent, to Malaysia 4.2 percent, to Taiwan 27.4 percent and to Thailand 13.6 percent, according to Impact, a trade publication.
In 1996, the total world market for Cognac was 9.8 million cases, according to Impact, down from almost 12 million cases in 1990. The six top Asian markets -- Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan, South Korea and Thailand -- accounted for just under 35 percent of the world market. China has been particularly disappointing. The Cognac market there declined by 11 percent last year, to about 600,000 cases, following a 10 percent decline in 1995.
Moreover, Asian Cognac fans have been moving to cheaper stuff. The average price paid for a bottle of Cognac last year was almost 18 percent below the 1995 figure in South Korea, 6 percent in Taiwan and 8 percent in Thailand. (Cognac prices range from $20 to $300 a bottle.)
Cognac shipments to the United States, which declined steadily between 1990 and 1995, were up 17 percent last year, thanks, according to Impact, to the upbeat economy and a renewed interest in luxuries like cigars and single-malt Scotch. But middle-class America's return to the good life can't do much to alleviate the problems of the Cognac region of France, where overproduction has become a crisis.
If every Cognac grower there were to close up shop for the next seven years, it would have little effect on the market. Currently, there is an almost eight-year supply in the warehouses of the Charente and the Charente-Maritime, the two western departments of France where Cognac is made. The ideal would be about four years' supply.
The Cognac region encompasses about 2.8 million acres, of which about 80,000 acres are planted with the two most important Cognac grapes, ugni blanc and folle blanche. Last year, 145 million bottles of Cognac were produced from the grapes planted on those 80,000 acres, more than two times what the producers can sell.
Most Cognac is not produced by big distillers but by individual grape growers and small cooperatives. Some distill and age it themselves, but most Cognac is distilled in small batches and then sold to the major producers, who blend and age it.
In the past, these producers like Hennessy, Martell and Courvoisier bought whatever the farmers produced. They assumed big crops would be followed by small ones. But now the large Cognac houses are owned by conglomerates -- Hennessy by LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, Martell by Seagram and Courvoisier by Allied Domecq -- and the emphasis is on financial return. The big companies do not buy grapes or Cognac that they do not need.
And so an effort is under way to pull up at least 30,000 of the 200,000 acres of vines currently in production. For every hectare (2.5 acres) of vines a grower in the Cognac region agrees to remove, he can earn almost $17,000 in financial incentives from the industry's trade group, from the French Government and from the European Union. According to the trade group, some 4,000 growers out of 6,000 have agreed to participate in the nine-year plan.
In addition to cutting back on the Cognac surplus, the plan envisions a change to diversified grape growing. Cabernet sauvignon and merlot have been suggested as new tenants.
Wine can be made from both folle blanche and ugni blanc (the French name for the Italian trebbiano), but not very good wine, which is why, for several hundred years, it has all been distilled into Cognac. Whether cabernet and merlot grown in the chalky soils of the Charente will fare any better is debatable. The wines made from them will have to compete with cabernets and merlots from the vast new vineyards in the Languedoc, which were also planted at the urging of the European Union.
Meanwhile, the Cognac companies have embarked on a campaign to encourage more people to drink their product, especially in France, which has never been much of a market for its own Cognac. About 95 percent of French Cognac is exported.
Drink Cognac on the rocks, the companies suggest. Drink it with tonic as an aperitif.
Cognac with tonic? Strange talk from the people who boast of their special soils, of their distilling methods, of their painstaking blending and the delicate tastes and aromas they produce. Are they not advocating something along the lines of Lafite-Rothschild with Coke?
 
TASTINGS
Brolio Chianti Classico 1994, Tuscany, Italy. About $10.
 
For years now, Chianti producers have reveled in experimentation. Their goal: to break away from the traditional Chianti formula of sangiovese, canaiolo and trebbiano or some other white wine grape. Recently, there has been a trend back to the classic blend, and if anyone should lead it, it's Brolio. Baron Bettino Ricasoli created the formula for Chianti Classico at Brolio Castle in the heart of the Chianti region in 1835. The grapes for this wine, about 90 percent sangiovese, 8 percent canaiolo and 2 percent white malvasia toscana, all came from the same estate vineyards the baron cultivated almost two centuries ago. The wine is medium bodied with intense blackberry sangiovese flavors and is destined to enhance any Italian-style chicken or veal dish.

HEADLINE: Several Retailers Report Earnings That Beat Estimates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Retailers of very different stripes -- Home Depot, Dayton Hudson and Tiffany -- reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that surpassed Wall Street's expectations.
But earnings at two women's clothing chains, Ann Taylor and the Limited, fizzled. 
 Retailers that focused on customers, that had a strong brand identity and that controlled costs outperformed rivals, analysts said.
"It doesn't matter if it's an appliance store or home furnishings, people feel freer to spend the extra couple of dollars for the brand, the customer service and the quality," said Art Bonell, a portfolio manager with the Bonell Growth Fund, which owns shares of Home Depot and other retail stocks. "That's the basic underlying reason for strength in retail sales."
Earnings at Home Depot Inc. rose 32.5 percent in the quarter, to $357.9 million, or 48 cents a share, from $270.1 million, or 37 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The results were 2 cents higher than consensus estimates by First Call Inc.
The results were fueled by a strong economy and swelling ranks of homeowners, analysts said. Home Depot, which is based in Atlanta, also benefited from consolidation in its market, with the Hechinger Company planning to combine with Kmart's Builders Square, and with Payless Cashways Inc. and Grossman's Inc. in Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
"They are really starting to benefit from the obvious acceleration of consolidation in the industry," said Don Trott, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman.
Analysts also cited good inventory control and expense management. Selling and operating expenses for the stores fell to 16.8 percent of sales, from 17 percent in the period a year earlier.
Sales rose 24 percent, to $6.55 billion. Sales in stores open at least a year rose 5 percent.
The Dayton Hudson Corporation, which owns department stores and the Target discount chain, said earnings rose 28.7 percent, to $130 million, or 56 cents a share, from $101 million, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The most recent quarter included a charge of $11 million, or 5 cents a share, for the retirement of debt. The results before the charge surpassed Wall Street forecasts of 56 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Revenue rose 9.4 percent, to $6.29 billion.
Dayton Hudson, which is based in Minneapolis, benefited from growth at its Target stores. Target accounted for three-fourths of second-quarter revenue.
Dayton Hudson said Target's operating profit rose 14 percent, to $274 million. The division's sales also increased 14 percent with those at stores open at least one year up 6 percent. Target's margins narrowed as it made larger markdowns on clearance items.
The department store division more than doubled its operating profit, to $33 million from $12 million. Sales increased 1 percent, with those at comparable stores down 1 percent. Margins improved at its Marshall Field's, Dayton's and Hudson's department stores on lower expenses and higher merchandise markups.
Tiffany & Company reported a 25.3 percent gain in earnings. The company earned $10.4 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $8.3 million, or 24 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. That beat by a penny the average estimate of 17 analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S.
Helped by strong jewelry sales at its year-old Tokyo store, revenue rose 7.1 percent, to $217.1 million.
Tiffany received a lift from international sales, which rose 3 percent, to $90.9 million, even as the dollar rose in value.
Limited Inc. reported sluggish sales for the quarter. Earnings fell 17 percent, to $27.6 million, or 10 cents a share, from $33.2 million, or 12 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. The results matched analysts' expectations.
"We haven't seen a turnaround at Limited," said Peter Schaeffer, an analyst with Dillon, Read & Company. "I can't blame it on the customer; I have to blame it on the company."
Revenue rose 6.6 percent, to $2.02 billion. Sales in stores open at least a year, were unchanged, he said.
The Limited owns 83 percent of Intimate Brands Inc., which operates the Victoria's Secret clothing chain, and 84 percent of the Abercrombie & Fitch clothing chain. It also operates Lane Bryant, Lerner New York and Henri Bendel.
At the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation, sales of clothing, shoes and accessories faltered as customers shunned fashions tailored more for younger women than for the professional and conservative customers above the age of 25.
"Sales fell below plan every month in the second quarter," said Maura Hunter Byrne, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities.
The company earned $812,000, or 3 cents a share, compared with $627,000, or 3 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. The most recent quarter included a charge of $173,000, or 1 cent a share, for the repayment of debt.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Little Change In Bonds as Fed Stays Put

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities closed mixed yesterday, with a token gain, after the Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee decided to keep interest rates unchanged.
The benchmark 30-year bond rose 4/32 to a price of 98 9/32 for a yield to maturity of 6.51 percent, down from 6.52 percent on Monday. 
 Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the central bank's decision had been widely anticipated because of the lack of inflation pressure.
"Indeed, despite the solid pace of economic growth," he said, "the Fed is likely to refrain from another tightening move until it has reason to believe that the business advance is strong enough to produce a sustained uplift in prices, in which case the central bank will act pre-emptively as a deterrent."
The Fed last raised an interest rate in March, increasing the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, by 25 basis points, or a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. Its policy group, the Federal Open Market Committee, left rates unchanged at meetings in May and July.
Strong economic expansion has pushed the official unemployment rate to 4.8 percent, the lowest in more than two decades, resulting in a tight labor market that has not, however, brought the inflationary pressure often associated with expansion. Fears of layoffs, new technology and global competition have been cited as factors that have helped keep price and wage pressure at bay.
Data on housing starts in July, released yesterday, were unchanged at 1.47 million units, an outcome that Mr. Fine called slightly below expectations. "Nevertheless, the housing market remains very vibrant and healthy, particularly for this mature phase of the economic expansion," he said. "Tomorrow's June trade balance should help shore up revisions to second-quarter G.D.P., while the Philadelphia Fed's manufacturing survey on Thursday will provide an early peek into the August economic environment."
The bond market, Mr. Fine added, appears to be in a trading range for now, and buyers are likely to wait for some major indicators to be released over the next three weeks, the first of which will be data on durable-goods orders next Tuesday.
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, an economic consulting and forecasting firm, said the housing data indicated continuing growth in consumer spending in the coming year.
"We have maintained that consumer spending will continue to grow at a healthy, but not excessive rate in the second half of the year, and the housing data support this analysis," Mr. McCarthy said. "For the Fed, the persistent strength of the housing sector is something they will monitor. If housing activity accelerates, it could be a cause for concern about possible overheating of the economy. But as long as starts remain in the range of the past two years, 1.4 million to 1.5 million units, they will have no impact on monetary policy."
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said he did not foresee a tightening of money by the Fed at its next rate-setting meeting on Sept. 30, but "we do foresee another 25-basis-point Federal funds rate rise in response to the inevitable string of very strong retail sales reports, although we currently do not see this happening until early 1998."
That view runs counter to the prevailing view among Wall Street economists that the Fed will tighten money before the end of the year, with one in four expecting a rate increase at the Sept. 30 meeting.
Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, Discover Card priced $789 million of asset-backed securities through a special trust, Discover Card MT 1997-1. Underwriters led by Morgan Stanley priced the securities, which are backed by credit card receivables, in two parts. The first part consisted of $750 million in securities with an average life of five years, that were priced to yield the London interbank offered rate plus 9 basis points. The second part, $39.5 million in securities, was priced at the London rate plus 27 basis points.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Again vs. Mark On Bundesbank Rate Decision

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday for a second consecutive day after the Bundesbank, the German central bank, left an interest rate unchanged. The dollar also benefited from a strong recovery in United States stocks.
Against the Japanese yen, the dollar advanced slightly as a Japanese economic official distanced himself from previous comments that record-low interest rates there were poised to rise later this year. 
 In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.8388 marks, from 1.8305 marks on Monday. The dollar also rose to 118.21 yen, from 117.82 yen. The British pound rose to $1.6054, from $1.6047.
The decision yesterday by the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates steady was expected and had only a minor impact in the market.
The dollar rose against the yen in Asian trading after Taro Aso, the director general of Japan's Economic Planning Agency, distanced himself from a remark earlier this month that Japanese rates would rise by the year's end. Mr. Aso had said that it would merely be natural if rates rose once the Japanese economy recovered from its stagnation.
Against the mark, the dollar climbed after the Bundesbank left its benchmark repurchase rate unchanged at 3 percent at a weekly securities repurchase auction. That decision, coupled with a smaller-than-expected July rise of 5.7 percent in the M-3 measure of Germany's money supply, convinced many currency traders that the Bundesbank would not raise German rates when its policy council meets tomorrow.
The rise in the money supply "eliminates the chance of a rate hike on Thursday because if you believe what the Bundesbank says, it closely watches the M-3, and today's number handcuffs them," Michael Malpede, senior foreign exchange analyst at Refco, said.
Comments from the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, also helped dash expectations for higher German rates. He told a Spanish newspaper that recent dollar strength was not a risk for European inflation and that the Bundesbank should wait before raising rates.
The dollar was also bolstered by continued strength in the United States stock market.
