HEADLINE: In Mir's Path: Hard Lesson

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Big rockets can launch warheads as easily as astronauts and throughout the space age have been used interchangeably for such wildly dissimilar jobs. This fact of technological life is one of the main reasons that Washington puts up with the tragicomedy of the Russian Mir space station.
As Mir has lurched from glitch to near-disaster, Americans who watched NASA astronauts join their Russian counterparts on the station wondered why the space agency would put them in a situation so seemingly unsafe. 
 The answer may be that NASA -- and the Government -- have a lot riding on the Russian program.
After the nightmare of the cold war, Washington wants to do all it can to help the shaky Russian economy, especially its aerospace component. The United States wants to encourage Russia to use its aerospace brawn for constructive rather than destructive ends. In particular, it wants to discourage the Russians from selling big rockets to countries that might use them for nuclear war and blackmail.
Many in official Washington, especially Vice President Al Gore, have forged cooperative links between Mir and the American space program and work hard to keep the bonds strong. When the cooperative program got under way, the United States provided cash incentives, and nowadays when things go awry, they look the other way.
These costs are considered small compared with the political, economic and technical benefits.
"Mir documents the possibility of big changes in the relationship of countries that used to be enemies," a White House official said yesterday. American astronauts gain valuable experience from their service on Mir, the official said, adding, "It looks like a tough day at the office, but people know how to handle these problems."
Perhaps no one in Washington has worked harder on the Mir conundrum than Daniel S. Goldin, the head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
"You can't make this unbelievable transition from pointing weapons at one another to working together without bumps in the road," Mr. Goldin said in June 1995 as a space shuttle roared aloft for the first Mir rendezvous. "If you put your mind to something and search for common interests, you can build bridges."
Despite recent woes and cliffhangers (some aerospace experts would say because of them), the aging Mir outpost is considered an important learning experience for the Americans, who have nothing similar.
It is also seen as important bridge to an even bigger East-West endeavor -- the international space station, a behemoth the size of a football field. Beginning next year, it is to be built piecemeal in space, and by 2003 it is to hold up to seven astronauts. Fifteen nations are contributing to its construction.
The deal includes financial aid to Moscow in the form of a $400 million contract for space hardware and launching services. Not coincidentally, Moscow gave in to American calls for it to drop a planned sale of advanced rocket engines to India, which Washington viewed as dangerously destabilizing the tense subcontinent.
As a warmup to the international station, shuttle astronauts are now making seven visits to Mir; five have occurred so far. The final visit is to end next June, just as work gets under way on the bigger outpost.
"It's the early phases of the long-term marriage of the U.S. and Russian" programs, Dr. John M. Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, said yesterday in an interview. "And it's a bargain in programmatic terms, aside from the broader geopolitical security elements."
If all goes well, the East-West collaboration will lead to a 470-ton, 356-foot-long outpost for scientists studying the heavens, the Earth and things like the physiological response to extended periods of weightlessness -- key information if people are ever to venture to distant worlds.
The big station is meant to last at least 10 years and will cost some $50 billion to build and run.
The woes of the 11-year-old Mir have raised questions about whether it should be abandoned in favor of the big outpost, which is viewed as safer. But many analysts say the new international station will have its own accidents and dangers, some of which could be major.
"All the things that have happened could happen in the future," said Jerry Grey, policy director of the American Institute of Astronautics and Aeronautics in Washington, a professional group of aerospace engineers. "If we planned the use of Mir in the most effective way," he added, "we would have had all these accidents. It's invaluable experience."

HEADLINE: Air Force Acts To Cut Stress Among Pilots

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Worried by reports that the pilots of its jet fighters and other warplanes were being worked too hard, the Air Force said today that it was sharply curtailing the number of major flight competitions and canceling a large training program.
The move came after a study prepared for the Air Force found that the high stress levels among its pilots were leading to alcoholism, divorce and low morale. 
 The Air Combat Command, which is based at Langley Air Force Base, Va., and which operates all of the service's warplanes, said in a statement that "reducing operations tempo is a top priority."
The Air Force said it was canceling two large pilot competitions planned for later this year, Gunsmoke '97 and Proud Shield, and rescheduling them for next year. Two competitions scheduled for 1998 were rescheduled for 1999. And a large training program, Checkered Flag, which was established in 1979 to insure the wartime readiness of the Tactical Air Command, was ended.
Commanders have been alarmed in recent years by the number of pilots who have chosen to leave the service, many complaining that their assignments were too long and too stressful. Earlier this summer, the Air Force said it would reduce the standard overseas deployment for air crews to 45 days from 90.
But the new study prepared for the Air Force by the Rand Corporation, a research organization based in California, shows that those cuts may not have gone far enough to deal with the pilots' concerns.
The Air Force declined to make the report public, but a copy was obtained by The Washington Times, which reported today that the Rand study had found widespread complaints among air crews about the pace and stress of their jobs.

HEADLINE: CONCLUDING THE U.P.S. STRIKE: THE PENSION PLAN;
Teamsters, Not Company, Will Reap Benefits of Bull Market

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The teamsters' tentative settlement with the United Parcel Service maintains a pension plan in which the benefits of the rising stock market flow to workers through increased retirement benefits instead of to the company through lower costs.
Because of the rising stock market, the typical U.P.S. driver's pension improved by about 60 percent from 1987 to 1994, said Teresa Ghilarducci, an associate professor of pension economics at the University of Notre Dame. 
 Had the kind of pension plan that U.P.S. wanted been in effect during those years, Professor Ghilarducci said, pension benefits would have risen by a fraction of that amount, but the company would have seen its annual pension costs decline or possibly even vanish.
U.P.S. participates in 21 defined-benefit pension plans, called multi-employer plans, which cover workers at many trucking companies. The teamsters union and the companies jointly oversee investment of the pension funds in stocks, bonds and real estate.
In multi-employer plans, each company contributes a fixed amount that is usually based on the number of hours worked by its employees. Over all, 8.1 million workers participate in such plans, the Labor Department said yesterday.
The more common type of plan, called a single-employer plan, covers workers at one company. The Labor Department said 32.3 million workers were in such plans.
Single-employer plans may be owned by the company or jointly administered with a union, as U.P.S. had proposed. In either case, the company contributes as much as is needed to cover benefits, with many companies not having to make any contributions in recent years because of the rising stock market.
The reason that the 20 percent of workers in multi-employer plans benefit from the rising stock market has to do with tax law. Congress limits the amount of money in pension plans, denying tax deductions for new contributions to any plan that has 1.5 times as much as it needs to pay pension benefits. When that limit is reached, the only way to make future contributions tax-deductible is to increase benefits until the funding ratio falls below the limit in the tax code.
When the full funding limit is reached in a single-employer plan, the company not only can stop making contributions, but it can also even take back the surplus.
Companies can also increase benefits, but that happens far less frequently, Professor Ghilarducci found after analyzing every pension plan report filed with the Labor Department in 1980 and 1993 to determine their generosity factor, which is the year-over-year increase in the value of benefits to each worker.
The generosity factor for single employer plans rose to $900 from $700, she said, while multi-employer plans increased to $1,000 from $400. That means that the generosity of multi-employer plans grew at nearly nine times the rate of single-employer plans.
Increased generosity shows up in bigger pension checks and other benefits, like shorter eligibility requirements for retirement benefits, larger payments to a surviving spouse and retirement with full benefits at the age of 50, compared with the typical normal retirement age of 65 in single-employer plans.
The tentative pact also works to the advantage of teamsters in the plans who do not work for U.P.S.
"The fact that U.P.S. is going to remain in the multi-employer plans is very good news for the teamsters institutionally," said Bob Walter, a pension lawyer with Buck Consultants in Secaucus, N.J. "If U.P.S. had won in this issue, it could have started a run on these plans by other employers."
Multi-employer plans, which are common in trucking, construction and other highly fragmented industries, allow workers to switch employers within an industry without reducing the value of their pension. Thus any U.P.S. drivers laid off because of business lost during the strike will not lose pension benefits if they find work with other employers in the multi-employer plans.
Workers in single-employer plans who switch employers end up with smaller retirement checks because their pension from the first employer is frozen and they must start over earning retirement benefits. Under Federal pension rules, an individual who works for nine such employers over 40 years can end up with no pension, while the same person in a multi-employer plan would get full benefits.
Harry Conaway, a pension expert at William M. Mercer, the nation's largest benefits consulting firm, said one reason U.P.S. wanted out of the multi-employer plans was the way the law treats money owed to such plans by employers that go out of business without having made all of their contributions. The other employers must make up these shortfalls if gains from investments do not cover them, said Mr. Conaway, a former chief of pension tax policy in the Reagan Administration.
He said a dominant employer in such plans could end up subsidizing competitors. Mr. Conaway cited as an example a multi-employer plan that requires 1,000 hours of work annually for full benefits and which requires a specific dollar contribution by the employer for each hour worked. A company whose workers average 1,600 hours, but whose competitors average 1,000 hours, would effectively subsidize the pensions of workers at competing companies.

HEADLINE: CONCLUDING THE U.P.S. STRIKE: THE EMPLOYEES;
Rank and File's Verdict: A Walkout Well Waged

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 19

 BODY:
When money for a baby sitter ran out several days ago, Maria Leon, a striking United Parcel Service worker, stood in the rain on the picket line with her 3-year-old son, Adolfo, and nearly wept at her powerlessness.
"But we didn't give up," Mrs. Leon said today, her eyes now as bright and full as sunshine on the prairie, "and that made all the difference." 
 On picket lines outside U.P.S. depots across America, as here in Chicago, there was downright elation over the terms of the tentative pact between the company and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
"It's a big win not only for the union but for labor," said Robert Ridley, a 44-year-old U.P.S. driver in Austin, Tex. "This was labor against corporate America."
In Chicago, home of the nation's largest teamster local representing U.P.S. workers, with about 12,000 members, the strike will last a day or so longer, a result of a longstanding tradition of independence by the local, No. 705.
The Chicago local will sign its tentative pact with U.P.S. soon after the national union formally completes its deal, probably only a day or two later, said Paul Waterhouse, a spokesman for 705. The terms of the Chicago agreement are unlikely to differ from the national package in any significant way.
Many United Parcel workers said they were eager to see the details of the agreement, but they voiced unreserved joy over two central provisions: the company's promise to add 10,000 full-time jobs over five years and to raise the pay of part-timers about $4 an hour during the same period.
"I'm looking for one of those full-time jobs," said Bob Hojnacki, a stocky 32-year-old in a baseball cap, who has been a part-time worker for U.P.S. in Chicago since 1984. "I can't tell you how happy that would make me."
Outside the United Parcel depot on the West Side of Manhattan, triumphant strikers were lifting clenched fists in celebration and shouting thanks to passing motorists who leaned on car horns in support.
"I'm ready to jump up and down and shout," said David Johnson, 49, who has worked for U.P.S. since he was a teen-ager. "I'm also looking out for the people who will come after me."
For all the brave talk during the walkout, strikers generally acknowledged that they had been taking a big risk, even in a time of a robust national economy. Indeed, Mr. Hojnacki, among others, said he probably would have voted to support what the company had repeatedly described as its "last, best and final offer," which came nowhere close to the settlement ultimately reached on Monday night.
"Everybody knows what's happened to some unions in this country," Mr. Hojnacki said, tracing the decline in the labor movement's power to President Ronald Reagan's dismissal of striking air traffic controllers.
What is more, many workers said, most American companies have become so focused on raising the price of their stock that interests of workers routinely take a back seat to the interests of shareholders.
Still, the teamsters had gambled that United Parcel had just as much to lose from a strike as the workers.
"Personally, I thought it wouldn't last more than a week, with so much money at stake," said Bill Tom, a $12-an-hour sorter at the main U.P.S. depot in Seattle.
Outside the huge U.P.S. center in the western Chicago suburb of Willow Springs today, hundreds of workers lined up to collect strike benefits. The plant -- which employs 5,500 workers, the vast majority of them part-timers -- has been plagued by problems of turnover and absenteeism, for which many employees blame the nature of an overwhelmingly part-time work force.
"They've even got a problem with workers' pilfering things," said Jeff Ernst, a 29-year-old part-time clerk. "Those problems are always worse when you don't have loyalty. And why are part-timers going to be loyal?"
Gloria Harris, 39, said the strikers had felt inspired by a sense that they were standing up for other working people.
"This sent a message to other companies that you can't keep pushing people so hard, and expect to get away with paying them part-time," said Ms. Harris, a single mother who lives in a two-bedroom apartment in the rough-at-the-edges Chicago neighborhood of Englewood.
Except for those who crossed the picket lines, Ms. Harris said, the strike brought people together in a way that company picnics and bowling leagues never could.
"We now feel more like brothers and sisters than co-workers," she said, noting the diversity of the strikers, who, until the walkout, had often kept to their own racial or ethnic group. "We all learned something about color. It comes down to green."

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE LETS RATES STAND

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, continuing a remarkable economic experiment in which the central bank has kept interest rates low despite shrinking unemployment and unusually strong economic growth.
Today's meeting of the Fed's policy-making committee was the third consecutive time that the central bank has passed up a chance to raise short-term interest rates. The last increase in the key short-term rate that the Fed controls came in March, a quarter-point rise, to 5.50 percent. 
 The Fed's action today was no surprise. A wide variety of recent economic measurements have shown that inflation remains at barely noticeable levels, below an annual rate of 2 percent in the first half of the year. That is the lowest inflation rate since the early 1960's, and wholesale prices have declined this year, the first time that has happened in more than four decades.
But the Federal Reserve's job is to anticipate economic trends and to act on such assumptions months in advance. So its decision today to hold its fire may only spur arguments over whether it is missing signs that wages and prices will increase toward the end of this year or in the beginning of 1998.
So far, such evidence is scant. But the concessions made by the United Parcel Service to striking teamsters late Monday, hours before the Federal Open Market Committee met here, are bound to figure in those arguments in coming months.
Some economists were already suggesting today that the wage increases won by the union could signal the end of a remarkable period during which companies have been hard pressed to find qualified new workers, yet there has been little effective pressure from workers for higher wages. Other economists, however, suggested today that the teamsters' gains were more symbolic than precedent-setting, and that global overcapacity, particularly in the production of automobiles, would keep prices down even if companies were forced to pay their workers somewhat more.
The U.P.S. agreement would raise average hourly wages over the life of the five-year contract for full-time workers by $3.10, to $23, and for part-time workers by $4.10, to $15.
As usual, the Fed did not explain its reasoning today, simply announcing that the Federal Open Market Committee had met and adjourned. But that was enough to help extend this week's rebound on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 114.74 points, closing at 7,918.10. Taken together with Monday's gains, the index is now up 223 points from Friday, when it lost 247 points in a broad-ranging selloff.
The stock market's potential reaction may have had some influence on today's decision to hold interest rates steady. The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, has made no secret of his fear that the air could come out of the high-flying market too quickly; that may have been why he declined last month, in Congressional testimony, to repeat his warning that investors risked "irrational exuberance."
Among economists and traders, there has been widespread speculation in recent weeks that Mr. Greenspan now fears that even a modest increase in interest rates could bring about the selloff he has been trying to avoid.
"Clearly, the market is overvalued," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation. "And with everyone this jittery and unsure, it would have been a very, very poor time to raise rates."
But Mr. Sung is among those predicting that rates may rise modestly after the Open Market Committee's next meeting, on Sept. 30. "By that time, there will be more evidence about growth in the third quarter," Mr. Sung said. That growth figure is widely forecast to be around 3 percent, meaning that growth over the past four quarters would average around 3.6 percent.
If such figures hold, the Fed will have to face anew the question of whether huge investments by American businesses in recent years -- combined with new technology, the effects of which are not easily measured -- have given the economy greater capacity for noninflationary growth than would be expected under conventional economic theories.
Over the last year, Mr. Greenspan has suggested that the economy may be able to grow beyond its traditional speed limits without risking trouble.
"There is scant evidence," he said in an assessment in May that still applies today, "of any imminent resurgence of inflation."
The question is when he might decide that such experimentation has reached its limits. A few months ago, economists were predicting he would do so this month. But Mr. Greenspan has acted less like a theoretician than a pragmatist, and the indicators he surveys each day have shown little sign of change. Many of the same economists who believed that rates would be increased in July are now saying that the raise will come at the Fed's meeting in September.
But whenever the Fed does decide to raise rates, Mr. Greenspan will have to marshal evidence to justify the move. He was harshly criticized in Congress for a series of increases in 1994 and early 1995, and the White House was visibly uneasy. Now, after a spate of revisionist history, Mr. Clinton's economic policy makers say those increases were vital to sustaining the current expansion.
So far, both organized labor and business have insisted that no interest rate increase is necessary, a position the National Association of Manufacturers restated today.
"The Federal Reserve has acted wisely by choosing not to act at all," the association said in a statement. "Clearly, there are no major cost increases in the pipeline. In fact, as these price declines feed through to the final sales level, the inflation rate should slow even further." The association said its own forecasts predicted that in the year 2000, inflation "will still be in the range of 2 percent."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

No Change in Rates, For Now, Fed Decides
The Federal Reserve voted to leave interest rates unchanged, continuing a remarkable economic experiment in which the central bank has kept rates low despite shrinking unemployment and unusually strong economic growth.
Still, the Fed's action was no surprise, as a variety of recent economic measurements show that inflation remains at barely noticeable levels, indicating no need to apply the monetary brakes. [Page A1.] 

While growth has been strong, the pace has shown signs of moderating. That trend continued in the housing market in July, with the Commerce Department reporting that housing starts remained at a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.45 million, the same as in June. Analysts had expected a slight increase. [D6.]
 
The economic developments appeared to have little effect on the bond market, despite a surge in stocks. The 30-year Treasury bond was almost unchanged, with the yield slipping to 6.51 percent from 6.52. [D15.]
 
Teamsters Celebrate U.P.S. Deal
Teamsters like Kevin Hartman in Watertown, Mass., are going back to work, celebrating an agreement with the United Parcel Service that they assert is a major victory. Though company officials said that as many as 15,000 workers may be laid off because of losses of business resulting from the strike, they acknowledged that they had made a series of concessions on pay, pensions and part-time workers. [A1.]
 
Mixed Results for Retailers
Retailers of very different stripes -- Home Depot, Dayton Hudson and Tiffany -- reported second-quarter earnings that surpassed Wall Street's expectations. But results were disappointing at two women's clothing chains, Ann Taylor and the Limited. [D3.]
 
Higher Bid for Canadian Insurer
A group led by Great-West Lifeco opened a bidding war for London Insurance Group of Canada, offering $2.1 billion, in a move to create Canada's biggest insurer. The offer is 22 percent higher than a previous one from Royal Bank of Canada. [D4.]
 
Strong Dell Results Lift Stock
Dell Computer reported earnings that exceeded estimates, as it continued to take market share away from other personal computer makers. In anticipation of the results, which were reported after the close of the market, investors bid up the company's stock. [D2.]
 
Settlement, but No Explanation
Presstek, a company whose stock was one of the fastest climbers in the mid-1990's and is still trading at more than 100 times earnings, disclosed that it had agreed to settle charges to be brought by the S.E.C. But in an unusual announcement, it provided little elaboration of what the charges involved.
Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
 
Ameritech Bid Is Rejected
Regulators, as expected, rejected Ameritech's proposal to become the first Baby Bell to offer long-distance phone service, but they tried to spell out how those companies could qualify in the future. [D3.]
 
Watching the Market, Nervously
Many universities are growing increasingly dependent on endowments that involve stock -- no problem, perhaps, when the market is booming, but cause for concern when there are price gyrations. [B9.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1554 words

HEADLINE: Center of Local Power in Capital Resides With Assertive Economist

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Over lunch recently, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. got the word from the man who has essentially taken over his job, Andrew F. Brimmer, the chairman of the financial control board. Dr. Brimmer said he would gladly approve Mr. Barry's nominees to head the major city agencies, as long as the Mayor picked the right people.
"I said, 'Look, we'd like very much if you were to recommend these, then we'd vote to approve your recommendations,' " Dr. Brimmer said in an interview in his office. 
 As Dr. Brimmer told it, the Mayor, after being stripped by Congress of almost all but the power to annoy the chairman, waited for a day before faxing over his acquiescence to the list of names -- minutes before the control board meeting at which the appointments were to be announced.
"I was literally out the door and we still didn't have his list," Dr. Brimmer said. "My secretary called the Mayor's secretary and she said it was being typed. We got it five minutes before the meeting."
Ultimately, he said, the right names were on it, "so we could say 'upon the recommendation of the Mayor.' "
Mr. Barry declined through a spokeswoman to comment on a discussion that she said Dr. Brimmer had promised to keep private. But the spokeswoman said the list had come late because the Mayor had had trouble reaching two of the nominees on it.
Such are the games the players play in the nation's capital, where a buttoned-down Harvard-trained economist, the private but prideful Dr. Brimmer, has faced off with an elected leader, Mr. Barry, whose credentials come from the civil rights movement and whose street smarts got him re-elected even after a misdemeanor cocaine conviction.
Dr. Brimmer, a former member of the Federal Reserve Board, has emerged as the real power in this power-loving town. The budget bill signed by President Clinton earlier this month gave the down-at-the-heels District almost $1 billion over five years -- and transferred more authority from elected to appointed officials, at least temporarily, on a board that was created by Congress two years ago.
The legislation expanded Dr. Brimmer's already considerable power by giving the control board the authority to approve agency heads. As a result, Dr. Brimmer has come under extreme pressure from both ends of the political spectrum.
Some community advocates call him an aspiring dictator, eagerly overseeing what Mr. Barry ceaselessly refers to as "the rape of democracy." Some Congressional Republicans grouse that he has not moved quickly enough to neutralize a breathtakingly inefficient local government with a history of corruption.
Even Dr. Brimmer's supporters seem to take an extreme view, tagging him as the last hope for an unruly place where the timely distribution of parking tickets is widely regarded as the most reliable city service. There are those who see him as a little too regal -- running through the streets shouting 'L'etat, c'est moi!' -- and those who feel reassured that he seems willing to do whatever is necessary to make the schools safe and fill the potholes.
But there are few who feel they really know him; unlike the flamboyant titular head of local government, Dr. Brimmer is understated. And with a manner that is quite formal -- some would say forbidding in these come-as-you-are times -- not many ordinary people dare to approach him, he said.
"For someone to come up and speak to me takes an effort, and I know that," Dr. Brimmer said. "I am widely recognized, but no one just rushes up to me."
They do feel free to swamp his home answering machine with messages -- he is listed in the directory -- but he said he got most feedback secondhand, or from taxi drivers.
Several dozen protesters chanting "Free D.C." disrupted the recent control board meeting where Dr. Brimmer announced that he was in charge of most of the city government. Still, he said he believed his mail, which he said was mostly positive, and discounted the critics.
"While the decibels have been very strong, I've never thought it was widespread or deeply rooted," Dr. Brimmer said of the opposition to his expanded powers.
Mark Plotkin, a political analyst for WAMU, a local affiliate of National Public Radio, who originally supported Dr. Brimmer, said he was out of touch with public sentiment.
"He's gone power mad," Mr. Plotkin said. "He doesn't respect the democratic process, and he's totally removed from the citizenry. His personality is such a handicap. There's no human face to the control board. We're a sick patient and he has no bedside manner."
But Dr. Brimmer, 70, who describes himself as the head of a rescue operation and his city as "in crises, in numerous crises," is not much inclined to explain himself. And he presents himself as immune to criticism.
Asked how he responded to specific complaints, Dr. Brimmer said: "I don't. I don't engage in public debate. I don't need the drama. Why should I produce drama when I can produce action?"
He is not cocky for nothing: His story is downright inspirational. But he cannot seem to help digressing into little tutorials while giving a guided tour of his life. ("I was born two miles from the Mississippi River on Lake St. Joseph, one of the oxbow lakes. How did they become lakes -- long, crescent-shaped and narrow? Because of soft soil.")
He grew up in rural Louisiana, the son of a sharecropper, and as a boy picked cotton and was in charge of raising the family's pigs. He went to a segregated high school that gave blacks mainly vocational training, left home at 17 to join a sister in Washington state and was drafted into the Army five days before World War II ended in Europe. Later, he went back to school on the G.I. Bill. And he becomes unusually animated when he talks about the first days of his love affair with economic theory.
"When I went to college in 1947, virtually every economist you talked to was caught up in ways to avoid another Depression," he said.
Later, he went to India on a Fulbright scholarship and taught at Michigan State University, the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard University, where he received his Ph.D.
His research assistant at Michigan State, Bernard Anderson, now an Assistant Secretary of Labor, said Dr. Brimmer was the most exciting teacher he ever had, a brilliant man whose passion for economics was contagious. Mr. Anderson recalled a seminar taught by Milton Friedman and said Dr. Brimmer had interrupted the presentation to correct the equation he was working on.
"Friedman said, 'You're right,' " Mr. Anderson, recalled. "He challenged the guru of monetary theory! It was thrilling, and not just because we were the only two African-Americans in the room."
In 1966, Dr. Brimmer was the first black person appointed to the Federal Reserve Board, where he is still remembered by longtime aides as an exceptionally hard-working and prolific researcher.
Even in those days, he was a controversial figure among blacks. He once said black banks were "ornamental," rather than engines for economic development, and presented a rather dire economic assessment of crime among blacks.
"They didn't use the word 'traitor,' " Dr. Brimmer said, "but they said I had provided our enemies with ammunition."
And then, as now, he said those who doubted his loyalties should "be concerned about stopping the deterioration rather than stopping the messenger."
Asked why he had taken the unpaid position of board chairman, which routinely takes at least four days a week from the consulting business that made him a millionaire, he said: "Maybe it's conceit. But first of all, I've been flattered that several Presidents thought I had talent to put to public service."
He was a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce under President John F. Kennedy. Lyndon B. Johnson appointed Dr. Brimmer to the Federal Reserve Board. And he was named to lead the control board by President Clinton.
Dr. Brimmer insisted that life in the District was getting better and said a mandate to fill the potholes had recently been sent to the new head of the public works department.
"I said, 'This is a campaign and you are the general,' " he said.
He said no one should expect a flash of light and an overnight turnaround. He also acknowledged that he had been extremely frustrated by city officials who did not respond to the board's recommendations until they were forced to.
"At first we thought we'd make recommendations and the City Council and Mayor would accept them and follow through," he said. "But instead, we'd make recommendations and nothing would happen."
"We were ignored," he said, until Congress expanded the board's powers. Finally, last fall, the board pushed out the schools superintendent, turned the elected school board into an advisory body and installed a retired Army general to run the schools.
Although critics saw that act as undemocratic, Dr. Brimmer said he had no doubts about whether he had done the right thing.
"I don't have sleepless nights, I don't toss and turn and I don't dream about the control board," he added, laughing at some length at his own jocularity.
Does he never doubt himself?
"No, of course not," he said firmly. "I mean, I don't always say everything I say and do is right. But I've never thought of myself as muddle-headed and I see no reason to start."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andrew F. Brimmer sees himself as the head of a rescue effort and Washington as "in crises." (David Scull)
